texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken AB
texts.text: On Life & Investment Management, grew by 13% supported by a strong equity market and ended up at an  operating profit of SEK 3.6 billion with a return on equity of 27.8%. Assets under management came in at year- end at SEK 1,830 billion. That was an increase by SEK 81 billion from the previous year. And even though this is  in the right direction, we are not completely satisfied with that increase not at least looking at the very strong  financial market that helped us here. Also worth noting here is that the product that we've developed within the  investment area for social responsibility investing, green investing, have done very well and continue to see very  positive demand.

file: SEB.A - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 30January2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jan-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Torgeby
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken AB
texts.text: It's  a year ago, Q4 of 2017, we met and we talked about this emerging little sign that corporate growth might  come back. We had had two or three quarters with absolute no growth in year-on-year or quarter-over-quarter  terms, and we talked about the green shoot. And now we can conclude that this year those green shoots turned  into some type of flower, and that was the 14% growth we saw in corporate credit exposure increasing. This is  slightly different from lending as one should be point out because it's also of balance sheet or credit commitments  on those types of businesses.

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In business innovation, which is our third leg between – we have Communication, Imaging IT Solutions and  Business Innovation, our little green house of new products. We have seen education grow quite substantially.  That is our visualization table, that some of you might have seen, a special way of viewing three-dimensional  images of the human body. And it's become very popular with training medical doctors or students to become  medical doctors.

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Radiation dose monitoring, that's interesting, that's one you want to track down in community how much  radiation a person gets, because you could go to different places. It's been a case – a few cases in the United States,  where doctors were paid for how much they did, not how good results they got. That's changing. But, that actually  radiated people until they almost died. And in France, actually a few people did die because of radiation disease  because they did too much X-ray on them.

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Now, this has led authorities to enforce that we have to have keep track. And we have one of the largest installs in  all of the world and one of the first in [indiscernible] (32:52) Sweden, and this system is called DoseTrack and we  sell that to many places all over the world. And that is quite a lot of interest for radiation dose monitoring.

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Okay. A little about – that's my general presentation. A little about upcoming events forward. We will have a  Annual General Meeting, September 7 in Linköping. Those of you who are shareholders are most welcome to  come there. Then we'll have a Capital Market Day. We haven't had that in two years. The last time we had it, we  had to do it twice, because there was a snowstorm. [indiscernible] (42:15) And I see from smiles from some of you  that you were on that train. But this we'll put in September and the chance of a snowstorm in September we think  is quite okay. So September 15, we'll have the Capital Market Day. And then we'll bring all the business line  leaders and we'll tell you much more in depth what we're doing and show you products and that will be here in  Stockholm somewhere, not yet decided where.

file: SECT.B - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 30May2017 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sectra AB
texts.text: We have a large interest in that now. We are selling now currently in the Nordics. We are increasingly trying to get  the infrastructure from Netherlands, where we are already with our encryption devices. The first customers are  now fully operational. The growth strategy is to focus on the energy sector, not do anything in critical  infrastructure. There's water suppliers, et cetera. We get that as a collateral, but we do not aim for water supply.  And to expand into new geographic markets after a while we get good references in Scandinavia.

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sectra AB
texts.text: It's a very interesting market because in the European Union, there's a lot of collaboration and there's also  legislation coming in this area. The European Union is concerned about our sensitivity for attacks towards energy  sector all over. So, there will be increasing legislation and directives coming out of the EU and we intend to be  well positioned when that happens.

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sectra AB
texts.text: But then, we have chosen cyber security for critical infrastructure because that is a major problem that has to be  solved. There is only a matter of time before we get a ransomware attack in a power plant. Now, I will close – or I  will look at it. During heavy rain, all locks down in a big hydro dam with his phone. And then someone, a controller  comes up when they want to open the gates because it's flooding, it said pay 3,000 bit coins on this account or  you can't open the doors. That would be a very nervous situation for that dam controller because if it goes high  enough, the dam will collapse.

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sectra AB
texts.text: We have several customers now in Sweden. We do secure the assessment and also, we protect and detect  intrusions into the system. And we have found inside some power production facilities in Sweden. We have found  things we wouldn't believe. We have scared the hell out of the owners when we found it, and including ourselves.  There are bad stuff in this area, dormant stuff, but it's ready to be activated by someone somewhere. And we  have taken them out where we have found them.

file: SECT.B - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 29May2018 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sectra AB
texts.text: Critical infrastructure, our new little business, is not big enough to really influence the concern yet, not even  Communications, but it's growing very healthily. We also got – we started doing that business for electrical power  distribution and production. That is the part of society you do not want someone to hack into and shut down in  February in a Western society. It would be very cold and a very bad situation. We protect the IT infrastructure of  those places. [indiscernible] (06:05) much more difficult to hack into them.

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sectra AB
texts.text: Now, we also got an order from the energy sector, it's a sector outside of electrical, and that was a private  enterprise which is very promising because that was the first one outside of electricity. And that agreement is for  five years and is several sites in Sweden.

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sectra AB
texts.text: Growth strategy is focused on the energy sector. We do not want to be [ph] dealing with (07:03) IT security for  everyone and everybody. We are focusing on energy because these people know each other and we have large  benefits from our brand in security because if a power company wants to secure things, they go to the National  Security Authority of the country, and they know us in Europe because they're already our customers.

texts.speaker: Clas Harald Torbjörn Kronander
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Sectra AB
texts.text: And that is – actually, we got the order for a proof-of-concept to see that the system actually works in their  environment, as promised. If that works, the intent is to have a contract for the entire state. Now, the proof-of- concept is still not delivered. So, we don't know if that's going to happen now or not.

texts.speaker: Alf Göransson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Securitas AB
texts.text: France, again, negative and a bit concerned about France. The environment is kind of pessimistic about the future  in many places. There are cutbacks in many parts of the industry and there are reasons to be concerned about the  top line in France. Actually, we have now another major contract, which represents another negative growth or  impact on the top line of 1% to 2% that we are losing in October to the French Railways, which is a major contract.  It has a negative margin. So it's not, from that perspective, a major issue, but on the top line, it will have an impact  – an increase, so to say, the loss on top line in – going forward.  But on the bottom line, it's the contrary. In France, it's one of the main contributors together with Germany and  Belgium and UK to the good development of the margins in Europe which are now gradually picking up. And even  we have lost in the top line in France, 6% year-to-date on the top line, we have improved our result by over 20%.  So, that is impressive under the circumstances in France.

file: SECU.B - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 7November2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Alf Göransson
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Securitas AB
texts.text: So, looking forward, I mean, we are not – the macroeconomic climate is tough; it's not done. And we are usually  about a year late to the macroeconomic recov ery. There are some fragile signs of recovery, but doubtful from  place-to-place, from country-to-country. But no matter what, I don't think we're going to get much of a help, from  a top line point of view, in the near future. So improving results comes fro m our strategy of increasing the share of  technology and security solutions, which, for sure, drives our margin; and that should continue to improve our  margins going forward.

texts.speaker: Jens Breu
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SFS Group AG
texts.text: Key messages division Automotive, driven by stable innovation trends. The division continued to significantly  outgrow the industry by ramping up new and innovative customer projects. Stable trends like the electrification of  cars continue to create innovation and growth opportunities for SFS. The time-consuming pass-through of  increased raw material costs despite intensive effort could be completed. The impact of U.S. import tariffs will be  passed along the supply chain in the same manner this time expected without major delay. Projects to expand the  global manufacturing footprint are nearing completion and will sharpen the competitive edge of the division  further.

texts.speaker: Rolf Frei
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SFS Group AG
texts.text: The segment Engineered Components increased its stake from 55% to 76% which reflects the dynamic and  innovation going on especially in Automotive and then Electronics. On the other hand, Fastening Systems is left  with the share of 12% only compared to 27% last year. This indicates that the substantial CapEx for the transition  projects are done, and to a great deal, over. The high level of CapEx in Engineered Components will continue  during the second half year. We expect for the year as a whole and for the SFS Group to equal above 8.5% of net  sales.

file: SFSN - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 10March2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Rolf Frei
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SFS Group AG
texts.text: Good morning also from my side. Jens has given you just the first glance at the key takeaways, and now, let's  have a deeper look into the financials and discuss together the development of important KPIs. This is the sales  bridge with the variances from 2015 to 2016. The green bars represent the growth areas. Certainly to be  remarked is the growth in the core business with CHF 79 million or 5.9% year-on-year. The non-core business of  division Electronics, also known as titanium inserts, is shown separately with the red bar. It accounts for a sales  reduction of CHF 53 million. This business is now down at $21 million and the maturity of it will probably run out  this year.

texts.speaker: Rolf Frei
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SFS Group AG
texts.text: The high capacity utilization led to some bottlenecks, especially in the heat treatment department. To overcome  these capacity shortages and also to support further growth, the capital expenditure is expected to increase again  towards 6% to 7% in this year, 2017. The development of net working capital, both as a percentage of net sales  and days outstanding, is rather stable with 31% and 114 days, respectively. There's really nothing else to report  on the net working capital.

file: SFSN - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 9March2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jens Breu
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SFS Group AG
texts.text: The key messages of the Division Automotive underline the electrification of cars as a confirmed growth driver.  High growth momentum has been achieved and sustained, thanks to the ramp-up of new projects. Vehicle  electrification and autonomous driving initiatives strongly support innovation activities and the corresponding  growth. Significant project wins in the reporting year are therefore expected to fuel future growth and will require  additional and substantial CapEx in the coming year. This bodes for already existing products as well as new  projects for next-generation products. For 2018, we clearly expect the positive development to continue.

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And I'm particularly pleased with our margin performance, maintaining margin in a difficult climate – a difficult  environment is actually a good performance and one that illustrates the continued discipline we have about cost  control inside the company.  So I would like now to turn over to Paul, who's going to cover more on the numbers.

texts.speaker: Stephen Kelly
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So just to give you a few elements; we highlighted some of the strength in the management team, focused a lot on  customers, so I've instigated things like code red, where if there is a customer fire burning anywhere in the world  we jump on it, [ph] a la our rainy day (31:44) model and put it out. But then we build what the lessons are into the  process around customer experience. So we are very lucky to have 3000 people in customer services.

file: SGEL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 5May2016 345 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Stephen Kelly
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: When we spoke last December to announce our full-year FY 2015 results, which was the first public milestone, we  were able to demonstrate the first steps in our journey. At that point, we delivered the fastest rate of organic  growth for eight years and shared some green shoots of progress against our transformation strategy.

texts.speaker: DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: A year ago when I took over as CEO, I said to you that Sage was a strong business with solid foundations, and I  can confirm that view today. But given a more normal economic climate, I'm now more convinced that we should  be able to achieve higher organic growth than we have historically achieved. Today, I intend to show you some of  the progress we've made and some of the change that is already underway towards that goal.

texts.speaker: Darren Fisher
texts.profession: Director of Finance, The Sage Group Plc
texts.text: Growth in the wider African market is becoming increasingly important. Revenue grew 20% and now represents  13% of South Africa's revenue. Sage ERP X3 is doing very well in this market. Australia grew by 1%, reflecting a  weak macroenvironment hitting software revenue. We were pleased, however, with renewals with the existing  customer base.

texts.speaker: Stephen Kelly
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: FY 2016 is a pivotal year for us. But we build in and have built an experienced team and have a balanced and  sequenced approach to ensure our success. We're building momentum and starting to see the first green shoots of  progress. I'll come back to talk to these after Steve. We're very reassured by the resilient business model that we  have in place, and we mean to continue to deliver financially as we transform.

texts.speaker: Stephen Kelly
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So, in summary, we're certainly pleased with the fastest rate of organic growth for the last eight years, and we are  pleased that we've exceeded the financial targets set three years ago. We started the transformation outlined at  CMD in June 2015, and can certainly see now, today, green shoots of progress, as we've shared with you.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Good afternoon and welcome to this Investor Day. I hope those who have been able to join us this morning in La  DuPont have enjoyed their visit. First of all, I'd like to say that we have not chosen the date of this meeting  according to the French Presidential Elections, but obviously, following the results, I'm more optimistic on France  than I watched some months ago. I expect a recovery of our first market to gather momentum and the program of  our new president on energy renovation is promising. Although, as always, we will need to know more about the  details of its implementation.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Concerning the third axis, management priorities, we have pushed further our cost saving programs. I think we  can say we have become a CSR reference. We have delivered attractive returns for shareholders, and we have  maintained a solid financial structure. But more globally than just the targets of 2013, when I look backward at the  last few years, I think we have achieved a lot on a number of fronts. I will select six topics.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Tom Kinisky has replaced John Crowe as Head of our U.S. Operation at the beginning of this year. Before that,  he was in-charge of our very successful plastic business and I will say over the years, he has worked in most of  our HPM activities.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: At the other extreme, on the left of the slide, we can talk about the evolution of the automotive industry. Comfort  requirements become more and more important for end users; vibration control, noise reduction. Durability are  becoming critical to the OEMs even for the very small parts. This is where we can add value, for example, to our  performance plastic bearings, parts in door assembly or seats, and there are many of them in each car.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: If I take acoustical solution, the example in the middle, the products will be sold more and more with a specific  service to help, to design the best combination to reduce noise in a given environment. Those trend we see them  everywhere at work. And it makes us very confident that our uniqueness will be a true positive differentiation  factor in the future.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: To take a few more specific examples, in the marine industry, we sell many products, insulation, glass, or even a  lot of plumbing and heating through our distribution network. We have decided several years ago to coordinate  our efforts toward this market, and to put in common the strengths and knowledge of all our businesses, on the  innovative material side, on the construction product side, and on the distribution side.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So, last but not the least of the topics where we have transformed the group over the last three years is our  corporate social responsibility activities in all their dimensions. These achievements have been recently  recognized through our inclusion for the first time into the Dow Jones Sustainability Index in 2016. And at the  same time, we enter immediately at the first track in Europe, and the second one in the world in our sector.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: In the field of governance, we strive to achieve the highest standards. Our board has reviewed and improved  practices consistently in line with best practices. We have now a board committee reviewing our CSR policies.  This year, the board has appointed a lead independent director, Jean-Dominique Senard, the CEO of Michelin,  who will start his office from this general shareholders' meeting next month.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: From an environmental standpoint, Saint-Gobain is committed to reduce the impact and we have taken strong  commitments to that effect whether it concerns CO2 emissions, water consumption or waste, as you see in this  chart. We are following methodically our action plans with strict measurements in all our facilities. These actions  are all the more important as Saint-Gobain is an important actor in the fight against climate change.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Our products and solutions are key to the reduction of the emissions of CO2 in buildings, which is the biggest  sector in terms of global emissions. We have calculated with independent international consultants that although  we are a significant emitter, our solutions, when installed, have a very positive effect. In fact, during their lifetime,  they allowed to avoid 90 times the emissions that have been necessary for their production.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Many of you know my personal commitment in that field because of personal convictions, but also because it is a  big opportunity for Saint-Gobain. In terms, the group should be leading the way towards a de-carbonized world.  The only tool going forward will be, in my view, a price of carbon. And in weighting political decisions, we have  decided to setup an internal price of carbon within the group to step up the mobilization of our businesses and to  encourage disruptive innovation.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: In a nutshell in Saint-Gobain, CSR is not just a set of practices to comply with international standard, it is an  integral part of our strategy. So, this is, with all the aspect, where I think that we can see that Saint-Gobain has  been transformed over the last three years. And now, I will let Guillaume answer the question about the  macroeconomic environment.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: In automotive, for example, the need for more comfort is creating opportunities for, for example, our coated  glasses or for our performance plastic parts, Pierre-André was talking about that. The progression of electric  vehicles is creating in general more constraints, for example, weight constraints and therefore more opportunities  for all of our businesses. In the aeronautic sector, same holds true, for example the CO2 constraints on a smaller,  but still quite important scale, in-flight Wi-Fi development, for example, is generating additional business in our  high-performance materials sector. And finally, in the healthcare industry, the move towards disposable tailor- made, high-tech systems is clear good news both for the patients first of all, but also for our high-performance  plastics business. But Tom will elaborate a little bit more about that right after my presentation.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So, benefiting from markets tailwind is clearly a positive for the company but long term what you are probably also  interested in as investors is whether we can go faster than the wind. And this is going to be the topic of the next  few presentations and I will now hand over to Tom Kinisky who will start to address this important question. Thank  you.

texts.speaker: Thomas G. Kinisky
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, General Delegate for North America, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Whether you're talking about autonomous cars, aging population, the need for healthcare, air transport growth, all  of these are having an impact across all of our businesses and sectors, but the real question isn't the underlying  market trends. It's actually how can we find and identify those trends that are – those markets or submarkets  inside of these trends that are growing faster.

texts.speaker: Thomas G. Kinisky
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, General Delegate for North America, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: On a personal level, I think we all want in our homes a positive outcome for our families, whether that's to reduce  the noise of the neighbors next door, whether that's to improve the air quality inside of our home, maybe by  lowering the VOCs, and we actually have products that can do that today. We have noise blocking gypsum board  for example to keep the noise out from the neighbors. We have gypsum board that absorbs VOCs to make a  better air and quality environment for our family. So those are our offerings today.

texts.speaker: Thomas G. Kinisky
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, General Delegate for North America, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: And I have another direct example, 18 months ago we moved the North American headquarters into a new – well  it's not a new facility, it was a 20-year-old building, but newly renovated. And what we did as we did that was we  put the building science behind the building. So it's got our materials in it, but it also has dynamic – it has sensors  and dynamic controls in which we are controlling the acoustics, the light, the ventilation system, the temperature,  we have electrochromic SageGlass for example in the building and it's all controlled sensor – where we are  actually now measuring the outcomes of the people inside of our building as well as their well being.

texts.speaker: Thomas G. Kinisky
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, General Delegate for North America, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: To give you one specific, we have a customer service center in the building. So 18 months ago, we moved in, and  of course we are controlling through sensors all of their environment and what we discovered after 18 months is  that the productive in that call center has gone up 180% and it stayed there now over six months to sustainable.  And it's all because we're impacting the well-being of the employees' environment. As a result of that, it's having a  positive outcome. That same group of building, scientists we're using them to design the next generation building  of the future and we have building scientists not just in North America, but across the entire world working on this  question of correlating comfort well-being with building science.

texts.speaker: Thomas G. Kinisky
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, General Delegate for North America, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: We want to have an impact on this. Guillaume mentioned, for example of that there is a potential labor shortage in  the U.S. and many of the mature countries. If we can impact productivity, we can also help to relieve that issue.  Here are three examples of how we're doing that. Pierre-André touched on this already with prefab. But if you look  at just bathrooms. If you take the bathroom module and make it an industrial environment, we've reduced the cost  by 50% and changed completely the amount of onsite work labor required, reducing it by 99%.

texts.speaker: Thomas G. Kinisky
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, General Delegate for North America, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The same thing is true with lightweight materials. If they're easier to handle on the job site, we can make people  more productive. If we can change the curing time and the drying time significantly and these are examples with  our mortar products, we can dramatically change again the amount of labor time on the site.

texts.speaker: Thomas G. Kinisky
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, General Delegate for North America, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: And the last one, and this is a kind of interface between new technology that's happening in building, modeling,  information systems as well as what we can do in advance, because we're getting sp precise, we can bring precut  materials on to a job site. They fit immediately, you're not cutting on the job site, and you're not generating waste  on the job site. And these are just three examples of many of other solutions that we're offering today.

texts.speaker: Thomas G. Kinisky
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, General Delegate for North America, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: On the far right, and this was already mentioned by Guillaume, but I'll elaborate on it. In the case of  biopharmaceutical manufacturing, the advent of personalized medicine, what's happening now is the  pharmaceutical companies which used to manufacture in large stainless steel reactors are now doing things in  small scale for personalized [ph] and (46:33) disposable plastics, which are impacting our plastics business. And  these are just a couple of examples that we have across our business.

texts.speaker: Thomas G. Kinisky
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, General Delegate for North America, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So I want to conclude by saying that this combination of what we're trying to do in terms of science, high efficiency  manufacturing and service is all supported by what we're doing with open innovation inside of these industrial as  well as construction markets.

texts.speaker: Thomas G. Kinisky
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, General Delegate for North America, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: In the case of high performance materials, two thirds of what we manufacture there either customized products or  co-developed products and we're inviting our customers, we're inviting our suppliers, we're inviting other partners,  universities into our innovation across the entire group around the world. One example of that is fablabs. These  are small labs that have been set up in a variety of our plants across the plastics business in which we have our  employees collaborating with outsiders to create innovation.

texts.speaker: Benoît Bazin
texts.profession: Senior Vice President & President-Construction Products Sector, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Second priority for growth, innovation. Our product innovation is closely connected to the markets. If I take the  example of insulation, we start from the customer needs, the market needs and we have developed over the  years, the multi material offer, fire resistance with stone wool, thermal and acoustic performance with glass wool,  wood fibers, for the ecological customers who prefer wood, PIR with the Celotex acquisition from a few years ago  for thin and high thermal performance and also traded goods and accessories again to make the products easier  and faster to install.

texts.speaker: Benoît Bazin
texts.profession: Senior Vice President & President-Construction Products Sector, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: But innovation is also in services, like in the pipe business, where we have developed sensors for either leakage  or corrosion detection or in mortars where we have trucks to deliver on multi-storied job sites.

texts.speaker: Benoît Bazin
texts.profession: Senior Vice President & President-Construction Products Sector, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Some of you have seen [indiscernible] (53:06) this morning our new friendly glass wool. I hope you had the  opportunity to touch it which triggered a very positive customer reaction. We have seen also Habito. Habito is a  revolutionary plasterboard with high fixing capability, high durability and also high acoustic performance. A very  great solution for better and stronger wool for both the residential and the commercial markets.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Let me give you a few examples. The surface treatment of my cell phone has been made with zirconia beads and  probably your cell phone has been made with zirconia beads of Saint-Gobain. If you have an accident tomorrow,  probably we will be able to give you and to provide you all the needed product for the repair of your car body,  refinishing and after that for protection of your car. Last time you took a taxi or you took your car, it's highly likely  that it was equipped with our bearings providing noise reduction and friction reduction and giving you intimately a  better comfort.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Let me give you few promising examples. So first example, coated veil is a product that we developed in co- development with Gypsum Activity. This is coated veil that is protecting the plasterboard from humidity and from  UV during the construction. Second example, an example more between new products and new market, we  developed a refractory product lines which is called wool for installation furnaces with recycled material, not only  we manage to find a solution with recycling of waste of our customers, which is a problem for our customers, but  we also got a cheap source of raw material to enter with a competitive product on this market.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Third example, more new markets entering in the new market segment, sandwich radomes. A radome is a  weatherproof dome that is protecting the weather antenna. It's a growing market. We developed an innovative  technology panels incorporating 3G fibers between the two, in and outer, surfaces avoiding the delimination  issues that is encountered by our competitor's position. On top of that, it facilitates the assembly and the  maintenance of the system.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: And fourth, application an example, ceramic filters. We developed a ceramic filter in co-development with our  customers to address the growing market of the water and beverage filtration, but also water treatment and the  pollution. So the second lever is to focus on development of new application end markets.

texts.speaker: Patrick Dupin
texts.profession: Senior Vice-President in charge of the Flat Glass Activity, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: I would like to focus on five axes to show you how we can outperform our markets. First is innovation in the  material, the glass material itself. The second is to focus of offer onto high-performance glazing for building in  which we can combine the different capabilities that we have. I could mention, for instance, the combination  between comfort and thermal efficiency or the integrations of blinds into IGU for hospital for cleanliness services.

texts.speaker: Patrick Dupin
texts.profession: Senior Vice-President in charge of the Flat Glass Activity, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The third element is the excellence in developing system for the automotive segments. Integrating high-level  technical customer requests. I can use the example of the heated windshield for commercial aircraft cockpits or  the lamination of sensor or the integrations of antenna of invisible camera on the sidelights or backlights. The  fourth axis is the execution in emerging countries, where in most of the case, we have leadership position. Finally,  the integration of the sustainability problematic from the conceptions of the lifecycle management to the process  or efficiency – energetic and efficiency. So let's elaborate on these five levers for growth.

texts.speaker: Patrick Dupin
texts.profession: Senior Vice-President in charge of the Flat Glass Activity, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: We do not only develop product. We also spend one-third of our R&D efforts to process improvements like, for  instance, cost management or focus on energy, reduction on energy or CO2 or improvement of the capability or  tolerances of our products. And finally, in terms of excellence of operational excellence, the float business and the  Sekurit business are really [indiscernible] (01:18:30) our industry in the rollout of Industry 4.0 digital processes.

texts.speaker: Patrick Dupin
texts.profession: Senior Vice-President in charge of the Flat Glass Activity, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So, I'd like to give you two example, one is the SageGlass product, which is the activation of electrochromic  technology for glass that can tint on demand. The second recent innovations that is under way is the joint  ventures that we have set up with the American glass manufacturer Corning in order to be able to produce extra  glazing windshield for electrical vehicles.

texts.speaker: Patrick Dupin
texts.profession: Senior Vice-President in charge of the Flat Glass Activity, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The second example is something quite new. We have developed very high-sized coated glass panels. Those are  18-meter glass panel with extreme glass neutrality, very, very clear, for very iconic projects that you can  sometimes recognize. This is a new facility that we have set up in Germany and we are just starting in [ph] here  (01:20:23) as well. We will export all over the world this kind of a very specific, specific product.

texts.speaker: Patrick Dupin
texts.profession: Senior Vice-President in charge of the Flat Glass Activity, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The second example is the smart windshield. This is a [ph] visionary (01:21:35) front glass that integrates on  enabled new features for the new generation of cars like electrical vehicles, like for autonomous driving or  infotainment. Here, we are in discussion with several players of the market in order to bring those techno  solutions like OLEDs, or LED, or sensors, or HUD-compatible windshields that we really integrate in the  windshields. So, as we can see here, it really goes beyond the pure material. Let's have an illustration with the  following video.

texts.speaker: Patrick Dupin
texts.profession: Senior Vice-President in charge of the Flat Glass Activity, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: What do we offer here? Here we offer reflective glass, which is [ph] Lorenzo of (01:26:07) coated glass for  residential. We processed facades and now we do it out of India, very complex facades. We offer advanced  coatings for the different solar control applications from India, from Korea, from Mexico. We provide as well  through digital channels a series of service and adjacent product like foams, sealant, spacers and different  accessories. So most of those markets are fast growing and in most of them, we are as a number one or number  two position. Our next target is now to go to Africa after what we have done recently in the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Patrick Dupin
texts.profession: Senior Vice-President in charge of the Flat Glass Activity, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Finally, I would like to elaborate a little bit on the fifth lever, which is the sustainability. I have a strong belief that  sustainability is not only an economical calculation for the customer but this is more and more a customer request  and experience where environment and well-being are really the two key motivations for them. And at Saint- Gobain, we want to have our technology and our product range saving the planet. So as we mention often, as an  example, double glazing units that we produce and that emit CO2, this CO2 is offset within three months after the  installation of this double glazing.

texts.speaker: Patrick Dupin
texts.profession: Senior Vice-President in charge of the Flat Glass Activity, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: But still, we continue permanently to reduce our footprint with very clear plans, with very clear technological and  operational roadmaps and we really – you can believe me that this objective of CO2 emissions, our reduction of  emission in our plant really matters for our customers. So as you can see here on the example, our very thin glass  like you can see here is saving, is providing for electrical vehicles, savings of rate of 30%, which as well saved  energy. And this segment of the electrical cars is going to grow, is predicted to grow 40% in average in the future  for the next decade, so it's really material [indiscernible] (01:28:20) right segment.

texts.speaker: Patrick Dupin
texts.profession: Senior Vice-President in charge of the Flat Glass Activity, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The other example is the electrochromic glass, we spoke about, SageGlass systems. Here as well we can reduce  emission and energy by 20%, but also it brings a tremendous feelings of comfort of well-being, so we really  combine the quantity and the quality and the comfort. Here as well, let's have a look of what SageGlass is made  of...

texts.speaker: Patrick Dupin
texts.profession: Senior Vice-President in charge of the Flat Glass Activity, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: As a conclusion, I'm really convinced that we have the right approach, the right organization, but also the right  team to amplify the market growth through focus on innovation, through business approach in building and in the  mobility segment, increasing our position in emerging country, where we have really a very robust position and  sustainability-enhancing solutions.

texts.speaker: Fabrice Didier
texts.profession: Vice President-Marketing, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: KANDU, for example, proposes noise reduction solution to restaurant owners based on data analysis and  measured by a simple smartphone. PAM with a start-up Echologics offers and sells leak detection and  maintenance services for the drinking water network to municipalities or to the contractors. And Kåre will develop  Homly You, maybe our most emblematic project.

texts.speaker: Fabrice Didier
texts.profession: Vice President-Marketing, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: You may have seen in the press our future headquarters that will be built only in 2019. It's a virtual picture you  have seen. The tool that has been used by Valode et Pistre, the architect, to choose type of glass they wanted.  And it is all over the world used by our sales team in glass to suggest to our partners how their future buildings  will look like.

texts.speaker: Kåre Ivar Olsen Malo
texts.profession: Senior Vice President-Building Distribution Sector, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Prefab solution, which was rightly mentioned early today, will be a part of our buildings for the future. It's also  increasing significantly and both from the industry side, but also we, in distribution, we'll play a significant role  within this area.

texts.speaker: Kåre Ivar Olsen Malo
texts.profession: Senior Vice President-Building Distribution Sector, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Communication costs have also dropped dramatically and a good quality Wi-Fi today on the plant has the power  of close to 1 giga per second.

texts.speaker: Kåre Ivar Olsen Malo
texts.profession: Senior Vice President-Building Distribution Sector, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So I will now show you a few examples of how these technologies work in Saint-Gobain. We here see on an  automotive glass production line that the extension of the number of sensors and the integration of the machines  can better control the process, reduce [indiscernible] (02:00:58) and decrease reject and material cost. The  overall equipment efficiency of the line can improve 2% to 5%.

texts.speaker: Kåre Ivar Olsen Malo
texts.profession: Senior Vice President-Building Distribution Sector, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The automated guided vehicles, also called AGV, are getting a new life. They do not depend on fixed pass on the  floor like tramways in the old days. They are now more like autonomous cars with beacon radar vision system,  which allow very good self positioning. These vehicles adopt to changing environment in order to take over the  bulk of transport in some of the warehouse. So productivity jump associated is over 50%. The cobots that we  have described earlier can handle complex tasks, relieves the operator from physical load and have very friendly  interface, easy to program.

texts.speaker: Kåre Ivar Olsen Malo
texts.profession: Senior Vice President-Building Distribution Sector, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Without even waiting for the end of the current saving plan, we have decided to launch a new one which would be  longer by one year and where the saving target is increased from €267 million per year to €300 million per year.  This is an important change compared to the recent evolution in which the yearly saving figure was decreasing  with time. But this is a commitment and we are comfortable given the number of opportunities that we see  opening, thanks to new manufacturing technologies. Thank you very much.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: [ph] Secondly, part (02:07:42) of this is that we are able to pass through raw materials and energy cost in our  prices. We have a good track records of doing this, but it is every year a renewed challenge. And the third  assumption is that the mix of businesses on our products is relatively constant. So, this is only – is it only the  theory or can we hope to turn it into reality.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So, usually the next question we get in road shows is about the potential normative margins in our businesses.  On the next three slides, we'll try to answer this question with ranges knowing that we don't give specific time  frames. But this is a good indication of what we think we can achieve in what we should call a normal environment  knowing that we would qualify the last few years as probably unfavorable and 2016 and 2017 as recovery.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Restructuring costs have gone down and, as volumes recover, they should stand the tight control. Asbestos has  been stable in the recent years. Ideally, I would like to be able to tell you today that we are going to trend soon  downwards, but it's still too early to make such a statement.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The tax rate is also in line which is [ph] little (02:13:37) talked about despite its important impact on the cash flow  generation. It has also gone down steadily from 34% to 27% in 2016. This is due to the overall environment  obviously, which is more favorable as well as through our optimization efforts. And if the announcements that we  see in some countries and in particular in the U.S. in terms of political changes are aligned with what has been  announced, it would be good news for our ability to maintain and maybe improve this good track record.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: I would like to illustrate maybe, first, all the engineering work, which is behind this structural reduction of CapEx  needs by taking two examples of things which are totally comparable because we are talking the same object on  the same side each time.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: On the left side, this is an example of what we were able to do on maintenance CapEx, which remains a  significant part of our envelope, with the successful rebuild of the same insulation furnace. And you can see that  we reduced by more than 50% the costs per output.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: To illustrates this strategy, I will use the example of our Performance Plastic business within HPM. Starting with a  very good tubing product in our historical portfolio, which is used in many different industries, requiring high purity  and resistance characteristic, we have found application in the medical sector where there is a growing trend for  single-use disposable systems. You've seen the [ph] video (02:25:17) in the last presentation. Progressively and  through six acquisition until now, we have built a very nice business with very quick value creation.

file: SGO - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 30July2010 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: In Europe, we’ve had betterment in the industrial output situation and in construction, it’s quite  contrasted. You may remember in the first half of the year, we still had the impact of the winter  because it was a very, very harsh winter, but since then we’ve had a rather gradual recovery in the  U.K., in Scandinavian countries, in Germany, in Poland. And in these – in the first three countries,  the figures are really moving upwards and all the lights are green.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: And as you know, we also have our input costs such as exchange rates, the prices of energy and  other raw materials. The prices are very volatile. So the general context is a lot more favorable than  in the first half of 2009, but it’s still very patchy.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: We’ve also seized opportunities in the other main line that I indicated in February, energy efficiency  and solar power. We’ve acquired a very small company in France that makes photovoltaic tiles.  And we’ve also acquired a majority interest in the leader in Japan which, of course, it’s a small  market, given the size of the country, and it’s certainly going to develop very quickly, given that  standards are evolving.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: And we’ve also announced the building of the – after the success of the first pilot plant, we’re  building the second Avancis plant in Germany. Let me remind you that, that makes thin-film PV  modules.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: Now we’ve also acquired a very small company for technical solutions, which is called New York  Wire. It’s an American activity but we are transferring that in terms of production to Mexico. We  have also carried out acquisitions in our priority fields, solar, power, energy efficiency and emerging  countries. You heard about that from Pierre-André. Insulation in Japan with MAG, PV tiles with  Solarwood and small acquisitions in abrasives in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: Building Distribution, minus 4.1%. Now this is – was also, of course, impacted by weather  conditions in the first quarter of the year where we were minus – at minus 8.1%. That means that  for over the second quarter of the year, we’ve practically been able to stabilize this, minus 0.1%.  And construction, of course, is continuing because we have minus 0.1%, because we’ve had a  slight downturn in our activities in Europe and the price effect is slightly positive.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: Now for Exterior Solutions, we’ve had an increase of – in organic terms of plus 3.4%. And the first  quarter, you may remember, was badly hit by weather conditions and we have been able to catch  that up through exports and especially in our – with our figures in China.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: In other countries, we are continuing to focus our investments in emerging countries. And so  emerging countries plus solar and energy efficiency, it represents about 58% of the group’s  investments. Thus, EBITDA minus CapEx is greatly positive and in strong growth in all areas,  particularly in Asia and emerging countries, we have tripled the EBITDA minus CapEx.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: So in terms of the economic climate, of course it will be strongly contrasted but there will be  continuous improvement, notably ongoing vigorous growth in Asia and Latin America. There are no  signs of an economic slowdown in those areas. Growth in China will remain strong, slightly less  than in H1, but in other countries there will be stronger growth in H2. Thus, very strong growth in  Asia and Latin America in H2.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: The operating income will fully benefit from the cost-reduction programs launched in 2010, and  these programs have been initiated. So 200 million, over the year, most of it will take place in H2.  Conversely, due to the increase in raw material costs, there will be a stronger impact in H2 than in  H1. So large percentage of the €200 million will only be felt in the second half rather than in the first  half.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: Thanks to this financial strength, we will be able to be slightly more active in the area of  investments, and that is why there will be a higher level of investments in H2 than in H1. In fact, we  have returned to our acquisition strategy and this effort will be intensified in the second half  compared to the first half, notably in emerging countries and in the solar area and in energy  efficiency. Of course, we will continue with ongoing – our research and development efforts.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. Laurent Guillot and I will be presenting the Results for the First Half
texts.text: So of course, a few words about the group’s strategic positioning, and it’s one of our  characteristics. This is going to give us growth drivers in both emerging and mature markets. And  this is due to the solar business, energy efficiency business, and so they’re going to be important  growth levers in matured countries and, as I mentioned, in emerging countries as well.

file: SGO - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 29July2011 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now in this context, the main points that concern Saint-Gobain's results are very good organically, up 6.7% over  the first half after a first quarter which we told you was rather extraordinary because of a very mild weather in  Europe whereas the weather had in 2010 – during the same period in 2010 had been not fair at all.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now for distribution prices that went 2% over the first quarter have gone up to 3% over the second quarter,  because – and this is important, because most of our raw material prices, of course, are in our industrial activity  and so we had to pass across the 3% hike in raw materials to offset the price in raw materials and energy.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: As Pierre-André told you we have started capital expenditure again and as you can see it's up 48% since between  H1 2010 and H1 this year. You remember, of course, that we have a seasonal variation between the first half and  second half of every year, but we haven't had a sharp upturn in our first half of this year, a little over €200 million,  actually €209 million. And the breakdown is about €100 million, which increases our CapEx in Asia and in  emerging countries at about €60 million, that's 30%. That is devoted to energy efficiency and to solar power. If  you add up the two that is about 80% of the increase in our CapEx, which is actually has – actually increased our  production capacity in emerging countries and is based on energy efficiency and solar power, which is what we  had announced last year.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Construction products 4.9%, with 3.7% for – over the second quarter. So, that was good. Building distribution up  by 7.3% throughout the first half of the year, 4.5% over the second quarter, which means it has continued to  improve, because the first quarter was, of course, suffered from the consequences of the weather conditions over  the first quarter. Then Verallia plus 4.2% of growth throughout the half, that was 2.2% over the first – the second  quarter, sorry.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now a little more detail, Flat Glass plus 8.2% of growth and this was also pulled up, continued to be pulled up by  emerging countries, but also by building in Europe. Over the second quarter in Europe, the figure was up 8%,  because of energy efficiency and value-added product, such as triple glazing and the penetration of triple glazing  in Germany, last year the figure was 25% and this year the figure is 33%. So, there has been a significant impact in  the product – in the sales of value-added products here in this particular business sector. And in the second  quarter, we did have a slight shrinkage of this activity.  Now prices continued to improve in Flat Glass, because over the local quarter, we are up by 4% and we will have  another increase in the month of September. High-performance Materials, as you can see, the sales figures would  seem stable compared to last year in absolute terms, you must not forget that we did sell-off Advanced Ceramics at  the end of 2010. So, in terms of organic growth plus 9.3% over the first half of this year. Strong growth also in  plastics which is linked more to industrial consumption.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now, if we look at EBITDA and CapEx, you can see once again it was at €615 million last year, €842 million this  year and investments have more than doubled in this particular business activity, and have gone up to €323  million with a lot of investments that we have made in the Float line in India and in Brazil as well and investments  in high value-added products for example in coating – coated glass in Europe and solar power as well.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now, building – construction products, sorry, you can see that is 4.9% up over the whole half of year. And this has  been pulled up by emerging countries but also through energy efficiency solutions in Europe. And overall we've  had an increase of 6.4% in Western Europe.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The prices in these activities have also increased especially for Interior Solutions plus 3% over the second half –  second quarter sorry. And this was necessary to cover the rise in costs of raw materials and energy and for  insulating materials such as foam and for certain products there.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now plus 4.1% in the – over the half year for exterior solutions with mortar doing well and in activities for exterior  solutions in the United States because of weather that has pushed up our activity. On the other hand, we have had  a negative impact for pipes as I told you earlier especially in Europe but also for exports to the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: In terms of profitability, you can see compared to last year for Interior Solutions we have once again, increased  our profitability plus 1.1%, it's gone from 6.8% to 7.9%. Thanks to the improvement in our prices, which offsets the  cost of raw materials and energy and here we have the impact of the leverage effect that we can have on our  Exterior Solutions – Interior Solutions, sorry, mostly in Europe.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: As for building distribution, you can see there is a growth of 8% this center in H1. As I said, 4.5% in Q1, principally  driven by the sustained growth which we've had in France up 6%, Scandinavia as well 6% growth and Germany  over 8% growth, all this in Q2. So, Q2 without taking into account the weather problems now, growth has been  sustained.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: There you've got the performance of innovative materials, industrial materials, which are improving. However the  basis for comparison is becoming more difficult. And then construction materials are more or less flat, excluding  exterior solutions, which has – which had profited from the bad weather which the United States suffered at the  beginning of the year.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: And just to finish, EBITDA and CapEx by geographic area. There once again you can see that we've been keeping a  slight lid on CapEx for France. Nevertheless we have invested in Europe. In Italy, for example, we've invested in  solar equipment in Germany. In North America investments in energy products and energy saving products. We  have invested quite heavily there with investment in proppants and in emerging countries a major priority of the  Group.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: What does this mean for the Group? For innovative material first of all, we think there will be a robust momentum  across all geographic areas with good levels of margins. With the IMs, innovative materials of our construction  justifies our significant level of investment in this region, we are at the maximum limits of our capacity in these  countries. In mature countries we will continue to develop slowly. We don't think however, that the cost of raw  materials and energy will take a more favorable turn, which means that price increases will probably be inevitable.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: What are our priorities for H2, 2011? Given our investment policy, well we will continue with this but, of course,  being very clear cut on our financials. We want, first of all, to give the priority to the sales price. We've already  been doing this. We have price increases across the board in most of our activities, which are going to be  continuing to be rolling throughout the year. We have to cover the rises in energy cost, of course. I think the  pricing power of Saint-Gobain which has been clearly demonstrated over the past months really gives us reason  for confidence for the rest of the year.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: A second major thrust in terms of growth is energy efficiency and solar power. Here we've started to build a  factory in electrochromic in glazing. We've announced the acquisition of a rock wool production site in the Euros  in Russia – rock wool in Russia, while, you know, the insulation requirements in Russia are enormous and were  the limits of our production capacity therefore at the moment that we've got very good visibility on that market.  And we have also launched the two Avancis plants, one in Germany and another one in South Korea, with high  performance levels, which are still improving in our pilot factory, which gives us a great confidence in our  technology compared with that of our competitors.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: We are taking advantage of our excellent strategic positioning in emerging countries which have strong growth  plus good positioning in the mature countries. I showed you back in February, we took the example of France.  Looking at the new measures on energy savings and these measures have really been positive. We stated back then  that we're going to build a new rock wool factory in France and this is similar to what we are doing in Japan, a  country where energy savings measures are going to be very strong, very robust in the next years for obvious  reasons. So, we have, as I said, good positioning on developed and developing countries.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: We're doing very well in terms of keeping a cap on our costs. Our road map is designed to keep our savings at  50%. 50% savings were in line for that Saint-Gobain has demonstrated that it is fully able to increase its sales  price in an inflationary context. This has to do with the cost of raw materials, energy cost, of course and we are  now in a very strong financial position, which means that we continue to expand and we can seize opportunities as  they arise in different fields across the board.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Over and above the H2 of this year our growth priorities are in the emerging countries on energy savings  measures. These focuses really put us on the right path I believe for growth in the future. And I think you can see  that from the figures our performance is validating our targets and our strategy. We are fully in line with what we  said we'd do and we are on the right path to hit the figures and the targets which I have planned previously for  2015.

file: SGO - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 27July2012 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So these results have been achieved within the framework of an economic climate that obviously was much  tougher than that of H1, 2011, and that they clearly did worse in the, compared to the first quarter of 2012, which  was more or less satisfactory and was in line with the economic scenario that we thought would play out at the  beginning of the year. The deterioration was especially bad over the last two months, especially in Europe.  In North America, we have continued to have a good level of activity, as far as our industrial sectors are concerned  and we have seen a very, very gradual recovery in residential constructions in North America and, therefore, the  signals for the months to come also are green.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And so, in the – it is true that the global economic climate has deteriorated with sharper deterioration in the last  two months. Now, of course, the basis for comparison was very difficult, because although we did have a negative  calendar impact in the second quarter in Europe, as I mentioned, I'm not going to talk about this very much but  it's quite clear that the weather conditions in Europe over the second quarter were really not very good.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We've also had a significant impact of the rise of cost of raw materials and energy, especially in flat glass, because  that is an activity that has really suffered from all the unfavorable conditions, and that is why our results have not  been good in flat glass, both in Europe and in emerging countries. I'll come back to that in more detail later on.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, given this deterioration in the economic climate, just as the group has done in the past, we reacted very  strongly and very quickly, as well with, and we took a number of measures. First of all, we have decided to  maintain and I believe that this is very important, although results have been rather patchy from one sector to  another, we have continued to focus, as a priority, on our sales prices, given the increase in the cost of energy and  raw materials.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We launched new cost cutting program and from the first half of this year, we've already seen the primary results  come up and, especially, we've had specific program in the flat glass division.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now for flat glass, we've seen a sharp downturn in demand in most of the countries where we are present. In  automotive glass in Europe, which has been accentuated by, of course, fallen inventory throughout the assembly  line and we've also seen a shrinkage in the solar market and for non-residential sectors in Europe, as well. And in  Asia and in Brazil, we have markets that were not a positive for the first half of the year and, above all, we've had –  there is a lot of overcapacity in China and, of course, this has led to short-term high exports that, of course,  impacted prices, both in Brazil and in Korea.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Some of these stoppages, of course, are final stoppages we did in the first half of the year. We stopped two other  floats in France and Germany and also we have sold two half floats, one in Italy and one in France. In Brazil, we  started up a new float, but we had to stop one of the other floats for repairs and, in Asia, we stopped one in China,  two temporarily in South Korea and another one in China that was for the solar market.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Of course, we had to restructure and downsize our solar business, given that although the market for solar panels  continues to grow in Europe, as far as the mid-term trends are concerned, but as you know there was a bubble in  2010, 2011 and, therefore, this year we've had a relative downturn. And given the actions that have been gathered  by the Chinese, our European customers, especially Germany's customers, have had a difficult time and, therefore,  we've had to restructure our activities in solar.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now, given all these elements and you'll see that we are going to – we've had made the lot of investments, but we  have frozen any new investments and we've decided to sharply reduce inventory in flat glass in order to ensure  that we are in line with the reduction of demand. Of course, the actions we've taken are not limited to flat glass.  I'm going to look at the two – so the two main examples of this are Spain and Portugal. I'm sorry, I don't think we  can continue says Mr. de Chalendar.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now, for the first half of the year, given the deterioration in the economic climate in Europe and in emerging  countries, especially over the last two months, we have launched an action plan with new measures that have to  adapt to the changing economic climate.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: You can see 2.6% rise, two-thirds of the positive contribution to sales and from distribution with the Build Center  and Brossette acquisitions. Brossette was consolidated as of the 1 of April, but the remaining third is made up of  the acquisitions made in performance materials, in energy efficiency, with Solar Gard and in construction  materials essentially on emerging markets.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Regarding disposal gains, you can see €66 million, essentially due to the main item, which is gains that we reaped  in from the disposal of a half float, an independent, [ph] Mr. Reulle (16:42). Assets depreciation, €193 million –  asset write-downs were €193 million. Depreciations in two main areas: first of all, write-downs in flat glass with  our float activities and in our solar activities, as well and, on the other hand, there was goodwill depreciation in  distribution in Spain. So, on the whole, operating income dropped 20.8%. That's the business income item.  So, a word about asbestos-related claims in the US, which is customary – situation was stable. Regarding the  number of claims, we're at 2,000 claims in the first half. Claim settled, slightly rising, but there are swings on that  number. As you know, when stocks are dropping at the end of the period, we were at 47,000 claims. Settlements  over the 12 month signing period are down, €70 million.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving on to cash generation, let me begin with EBITDA, you can see a 7.9% drop. It remains at a very high level,  €2,284 million. There was a rise in CapEx in the first half, because we initiated investments in 2011 notably on  emerging markets. As you can see, nearly 50% of our industrial investments were made in Asia and in emerging  countries. And you can see that the growth CapEx and development CapEx have an 80-20 split. Well it's 80-20 if  you'll include energy efficiency. With regard to Europe, that is 80-20 between Asia and Europe.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now moving on to free cash flow plus change in operating working capital requirement, so you see cash  generation proper. Actually, you see quite an improvement against a pretty difficult backdrop. You see a 21% rise  in cash generation, which confirms the priority that we clearly set out on cash generation for the half year.  There were a few acquisitions in the half year. The top two are Brossette, obviously, which we integrated on April 1  and SAGE, which is our specialized glass. This is in energy efficiency. With respect to last year's half year, you see  that we're more cautious in acquisitions, because we spent €277 million versus €520 million in H2 2011. And the  acquisitions are essentially in line with commitments made in 2011. As Pierre-André suggested, we postponed any  new acquisition projects that we had.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Conversely, regarding High Performance Materials, you see the prices performed well, thereby driving H1 growth,  so greater than the volume performance and it pretty much offset the volume situation. In terms of the numbers,  you see the impact of the integration of Solar Gard and a positive FX impact.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
