texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer  Okay. So I’ll say a few words on strategy because after all we had spent a lot of time on that on – in  November. Now the vision that is the framework for our strategy is that we want to ensure that  Saint-Gobain should become the best-known reference in terms of sustainable housing.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: We want to bring innovative solutions to the critical challenges of today, and we want – and I think  that what we’ve done – what happened in the beginning of 2011 shows very clearly that these  concerns that Saint-Gobain has are very important to the problem of access to energy, to raw  materials, the problem of environment and of growth in emerging countries.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: And we wanted to also bolster the Group’s position in high value-added Habitat solutions or  housing solutions. I gave an indicator that I will mention very quickly here, the first one was to  increase the part of our new products. And from that point of view, the fact that we’ve maintained  and we’ve continued to prove – to increase gradually our -- the – what we invest in R&D, of course,  means that we will be able to bring out new products on to the market and we have pushed that up  to 25% for 2015. That’s quite ambitious.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Then the high energy or energy efficiency and energy environment that will be up by 38%, and if I  explain what I said in the month of November, we hope to do this by including all the parts of the  Group that have growth that is higher than the growth in their market, because they bring in new  solutions. And we want to ensure that those high value-added solutions will be pushed up to 60%  by 2015 as compared to 51% in 2010.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: 9 Now what is happening on all these subjects, today I’d like to talk about the regulations concerning  new builds. This is of course an important part of our activity, but not – that’s not all of it, so that we  are going to talk about the new build markets for France and Europe. Now I’ve used base 100 for  2008 in an arbitrary manner, but when we look at the improvement in energy efficiency in new  buildings that have been bought about by regulation as you can see between 2008 and 2013.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: If I look at the four big countries in Europe, UK, France, Germany and the Netherlands, this  reduction is extremely high of about 50% and it will continue, because a certain number of  countries – we do know what’s going to happen to this regulation in the medium term and we know  that it’s going to continue because in 2010 for – 2020 sorry, for France, we will be building new  buildings that are positive energies, with BEPOS standard.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Now back to go into a little bit of detail, for France, first of all because it’s one of the biggest  markets of the group and also because it’s really becoming significant. We want – the aim is to  reduce 50% of energy consumption and more in new buildings, and this is very important because  of course insulation becomes very important. I’ll give you two examples; sales of glass wool and –  so you know that in France the market is at about minus 2% to minus 3%. But if I look at the sales  of Isover by Saint-Gobain, which is glass wool in 2010 in terms of square meters, it’s gone up by  2%. And in terms of tons, it’s gone up by 8% to 9%, because people have – we have of course  ensured that our products are thicker and more dense because of the new regulations. And this is  going to continue in this direction and for flat glass as well plus 7%, and the – whereas actually the  flat glass sales in France was quite flat for residential buildings.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Now another very important point concerning regulations of the RT 12 thermal regulation in France  in – furthermore, specific provisions that have been adopted recently to – has been set down  clearly that for old buildings that have a minimum of glass surface that has to represent one-sixth of  the living surface and this because in well-insulated buildings the best way to improve energy  efficiency is to let sunlight in. Now and of course for that, flat glass plays a large role.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: What does this mean for us? For new buildings, the rate – the average rate of glass surface –  glazed surface is today 13% compared to total surface. And if I look at 6% that’s – that one-sixth,  sorry, that’s 17% that means 30% of flat glass sales more. So the environment rules, first of all,  they are going – they are beginning to be applied and as I showed you in the earlier slide, this is  going to carry on and in – between 2013 and 2020 this is going to go up considerably and that is  why we are investing in these products.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Now if I look at all of the industrial units that is in Innovative Materials and Construction Products,  that’s even more – it’s even clearer, because the objective is to go from 31% this year which is  already – has already meant a big increase, but we want to push that up to 39% for 2015.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: 10 countries. That is already the case in the second-half of 2010 and 80% for solar energy and  emerging countries.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: On the other hand, I can tell you that in – we’ve had a positive effect in the month of January.  February is not over yet, but it should be more or less the same. So we believe that that in terms of  the climate, since it’s slightly better we believe that this first two months of this year will help us to  recover little bit from the bad impact that we had in December last year. So we hope that the  upward trend will continue.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: So now if I look at the whole Group as a whole, this means of course that we will have an upswing  in our sales volumes and we – this should become faster. As I told you, we were able to  consolidate the upward trend in our sales prices in spite of the fact that – of course that has to be  done given that we know that raw materials and energy will – the prices will increase in 2011,  probably more so than in 2010. And therefore, we will have to push our prices up even more in  2011 than we did in 2010 if we want to offset the risers – the increase in our – in the prices of our  input.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: And from that point of view, the increase in energy prices, which of course is unavoidable in the  medium-term, is – has been taken into consideration and the strategy of the Group is appropriate       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: 12 given the rise in the price of energy and raw materials, given our position in emerging countries.  And we also have a much leaner cost base as of now and we hope that will make it possible for us  to have a significant operating leverage. And although it will – that will of course be tampered by the  rise in raw material and energy cost and we hope that we will continue to – we will be able to  continue to pursue our development policy and capitalize on growth opportunities by increasing our  acquisitions.

file: SGO - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 17February2012 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now construction markets in North America for the whole year, we were at quite low levels, we had been so as far  as the new-build segment is concerned. So nothing has changed much, nothing significant anyway. And for about  the first half of the year, or at least the second and third quarters, we did have a temporary growth in the  renovation markets because we – in North America, there had been rather severe storms in the early part of the  year and that hurt us, especially for roofing activities.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now three main priorities, they are actually priorities in our strategy that I already told you about. I'll come back  to that later on. We invested really in high growth countries, and we invested about €1.1 billion energy efficiency,  that's about €900 million. And then we also consolidated our strength in Building Distribution and Construction  Products, and basically in Distribution actually, to about the extent of about €300 million. So as we told you at the  beginning of the year, we would start reinvesting, and that's what we did.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Quarterly-wise, you see here on the quarterly basis we've got another couple of things. Firstly, the trend in  volumes with the positive effect that you're all familiar with for the first quarter, linked to the positive weather  conditions we had compared with the negative conditions in the first quarter of 2010, but if you look at the  following quarter that are more significant. As I told you, there'd be a negative impact in the number of days in the  fourth quarter, but if you restate those figures on a comparable number of days basis, you have a growth of 1.7% in  the second quarter, 1.7% in the third quarter and 1.3% in the fourth quarter. So no substantial important trend.  Besides kind of slowing down, December was a favorable month, but it was a small one.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Let's look at prices next. You see here clearly good price momentum in the group for several quarters now because  it went from 2% price growth at the beginning of the year to 3.2% price growth in the fourth quarter. And this is a  priority for us in our strategy, as we told you before, and this strategy is now panning out. And it's more than just  necessary because this price evolution for the whole of the year didn't enable us to totally offset the upswing in raw  materials costs and energy costs.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: What's the impact then on the operating income? If suggests 11% on a like-for-like basis, that's constant exchange  rate, so double digits. As Pierre-Andre said, our objective has been achieved. And if you look at the variation  compared to last year 2010, with 5% of growth in revenues but 2.7% of growth in prices which were not totally  sufficient to offset the raw materials and energy price hikes, so the 2.3% of growth in volumes plus the leaner cost  base that we've set up enabled us to increase our operating income by 11%, so it's a good operational leverage.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: If you compare it with 2008, which is a worthwhile comparison, we almost came back to the level of profitability  we had in 2008 for all of the group. Excluding distribution and in distribution, we see that we're still at 11% of  volumes below 2008. The price in the period over the three years, the prices enabled us more or less to cancel out  the strong inflation of raw materials cost and energy prices. So the drop in costs we fully off – the drop in volume  rather, we fully offset by our other measures which were the leaner cost base measures. So about half of those are  sustainable, are fixed. So if the volumes come in in bigger numbers, we'll avail more of that.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: As Pierre-André said, we increased, as we announced, our capital expenditure over the course of the year by a bit  less than €500 million, plus 34% is the figure you see here, so €486 million was the actual figure. That 50% of it,  then that's what's dedicated to capital expenditure in high growth countries and capacity in investments mainly  and 20% capital expenditure to guarantee energy efficiencies in developed countries. So that's 50% and 20%, so  investment in growth and in energy efficiency in high growth countries, so 50% in high growth countries, Asia and  the emerging countries, and 20% in energy efficiency in the developed world.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The increase this year, well, there's some exceptional factors. You have the foreign exchange impact with the  closing rate, that's not the same as the average ratio, that penalizes us a bit. The December impact, taking into  account the weather conditions, saw some raw materials' prices too that we – I mean, raw materials that we stored  because we anticipated the pricing hike, but, nonetheless, there's a slight decline especially regarding the  inventories. Regarding trade tables and receivables, no deterioration there. But we want to come back more on  track towards our long-term objective.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: A substantial acquisition in energy efficiency, too, with Solar Gard being acquired in the U.S., and consolidation in  Building Distribution with Build Center that you're familiar with, but also some small bolt-on acquisitions that are  really value-enhancing ones, especially in France.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: But I'll go into that in some more detail. Look at the moment there throughout the year in the second quarter and  the fourth quarter. Well, there were some slowing down in Flat Glass and Exterior Solutions, especially Piping.  But conversely, we had Interior Solutions, Distribution and, in the fourth quarter, Packaging holding their own  fairly well. So we'll go into the details of that as we walk through the different business sectors.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: I'll put on this slide now the internal growth, the organic growth of the year and I've separated out the first half  and the second half. So here you see the slowing down of growth in Innovative Materials, especially in Flat Glass  growth in the second half was only 1.4%. That can be explained by the shrinking of the solar markets that were  present in Flat Glass, of course, and the slowing down of certain emerging countries in a situation where Europe  remains difficult. However, in automotive in the second half of last year continued to fare well. And our strategy to  focus on added-value products has continued to pay off because our film glass sales are up by 13%.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So in the second half there was more pressure on prices. In June it was about €3.5 and at the end of the year it  stood at about €3.16, at the beginning of this year €3.01. So there are price hikes plans in February and March  there. For High-Performance Materials, plus 5.2%, that's good momentum in the second half, mainly driven by  pass on the energy price hikes and the raw materials price hikes and the High-Performance Materials managed to  do that.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: However, between Ceramics and the other parts of this business sector there were differences. Ceramics and  Plastics and Abrasives – Ceramics not doing as well as Plastics and Abrasives, that grew quite a bit. On  profitability, you can see here in Flat Glass the drop by 1 percentage point compared to the last year, in the first  half, that is. And that can be explained by the fact that price did not offset the raw materials and energy price hikes  in Europe, but also in certain emerging countries, like Brazil. And the volumes were steady over the year and our  cost-cutting measures were not sufficient to offset that. But all told, you can see in this difficult context, especially  compared with the other competitors, the performance and the soundness of our results were seen quite markedly  in the second half of 2011.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: In High-Performance Materials, results are steady in the second half year-on-year, minus 0.2, but that's because  of the product mix in High-Performance Materials with less sales in Ceramics, and in High-Performance Materials  we managed to pass on the price hikes better and that explains the steadiness of the operating income there now.  The EBITDA is high, up by 6.6% compared to the previous year. And capital expenditure running at a high level  here, especially in Flat Glass, which this capital expenditure was quite substantial in the emerging countries, a  float industry – business line, sorry,  in India and Brazil, and also energy efficiency capital expenditure in  electrochromic glass and in silver panel glass.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So as you see, we have Exterior Solutions up 2.9%. That's weathering the storm pretty well especially in Piping, in  the Piping sector that are largely due to – in the past, that was offset in the half year by the improvement of our  Exterior Solutions in the U.S., and quite a buoyant market in Mortars as well. So all told, nonetheless in Exterior  Solutions, as you'll see in our results, the prices were short of the mark and we couldn't pass on all of the energy  and raw materials price hikes for the full year.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: On Exterior Solutions, a slight drop compared with the second half last year, minus 0.5 points, with raw materials  prices that were not totally offset by our price hikes and also fixed cost absorption. Because of the drop in volumes  and pricing, we had to live with the higher costs. So the EBITDA is good, €1.59 billion, and an increase in CapEx,  too, to be seen with energy efficiency doing fairly well.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: But the biggest contribution to this growth here you see the [ph] 3.2% fourth quarter, but (31:19) 2.8% of that  growth connected with price and those price hikes are necessary and will be even more necessary in 2012 or will  continue to be necessary because of the raw materials and energy price hikes that we anticipate in the coming  while. So in terms of profitability, we got a further marked improvement compared with the last year and  compared to 2009 as well, up €15 million of operating income in the second half, compared with the previous  year. Good profitability, too, so this is a business line that was resilient during the crisis, but also even nice to  improve its results and its cash generation.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Let's now take a quick look at our strategy and I'm going to remind you of the positioning of Saint-Gobain and its  fundamentals and try and illustrate our actions on the strategic priorities of the group. So the strategy of the group  is, of course, within the framework of the position that I outlined to you at the beginning of 2007. And that hasn't  changed and still focused on residential markets or the habitat market, which has a lot of growth potential and we  find innovative solutions. And the focus has been reinforced by the crisis, and we work in emerging countries as  well, and we are trying to find answers to the challenges of energy and the environment. And more and more,  Saint-Gobain is becoming the reference in terms of sustainable habitat.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now this gives us a positioning that I think is quite unique and a very buoyant position, very attractive position,  because Saint-Gobain is today positioned on growing markets at different positions within the development curve.  So we have taken up a very good position for residential and the residential buildings for tomorrow and, of course,  in solutions for developed countries where, of course, these curves are going upwards, and in emerging countries  as well. I don't need to explain this to you but I definitely need to say that in the construction market, which is still  a quite difficult one, the thermal renovation sector is a very dynamic one and we've come back to growth rates, for  example in France, which are pretty good, 5.5% in 2011.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The second main strategic act of the group is, of course, high-value added solutions for Habitat and new energy  efficiency, solar. In as far as solar panels are concerned, we know that there's a lot of growth there. We can't really

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: And another thing has a significant impact on our group businesses is, of course, regulation. I told you that  thermal renovation was up 5% in France. It's actually up 12.5% on a like-for-like basis, and Isover in France is  really developing insulation systems – that thermal insulation from –  with Exterior Solutions with which –  in  which actually France is lagging behind other countries in Europe, and so 12.5% this year.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: We have also made investments in energy efficiency, of course. We have just finished a plant in Germany, Avancis,  and there's another plant Avancis plant that we are building with our partner Hyundai in South Korea. They both  make a thin-film glass. And we are also building a wonderful plant, the very first big worldwide plant for  electrochromic glass with SAGE, in which we've taken out a stake. And that's also a product that has a huge future.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now we also bought companies in the sector, a very good acquisition in a sector that we were not present in, that  is Technical Plastics, firms that have properties that are very much complementary to our glass products. And so,  we bought a company that is based in the United States but that is also developing very strongly in China. And we  also rounded off our Italian presence with an acquisition in Mortars.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now I talked about the importance of regulations. I've added a few other countries to this graph. Of course there  are more cold countries here than hot countries, because that's where insulation is most important. But just to  remind you that between 2008 and 2013, in new-build in all of these countries, the energy consumption in new  buildings will actually have been cut in half. So the – has to be cut in half, sorry. So the only way to do that is to  really insulate buildings from the outside. And that's going to be a very important market for us.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So new products, our definition is products that have been launched less than five years ago. And, as you can see,  these figures have gone from 20% in 2010 to 22% in 2011, and we hope to push that up to 25% by 2015. I'll give  you a few examples of successful launches. In 2011, we launched a new windscreen, which actually means that you  don't have to scrape the ice off your windscreen.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So it's a special kind of glass and so we do have the – and of course, the car makers are going to have different  versions of this glass, which will be in mid-ranges and will go up to the top of the range. And we have the light  plasterboard as well, and this comes after the soundproof plasterboard that we launched last year. This is very  light and very useful in many sectors.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now what about Western Europe? In Western Europe, there is going to be certainly a shrinkage in the car market,  it's been announced by the carmakers. But I believe that the rest of the industrial sector should remain at quite a  satisfactory level. The indications that we have from Abrasives, Plastics, don't really lead us to believe that there is  going to be a big deterioration.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now in 2012, we will once again have a rise in the prices of energy, especially energy, and of course, electricity.  There's – we can't expect any miracles there because the decision that was taken by Germans last summer is,  obviously, going to translate through into higher prices for energy, not just in Germany. And then to a lesser  extent, we will also have a continuing rise in raw materials costs.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Construction products, we hope to have continued strong momentum in high growth countries and in the market  that concerns energy efficiency in Europe in 2012. And we saw in 2011 and probably that's going to continue into  2012, it's not very easy to predict, we believe that there is going to have – there's going to be an impact of the  negative spread in a certain number of factors between the price and the cost. And those, of course, are things like  Pipes or Exterior Solutions in the United States, which are the sectors in which really raw materials prices have  impacted us the most.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now our priorities for 2012. As I told you, they may change as compared to what I said last year. The main priority  is our price policy, with our targets being clearly to pass on the rise in raw material and energy costs to our  customers. We are going to continue to maintain a very, very close eye on costs. Laurent told you that we have a  set number of business sectors and geographical zones where we have to continue to make an effort to reduce  costs, we will restructure where necessary. We don't really have an overall plan for this year, but we will certainly  tweak things wherever they need to be tweaked, especially in the zones where we are having more problems in our  costs.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Now of course as far as finances go, we have to continue to keep a very tight rein on cash in order to keep up the  good financial strength. And we're going to continue to invest as well in the group's main growth drivers, emerging  countries' energy efficiency, by adopting a policy that is quite selective in terms of capital expenditure and  financial investments as well. We're going to targets our financial investment that will, of course, depend on the  different companies that we believe we can afford to buy.  And then we are going to continue to maintain and to grow our efforts for R&D. And, in this context, which is  quite uncertain in terms of the financial and economic conditions, we believe that we will have moderate organic  growth and it's going to be driven chiefly by sales prices. We hope that operating income and profitability will  continue to prove resilient. We will have high levels of free cash flow. As I told you, we are going to stabilize our  capital expenditure the same level as in 2011, that's about €2 billion, and we are going to continue to preserve a  very strong balance sheet.

file: SGO - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 21February2013 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Just a few words about the flat glass. Back in July the first half of the year had been difficult as flat glass has  slowed down in trading for the building industry, plus the automotive industry as well. This covers Western  Europe and Asia and the emerging countries. The solar business had developed as you will remember quite  significantly, but the markets really collapsed here in Europe in the course of 2012. And things have been  extremely difficult there given the activities from Chinese producers. All this affected the construction business,  and we've had, as I said, problems in the automotive market as well linked to this, linked to a falloff in demand.  We've also seen a fall in the float glass prices, which has gone hand-in-hand with an increase in September and  October. Well there was an increase in price, but this did not offset in any way the hikes in energy costs and the  rises in raw materials, which hits us particularly in the first half of the year.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Across the board, flat glass particularly, but across the board, generally, given the reduction in activity now things  have not been easy to do, but we have managed to increase our sales prices with an increase up 1.7% over the year,  therefore, and up 2% excluding flat glass. And this has enabled us to reduce overall the impact of the rise in raw  material and energy costs. I was talking about July. We said that we had a significant cost-savings program. The  impact of this was forecast for €500 million over the year. In fact, we have managed to hit the figure €520 million  compared with the 2011 cost base. And this translated into the accounts by an increase in the restructuring costs,  and Laurent will come back over this later on.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: 2012 nevertheless has managed to pursue its strategic goals, and we've continued to focus on our strict financial  discipline, which we've imposed upon ourselves. In terms of capital expenditure and acquisitions, we've really  focused on high growth countries. First of all, countries which have not really grown that much in 2012, but good  prospects for the future. Also we've concentrated on energy efficiency and the energy markets and we've decided  to consolidate our strengths in the building distribution.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: All of these different activities represent two-thirds of the group's total investments in 2012. We've also moved  into a new chapter of our activities in terms of refocusing on Habitat, and we've got very good financial conditions  for this. So with the disposal, the future disposal of Verallia in North America at a price of $1.7 billion.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Perimeter, up 2.7%. 2/3 of this comes from acquisitions of Brossette and [ph] Build (9:09) Center. And we've also  made a few more minor acquisitions in construction products in the emerging countries and acquisition of Solar  Gard in the high-performance sector.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Growth on a like-for-like basis is minus 2.9%. Prices up 1.7%. Overall for the group, it's 1.7% not really sufficient to  offset the impact of the rise in raw materials and energy cost, particularly in the glass sector where we need sand,  for example. And the major impact of course was in flat glass. Excluding that, we offset overall the rise in energy  prices. Volume changes minus just over 3% concentrated mainly in Europe, but we'll talk about that a little later  on.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: If we look now on what's happening quarter-by-quarter, there's a settling of prices 2.4%, in line plus one. Gere  we've got a slow increase of the impact of raw materials and energy, which emerged across the year as a whole.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The other element, which weighs on these figures is depreciation of assets, €436 million. Here €310 million  relating to depreciation of assets in the solar activity particularly advances therefore, but other flat glass activities

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: If I look at all the industrial acquisitions and the investments we've made, as I said, we worked very largely on the  high-growth countries: €760 million investment there mainly in terms of industrial investment; €200 million on  the energy efficiency and energy markets with particularly the follow-up to the acquisition of SAGE. This work is  in electrochromic glass in the U.S. And we've also taken a share in Celotex in the U.K. and acquired a stake in  Isoroc in Russia, and then Brossette in France as I've talked about. And we've moved into bolt-on acquisitions in  Scandinavia. This is in the building distribution sector, and the total in terms of acquisitions there is €440 million.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Construction products, minus 1.3%, broken down into an increase in interior solutions driven by the emerging  countries and the U.S., but also given the growth differential in Europe because of energy efficiency business  plans. And then you have exterior solutions going down by 3.7% and the second half was penalized by the trend on  the pipes market and also the difficult comparison with the U.S. given the 2011 storms, of course, that led to good  trading that year. Then building distribution down by 2% growth in the year in the Nordic countries and in  Germany, and good resilience in our business clients in France. And then, packaging, plus 3.5% mainly driven by  prices.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Building Distribution, next you'll see the trends in revenues over the year, down 2%, especially minus 3.2% in the  second half, penalized by a slowdown in our trading in Sweden and towards the very end of the year, in Germany  also compared with the first half. That's because of the weather conditions in December.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The EBITDA, €1.035 billion, that's quite a lot down compared to the previous year. Well, it's down a bit, but not  hugely rather. Sorry, the interpreter corrects. So you see there is a slight difference, but not huge. It's fairly steady.  The increase in revenues in packaging plus 3.5% for the whole year speed up in the second half plus 3.9% for H2.  In the 3.9%, the main contribution is from price plus 3.1%, but the price of 3.1% is not sufficient to offset the raw  materials and energy price hikes in the gas making industry.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Geography by geography, you see this is the same kind of presentation I made earlier from a different perspective  by revenue and by industrial asset. So it's just to show you the share of Asia and the emerging world in our  industrial asset base. They will continue to grow. They now represent 33% of our industrial assets, and they have  now passed out the other Western European countries you see in the green here.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Let me just focus on the strategy now. The Saint-Gobain strategy, which is really fully part of the vision, which  we've been developing over the past few years. So they're saying that Saint-Grobain is to be the number one  reference in sustainable Habitat. And we have to face up to the challenges of our time, managing growth in these  emerging countries, having to contend with development of energy, for example, and preserving the environment.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The medium term vision, which we have is a very buoyant, profitable one. And more than ever Saint-Grobain is  sticking to its strategy. Let me outline the four points, which are at the heart of the implementation of our  strategy. First of all, with the disposal of Verallia in the U.S. So we're refocusing on Habitat.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: This operation was fully in line with our strategy. We're very clear about our strategy. We've demonstrated that we  do all this, or we carry this operation out in very good conditions. And you can see that, as I said, we did this just  at the right time. So we're refocusing on Habitat, which means that we've been able to strengthened the group's  balance sheet because this has translated overall into a reduction in net debt of €1 billion.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: I think that this operation, too, has allowed us to preserve over and above the geographical region of the U.S.A.  You know that the U.S.A. was a market where we had the weakest positions. But nevertheless, Verallia has  remained a global entity, leader on the market of bringing in high levels of cash. And so we're sticking to our  schedule, to our targets, and we will execute the whole operation when the right time comes. And I'm not in any  terrible rush to do this given the financial conditions, which are ahead of us for 2013.  Second strategic thrust I want to talk about is constantly adapting to the economic climate. And given that climate  we have to adapt very swiftly and very strongly to ups and downs on our markets while maintaining strict financial  discipline. We've done all this, of course, over the past years. If you look over the past 20 years, what we've done,  we have always been capable of pushing our prices up when there's been fall-off in volume with the exception of  2009, 2012 for flat glass as well. But overall I have to say we've always given priority to and will continue to do this  to pushing up our sales prices.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: We'll be continuing to work on purchases of cost of buying equipment, energy, raw materials. And we've identified  new sources of savings by pooling the purchases, which up until now have been decentralized with further  continuing of our sourcing policies in the lowest-cost countries. So we're developing this program and we're  extending it and amplifying it.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: We're also making significant operating cost savings, working on the WCM. And given the fact that as part of the  activity reduction plans, we have to tailor our reduction plans to the prospects of recovery in different countries.  And therefore these structural reduction plans are bigger in certain countries. Spain, for example, then in others  where we may feel or we identify a momentary dip, but prospects of a speedy recovery.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Let me come back to what I was saying just now on flat glass. And we have stopped a certain number of activities  quite significantly representing 20% of lines both in Europe and outside Europe. These stoppages started to be  translated into a price increase in the autumn. Given the seasonal variations that we have on this market, we're  looking forward to prices given the fact that we're moving into better weather. We hope that prices will be moving  into an upward trend on these markets.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Given the collapse of prices on the solar activities, we've had a considerable increase in production capacity on the  market both in China and the fact that the Chinese players there have accepted significant levels or colossal levels  of cash losses. And therefore, the solar business has very depressed prices and our targets are not going to be met  on that for the moment.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: What we see for the events of the plans in Germany, we believe that they have considerable prospects for the  future. But for the moment we're not developing this activity at the moment. So we're really reducing solar  business activity overall.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Having said this over the medium term, of course, the construction market, the underlying market is currently  given its overall medium term trend is in a dip as you can see from the right-hand graph. But over the medium  term we are looking forward to strong growth. Our markets in this sector and our position as the Saint-Gobain  Group is drawn by the energy efficiency market where there's rapid expansion both in developed and emerging  countries.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: And energy prices will be developing or going up in Europe. There are purchasing sustainable policies for  procurement policies in the public and private sectors. And we believe overall that the Habitat market is one  which is going to be developing strongly in the medium term both in the emerging countries and the developed  countries.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Can I illustrate the effectiveness of our policy on the French market, which is currently boosted by the  implementation on the 1st of January of a new thermal energy policies. You've got three columns for 2000 and  2012. You've got the Isover underlying market. This is one of our estimations. This is a market which slightly  above the construction market in terms of insulation generally. Things are going well.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The green column is an indicator for thermal renovation, and then you've got the Isover sales. And basically you  you can see that even for 2012 in a construction market, which was relatively flat for Isover and the construction  market was negative. Nevertheless, we're continuing to develop a pace.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: We've launched a new generation of unleaded mirrors in order to better preserve the environment with excellent  optical qualities. We've also got windscreens, which heat up in winter and improve better, or better manage the  sun rays in the summer.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: On the left-hand side you've got high-quality, triple glass glazing developing strongly in Germany. You also got the  new paints and textiles, which have environmentally friendly qualities. We've got sheet plasterboard with high- quality acoustic qualities, an example of synergies in R&D. And we've launched this on the new hospital build  market, and we're now working on buildings for public authorities, collective buildings as it were and schools. And  we're strengthening glass fiber market with the new products coming out there offering a better fire resistance and  damp resistance as well. These are just a few examples of the kind of products which we've launched. And this is  one of the key things which we do in the group.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So great technical content, but across the board offering as well this is one of the key characteristics of Saint- Gobain. As I've said, R&D is very much pushed by what's happening locally. We're working for these local markets  with great communication between the central R&D departments and the more local based markets. All of this  bearing in mind of the organization, which we've set up as very lightweight organization. It's not an extra layer of  administration. All this is set up existing in 23 countries overall. We have a new program called Multi-Confort.  We're talking about thermal and acoustic and air quality comfort, visual comfort as well with a scalable comfort  bringing together whole series of offers from different activities. And this is one of the key things we're working on  for the future.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Let me come to the final point, which is the outlook for 2013. So in terms of the business cycle, we're not expecting  the economic climate to become very conducive in Western Europe for the moment. We think the slowdown will  continue, especially in the automotive sector. There's great uncertainty still hanging over the construction markets  with great disparities from one country to another.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: But as I've shown with the example side, we think we have the support of thermal renovation programs in quite a  lot of countries. In North America, we have seen a taking off after several years at more or less all-time low for our  residential housing starts. But it got off the ground again in 2012, and we hope this will continue in 2013. It should  pick up pace. And industrial output should remain at good level, driven by capital expenditure running at a higher  level in the U.S. in the last 18 months.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Construction products, good momentum in both Americas, that is North and South America. Lack of visibility,  however, in both Western and Eastern Europe, even though regulation should help us to shore up the energy  efficiency market. Then the situation should remain challenging in Asia, particularly for heights even though it  just picked up slowly but surely. And then the tight cost spread should improve compared with 2012 we think in  the construction product market. Building distribution, the trading level should stabilize overall, but there would  be great disparities we think from one country to another.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Priorities for 2013 in line with our priorities strategically, too, in the medium-term. Priority, focus on sales price.  As I've said with the end of passing on the raw material price hikes and the energy costs increases. New cost  on our cash management and our financial strength of course, pursuing targeted development of our key growth  drivers. That's energy efficiency, Asia and the emerging countries, and consolidation then in construction  products and the Building Distribution sector.

file: SGO - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 20February2014 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So this set of figures have been registered in a context which are seen as we thought at the beginning of the last  year with a turn during the year, although not a great macroeconomic scenario, with a very difficult first half in  Europe not helped at all by the weather conditions which were especially difficult in the fall's first months. And  overall, I would say a sluggish economic environment in Europe, better in the second half led mostly by the UK  and to some extent by Germany and some countries in Northern Europe.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: In 2013, we implemented our priorities which were quite clear focused on price. We have achieved a 1% price  increase in context which was slightly better in terms of cost especially of the raw material and energy input costs.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: On a like-for-like basis, the evolution of the turnover is minus 0.3%, plus 1% in price was a good performance –  continue to be a good performance in pricing environment where raw material and energy costs are stabilizing  through 2013.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Concerning the volumes, you see the very significant new shape of the volume evolution with a significant drop of  the volumes in 2012, beginning of 2013. Clearly, the comparison basis for the beginning of 2014 will be relatively  easy due to the bad weather conditions last year. And you see the strong improvement through the year with  positive numbers in Q3 and Q4. Q3, you remember that we had a positive impact of number of days, plus one day,  which means approximately 1.5% of our sales. So if you compare Q3 and Q4 at the same number of days, we have  a stable situation in terms of growth of volumes or a slight improvement in Q4 compared to Q3.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: HPM, flat compared to last year, which is a very – I would say, a much better performance if we compare to the  first half. We continue to – we have zero price in our environments where the costs in 2013 were slightly negative  in terms of raw material and energy, so a positive spread but nevertheless zero prices. Also zero volume, we had a  strongly negative contribution coming from ceramics as I told you for several quarters already, minus 12% here in  the second half in ceramics that was fully compensated by our other activities, Abrasives, Plastics and – with  strong performance of [ph] at force (24:14) driven by emerging countries. Europe and the U.S. had a small  contribution this second half.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Exterior Solutions, some price stabilization in the second half of this year, minus 0.4%, mainly due to the price  evolution of roofing and the Pipe business. But at the same time, we had a reduction of our cost of raw material  and energy, so the spread in these businesses, we are positive. In terms of volumes, a strong volume improvement  in Exterior Solutions, mainly coming once again from emerging countries but also coming from the Pipe business  with the exports contract.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: €433 million in CapEx with a significant project in gypsum in emerging countries, in Brazil, in Russia, in  Indonesia, but also coming from some projects in the U.S. with one greenfield plant in roofing and for a series of  small capital expenditures in Mortars.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Building Distribution, 1.4% negative in 2013, clearly driven by the impact of the weather in the first half. The  second half was positive at 1.7% driven by a strong improvement of our businesses: in the UK, plus 8%; in  Germany, plus 5%; the continued good situation in the Nordics with 2.4% improvement compared to last year. On  the opposite, we had – we posted – I'm talking about H2 numbers. We continued to have a slight reduction of our  turnover with a minus 1% in France but improving through the year, clearly, with a trend to stabilization of the  situation in both France and in the southern part of Europe where we are almost on time in the second half  compared to the second half last year.

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Concerning the profitability, you remember that we said in the end of the first half that we would be around and  above the number of last year. We are clearly significantly above the number of last year with – at constant  exchange rate and perimeter 11% improvement between H2 last year and H2 this year, 11% in profit compared to  1.7% in internal growth. This is a very good operating leverage. Not coming from the commercial margin where we  continue to face some pressure but clearly coming from significant cost reduction in Building Distribution. So,  4.4% margin in distribution in H2. Clearly you can see that on this graph that H1 was clearly strongly affected by  the weather condition. And EBITDA minus CapEx at a very good level of around €700 million.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: We will also reduce the group's capital intensity in developed countries, progressively realigning our mix of  business. So, our industrial activities will focus more on downstream activities which are less capital-intensive  with value-added solution, asset-light solutions with the development of Building Distribution and a specific  action to reduce the capital intensity of Flat Glass by 15 points by 2018.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: And third point, we – second point, sorry, we will accelerate the development of our highly innovative industrial  niche, and we'll strengthen the leadership of the group on our sustainable habitat solutions based on additional  comfort what we call the Multi-Comfort program for habitat.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: New steps in terms of corporate social responsibilities which are, by essence, in the heart of our business model in  terms of sustainability. That's what we provide to our customers, and that's also the way we want to look at our  involvement in our environment.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So now I'd like to give you a few hints about the way we see 2014 with our outlook and the perspective and our  action plan. In terms of outlook, the economic climate is progressively improving. Although in Europe, I would say  that the industrial markets are still sluggish.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So five priorities for Saint-Gobain in 2014, the first one was already there last year and has been there for the last  few years. You know it has been one of my strong focus is to push for a price increase, to exercise our pricing  power and leadership in the context of reduced inflation and raw material and energy costs. But overall, I think  our costs are increasing and we need to continue to increase price. This cost-reduction plan that I mentioned,  implementing and delivering on this cost-reduction plan is clearly a very strong [indiscernible] (52:54) so far this  year.

file: SGO - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 26February2015 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Laurent Guillot
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: So, as you can see in this – on this slide, an evolution of Construction Products that has been clearly very different  between H1 and H2. H1 was very strong, boosted by Q1 on weather conditions. H2, at plus 0.4%, slower than H1,  definitely, due to the reduction of the prices in the roofing business in the U.S., but also due to the slowdown of  the macroeconomic situation in Continental Europe, France and Germany.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In line with that, another metric was to reduce the capital intensity of Saint-Gobain, especially in developed  countries, with a specific focus on Flat Glass. Here also we have made a progress towards our objective. So, the  first metric which is for the overall industrial assets, we have reduced from 32% to 31%, in line with our 28%  objective for 2018.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, I would like to give you a few elements about our outlook for this year. In terms of economic climate, there  will be a gradual recovery in Western Europe, which will be nevertheless hampered by the fact that the  construction market are going to stay depressed in France for at least a significant part of this year.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Construction Products, we will continue to see good momentum in Interior Solutions, and we expect the  situation in roofing to stabilize. And in Building Distribution, we will have a mix depending on the evolution of the  different countries, but overall, the organic growth will be reduced by the downturn that is still going to be the  case in France. And clearly, the first half comparison will not be easy with the first half of 2014, also because of  some weather impact. In Packaging, we expect a good level of operating income, and clearly a continuous  improvement.

file: SGO - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 26February2016 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the industry activities in the U.S., which is a big part of our HPM businesses, we have been clearly hit. But what  happened in the oil and gas market, especially with our proppants division, some of our industrial activity has  remained solid.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Organic growth was positive 0.4%. Prices were up plus 0.3%, showing once again the group's ability to drive prices  even if the environment became increasingly deflationary during the year. Volumes edged up by 0.1%, and this  performance was achieved despite the adverse effects of oil and gas-related businesses and the strong slowdown  experienced in our Pipes business. Those two businesses represent more than one-third of a point of negative  volume growth this year on the group.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: As Pierre-André mentioned previously, excellent working capital performance, as we co ntinue to harvest the  benefits of a very strict cash discipline. This is a historical low, and this is substantially better than what had been  guided previously as a long-term objective, partly helped by good weather conditions at the end of the year which  led to a busy month of December. So two days improvement compared to 2014, with approximately one of those  two days coming from exchange rate.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So, let's now move to sector-by-sector and regions-by-regions comments. So, Innovative Materials had a solid  year, with a strong contribution of Flat Glass of plus 5.1%, driven by a strong [ph] Sika rate (21:08) but with a  solid upstream, too. High-Performance Materials showed a good resilience despite the effect of oil-and-gas- related businesses.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Construction Products is growing overall by 0.5%, with Interior Solutions at plus 1.9%, which is a growth entirely  linked on the full year to volumes. Exterior Solutions was lower and weighed on the average, mostly because of the  difficult environment in the Pipes business in the second half. In this activity, I'm talking about Exterior Solutions,  the volumes were positive for the year, however, with a negative price effect of 1.8%, also impacted by the roofing  asphalt price decrease.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: High-Performance Materials was impacted by the decrease in ceramics, which is itself mostly the effect of oil and  gas-related businesses, especially North America. All other activities of HPM, abrasives, plastics and textile  solutions, are growing. And without proppants, HPM growth would have been around 1.5%.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: A substantial part of the CapEx is one-time heavy plant maintenance, for example, in Interior Solutions in the U.S.  Another important investment is our new roofing plant in Missouri, to be started in the second quarter of 2016.  This will help us improve our geographical footprint, our service level, and our logistic cost in a profitable  business.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Looking at the results by geographical area, you can see that all areas have improved this year on both semesters.  The only exception being France. North America, which was helped by exchange rate on one side, could have been  better had it not been for the oil and gas effect, first, and start-up cost in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: In terms of margin percentage, substantial progression in Western Europe reaching 5.9% profitability in the  second half; strong improvement also in emerging countries in the second half to 10.7% profitability despite Brazil  slowing down. And France and North America, a little bit less positive for reasons which were already explained  namely volumes and Pipe in France on one hand and oil-and-gas-related businesses in the U.S. on the other hand.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Okay. Now, I'd like to give you a quick update on our strategy and the outlook for 2016. So, our ambition remains  the same, building on our worldwide leadership on sustainable habitat. We aim to create and deliver innovative  and high-performance solutions to enhance our habitat and our daily life. And following the divesture of Verallia,  we are concentrated on our three pillars to serve our main construction market and an additional industrial niche  markets around with each of our three sectors bringing specificities, Innovative Materials, Distribution, and  Construction Products, and leveraging strong synergies between them.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, second priority is to answer the major trends in our markets. If we look at what's going on in the construction  markets, I think I would say three things. First, there is a change in the respective role of the various players, of  the key decision makers in the construction industry. And this is boosted by the digital evolution. Globally, the  user, the final user is much more involved. The boundaries between the final users, what is called also B2C  approach and the traditional approach, are reshuffled to some extent with digital with the user focusing more and  more as growth and well developed on making sure it gets more comfort in many areas whether it is acoustic,  whether it is thermal – it's more thermal comfort than energy savings – whether it's visual. And I think this is a  very important trend.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We expect a slight growth to continue in North America, with some uncertainty in some industrial market. I think  – and we have – we should not underestimate the importance of the energy sector in the U.S. And I think the oil  and gas issue is spilling over to a number of industrial sectors in the U.S. At the same time, there are others which  are quite positive. But I think there are some – there is clearly a slowdown in industrial activity in the U.S.

file: SGO - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 24February2017 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: We invested in niche technologies and new services. For example, we bought a tapes company in Italy, which  complements our successful performance plastics portfolio. In Flat Glass, we continued to invest downstream with  a windshield replacement network in France, an interesting asset-light and services oriented business. In  insulation, other example, we continue to diversify our materials portfolio with the Isonat acquisition in wood-fiber- based insulation.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: And in the High-Performance Materials, the CapEx are more granular in nature, but I will mention our investment  to sustain the fast growth our plastics business in the U.S. or our capacity expansion to produce technical glass  fabrics for various construction related applications in Czech Republic.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: In North America, we had a very dynamic H1. Our H2 was less booming but still growing. Here, again, prices  were under pressure in 2016 on the back, however, of low energy and raw materials cost which benefited our  P&L.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: In terms of the outlook, and first the economic climate, we are forecasting a gradual improvement in France,  driven by a good growth in new-build, and despite a still uncertain renovation market, even though we start to see  some early sign that this could improve. Further growth in other Western European countries, despite less  visibility, as Guillaume already mentioned, in the UK, but good growth overall in all our other countries.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: In Construction Products, we will have better volumes and further cost saving, which should offset – more than  offset – sorry, not offset – more than offset the exceptional weather impacts of Roofing in 2016. We can't predict  the weather, but we have in mind that it was a significant impact in 2016. And Building Distribution should benefit  from what I said from better volume growth in Western Europe and, as you know Distribution, if pricing overall  gets better, Distribution benefits clearly from a bit of more price inflation.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So in terms of our priorities, our number one priority, I repeat myself, but the environment changed and this year  it's a very important topic. We are seeing a change in our raw material and energy situation, which went down  significantly in 2016. This trend is reversing and we need to have an upturn in price. You have seen the fourth  quarter. So, this bodes well for 2016, but it is clearly a strong priority to change from a deflationary environment to  some price increase for all our businesses.

file: SGO - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 23February2018 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: So, a good performance but this performance was absolutely necessary because of the context of increasing cost  in raw materials and energy that we faced with inflation of those costs ending up amounting to over €500 million  for the year.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: I'll now turn to each one of those businesses, the High-Performance Materials and Flat Glass, to give you a little  bit more details. So, in Flat Glass, Flat Glass delivered good results with organic growth of 5.2% driven both by  2.5% of volume and a price effect of 2.7%. The good pricing over the year allowed us to achieve a positive spread  versus raw materials and energy costs.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The operating margin went down to 9.5% compared to 10.3% last year, hit mainly by the inflation in raw materials  and energy cost over the course of the year. A number of the materials that we have seen the most inflation on in  2017 are using the Interior Solutions sector. For example, steel profiles, paper and gypsum, with the move  towards natural gypsum and away from synthetic gypsum, resulting in some additional costs across industry as I  explained in the first half results.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Interior Solutions is also the area where our teams push price the hardest with good success, with prices up 3.1%  for the year, 3.5% in the second half and even 4.1% in the last quarter. So, we are seeing momentum here even  though we experienced a time lag at the start compared to the raw materials and energy inflation.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Exterior Solutions delivered organic growth of 6.7% over the year, with an acceleration to 10.1% in the second  half. This acceleration was driven by an improvement in all three businesses, but in particular, Exterior Products  in the U.S. This business benefited from additional weather-related demand resulting from repairs after the  hurricane in the U.S., and also of the very good construction and renovation activity in the U.S., overall.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Despite the raw material and energy cost inflation, we managed to achieve a wider margin of 8.4% for the year,  up from 7.9% in 2016.

texts.speaker: Guillaume Jean Philippe Texier
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: North America, we mentioned that already when we talk about High-Performance Materials and when we talked  about Construction Products. North America grew by 6% like-for-like over the year, with 9.8% growth in the  second half. In Construction, volume continued to trend well and was boosted by additional weather-related  demand in the second half. And I mentioned earlier that in the industry, we saw a good volume improvement  overall and particularly in Ceramics.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: We should have a good progression of other Western European countries, whether it is in the south, whether it is  in the north and in Germany. There is one country where there are some uncertainties, which is clearly the UK  given the very uncertain process of the Brexit, which is more creating uncertainties on the market than having a  direct impact because Saint-Gobain, we buy and what we produce in the UK is sold in the UK. So it's more – we  are not going to be affected strongly by what's going on between Europe and the UK, but the general climate in  the UK is uncertain at the moment.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The environment is getting a bit more supportive, but in some cases, we are clearly to take some risk in terms of  short term, in terms of our market share. We are ready to do that. In some cases, the industry is having the same  pressure on cost and also is acting. It is a clear focus for Saint-Gobain.

file: SGO - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 22February2019 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Sreedhar Natarajan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The cost inflation for the year from the raw materials and energy was around €600 million with most of the  inflation seen in Construction Products but also in HPM and Glass.

texts.speaker: Sreedhar Natarajan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: The inflation in energy and transportation was quite significant. Looking forward to 2019, we still not have the full  visibility at the beginning of the year on raw materials and energy inflation, but it is likely to stay at a high level  even though probably a bit lower than 2018.

texts.speaker: Benoit Bazin
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Innovation is also a strong pillar for growth. We are pleased to be for the eighth consecutive year within the top  100 most innovative companies globally. We keep pushing our group synergies on transversal R&D with our eight  cross-businesses R&D centers. We leverage the critical mass of our spend, €450 million last year, and we'll  continue to do that in 2019. We share joint labs, could be on thermal or acoustic labs that are spread in our major  regions. We leverage also common technologies, [indiscernible] (00:37:28) or polymer extrusion, for instance,  across all kinds of product lines and markets. We leverage material platforms such as ceramic, plaster, plastic, or  glass whether it's glass for [indiscernible] (00:37:41) insulation or automotive or building glass, and we'll continue  to invest on innovation.

texts.speaker: Pierre-André de Chalendar
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain SA
texts.text: Second, we want to enter new countries, and that we can do it either with greenfield or through acquisition. And  third, about the local leadership, and that's where we will have what I said in terms of country analysis, and we will  take more of that into account. So that means that in some countries, we will grow certain businesses which are  linked with the portfolio. For instance, one of our most important acquisition in 2018 was in distribution in Norway.  We are building a very strong position, with very good synergies.
