texts.text: But actually because of the special planning zone status we have at Slough, we were able to deliver a new  production pool for them in seven months. And so it's now actually being handed over, their equipment has  arrived and they're installing it, and we've gotten there now on a 15-year lease. And in France, we just completed  ahead of schedule the development of a 28,000 square meter distribution and cold storage facility at Gonesse,  which is outside just north of Paris for Casino, the retailer.

file: SGROL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 2August2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So before handing out over Justin to run through the financials, I just want to make a few opening remarks, if I  may, give you my take on the half year. Operationally, I think we've delivered good results despite what is clearly a  very challenging macroeconomic climate. And we're very pleased to have EPRA earnings up just over 5% for the  half year. Secondly, since the strategy announcement in November last year, we've made some very encouraging  at this stage in the process. We have taken some further write-down in terms of NAV, largely as a result of the  lower valuation of the Neckermann site and the other large non-strategic assets, which I think reflects the  relatively illiquid nature of such assets in today's difficult market environment. So more encouragingly, the core  portfolio has performed well, both operationally and in terms of capital value, and those core assets now represent  81% of our total portfolio compared with 69% when we announced the strategy. So overall, I'm pleased with the  progress we're making and I think we're well on track towards our goal of becoming a leading income-focused  REIT.

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: I'll come back to the strategic repositioning in a few minutes, but as it's a half-year results presentation, what I  want to start with is an operational update. So, I'm going to cover the full point first. Now, lot of data on this slide,  and I'm not going to go through all of it. But to highlight a few key points, I think we've made a solid first half or  had a solid first half in terms of leasing and lease renewals with 171 deals in aggregate signed during the period.  Our retention rate has been pretty good at 63% and nearly 70% in the core portfolio. We've held the vacancy rate  flat at 9.1%, just down from the position at the end of the first quarter. And we've managed to increase our like- for-like net rental income on the existing assets by 1%. The development program is continuing to build, and I'll  touch on that separately in a few minutes. And finally, we've achieved further cost savings and are making  operational improvements in several areas of the business such as in our management of cross-border customer  relationships, sustainability and property management systems, all of which will help to drive future efficiencies  and performance improvement going forward.

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: In the appendix of your packs, you'll find a slide on each of the remaining large non-strategic asset. So, I'll you a  bit more detail that I'm going show here. But briefly for those who aren't familiar with the assets, Pegasus Park is a  successful and well-established office park within close proximity of Brussels International Airport. It has a very  good customer list. It's well managed. And we're maintaining and indeed growing income with an improvement in  the vacancy rate from 23% at year-end to 16% at the end of June in a local market where there has been weak  demand and over-supply. Energy Park in Milan is a very attractive out-of-town office development site where  fully occupied. The second and third pre-let development schemes are under construction, and we believe there  will be demand to support further phases of development and refurbishment in the coming years. The MPM site is  a large 150,000-square-meter manufacturing facility in an excellent business location to the west of Munich. The  site is fully occupied and is leased to Krauss-Maffei, which produces machinery for the plastics industry, with  Siemens as an important sub-tenant for a big piece of the site. This asset offers a number of opportunities to our  value.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: Following those sales, we'll have £560 million of the original non-core assets left, of which £157 relates to Energy   Park near Milan and Pegasus Park in Brussels which are the remaining two of the so -called big six non-strategic  assets. The other non-core assets are broadly split 60/40 between Continental Europe and the UK, so 7 0/30 in  total terms.

texts.speaker: Justin Richard Read
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: As you can see the incremental benefit from developments completed during the first half is to an extent offset by  Alcatel moving within Energy Park from their existing office space and into their newly completed  accommodation.

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: We have I would say a knockout market position in London, especially in the key West London markets of Park  Royal and Heathrow. This is where we're seeing the most acute effects of the improving occupational environment  and the severe shortage of available space, particularly new space. Investor demand also I have to say is extremely  strong around there.

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: We're there. We're well underway with our first phase of spec development, 150,000 square feet, three units we're  building. We got delayed because of HS2 safeguarding the site. But now if you drive around there you'll see that  the first phase is well on the way. And two of the three units we're building are already under offer, about to  exchange I suspect very soon. And interest in the third, and almost certainly we'll be starting the second phase  there pretty soon.

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: Now just try to put Park Royal in context. We've talked before about the fact that London is losing its industrial  land. And we've mentioned a 46% reduction in industrial land in London over the last 25 years.

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: But what it's saying is that in just three of London's key areas of redevelopment over the next few years – being  White City, Nine Elms and Old Oak Common – there's going to be a loss of 358 hectares of industrial land, which  will force many businesses that are serving the capital to relocate. In old money that's 850 acres. That's a lot of  land.

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: The only thing I can say about these bar graphs is it won't be like this. But it's just an idea. We've got roughly a  similar amount coming through each year. And in fact given that we now have burned through a lot of our land in  some of the key markets we want to be in – we've got a good land bank, but there are one or two places where we'd  like to do more – I suspect you'll see us adding to this pipeline over the next couple of reporting periods.

file: SGROL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 28July2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-15.pdf
SGROL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 26July2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-16.pdf
SGROL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 25July2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-17.pdf
SGROL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 26July2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: So, let's now talk to the future opportunities. As we've previously explained, there are some powerful long-term  structural tailwinds behind occupier behaviors in our markets, most notably, urbanization and the technological  revolution. It's clear that more and more people are choosing to live in cities. This creates pressure to build more  homes often on land previously allocated for industrial uses, which is why we keep banging on about the loss and  the diminishing supply of such industrial land. But these growing urban population centers also push up demand  for goods and services, which require warehousing and large industrial space leading to strengthening demand  for such urban property. And this demand is being supercharged right now by e-commerce, which increasingly  needs space close into the final consumer for last-mile delivery. This can only intensify in the future as pressures  mount to use greener delivery methods in order to reduce vehicle emissions. These are some of the forces which  are driving up rents and land prices and which are leading developers and planning authorities to look at greater  intensification of use, in other words, multistory.

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: What all these trends have in common is the need for more efficient buildings, much greater power requirements  and digital connectivity, and substantial capital investments being made therefore usually by the occupiers inside  many of the buildings, which of course tends to make them much stickier long-term tenants. Suitable buildings  and development sites to provide these requirements are hard to find especially in urban locations and planning  processes are slow and difficult to navigate which inevitably puts a break on new supply coming through. These  demand drivers and the supply constraints in many markets will we believe continue to provide a structural  tailwind for good quality well-located assets and landholdings for some years to come.

The near- term bit represents 500,000 square meters, another 500,000 square meters, CapEx of about £250 million and  rents of £27 million. texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: Having gained planning consent, we've now committed approximately £130 million to buy the land and develop  the infrastructure needed to prepare the site for construction of the first buildings which potentially could be next  year. Now, this magnitude of upfront investment is much larger than you'll normally see with a typical SEGRO  development scheme, but it's not going to cause us any significant cash strain, because the timing and the  amount of the investment we're putting in broadly match the funds we expect to receive from the two West  London resi site disposals that we referred to earlier. And interestingly, having now bought the land and started  the infrastructure programme, we're already starting to attract early interest from potential occupiers.

file: SGROL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 16February2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: Delivering sustainable returns also isn't just about building or buying modern warehouses in strong locations; it's  also important to own very generic buildings that are highly flexible and appeal to a wide range of occupier types  which is something that we've been very focused on. And it's about future-proofing them in line with our  customers' present and likely requirements, and taking a responsible approach towards sustainability.

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: In 2017, we've continued to focus on reducing our carbon footprint, mainly by further investing in renewable  energy, in particular rooftop solar panels, including our largest-ever array in a single building where we installed  3.4 megawatts of capacity at Tesla's facility in Tilburg. We're also seeking to minimize carbon consumption  through the development process, firstly, by minimizing waste and reusing as much of an existing building as we  can, but also by using more sustainable materials as we did in Paris where we made the roof beams out of  laminated wood.

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: With customers often investing massively now in automated systems and tech inside the buildings, we've been  future-proofing our developments with power upgrades. So, For example, at our development site in East  Midlands, we spent £7 million extra in order to provide a lot more capacity than a traditional logistics we would  need because we're just sure that our customers are going to want it. All of our new developments as well now  have electrical charging points. So, you'll increasingly hear us talking a lot more about these things in the future.  And during 2018, we're going to be setting out new long-term targets for the business that we will be sharing with  you later in the year.

file: SGROL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 15February2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: On slide 18, I think it's important to note that delivering sustainable return is partly about building or buying  modern generic and flexible buildings in strong locations, but it's also about future proofing them in line with our  customer's present and likely requirements. All of our developments are built to vary exacting environmental  standards now and we've reduced our carbon footprint again during 2018. We now also have enough solar panels  to power 3,000 homes and we'll continue to install them where feasible and viable.

texts.speaker: David J. R. Sleath
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SEGRO Plc
texts.text: Having achieved our SEGRO 2020 target already, we've now set ambitious 2025 targets which will include  reducing our carbon footprint by 40%. We're also starting to look at our buildings on an embedded carbon basis  and thinking about ways that we can help make our warehouses energy efficient throughout their lives rather than  just focusing on the construction phase. And these include investing in systems and technology inside the building  to help our customers reduce their own energy usage and ongoing running costs.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SGS SA

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SGS SA

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-IT, SGS SA

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-IT, SGS SA
texts.text: Just out of interest, if you didn't know, because it took me some time, the green things on top of that LNG tanker,  does anybody have an idea about that? texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-IT, SGS SA
texts.text: Another one of our businesses that – somebody wrote and ENVI as always. Is that [indiscernible] (33:28)? As  usual, yes. ENVI is very close to the mining sector. They are very, very, very closely aligned. And that's why you see this business kind of a little  bit  slow.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-IT, SGS SA
texts.text: We've decided, as a group, to withdraw from the clean defense mechanism. It's a shame, because I think the  monitoring of carbon plants, carbon control is really a good thing. But, the reality is, it's becoming more and more  politically challenged. And as a consequence, ourselves and one of our key competitors have decided that – not  collectively, we just decided separately that we will no longer be in that business until such times as carbon really  regains its value, and for the moment, it hasn't quite regained its value.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-IT, SGS SA
texts.text: But we've entered into two – Thomas is very keen to develop testing within this sector and we've entered into two  new services, one of which is quite fascinating and we've discussed this for hours. The normal way to age a catalyst  in a car is to run a car for a long time. And y ou run it and, of course, it's polluting while you're doing the test.  Thomas has bought a business, which will take those catalysts and it will age them without pollution virtually. So  it's a very interesting tool for large manufacturers of cars. We've gone and spoken to big auto, particularly in the  U.S., and it seems as though that the uptake is going to be high.

file: SGSN - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 18July2016 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: Thirdly, our minerals and energy-related activities continue to operate in a volatile market during the first half of  2016 and this resulted in pressure on the volumes in Industrial, Minerals and the OGC business.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: The green part reflects the effect of the acquisitions made in 2014 and 2015, as this is on a 12-month rolling  basis. During that period, we acquired 20 great companies and made solid contribution to our goal of acquiring  CHF 1 billion of incremental revenue by 2020.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: The group continues to focus on small- to medium-sized companies to expand into new markets and to create a  more diverse service offering. The 2016 acquisitions strengthened the portfolio in Environmental, Health and  Safety, Industrial, Transportation and Agriculture, Food and Lifestyle.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: And as you can see, Environmental, Health and Safety; Transportation; Certification and Business  Enhancements; and Agriculture, Food and Life increased their relative weight as a result of their very strong  performance in the first half of this year.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: The business that is impacted the most is the Environmental, Health and Safety. In total, the Environmental,  Health and Safety increased year-on-year with 27%, of which 17% inorganic.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: The most important acquisition in the Environmental, Health and Safety portfolio is Accutest in North America. In  total, the organic revenue added to the portfolio amounts to CHF 30 million. But next to the inorganic growth, also,  the Environmental, Health and Safety achieved a solid organic growth and this across all the activities in the  portfolio and across the geographical network.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: Overall, the market is more stable than last year. However, the upstream activities are still heavily impacted and  this mainly in Australia, the Middle East and some of our European countries. We are fortunate that the majority of  the oil and gas activities relate to the downstream and the midstream activities.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: Last, but not least, Industrial. Industrial nearly reached a break-even position from an organic perspective, but  they strengthened the growth by acquiring five businesses in China and in North America. We experienced a  further organic decline in the industrial activities linked to the oil and gas sector, including construction services  and this is as a result of the lack of investment in infrastructure in the energy sector. This is particularly the case in  the U.S., and it's particularly the case in Australia.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: The highest organic growth has been achieved in the European region, and the European region performed well  in our Consumer & Retail Services; Environmental, Health and Safety; Transportation; and Agriculture, Food and  Life while Eastern Europe and the Middle East achieved a mid-single digit growth, and this is across the whole  portfolio with the exception of the OGC business.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: The green box reflects the impact on the adjusted operating income related to the 2015 and 2016 acquisitions.  The acquisitions are margin-dilutive as we invest it in two major underperforming assets, Accutest and Bateman,  which we believe have a significant upside going forward.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: We realized a similar strength for the Agriculture, Food and Life; Transportation; Environmental, Health and  Safety; and our Certification and Business Enhancement business.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: And Industrial, they suffered the most from a margin perspective. The decline in the margin is related to the  volume pressure in the energy-related activities, which is market-driven.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: The weakening of the margin in the Environmental, Health and Safety is mainly related to the Accutest  acquisition.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: CRS remains, by far, one of the biggest spenders and is also the business with the highest capital intensity  around 5.1%. Although similar in absolute amount, the CapEx intensity in OGC decreased to 3.8% this first half,  which is mainly the result of having actually no further investments in our Upstream activities.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: So to conclude, actually, on my presentation, I would like to leave you with some important financial highlights  that characterize our first half of the year. Against a challenging macroeconomic background characterized by a  strong Swiss franc, a continued slowdown of the Minerals business and a continued low oil price impacting our  energy-related activities in OGC and Industrial, my OC colleagues together with 88,000 colleagues around the  world delivered what I call solid results in the first half of 2016.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If I go to Minerals Services, a difficult market situation; however, we are still able to win and operate some new  projects. I mentioned earlier this year about the Richards Bay Coal Terminal project in South Africa. This is now  becoming one of our most well-established lab into a network in term of coal testing, and it is now fully operational  and will process over [ph] 60,000 (37:33) samples a year for the next seven years. And this is a significant project  for sustaining the growth of our activities in this regions. So, again, a pretty interesting project for us in South  Africa.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Oil, Gas & Chemicals, equally difficult market conditions especially in the Upstream activities as already  mentioned by Carla. However, like in Minerals, we have managed to secure new contract in this challenging  environment.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I go to Industrial Services, again, difficult market conditions. I'm not going to comment on that. In some areas of  operation, we can still be able to make some solid growth. I will take the example of Brazil. You know that the oil  and gas industry in Brazil is in a kind of turmoil and the construction sector is pretty down in this aspect, so we –  which has a big hit on our operations because we're quite focused on that.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Environment, Health and Safety. Accutest, being the largest event for EHS, which is more in the traditional field,  but the EHS team is also looking at quite a lot of new innovative solutions to capture new market. One example is  in partnership with our customer, Eni, who are currently looking at use of drones to do flare stack sampling to  determine the combustion product at the tip of the frac source. This is in relations to new flare gas emission  regulation in Europe and U.S.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Basically, taking a drone, going up on the flare, the tip of the flare and trying to capture the smoke because when  they burn this gas, there's a lot of nasty materials that goes into the air. There's a regulation we call [indiscernible]  (42:40) is going to pick up this vapor and going to test it in our labs. So, this is in collaboration with our customers  in Italy, Eni.

file: SGSN - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 15January2010 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Jan-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: This one that we spent time on before, I will just briefly touch on it, one of the reasons that the SGS  Group was able to post growth in the environment in 2009 but having certain geographies and  certain businesses under duress, I guess, is the best way to say it is the strength of the portfolio  itself and the diversity from a view point of geography. So in a large measure our performance is  somewhat of a mirror of economic activity by geography, which is flexed depending on our  participation by business and we can maybe spend time on that in terms [inaudible] businesses are  in the Q&A.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We introduced, during the year, market and crop research so you may have seen a few of the crop  research reports that we’ve done, published on Bloomberg. Bloomberg is actually a customer of  ours, where we actually send people into the field to determine what the crop is likely to be, what  the impact of pesticides, what the impact of pests is likely to be, and we publish those results.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: One of the good things because of the restructuring we’ve done some of the productivity initiatives  forgive me, it was [inaudible]. We’ve got sufficient installed capacity; we can take on much more  volume in our laboratories around the world without increasing our cost services. It’s a good sign for  the minerals businesses. Oil and gas had a slower growth here, I mean this is our biggest business  is Alim’s business the one that has really lost, it’s retained its existing businesses so it’s moved  distinctly upstream, well we’ll talk about that in a moment.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We see the oil and gas industry coming back to some level of revitalization, the refiners are getting  a little bit better margins now. Slow but sustained recovery in chemicals, and again because of  what we assume to be improved industrial consumption, but a very positive outlook for our  production through testing all of our upstream services. You would have seen that we’ve entered a  Join Cooperative Agreement with Halliburton in the last 24 hours, 48 hours, that’s a unique – we  offer a unique testing service and it’s a unique combination of services together with Halliburton.  Alim can you just give me two words on the Halliburton arrangement?       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 5 Alim Saidov, Executive Vice President, Oil, Gas and Chemicals and Environmental Services  Thank you, Chris, good afternoon.  Chris Kirk, Chief Executive Officer  [inaudible].  Alim Saidov, Executive Vice President, Oil, Gas and Chemicals and Environmental Services  I was waiting for this anyway because [inaudible], thank you very much. Yeah, we have entered  into the unique agreement between two companies, which are both acting in the same market. And  the uniqueness of the agreement that we have entered in is having few components, which I  wanted to highlight briefly. One of the unique – one of the features of this combination is the  independent service or independent data evaluation or data validation. The industries used to have  a fact that the developer of the field is generating the sample, is testing the sample, and is  validating the sample as well.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We have found both Halliburton Energy Services and SGS have identified an opportunity to come  into the market with totally independent validation of the data, which is really a core competence of  SGS. The second uniqueness of this – for the lack of a better word, unique feature of this joint  agreement or joint cooperation is that we are bringing the expertise and the market position and  excellence of Halliburton in the acquisition of the sample from the down-hole, bringing to the  surface with uncompromised quality and SGS capability to stand right at the well head and test  those samples with the accuracy and the precision of the fixed lab, fixed land based lab.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: This became possible only because of the fact that we are in the position we have developed in- house and we are in a position of the robust technology; we have basically reduced the size of the  land-based equipment eight times at least to bring it to the size of the bench top equipment and  being able to put it on board of the offshore certified cabin, put it on board of the platform and be  there to get the samples first hand, restore it, test it, and pump the data into the operator’s house in  order to make them able to deliver efficient decisions to save on the rig times and be able to save  at the end the owner’s money.  Chris Kirk, Chief Executive Officer  Excellent. Thank you.  Alim Saidov, Executive Vice President, Oil, Gas and Chemicals and Environmental Services  Thanks.  Chris Kirk, Chief Executive Officer  In terms of competitive advantage, the normal time for these samples to be drawn down well, flown  onshore, tested, and the results given is would be what?  Alim Saidov, Executive Vice President, Oil, Gas and Chemicals and Environmental Services  The normal terms are only on the samples shipment, which is months.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 6 Chris Kirk, Chief Executive Officer  Months?  Alim Saidov, Executive Vice President, Oil, Gas and Chemicals and Environmental Services  We have to bring it onshore and then from the onshore we have got to take it through the customs,  ship it to the fixed lab and the fixed up are not scattered all over the globe, they are in certain  locations.  Chris Kirk, Chief Executive Officer  And here it’s based?  Alim Saidov, Executive Vice President, Oil, Gas and Chemicals and Environmental Services  It’s based, yes.  Chris Kirk, Chief Executive Officer  Because the testing takes quite sometime. So a really significant competitive advantage which  means that the oil producers are able to make much clearer, faster decisions on almost on real- time. So it’s a big competitive advantage to our sector. So Life Science, the Life Science business  continues to improve, thanks there. We had relatively slow organic growth 3.3%, but it was a  difficult CRO, Clinical Research Organization, market. We had a weak performance in our late  phase business, a good performance in our early phase, first-in-man drug administration business.  The bio-analysis, the laboratory part of the business QC and bio-analysis performed well, and we  spent our year building capacity for this business, for the laboratory part of this business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 7 thought it was going to disappear. ISO 9000 was the singular standard that nobody really wanted  anymore, and it has like a number of our businesses reinvented itself. They’ve really focused this  year on customers needs in the environmental sustainability sectors.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The Renewable Energy business that we’ve been talking about now for a couple of years. I think  we’re now number one in wind energy. We have built together with the government in Jiangyin.  We’ve built the first and probably largest commercial wind turbine blades testing center in the world  in Jiangyin. This blade testing – sort of just to give you an idea of scale, it’s taller you all came in  the front door, I guess, it’s taller than this building, it’s wider than this building and it’s 45 meters  longer than this building. We have to be able to test single blades, which are 75 meters long and  we have to flex them and bend them. And so you imagine it’s a fairly significant business. On top of  that these guys, as well as Frankie Incorporation are involved in photovoltaics, solar cells and D- batteries. So we have a group thrust towards renewables.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Environment, here we had growth in both the operating income and the margin, the second such in  the general environment, for working in the environment was difficult. Our business really grew in  the emerging markets. Our Climate Change services were really the one – well it was a significant  contributor, was a beneficial part of our business during the year. As far as the balance of the year  – this New Year is concerned we always get a seasonal weakness, it’s very difficult to get solar  samples when the ground is frozen as I keep getting told, but we expect revenue margin to keep  growing and the acquisition of EKO-PROJEKT in Poland will allow us not on the good footprint in  Eastern Europe, but it will also allow us to pull samples out of Eastern Europe to our high  performance laboratories in Germany.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Like everybody else in the auto industry, our Automotive business declined this year especially for  those of you who perhaps don’t know we have two parts to this business, the statutory business,  which is testing vehicles for safety and for emissions and the other part, which is the commercial  business, the new car on and off lease. The Statutory business did very well; we grew the  business, we have a new contract just in Albania, we’ve expanded our business in terms of the  U.S. in Massachusetts and New Jersey, yeah – Massachusetts and New Jersey. So it was a good  year for that side. On the commercial side, the new car business it was very difficult for them, it was  a tough year for you, but you’ve seen what happened in the whole of the auto sector. Our Chairman  is trying to change that for everybody, so hopefully he’ll do it.

file: SGSN - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 17January2012 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jan-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Michael Belton
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Minerals Services, SGS SA
texts.text: We're building our energy minerals business, we're building our metallurgy business; we're building our  geochemistry business. And the second one is OceanaGold in New Zealand which we have been trying to get for, well since I was about  three years old, which is about 1,000 years ago. We've been trying to get it for a long, long time from one of our  competitors and finally we managed to get it, so that's really two very, very effective wins for the Minerals  business.

texts.speaker: Michael Belton
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Minerals Services, SGS SA
texts.text: The prospects for the balance of the – for 2012 are very, very good. I think this is going to be the year – I was  talking to Alim about it last night, I think this is going to be the year where you see first of all the OGC business do  very well indeed, but secondly the upstream sector of the oil and gas business do incredibly well. We've made the  investments, we've got the focused people, I think we're going to get that. You're agreeing with me? I knew you  would say that. No, really, it's very, very exciting.

texts.speaker: Michael Belton
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Minerals Services, SGS SA
texts.text: The statutory business in – particularly in Germany which was let's say deregulated, I can't think of a better word  than deregulated, deregulated has been very good for us, it's driven a lot of growth. Since it has become  deregulated, Non-Destructive Testing business in Europe is now well in excess of CHF200 million for us. So that's  a growing business, and we're pushing very hard there in the nuclear sector. Now some of you may say, well the  nuclear sector is just about to collapse because of what happened in Japan, but in reality, the existing plans will all  continue to need Non-Destructive Testing for probably as long as I'm alive, I bet on these things today

texts.speaker: Michael Belton
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Minerals Services, SGS SA
texts.text: We've brought a company called PfiNDE in the U.S. and I was just checking because I like to do these things, there  are 793,000 kilometers of pipeline in the U.S. There are 254,000 of those 793,000 are oil pipelines. The rest are  gas. You may remember the San Bruno disaster where the pipeline exploded and took out virtually a suburb of  California. This business, PfiNDE,  works for the pipeline owners when they dig up the pipeline, they X-ray the  pipeline. They do non-destructive testing on the pipeline, they determine where any potential fault is on the  pipeline and then another company comes and repairs it.

texts.speaker: Michael Belton
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Minerals Services, SGS SA
texts.text: So, if they start now, we did a silly sum, if they start now, they could be in business for about the next 15,000  years, but the problem is there are other competitors. Very, very good business, very exciting, something that we  really want to grow both in the U.S. itself and in Canada thereafter.  Environmental Services – where is Mike, you have met Mike. We always say Environmental Services is tough, it's  very competitive, we normally have some sort of minor complaint it, it had a great year, well done Mike, you and  the guys and girls, just a fantastic year. Good performances in Europe and Canada, good performances in the  emerging markets, added some new stuff like green buildings, added some new things and particularly in those  emerging markets did very, very well.

texts.speaker: Michael Belton
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Minerals Services, SGS SA
texts.text: Renewable, oil and gas sector and particularly leveraging, we try to cross-sell in SGS obviously, leverage off the  mining industry is a growth area for this business in the future. So watch this space. I think we're over the hump  now Mike, otherwise I'll come and haunt you. Now, really a great year.

texts.speaker: Michael Belton
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Minerals Services, SGS SA
texts.text: This business has really focused on statutory testing for safety and emissions of vehicles, and as a consequence of  that, we're trying to push in South America. In South Africa, we bought some recent statuary testing stations  there; I thought to check in your way. So, good growth prospects.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: A couple of big wins, Nui Phao – and you'll have to forgive my pronunciation – a large multi-element  geochemistry – sorry, a large multi-element mine in Northern Vietnam. We have a new geochemistry facility in  there, very complicated chemistry associated with the rocks, but something that is quite a spectacular win for us  Mike [Belton]. And the second one was Base Resources in Kenya.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: So as far as Oil and Gas, as you heard from Geraldine, this is the first business since we opened our shop door in  1878 that's generated CHF1 billion, in excess of CHF1 billion, so well done, Alim, just fantastic. Excellent,  excellent, excellent.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Continued slowdown, probably in the first half, again, related to that refining situation here in Europe, but more  growth in Upstream. One of the things that everyone is talking about is obviously shale oil and shale gas, coal-bed  methane and what we call unconventional energy sources. The solution we have for that – and I know some of you  will have seen it who came with us to Toronto – is a piece of equipment call GasPro.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: GasPro, we're marketing now very strongly and Carol's responsible for doing that. We expect to deploy 30 GasPro  units in the U.S. this year and effectively what they do is measure the calorific value of the gases that comes out of  the ground, measure the impurities, quantify the gas so that by the time it gets to the utility from the hole in the  ground, it is quantified and the utility can then pay for the gas according to the analysis of the unit online.  So there you go. There are a lot of synergies, in fact, with unconventional energies, with our Industrial business  and with our Environmental business. So it's something that we're really focusing very hard on in the U.S.,  particularly in the U.S. Maybe one day when Europe allows it to happen in Europe, too. I'm not holding my  breath.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Environmental Services. We normally complain bitterly about Environmental Services because it doesn't ever  seem to get where we want it to go. We've changed the focus; it's now on field work by taking samples, laboratory  analysis, and studies – environmental impact assessments, environmental baseline studies, et cetera. So  something that differentiates us from the mom and pop shops in every corner of the world.

texts.speaker: Geraldine Matchett
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: And Environmental is in a very similar situation. They're not quite at double-digits in the rest of the world, but the  European component is significant in its slightly negative performance or decline in organic revenue.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Oil and gas is heading up. The Life Science is correlated to the winding down of our Paris operations and the  Consumer held their margins. So they're the ones that I'd highlight here as we're going to run through anyway one  by one.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Oil and Gas and Chemicals. Well, Alim and his team had a stellar year. Specifically in Asia Pacific, as far as we're concerned, in the Middle East; some parts of  North America, we've just started to establish ourselves in parts of the shale fields in the U.S., so very, very good.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Environmental Services, again the European story. We had a significant slowdown in Europe, again because of the  difficulties, the recession in many countries. That's what we would expect from  this business as we go forward. We have a gap in North America. We're just not as big as we should be in North  America in the Environmental business, so we're really trying very hard to fill that gap and drive the organization  the Environmental organization faster in that part of the world.

texts.speaker: Carla De Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: And then last but not least, I would say the low oil price that definitely had an effect also. Fortunately, I would say,  the effect on the 2014 results was quite minimal because, yeah, I would say, our exposure to upstream activities  and the effect it had in 2014 is very – was very digestible, okay?

texts.speaker: Carla De Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: There was a slight impact, I would say, from the low oil price and the effect that it had on our upstream activities,  however, very minimal. To give you a bit of a feel, the difference in growth rate between the first half and th e  second half amounts to approximately 0.5%, so rather minimal.

texts.speaker: Carla De Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: When we look at Asia Pacific, it had also an fantastic second half, and a fantastic performance I would say  throughout 2014. And that is mainly driven by the solid performance in CTS and Industry. When we look at the  Americas, it's a combination of South America and North America. It's also a bit of an – and I would say mixed  messages here. First of all, North America was impacted by the slowdown of the minerals, and of course, the heat  was severe, I would say, for U.S., Canada, Mexico. In South America, we really experienced also a very good  growth in the other businesses, okay? So, overall, some compensating elements here, but good results.

texts.speaker: Carla De Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: When you look at the green box there, you actually see the impact of the acquisitions that we made in 2013 and  2014 as this is on a 12-month rolling basis. So, 2013-2014, we made in total, 22 acquisitions. 10 of them were  actually made in 2014, and as such, we acquired businesses in the Auto, in Environmental, in CTS, and Industrial,  and actually, in the three regions, so in the U.S. or in North America, in Asia, and in Europe.

texts.speaker: Carla De Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Now, in terms of giving you exact guidance, of course, given all these external factors that are impacting our  business, we can say that, okay, if we exclude the effect from the low oil price, because I think none of us know  exactly where the oil price will actually evolve to. And we'll exclude also actually the potential impact of the fishery  activities in Latin America, and Chris will touch on it.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Okay. Minerals. For the sake of it, we dwell on Minerals like there's no tomorrow. We kind of – the Minerals  business has done a fantastic job of maintaining a good margin in what is an incredibly difficult environment.  There isn't a mining company in the world that has got a smile in its face right at this moment. Not one. The coal  business is down. We're number one in coal in the U.S. or worldwide, we're the number one in coa l. The gold  business is down. Base metals are down. Prices of base metals, copper hit what the other day Mike? $6,000?

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But Australia is a significant part of that business. So, whilst it was good right at the very beginning, we've seen –  because of what's happened with the oil price, we've seen some slowing here. That's really what  I wanted – I  wanted to touch on those two parts of the business particularly because they're both large drivers of profit in  terms of actual profit. The margin, however, in Port and Terminal Operations, if you can imagine what this  business is, it's a question of putting qualified people on site at a cost-plus business, and the margins are relatively  low versus the rest of the SGS business. So, we expect margins around 11%, 12% top end.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: That's had an impact as you see here the margin in OGC has dropped a quite a lot. That has had an impact because  as that business has grown, then so the margin has taken a hit. Also the Upstream sector is a very, very profitable  part of our business. And as that has slowed, that's also hit the margin. So, the margin here – I don't think there's  anything systemic unless the oil price remains at less than $50 for the next five years, but the margin impact that  has happened in terms of Oil, Gas & Chemicals has also – and also has had an impact on the group, is effectively  because of those two things, Port and Terminal Operations and Upstream services being low, and we can talk  about that until the cows come home. I'm sure you all have a lot of questions.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Environment, Peter? Great. Y eah. Well done. It's also going to be one of our highest growth areas in 2015, too. We  did a lot of restructuring – this is the corollary to everything else. We tell you, Europe is a dog. We don't do  anything in Europe. Europe's flat. It's no fun to be in Europe, and one of our smallest businesses, I have to say;  has a fantastic year in Europe.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, GIS. I still don't quite understand how we had was – there he is, Roger. I still don't quite understand how  we got a 0.4% reduction. We'll figure that out at some stage, maybe tell you. It's not going to be that again, though,  is it?

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The interesting thing is finally, we've managed to pull this business not only out, not only operating  for  governments and institutions, but also into the private sector. The latest OMNIS – the latest tracking service that  we offer in Africa is for a private company. It's a very large petroleum producer, and they want to track where their  trucks go, and we track them using our OMNIS system. So they know that at any point, any day, anywhere where  their truck is. So, if he's discharging into another garage, they can find that out quite readily.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Lots of good things going on. Another one is our highest growth areas for 2015 if one looks at Roger's budget. So  really, it's quite clever. There's a couple of things, if you want – and I only say this because I don't fully understand  it myself, and he knows this. There's a thing here you see called SGS Renovo, that's all about waste and waste  management and the collection of fees for end-of-life of equipment.
