texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Our revenue growth of 6% is solid, considering the fact that the energy-related markets remained a challenge  during the year. Our organic growth amounts to 2.5%, mainly as a result of the strong growth in non-energy  related businesses. We improved the adjusted operating income by 2.4% despite continued pricing pressure in  the energy-related businesses. In an effort to offset the pressure on the margin, we identified unproductive assets  and unprofitable businesses, and we implemented a restructuring plan.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Secondly, our Minerals and Energy-related businesses continue to operate in a volatile market, resulting in  pressure on the volumes in our Industrial, Minerals and OGC business. And thirdly, we invested in our growth,  transformational and efficiency projects, in line with our strategic plan which will allow us to grow the top line and  improve the bottom line going forward.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: I will now break down our top line growth. Year-on-year, the company grew its revenue by 6%, of which 2.5%  organic and 3.5% inorganic. The orange part of the chart reflects the organic growth, which is driven by the  continued strong performance in the non-energy related businesses which is exceeding 6% for the full year.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: The non-energy related businesses amount to 53% of the revenue and the growth is more than offsetting the  decline in OGC, Industrial and Minerals. The dark-gray part of the chart reflects the effect of the acquisitions  made in 2015 and 2016, as this is on a 12-month rolling basis. The inorganic effects on the top line amounts to  CHF 203 million, representing a year-on-year growth of 3.5%. We acquired 21 companies, including two minority  stakes in promising technology companies as AgFlow and Transparency-One.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: This graph breaks down the importance of our line businesses from a top line perspective. And the change in the  relative rate versus last year is indicated as a percentage point change. All non-energy related businesses  increased or maintained their relative rates in the portfolio as a result of the very strong performance throughout  the year, and this at the expense of the energy-related businesses. This is in line with our strategy to reduce the  overall importance of the energy-related business in our portfolio. The relative rate of the energy-related business  declined by 2% year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: The first one is Environmental, Health and Safety. Environmental, Health and Safety achieved a stellar double- digit growth driven by strong inorganic growth through the six acquisitions contributing more than CHF 60 million  of revenue. Next, to the inorganic growth, Environmental, Health and Safety is also star performer in terms of  organic growth, which is driven by strong performance across the whole portfolio of activities.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Our strong growth of 6% was delivered by 92,269 colleagues around the world representing an increase of 4.9%  versus last year. As said before, the organic growth relates mainly to the non-energy related businesses, while a  big part of the restructuring is touching on the energy-related businesses. Under the new restructuring plan of  2016, we are planning to reduce the head count by another 600 FTEs.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Similar to the trends in the revenue, the relative rates of the non-energy-related business increased or remained  stable, while the relative rate of the energy-related business decreased by 2.5%. The only exception is  Transportation, whose profitability mainly in the second half of the year was impacted by start-up costs for new  contracts such as the Uganda statutory inspection contract as well as impacted by increased investments in  development of new testing activities.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Industrial suffers the most from a margin perspective, as it continues to face difficult market conditions in the  energy-related activities, which has partly been compensated by the restructuring benefits. And the weakening of  the margin in Environmental, Health and Safety is mainly related to the Accutest acquisition and the margin  pressure in the Australian market.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: During 2016, we spent CHF 288 million of CapEx, representing 4.8% of sales which is in line with last year. And  our primary CapEx investments were made in Consumer/Retail services and the Agriculture, Food and Life  business which are, together with Transportation, the most capital-intensive businesses in 2016.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: In Asia-Pacific, the biggest part of the CapEx is spent in China and Hong Kong – Hong Kong, given the strong  relative rate of the Consumer/Retail business and the solid growth in the region. And the relative importance of  the Americas decreased as a result of the decline in the capital-intensive energy-related businesses. You can see  from the chart, at the right bottom part, the CapEx is slightly below the depreciation due to the reduced  investments in the energy-related businesses.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Looking at the revenue growth for the second half, there are two key messages to highlight. Firstly, our organic  growth slowed down in the second half of 2016 and amounts to 1.6%, and this as a result of the further decline in  OGC and Industrial, as well as a slowdown of our organic growth in Environmental, Health and Safety and the  Consumer/Retail services.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: The growth slowdown in the Consumer/Retail services is only related to the decline in the wireless activities. And  the weaker growth in Environmental, Health and Safety is related to the increased competition in Australia and the  fact that we completed some major European projects.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: During the second half of 2016, three businesses realized double-digit growth: Environment, Health and Safety,  Transportation and GIS. While the Environmental, Health and Safety is mainly driven by inorganic growth  resulting from the Accutest and AXYS acquisitions, the Transportation and GIS business is mainly driven by  organic growth.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: So if I start with Agriculture, Food and Life, the performances for 2016 was really good and we expect that to  continue in 2017 with an improved trade activities. For your information, the activities in terms of trade was slow in  the second half of the year also because of bad weather [indiscernible] (47:55) of crops that has reduced the  number of transactions. So this should be improving in 2017.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Oil, Gas and Chemicals market condition remains challenging, and we are cautious moving into 2017. There are  trade activities expected to improve in the second half of the year, while the upstream explorations will remain  under pressure throughout the year. However, we have won a new contract with our North American team in the  petrochemical sector, and our refocus on the upstream service on the production and market will support our  growth momentum.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: And also, on the upstream, the exploration is weak. The maintenance of projects onsite, there are still  opportunities. I mentioned to you in the first half result that we had won contract in New Zealand in these  production activities and also won some additional contracts in the Middle East in the second half of the year. So,  this will help us to keep some kind of growth momentum in the oil and gas sectors.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: To give an example, we have bundled a suite of services to support the textile and footwear industry in the  coming months towards a zero discharge of hazardous chemicals. This suite of services include testing chemical  risk assessment on nine chemical database, product testing and wastewater screening and with close analysis.  This is a quite fast-growing market, as the textile and footwear industry is pushing really for a better use of  chemical in their product as this is a haphazard for the consumer as well as for the environmental. So, there's  quite a large portion in the industry to resolve these issues and the volume of activity should increase over time.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Certification and Business Enhancement. The deadline for the transition to the new ISO 2015 standard will  support the growth momentum of CBE in 2017. In fact, if you look at the current conversion rate from the old  standard to the new standard, it is still rather low. If you look at it, we're still one year close to deadline of 2017 –  2018, so we should expect an acceleration of the request for those audit being transitioned into the new standard  in 2017 as the deadline is in 2018.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Industrial services, difficult market condition expected in 2017, especially related to the oil and gas sectors. We  see limited volume in the CapEx-related activities, and we see increasing competitions and pricing pressure in the  OpEx maintenance-related activities due to excess capacities. Although the picture is slightly different, we have  more pressure in North America, Australia and South America and we're actually seeing some growth in China,  Middle East and Africa.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: If I move to Environmental, Health and Safety, growth momentum will carry on in 2017, driven by increasing  laboratory testing associated to persistent organic pollutant, toxin and all the hazardous substances. So regarding  Environmental, it is becoming stricter and we are seeing market demand increasing with our customers.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: So, this is our last business line. And if I go into the outlook 2017. Overall, we expect the market conditions to  remain challenging for the energy-related business lines, especially Industrial, because of the market condition of  oil and gas, CapEx and some of the infrastructure and construction sector. And then, to a lesser extent, OGC, we  see the market conditions to improve, as I mentioned.

file: SGSN1 - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 17July2012 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now in terms of acquisitive growth, the green part, as I mentioned earlier, the 24 green bits. I'm not going to run  through all of them. I'll just highlight the minerals one, it's the one acquisition which is CIMM in Chile, but as you  can see, it has quite an impact on the division. And the two other divisions that are picking up the most of the  acquisitive growth are industrial and NV.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Agricultural, the Agricultural business, our Seed and Crop services, which is field trials, feed trials, crop trials,  precision farming, that business grew by as you see there, nearly 14% of which 13.3% was organic, which is really  quite spectacular. Our Seed and Crop services grew by 40% amongst that, and that's really an exceptionally high

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: But the balance of Seed and Crop services will also be very, very good. We're expecting to grow in Asia, in Africa  and in South America. And to that point, we just acquired a company in Brazil called Gravena. Gravena is  probably the market leader in Brazil for Crop services. Just out of interest, one thing I did miss in terms of the  trade services, this growth was achieved while we had one of our biggest agricultural countries in the world under  water. As you remember, at the beginning of the year, Thailand had significant floods. Thailand is one of our  major agricultural businesses. And effectively, all exports stopped. It just stopped for several months, while the  place dried out. But it should bode well for the second half of the year [indiscernible] (21:02).

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Our geochemistry businesses, we have insufficient capacity right now. So we haven't got the capacity to be able to  analyze the samples that our customers give, actually, a little bit ashamed of that. But when you think that we now  analyze in our geochemistry business in excess of 10 million samples a year, you will be able to understand that  ramping up is not the easiest thing in the world. We opened new laboratories this year in Liberia, in Turkey, which  is now becoming a major exploration market. And we set up neutral services in northern Queensland, which has  been the major exporting coal area for Australia.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Oil, Gas and Chemicals, we had very, very strong revenue growth in upstream oil and gas, which is really good.  This is an area that Aleem and his team have been investing in for the last two and a half years. And that's been  very, very good. Our oil condition monitoring, which is checking the metallic components in used oil has been  very, very good, as has been our port – sorry, plant and terminal operations.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: The plant and terminal operations where effectively we've moved products around inside plants and terminals is  driven by most of our customers wishing to outsource their work. So in so doing, they give us the responsibility for  moving products in their plants and their terminals, and we take it from there, again, continues to grow  significantly. The margin was impacted. As you know, we had some refinery closures here in Europe. We also had  some refinery closures in the Caribbean. And of course, because the upstream sector is brand new to the SGS  Group, we had some initial establishment costs that have in fact impacted the margin.  All of our existing businesses will continue to grow. And Aleem? We have a training session and his answer is –  everybody just says or if I say, they won't grow, will they not? But some of the new innovative services – Aleem  and his team have developed this thing called the attic. Is it a big concern? I think it's about a poet sitting on top of  an attic, somewhere writing poetry. But in fact, this [indiscernible] (24:11) Advanced Technology Innovations  Center, which we've established in Houston. These are a group of gentlemen, very highly qualified engineers who  are allowed to play with toys and money, and they invent things. They invented the [indiscernible] (24:26), the  [ph] mini gor (24:27) that we talked about historically. And the most recent innovation they have come up with is  the thing called [ph] Gaspro. (24:34) You'd be crazy if – or if you don't read the newspapers, unconventional gas –  shale gas, coal bed methane, all of these new forms of gas are obviously of significance. I mean the U.S. economy is  converting 70% of their coal-fired power station to gas, and they're getting the gas from these unconventional  sources. The [ph] Gaspro (24:56) attaches to the source as it comes out of the ground. It analyzes the quantity and  analyzes the quality of the gas as it comes out of the ground before it goes into the utility.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: SSC. These days are tough to me. Great market share gains, double digit growth across most of the platform really  a very, very, very good start. We've invested in a number of new things, sustainability services, health and safety,  supply chain monitoring and ensuring compliances across supply chains. So all in all very, very good. Expecting  solid growth. Training is becoming an important part of our business. It's something that we've done historically  in each of the businesses across SGS and now we've got a systematic focus on training within SSC and that should  be an area for growth in the future.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Approved Mike Belton who I guess is here. Where's Mike? Is he here? Mike [indiscernible] (31:59). I'm not. It's a  name day. Mike [ph] funny (32:04). Mike normally gets beaten because of the environmental services. Every time  he comes in he looks at me, no, no, no. This is the best ever performance in our environmental services in its  history for the first half of any year. So well done, Mike. You need to congratulate the entire team.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: The new studies offices. As you see, we set them in Paris, Shanghai, Durban, Doha, Kuwait. Did we do all that in  six months? Excellent. So really very good. Key acquisitions, Environ and Analytical Services – Analytical  Perspective. Environ, the largest occupational health and safety and environment testing house in Brazil, which  gives us a really strong foothold in Brazil and Analytical Perspective, together with our existing high specification,  high end testing business in the U.S. makes us the number one test house for very, very [indiscernible] (34:02)  very, very environmentally unstable and – we shouldn't have them around [indiscernible] (34:15) in the U.S.  Again, this business is very much second half loaded. We're going to have a good year, Mike? Yeah, I didn't wait  for an answer because I know you are going to have a good year. So that's very good. Thank you.  Auto. Two parts to the business, the statutory business and the commercial business. This is Thomas' business.  The statutory business is doing very, very well. The commercial business is suffering a little bit in North America.  We continue to grow. We've added new businesses in South America – South Africa, sorry, and in particularly  Ivory Coast. Good prospects here. We don't expect to have the commercial business growing too rapidly in the  U.S. because it's just not unlikely to grow rapidly in the U.S. But in terms of the statutory business, we are looking  at some continued growth. One good thing, if you remember probably about a year ago, we kept on and on and on  about the fact that we came out of Ireland. The Road Transport Authority – the Road Safety Authority in Ireland  has just given this contract for the next two years worth about CHF20 million. So that's a very good replacement  for what we lost a couple of years ago, a year and a half ago. Thanks, [indiscernible] (35:36).

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: And we have started the very first ever scanning contract for logs. SGS has been involved in forestry, particularly  in GIS, for a number of years, but normally it's a question of putting a tag on a log and monitoring that log  through the chain of custody. Well, that's so well and good if you can see the log on the back of the truck because  you know where it is. But if you're intent on smuggling, why not put it inside a container so you can't see it and  then say that the goods are – a container full of water or whatever.

texts.speaker: Christopher Kirk
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Fred and his team have designed and built scanners or utilizing scanners to ensure that all those containers as  they are being transacted through a truck towards the port gets scanned, so we can see inside the container  without having to stop them and open them and ensure that what's inside is not, in fact, logs and, therefore, if they  are not logs the country was going to miss out on the revenue they generate from exporting wood. So all in all, very  good.

file: SGSN1 - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 17July2015 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: During the first half, we made seven acquisitions to grow our footprint in Australia, Brazil, France and the UK.  Four of those acquisitions are in the environmental sectors, two of them in the automotive sectors and one in the  consumer testing sector. At the end of June, the SGS Group has over 85,000 employees, 1,650 laboratories and  are well spread across the three regions reflecting our global activities.

texts.speaker: Carla De Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The second external factor relates to the continued slowdown in the minerals business. We will talk about this  later in the presentation. And the third factor relates to the historical low oil price and the volatility in the oil  market and as a result, we experienced pressures in two industries, OGC and industrial.

texts.speaker: Carla De Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Last but not least, Industrial. Industrial declined organically at 3.3% and this is clearly the impact of what is  happening in the oil industry and the effect it has on the capital expenditures, but as well as the spillover effect in  the OpEx expenditure. So, we experienced price pressure, but next to that we also experienced a delay in  maintenance-related projects. From a geographical perspective however, this is mainly related to our activities in  America, in Canada, in Brazil and in Australia. So, there are a number of other markets and Frankie will point that  out, where we actually experienced good growth.

texts.speaker: Carla De Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: First of all, let's just tackle the Minerals. You see the gray part in the circle and the dark gray part actually  represents the write-off of assets. So a major part of the Minerals restructuring relate to asset write-off. And this is  particularly relating to the write-off of assets of the oil sands pilot plant in Canada, as well as the coal ops in  Australia. Part of it is also related to the termination of head count and that is actually also mainly related to the  areas that I pointed out.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Okay. Thank you, Carla. Carla has given you quite a lot of information on our H1. I'm going to focus on giving a  few highlighted project that we'll be undergoing in H2. So let me start with Agricultural Services. H1 has been very  good. We have a lot of project that we're planning to launch in H2. So, let me just speak one of them. It is our new  water management solutions. Globally, 70% of the water taken from rivers and groundwater is used for  irrigations. The efficiency of water used in irrigated agriculture is less than 40%. So, our new water management  solutions is a set of services that helps the agricultural professionals to optimize the use of water.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Basically, it's cutting water consumptions. Water is not as cheap as resources anymore. I mean, the future will  become more and more expensive. So, our customers has a lot of interest to understanding how we can help them  to optimize their water consumptions. So, this is something we'll be launching into the second half in selected  countries and we'll be making a more global deployment in 2016.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Oil, Gas & Chemicals. As Carla already mentioned, the price fluctuations of the oil market has created several  different factors. On one side our upstream's businesses have been slow, because our exploration is so long. But on  the other side, our trade-related activities has been very strong. And this is the bigger part of our portfolio. This  combination will be carrying on into second half. We have new contract that we won in the high profitable fuel  integrity programs sectors in Africa and in Middle East. We are looking at an improvement of the margin into  second half for oil and gas.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Industrial Services. Carla already mentioned the weaknesses that we have in the oil and gas related activities.  However in the other side of our portfolio, in the construction sectors, we've been having pretty solid growth,  especially with the construction supervision, and the Toluca Rail construction project in Mexico is a good example  of that.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Environmental Services. A lot of project is listed on this slide, but I will mention one that is not on the slide, is our  collaboration with the International Maritime Organization, IMO. We were involved in the development of  sampling equipment and testing procedures to control if living organism are still alive or are dead in ballast water.  This is a very important procedure to avoid invasive species to be released by this shot of ballast water into sea  water in another area. So, is really to protect the local sea species to avoid being contaminated by other invasive  species. These are the important procedures on the market at the initial stage is worth around CHK 250 million.  So, an important procedure will be implemented over the next few years.

file: SGSN1 - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 17July2017 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: On the other hand, market conditions remained difficult in the oil and gas sector, affecting our industrial activities.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: One of the key takeaways, as we look at the graph that breaks down the importance of each of our nine  businesses from a revenue perspective, is that we continue to deliver on our strategy to grow the overall  importance of the non-energy related business in our portfolio.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Environment, Health and Safety revenue declined of minus 1.4%, which is mainly driven by the benefit of a  commercial contract that was completed in the first half of last year. Moreover, we made a decision to restructure  the Accutest business and exit high-revenue, low-margin contracts. We achieved strong growth in traditional  Testing and Health and Safety services in Europe, Asia and Australia. And in addition to the solid growth in the  lab services, we believe that the foundations are in place for our Environment, Health and Safety businesses to  continue to grow moving forward.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: The first half of 2017 represents the first time that OGC has also experienced a positive growth since 2014. The  growth is mainly driven by contracts secured in the petrochemical industry, while trade-related activities were  declining. After realignment of our asset utilization and sales strategy, we managed to grow our upstream  activities at mid-single digit. Additionally, we achieved strong growth in sample management, oil condition  monitoring and stock measurement. We expect the growth in the second half comparable to the one of the first  half.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Last but not least, the only business that was – which was in decline in the first half was Industrial, and the reason  is twofold. First, the ongoing depression in oil and gas capital expenditure kept the volume and price under  pressure, impacting the services – the industrial services, mainly in mature European and North American  markets.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: China's very strong growth is across the portfolio and particularly driven by the recovery of the Electronics and  Electrics. In addition, Taiwan's double-digit revenue growth was fueled by Consumer/Retail services, Certification  and Business Enhancement, and Environment, Health and Safety.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Acquisitions were the main drivers behind the Americas' positive growth, related mainly to the acquisitions we  made in Industrial, Transportation, AFL and Environment, Health and Safety that have been made last year.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: The growth in the head count in Europe, Africa, Middle East is mainly driven by the organic growth in Agriculture,  Food and Life, and Environment, Health and Safety, and the staffing of new Industrial and Mineral projects in  Russia. Headcount growth in the Americas outpaced revenue growth as we are staffing a new major Industrial  project in Peru and supporting the strong growth of Agriculture, Food and Life in South America. In addition, the  Americas region is impacted by the decline of Industrial activities in North America and Brazil and the decline of  Minerals in Chile.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: The relatively low flow-through of the incremental revenue can be explained by the four developments I outlined  before. First, the bad debt provision of certain GIS receivables; second, the volume and price pressure mainly in  the Industrial business; third, the fact that we benefited from the completion of a large non-repeating Environment,  Health and Safety contract in 2016; and last, but not least, the flow-through was impacted by the continued  investment we made in our growth, transformational and efficiency projects in line with our strategic plan. These  are the main reasons why the restructuring savings, as well as the uptick of the margin realized by the majority of  the businesses is neutralized on an adjusted operating income level.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Our adjusted operating income portfolio further communicates the increase in importance in our focus business  lines. The non-energy related businesses represented 69% of the total SGS income. This is an increase of  approximately 3 percentage points versus the same period a year ago.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Agriculture, Food and Life, the second contributor, increased its relative rate by 1.3 percentage points.  Interestingly, Transportation overtook Minerals to become the number four most important contributor. Industrial,  GIS and Environment, Health and Safety, decreased their relative rates as a result of the developments outlined  before.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Let me now give you some insight into the development of the adjusted operating income margin by individual  business. In the middle of the slide, you can see the decrease of Environment, Health and Safety operating  margin by 250 basis points versus a year ago. I reemphasize that this results from last year's positive one-off  effect related to the completion of a contract which had a significant impact on both the top and the bottom line, as  well as the ongoing restructuring of Accutest.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: The decrease in relative weight in Asia Pacific results from the large investments in CRS and Industrial in 2016.  As you can see from the chart at the right bottom part, the CapEx is slightly below the depreciation due to the  reduced level of investment in energy-related business and the CapEx efficiency realized by our procurement  team.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Oil, Gas and Chemicals, the market condition remain challenging, but with the current extension of our agreement  on production cut, we expect the market to be rather stable. However, we're not predicting an increase of our  trade activities in the second half. Our Plant and Terminal Operations and our non-trade related activities by oil  condition monitoring and fuel retail services will continue to see solid growth in the second half. As Carla already  mentioned, for Oil and Gas – Oil, Gas and Chemical, we're expecting similar growth in the second semester than  in the first.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Certification and Business Enhancement. Well, again, the deadline for the transition to the new standard, the ISO  2015 standard, is in the second half of 2018 and we are seeing an increase in demand from our customers for  training and performing transition audit. We expect this momentum to continue in the second half of 2017 and  also in the first half of 2018.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Environment, Health and Safety, EHS. In fact, the market drivers have not changed and demand for traditional  testing, inspection industrial hygiene and field audit have been steady. Demand for testing of dioxin, asbestos,  persistent organic pollutant and other hazardous substance has actually increased in the first half and should  continue to develop in the second semester. Also, one important point is the current stability of the mineral market  should lead to increasing testing volume for our EHS laboratories. So, for EHS, we're looking at a stronger second  half with a better organic growth and improved margin.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: And to conclude, Governments and Institutions. In the second semester, we are planning to start three new e- waste monitoring programs in Africa and also the implementation of the third scanner in Cameroon. Those  programs will have to accelerate growth, and we are looking at a stronger second half in both top line and bottom  line.

file: SGSN1 - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 18July2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Carla de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Finance Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Three clarifying points regarding this uptake of the margin: First, the market recovery in minerals and the  efficiency gains in GIS; CBE; and Environmental, Health and Safety positively impacted our margins. Secondly,  we delivered a margin uptake resulting from the initiative program supporting the 2020 plan. And thirdly, we  benefited from the recovery of the bad debt provision we accounted for in the first half 2017 in GIS, and which  was of course related to a number of GIS contracts.

texts.speaker: Carla de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Finance Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Most activities in the mineral portfolio experienced double-digit growth. Trade saw robust demand in Energy  Minerals, and the Geochem saw a strong increase in sample volumes, while the Metallurgy business achieved a  big performance, particularly in Canada and Australia with a higher demand for pilot plant testing.

texts.speaker: Carla de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Finance Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Environmental, Health and Safety realized a strong growth of 6.1%, mainly driven by double-digit growth in the  Health and Safety services, and this was complemented by mid-single-digit growth in field and monitoring  services and a key contributor to the Environmental, Health and Safety growth is regulation enforcement around  the world, accentuated by the new push in developing geographies.

texts.speaker: Carla de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Finance Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Acquisitions made in Industrial, Agriculture, Food and Life, and CRS helped the Americas region to achieve a  growth of 7.2%, of which 5.9% organic. And the growth was positive in both sub-regions. South America  outperformed North America, driven by a double-digit growth in Minerals and Industrial. And the organic growth in  North America is mainly driven by a double-digit growth in Agriculture, Food and Life, OGC, and Environmental,  Health and Safety. The total inorganic growth relates to the North America region, which remains a focus area for  future acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Carla de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Finance Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Environmental, Health and Safety margin improvement by 210 basis points resulted from improved performance  in the U.S. as well as increased volume in health and safety work in Europe and ongoing operational efficiency in  Asia Pacific and Europe. Our Minerals colleagues were successful in accelerating the top line growth, while  increasing the margins by 150 basis points. The team continued to work successfully on improved lab utilization  and lab operational efficiencies. And in addition, they continued to add a number of profitable contracts to the  portfolio.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Oil, Gas and Chemicals. Some market condition expected in the second half. Strong volume already secured for  our PTO activities, especially in the U.S. Trade volume is expected to remain stable but with competitive pressure  on price. Further efficiency measure will be taken to limit the impact. Positive momentum on our Upstream  activities, particularly in the Africa and Middle East where we secured new contracts that will be put in place and  running in the second half. On the overall is the pickup of Upstream and the pickup of PTO, and in other parts of  portfolio expect the second half margins to be back in line with the second half of 2017.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Environmental, Health, and Safety. While market conditions still remains similar to H1 with increased weightage  driving volume in our laboratories. The expansion of our services in marine, industrial hygiene, and hospitality  sectors will continue to drive growth in our field activities and also move more volume into our laboratories. We  expect both revenue and margins to improve in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Growth in GIS have been strong despite the delay in some of the implementation of the renewable e-waste  project in Africa and this new project in terms of e-waste should be coming online on the quarter four of this year,  which will support further the growth of the division here.

texts.text: So let me describe a little bit how we thought. Strategically it was a great year for agriculture. texts.profession: Operator

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Second, two out of the three energy-related businesses performed strongly. texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Operating income increased by 9.6% to CHF 894 million. Our operating income was strong despite the  impairments of the industrial goodwill in North America amounting to CHF 30 million. This impairment of goodwill  is the direct result of challenging market conditions in the oil and gas services, with volume reduction and price  pressure impacting our results in this specific region.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: The Energy Minerals and the Trade Services representing more than 50% of the portfolio achieved double-digit  growth with exceptional performance in Indonesia, South Africa, Colombia and Russia. The team continues on its  successful journey of operating onsite lab activities. And the Geochem activities generated a nice sample volume  particularly in Australia and Africa.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Freight activities remained weak in Europe, Africa and North America and this was partially offset by growth in  Asia and the Middle East. Second, with the decision to restructure the Accutest business and exit high-revenue low- margin contracts.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: The underlying business is performing very well driven by continued Environmental, Health and Safety regulation  enforcements around the world with a new push in developing geographies and the development of innovative  packages aimed at hospitality, retail, and real estate sector.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: I'll give an example. The acquisitions we made in the construction, material testing, and asset monitoring for the  manufacturing industry. The reason for the organic decline is twofold. First, the depression in the oil and gas  capital expenditure led to a volume decline and pressure on price, impacting the energy activities mainly in North  America. Second, there was reduced public investment in infrastructure and construction markets in South  America, impacting both volume and price.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Acquisitions made in Industrial, Transportation, Agriculture, Food and Life and Environmental, Health and Safety  helped the Americas region to achieve a mid-single-digit growth. The organic growth was positive in both sub- regions. However, North America outperformed the southern part. And this was driven by strong performance in  the Minerals, the Transportation and Agriculture, Food and Life.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: [ph] EASA (00:23:49) the second largest contributor increased its relative weight by 0.6 percentage points fueled  by the solid growth and increase in margins, and combined, both CRS and AFL delivered now more than 40% of  the adjusted operating income. Obviously, industrial GIS, environmental health and safety and  OGC decreased their relative weight because of the areas that I outlined before.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Let's take a look at the adjusted operating income margin by business comparing 2017 with 2016. texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Another initiative which is focused on driving margin improvement across all businesses is our procurement  initiative. And I'm pleased to announce that 2017 are in line with the targets, the split of the savings by nature is  also in line with the projections that I gave you during the Investor Day. CapEx savings amounting to 29% have a  positive impact on our CapEx intensity, as I will explain also later during the presentation.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Consequently, the declining CapEx intensity is applicable to the majority of the business portfolio with the  exception of GIS and Transportation. We made incremental CapEx investments in these two businesses based  on the new contracts that we entered into 2016 and 2017.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: And before I conclude my presentation, I would like to share an overview of the company's performance during  the second half of 2017. There are four points to highlight to you. We realized a solid growth of 5.8%, 0.6  percentage points higher than the second half of last year, and 0.9 percentage points higher than the first half of  2017, in which we realized 4.9%. The organic uptick in the second half accelerated, and this is mainly due to the  nice growth in the Minerals, OGC, CBE, Industrial, and Environmental Health and Safety business.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Let's take a look at the revenue growth by business. During the second half of 2017, five businesses accelerated  their growth compared to the first half. These are Minerals, OGC, and Environment, Health and Safety, which are  the most noticeable ones. Four businesses realized high-single-digit growth. These were CRS, Transportation,  Agriculture, Food and Life, and Minerals, and this growth was mainly driven by improved organic growth and  additionally supported by inorganic. The growth slowdown in Transportation is mainly related to the completion of  the commercial inspection contract in North America.

texts.speaker: Carla D. F. de Geyseleer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SGS SA
texts.text: Looking at the adjusted operating income by business, I'm happy to share that eight of our nine businesses  improved their margin in the second half of the year, of which GIS, Environmental, Health and Safety, CBE and  Minerals the most noticeable ones. This is the net effect of the benefit resulting from the improvements of the  underlying profitability in these businesses, the restructuring benefits and the measures resulting from the [ph]  Dow Jones (00:40:22) review, as well as the procurement savings and continuous profit improvements that we  focus on.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Moving to Minerals, the Minerals overall market conditions are expected to be stable in 2018. Our strategic focus  on onsite laboratories is generating the expected returns with more projects moving into production phase. We  have recently secured an onsite lab for smelter facilities in the Middle East, first with SGS Group, and this should  open new opportunities for us. Overall performances should be in line with 2017.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Oil, Gas and Chemicals, I expect market conditions to be also stable in 2018. Plant and Terminal Operations in  the petrochemical field and upstream in the production area are expected to have a good year with a strong  pipeline – project pipeline already secured. On the other hand, market condition for our trade activities will remain  challenging with uncertain volume and competitive pressure. The remaining of the portfolio should perform in line  with 2017. Portfolio mix and efficiency measure including moving back office operations to the shared service  center will have to create margin improvement.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Certification and Business Enhancement, growth will still be driven by the transition to the new ISO 2015  standards with the deadline in Q3 2018. Conversion rate will be the critical formalities in ensuring growth  momentum in the transition with ISO certification.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Industrial services, market conditions are not expected to improve in oil and gas sectors in 2018, and the  infrastructure and construction sector in South America will remain challenging. The [indiscernible] (00:46:13)  should see some stability especially in testing, supply chain, and other services to the manufacturing and power  and utilities sector. The efficiency measures put in place together with the portfolio diversification should provide a  strong improvement on margins in 2018.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Environment, Health and Safety, our market position to remain similar to 2017 with increasing laboratory testing  associated to organic pollutant, toxin, and other hazardous substances. The regulatory environment has become  stricter and market demand are increasing accordingly. We expect EHS to grow in the mid-single digit and with an  improving margin driven by the portfolio mix, efficiency measurement taken in 2017, and an improvement of result  in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: And finally, for Government and Institutional Services, GIS, GIS is expected to be back to a stronger year in 2018.  The scanning contract in Cameroon using our remote image analysis solution is in full operation and delay in e- waste renewable contract in Ivory Coast, Togo, Kenya are to come online in 2018.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: Just a reminder, those renewable contracts are forcing the Basel Convention monitoring to transboundary  movement of hazardous good. [indiscernible] (00:48:20) but they're eco levy collected for recycling of the  consumer electronics is channeled to the country of import allowing governments to implement a safe and sound  recycling policy. Furthermore, we anticipate another strong year for our TransitNet services and the remaining of  the portfolio is expected to perform well and our margin to strengthen across the portfolio.

texts.speaker: Frankie Ng
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SGS SA
texts.text: On that let me just go through the guidance for 2018. I expect good market condition for most of our business line,  except for industrial where uncertainty related to the oil and gas and [indiscernible] (00:48:59), industrial  construction market remains.

file: SHCL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 30July2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: We announced earlier this month that terms have been established with TfL for a participatory joint venture over  the Earls Court 1 & 2 landholding, which Gary will discuss later. The Conditional Land Sale Agreement with  Hammersmith & Fulham was signed in January and terms were settled with Network Rail regarding air rights  over the West London Line in March.

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: Just to show that graphically, here's a heat map of the estate. Our objective's simple. It's to turn everything here to  red. Y ou can see that a good amount is actually still yellow and orange and that's rents of less than £200 and £450  per square foot, respectively. So there is plenty of scope for growth in the coming years.

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: A number of you attended the presentation we gave at Kings Court, planning applications have now been made.  It's a 90,000 square foot development with an increased store area of 20,000 square foot over the existing and it  will provide eight purpose-built retail units, two food and beverage units and a courtyard linking Floral and King  Street and this change in pedestrian flow will significantly improve rents on both streets but particularly Floral  Street where Zone A rents are as low as £130 a square foot at the moment.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: The air rights agreement for development over West London line to enable the construction of the Lost River  Park, a core component of Sir Terry's Masterplan was concluded with Network Rail in March and a series of small  acquisitions have also taken place to enhance the development opportunity available to us.

file: SHCL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 1August2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: Pre-enabling works have started on-site and demolition is now due to commence in 2015. We've also achieved two  key detailed planning consents. Earls Court Village which covers the majority of Earls Court 1 and 2 area will  create 2.4 million square feet and over 1,200 new homes all primarily within Kensington and Chelsea. And the  Empress State Building itself which now has consent for change of views to residential and will bring a further  610,000 square feet into the Masterplan area. We've also made a series of further acquisitions totaling £18 million  which relates to smaller properties around the periphery of the site which will allow us to consider inten sification  opportunities in due course.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: Finally, in respect to the CLSA land at Hammersmith & Fulham, we'll continue to work with the council  throughout the year to fulfill the requirements of the contract, enabling the construction of replacement homes for  the residents of West Ken and Gibbs Green estates. I'll now come on to what I think really is the undoubted  highlight of our year so far at Earls Court which has been the positive launch of Lillie Square. Lillie Square is an  exciting development immediately adjacent to the Earls Court scheme. Covering over 1 million square feet it will  deliver modern garden square living in over 800 units.

file: SHCL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 29July2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Managing Director & Chief Investment Officer
texts.text: As you've seen, construction is underway, and we're on track now to deliver the first units for occupation in 2016.  Our plans are now being finalized to begin sales of Phase 2, which will commence shortly.

file: SHCL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 26July2016 445 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Our demolition at Earls Court is going well. The main superstructure's now dismantled. Later this year, we'll  progress to the next phase of demolition and enablement by the railway lines to be completed by 2018. And  during this period, we aim to progress a planning argument supporting an increase in the development density at  Earls Court.

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, following a request from the GLA for submissions in respect of the forthcoming London Plan review, we  suggested that Earls Court could accommodate an increase in new homes from the existing zoning of a minimum  7,500 to a minimum of 10,000 new homes of various tenures. Our partnership with TfL is working well. We're  pleased to secure government backing in the form of £150 million infrastructure loan from the Homes and  Communities Agency to the Earls Court partnership.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Investment Officer
texts.text: So, it's this picture really that I'm most pleased about. On the ground, we've been making great progress. At Earls  Court, we've been busy with the complex establishment of former exhibition centers as we prepare the site for  future development. As you can see from this image, we've made significant headwork across the site with the  demolition of EC2 now complete and the demolition of EC1 onset for completion later this year. This will take us  to ground level across the full sites by the end of the year.

file: SHCL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 21July2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: We've had some very positive discussions with the London planning authorities on progressing the enhanced  Masterplan over the next 6 to 12 months. And just to remind you, our aim is to increase the provision of new  homes from 7,500 to a minimum of 10,000 new homes, and that's increasing the developable area by about 30%,  whilst enhancing, we hope, the efficiency and costs of development.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Managing Director & Chief Investment Officer, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: In the meantime, we will complete the land enablement works in preparation for future development, and at Lillie  Square, complete the delivery of Phase 1 units and continue to progress with Phase 2. I'll now hand you back to  Ian.

file: SHCL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 25July2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director, Chief Investment Officer & Managing Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: Now, in addition to our land interest, Capco has implemented an option to acquire approximately 22 acres of land,  including the West Kensington and Gibbs Green estates under the Conditional Land Sale Agreement, which we  know as the CLSA with Hammersmith & Fulham. To date, Capco has paid £75 million of the £105 million cash  consideration payable to the council. Under this option, Capco must also provide replacement housing for the 760  homes currently located on the Estates. Now, basement works on Block D at Lillie Square have been completed  to facilitate this first phase of the replacement housing for The Estates residents. [ph] We're already in train  (24:58).

file: SHCL - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 2March2011 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Chief Investment Officer, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: Going forward into 2011, we have just over 65% of license fees already contracted and therefore, once again, a  good visibility on this year's projected income levels. Utilization rates continue to run at approximately 40% and  this provides us with the opportunity to implement our decant strategy to Olympia, in the long-term using the  venue far more efficiently. And to this end, consultation with our key clients regarding the transition are  progressing well and Nigel and his team are negotiating these contracts [ph] free (28:48) for us.

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: I say, well, I think a good first year for us. We are now well-positioned to benefit from the further improvements  that are anticipated in the London property market. I think the outlook for the market does remain positive with  strong investor and occupational demand for well-located prime Central London. Our profit is whether they'll be  office, retail or residential and although, the macro-environment is uncertain, we feel that the conditions do exist  for further rental and value growth in our portfolio.

file: SHCL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 29February2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Soumen Das
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: EBITDA of the venues business fell 2% to £18.5 million. The difference in the net rent going up and the EBITDA  falling is £0.9 million of rent reporting in the active segment relating to proxy restructure and the pension scheme  closure. Just to flag this proxy restructure involves separating the eco-property interest from the exhibitions  businesses, and we undertook that in November. That in fact contributed £1.2 million to EBITDA during 2011.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: And I think most of the pictures that we have around Covent Garden really do offer very specific opportunities.  And I think that's highlighted on the heat map that we show on the right hand side, where we've taken average  ITZA rents and plotted it onto specific streets. And you'll see that James Street, which is the red bar, which is an  average of £650 but actually now has spot rents of over £700, is significantly more than Floral Street, which is a  short stroll away. And it's sort of underscores the importance of the acquisition that we made last year at the Kings  Court lot which is at the end of Floral Street and straddles into King Street. And there's a really tremendous  opportunity to create value through linkages and drive rents on those streets towards the averages, towards prime,  which is close to £700 a square foot.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: Secondly, we got to secure our a planning consent for our residentially-led mixed-use development on the Earls  Court and West [indiscernible] (23:33) area in line with Terry's master plan as you've all seen. But strategic we  must of course assemble the land and future development rights over the land currently controlled by  Hammersmith & Fulham and Transport for London and finalize our lease extension with TfL and the landfill  agreement with Hammersmith themselves. Clearly, we need to consider our options thereafter in releasing the  maximum value possible from the wider site and more immediately from the Seagrave Road project through  participating in the residential scheme that we now have consent for.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: With Hammersmith & Fulham, we entered into a 12 month [ph] ex-receivership (30:29) arrangement on 28 July,  which provided both sides with the opportunity and time to finalize a conditional landfill agreement for the  Hammersmith land. This process has proceeded well and we now look with interest at the state consultation  process, which is due to conclude next month.

file: SHCL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 28February2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: So I'm confident that this is a competitive location and that we're going to be able secure good growth in the  coming years. And just to sort of try and graphically illustrate, this is a Zone A rental heat map transposed across  the estate holdings. And this is how it looked three years ago.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: On the land assembly side of the equation, we've completed our joint venture with KFI in respect to Seagrave  Road, and just after year end, completed the Conditional Land Sale Agreement with Hammersmith & Fulham. The  completion of the CLSA is a landmark transaction as it provides us with the ability to include the 22 acres of the  West Kensington and Gibbs Green estates into the project, and provides the replacement of the 760 homes that  are currently on the site. The ability to provide a fully joined up regeneration project with the counsel benefiting  not only those who will be new to the area, but also local residents and tenants, as again, becomes our reality.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: Likewise, the Network Rail arrangements, the air rights over the West London line are nearing completion and we  are currently finalizing the detailed terms whereby Network Rail will be compensated over the last of the project  as lands gone down for development purposes.

file: SHCL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 25February2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: Now, this rental heat map shows the position of Zone A rents at December. The strategy is to turn lower rent  yellow and orange locations into red. Y ou'll note that over the last few years we've been focusing acquisitions  which are edged black in the lower rental yellow areas.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: We have signed the Section 106 Agreement. This is an important landmark as it further cements our links and  commitments with the local boroughs and the community. We've also now submitted detailed planning  applications for Earls Court Village, which progresses the design from the outline planning consent stage and  starts to really demonstrate the quality of place that Earls Court can provide. At Empress State, we have submitted  a planning application for change of use to residential to allow us more optionality over the asset in the future.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: No further applications for judicial review have been made in regard to this agreement or in relation to the  planning progress we have made. But as we have always highlighted, we cannot rule out further legal challenges of  this nature. The option on CLSA land has been exercised and we are working with Ha mmersmith & Fulham to  incorporate these 22 acres into the Masterplan. The proposed first phase of the CLSA land holdings comprising  some six acres will be facilitated by the delivery of the first phase replacement homes at Seagrave Road and we're  currently refining these designs to meet the needs of the residents that will be re-housed in fantastic new homes  meeting the mayor's new design standards of space and quality.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: At Empress State, we now own 100% of the building giving us full control here. Located at the crossroads of the  Masterplan area, we're now considering the most appropriate way to incorporate the building within our vision for  the site going forward. Finally, we have also completed the air rights transaction with Network Rail over the West  London Line to incorporate the Lost River Park.

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: As Gary's outlined, Earls Court is one of the most significant pieces of urban re-imagination in Europe. With  initial planning and land assembly milestones largely complete, our focus turns to value creation through the  animation and enhancement of the Masterplan and the careful implementation of further planning and  development activity including the forthcoming launch of Lillie Square.

file: SHCL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 26February2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Soumen Das
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Looking at Kings Court and Carriage Hall in a little more detail, as you can see, the work is well underway. We  demolished the existing office building on Floral Street at the end of last year. A construction contract is placed  and work is underway to complete the scheme in the first half of 2017. It will deliver over 100,000 square feet of  space, of which 20,000 square feet is new. Floral Street will be transformed with improved pedestrian flows and  prime retail frontages and entrances into the Kings Court Courtyard on the south side and the flagship retail store  and Carriage Hall on the north.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director
texts.text: Now, Earls Court, as I think we all know, is a GLA opportunity area, so that makes it a key strategic scheme for  London. And it's arguably the most attractive and the most deliverable. Its formally consented status, the limit in  land ownerships involved, the high transportation accessibility rating we have, the PTAL rating we always go on  about, make it a unique scheme in a very, very prime location.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director
texts.text: Lillie Square is where we hold our joint venture with the Kwok Family Interests, the 50/50, where the  development is being undertaken at the moment on the old former car park. And then the West Kensington and  Gibbs Green estates, which we exercised an option over in 2013 and where the first phase of replacement housing  is currently being considered.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director
texts.text: And finally, there's the Lillie Bridge Depot, which is currently 100% owned by TfL and who have already reported  in a feasibility study which was published late last year that moving the depot that currently sits there is viable and  something that they'd want to look at doing.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Executive Director & Investment Director
texts.text: Now, we've also consolidated our interests in Earls Court 1 and 2 and created the new investment vehicle the Earls  Court Partnership which we are leading and we're delighted to have TfL as our strategic partner. And in taking  forward the partnership, and following the successful completion of enabling works on the site and the closure of  the Earls Court Exhibition Centres, demolition is now well underway, and by the summer of this year, we'll start to  see blue sky where the buildings were before.

file: SHCL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 24February2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: You know that we target the best brands. We provide and manage the environment in which they can trade. We're  aiming to drive sustainable sales densities and encourage the highest margins, which in turn supports stronger  rent. So, from Chanel to Frenchie, Covent Garden now has some of the best brands anywhere in the world and  certainly in London. In 2015, we agreed 74 leasing transactions. That's an average of 11% over the December 2014  ERV. ERV increased by 12% like-for-like to £86 million. So, we're well on track to achieve the ERV target of £100  million by December 2017.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Managing Director & Chief Investment Officer
texts.text: Next is our Lillie Square development, which is currently under constructions and is held in a 50:50 joint venture  with the Kwok Family Interests. The CLSA land shown in green, which includes the West Kensington and Gibbs  Green housing estates, was acquired from the London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham and is where the first  phases of replacement housing are currently being considered. And finally, the Lillie Bridge Depot located  adjacent to the A4 Cromwell Road and owned by TfL, who have previously published their report highlighting the  feasibility of moving the depot to facilitate the final phases of the opportunity area in the future.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Managing Director & Chief Investment Officer
texts.text: This is my favorite slide. As you can see from this image, we've made tremendous progress over the last 12 months  with the demolition of Earls Court 1 and Earls Court 2. Earls Court 2 is now gone, and the demolition of Earls  Court 1 is on track for completion in the autumn of this year. Following this, we're looking to extend demolition  through to the basement levels, further de-risking our land holdings as we go. This is currently the largest and  most complex demolition site in London. And to give you an idea of scale, there are over 300,000 man-hours  worked and approximately 75,000 tons of materials removed into 2015 alone.

file: SHCL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 22February2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: At Earls Court, we completed the first phase of demolition of the former Exhibition Centres and commenced  below-ground works, which will complete by the end of this year. As part of our strategy to enhance Earls Court,  during the year, we made representations to the GLA's London Plan to increase the density of the Earls Court  Opportunity Area. We suggested an increase in new homes from the existing zoning of a minimum of 7,500 to a  minimum of 10,000 new homes across various tenures.

texts.speaker: Ian David Hawksworth
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: Our construction of Lillie Square progressed well, and the first apartments were handed over to residents in  December, and we are absolutely delighted with the quality of the product and the environment. Sales of Phase 2  continued with 59 apartments now reserved or exchanged, and preparations are being made for the next release  in the coming months and plans for construction of Phase 2 are progressing.

texts.speaker: Gary J. Yardley
texts.profession: Managing Director & Chief Investment Officer, Capital & Counties Properties Plc
texts.text: Thirdly, land enablement, we've completed the above-ground demolition of the former Exhibition Centres and  commenced basement works, which will create a developable site capable of phased implementation over time.

While the environment for large-scale residential development remains challenging, Earls  Court planning consent, high-quality location and connectivity underpin its desirability and prospects for future  realization.
