SIE - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 26January2010 245 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jan-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let me name a few. In Industry, the Mobility division won a major contract of up to €580 million to  supply regional trains for the 2014 Winter Olympic Games in Sochi. In Energy, we saw continued  activity in renewables, with contracts for six large onshore wind farms in North America worth €600  million. In addition, Power Transmission won a €128 million contract to provide the grid connection  for the largest offshore wind farm London Array.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Within the Industry sector we have transformed the low-voltage business, transferred the low- voltage business from Industry Automation into the Building Technologies division and integrated  all low-voltage activities into a new business unit called Low-Voltage Distribution. With this move,  we strengthen our building automation focus and we create synergies in both technologies and  market access.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Looking at the order side of the businesses, we don’t believe that we’ve seen the end of volatility  and uncertainty. In our longer-cycle businesses such as Industry solutions, Building Technologies  and in parts of Drive Technologies, order activity has continued to slow. With the exception of  renewables, we also see a similar slowdown in the energy infrastructure markets, which typically  lack macroeconomic cycles. Market contraction leads to price pressure in the energy markets.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In general, margins in the first quarter came in at improved levels within all divisions. Clear  standouts were OSRAM with improved capacity utilization which was fueled by strong LED demand  and the lighting season – LED accounts now for 14% of our Lighting business; Imaging & IT,  supported by a favorable product mix and positive currency effects; and Fossil Power Generation,  combining strong project execution with excellent development of the service business.

file: SIE - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 25January2011 245 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jan-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: A major growth driver was an excellent flow of large orders in Fossil Power Generation and also in  Mobility. Let me mention just a few examples of important order wins.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And second, Fossil won the Bugok 3 turnkey project in South Korea, which will be the ninth  combined cycle power plant built by Siemens in this country during the last 10 years. And even  more important, this is the first H-Frame deployment in the Asian market and has proven its  success now on three continents.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Revenue growth of 6% year-on-year and on a comparable basis was well balanced between the  sectors. It was paced by strong double-digit growth in our short cycle Industrial businesses and  backed by our robust backlog, for example, in Renewable Energy.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The good news is that we see also growth in the developed countries where our innovation-driven  solutions for energy efficiency, infrastructure, modernization and industrial productivity help to build  on our leading positions.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And finally, we increased our research and development investment by more than €100 million,  compared to the fiscal quarter of [audio skip] 2010 to maintain the innovation lead in area such as  Wind, LEDs, or smart grids.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Advance payments and billings in excess so far held up well against our concerns of a – of a  change in customer payment behavior. Mobility and Fossil Power Generation still achieved strong  cash conversion rates. Due to the steep revenue increase in our short cycle businesses, we saw a  corresponding growth in working capital.

file: SIE - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 24January2012 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Jan-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: From a strategic perspective, we made in the first quarter significant progress in further developing partnerships  to better address important growth markets in the emerging markets. First, we will adequately access the large  wind market in China through joint ventures with our long-standing partner Shanghai Electric, and second, we  will extend our global gas turbine manufacturing network with a set-up of a majority joint venture with Power  Machines in Russia.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let's have a look at some key developments in each of the sectors. The first sector, Energy. Orders in Energy  declined substantially, by 11%, mainly due to a much lower number of large solution projects in Fossil and  Transmission. Orders in Fossil were driven by product business, in particular, gas turbines, and had to compare  with very strong Solution orders from the prior year. The overall decline was only partially offset by a jump in  orders in Renewable Energy due to a series of onshore wind orders in the Americas. The book-to-bill ratio was  again at a very healthy 1.16.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: First quarter revenue rose by 8% on the conversion of Energy's strong order backlog, with rapid growth in Asia,  mixed picture. Fossil continued its excellent project execution in the Solution business and also achieved a higher  earnings contribution from the Service business. Profitability was also supported by a net positive effect of €36  million from the divestment gain of the sale of Power Machines' stake, more than offsetting further project  charges from the Olkiluoto project.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: On the downside, Renewable Energy posted a loss of €48 million. Main reasons are higher expenses for research  and development, marketing and selling associated with the expansion in a highly competitive wind market.  Furthermore, we have seen a less favorable revenue mix and increased pricing pressure, which led, all in all, to a  loss in the Wind business. We expect the Wind business to continuously grow revenue and return to profitability  in the coming quarters.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Power Transmission reported a significant loss of €145 million in Q1. The division was also impacted by a less  favorable revenue mix, which weighted on the profitability. But most importantly, a major factor was €203 million  in project charges mainly related to grid connections to the offshore wind farms in Germany. The reasons are  project delays resulting from a complex regulatory environment and cost increases for the marine platforms. We  are in intense discussions with the involved parties due to resolve the challenges, but expect continuing challenges  in coming quarters.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Profitability in Industry Automation declined 240 basis points, due to a less favorable business mix and increased  selling expenses and footprint expansion to leverage growth opportunities in emerging markets. For example, IA  will set up a new electronic factory in Chengdu by 2013 to meet the rapidly growing demand in Asia.  Drive Technologies' margin of 9% disappointed, despite strong motion control profitability. Main reasons are  higher OpEx on relatively low volume and increased price pressure in the wind energy-related Drive business. We  expect a return to double-digit profitability in the coming quarters.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: The Power Grid Solutions & Products business saw a temporarily weakening profitability in low and medium  voltage, due to a less favorable business mix. In the Smart Grid division, we will continue to invest to grow our  Smart Grid portfolio and footprint. Building Technologies achieved a solid profit margin of 6.2% on 3% revenue  growth. Markets for energy efficiency showed decent growth rates.

file: SIE - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 23January2013 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Jan-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Thank you, Mariel. Welcome and good morning to everybody. Thank you for joining us to discuss the first quarter  results of 2013. In a nutshell, our start into the new fiscal year and towards our Siemens 2014 target was solid in a  still difficult macroeconomic environment. Despite the clear stabilization in the financial markets in the euro  zone, the recession in a number of countries continues and leads to an overall subdued investment climate. The  U.S. economy has stabilized, yet the ongoing discussions about raising the debt ceiling and pending decisions  about budget cuts result in a certain reluctance to invest.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: As discussed during Q4, a key lever of Siemens 2014 is focusing our portfolio, where we made good progress.  during the Capital Market Day Industry at the Hannover Fair in April, we will give you an in-depth view on our  well established capabilities in industrial software design and simulation capabilities. Second, we signed the  acquisition of Invensys Rail to further strengthen our Rail Automation business. And third, we have started the  divestment process for the recently announced disposal of our Water Treatment, Postal Automation and Baggage  Handling businesses. All of them are currently still reported in continued operations.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: For the solar activities which are currently held in discontinued operations, we had to record a further loss of €150  million this quarter, mainly due to €115 million pre-tax impairment charges mostly as a result of ongoing  challenges related to a major project in Spain.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let's have a look at some key developments in each of the sectors. First sector, Energy. The book-to-bill ratio in  Energy is back at a very healthy 1.13. Orders were down 3% mainly due to a sharp decline in the U.S. Wind  business and more selective order intake in the Transmission business.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Fossil order intake was up significantly by 16% due to a number of large solution and service orders such as  Lausward in Germany. Some of the project awards were earlier than expected, so we will see some normalization  during the next quarter.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: First quarter revenue was stable on the conversion from Energy's strong order backlog with significant growth in  the Americas and driven by an increase of 23% in the Wind business completing all wind farms ahead of the old  BTC expiration. We are currently evaluating details and impact of the newly announced BTC scheme in U.S. based  on the new triggering event, start of construction until end of 2013. We are confident that we will see renewed  interest from our customers in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: On profitability, Energy delivered a mixed picture. Fossil delivered a healthy 19.6% profit margin, continuing its  excellent project execution in the solution business and a seasonally strong earnings contribution from the service  business. Wind Power achieved 4.6% profitability through higher revenues and positive effect in connection with  the settlement of a claim related to a major wind farm project in Europe. On the downside, Oil & Gas faced a sharp  decline in profitability due in part to €46 million in charges, resulting from further Iran-related legal and  regulatory matters. The impact of these sanctions may also affect the division's operational margin going forward.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Power Transmission is executing on its restructuring program called transform to win and works through the  Greek connection projects to offshore wind farms. Profitability was held back by €28 million in project charges  related to these projects and the conversion of lower-margin projects from the order backlog. As indicated in  December, during the Capital Markets Day, the energy sector expects transformation charges for the full year in  the magnitude of €300 million.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Profitability in Industry Automation declined moderately by 40 basis points due to lower volume, while Drive  Technologies lost 90 basis points, impacted by weaker demand for higher-margin short-cycle products and lower  contributions from its renewable offerings. With the closing of the latest IA acquisition in the integration of LMS  in the software business of Industry Automation has started, industry expects around €400 million further  transformation charges as part of Siemens 2014.

file: SIE - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 28January2014 130 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jan-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: As far as the operational business is concerned, we are making satisfactory progress toward the productivity and  cost reduction goals we set for 2014. But we prioritize – and in cases of doubt, securing business process and  project implementation is given priority over cost reduction.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: A look at the key figures from the first quarter shows that we can, all in all, be satisfied with developments even if  the new charges related to offshore wind connection projects in the German North Sea at the Energy Transmission  Division serve as a bitter reminder that these legacy projects, as we call them, that is to say, the North Sea  projects, our train projects, and the power plant Olkiluoto in Finland will likely to be latent material charges for  years to come. I repeat, for years to come.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We won several large contracts, especially for rail projects and wind farms, which will take several years to be fully  executed. 41% of our orders came from emerging markets. This demonstrates that alongside industrialized  nations, our business is no longer conceivable without these growth markets.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: The energy sector saw a moderate increase in new orders and a moderate decrease in revenue. Energy contributed  the most to total sectors per the profit, with earnings of €506 million.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We are very pleased to note that in the energy sector, we had really good order intake. We've been capable of  landing its largest onshore installation order-to-date for five wind farms and an order for two combined-cycle  power plant blocks in Pennsylvania, which we will equip with our H class turbines.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We have also been chosen as a supplier for the country's first large offshore wind power plant. Orders like these, in  a land where competition often limits opportunity, are of course especially gratifying, and we are proud to have  won these contracts.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We are a respected partner in the energy transition made in the U.S.A., which distinguishes itself from less well - executed approaches in other countries by its hitherto discipline d approach.

file: SIE - Q1 2014 Earnings Call Analyst Call 28January2014 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jan-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Now let's have a look at some key developments in each of the sectors. First, the book-to-bill ratio in Energy was at  a very healthy 1.25x. Orders were up 3%, entirely due to a doubling of orders in the Wind business, where we, for  example, recorded the largest onshore order ever from MidAmerican Energy for five projects in Iowa totaling to  448 wind turbines.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Beginning of fiscal 2014, the new combined Power Generation division started, a merger fro m the former Fossil  and Oil & Gas divisions. Orders were 12% lower across all regions due to less volume from large orders.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Overall, the market environment for energy remains highly competitive and should not change any time soon.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: First quarter revenues were down 4% with growth in Wind and lower revenues in Power Generation driven by less  solution and gas turbine business. On profitability, Energy  showed an improved performance year-over-year.  Power Generation achieved an excellent 16.6% profit margin continuing its stringent project execution and a  seasonally strong earnings contribution from the service business. As indicated before, we expect th e division to  have a normalized margin of around 15% going forward. Wind Power reached 4.8% profitability, supported by  higher revenues also from the expanding service business and adversely affected by a seasonally lower share of the  offshore revenues.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: On the downside, Transmission faced continuous project execution challenges, resulting in charges of €67  million,  mostly related to the North Sea offshore grid connection. Above and beyond obviously on the offshore grid  connection, we do continue to have our focus on Transmission because what we see in the underlying  performance is not what we like. So, actions going forward are imminent.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Power Transmission is executing on its restructuring program, Transform the Wind, and continues to work  through projects with very low margin throughout the rest of fiscal 2014. So we do not expect a significant  improvement in 2014. This will be reserved for 2015 and beyond. And as you will remember, we have said that on  various occasions that Transmission needs time in order to fix the business as we move along.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: In January 2014, we closed the divestment of our Water Technologies business to AEA Investors for a purchase  price of about €600 million. We do not expect significant effects on income from discontinued operations from  this transaction.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Last but not least, the sector Infrastructure & Cities showed a clear improvement driven by its transformation  efforts, which the sector reported on during its recent Capital Market Day.

file: SIE - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 27January2015 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jan-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Mariel von Schumann
texts.profession: Head of Governance & Markets, Siemens AG
texts.text: Since I'm sure that the potential impact of oil prices is on everybody's mind, let me upfront give you our take on  the oil price development. We do not see the current sharp oil price decline as a structural demand issue but  rather output-driven. We, therefore, believe there will be a recovery in the midterm. The fundamentals of the  markets in terms of demand are intact, at least in our view.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Schumann
texts.profession: Head of Governance & Markets, Siemens AG
texts.text: However, in the short term, we expect a significant CapEx decline and some project delays associated with the oil  price development. These developments are already visible in the tendering activity of our oil-and-gas-related  businesses, such as Power and Gas and Process Industries and Drive.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Schumann
texts.profession: Head of Governance & Markets, Siemens AG
texts.text: OpEx and service-related spending, however, is rather stable and should not be materially affected. Negative  knock-on effects on infrastructure spending in oil-exporting countries can't (sic) [can] (3:33), however, not be  ruled out and depend on the duration of the low price level and their financial reserves.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Schumann
texts.profession: Head of Governance & Markets, Siemens AG
texts.text: On the positive side, we expect to benefit from higher investment in infrastructure due to lower energy bills, in  particular emerging economies such as India and increased demand from automotive and downstream customers.  In this environment, we focus on our area of influence and continue to implement diligently our Vision 2020  Strategy.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Schumann
texts.profession: Head of Governance & Markets, Siemens AG
texts.text: Revenue was up by 3% on growth across all divisions, except for Power and Gas, due to lower orders in previous  quarters as flagged before. Main growth drivers were in Mobility and Wind Power as well as a strong, sh ort-cycled  business in the Digital Factory Division.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Schumann
texts.profession: Head of Governance & Markets, Siemens AG
texts.text: Above and beyond the operational business, we have made material progress in strengthening our portfolio. The  acquisition of the aero-derivative gas turbines and compressors from Rolls-Royce closed early December and the  integration is on track. After the positive shareholder vote in last November, there's also clear progress in the  approval process of Dresser-Rand, which we expect to close latest in summer 2015, probably earlier.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Schumann
texts.profession: Head of Governance & Markets, Siemens AG
texts.text: Now, let's look at some key developments in the division. As previously flagged, Power and Gas need to step up its  efforts for productivity and cost reduction. They have initiated a comprehensive program, which addresses the key  challenges of the division. The trend towards distribution generation is continuing and we will benefit from this  long-term development with our enhanced portfolio spectrum.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Schumann
texts.profession: Head of Governance & Markets, Siemens AG
texts.text: At 5.4% profit margin, Wind Power is within the target range, supported by increasing revenues and rising  contribution from the service business. The division works diligently on the ramp-up of new offshore products and  further industrialization of the product, while closely monitoring operational improvements. [ph] The limitation  (10:10) of technical difficulties with main bearings and plates progresses as planned.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Schumann
texts.profession: Head of Governance & Markets, Siemens AG
texts.text: In Energy Management, there is strong order flow across all businesses, with a clear focus on margin quality and  risk profile. The largest order was an HVDC project in Canada, it's called Nelson River, very successfully  integrated the experience from previous projects. Low voltage continued to improve its margin performance and  delivered strong growth, particularly in the United States, as well as in China.

file: SIE - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 26January2016 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jan-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: And with that, I'd like to hand over now to Joe.  Joe Kaeser  President & Chief Executive Officer  Thank you, Sabine. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us to discuss the first quarter results of  our fiscal 2016. Before I move to the financials, let me briefly recap yesterday's announcement to acquire CD- adapco, a privately-held software company. The transaction is another important step to optimize our business  along the entire electrification, automation and digitalization value chain, or what we call the EAD systems.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: So, what does CD-adapco do? CFD or computational fluid dynamics, simulate fluid flow, heat transfer, and fluid  structure interaction of liquids and gases with, for example, the wing of an airplane or a car. Through t his  integrational offering, we can combine the automated feedback of simulation and testing of multi-domains into  product design and optimize the entire system, for example, regarding weight or costs. Time -to-market can be  reduced up to 35% and obviously, ladies and gentlemen, time is of the essence.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Now, let's look at some key developments in the divisions. Key focus of the Power and Gas division is on  relentlessly improving its cost position, focus on the opportunities in the market, and drive innovation going  forward. Our new divisional sales setup in the regions has already been gaining traction, and we have seen  substantial order growth. In total, we did record 20 orders, firm orders for large gas turbines and, the other, 12 H- class turbines.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Wind Power recorded a major offshore order for the Galloper wind park in the UK including a long-term service  agreement totaling €1 billion order intake. Revenues were down as expected due to timing effects related to the  project execution, which also obviously affected the profit development.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Energy Management continued its turnaround in all aspects. Orders were up by 9% on a higher number of large  orders. Profitability approached the target margin range on the back of stronger profit contributions from high - voltage products and the transmission solutions business, where the share of low-margin legacy projects is coming  to an end.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: After probably the exception of fourth quarter performance, Building Technologies continued its positive trend  with a good start into fiscal 2016. Top line increase was mainly driven by the Americas, wit h strong demand for  solutions and services, and what we do see in that region is that it's all about energy efficiency, and this is really  something that we like to see. Margins improved due to a larger share of high-margin service business.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Process Industries and Drives benefited from strong orders in wind-related businesses, which were offset by a  weak demand from commodity-related industries. Positive currency effects are compensated by ongoing  structural challenges, in particular, in the oil and gas and the large drives businesses.

file: SIE - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 1February2017 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We had a strong start into the fiscal year across all our businesses. I'm very proud of our teams, who worked  really hard to deliver another strong showing for many quarters in a row now. However, we do not only perform on  the financial targets. Our holistic efforts on sustainability were recognized by the research company Corporate  Knights, which placed Siemens as number one amongst the world's most sustainable companies, well ahead of  our competitors. We more and more do experience that a company, which is responsive to society and  environmental needs, resonates well with preferences of the best talent all over the world.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Now, let me briefly touch on some key developments in the first quarter. As expected, comparable orders were  down by 14% on tough comps, due to a significant amount of large orders in fiscal Q1 2016. However, our base  business was stable in the first quarter. And we do see a good order pipeline for the second quarter in  Renewables, Energy Management, as well as Mobility. For example, we just recently announced a significant  project win such as 1.2 gigawatt power plant project in Thailand, or a frame contract for 200 locomotives in  Austria.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Book-to-bill [indiscernible] (4:58) remained above 1. With revenues up 3%, we continued at our path of  comparable organic revenue growth. And among other things, this was driven by the energy project businesses  as well as Building Technology and Digital Factory.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Free cash flow surged to a positive €740 million. I think we need to go back many years to find a similar topic,  which provides us a positive swing year-over-year of more than €1.4 billion. This was mainly due to improved  working capital performance in Energy Management, Mobility as well as Wind Power. Finally, we recorded a  significant decrease of €2.6 billion in provisions for pension and similar obligation due to higher discount rates for  future liabilities.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Now, let's look at the key developments in our divisions. The market environment in Power and Gas continues to  be tough due to slow demand and continued overcapacities in the market. The team continues to be focused on  the opportunities in the market, and our new H-class design is very well under way. In total, we recorded 11  orders for large gas turbines, and delivered 12 turbines during the quarter. Revenue growth was mainly driven by  backlog execution, in particular, from the Egypt project. PG achieved a margin improvement of 230 basis points to  11.8%, due to a smooth project execution and reliable contribution from the service business.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Energy Management continued to be a reliable contributor and inched out a few improvements in almost all  business areas. Profitability was at target range on the back of stronger profit contribution from the high-voltage  businesses and the transmission solution area.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Process Industries benefited from a strong order in Wind Power components, which was still more than offset by  weaker demand from the commodity related industries. PD executed the structural program as planned. But since  a material part of the resource alignment is in Germany, this may take time beyond fiscal 2017 to convert into P&L  savings.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: The growth momentum of the global environment seems to be strong in most economies. And our investment in  key businesses and sectors is paying off. texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Furthermore, the structural challenges in the fossil power generation market will continue. We have initiated and  will take decisive steps to adjust our capacities accordingly. Meanwhile, the dialogue with the employee  representatives have also started in Germany.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Energy Management developed sideways in the quarter with lower volume from large orders. The profit margin  was at the lower end of the target range, impacted by extraordinary adverse FX effects in the magnitude of 80  basis points.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Process Industries and Drives achieved strong order growth of 10%. However, we saw diverging end customer  trends. While commodity-related end markets showed further stabilization, the demand for mechanical  components particular in the wind business was weak. Profit margin improved by 90 basis points despite  significant currency headwinds. This was driven by record-high profitability in the process automation business.

file: SIE - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 30January2019 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jan-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Also, our Energy Management division, which sort of disappointed on the bottom line performance, also appears  with a very strong bookings record. And our  Power and Gas division booked an order to build the most efficient power plant in the United Arab Emirates,  bringing our H-class turbine in the region for the first time.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Thank you, Joe, and also good morning from my side. Power and Gas continues to face tough market conditions.  However, service remains a very stable contributor to top and bottom line. This quarter, Power and Gas booked one large H- frame gas turbine in Middle East, one large steam turbine, and 36 small and medium gas turbines, a particularly  decent achievement which deserves being mentioned.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: However, the margin development was not satisfying mainly due to negative effects from grid control projects  which we closely monitor going forward. In addition, lower revenue and profitability [Technical Difficulty]  (00:08:17) impacted margin in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Process Industries and Drives achieved excellent and broad-based order growth of 15%. Commodity-related  industries such as mining or oil and gas continued their CapEx-related recovery. We like to see that PD's  profitability increased and the resulting efforts are paying off.

file: SIE - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 25April2012 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Profitability was substantially burdened by further charges mainly for the German offshore grid connections in  Power Transmission. As indicated, the fundamental restructuring of NSN weighted on our equity investments  results. This led to a significant decrease of profit from total sectors by 48%. Major part of the difference was also  the Areva disposal gain of more than €1.5 billion in the second quarter of last year. Together with the additional  NSN effect, this led to a 67% decline in income from continuing operations. We saw some moderate improvement  over the last year in our free cash flow, but net working capital stayed on a high level during Q2, and Joe will  discuss this topic in more detail.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: From a strategic perspective, we continued our selective approach to do bolt-on acquisitions. For example, we  strengthened our portfolio in Industrial Software through the acquisition of RuggedCom, a specialized Canadian  company providing communications solutions for harsh environments, such as in electric utility substations, oil  refineries and rail applications. In Oil & Gas, we complemented our subsea power grid offering by taking over the  Connectors and Measurement division of Expro Holdings.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In Energy, the comparables were particularly tough in Germany where we won three major orders for offshore  wind parks a year ago. But also in emerging markets like the Middle East where we booked a major Combined  Cycle power plant order in Saudi Arabia in Q2 of last year.  The U.S. showed strength both in orders and revenue in a better-than-anticipated economic environment. Our  sales growth was very broad based with particular strength in emerging markets, such as in India with remarkable  48% growth or Brazil achieving 18% increase. For the second quarter, this resulted in a further shift of our  revenue distribution towards emerging markets with a share of 31%b up one percentage point over the second  quarter of fiscal 2011.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: What were the key developments in each of the sectors? First, sector Energy. As already mentioned, orders in  Energy went down substantially by 36% due to a broad-based decline of large projects in all divisions. The Energy  market remains highly competitive but our sales funnel for the coming quarters looks promising. And we expect a  book-to-bill ratio above one for the full year.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Intentionally, we were more selective on orders and walked away from low-margin businesses. The sector's  backlog was at a healthy €56 billion at the end of the quarter. A major highlight in Q2 was the order for the 834  megawatt Combined Cycle power plant in Ansan in South Korea where we will deliver, among other equipment,  two world-leading H-class turbines to Posco.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Second quarter revenue rose by 10% on the conversion from Energy's strong order backlog with substantial  growth in Asia, Australia, and a sharp increase of 42% in the renewal business. I want to point out that besides the  challenges in Transmission, the sector Energy delivered a very solid quarter regarding profit and once again  proved that our position as the only integrated energy company is fully intact.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Fossil delivered 17.5% profit margin and continued its excellent project execution in the solution business, also  achieved a strong earnings contribution from the service business. We were very pleased to see Renewable Energy  rebounding from the weak Q1 and also taking up profitability sharply to 8.2%, which was basically volume and  top-line-driven.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our clear number one position in Offshore Wind gives us a competitive advantage since we achieved a healthy  revenue mix of around one-third of Offshore and two-thirds on Onshore businesses in the first half of fiscal 2012.  We are working hard to maintain the lead in Offshore Wind and stay competitive in Onshore to be successful in  the expected difficult market conditions ahead. Besides ongoing pricing pressure and expected industry  consolidation, this is mainly caused by the uncertainty over the extension of the U.S. tax benefit scheme beyond  2012.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Power Transmission reported a significant loss of €169 million in the second quarter, major factors were  additional charges of €278 million we had to take, mostly related to the grid connections to Offshore Wind farm  projects in Germany.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: During the second quarter, we conducted a very detailed and thorough review of all of our offshore grid  connection projects in the North Sea. As a consequence, we had to rework our installation schedule for BorWin2  and HelWin1 platform, whose installation dates are anticipated to be delayed to 2013.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I don't want to sound like providing an excuse, but this kind of offshore grid installations have not been done  before. An 800-megawatt platform has a weight of up to 19,000 tons in around 70 meters water depth and 100  kilometers off the coast. The timeslot for installation work is restricted to the period from May to September  because of weather conditions. And for all this – those reasons, it's also much more complex compared to existing  AC offshore platforms we have successfully installed already in the U.K.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: It is fair to say that we now have a better understanding of the situation and have put a lot of effort into measures  to mitigate and to contain the risks. One example is the set-up of a joint working groups with the authorities, with  the grid operators and our peers to work on the standardization of the regulatory environment and the approval  processes. In addition, we have massively ramped up our resources in the offshore grid competence center in  Hamburg. We feel we get this major mistake step-by-step under control and can learn from these experiences for  future tenders and future projects.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In particular, in Europe, there will be a number of further tenders of offshore wind grid connections and other  HVDC projects similar to the recently awarded Western Link between England and Scotland. We want our fair  share in this attractive market but with a clear focus on risk control and profitability. If a project does not meet  these standards, we will have the discipline to walk away.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: First, as a clear sign of accountability, we decided to change the leadership of the division. Yesterday, we  announced that Karlheinz Springer will take over the divisional CEO role with immediate effect. He is a very  experienced manager who was previously responsible for the excellent development of Instrumentation &  Electrical business unit in the Fossil division. He has experience in project management and project execution and  will be of great help in this regard.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And finally, I want to briefly highlight the key developments in the sector Infrastructure & Cities. Order volume  for the sector declined by 8% due to fewer large rolling stock orders. Nevertheless, Rail Systems was again able to  win a contract for 20 Desiro regional trains in the U.K. for the customer London Midland for around €170 million.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: If we take a look on the free cash flow development, you should see here as a green line, then I guess there are a  couple of things I want to mention. First of all, in the first six months, we have significantly increased our  inventories by €1.5 billion, and also accounts receivables by almost €600 million in order also to reflect the  continued revenue growth and expected growth also in revenues for the second half. And there has been a  material decline on the prepayments including the biddings in excess, and that amounts to €700 million for the  first half of fiscal 2012. And the ones who have been following us for a longer period of time already know and  remember that it's been consistently mentioned in that item that there is some behavioral change if it comes to  bigger, or especially from the public sector as far as prepayments are concerned.

texts.text: In contrast, revenues were down 6% due to weakness in short-cycle businesses and on the back of tough comps in  Energy, where we benefited from the U.S. wind boom and from a higher amount of turnkey solutions in the  previous year. As a consequence, our book-to-bill ratio reached a strong level of 1.19. The order backlog increased  to a very healthy level of €101 billion and profitability was burdened by further charges of €84 million, mainly for  the German offshore grid connections in Power Transmission and €161 million for further delays for the high  speed trains, Velaro D and Eurostar.

texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: A number of businesses such as Healthcare, Fossil or Oil & Gas delivered strong profit margins, while the  industry's profit margin declined significantly due to lower volume in the high margin short-cycle businesses, a  less favorable product mix and continued weakness of the renewable offerings.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Invensys closing is taking place as we speak, and we are looking forward to create a leading rail automation  business. The integration teams are ready for implementation. The exit from the solar business proves to be more difficult, while the whole industry continues to suffer and  technical challenges remain in our project in Spain.
