texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: From a regional perspective, for orders and sales in the second quarter, also a mixed picture order growth in  Europe was driven by two very large offshore wind orders in Germany and the UK as well as two large rail orders  in Germany and Austria.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: The base business across all sector was flat, with some positive momentum in Energy and Healthcare and  weakness in Industry. We also saw good order momentum in emerging markets, with a comparable growth rate of  25%. China was up 3%, driven by Healthcare and Energy balancing the industry business. And Russia, plus 107%,  Africa and the Middle East with an increase of 40%, and Brazil plus 25%. Emerging markets accounted for 32% of  total orders. The decrease in revenues was regionally broad-based in the U.S. The main driver was a sharp decline  in wind power, driven by the PTC uncertainty and compared to an exceptionally strong quarter a year ago, though  in emerging markets, we had some pockets of growth such as Russia and Africa both growing above 50%.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let me now briefly highlight the key developments in each of the four sectors. First, sector Energy. Overall,  continued strong performance was backed by Fossil and robust service. As already mentioned, orders in Energy  went up sharply by 45%, largely due to the highest quarterly order intake ever in Wind with €3.3 billion.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: I want to specifically mention the €700 million Butendiek wind park order for a total capacity of 288 megawatts.  It is the first offshore order with a 10-year long-term service agreement and supported by an equity stake of 22.5%  from SFS, an excellent example for our unmatched comprehensive offering in this field. We expect the PTC  extension in the U.S. to have a positive impact on orders in the course of the second half of this calendar year, too  late though to show a significant impact in our revenue in fiscal 2013. Fossil showed strength in orders, with  several large service awards and we booked orders for 12 advanced gas turbines, well ahead of our competition.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: The sector backlog was at a solid €58 billion at the end of the quarter. Second quarter revenue decreased by 9%,  mainly due to a lower volume of turnkey solution projects in Fossil and the weak Wind business in the United  States.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: On profitability, Energy shows a heterogeneous picture. Fossil delivered again a strong 17.6% profit margin,  despite lower volumes and supported by a strong earnings contribution from the service business. Wind Power  achieved 5.1% profitability, down from last year's extraordinary strong quarter, due to lower revenues and some  adverse mix effects. After some weaker quarters and charges from legal and regulatory matters, Oil & Gas  returned to a profitability of 9.8%.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Power Transmission executes as planned on its restructuring program Transform To Win. More than 40% of the  planned head count reduction by 8% until 2015 has already been achieved. But Transmission faced, again, charges  of €84 million mainly related to the execution of grid connection projects to offshore wind farms in the Northern  Sea. We expect continued challenges in coming quarters related to the transport and installation of those  platforms. As mentioned, Solar was moved back to the sector level and posted a loss of €21 million pre-tax this  quarter. We expect a full-year loss of approximately €300 million post-tax. Sector energy recorded €20 million in  transformation charges for Siemens 2014 and expects a significant increase in the second half of fiscal 2013.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Finally, I want to highlight key developments in the sector Infrastructure & Cities. Order volume for this sector  increased by 34%, due to two large rail orders, one from Deutsche Bank for an ICx extension contract and the first  order for 100 local and regional trains worth around €550 million from the frame agreement with Austrian  railway provider ÖBB.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: The Transportation & Logistics division posted a loss due to the above mentioned charges of €161 million, which  severely impacted profitability. As in previous quarters, the revenue mix was less favorable due to lower margin  associated with large long-term contracts from prior periods. Power Grid Solutions & Products delivered steady  margins of 6.8% with favorable mix in smart grid business, while low and medium voltage was seasonally weaker.  Building Technologies saw a profit decrease by 100 basis points, mostly due to a revenue decline of 5%.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let's talk now about the status of our Siemens 2014 program. The whole organization is fully committed to  achieve and deliver this program. First of all, as you may have seen also in the Flash slide distributed this  morning, we have restated our 2012 starting pace by including the Solar business. As discussed already in detail  during the Capital Market Day's Industry & Energy, the impact of the transformation measures is rather back-end  loaded and still around 45% of the 2013 productivity target is already P&L effective, with a large portion coming  from procurement.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: The additional measures required to achieve €2 billion in 2013 are well on track. Also, a significant part of those  measures, which will be effective in fiscal 2014, are already in implementation. They are particularly in design to  cost area as well as footprint measures, where we are in intense discussions with the employee representatives.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Finally, let me complement the missing pieces to the four sector bridges. Assumptions are fully aligned and  broken down to the sectors. You saw already the Energy and Industry bridge during the respective Capital Market  Days. We have updated Energy where we need some additional productive to cover a slightly higher price erosion.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Infrastructure & Cities is also planning to compensate with volume integration for price erosion effects of slightly  less than 2%. The required productivity is €800 million over two years under the assumption of reliable project  execution in fiscal 2014.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: Head-Corporate Finance & Controlling, Siemens AG
texts.text: Now, if you look into the Lighting business itself, this is quite a paradigm shift which the asset has been going  through. We do see a massive decline of the basic elements of Lighting, such as light bulbs, but also the so-called  energy-saving lamps and what we see growing and that's what the equity story will be mostly focused about, that's  about the solid-state Lighting. That's about LED and the industrial application of LED.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Charges associated with the Siemens 2014 program in the sectors, I expect it to total up to €4.9 billion for the full  fiscal year and given this developments and financial results for the first half, we expect income from continuing  operations in fiscal 2013 to approach the lower end of our original expectation. €4.5 billion before impacts related  to legal and regulatory matters and significant portfolio effects, which we expect to burden income by up to €0.5  billion, due primarily to the Solar business.

file: SIE - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 7May2014 245 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: I'd like to refer to our statements on our Safe Harbor Statement which can be found on page 2 of the presentation.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: At the Annual Shareholders' Meeting in January 2014 I emphasized that we would be leading the company more  stringently and in flatter hierarchies. I also added that our commitment to being a leading company and that we  would develop along the value chain of electrification and automation, and manifest itself in the utilization of the  opportunities presented by digitization. That would enable the company to close profitability gaps in the long term  and reduce them in the short term.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: A quick look at the key figures shows that new orders clearly dropped relative to the extraordinarily strong  previous year, due to the decline in major orders in our Wind and Rail businesses. Nevertheless the book-to-bill  ratio remained positive at 1.06 [times]. Revenues rose 1% on a comparable basis. The 6% revenue decline at  Energy was more than compensated by the other sectors. Total sectors profit climbed by 16%, driven by significant  profit increases at Infrastructure & Cities, Industry, and Healthcare, as well as a sharp decline at Energy.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let me comment briefly on the individual sectors. The lower revenue in the Energy sector reflects both the  difficult market environment, especially for gas turbines, and the much more selective approach to accepting  orders in the Transmission Solutions business.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Our Wind business on the other hand was burdened by one-time charges of €48 million for the repair of defective  supplier parts. Since among other things the high margin offshore business had a smaller share of the total  business, its contribution to profit was much lower. For the third quarter we expect the margins of our Wind  business to normalize.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Finally let's take a look at the Infrastructure & Cities sector, which in the past quarter once again reached the  projected gains and earnings in all of its businesses. The main drivers here were significant improvements in the  execution of rail orders and the successful implementation of Siemens 2014 productivity measures throughout the  sector.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: New orders dropped significantly in the regions Europe, Middle East, Africa, and CIS states because a number of  major Wind and Rail orders were booked in the same quarter of the previous year. In contrast to that the  substantial surge in Wind orders, albeit in comparison to a weak previous year quarter, boosted order volume in  the Americas.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: The recurring changes ladies and gentlemen if you look at Q2, and I think it becomes clear that we are good at a  lot of things. But we also need to take action in a number of different areas. That applies in particular to the  charges from the Energy sector. And this also applies to how we deal with all of this. We need to take  responsibility. And it's a question as to how these businesses in this sector can look forward.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We expect our more traditional electrification businesses to grow moderately overall at 2% to 3%. And markets for  automation will achieve attractive medium-term growth rates of 4% to 6%. So that's nearly twice the global GDP,  which we expect.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: When it comes to digitization and electrification and the combination of e lectrification and automation is where  we want to play a leading role. And we will do so because we have excellent prerequisites for this.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Why? We can do this because we have an excellent position. We have a strong base in electrification. And we also  hold a clear number one position in nearly all fields of automation, power plant control technology, power  transmission grids, rail automation, or discrete manufacturing industries.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: So ladies and gentlemen this gives us attractive opportunities as well. And we see that we can take the small and  more flexible gas turbines, which are very important for the highly attractive markets of oil and gas as well as in  the market for the decentralized power generation.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: In the area of renewable energy we will continue to focus on expanding wind capacity, especially in the offshore  segment, a segment which will grow at a double digit rate in the medium term.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: As far as flexible gas turbines are concerned we've already set a very key milestone today. The acquisition of the  aero-derivative gas turbine business of Rolls-Royce closes a gap, an important gap in our portfolio and broadens  our access to the attractive market for small gas turbines. We're talking about a range of 4 megawatts to 7 0  megawatts. And we believe that this is a market which will continue to grow at about 8% in the years to come per  year.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen next to Power Generation. Power transmission and power distribut ion play a fundamental  role. Energy systems in urban centers are converging and being integrated in their environments. We refer to  decentralized energy management. This is a term that is often used in this context.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: That's why we have – this has been neglected in the past, but it makes good sense to implement the transition in  energy policy here in Germany. That's why we've merged Transmission, Low and Medium Voltage, and key parts  of our former Smart Grid unit into a powerful Energy Management division. This will give us a full portfolio. And  we will make use of the opportunities that open up for us.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Aside from industry and process in automation, we see growth opportunities particularly in Germany, especially  because these can create customer benefits. And this applies not only to Germany, it applies to the industrialized  economies worldwide. Automation and electrification in grid management are a key prerequisite for this. And  that's why we will invest substantially in this area and strengthen our positio n.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Buildings also play a major role in these grids, so we will rigorously tap the opportunities presented in the building  technology market and also make use of mobility in the future.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: And we are proud of our world class plant in Amberg. They generate 50 million pieces of process information  every day and this allows for manufacturing with a quality of close to 100%. Every large Siemens gas turbine  contains about 1,500 sensors. These 1,500 sensors and each and every one of them has data. That's where the data  comes from. And that's why we fulfill all of the prerequisites in dealing with the data and with digitization. And  this is something that can give us profitable growth.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: In addition even though we may have missed a few opportunities, especially in unconventional oil and gas  exploration, we still have excellent market entry opportunities, especially in North America. And we plan to  expand our position there. And if you look at where the markets are located, you can see that on this chart, then  you will see that 7 5% of the market is in North America. And this shows that we must send out a message. We  don't just talk about it. We take action there. And this is where it is relevant.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: And that is why we have decided that for Energy Generation, Power Generation division will be moved to the  United States to Orlando. And this will be managed by Lisa Davis who will be on the Board of Management, as of  the 1 of August this year. And I'm sure she will provide a welcome addition to the company.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: For example we're creating a very good powerful joint venture with Mitsubishi-Hitachi Heavy Machinery from  Japan. And that will mean we are creating a global and a strong metals technology company. Siemens will hold  49% of the interest here. The two partners really are an excellent match in terms of both product portfolio and  regional presence, which is strong. And all together that will enable us to assume a global leadership role.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: To lead the company more effectively we have expanded the One Siemens financial target system, which you  already know, to a comprehensive management system. And we've added elements like operational excellence in  particular as well as sustainability and social responsibility.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: And another subject that's very dear to [Ralf] Thomas' and my heart in particular, the cutting one-time charges  from projects. We've examined high-risk projects from recent years and analyzed the causes of the problems. Very  often these lie in the bidding phase. And we have initiated the necessary changes. In the BorWin 3 offshore grid  connection project, which we recently won, we've already taken into account the experience gained from these  other projects.

file: SIE - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 7May2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We do see, of course, the impact on oil. We do see the impact on secondary effects. We did discuss the matter on  our wind business, and is also said that the mix in our digital factory would be unfavorable in fiscal Q2.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: If you look at the top line, we believe we're pretty much in the ballpark of what this industry has able to deliver at  this time, given the global macroeconomic and specific circumstances. If you look at the orders, we saw some  significant growth in Mobility where we did win a v ery prestigious order. We also believe that what we see in  Power and Gas has been a significant recovery in both in volume but also in terms of market share especially in  large gas turbines, as seen in the McCoy statistics coming out I think as recently as yesterday. And it confirms our  view that Siemens is reasonably successful in what I would call, a difficult and highly competitive market.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Now obviously, it's been going to the media, Siemens has been very successful on a co uple of mega deals.  Obviously, the Mobility order issue we have booked in fiscal Q2, there is orders to come in from Egypt. We have a  reliable agreement on building three huge power plants in Beni Suef, Burullus and New Capital for about 13.2  gigawatts. With our fast-track projects, it's about H-Frame combined cycle gas turbines.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We also have a firm agreement for 2 gigawatts of onshore wind, which is also going to be built in Egypt around the  Suez area. So why have we been successful? Obviously, first of all, we've been able to really tailor our offering to  customers' need. We've been able to consult and help them to optimize the full range of the value chain from  generation, transmission and distribution, so we can generate a unique value to our customers when it comes to  optimizing electrification in a country and in a society.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Now, obviously the volume of those orders will depend on whether or not they're going to do the full EPC  contracting or whether we will have to split between products and EPC but that's something which is yet to be  fully finalized. So we expect orders to come in for the total projects including wind, in the neighborhood between  €5 billion or €10 billion. And if you look at the global environment, we believe that there are more opportunities  out there, like the ones in Egypt.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: And I'll go through the divisions, altogether. Obviously, Power and Gas, it's a complicated environment. We've  won 12 large gas turbines especially in the Middle East. We've also seen some growth coming out of t he Rolls- Royce acquisition, which we have not been including in our numbers. We do have 180 basis points effect from  restructuring in the division, which is an ongoing task to right-size the business. And you've also heard this  morning that there is a further restructuring going on also in PG to make the business not only successful in the  market, but also competitive if it comes to orders in the midterm. It's important. We've seen quite a comeback yet  in the market, but obviously the cost effective is crucially important.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: If we go towards the Wind and Renewables business, obviously that's clearly disappointing. We believe that we  have fully understood what needs to be done. We also see that the actions are well underway. It may still take  some time till we can fully improve the efficiency of the supply chain in the division. We are well underway in the  innovation pipeline. But obviously, we need a significant improvement of the operational reliability going forward.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: On Energy Management, we clearly do see a significant progress in turnaround. Margins have been up quite a lot.  We do see the swing from a minus 7 .6% in fiscal Q2 2014 up to now, 3.3%, 3.4% in the division and counting. So  we are right on the way as to what we said we would do, and we continue the restructuring as a turnaround in the  Energy Management division.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We have a different picture obviously in the Process Industries and Drives. This is the division which has been  falling victim for the most part on the oil and gas topic, especially oil price obviously, but also on the geopolitical  issues have been a huge backdrop in Russia on both LNG, oil and gas, and also what I call the secondary effects of  a weak oil if it comes to the income statements of those countries. So we do expect continued weakness on the top  line. Although we expect that the margin impact going forward will be more favorable as what we have seen in our  fiscal Q2.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: SFS delivered an extraordinary strong profit of €195 million, also benefiting from gains through selling equity  stakes in renewable energy projects. During the second half of fiscal 2015, the SFS performance is expected to  normalize on prior year's level. Centrally managed portfolio activities recorded a gain of €1.4 billion on the  disposal of Siemens' stake in BSH. As indicated, we saw a negative impact of around €200 million due to the  funding related to our share in Unify.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: For the second half of fiscal 2015, we are cautious on CMPA since we expect some negative impacts related to the  remaining businesses like Unify, Postal & Baggage Handling, Metals and Solar. Please note that CMPA includes,  as of Q2, also the solar business which was transferred from the Wind Power and Renewable division.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Net income all-in benefited from major gains of around €1.8 billion of successfully completing the sale of the  hearing aid and hospital information system businesses within discontinued operations. For the second half year,  the impact from DO will be rather limited. Having said that, I would like to focus on the clearly weaker free cash  flow development year-over-year in the second quarter with a minus of €241 million. There are two major reasons  for this development. First, power and gas as well as wind power significantly increased the net operating working  capital. Power and gas mainly lifted its inventories for an intentional increase in stock units for fast track projects  as Joe has been indicating before.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Wind power faced a weak quarter regarding large milestone payments. Secondly, there was also a significant  negative impact in corporate treasury mainly related to settlements from hedging instruments as Joe said. For the  second half of fiscal 2015, we expect a material improvement from the industrial business with regard to cash  flow. With regard to liquidity, we continue to have a very sound position of €9.9 billion, fueled by the inflows from  our recent divestments.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: To make this more tangible for you, currently, we have 14 major projects in our pipeline where technical risk  assessments were conducted by very experienced experts, so-called silverbacks of which we have identified around  60 globally in our company. During the first half year, we executed our projects in a solid way without major hits  on the bottom line. In addition, we made significant progress in delivering on our legacy project. Between January  and April, for example, we handed over three out of four North Sea offshore grid connection projects to our  customer, TenneT for commercial operation. And the fourth project, HelWin2 is on schedule to be put into  operation in the coming weeks. The percentage of completion in this project is above 85% now.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We discussed matters like compressors. We obviously have our challenges, our economic challenges in  transmission. And it's also a matter which we have addressed such as mechanical drives. There is a series of  actions, which we have been discussing and agreeing upon is the management team of those businesses. Then we  discussed the business plan. And now, we've got a clear view on how to fix those businesses. The fix will, among  other things, will include a footprint optimization, which predominantly also relates to businesses like the  transformer business within transmission.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So by doing that, we'll create about €1 billion incremental profit for that business and about €400 million to €500  million incremental EVA. Obv iously, we also have to keep all our options open on the way to achieving those  goals. That's how we do it, that's how we execute, and that's how we are going to narrow the scope on those  businesses which needs to be fixed from an economic perspective. Now obviously, let me close and wrap it up with  the outlook for fiscal 2015. Now, obviously, we do have a lot of weakening indicators, and I've heard of course also  the questions from the market. What will that do to the guidance? We do have oil-price-related matters, which  obviously we all know about. We do have secondary effects from this oil price development if it comes to income - related issue of those economies.

file: SIE - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 4May2016 415 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We're in the middle of executing on our Vision 2020, and we are executing well. We are building a leading and  highly adaptive company along the value chain of electrification, automation, and digitalization. That's all based  on a, what we call, powerful ownership culture. The system of EAD – electrification, automation, digitalization –  is unique. And it matters, matters to our customers, matters to our employees, our shareholders, since it provides  a unique value proposition.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As you can see in our financials and also in other areas of our Vision 2020 concept, we delivered what  they  promised, and they achieved a convincing – at least what we believe convincing – top and bottom line  performance compared to both the previous year and the industry. Orders continue to grow and were up 10%  excluding currency effects, driven by obviously some major orders. Major contributors came from Power and Gas.  They booked the remaining two combined cycle power plants in Egypt for about €3.1 billion. And also secondly,  Wind Power, we recorded a €1.2 billion order from an offshore wind farm project in the United Kingdom. And I'll  give you more details in a minute.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As indicated, we accelerate revenue growth to 7% excluding currency effects and 5% on a pure organic basis. Wind  Power and Power and Gas delivered double-digit growth, while Mobility and Healthcare also showed strength in  growing their business. The Industrial profit margin was at 10.9%, which obviously was up 190 basis points year  over year. That was driven by what believe strong showings in most businesses, particularly in Wind Power and   also in Energy Management.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now maybe we should have a look at the regional trend. We already mentioned large energy -related orders drove  growth in the Europe and Africa region, while Germany and the Americas were down on tough comps from a year  ago. In line with a particularly difficult macroeconomic environment in those regions, we saw continued order  weakness in Russia and Brazil, while order intake in China actually looked good and we took advantage from our  competitive position in efficient gas, decentral generation, and HVDC while, short-cycle demand was still  reasonably weak.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Then I'll give you maybe some information on two major orders in the first quarter. As you know, we've won a  mega-deal order in Egypt for a three combined-cycle power plants with a total 24 H-class turbines, including  service. That's all now fully in our books. Closing for the financing of Burullus and New Capital projects took place  during the second quarter. We are lining up all our resources to execute those mega-projects in time, in the  money, and also support our customer with a comprehensive training scheme for future operation.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Just a few days ago, we announced the East Anglia ONE project with ScottishPower Renewables, our largest  offshore order ever, regarding the capacity volume. This is about a 7  megawatt direct drive turbine, which receives  quite a strong acceptance in the market. And we'll deliver this project out of the manufacturing places in Hull,  here in the UK, as well as Cuxhaven, and both facilities are being built as we speak.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, let's have a look at some key developments in the divisions. As mentioned, Power and Gas operates in a very  competitive market environment, and the team continues to drive productivity, cost-efficiency, and focus on the  opportunities in the global marketplace. In total, we shipped 16 large gas turbines in the quarter – among those  five H-class turbines – and we continue to grow our market share. We have sold 78 H-class turbines now and  improved our own world record to 61.5% efficiency at 603.8 megawatts electrical output at our Lausward plant.  Above all, our fully operational H-class turbines have now received more than 200,000 operating hours,  demonstrating a unique – a real-life – day-by-day performance and reliability.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Wind Power has a very robust sales pipeline resulting from abundant backlog of almost €15 billion. Strong  conversion of exactly the backlog drove revenue growth in both onshore as well as offshore. Significant process  and progress in our efforts to optimize our operational excellence and a strong project completion and execution  helped drive an exceptionally strong profit margin of 9.4%. Although this may not yet be sustainable for the  quarters to come, we expect Wind Power to deliver within the target margin range for the remainder of the year.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Energy Management continued to improve its performance, approaching the target margin r ange on the back of  stronger profit contributions from solutions, transformer, and high-voltage projects in the business. In the  transmission solutions businesses, we continue to have a very clear backlog focus on quality of the backlog,  including risk and margin.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As laid out previously, Process Industries and Drives faced further weak demand from commodity -related  industries, which were only partially offset by order growth in Wind Power-related businesses. As a consequence,  we announced a restructuring program to adjust capacities and the line footprint on demand structures. For 2,500  jobs and other assets which are affected by the restructuring, we expect severance charges of about €200 million  to €300 million probably impacting fiscal Q4.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the second quarter, the divestments of Unify and Sivantos, that's the former hearing aids business in Siemens,  were successfully closed. Clearly ahead of our original schedule, we closed the acquisition of CD-adapco, a  simulation specialist for fluid dynamics, for $170 million, in early April. CD-adapco is being integrated in our PLM  software business, and you already heard a very convincing joint appearance at the Hannover Fair, which  obviously left a lot of customers impressed about our digital strategy in this area. And we are also looking into  strengthening sustainability evolution and long-term visionary innovation. A good example for efficiency driving  is the sustainability agenda which we write with the formation of a 50/50 joint venture with Valeo, to provide  high-voltage powertrain for electric cars.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As for the longer-term aspects, we have also announced a collaboration agreement with Airbus where we joined  forces to electrify aviation through hybrid electric propulsion systems, drastically reducing the emissions in  aviation. Until 2020, about 200 employees from both companies will develop prototypes for such drivetrains, and  we want to demonstrate the technical feasibility. Together, we will invest a mid-three-digit million euro R&D  amount until 2020.

file: SIE - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 4May2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let me walk you through some highlights. The acquisition of Mentor Graphics took place at the end of the second  quarter while the merger of our wind power business with Gamesa closed at the beginning of Q3. texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let's have a look now at a selection of some large orders we received in the quarter. We saw very strong order  development in Germany, up by 94% year-over-year. It was driven by the €1.4 billion order for the Hohe See  offshore wind power plant solution for EnBW. We will connect 71 of our 7 megawatt turbines to the grid by 2019  followed by a five-year service contract.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Power and Gas was very successful to gain share in the distributed generation area, and will supply 12 industrial  gas turbines with the total capacity of 690 megawatts in Argentina. These orders come with a 10-year long-term  operations, maintenance and service agreement centered on our comprehensive digital service portfolio.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Now, let's look at some key developments in the division. Power and Gas operates in a very competitive market  environment. Global energy trend towards renewable continued to put pressure on customer demand for fossil  power generation. This results in decline in new unit business and corresponding price pressure. Due to project  shift particularly in the Middle East, we expect a decline in the large gas turbine market in fiscal 2017. In total, we  shipped 11 large gas turbines in the quarter. Among those, five H-class turbines.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Energy Management accelerated top line growth, improved profitability, and gained market share, supported by  several major orders. The two largest contracts alone, one in the Middle East and the already-mentioned HVDC  order in India, add up to around €1 billion.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Mobility delivered again industry-leading margins and significant top-line growth, clear positive evidence of our  vertical integration strategy. Successful project execution and a largest share of the high-margin rail infrastructure  business drove profitability.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let me now walk you through the line items below Industrial Business, where we saw quite some movement, and  I will also give you some guidance for the second half of fiscal 2017. SFS again delivered a very strong profit of  €207 million, driven by an equity business, including a mid-double-digit million gain from selling a stake in an  offshore wind farm.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Our push to roll out our state-of-the-art cost and value engineering approach across all divisions is ramping up  quickly. We want to achieve cost-optimized design solutions in a very early phase, provide cost transparency and  unveil savings potential along the entire supply chain.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: For example, we were awarded a large order in Bolivia to significantly expand the three power plants with 14  SGT800 turbines. We used the CVE methodology combined with the e-bidding to substantially optimize the cost  position for the heat recovery steam generators during the bid process.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: A few weeks ago Energy Management announced with SAP that our Meter Data Management solution, EnergyIP,  will be combined with SAP software suite for utilities and SAP will sell it to its customers. This will significantly  broaden the customer base and bring them a high level of intelligence to make data actionable in a more and  more distributed energy landscape.

file: SIE - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 9May2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Now, let me walk you through some highlights of the quarter. We were pleased with a healthy book-to-bill ratio of  1.11 times and the new record backlog of more than €129 billion in the Industrial Business with a solid gross  margin quality. Comparable orders were slightly lower 1% due to a substantially higher volume from large orders  in the energy-related businesses one year ago. Base orders below €50 million were clearly up 9% on a nominal  basis. Organic revenue was overall flat with growth in most divisions driven by an excellent short cycle  performance offsetting weakness in Power and Gas.

texts.speaker: Lisa A. Davis
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: Looking at three of our main markets, the pattern has been very similar since fiscal 2015, sharp unit demand  declines combined with significant price erosion. The good news is that we have significantly increased market  share over the last four years in both our large gas and small, medium, and aero derivative gas turbines. Looking  forward, based on our project funnel for large gas, we expect to see less than 100 turbines being awarded in the  industry in fiscal 2018, and there are no signs of midterm recovery to higher levels.

texts.speaker: Lisa A. Davis
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: On the other hand, we expect a bottoming and moderate recovery in the small and medium gas turbine segments  as well as in compression. A higher oil price above USD $70 is beginning to support investments in upstream and  pipelines. However customers are very cost-sensitive and competition is fierce. As I already mentioned, the  measures to drive cost-out are in place.

texts.speaker: Lisa A. Davis
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let me also give you an update on our service business. Our installed base is a great asset and our service team  is doing an excellent job to make it even more valuable for our customers. From the current backlog of €31 billion,  around €25 billion are related to large gas. And we expect to increase the backlog even further. The service- relevant fleet continues to grow as our previously sold units reached their first major outages. This includes our H- class units, for example, in the U.S. and Asia, as well as our fast-growing base of SGT-800 units in Latin America  and elsewhere. We rigorously track our outage activity and utilization to ensure constant visibility. As you can see  from the charts, gas turbine utilization so far has been moderately up in 2018 and our balanced distribution across  the many regions helps to handle any fluctuations.

texts.speaker: Lisa A. Davis
texts.profession: Member-Management Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: I want to reiterate that customer proximity and innovation remain our key success factors. In the second quarter,  we sold six large gas turbines among them are the first two H-class turbines on the China Mainland, which will be  part of the most efficient gas-fired power plant in China. We have sold now 88 H-class turbines, of which 65 are  already in reliable operation. A key technology for our business is additive manufacturing. We will invest a further  €30 million to expand our 3D printing factory in the UK, fully equipped with software and automation from our  Digital Factory colleagues.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Process Industries and Drives is making good progress on its restructuring program and achieved clear order  growth of 6%. However, we saw diverging end customer trends. While commodity-related end markets showed  further stabilization, the demand for mechanical components, particularly in the wind business remained weak.  Profit margin improved by 60 basis points despite significant currency headwinds of 50 basis points.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: The PLM software business is very well on track to achieve its €3.4 billion revenue target in fiscal 2018 on strong  profitability despite significant invest in MindSphere and Software-as-a-Service solutions. Energy Management  showed broad-based improvement across its businesses with clear revenue growth and a margin well in the  target range. Large orders were lower on tough comps. We have seen some push-outs of HVDC solution projects  into fiscal 2019.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: The recent MAKE study on global market share developments in the wind industry confirmed the compelling  industrial logic of the merger. Siemens Gamesa took the lead in 2017 with 8.8 gigawatt new installations and 17%  market share, an increase of 3.3 percentage points.

file: SIE - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 8May2019 130 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: And interestingly enough, here we are always talk about the major project. I'm talking about the LNG-to-power  project in Brazil, 1.3 gigawatts, 1,300 megawatts. So that's a huge power plant. It's the first contract for the H- class turbines which is our flagship, if you want to put it this way, which we developed together with E.ON here in  Germany. And here we've reached more than 60% of efficiency. And this is really important project, because we  did lose a couple of projects here in Germany. And this is also a message to our customers. The H-class has now  exceeded 1 million operating hours without any failure. No broken blades, no major signs of abrasion, no  hundreds of millions of so-called project charges.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: So, that is quite an achievement. We've got 70 turbines in operation and 100 units have been sold. We are the  world market leader with our H-class. And that's just a message the numbers are telling you, and that doesn't  require any further explanation. We also signed a project for the energy roadmap for Iraq not too long ago. And  not only did we – does win the upper hand over our competitors, but also over other forces who've got other  interests in this area. And in this current quarter, we will have an order intake of about €1 billion as a first stage.  That's the €700 million which you have read about in the press release and about €300 additional million which  we didn't even talk too much.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Orders increased. The same goes for revenues. The slight decrease is especially due to portfolio and currency  translation effect. And the order backlog now amounts to €142 billion. That is really a very reliable number which  you can build upon. Half of that is the order backlog of what we described yesterday as the Power and Gas  NewCo. Now, why am I saying this, because later on we'll also see a change in Siemens Industrial. Market  proximity and better understanding of the market will become even more relevant than in the past.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: The Energy Management division posted considerable order growth, spanning almost the entire EM portfolio, and  profited particularly from several larger orders in the product business for high-voltage power transmissions. The  slight increase in revenue resulted from continuing growth in the business with low- and medium-voltage  products. This was partially offset by declines in the products and solutions businesses in the transmission sector.  The adjusted EBITA margin of 9% was clearly within the division's margin range. The adjusted EBITA also  benefited from a gain of €55 million from the sale of a stake in an equity investment.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Now to the Process Industries and Drives division, which continue to make solid progress. Now, revenue rose 9%  year-over-year across all businesses, most strongly in the wind power components business. Orders remained  stable. The adjusted EBITA margin grew 6.8%, also driven by ongoing operational improvements in the large  drives business. The efforts being undertaken at PD are paying off truly, and the team has again done a very  good job. We are firmly convinced that we will be much more effective at leveraging the potential of these  businesses in the new setup.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Welcome and good morning, everyone, to our third quarter conference call. And let’s get right into  the highlights of the quarter. Our three sectors are executing extremely  well and steadily improving their competitive positions. The order intake was up across the board  with the shorter cycle businesses and industry coming back strongly against easy comps, and in  the third quarter we booked a number of large orders in the energy sector across almost all  divisions.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The energy sector remains the biggest contributor to the backlog with €54 billion. Be it in Fossil,  Transmission or Renewables, all divisions saw significant order wins in Q3. In Fossil we sold our  new class of turbines, the six H-class turbines to Florida Power & Light. Renewables won a number  of very large offshore windparks, among them 20 more in the UK from RWE, Baltic 2 in Germany  from EnBW, and an important step in U.S. was the win of our so far largest onshore project, 150  turbines for the Lower Snake River Windpark.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And in transmission, we extended our leading position in offshore grid connections through several  large contract wins. Among them was the BorWin2 contract from Transpower worth more than  €500 million. These wins are clear evidence that our integrated energy offering is a unique  competitive strength.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: OSRAM’s outstanding numbers are fueled by healthy automotive demand and an accelerated shift  towards LED, which accounted already for more than 20% of revenue in the third quarter. Our late  cycle businesses, Building Technologies and Industry Solutions are still operating in difficult  markets, but there are signs of some market stability returning.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Mobility executed its projects well and showed solid order growth. The sales funnel is looking  promising, but of course the timing of further orders is never easy to predict. Sector Energy again  showed its excellent execution abilities and achieved 14.3% profit margin in the upper range of the  target band. In particular Fossil delivered outstanding profitably supported by diligent project  delivery and a favorable revenue mix. As indicated, the broad energy market showed signs of  improvement while the speed of recovery varies by division.

Nevertheless, book-to-bill for the sector, again, stood at a very healthy 1.18; also sustained its outstanding  project execution performance, combined with a favorable business mix of high margin products and service  business and achieved an underlying margin of 22.6%.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG

In addition, market conditions remained challenging for the Solar Thermal business,  which continued to boost negative results.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: A good example of an important strategic partnership is the recently announced letter of intent with the  Australian company Lynas; and we will set up a majority joint venture to produce rare earth magnets, which will  be used in our energy-efficient drives and wind turbine generators. This partnership will secure a sustainable end-

file: SIE - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 26July2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: We have seen quite a cooling down in demand in important end markets that are driven particularly by the  export-oriented German industry, as you can also see from the current IFO level or VDMA numbers. The  investment climate in a number of Western European countries remains very weak due to the ongoing austerity  measures and restricted access to and high cost of capital.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Profitability clearly exceeded the prior-year level which was substantially burdened by the Areva arbitration  decision and the Particle Therapy reevaluation. Fossil and DX delivered strong earnings. However, profitability  was impacted by higher OpEx in all sectors and a significantly lower contribution from the Industrial sector.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: As for OSRAM, we stick to our original plans to deconsolidate the asset but changed our primary plans. Since  market conditions continue to be highly volatile for an IPO, we decided to pursue a spin-off to our shareholders as  the most probable part of divestiture. This option requires shareholder approval at the next AGM in January 2013  and Siemens still intends to remain an anchor shareholder in OSRAM. Though our strategic intent remains the  same from an accounting perspective, this results in a significantly negative non-cash P&L effect in discontinued  operations through a so-called cumulative catch-up of depreciation and amortization related to OSRAM.  For the record, here is the overview of the key figures for the third quarter. These challenges are reflected in our  regional split of orders and sales in the third quarter, the lack of large orders, particularly in Energy and the Rail  business, compared to a strong prior-year weighted on growth rates in Europe and also the U.S. Major driver  behind the 28% order decline in the U.S. was the expected expiration of the U.S. tax benefit scheme on  renewables, which led already to a sharp decline in new Wind orders.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: What were the key developments in each of the sectors? In sector Energy, as already mentioned, orders in Energy  went down substantially by 33% due to a broad-based decline of large projects in all divisions. The Energy market  remains highly competitive with some postponements of projects and competitive pricing in the market.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Those of you following our news closely probably have noticed our recent order announcements, such as  Lausward, the next H-frame power combined cycle power plant for the Stadtwerke Düsseldorf with our second H- frame sold in Germany and 15 in total. We plan to achieve for the first time an efficiency level of above 61%. The  Panda Temple Power Project in Texas in the U.S. with an order volume around $300 million and the large-frame  agreement with DONG Energy to deliver 300 of our new 6-megawatt direct-drive turbines which will strengthen  our market leadership in offshore wind. And this largest offshore order ever adds another 1,800-megawatts to our  installed base of 2,700 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: For Energy, we expect a strong rebound in orders in Q4 and the book-to-bill ratio for the full year likely just shy of  1% – of 1. The sectors backlog remained at the healthy €56 billion at the end of the quarter. And second quarter  revenue rose by 8% on the conversion from Energy's strong order backlog driven by a substantial increase of 35%  in the renewable business.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Fossil continued its excellent project execution and delivering once again a strong margin of 17.6%. The product  and service business contributed significantly to this performance. Unfortunately, the strong top line growth in  renewable energy did not adequately convert into profitability. The reasons were supplier-related provisions of  €32 million and the €20 million charge for capacity adjustments weighting on profitability in the Wind business,  while the Solar business posted higher losses year-over-year.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: As previously indicated, Power Transmission reported a weak margin of 3.2% due to the conversion of lower- margin contracts and further charges of €22 million mostly related to the grid connections to offshore wind farms  in Germany. I will give you more details in a minute about the progress we have achieved to bring Power  Transmission back on track.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: As already mentioned, industry faced headwinds particularly in the short-cycle businesses of Industry Automation  and Drive Technologies, and in addition the sector's renewable offerings were held back by the difficult market  environment. Revenue in the sector was down 2% year-on-year while orders went down moderately by 4%, yet  supported by contract wins in the metals business. Profitability in Industry Automation was down 260 basis  points compared to the last quarter, mostly due to a significantly unfavorable product mix and also high OpEx  spending.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: The drop in profitability of Drive Technologies to 8.6% is largely due to a weaker margin in the short-cycle motion  control business and continuous challenges in the Renewable Energy offering of Drive Technologies.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: Finally, I want to walk you through the key developments in the sector Infrastructure & Cities. Revenue for the  sector was slightly up, 1, driven by an increase in the Power Grid Solutions & Products business. Profits in the  Transportation & Logistics division achieved 4.2%, 100 basis points below the prior-year level due to lower  revenue and some impact from lower margins in the long-term contracts.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: And third, we put a strong emphasis on stabilizing and mastering the offshore grid access project in Germany. The  resource ramp-up is almost done and each of the project is staffed with a very experienced project director. Our  team is collaborating closely with the customer, suppliers and regulatory bodies to resolve the outstanding  challenges. By this program, Transmission will achieve by 2015 30% cost savings, 8% profitability and grow faster  than the market after a consolidation phase.

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Siemens AG
texts.text: And finally, mastering the offshore grid projects successfully is a crucial cornerstone for Transmission, and since it  will be the reference for further projects to execute the so-called [indiscernible] (14:58) in Germany and  elsewhere.  Now I would like to hand over to Joe for some more background on the financials.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: The only one significant volatile here is our so-called asset retirement obligation. That's a construction matter of  some nuclear remains in Hanau. As you might know from our filings. It is a €2.7 billion liability up to 2075. And  alone from those numbers, you can see how heavily those future liabilities will be impacted in terms of net present  value by the discount rate which is used. So it was positive in Q3 with the plus €44 million, but that could also  change course if the discount rate turns smaller.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: If we move now on the margins, I mean, obviously, Energy is pretty close to where our bandwidth is. There's been  some weakness in the so-called Renewables which is predominantly affected through solar. Wind is actually  developing according to our expectations and produces decent margins compared to competition, at least. The  solar matter obviously is being affected by some structural changes in the global environment of that industry, and  that also means that we need to take close attention on what that means in Siemens.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: And as far as the Transmission is concerned, there's a program underway which looks promising. On the same  The reason being that the majority of the backlog on those wind projects in the North Sea, obviously, is now  running with zero gross margin and will ultimately dilute the P&L, which actually should not come as a surprise  because if charges are being made that means that gross margin will be zero as we move along. Good news is we've  been on the cap of liquidated damages here, so any potential unforeseen delays would not materially affect any  provisions as they relate to liquidated damages going forward.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: Infrastructure & Cities; I mean, obviously, it's been not exactly there where we want it to be, and where it needs to  be. On the other hand, we always made it pretty clear that the whole city infrastructure has its long-term  potentials and in the short term still needs to take some efforts on getting the product margin in order.

file: SIE - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 31July2013 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-13.pdf

texts.text: Our key financials for the third quarter show a mixed picture in what I would call an ambiguous macroeconomic  environment. texts.profession: Member-Managing Board & Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser

The outlook excludes  other significant portfolio effects and obviously also legal and regulatory matters in the fourth quarter.

file: SIE - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 31July2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: Member-Supervisory Board, Daimler AG
texts.text: As for the third quarter, we delivered a good performance with progress in most areas. Continued challenges in  the energy business held back an even stronger profit improvement for Siemens as a whole. As for the full fiscal  year 2014, we are on track to deliver our outlook. The macroeconomic picture continues to show a heterogeneous  regional development.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: Member-Supervisory Board, Daimler AG
texts.text: In this environment, the order intake remained on the same level year-over-year on a like-for-like basis. Across  the sectors, we saw significant shifts. Large orders in the Energy sector such as the €1.6 billion Gemini offshore  wind-farm project in the Netherlands compensated for sharply lower rolling stock orders such as the €3 billion  [indiscernible] (04:34) contract which we booked about a year ago.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: Member-Supervisory Board, Daimler AG
texts.text: Sector profit was driven by a higher contribution from our short cycle businesses in Industry sector, as well as  from solid project and productivity execution in the Infrastructure & Cities sector. On the other hand, the Energy  sector is facing operational challenges that held back further profitability improvement and will require some time  to get fully fixed.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: Member-Supervisory Board, Daimler AG
texts.text: Now, let's take a look at some key developments in each of the sectors. First, the Energy sector. Let's start at the  bright spot at the beginning. Orders were up sharply with growth in all businesses and geographies, however on  obviously relatively easy comps in the quarter last year.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: Member-Supervisory Board, Daimler AG
texts.text: In Power Generation, we were able to catch up successfully and sold 16 advanced gas turbines in a very  competitive market, multi-connection with turnkey contracts. The global advanced gas turbine market, in our  view, is likely to be smaller in 2014 as compared to 2013.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: Member-Supervisory Board, Daimler AG
texts.text: On Power Transmission, we've booked the fifth offshore grid connection platform which we call BorWin3,  however, at this time, on a strongly improved – and I repeat that it was strongly improved -- first management  concept. Looking ahead, we expect the market environment to remain highly competitive for our Energy sector in  mostly all business areas.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: Member-Supervisory Board, Daimler AG
texts.text: Wind Power reached only a 2.7% margin, already well below its earnings potential, for several reasons. While the  revenue and mix was less favorable, with a lower share of the higher margin offshore business, also new product  launches, and a steep capacity ramp-up in production led to higher cost associated to the production ramp-up.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: Member-Supervisory Board, Daimler AG
texts.text: Power Transmission continues to deal with a broad-based challenge arising from legacy issues such as the wind  access, good access in the North Sea, but also some other legacy projects which we reported on in Canada and the  likes, and had a loss of €188 million in the third quarter. As I said previously, there is no quick fix on this matter.  The division's new leadership team is working hard on the remedy since the Transmission business is a key  element of the value chain of electrification.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: Member-Supervisory Board, Daimler AG
texts.text: But there's also operational progress. Meanwhile, we installed four offshore grid platforms in the North Sea. The  average completion rate is about 80%, and commissioning will take place over the remainder of 2014, and into the  first half of calendar year 2015.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: Member-Supervisory Board, Daimler AG
texts.text: The Energy sector in its current set-up, and you know we are going to change the set-up as of October 1, has  several legacy matters such as Olkiluoto, the North Sea project, and others which do pose further financial risk  potential going forward.

file: SIE - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 30July2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: First, we made a recent agreement with the workers' representatives for comprehensive measures to improve  productivity and simplify structures in the support function areas. Implementation of these measures across the  organization is now in full swing to drive our performance towards 2016 and onwards. In total, you'll recall the  €274 million severance charges, €173 million of which is in the industrial businesses. Negotiations with the  workers' representatives for the recently announced actions on footprint optimization as well as fixing the  underperforming businesses are in well-advanced stages.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Second, we strengthened our core and closed the Dresser-Rand acquisition, giving us a significantly strengthened  offering and footprint, in particular for distributed power generation, including the oil and gas industry.  Integration has started and initial customer feedback is very encouraging, although the depressed oil price  remains a concern in the short term.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now let me highlight some key developments in the third quarter. The product and service business delivered  healthy order growth. However, compared to the same quarter a year ago, we saw some significant lower large  order volumes in Power and Gas, Wind Power as well as Process Industries and Drives, adding to an overall order  decline of 5% like-for-like.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Revenue was down about 3%, mainly driven by the project businesses, but Healthcare, Digital Factory and Energy  Management showed their strength in growing the business.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now let me take a closer look at some key developments in the division and the Industrial Business. Power and  Gas is diligently implementing its growth and productivity program, PG 2020, to improve its market and cost  position by footprint optimization and accelerated innovation. The environment remains challenging with global  overcapacities and aggressive competitive behavior.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the third quarter, orders were down on tough comps due to fewer turnkey projects. However, we succeeded  well in the market by selling 17 large gas turbines particularly through increased demand in the United States as  well as in Mexico.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Wind Power managed to swing to profit and delivered a margin of 3.6% including a strong contribution from the  service business. We expect the fourth quarter to be very robust in terms of orders, since we have already booked  some of those orders in July.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We like what we see on this slide with a lot of green color and I'm talking about Energy Management. The division  reached a profit margin of 3.7%, making steady progress across the businesses. The restructuring program,  Transform to Win, is well on track and will drive underlying profitability going forward in the quarters to come.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Process Industries and Drives faced lower volume from large orders from tough comps and ongoing weak demand  from commodity-related industries including metals and mining as well as oil and gas. Margins came back nicely  Q2 over Q3 towards the lower end of the target range. The challenges in oil and gas and other verticals remain in  place and, therefore, further measures to optimize the footprint and to reduce cost are underway.

file: SIE - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 4August2016 345 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Above and beyond our operational strengths and reliable execution, we will further accelerate our innovation  excellence and strengthen our portfolio in smart ways. In June, we announced the planned merger of the  Siemens Wind Power business and Gamesa. We intend to own 59% of the merged entity. We do have  substantial growth potential, highly complementary strength and a strong value proposition towards our customers  to help them get their cost down and revenues up.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: Industrial profit margin was at 10%, up 130 basis points year-over-year, with hardly any support from FX for the  company. Eight out of nine divisions are in the target margin range, with margin expansion in most divisions ,  particularly in Power and Gas, Energy Management and Wind Power.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We shipped 16 large gas turbines in the quarter, among those 7 H-class turbines. Our Egypt megaproject is  progressing well as planned, with 11 H-class turbines and 11 generators already at the foundation on site. This  ramp up was a major driver for a convincing revenue growth of 22% in the quarter. However, we expect revenue  growth to soften in the fourth quarter on tougher comparables in the divisions. As already mentioned, Wind Power  has taken in major orders including a €1.4 billion order from the Beatrice Offshore Windfarm in the UK. The  division increased its backlog to almost €16 billion. Strong backlog conversion and good service turns drove  revenue growth in both onshore and offshore.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: With €1.7 billion, we achieved the highest quarterly revenue ever in the wind business. The division is making  excellent progress in optimizing its supply chain and pushing for productivity on all levels. This and the better mix  help to drive the profit range beyond the target margin range to 8.3%. I would have to say the Wind Power team  has built a very solid performance track record and is ready for contributing a strong business into the world's  strongest wind enterprise together with Gamesa.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: We also like what we see from the Energy Management team who executed well on their plan and continue to  improve performance across most businesses, in particular transmission solutions and high-voltage products.  Also like the progress of the transformer business, which has been one of the, what we called, underperforming  businesses in the space. There's a profit margin of 8.3%. Energy Management is back on the target range and we  now expect the division to be in that range also for the full year in 2016 and counting.

texts.speaker: Sabine Reichel
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: The negotiations with the employee representatives regard to planned capacity adjustments and footprint  alignments are progressing reasonably well, and we do see a good chance to have an agreement by year-end  already.
