texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: For example, we were rewarded the order for the DolWin6 offshore grid connection from TenneT. Free cash flow  of €941 million was below prior year mainly due to the net working capital build-up at Siemens Gamesa.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: As indicated, Power and Gas continues to operate in a very challenging environment with declining markets. This  resulted in a sharply lower large order volume in the third quarter. In addition, the demand from oil and gas  customers is still sluggish. The fight for every single order is really fierce, and we see continued price pressure  due to over capacities. Lower order intake in previous quarters led to a revenue decrease of 11% particularly in  large gas turbine and compression businesses.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Combined with lower capacity utilization, this resulted in a margin decline of 140 basis points. Key focus of PG is  on adjusting their cost space, driving productivity, innovation and project execution. Our philosophy is to deliver  on our commitment. A good example is the Megaproject in Egypt where all 24 gas turbines have been delivered  within the agreed timeframe.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Already 12 gas turbines are in regular operation. After we had to catch up in turbine efficiency in the past years,  we are gaining now speed to drive technological upgrades and competitiveness. We improve our entire fleet with  new coatings, new materials, additive manufacturing and digital solutions to optimize output and life cycle cost.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: The HL family is paving the way to the next-generation of gas turbines entering into new performance levels north  of 63% with a clear roadmap to 65%. In this context, Duke Energy and Siemens have entered into a strategic  partnership to test and validate advanced gas turbine technologies.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Orders in the quarter were slightly down on tough comps in the transformer business. However, we expect a  strong order intake in the fourth quarter among others driven by the recently announced DolWin6 offshore grid  connection project with TenneT.

texts.speaker: Michael Sen
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: I'm going to spend a few moments to share some first conclusions and to give you an update on the areas that I  have responsibility for overseas. One area is Global Services, which encompasses IT, real estate, supply chain  management, and shared services. IT, for example, is a very crucial function, particularly when you look at  digitally transforming the enterprise and stirring up organizational agility. The two other areas are our Healthcare  business, Siemens Healthineers, and our renewable interest in Siemens Gamesa Renewable Energy.

texts.speaker: Michael Sen
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: It is primarily Siemens Healthineers and Siemens Gamesa Renewable Energy that I will be focusing on today.

texts.speaker: Michael Sen
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: We also continue to strengthen our portfolio with bolt-on M&A; the recent agreement to acquire Epocal from Alere  will make Siemens Healthineers the only company that covers blood-gas analysis from high volume, all bench-top  analyzers, all the way down to handhelds.

texts.speaker: Michael Sen
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: Now, let me move to Siemens Gamesa Renewable Energy. Last week, we have all seen the numbers and let me  be very clear from the outset, the business did not live up to its potential. As the major shareholder, our  expectation towards the leadership is clear. We expect a leading position in the industry and sustainable value  enhancement of our interest in the company.

texts.speaker: Michael Sen
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: As I've gained experience in this industry from the customer/utility side, I can tell you that there are three things  that are decisive to win in this market. First, it's cost. Second, it's cost. And third, it's cost. To be precise, it's the  cost for megawatt hour of electricity.

texts.speaker: Michael Sen
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: The question is who is most efficient in reducing the levelized cost of electricity more significantly and faster. The  Dutch Borssele offshore developments provide a case in point. DONG Energy, won the auction with a bid far  below the previous benchmark of €100 per megawatt hour. A few weeks ago, DONG Energy issued an awarded  letter for Borssele 1 and 2 to Siemens Gamesa 750-megawatt project, which makes me personally very happy. I  had also looked into this project from the utility side. And therefore, I'm particularly happy on this customer win.

texts.speaker: Michael Sen
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: Important initial integration steps have been announced. The combined organization is taking shape, portfolio  decisions are being taken. As an example, we expect to hear more about Adwen in the near future. Footprint  decisions are being prepared and taken such as the closing of the Tillsonburg blade factory in Canada.

texts.speaker: Michael Sen
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: To sum up, we put Siemens Gamesa Renewable Energy on track to win in the changing renewable market. And  they have the independence, size, scale, and financial strength to do so. Now, it's all about execution.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let me now come to the key figures of the fourth quarter. texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: As previously indicated, we saw a market driven slowdown of order activity in Fossil Power Generation while we  already mentioned large orders in Renewables compensated for this. texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Fossil Power Generation led all divisions with a profit of €407 million based on excellent project execution in its  Solution business. texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: The program contains a combination of growth investments in product development and footprint expansion as  well as productivity program to improve the cost position in Diagnostics and repositioning of the Radiation  Therapy business. One year ago, we set ourselves ambitious targets with the One Siemens framework to  continuously build on our strong and highly competitive, strategic and operational platform and improve  performance further.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: When you look at the charts, they were very encouraging. Our organic growth rate of 6.6%, so this is revenue  growth versus competition on the upper-left hand side, is 6.6% of Siemens, 3.3% below the 9.9% reported by our  peers. But we have to consider that some of our competitors significantly added to our top line through  acquisitions while we look for the right target prices at the right time. Despite some headwinds like particle  therapy charges in Healthcare and Solar impairment charges, all sectors are well within the targeted margin  ranges derived from our industry benchmarks.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Siemens AG
texts.text: Thank you very much, Peter. Very warm welcome also from my side. Let's see how that works here. Here we go.  And what I would like to continue with is the free cash flow generation. file: SIE - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 8November2012 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: However, let me start with a couple of key takeaways and financials of the fourth quarter of 2012. Orders were  moderately down by 4% year-over-year due to continued softness of the global economy impacting many of our  businesses, while Energy boasted organic growth due to a large number of orders, mainly in Fossil and Wind  Power. Revenue growth eased to 1% year-over-year, driven by strong backlog conversion in Energy and strength in  Healthcare.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Mostly due to the strong operational finish in the fourth quarter and positive impacts from below the fixed items,  we reached the lower end of our guidance for the full year. Revenue growth for the fiscal 2012 reached 3%, while  the book-to-bill ratio was at 0.98. Income from continuing operations came in at €5.2 billion, including significant  adverse effects from legal and regulatory on the lower right-hand side of the charts, and benefiting from  discontinuing the Solar business.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: The underlying business in Fossil and Oil & Gas was again healthy, with a strong product and service business. I'm  sure you saw our announcement with regard to the planned divestment of the Solar business, and therefore we are  reporting only Wind numbers instead of renewable, and moved our Solar activities to discontinued operations as  of Q4. Our Hydro activities, mainly the equity share in Voith Siemens Hydro, are now held at the Sector Energy  level.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Diagnostics is on schedule with its competitiveness program, while profitability was temporarily slightly lower. In  its short-cycle businesses, Industry delivered a solid performance in an increasingly volatile market. We are  cautious for the next quarter since we currently see a cooling down in important end markets such as automotive  and machine tool builders. Profitability was weaker due to the renewable offerings of the sector, such as wind  gearboxes and solar inverters. The sector took action to adjust capacities and optimize the portfolio in this area.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Industry is also rigorously executing on further focusing its portfolio with the acquisition of the Belgium software  company, LMS International, and the subsequent divestment of the Water business, which I will touch upon in a  few minutes in more detail.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let's move on to Infrastructure & Cities. Orders were down on a lower volume of large rolling stock orders, while  revenues were supported by strength in Americas. Profit margins saw in particular in the Power Grid Solutions &  Products business a nice upswing supported by strong earnings conversion from higher volume in low and  medium voltage. Building Technologies delivered again a seasonal strong profitability, driven by good demand for  its energy-saving solution and positive impact from cost reduction actions.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: SFS, obviously be coming in at €100 million-plus, which was well above what we had been hoping for, reason  being that this has also been positively impacted by a few favorable one-offs. But what you also see in Q4, and we  expect that to be continuing, is that some credit hits are showing off along the lines, most of them coming from the  renewable environment. This is not a default, but we could clearly see that there is some stress in the system,  which we carefully watch. We don't expect major adverse impacts in 2013, but this is something which we see  coming. It could also be serving as an early indicator that matters are cooling in terms of economic impact.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: First, with Siemens 2014, we are stepping up our efforts in improving our cost position, and in this area we will  also see the vast majority of our activities. The single-largest lever for optimizing the cost base is our supply chain  management, where we see further potential to generate productivity gains of, in total, at least €3 billion in the  next two years, and Joe will elaborate this in a minute. A second major lever will be continuously to optimize our  global capacity and footprint with a business-by-business approach. For example, we have announced in recent  weeks several measures, such as the market-driven capacity adjustments of 600 people in U.S. Wind factories.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: As a third topic, we see significant potential to further improve process efficiency and quality, such as improving  the projects' execution excellence in the Projects businesses, in our large Infrastructure businesses, and  particularly in the Sectors Energy and Infrastructure & Cities. And as I said, this second lever, strengthening our  core activities, is of significant essence, and you can see further proof in today's announcements. We'll work with  rigor to improve our portfolio and strengthen the strongholds, but also fix underperforming businesses or find  sustainable solutions elsewhere.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: In terms of, as you can see from a series of examples, we are already well underway to execute on Siemens 2014,  particularly in the cost reduction portfolio area, and we will give you continuous updates on the various topics  over the coming quarters and also deep dives and proof points during Capital Market Days and investor  conferences. The first one coming up will be Energy, and then Infrastructure & Cities in March next year.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: A few weeks ago, we announced the divestment of our solar activities, where the framework conditions have  obviously significantly deteriorated, and as you all know, the solar market faces substantial overcapacities, strong  price pressures in the photovoltaic area, whereas CSP, the concentrated solar power, has remained more of a  niche technology. Solar was moved to discontinued operations, and delivered around €200 million in sales and  even bigger losses, including an impairment charge of €150 million in Q4 2012. We are in discussions with  potential buyers, and we will update you accordingly.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Going forward, our renewable offering is focused on Wind and Hydro. Today, Sector Industry announced also the  acquisition of the Belgium software company, LMS International, a well-established provider of CAE software for  simulating and testing mechatronic systems, mainly in the automotive and in the aerospace industry.

texts.speaker: Peter H. Löscher
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: However, Sector Industry is further focusing their portfolio and allocating resources to the most promising  businesses. The water treatment actives which have been part of the Industry Automation division will therefore  be divested. We thoroughly assessed the options and came to the conclusion that there are too limited synergies of  the water treatment activities with our core automation drives and industrial software businesses. After a  successful restructuring over the last 18 months, we have put this mainly U.S.-based business, with more than €1  billion revenue, up for sale.  And Joe will go now into the details of the other Siemens 2014 levers, so over to you, Joe.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: As far as the operational topics are concerned, you'll see one each from the four sectors. And it's not really helpful  for everyone to go through the technical details of it, but if you only look at them on what they get us in terms of  savings, you can see the design-to-cost matter in Fossil frames get to the €250 million to 2014. The consolidation  of mechanical drives in the Sector Industry, which is a somewhat sensitive matter because you talk about  manufacturing footprint here, and manufacturing footprint and consolidation always means that there is some  sort of value-add to a consolidation, but that also will provide us a meaningful three-digit number on savings, and  you will see a series of those topics especially related to Industry and Infrastructure where there is a majority of  manufacturing plants around the world.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: So if you take all that together there, all those four examples, what you'll see here already accounts for about €600  million out of cost reductions or productivity. That's only a few examples, and you will see more of those in a deep  dive when we do have the Sector Capital Market Days, the first one, as Peter mentioned, starting with Energy in  December 2012.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Managing Board, Siemens AG
texts.text: And obviously it's not just about purchasing being the biggest, the best lever; it is also about the area where you  best put it. It's sustainable, because it involves everything, it gives a sustainable value, also to the suppliers that  are negotiating, and then one's a dollar short, the other one is a dollar long, and the moment the power changes, it  goes the other way. So there is very little restructuring involved. It goes quick. The savings are quicker. About 40%  – four-zero – 40% of the total cost of the company is about purchasing of services and bill of materials. So you can  clearly see how huge the impact is, and this is what we're going to go about. Now, obviously the design-to-cost  element is nothing which is for the short term; this is more related in its impact to 2014.

file: SIE - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 7November2013 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: So we ended the fiscal year at €4.2 billion, profit from continued operations after tax including a gain of about  €400 million through the disposal of NSN and about a reclassification of the solar business which accounts to  about €300 million. So all-in-all, this is also a sort of a like-for-like guidance.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We've seen quite a strong Healthcare performance, which is on the top end of the EBITDA margin band. We like  what we see in both growth as well as profitability. Other areas have some work to do. That is true for energy as  well as for industry and predominately for the Infrastructure & Cities Sector. I would expect all those sectors to get  significantly closer to where they should be in terms of their margin bands in 201 4.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: If we go quickly on the regional aspects of our business, as it comes to fiscal Q4, as what I said fiscal 2013, later on  you can clearly see that the Americas have been quite, quite active in terms of order growth. That's  of course due  to the fact that we have seen a resurgence of the tax benefits associated with Wind. So we've been booking a lot of  orders in both Wind, as well as the associated areas if it comes to gearboxes and the likes. We also do see decent  order behavior in Fossil in the United States, and we expect that to continue also into the year of 2014.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Energy, it's been a decent development in 2013 given the aspects of transformatory charges as well as our  challenges which we have in the Power Transmission, that's been the area that has a lot of work to do and we  continue to execute on our turnaround program. It will take time and there are, of course, uncertainties if it comes  to legacy projects such as the access offshore as Olkiluoto and minor other things. So those aspects are also and  those uncertainties are also considered to play a role in the 2014 outlook.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Other than that, we will also combine the Fossil products together with the Oil and Gas products in order to make  sure that we see the full range of turbines from the lower end all the way up to 560 megawatts, 580 m egawatts on  our H-frame 8000 so we do expect synergies coming from that combination by the year 2015. So we continue to  accelerate and use all our opportunities, which we still do see in a last but not least attractive Energy sector going  forward.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: If you look at the numbers, Wind power's been weak in terms of orders but that's project-based so that does not  mean there is underlying weakness. We've seen quite the strengths for the quarters which we had in 2013, thanks  to the renewed tax credits in the United States and that will also play, as you can see, a major role in our revenue  development going forward.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: If you go to the area of Below Total Sectors, it's always been an area which has been calling for volatility. One of  the most volatile aspects from the recent quarters and recent years we've been solving by the sale of our NSN  stake. So we are basically left with some areas there like Bosch Siemens Appliances, as well as some parts of the  Enterprise PBX business. So if you expect a €100 million contribution per year in 2014 that should actually carry  your model in a meaningful way. Siemens Energy Services and Centrally Managed Portfolio Assets should just b e  about what we had in 2013.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: As far as the quite remarkable amount of disposal has been concerned, we've been completing Turbocare by  selling it to the Wood Group. TLT is sold. Oncology ramp down has been completed. Water, we just announced as  late as yesterday.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Well, first of all we do expect markets to be still not coherently up. If it comes to energy we do see some weakness  in fossil in the European environment. This is true for both new orders, new projects as well as service to servi ce  part of it due to the fact that utilization is somewhat volatile, talking about Europe. There is work to do in the  transmission area to fix our division and this is important to us as well as getting it back to where it belongs to be.  Wind should be fine in terms of delivering steady merchants.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: And last but not least, we obviously have been seeing that for quite some time, that process industries is an  attractive area to be at. You should also know that Siemens got a bunch of very, very good products to serve that  market. And that's why we have been announcing a corporate project, which will be led by Mr. Herweck, who used  to be the Strategy Officer of Siemens, on how to better penetrate the Process Industries market. We believe this is  important. We believe we've got opportunities, and the project will reveal those opportunities on how we are going  to access that environment, among other things, in the industry space.

file: SIE - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 6November2014 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Mariel von Drathen
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations
texts.text: While Joe will give the overview, Lisa will provide more details on the energy business, and Ralf will illustrate the  financials. After that, we have time for Q&A with Joe, Ralf, and Lisa. And with that, I would like to now hand over  to you, Joe.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Unfortunately, the challenges in the Energy sector accumulated throughout the year and led to a full-year EBITDA  margin of only 8.1%, which obviously is well below our own aspirations and strongly weighing on the operational  and, of course, also, overall results. And Lisa will talk about this in more detail later.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, let's have a quick look at the regional aspects of our business during the fourth quarter. While Europe and  Middle East was the order growth engines in Q4, United States and China were a stronghold in regional revenue  growth. In Europe, we benefited strongly from several large offshore wind orders in the UK, in Germany, as well  as in The Netherlands. We did see excellent success in the Transportation business in the United States such as  the large light rail order in San Francisco worth about €483 million.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, as far as Energy is concerned, I'd like to hand it over to Lisa and talk about the opportunities and challenges  we have in Energy. Lisa.

texts.speaker: Lisa Davis
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board
texts.text: All right. Thank you, Joe, for the introduction, and also, welcome and good morning to everyone from my side.  Looking at the fourth quarter performance in our Energy sector, we clearly saw the impact of a very competitive  market on our order books with an organic decline of 5%. This was mainly driven by fewer power generation sales  in the Americas. Our book-to-bill ratio was just shy of 1 with 0.99, and we have a strong order backlog of €58  billion.

texts.speaker: Lisa Davis
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board
texts.text: Power Generation delivered a solid margin of 13%, albeit lower than one year ago. While the service business held  up well, we saw the impact from the competitive large gas turbine market in our margins as well.

texts.speaker: Lisa Davis
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board
texts.text: Wind Power has been strong in orders due to a number of large project awards, although even with this,  profitability was disappointing. The primary factors for the significant profit swing were charges totaling €223  million for two key topics.

texts.speaker: Lisa Davis
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board
texts.text: First, charges for inspecting and replacing main bearings due to the early degradation of these bearings for a  certain onshore wind turbine type. These issues appear to be related to recent batches of bearings, and we are in  close discussion with our supplier.

texts.speaker: Lisa Davis
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board
texts.text: Second, we had to take significant charges for blade repairs caused by harsh weather conditions, both offshore and  onshore. This is a topic which we see across the industry and where we have already successfully implemented a  design change for leading-edge protection in our manufacturing facility. We'll also roll out a similar retrofit at  affected locations.

texts.speaker: Lisa Davis
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board
texts.text: On the positive side, the four offshore grid connection projects are now installed in the North Sea, and  commissioning takes place. Two of them are already in trial runs, and overall percentage of completion is now  above 80%.

texts.speaker: Lisa Davis
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board
texts.text: As Joe mentioned, I want to give you a brief overview on the action plan we have put in place to address the  challenges in Power Generation and Wind Power. In recent years, we have seen some fundamental shift in the  new equipment market, particularly for gas turbines. Demand for large gas turbines is clearly lower than expected,  while the market for smaller turbines and decentralized generation has been growing significantly, and this shift  will continue. This development holds particularly true for Europe where utilities are reluctant to invest due to  high uncertainty about the payback, as we have seen soft demand and overcapacity in the market results in market  consolidation and price and margin pressure.

texts.speaker: Lisa Davis
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board
texts.text: Wind business is operating an attractive market and we have great opportunities due to our leading position in a  fast-growing offshore market and a rapidly emerging service business based on our installed fleet of more than 25  gigawatts. As already mentioned, moving from a handcraft production to industrialized structures along the entire  value chain is causing some friction.

texts.speaker: Lisa Davis
texts.profession: Member-Managing Board
texts.text: We have a comprehensive set of actions in place to bring margins back to the industry level. First, we put  additional resources in place with a strong focus on improving engineering processes and quality management.  Second, we work continuously on further cost out and industrialization to drive down the levelized cost of  electricity. And third – our third focus is bringing new products to the market with higher performing turbines  also for low-wind locations and rapidly developing a strong service business in the installed base.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Please keep in mind that Unify, remaining metals projects and our Postal & Baggage Handling business are  undergoing significant structural changes which may have an impact on the CMPA result. SRE is, as usual,  depending on disposal gains, but we see them lower than in fiscal 2014.

texts.speaker: Josef Käser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Power & Gas and Energy Management will be the biggest contributors to achieve a book-to-bill above 1. Pricing  should be down by around 2.5% of revenues overall, with Wind Power, Power & Gas and Healthcare being affected  the most.

file: SIE - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 12November2015 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now let me highlight some key developments in the fourth quarter. Orders as reported increased by 15% and were  clearly up by 6% organically on the back of many large orders in all power-related businesses such as the Power  and Gas, Wind and Energy Management.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Revenues as reported increased by 4% organically. It was moderately down by 4%. As we have obviously expected,  driven by the project business, while Energy Management, Building Technologies, Healthcare and Digital Factory  showed strength also in growing the business.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let's now have a quick look at the regional aspect of our business during the fourth quarter. Europe and Middle  East, the order growth engine in Q4, United States delivered a solid and a broad-based revenue growth. Germany,  we benefited strongly from the large offshore wind order called Veja Mate which is about a 400-megawatt wind  project coming together with a 15 years of service agreement.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Bookings were significantly up due to some large order wins. And in total, we are able to take about 10 large gas  turbines into our books, which helped increasing our market share for the full fiscal year from about 20% to 25%.  As expected, profitability in Power and Gas was impacted by low margins in the large gas turbine and solution  business, while the service business remained very solid. We also benefited from a project settlement adding  about €55 million to the bottom line.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Wind Power delivered a strong finish in most aspects. While orders came in high as previously forecasted.  Revenues were primarily down on lower onshore revenues. Margin improvement to 4.8% delivered a decent  turnaround just a bit shy of the targeted range. The division executes well on its comprehensive productivity and  quality program and will continue so in 2016, although, it will take time to show the desired result.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As promised, Energy Management delivered an excellent performance, especially comparing to where we come  from in all metrics and reached a profit margin of 7.5% for quite some time. The first quarterly performance was  in the target margin range, and we really do like to keep it that way. Main reasons were higher revenues in the  transformer and smart grid businesses and strong profit contribution from the solution business. Free cash flow  was impressive with €1.1 billion in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We also did make substantial progress in working through the legacy project, for example, in Canada, and saw  also some positive completion effects elsewhere. The Energy Management transition program is well on track to  steady drive progress in profitability and growth going into fiscal 2016.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Building Technologies again has quite a seasonally strong fourth quarter with what we believe was a decent  revenue growth particularly in the higher-margin product and service business. Just to give you one example on  how excellent our customer relationship and the customer proximity in the BT business has been shows our new  strategic technology partnership with Credit Suisse environmental real estate fund where we evaluate and  optimize the CO2 footprint prior to their investments into their buildings. In addition, the stringent execution of  productivity measures helped to mitigate the effects from the appreciation of the Swiss franc which still weighs on  the business.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Now, what are our main assumptions for the items below Industrial Business for fiscal 2016? As I said, we'll  continue to operate on a similar operational level as in fiscal 2015. Centrally managed portfolio activities contain a  number of assets, such as Unify, until its closing, remaining metals project, ramping down of solar, and the Postal  & Baggage handling business. These assets are undergoing further structural changes and, therefore, we expect a  negative impact and some volatility going forward.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: This quarter included also inflows of €2.2 billion from a significant decrease in operating net working capital,  mainly from lower inventories in the energy-related project businesses. In addition, the Egypt orders had a  significant positive impact of around €0.5 billion on advances received. Other than in previous years, we saw for  advances and billings in excess in fiscal 2015, a positive impact of around €900 million.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: First of all, we have set a clear target to lower project-related charges through improved risk mitigation. The  improvement was significant, since project-related charges in the Industrial Business declined to around €200  million in fiscal 2015. Furthermore, we accelerated the cost savings related to our functional cost reduction  activities, which we had been guiding conservatively. We reached around €400 million savings already in fiscal  2015, well ahead of the €150 million to €200 million originally guided.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Former Siemens' compressor unit has been integrated as of July 1 into the new Dresser-Rand business. We expect  significant synergies by combining those units. As promised at our Q3 conference call, we want to give you some  data on how the Dresser-Rand business looks like starting into fiscal 2016. These numbers for the fourth quarter  of fiscal 2015 show already pro forma, the new setup of the Dresser-Rand business which is an integral part of the  Power and Gas division. You can see that the strategic logic of the acquisition is really working very well. For  example, we want a break through order in large-sized LNG in the United States where we will deliver gas turbine  driven refrigeration compressor train.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Now, the landmark order is a combined 18-year service contract for both aero-derivative gas turbines from Rolls- Royce and the related compressors from Dresser-Rand. The synergies of around €200 million until 2019 has been  confirmed by the management team, of which 25% will be delivered in fiscal 2016. Additional savings are under  review. Putting this together, we see stabilizing orders but a book-to-bill ratio below one due to the challenging  market environment.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: 2015, our R&D intensity increased by 30 basis points to 5.9% of revenue. Our R&D investment will grow further to  around €4.8 billion in fiscal 2016. As you can see from these examples, the focus topics for R&D are linked to  growth areas and profit stronghold indicating a stringent resource allocation, both in R&D. Our innovation is not  about input, it is all about outcomes.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And the ones who already visited our electronics factory in Amberg or the twin factory in Chengdu certainly  became an impression how the Internet of Things look like other than hear a lot of stories about it. As a second  example out of many more, I'd like to highlight the new DC grid connection solutions which we recently  announced. This is much about driving cost down in a very significant way. The reconnections are very vital for us  to achieve the target of €0.10 per kilowatt hour to offshore wind. Instead of building a large central converter  platform, as we did in the past, our new concept builds on smaller, lighter and more flexible decentralized  platforms. And the benefits are impressive.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: There is huge demand in the market for digital services. For example, our 40 data-drive flex long-term term  service contract has been sold cleverly by our power generation services. In a nutshell, executing our Vision 2020  milestone is on track and we will continue to deliver what we promised.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: However, we do see plenty of opportunities to chase in all part of the global world. We'll find them, we'll take them  and we execute. Pricing should be down by slightly 2% of revenues overall with Power and Gas, with power and  healthcare being affected the most.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Supporting our midterm growth agenda, for businesses, such as Wind Power, Digital Factory or Energy  Management, CapEx investment will be going up substantially in fiscal 2016. Although, we are excited about our  energy efficiency program for our buildings and factories to cut the carbon footprint in half by 2020, at least this  year to neutral by 2025.

texts.speaker: Joe Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We'll be the first company in our space and our size which steps up and show the way for an economically sound  environmental CO2 concept. In the case of the current levels of the euro United States – U.S. dollar exchange rate,  we see only modest tailwind on the Industrial Business margin going forward.

file: SIE - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 10November2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Now, let's have a look at the key developments by division in the fourth quarter. Power and Gas is swiftly  executing its measures to strengthen go-to-market productivity and enhanced technology to counter aggressive  prices behavior. These investments will significantly strengthen our competitiveness. We are making good  progress to improve our footprint and deliver cost savings.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Overall, the market, especially on the large turbine environment, remains challenging with sluggish demand on  the back of global overcapacities. Bookings are down in Q4 on tough comps due to a sharper lower number of  large orders. We at least recovered several large orders in the year, including several hundred million euros for  the make-up project in Egypt. Revenues were significantly up on strong backlog conversion and a material  contribution from the Egypt orders. In total, we delivered 16 large gas turbines in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: The team is working hard and did a great job to gain market share from about 25% a year ago to now close to  30% in large gas turbines. We also saw material market share gains in the small and medium gas turbine  segment, and we do intend to continue that path. Also, Dresser-Rand integration has progressed very well. The  business achieved a margin improvement of 140 basis points year-over-year, excluding transformation costs. The  ramp-up of synergies is ahead of plan. We already realized about €70 million in fiscal 2016.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Wind Power delivered again an excellent performance with 8.3% profit margins on the back of strong growth  conversion and significantly improved execution. After nine months of very strong order growth, bookings were  down in Q4 on lower large orders volume. The prior year, we booked, among other things, the €1.2 billion  offshore order, Veja Mate. The division has built a sustainable execution track record and announced a number of  few new turbine models during the Hamburg wind fair, a strong foundation to enter into the planned merger with  Gamesa.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: As promised, Energy Management delivered an impressive performance in all metrics and reached profit margins  of 8.4%, which is well within the target range and with improvements in most of its business. And there's more to  come due to further productivity measures and innovation. Top-line, we clearly outperformed our competitive  environment. Orders are up in the high voltage products and digital grids businesses, as revenues are driven by  the solutions and transformer business.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Building Technology had, again, a seasonally very strong fourth quarter with double-digit margins on tough  comps. Order growth was mainly driven by a strong base business and contract wins for energy efficiency  projects mainly in the United States. We did make very good progress to drive a digital transformation and  increase the number of connected sets by 28% in fiscal 2016. The number of connected data points reached  almost half a million items.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Process Industries and Drives continue to be affected by ongoing weakness in oil and gas and other commodity - related markets with sign of finding a bottom. As expected, the profit margin turned negative due to about a €200  million in severance charges to execute necessary structural realignments and capacity adjustments.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: First of all, we further accelerated the functional cost savings measures and achieved the €1 billion savings target  ahead of plan. We have further substantial measures across the company in place to deliver on a sustainable  basis our 3% to 5% productivity target. The team has a tight grip around the measures which are executed based  on a stringent operating model.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: In fiscal 2016, we made further substantial progress in risk management and project execution. There was no  negative net effect. Project-related charges or cost overruns were compensated by reversals due to improved  delivery in other projects. To illustrate this positive development, I've picked two examples. Mobility has achieved  in a number of crucial projects such as Velaro Eurostar, ICE4 and Thameslink important milestones on time.  Power and Gas mega project in Egypt to build three combined-cycle power plants with 14.4 gigawatts is on track  to deliver first power to the grid by the end of this calendar year. We will see around 40% of revenue recognition  of the solution-related project value of €3.6 billion in fiscal 2017 from them.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: We're building on our leading global number one position in automation across our domains and drive  digitalization and enhance our integrated offering, electrification along our, what we call, EAD strategy,  Electrification, Automation, Digital enterprise.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: A key element of Vision 2020 is the continued ambition to strengthen our portfolio along our strategic imperatives.  As you can see, we made further decisive moves and continued progress. The announced merger with Gamesa  to create a leading wind power player received a fabulous approval of the Gamesa shareholders with 99.75%.  Scheduled to achieve closing is on track and we expect to consolidate the financials of the new entity as of fiscal  Q3 in 2017.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: The existing cooperation in Digital Factory and Process Industries and Drives will be significantly expanded  across all Siemens domains, such as energy management, mobility or building technologies. With strengthened  ties, we have also invested around €70 million in secondary shares under a company program that will continue  until such a time as Bentley Systems stock is publicly traded.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Secondly, we do drive industry-specific approaches across all the divisions or verticals such as food and  beverages, oil and gas, chem-and many other interesting areas, including a more process-oriented specific  design in discrete industries.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: A recent success was the award of a front-end engineering and design contract from LNG company, Cheniere, for  a midscale liquefaction project to us and our partners. In many of our businesses, the customer journeys are  changing. We do see customers who educate themselves through social media and to also expect highly efficient  transactions through digital channels with our suppliers. Therefore, we're currently developing a new B2B platform  to take these changes into account and further expand our digital sales volume.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and CEO, Siemens AG
texts.text: Next assumption is that negative pricing should be around 2.5% of revenues overall with power and gas and wind  power being affected the most. Regarding productivity, we do expect to be in the range of 3% to 5% and the  meaningful assumption would be just the midpoint to that.

file: SIE - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 9November2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Organic revenues grew moderately by 3%, while book-to-bill was at 1.3 (sic) [1.03]. Placed orders below €50  million also showed clear growth in fiscal 2007 (sic) [2017], very important that's, obviously, associated to the  short-cycle performance. Industrial Business margin of 11.2% was up 40 basis points year-over-year and reached  the increased target corridor of 11% to 12%. Although, we have been challenged for some market, as well as  internally-driven topics, which we need to take care of in the Siemens Gamesa Renewable Energy environment.  Earnings per share grew 10% to €7.44 compared to fiscal 2016 and well within the raised guidance.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: As a key pillar of Vision 2020, we achieved major milestones in strengthening our portfolio during the course of  2017. We expanded our leadership in the digital enterprise through the Mentor Graphics acquisition, which  actually has turned out to be quite favorable as to what we were originally thinking. So, very valuable asset  integrating the physical, mechanical design together with the electrical design going forward. It already shows  now that this was a very important move to complete picture in the environment of simulation. The three important  steps in the portfolio like renewable energy, mobility and healthcare, we set strategic directions to give them more  independent, going to market innovation and obviously also resource allocation.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We continuously expand our data analytics and application capabilities to offer leading digital services, which  makes customer pay for because they get the value for it. A good example, outside Digital Factory which is  always being named is Mobility where we just have implemented digital service projects with more than 50 real  customers. It clearly shows us that our EAD system, electrification, automation, digital enterprise, is working. It is  the winning formula in the marketplace. However, obviously, one of the key areas and priorities for fiscal 2018  which we have and will tackle are the structural challenges at the Power and Gas division. We'll do that in a  prudent yet consequent way going forward.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We expect a further decline in the large gas turbine markets by around 40% for the period of 2017 to 2020 if we  compare that to the 2016 levels. And as a consequence of overcapacities and other behavioral aspects, prices  have come down significantly. We have thoroughly analyzed the market situation and our footprint and are close  to coming up with a comprehensive concept for a future-oriented setup at Power and Gas, mostly associated with  the area of larger turbines going forward.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: So, thank you, Joe, and also good morning from my side. Let me highlight now the performance of the divisions.  As we have pointed for quite some time Power and Gas continues to operate in a very challenging environment.  Global energy trends towards renewable lead to declining markets for new units across the portfolio. In addition,  the demand from oil and gas customers remains at low levels. This unfavorable environment, we booked orders  for 11 large gas turbines and 23 small and medium gas turbines.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: For fiscal Q1, we expect revenue to be clearly below prior year, which will have a corresponding negative effect  on the profit margin. Energy management outperformed competition once again on strong orders, up 23%, driven  by large transmission solution projects such as DolWin6. Profitability recovered from the weaker previous quarter  due to a decent performance in our product and system businesses.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Digital Factory's margin is a strong 20.5%, excluding severance impact from Mentor effect as well as expenses for  advancing the MindSphere platform. Process Industries and Drives showed again order growth up 9% after oil  and gas and commodity-related markets are stabilizing, while on the other hand, demand for wind power  component business fell substantially; main driver was the business in China with a sharp increase.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: China will see further industrial expansion, but on a more moderate level. Reflecting on Siemens, we expect the  mixed picture in our market environment in fiscal 2018 ranging from robust markets for our short-cycle businesses  to unfavorable dynamics in our energy generation markets, as well as geopolitical uncertainties that may restrict  investment sentiment. Negative pricing impact is expected to be around 2.5% of revenue.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Now, let me explain the outlook for our Industrial Business. As already mentioned, some of our businesses are  operating in a very difficult environment. Related measures to address capacity adjustments are still in progress.  But one thing is very clear, we will take decisive steps to strengthen our business and we will look at necessary  footprint adjustments.

texts.speaker: Ralf P. Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We believe this is ambitious. Let me explain you why. Most of our businesses, such as Energy Management,  Mobility, Building Technologies, the Healthineers and Digital Factory are extremely well underway, just to name a  few. They will compensate for significant headwinds, which we expect next year.

file: SIE - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 8November2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Siemens is growing, and in many of our businesses, we are stronger than ever. We're gaining further market  share in highly competitive markets, such as the industrial digitalization, automation, Building Technologies, or  first and foremost also in the Mobility sector. And we are rigorously addressing these challenges, in those areas  where the markets are structurally declining, we're shifting the center of gravity, for example, from fossil to  renewable energy generation.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We made excellent progress on our strategic priorities. If you think about the completion of the Egypt mega  project, which happened in a record time of less than 2.5 years after financial close. Each of the three 4,800  gigawatt power plants have become the largest gas-fired combined cycle power plant ever built in one piece and  operated in the world.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: In total, we added about 14.4 gigawatts capacity to the national grid of Egypt, which is obviously enough power to  serve more than 40 million people to be the backbone, of course, what we believe to lead to economic prosperity.  If we really look at it, we not only provided energy, we're also helping the country to save more than $1 billion on  an annual fuel cost compared to what they had in store and operating before the mega power grid's trigger.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: For us, it has resulted in something to help Egypt's power grid to be improving. It is also a crucial topic for us  when it comes to creating jobs and [indiscernible] (5:27) at a sustainable economic development. Trained 600  Egyptian engineers and technicians to make sure that they can properly operate and maintain the plants.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Let me now highlight the performance of our divisions. As we have mentioned for quite some time, Power and  Gas continues to operate in a very challenging environment. Global energy trend towards renewables led to  declining market for new unit, in particular for large gas turbine. Demand from oil and gas customers show some  signs of stabilization.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: We booked orders for 5 large gas turbines, 11 large wind turbines, and 12 small and medium gas turbines in the  quarter. The service business held up again very well and drove order growth of 13% with continuous strength in  the digital portfolio. Our backlog for so-called FlexLTPs has grown now to €7.5 billion, while Power and Gas total  backlog stands at €40 billion. A significant order contribution came from the contracts already mentioned by Joe  to operate and maintain three mega power plants in Egypt.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Some weeks ago, we agreed to a reconciliation of interest with the Central Works Council in Germany to  implement measures to boost competitiveness in Power and Gas. The goal is to save around €500 million  globally.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Energy Management continued its steady improvement path and closed its annual profit exceeding the €1 billion  threshold for the first time. In the quarter, all systems and product businesses recorded healthy order growth with  a very strong data center business.

texts.speaker: Ralf Peter Thomas
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: Top and bottom line, most of our divisions have demonstrated competitive strength and are on a positive  trajectory. We continue to expect revenue growth, market share gains and margin expansion in most of our  businesses. However, the positive momentum will be held back to some extent by declining power generation  markets, as already mentioned. Negative pricing impact is expected to be around 2% to 3% of revenue, with  stability in short-cycle and ongoing pricing pressure in power generation businesses. Personnel cost inflation is  expected to be in the range of 3% to 4%.

texts.speaker: Josef Kaeser
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Siemens AG
texts.text: The Mendix acquisition now closed on October 1, and we are starting to use – massively use the low code  platforms to speed up our application development, which obviously again in turn provides customer solution  which are – make customers willing to pay for a benefit there.

file: SIGN.XX1 - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 26February2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Rolf Stangl
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SIG Combibloc Group AG
texts.text: Generally, and in Europe in particular, there is a growing focus on the environment and on the recyclability of  containers in particular. We believe that the favorable profile of our aseptic carton tax puts us in a strong position  to meet these concerns and to retain our competitive position versus other forms of packaging.

texts.speaker: Rolf Stangl
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SIG Combibloc Group AG
texts.text: 2018 saw also the successful rollout in China of our combismile product, which is one of our key recent  innovations catering for the trends towards on-the-go consumption. combismile is produced on a new type of filler  machine that can be equipped with drinksplus enabling the customer to fill particulates and to offer products such  as, for example, ambient yogurt with real blueberries or cereals. combismile has now also been launched in the  U.S.A.

texts.speaker: Rolf Stangl
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SIG Combibloc Group AG
texts.text: I mentioned in my introduction the growing focus on the environmental profile in general but also on the  recyclability of packaging. Our starting point is that our packs are fully recyclable and recycling rates are  increasing. In Europe, the recycling rate now stands at 48%, and it's considerably higher than that in some other  EU countries. Our carton packs contain between 70% and 80% renewable material in the form of liquid  paperboard, but we have already gone a major step further with SIGNATURE PACK, the world's first aseptic  carton pack with a clear link to 100% plant-based renewable materials.

texts.speaker: Rolf Stangl
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SIG Combibloc Group AG
texts.text: SIG has also been a pioneer in responsible sourcing and certification. We're the first to offer our customers  globally FSC, Forest Stewardship Council, certified board. And in 2018, we were one of the first companies in the  world to achieve certification to the new Aluminium Stewardship Initiative, ASI, standard for responsible alu  sourcing. We carry our commitment to sustainability also into our manufacturing operations and in 2018 reached  our objective of 100% renewable energy two years ahead of schedule. I hope in my short introduction, I've given  you some idea of the steps we are taking to ensure the long-term and sustainable growth trajectory of our  business.

texts.speaker: Samuel Sigrist
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Chairman of Middle East Joint Venture, SIG Combibloc Group AG
texts.text: Our sourcing of LPB is split between our three major external suppliers and our Whakatane paper mill in New  Zealand where production is ramping up and which has now a potential to fulfill 20% to 25% of our needs. With  regard to aluminum and polymers, we hedge our exposure through 1 year rolling hedges covering approximately  80% of our purchases.

texts.speaker: Rolf Stangl
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, SIG Combibloc Group AG
texts.text: These qualities explain why many of our customer relationships have been in existence for an average of 25  years or more. And finally, we're leading the way in sustainability, which has become a crucial success factor in  the broader packaging industry and one in which carton in general and SIG in particular are well-positioned.
