texts.text: And in North America, we have 430 airports which needs to be renovated, we have 70,000 bridges  which need to be maintained, and we have 25 nuclear plants. Of course, some of these projects –  or a large number of projects depend on the availability of funds of governments. But if the bridges  collapse, at latest the governments will spend some money in order to come back to a reasonable  situation.

texts.speaker: Walter Grüebler, Chairman
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, it’s a great pleasure to welcome you to the first Media Conference and
texts.text: There is a next dimension, the megatrend sustainability. You remember last year we gave you a  documentation about our activities with regard to sustainability in CO2, in energy and in water. We  will provide you next year again with such a documentation, because here we have huge  developments.

texts.speaker: Walter Grüebler, Chairman
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, it’s a great pleasure to welcome you to the first Media Conference and
texts.text: In emerging markets, sustainability is a luxury topic – still a luxury topic. We talk about sustainability  in particular with latest technologies in the innovation and technology leader segment. In mature  markets, sustainability is a question of survival. Sustainability solutions will be introduced in the  base segment.

texts.speaker: Walter Grüebler, Chairman
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, it’s a great pleasure to welcome you to the first Media Conference and
texts.text: We see that, for instance, solar or in automotive, China makes huge efforts in order to have  sustainable solutions, in order to overcome their sustainability topics in their mega cities. And this  gives them a totally different advantage. You can imagine that if 50% or 60% of the world market is  in China, the Chinese competitors will have huge competitive advantage compared to the luxury  based western type of sustainability solutions.

texts.speaker: Walter Grüebler, Chairman
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, it’s a great pleasure to welcome you to the first Media Conference and
texts.text: 9 Global climate asks reduction of CO2 emissions. We see that we would like to allow reduction of  clinker by fly ash and limestone, reducing up to 5% of the global CO2 for the global world cement  production or concrete production. We reduced the concrete consumption by using admixtures with  about 1% impact on the global CO2, of course together with a competition.

texts.speaker: Walter Grüebler, Chairman
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, it’s a great pleasure to welcome you to the first Media Conference and
texts.text: We have blended cement which reduces the production – in the production the energy  consumption substantially. And we have weight reductions in cars, which also can add or help to  reduce the CO2 emission.

texts.speaker: Walter Grüebler, Chairman
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, it’s a great pleasure to welcome you to the first Media Conference and
texts.text: Increasing e-demand asks for a better e-management. First of all, the PU Roofing contributes to  15% energy savings compared to normal solutions. We have a good insulation effect on the  facade, on windows, on basements. And we support the wind energy and the solar energy with  bonding solutions, the wind energy on top with concrete solutions for the towers.

texts.speaker: Walter Grüebler, Chairman
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, it’s a great pleasure to welcome you to the first Media Conference and
texts.text: And we offer solutions which reduce the water consumption. Optimized water management will play  a key role. We see an increase of demand for respective constructions of reservoirs, sewage water  handling, purification facilities, dams, tunnels, pipes et cetera. And Sika is clearly the world leader  in waterproofing, which I will show you afterwards in a summary.

texts.speaker: Walter Grüebler, Chairman
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, it’s a great pleasure to welcome you to the first Media Conference and
texts.text: Innovation. We have, again, a large number of new innovations which will be introduced in the  market. First of all, i-Cure top sealing technology, a new hardener technology with a new dimension  of environmental protection and longer shelf life, solvent free, odor free, bubble free technologies.  In general, solvent free adhesives reduces the emissions, comply with future regulations. We can  reduce the curing period of adhesives, for instance, for automotive windshields, if you replace the  windshields.

texts.speaker: Walter Grüebler, Chairman
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, it’s a great pleasure to welcome you to the first Media Conference and
texts.text: Then structural bonding; faster production, high flexibility in materials, lighter cars. We have liquid  membranes, so with an easier application in complex environments, in particular for  modernizations, and we have for the gypsum production and make sure they speed up the process  at the time in manufacturing of gypsum boards.

texts.speaker: Walter Grüebler, Chairman
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, it’s a great pleasure to welcome you to the first Media Conference and
texts.text: 10 You see here some of the positions which we already have, with the latest figures. We are still  number two in concrete. The biggest competitor is BASF, but we grew again faster than BASF last  year. Roofing, we are number one, with the biggest competitor, Firestone. Waterproofing, we are  number one, with Grace as the biggest competitor. Flooring, we are number one, with RPM as the  biggest competitor. And Automotive, we are still number two, with Henkel as number one.

file: SIKA.AGREG - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 1March2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Ronald Trächsel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: If we look at the cost side, the other very critical element, I think you can see, we have some efficiency gains. Our  gross, now including acquisition, growth in the net sales, top line is 3.2%. If we look at the total raw material cost  increasing only by 1.1%, so we have clearly efficiency gains if you look at this.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Now let's look into a bit in the detail of these six points. First market potential, our markets at this point are  estimated at over CHF50 billion and all our define target markets you see here from the admixture for the  concrete to waterproofing, sealing and bonding, roofing, flooring, refurbishment and our markets in industry has  excellent growth opportunities.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Overall, we are the market leader. However, you see in the next slide, we're not yet the leader in all of these target  markets. We have a number one position in waterproofing and in flooring and in the other target markets we grow  faster than the main competitors, but still fantastic room to grow the company.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Innovations, just a few examples. As you know, Sika is not really a big producer of CO2, we have a very clean  production and so on. However, the sustainability trend is very important to us as our customers have here big  development opportunities. We have the cement industry as one of the highest producer of CO2. We have the car  industry and then also we have the general real estate housing industry where we are working with our customers  to come to zero-emission housings in the future. This is a trend. We are very excited and we believe that our  products can again be the leader in this sustainability at our customers.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: We have also some our chemicals, I have one example, we have a new hardener system, we call it i-cure for  'intelligent curing'. It's a new hardener system for all our adhesives in the polyurethane range. As you know, we  are the biggest producer of polyurethane adhesives worldwide, and now we have patented new solution to make  our products better from the performance and more environmental friendly. We could exclude some chemicals,  which are maybe going to be on the watch list in the future and also the product itself will be solvent-free and  odorless. So, we made a huge step in one of our most important technologies.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Maybe I would like to share two examples with you from last year. We had the big flood in Thailand, as you may  recall, starting in summer and really putting the country in a crisis. And you have seen the pictures, I think about  one-third of the factories in the country were under water. And then, of course, you can make big reports and say  how bad the situation is and that you have no chance to sell and so on.  Instead, our people secured the supply chain, so they were renting a warehouse on a hilly area, so they could  secure the supply. And, at the same time, they were preparing a new special product package to repair the  damaged factories. And we're starting to visit all our customers, for example, the large Nestlé factory, which was  under water and they were doing so by boat. So they were going to these thick industrial parts and visiting our  customers who were struggling with the situation and offering repair solutions for the damaged factories.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Another example I would like to share is Japan. As you know, on March 11, there was a huge earthquake and  tsunami and you know how much Japan is struggling from their own – with the supply chains, electric supply and  the country is a bit depressed and you can also read the newspaper many articles about the how difficult the  situation is in Japan.

file: SIKA.AGREG - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 28February2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I brought you three examples today out of the many we have. The first one is waterproofing for bridges. This is  very exciting because it's for refurbishment market. As you know, we have our life cycle concept, so our product  range works for the new build construction up to the refurbishment. This is a refurbishment solution where we  developed a new waterproof solution which is much faster than the existing systems. That means you are able to  the traditional system where you need significant more time and you have to close down the bridge and the traffic.  That is one example we are introducing in the markets.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And a second one is now also waterproofing, but this time it's for new buildings. It's basement waterproofing. We  developed a new exciting membrane solution to seal off the concrete basements in houses, buildings, and  infrastructure.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: This new system, traditionally you're using a bituminous solution to seal the concrete against water. And now we  are doing this with a membrane. On the back of the membrane, we have only the fleece so this system is bonded to  the fresh concrete and has a perfect seal. So even if you have one hole which can accrue at some point, you have no  lateral water intrusion into other areas. So this is an excellent system, very easy to apply, very flexible and – with  these prefabricated membranes, and we are now have started to roll out this solution worldwide.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We have then the third example I have is the new hardener system i-Cure, we presented this to you already several  times which is for our core technology for sealing and bonding which is the main part and backbone of Sika's  success. And here we have the new hardener system which enables us to fulfill much higher standards in emission  solvent-free products, and we are introducing this hardener system step-by-step for all of our Sikaflex products  and this is another one here, the sealant with very high UV resistant which we are now introducing into the  market.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: From the acquisition viewpoint, 2012, we had three acquisitions. I would say they were maybe a bit small volume  wise but very beautiful if you look at the countries where we were able to acquire these companies and also from  the target markets, very happy about the acquisition Yean-IL we did in Korea for waterproofing of panels. This is  very important, very big growth segment in the future in Korea where we have the sports events coming up and  they have huge investment plans for infrastructure planned for the future.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: You have seen some of our concepts when we talk from roof to floor with our seven target markets. I have shown  you two target markets of waterproofing and also sealing and bonding and to show you a little bit how the  innovation works in the practical life. We have also seen from the waterproofing from the new build to the  refurbishment also our life-cycle concept works.

file: SIKA.AGREG - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 4March2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: We acquired – the second biggest acquisition of Sika ever was the Building Adhesives business of AkzoNobel.  They are mainly active in Europe in the markets of Germany, France , Switzerland, Scandinavia and Eastern  Europe. Radmix, a specialty company for fibers for the concrete business in Australia.

texts.speaker: Adrian Widmer
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: In looking at the quarterly growth, we can clearly see an accelerating growth momentum throughout the year. Q1  was even slightly negative. This was largely due to very harsh weather conditions in the first quarter in Europe and  in North America, but also influenced by the public holiday pattern. So we effectively have to look at the first two  quarters in combination.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: What is even more exciting for us is that this growth takes place not on the countryside but in the cities. So we see  bigger cities, more cities, and we see the so-called megacities. This is very exciting for us because the bigger the  city, the more Sika products you need to use. Why? Because you have the high -rise buildings. The high-rise  building needs a totally higher concrete quality compared to low-rise housing. So if you want to build high-rise  buildings you need very high specification on your concrete. And we are of course very happy to support this with  our products. At the same time, all these megacities or the high-rise buildings, they have flat roofs.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Our roofing and waterproofing products, they are for flat roofs. We are not a tile manufacturer for the pitched  roofs, we do our membranes and our liquid PU and acrylic products are for flat roofs, and, you can imagine that  this city trend is a huge driver of our product -- demand for our products. At the same time, you also build  wherever you have space and land. Y ou're not concerned so much with water in the ground, like we were before.  So you build this high-rise building. They go very deep in the ground and they are also built in areas where you  wouldn't build before in the past. So you need plenty of good waterproofing to make these buildings happening.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Then of course all these buildings, the standard for safety, for fire standards, also for earthquake resistance, as you  can read in the media, is increasing year-by-year. And you need solid Sika adhesives and bonding products to  make this happening in the buildings.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: When we go to another leg of Sika in the motor vehicle industry, you see the trend for lighter cars, for electrical  cars, for safer cars. We have that in the newspaper every day. And one key trend behind this is that these cars are  using new materials. You all read about the BMW i3. That's the first mass vehicle built completely out of carbon  fiber. And this carbon fiber cannot be welded anymore like the traditional steel body of a car, it has to be bonded.  And they're using large amounts of adhesives, as you can imagine, to really  bond all these different carbon fiber  parts together.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: We have different trends also for other materials. The modern car is not a steel car anymore. They use a  combination of steel, of high-strength steel, of magnesium, of aluminum, and all these different material mix  cannot be welded anymore, it has to be bonded. So we have a huge increase of bonding applications in the motor  vehicle industry. And we are very confident that this is a very important megatrend for us in the future.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: We have then the third megatrend which is increasing the trend for Sika products is sustainability. We are all  aware of that. It's a huge task for everyone, so buildings in the future have to be better isolated, have to be better  sealed. And this can be done, of course, with fantastic sealing solutions from Sika. Also the durability and the  lifecycle concepts for these buildings, you need high quality to make these building last a very long time. Y ou see  the gentleman here enjoying the flat roof here in the megacity. And this gre en roof is only possible because we  have a special Sika membrane system underneath, which allows to grow plants and grass on the roof.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Last but not least, also our products have a big challenge. Of course, we want to be the front -runner with green  products. We don't want to harm any user with our products. And we have big developments to have safe  chemistry available for the consumer and the applicator. So these are the three megatrends which I want to  present to you, which we believe is a strong driver of the future growth. Of course, it doesn't come overnight. The  construction industry, the motor vehicle industry is conservative. They have a long planning period. So you will  see a positive effect of 1%, 2% or 3% each year for our markets, but I think for a very, very long period of time.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: We are focused with our core competencies of bonding, sealing, damping, reinforcing and protecting for these  seven target markets, to make the right additives for the concrete, provide liquid and membrane solutions for  waterproofing, the same for the roofing to have our epoxy, polyurethane floorings for factories, but also for  hospitals, for office buildings. We are one of the leading companies in sealing and bonding for construction and  for the motor vehicle industry. And last but not least, we offer the right repair and refurbishment solutions in all  our application fields.

file: SIKA.AGREG - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 27February2015 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let's look into some details about the markets. I'm sure you will have many questions later. But overall, it's really  astonishing how we can take off here in all regions. Maybe, the most positive market is the USA with the shale gas  boom.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let's move a little bit to innovation. I just want to briefly talk about three examples of innovation. First one is  mortars. We have an exciting new product for tile adhesive. This tile adhesive enables to have, with the same kilo  amount, to make 80% more tiles. Very simple; this product has a low density, so we can do with the same 20 kilo  or 25 kilo bag, we can make 80% more surface; very exciting. At the same time, 50% of the ingredients are  sustainable materials. And this is a slag sand, which comes from the iron production. It's a leftover product. And  we can replace cement with this slag sand from the iron factory.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The other product we have in there is the pumice stone. It's Bimsstein in German. And the pumice stone is,  basically, from the old lava fields you have everywhere in Germany. And this is an excellent filling material,  because low – it has such a low density, it swims on water. And this we use in the product. And our chemist made  this product [ph] happening (12:02). Same performance as a normal tile adhesive, but 80% more outcome. So you  can imagine how exciting this is for the craftsman. He can actually – he has less to carry.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Usually, the tile manufacturer or tile layer, he has to climb up all the floors in the buildings, and now he has to  take much less material, very exciting product; very sustainable. And in the last year, we grew already 30% with  this product and we will see another growth this year in the same dimension.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Another innovation I want to share with you is in concrete. We always talked about how we work on the next  generation of polymers to make concrete stronger, make it faster. And this is a new polymer now for better, longer  workability.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Until now, our admixture for concrete has a maximum working time of two hours. So, from the concrete factory to  the final application, you only have a window of two hours. And you can imagine, in today's traffic environment,  especially in the megacities, but also, this very complex infrastructure sites with long tunnels, high buildings,  steep buildings, it's not easy to manage within two hours.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the other side we get some – request a tailwind. Y ou always request it from the raw materials. We, of course,  see it now. The crude oil came between $50 to $60 from over $100; and after this time, like we always discuss, of  four months to five months, we now of course see significantly lower input costs.

texts.speaker: Paul Johann Hälg
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: We made two proposals to overcome this problem. One obviously would be 100% takeover of Sika, the most clean  and clear one. Then there would be no competition, is 100% ownership, so not an issue. We understand that this  might be a bit difficult to finance, so we made a second proposal, which follows the same logic: namely, that Saint - Gobain would bring in their mortar business into Sika; could be a capital increase in Sika, or could be a combined  cash payment and a capital increase.

file: SIKA.AGREG - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 26February2016 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Paul Schuler
texts.profession: Regional Manager-EMEA
texts.text: The forecast in investment, in infrastructure and energy is expected to grow over 380 billion, so quite a exciting  number for us. According to the strategy 2018, we decided to analyze Africa at the beginning of 2013. And we went  to 54 countries and analyzed the political stabilities, the demographic trends, the infrastructure spend, as well as  the GDPs on one side. And the other side, we went then to the micro criterias where we looked at the cement  consumption and the market potential for concrete as well as the mortars, tiles and adhesives. So then, we ended  up with 25 countries and along ways. And finally, we decided to go with 10 countries in the next three years to four  years to develop them, that was in 2013.

texts.speaker: Paul Schuler
texts.profession: Regional Manager-EMEA
texts.text: Then there is a big huge fertilizer plant in Lagos, unbelievably huge, and they pour concrete every day. Around 15  trucks to 20 trucks arrive on this construction site with our liquids and with our products in the concrete. So, huge  potential and great business for us and there are so many projects in Lagos, unbelievable.

texts.speaker: Paul Schuler
texts.profession: Regional Manager-EMEA
texts.text: So huge project also in Egypt, where they build a huge mall and then a mall like that, we start from the roof with  our PVC membranes. We have floors in there, we have sealiong and bonding, we have the windows, the glass, then  we put concrete. This is a project below the water levels, so they need a lot of SikaProof and waterproofing  products. So, huge potential on a mall like that. And that's only four projects where we have hundreds. It's huge,  but also we have to get it and we don't know when they start to build. But in future, I am convinced that Africa will  have a great future in the Sika world, and Sika will enjoy the business over the next 20 years, 30 years to grow.

texts.speaker: Christoph Ganz
texts.profession: Regional Manager-North America
texts.text: Another project is the Tesla Gigafactory, it's called officially where they produce batteries for cars, but as well as  for homes, in the middle of the desert of Nevada. It started also. We could supply already the floor. So it's a huge  building as you can imagine, and there is now of course more – there are more opportunities to come for us.

texts.speaker: Christoph Ganz
texts.profession: Regional Manager-North America
texts.text: Then there are a lot of arenas being built in the U.S. every year. And an arena in the U.S. is worth between $1  billion and $2 billion. So the two arenas you see there, they're all $2 billion projects and for us, again, great  opportunity for membranes. So what you see on the roof there in white, these are white PVC membranes that we  manufacture in Canton, Massachusetts in our factory. And on the left, you see the State Farm Arena. This is a so- called liquid waterproofing. They don't apply membranes. They apply, like paint, of course, the coating. We call  this, to make the roof waterproof. A lot of shopping malls consumption in the U.S. this what drives the economy,  and this is a $1.5 billion project in the Miami, new shopping mall where we also could supply a lot of products  into.

texts.speaker: Christoph Ganz
texts.profession: Regional Manager-North America
texts.text: Sometimes, we can sell all our products, again, from sealants, roofing material, waterproofing material, concrete.  So lot of liquids going into concrete in New Y ork especially after 9/11, they started to build so-called high-strength  concrete, really the best.

file: SIKA.AGREG - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 24February2017 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Multi-company for the Hong Kong market, and then insulation for our facade building envelope and roofing  strategy, beautiful business in the U.S. with three factories. So very promising for the years to come, and then,  just last week, we closed the waterproofing acquisition in Austria, Bitbau, with CHF 50 million in sales. Also a  fantastic business for the technologies and for our market share in Austria and the neighboring countries.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: For the market penetration, maybe a few comments I like to make is we have fantastic megatrends going in our  direction, which – the number one being the urbanization. Everyone talks about population growth in the world,  and for us, the fortunate situation is that all this population growth is happening in the cities, and cities need plenty  of Sika products. So, whenever you make a high-rise building, you need our additives for the concrete, you need  our waterproofing, you need our flat roof waterproofing, you need our park decks, plenty of Sika products, plus all  the infrastructure, all the tunnels, the bridges, the water treatment plants.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Similar exciting is the life-cycle concept we have in construction. You see here three lines, you see the  infrastructure, that's the first cycle in an emerging market. So, what we see now a lot, for example in the African  market, so the infrastructure means, we are building from water treatment plants, to airports, to seaports, to power  plants, to the first high-rise buildings, to bridges and tunnels for the traffic, and the great thing is that, all these  projects follow international construction standards, meaning they need Sika products to achieve the right level of  concrete, the right level of water-proofing and so on, very exciting.

texts.speaker: Jan Jenisch
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: And so, this gives us the opportunity to come into these markets very early, and then we get ready for the second  cycle, which is market education and building standards, so that high-performing Sika products we see in the  global infrastructure projects will then come into the general market and they will start to use our additives, they  will start to use our mortars and so on, and that's the second life-cycle we focus on. And the next cycle is, at least  as exciting as the first two, that's the repair and refurbishment. We are in the fortunate position that we have a full  product range and a full technical sales force for all the re-roofing, the re-flooring, the concrete repair, everything  you need to do after a city is established or infrastructure is being built.

file: SIKA.AGREG - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 23February2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Paul Schuler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Another exciting one in Italy, CHF 115 million, it's the leader in waterproofing and roofing. Was quite a competitive  fight to get it and we're very proud to have it. With this acquisition, we are now CHF 220 million profitable  business in Italy, very strong organization now. And together, we are quite confident that we will have a great  future in Italy with this excellent new company.

texts.speaker: Paul Schuler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: One of the megatrends which also help us are the urbanization. For example, rising demands for high building,  the standard's going up. Or if we go to the vehicles, light vehicles, [ph] strong (25:26) vehicles, more lower  emissions vehicle, [ph] this all the trends which keeps us dramatic (25:31) and create opportunity to grow. We  have everywhere the right products. We have a lot of potential, for example, safety increased, fire, water,  earthquake, and Sika has the right products and the right systems there.

texts.speaker: Ivo Schädler
texts.profession: Regional Manager, EMEA & Member, Group Management, Sika AG
texts.text: In Middle East, we're working very strongly in projects – in big projects. I'm sure you heard about this huge  investment in Turkey, Istanbul Airport. They are building there the largest airport in the world, and we are very  well-positioned there with our concrete and waterproofing systems and all our cross-selling activities in such  major projects.

texts.speaker: Ivo Schädler
texts.profession: Regional Manager, EMEA & Member, Group Management, Sika AG
texts.text: Also, in Dubai, they are building a sort of a new part of Dubai with this – also this Tower project. This will be the  tallest tower in the world. We are already active there, we're already with our system – with our waterproofing  system in the basement. Just visited there some months ago. So, this project is well on track.

texts.speaker: Ivo Schädler
texts.profession: Regional Manager, EMEA & Member, Group Management, Sika AG
texts.text: Also, in the more mature markets, let's say, in Europe, where we have substantial infrastructures and very good  project wins. For example, in Paris, this Grand Paris project with 50 kilometers of tunneling where we are also  very well-positioned with our systems. Also, in London, there are new developments of the former Battersea  Power Station. So, a huge development there, also a very big potential for Sika.

texts.speaker: Ivo Schädler
texts.profession: Regional Manager, EMEA & Member, Group Management, Sika AG
texts.text: Also, in another major project in Central Europe, the Brenner Tunnel between Italy and Austria. Sika won big  parts of the concrete and also the waterproofing membranes for this project. And also, in Germany, the Stuttgart  21 project is well on track and also with the strong presence of Sika products. We're continuing, also 2018, of  course, as you have seen already before in extending our production sites to increase our local footprint and our  capacities. The new acquired companies will bring a lot of synergies. We are about, of course, to roll out this in  the markets and then combine the efforts there.

texts.speaker: Christoph Ganz
texts.profession: Regional Manager-North America & Member-Group Management, Sika AG
texts.text: Starting with North America, I guess it will not surprise you that we believe the outlook is pretty positive. I mean  also in the Swiss press, you read a lot about our President and what he is promising to us. So, we believe we  might even see a slight uptake in GDP growth this year, mainly due to U.S. infrastructure build, which has been  promised and the tax reform of course, which will have a positive impact there. But also in Canada, increasing oil  and gas prices will have a positive impact on the construction [ph] sector level (39:42).

texts.speaker: Christoph Ganz
texts.profession: Regional Manager-North America & Member-Group Management, Sika AG
texts.text: And then, maybe a bit less nice on one side, I mean we're, of course, kind of profiting also from, let's say, the  climate change. I would say, during the last 12 months in North America, we've seen pretty rough weather, the  two hurricanes in Florida and Texas that happened last year. We see, of course, huge repair works happening  right now. So, in the Bermuda, for example, or in the Caribbean, lots of these hotels, they want to open again very  quickly. So, they have to repair all these roofs. And these are really big, big projects that we have seen coming in  over the last few months, several million dollars of sales every project. And this will continue at least for another  half year to a year.

texts.speaker: Christoph Ganz
texts.profession: Regional Manager-North America & Member-Group Management, Sika AG
texts.text: We had a very heavy rainfalls at the beginning of last year  in California. [ph] Thanks, God. (42:18) They  appreciated that but that has damaged a lot of structures, roads, dams and all these structures have to be  repaired and Sika's involved here really very strongly and we will see this also continuing during 2018. And then, I  experienced it myself, I've never seen such a harsh winter like this year in East and Central U.S., Canada, even  down to Texas. So, we've seen freezing temperatures even in Texas. And that you see it really, that has damaged  a lot of these structures, and repair works are happening right now.

texts.speaker: Mike Campion
texts.profession: Regional Manager, Asia/Pacific & Member, Group Management, Sika AG
texts.text: To sustain our growth model in Asia Pacific, we'll continue to expand our production base and our overall supply  chain. We'll build four new plants in 2018. Actually, each quarter, we'll bring one: a water plant in Vietnam; we  have a waterproofing membrane line in Korea; we have a high technology hot melt production in China; and  finally, a huge water facility in Australia. So, we continue to build, and we'll continue to look forward to expand our  supply chain in 2018 and beyond.

texts.speaker: Thomas Hasler
texts.profession: Head, Industry and Automotive, Sika AG
texts.text: Electric vehicle built is a hype in the industry, it's a hype in politics and so on, but it's a reality when it comes to our  activities. And we are active in this field for several years now at the OEMs. We are active at the tiers, Tier 1 and  Tier 2, and not only in automotive but also in bus, truck applications. And it has to be seen as a thing that is  maybe on the car side, speculative how many cars are going to be on the road in the future.

texts.speaker: Thomas Hasler
texts.profession: Head, Industry and Automotive, Sika AG
texts.text: But I would like to draw your attention to the bus section, where we have already, today, in China 50% e-vehicle  rate on the buses in China. They are building 200,000 buses a year and 50% of those buses are full electric  buses. So, that's a reality, and we are in that market, and we are providing with our technology solution to make  those batteries , to make those specific needs of the e-vehicle better and more efficient going forward.

texts.speaker: Thomas Hasler
texts.profession: Head, Industry and Automotive, Sika AG
texts.text: Finally, also acquisition is a topic that drives our growth. As you have heard, FAIST ChemTec is an acoustic  solution provider in automotive. It makes us now the strong number one in all acoustic applications in the car build  for the body shop. So, we are doing excellent works in airborne and structure-borne acoustics. So, with that, we  can leverage these at the carmakers. But as well, it goes into the industry as well, it goes into the car, into the  truck, into the bus, as well as into shipbuilding. Acoustic is a mega trend that is relevant for our customers. And  we have solutions with this acquisition that we can roll out and leverage perfectly in the future going forward.  Thank you.

texts.text: Then, we have the concrete fibers in U.S., great business. Concrete fiber will be more and more we'll see in  construction sites, so great to have it there. And then a small one in Romania to strengthen our position. This will  be acquired as soon as we have the closing.

And we had to find materials to continue to  produce and I also think that was a little bit challenging. I think we are on top of it, all the organization are keen.  We follow the margin, we follow the pricing and we push pricing. But that's the explanation why we probably had a  tougher year than other years and we will see how this year goes.

texts.speaker: Paul Schuler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: [indiscernible] (00:16:26) is the urbanization. I think a lot people know that but I want to highlight it again why we  see and why we had an excellent 2018. All the high-rise buildings for example needs now increasing safety, fire,  earthquake, quality requirements, better waterproofing solution or high-performing and special concrete demand.  And I think we have a very, very strong position there.

texts.speaker: Paul Schuler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Last year, we did many, many high-rise and we feel very strong in this one. And if you look at this picture, if you  look into 2010 there were around 300 high-rise building, it means higher than 300 meters. In 2020, we expect  another 10 rows, a 1,000 and then we have a huge for 2030 there's a planned and forecasted high-rise and we  have a very strong position there. So, if that just half comes through in 2030, I think we have a lot of opportunity to  bring market share, to have market share, and we have a very, very strong position. And if you look how this is  built now, this high-rise, in the old days, they took them quite a while to build. But now, they want to build it faster,  they want to build it more strength and higher. Sometimes, they go up to 1,000 meters. So in the old days, they  used steel. Now, they started then the concrete and now concrete steel composite and I think it's all our potential  we have in this high-rise. If you see the amount of high-rise and how much more material we can sell in this high- rise, it's just fantastic to see how we have a great business model just in this one.

texts.speaker: Paul Schuler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: And what is so special in our concrete? I think to pump concrete up to 300, 400 or 500 meters; you have to have  special concrete. Then, to have buildings like that, you need really good grade concrete. Otherwise, your building  will collapse. So high pressure, but still cohesive.

texts.speaker: Paul Schuler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: Then if you see in the city, this urbanization. We have to pump the concrete 500, 600 meters up but usually there  is no factory in a big city. So, they come from outside and have to go to the job site. Usually in New York, we have  an example here. It took them one-and-a-half hour to get from outside in the city to pump the concrete. But when  the concrete is pumped, it cures very fast. If it's not curing, we cannot work, so continuously.

texts.speaker: Paul Schuler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: And then it's 100 trucks, 100 trucks a day and every fifth truck was controlled in New York to see if the  [indiscernible] (00:19:30) So, to have first a concrete you can pump, you can transport, pump it up and then as  you cure, not everybody can do that. That's a few companies around the world that are able to do that and I think  we are here in a very leading position. So, that helps us and Vanderbilt [ph] does – where (00:19:50) it's now  finished this year, but we had a lot of concrete [ph] purity (00:19:57) in last year. So, that was one of our  highlights. But Vanderbilt is just one of 300, 400 buildings around U.S.

texts.speaker: Paul Schuler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sika AG
texts.text: So we're optimistic here and to remind you again what we're trying to do, as you know, we have these five  technologies in our hand. And that the biggest one is thermoplastic for roofing with around 28% of our CHF 7  billion, then we have our nice adhesive business for our construction and automotive in industry with around 26%,  then we have the concrete system, which I explained before with around 17%. And then we have the coating  system for the flooring business and for coatings with around 14% and we have business of mortars with around  15%. If you look back the last five years, you saw a lot of investments in mortar plants. This is our fastest growing  target market, our fastest growing technology, and one of our more profitable technologies.

texts.speaker: Thomas Hasler
texts.profession: Head Global Business and Industry, Sika AG
texts.text: So, driving besides the acquisition, the recognized [indiscernible] (00:51:28) synergies we have. We also have  very positive trends in the market or let's say needs of the market where we are more than willing to be the  painkiller and help our customers to overcome their challenges. A big challenge of course is the electrification.  That is a major game changer. And as you can guess the [ph] OEM CDs (00:51:50) as a most important  differentiation topic and everybody is investing heavily. There is no common way or common [indiscernible]  (00:52:00) to this topic. And we have engaged with all our existing current traditional carmakers as well as  newcomers to find for them the best way to deal with this challenge. And of course, ultimately, have a competitive  advantage also with the new powertrain system.

texts.speaker: Thomas Hasler
texts.profession: Head Global Business and Industry, Sika AG
texts.text: Not to forget, besides the electrification, cars need to become more fuel-efficient which means [indiscernible]  (00:53:14) this trend – this mega trend of increasing fuel efficiency by decreasing the weight of the car by also  increasing the comfort aspects which is very much in favor of our acoustic competence. This is also driving  additional growth for us. And so, we are very optimistic and positive about the general outlook in automotive.

texts.speaker: Thomas Hasler
texts.profession: Head Global Business and Industry, Sika AG
texts.text: So, I'm excited about 2019. The [indiscernible] (00:56:17) is full. We have a bit of wind in all directions, doesn't  bother us too much. We are winners and we are going to bring our [indiscernible] (00:56:25) per car up and the  customer needs us, so I need to go to the customer as we speak.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer Region Americas & Member of Group Executive Board, Sika AG
texts.text: [ph] Or (01:03:37) we're selling Mexican acrylic waterproofing technology that we produce in Mexico and that we  supply now into, we call it, the sunbelt of the U.S., so the Southern California, Texas, Florida where you could say  is kind of a Latin culture within the U.S. culture that's been established.

texts.speaker: Christoph Ganz
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer Region Americas & Member of Group Executive Board, Sika AG
texts.text: Also new costumers that we won last year in North America some significant customers I must say. I cannot  mention the names, of course, here in the concrete business but also in the waterproofing business, for example,  we will see these sales coming through now this year.

texts.speaker: Christoph Ganz
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer Region Americas & Member of Group Executive Board, Sika AG
texts.text: So, on one side, it's the tile adhesive business, we've never been active in that business. On the other side, it's  the façade business. You must understand we are very strong on the roof, we're strong on the floor, we're strong  on the waterproofing of basements and joint sealants, for example, but we almost did not have products for the  facades and the facades of course, is an integral part of a building, a structure. And with Parex now, we can offer  now a wider package to specifiers and of course to distributors and other customers.

texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, SEB SA

texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: Just imagine if you cover a piece of meat with some egg white and you put bread crumbs on it, you'll get  something that it must be to cook lightly, and we've managed to do it both by controlling the temperature flow but  also by fully controlling the speed of the rotation of the product. And quite obviously this is a strong demand  because these are products that of course have a lot of fatty matter and so in a diet conscious aspect it can be very  important, but it nevertheless is a product that will make us possible to adapt fully -fledged woks and so able to  adapt it to Asian constraints.

texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: It's not an innovation, but I think it's important to talk about this. We're being successful in oil-less fryers, but we  nevertheless feel it's important not to give up on these products which were the key success factor of the SEB  Group, I mean oil cleaning, antismell and so on. And because we have plus 10% on a like -for-like basis on this  family of products, it's not really related to the innovation. It's related to the industrial vision and capacity that we  have. And it's very important for us to use our industrial capacity as a real leverage effect in order to gain in  performance and competitive nature of the competition and we've concentrated all our products on couple of  plants; in Supor we're producing 70% of our sales in one plant and this has it possible to gain in cost to make us  very competitive, and a number of our competitors are in fact getting out of this market. We've done everything that needed to be done for it to also  be consuming the least amount of energy possible and with a search for the greater efficiency for our staff with  collaborative work made easier and the improving quality of life and a strong team cohesion.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Now, as to the Americas, in the North America, the only area which is down in the first half of year, it's true that in  the U.S. and in Canada, Bertrand will talk about the U.S., as to Canada, the environment – the economy is very  difficult due to the cost of oil and the decrease in the currency value, a very significant effect on this market, and  objectively it's quite difficult. And to South America, plus 0.4% that's good, given the context, which is [ph] horrible  (29:13) in Brazil. We'll talk about Brazil in a moment, and Colombia performed very well in the half year, two-figure  growth. So, we're happy about that.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Now electric cooking, a big category for us, electrical cooking which is led by innovation. You'll see a certain  number of illustrations of that, very remarkable OptiGrill, which is performing in the U.S., but is also very strong in  Germany. Fry Delight is a very small fryer, oil-less fryer, that will be positioned right next to and just below Actifry.  And rice cookers, we talked about a lot, which are performing well in China and even outside of China.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: About cookware, despite less loyalty programs this year, the performance was still very strong and one innovation  which is continuing to take over, there are a few examples here. On the bottom-left-hand-corner, you have a fry  pan, which – it stops the induction heating. It can never heat more than 250 degrees. That is a first in the world.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: On the top-right-hand-corner, you have a heat sensor temperature monitoring, so that makes it possible to better  measure the temperature in the middle and you have a small reader on the handle which tells you the  temperature on an ongoing basis and the temperature at the centre of your fry pan and you have various  cookware coatings and adhesive products, so a very good performance as we said earlier about accessories  generally.

file: SK - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 26July2017 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: The first measure we decided on was to restructure our Consumer business. Consumer means in WMF, I think it  basically means small domestic appliances. That's our traditional business, in other words, cookware that's non- electric and small electric appliances. We've also created business development for this, where, in fact, WMF  before had a vision that was extremely Germanic of things because the Consumer BU included the German  market. There are also Switzerland and Austria, what they called DACH, and that is naturally what our vision is  because, as you know, we've always made a distinction between the business units and what makes products  and the sales structures that are global, too, and then tasked with deploying the brand worldwide because WMF  will be a global brand and far more than just a German one. So, we've got a business development function that  will serve as an interface between markets and the business unit.

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: Thank you, Thierry. One word about the environment. In terms of the currency situation, a much more favorable  environment that we've had in the past, in the last few years. It used to be fairly neutral last year, but very  favorable over the last three years. It's highly contrasted but it is neutral now ,which is a great news to us, but we'll  get back to that.

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: Now, you had a great presentation because all the countries are growing. Just two words about Colombia, which  has had unfavorable sales of fans because of the climatic conditions. In Saudi Arabia, there's a lot of inventory.  Even though we have reinforced control of the distributor, there's still quite a few back-and-forth movements in  terms of inventory and industrial activity.

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: Russia. As you recall not long ago, this is a country that we considered as a difficult country. This year, every – all  the signs are green. Although the lights are green in terms of growth, in terms of market share gains, positions  have strengthened throughout all of the markets, a very strong growth. Gains in market share, systematically,  whether it'd be on our SDAs, electrical products or our non-electrical products, with another detail, which has its  importance, this is a very strong growth in our own retail products. We have nine stores in Russia and they're  doing very well.

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: Now, what about product news? Here, again, there is a slide that's pretty easy to explain. All of the product  families are up. If you look at the two ends of this chart, the home care of air and fan products are suffering a bit in  terms of the product, the product performance. We'll get back to that. But the bubble at the top, which is not even  on the scale, is home care, which has been growing more than 40%, and this is a small bubble. I remind you,  we're talking about the first category of the small household appliances in terms of volume and in terms of value.

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: We have done a lot of innovation in terms of the product itself. There is a new pressure cooker, the ClipsoMinut'  Perfect and the Tefal Assisteo fry pan. Because it has a heat sensory, you can actually measure the heat at the  center of the frying pan. And, in fact, you can actually monitor this on your smartphone, which illustrates the  capacity for innovation that we also have in non-electrical products. And here, again, we want to indicate the  wonderful performance of kitchen utensils, which are continuing to increase, but Thierry will be getting back to  that later.

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: Now, the home care product, which is our champion with a growth that's greater than 40%, which is led by the  European labels, Eco Energy. As you can see here, after having invented the 4A, we had to invent the 4A+ to  demonstrate or the wins and performance for each product line. So, we have launched and we are continuing to  be at the leading edge compared to our competitors for each of these innovations.

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: So, now, we are at 4A+, but fundamentally, the growth is being led by bagless Hoovers or vacuum cleaners and  by launching innovations, which are working very clear. The Clean & Steam, for example, you clean and steam at  the same time by – and Air Force, which very simply is the competitor of [ph] Bison's (55:15) new model of a very  similar appearance, wireless and agile and a beautiful object. Yes, it's magnificent.

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: And domestic home comfort, just two words. Colombia, it's hard. Brazil, it was hot, so it worked well. And Europe,  as you all noted, we had a very hot month of June. So, thank you very much, it's doing very well. Thanks to these  small fans, they're doing well. But the essential part of growth comes from our air processing devices in China but  not only in China, which have a very good performance; air purification, air purifiers.

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: Thierry has already talked about the 9,000 and the 1,200, so I don't have to go over this again. This runs our  WMF range at either end of the scheme, the entry level and the high-end range as well with very important coffee  dispensers, up to 350 coffees per day, which will address both new types of customers and product price ranges  that are very different. You'd also see some examples as well for the hotel from chafing dish to everything we do  with heat-protected [ph] Krups (59:53).

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: The breakdown of our offer is a little more complex given these famous PPAs. The left-hand side is conventional,  it's traditional. Here, we're talking about the non-WNF scope. It is traditional but differs from what we knew in the  last three years. You will recall that the currency trend would hang around between €90 million and €120 million in  the last three years. This year, it's at €16 million. So, the environment is far less unfavorable or practically neutral  for this first half of the year from currency [indiscernible] (01:03:29).

texts.speaker: Thierry de la Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: Very well, now, the environment very quickly now. Because very few surprises are in the offing. There's some  stable environment. texts.speaker: Thierry de la Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: So, the year now for SEB, currencies, we've mentioned them. We'll come back to that later on with Vincent when  he analyzes the impact on our P&L. Competition comes from our normal competitors, but also  from our retailers who, very often, are into a warfare, and use us to – as they want to get to catch – they have last  leaders to attract consumers. So €90, it's not sold – it's a reduction of €90 compared to the €129 official price in  2012.

texts.speaker: Thierry de la Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: So, what is interesting here is that this year there is no family of product that is in negative territory. They are all  expanding and for some of them, with very sharp growth rates like domestic comfort. The home comfort is linked  to weather, 14%. But home care at 6%.

texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: We have to fight every step of the way obviously, but we are in leadership position with Rowenta. So, the overall  situation in the U.S. is good. We'd like to thanks one again [ph] ORFA (26:21) for the Actifry, but it didn't help us a  lot because the sales didn't take off. texts.speaker: Thierry de la Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: So, you need to be present and in products that will be the big – the Open Food System project which groups  together several French companies, roughly 15, including SEB, and competitively groups. Pressure cookers, people are scared of those, but you can actually see where it stands on your iPhone or iPad. You  can see if it's going to explode or not, but obviously, they've never exploded. But anyway, people worry about them

texts.speaker: Vincent Léonard
texts.profession: Senior Executive Vice-President, Finance, SEB SA
texts.text: Now, on a quarterly basis, 2013 is the green line. All quarters were up. It tends to accelerate over the period of the  year. So, the trend now is quite different in 2013. A very  good trend.

texts.speaker: Thierry de la Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: As a last part before we come to the Q&A session, maybe let's talk about the outlook we may have for 2014. What  we intend to do we'll then talk about the macroeconomic environment. What we can expect, how we see our  products, and what we intend to do, so the environment now.

texts.speaker: Thierry de la Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: I talked about vacuums. These are products where there's been a huge amount of work done by our teams today, I  think we can say that vertically whether they'd be upright or floor vacuum cleaners we're doing very well. And  their 2014 launch is planned and that will have a certain impact. So, we know that this is long term, but we have to  go there.

texts.speaker: Thierry de la Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: Today, the Shaoxing plant near Hangzhou builds 8 million of these per year, 3 million for China and 5 million for  export. That's 30% of cost price production over four years. 8 million components, one per kettle, and obviously  you get a better price. Also, you have production savings as well. And we'll be extending this. So, it may be not the  biggest plant for the moment, but it will be. And we have extended this industrial approach not only to kettles but  also to toasters, filter coffeemakers and blenders.

texts.speaker: Thierry de la Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: So, the group is fully engaged in that process and has been for several years. We're starting to see – starting to  bear fruit and we're going to be continuing along that vein. I could talk about electric fryers. There's obviously  Actifry but also a normal fryers are dealt with in the same way.

texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer

And, basically, it is market that is contracting and this is, in particular, for the categories that are  mainly driven in 2013 and that was the electric auto cookers in which this year decline by 45%.

texts.speaker: Bertrand Neuschwander
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer
texts.text: And in terms of kettles, we don't yet have the results, but we launched at the end of 2014, the product lines for  home and personal care and with addition adding iron, steamers, vacuum cleaners and air purifiers and this will  make it possible to extend our category scope.

texts.speaker: Bertrand Neuschwander
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer
texts.text: For Air Force, there is focus here because you'll see in the appendix as you'll find more details. Air Force is  continuing in France, stood at plus 16%. [indiscernible] (40:47) many ventilators made in Vietnam which are now  being extended to Thailand. If you look at ecodesign and ecolabel standards, these have come in force since  September 1, 2014. And these imply that all vacuum cleaners now have a power range of 1600 watts and in 2017 it  will less than 900 watts. And so there is strong pressure on the motors and when you do – when you put  [indiscernible] (41:20) on the motors, you have to qualify the performance because by reducing the quality of the  constant electricity consume, these standards also imply and new standards for noise, cleaning patent, and these  are four As.

texts.speaker: Bertrand Neuschwander
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer
texts.text: And it makes it possible to download into the machine which is then going to guide you step-by-step and going to  adapt its temperature rise and adapt to the cooking process and it will make it possible to, in a very regular  fashion, produce recipes with a homogenous result. And this is something that is working by building both on  experience, on sharing, and results. And this quite clearly, corresponds to what consumers are expecting from our  products today and I think that's about it, yes.

texts.speaker: Vincent Léonard
texts.profession: Senior Executive Vice-President, Finance
texts.text: Also the country mix effect as you know, it is negative, when China is doing fine then the margins of China being  lower to the average margin at group levels is a dilutive effect to a certain extent of our margin. So all those effects  which are quite complex are baked in here. The good news is that the net effect is positive which was not given  taken the environment. So €13 million in positive impact and then the unit price revenue which captures both our  purchasing savings for about €15 million this year with purchasing indices which are around [ph] 99 (49:41) and  our production indexes, our potential savings such as with aluminum or commodities or raw materials when  market are ready for that and significantly productivity, mentioned by Thierry, especially our industrial  productivity which is captured here for about €20 million in this section

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let's focus on our vision of our environment and market, so that what we expect this year in France and in  Europe. In Western Europe, our vision is rather upbeat and is quite similar to last year North America and even  it's suffering -- they are suffering more in Canada, due into the currency effect there. Many products come from  the United States for them. So it's mixed. And even depending on the countries but rather looking up and stable in  regard to cookwares although our sales have sharply risen in particular, thanks to that.

texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer

texts.speaker: Thierry de La Tour d'Artaise
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: Now, let's look at these products. Some figures, in 2007 we had nine product categories in culinary, eight in  cookware. Today, we now have in SDA against nine and 16 in cookware. In the last years two products families which have grown spectacularly were  gas cookers and hoods. When you about supports, the supports product categories, the extractors and gas hobs,  we have increased almost €100 million. So I think it's a very big success.

texts.speaker: Vincent Léonard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Executive VP, SEB SA
texts.text: Our top 20 markets, they are ranked between those that are growing and the one that is decreasing, 19 in growth  – nearly 19 out of 20, Colombia is in negative territory, it's not very strong for us. Let's focus on some of those markets. Bertrand, over to  you.

texts.speaker: Bertrand Neuschwander
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: Now Brazil, Brazil now – we are finalizing the ramp-up of the cities, let's say in the Rio state we are putting in the  latest cookware lines, it might create some disturbance in the first quarter 2018, but basically we trust the fact that  the end of the first quarter, these lines will be in place and in full upswing. Otherwise, Brazil similarly to Colombia  is impacted by poor weather conditions which had a major impact on air conditioners and others.

texts.speaker: Bertrand Neuschwander
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: In terms of actual usage, we're very clearly aware that the way products are being used or changing. For example  in this slide, what about ironing. Young people today no longer iron the way our grandparents did. The idea of  having a perfect or ironing job has gone out the window. So, we're launching product ranges where little by little  we'll provide solutions to this change, we have vertical ironing or ironing with very small irons. So these are  trends, and this is essential to follow these trends.

texts.speaker: Bertrand Neuschwander
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, SEB SA
texts.text: And then connection, connectivity, and there are four examples here; connection is really starting to bring in  sales. Air treatment – you can actually start filtering the air remotely, so that you can have it cleaned, you can  actually clean the air while you're not there. And you can also have probes or sensors that will enable you to  trigger that automatically; Body Partner, the scale system, it doesn't just measure your weight, it also measure  various health, you can measure your circumference, breadth, whatever.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Skanska AB

file: SKA.B - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 22July2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Karlström
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let us say some words about the tunnel project in Virginia. Our equity there corresponds to – our equity portion  there corresponds to 50% of the total investment on the equity side. We have an external partner. And our  investment will be $136 million, but the construction value, that is over SEK 660 million for Skanska. And we have  45% share on the construction side. And we have two other partners there. We are building a tunnel under the  Elizabeth River, but we will also take over existing tunnels. And the whole facility, all the tunnel there, we will run  the operations to 2017. The PPP set-up here that is traffic risk, which means that it's – the revenue is coming from  the tolls that we have on that project.

texts.speaker: Johan Karlström
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If I look at the geography or the overall market for ID in the U.S., if I look at the math here, you can see all the  green space. All the green space, they have the legislation in place for PPP project, but they have started up to  invest a lot of infrastructure here, and have it in place. We are not focusing on all these states. There's a lot of  projects out there in the market. And the project that you can see that is highlighted on the picture here, that's the  project that we have decided that we will go for, and we will tender for. I will not go through all of them. I just want  to point out some few projects that we will focus on, in the near future. That is the I-66 project in Virginia; and  another highway project in Colorado, I-70. And then there is two other airport projects at the LAX Airport in Los  Angeles that we think that we have a good chance to win. So, there is more projects in the market that we can  focus on, which is good, because we can pick the ones where we see the greatest opportunity.

texts.speaker: Peter Wallin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: The free working capital chart, which I know is of interest for me and for many of you continues to show a positive  momentum with cash flow increasing on the back of increasing business volume. But we are also increasing the  relative proportion of free working capital compared to the construction revenue, the green line. But the green line  is now at around 13%. Going forward, on the back of increasing volumes in our Construction business, don't  expect the green line to continue to develop in this very favorable way, because, I think, that we are operating on  a good level now. The absolutes on the other hand should be trending in relation to that of the business volume in  the construction stream.

file: SKA.B - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 7November2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Karlström
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Skanska AB
texts.text: This slide is something that I think is important that everybody understand. It's showing the Skanska model, the  financial model. In the green box here, construction, we are running it in – with a lot of prepayments. So we got  the big pile of cash from the construction units. As we are sitting on a positive cash flow, we are using that positive  cash flow and invest that into new projects in the development arm. We get a profit of the investment. And on top  of that, we also have a profit in construction when we build it. So we get profits from that float in two boxes, both  in the development with the return on the capital employed that we plunk in there. And of course, we use our own  construction business.

texts.speaker: Johan Karlström
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Skanska AB
texts.text: Latin America, it's a lower number. And it's both coming from that we are cautious to taking projects and make  sure that we know what type of projects we are taking into new backlog. And it's also a reflection of the market.  Raw materials is down, and that means that the mining sector reducing their investment. And we can also see  lower activities in the energy sector, especially from a big client like Petrobras. And that is two niches just we are  active in, in Latin America.

texts.speaker: Peter Wallin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, Skanska AB
texts.text: So taking a look at the change in the financial position here, we have the negative cash flow of SEK 3.5 billion,  going out negative. Then as a positive change, the increased interest rates in the environment right now, because  of everything looking a bit brighter, is actually lowering our defined benefit obligations, our pension liabilities.  And that's a positive impact on our net debt, so that puts it down to SEK 4 billion. To get through the ONFAL  which I talked about, we then only add back the pension liability and the liabilities to the co -ops because the co- ops liability, when we hand over the [ph] keys to performance, (36:11) the liability disappears.

texts.speaker: Peter Wallin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, Skanska AB
texts.text: Latin America, we've done both in the two sectors, the mining sector and the energy sector that I mentioned  before. And in U.S, we see that the civil market, the public civil market with a large infrastructure projects that is  our target continue in the same way as we have seen before.

texts.speaker: Peter Wallin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, Skanska AB
texts.text: On the private side in the civil sector, and now I'm talking about the energy type of projects and industrial  investments, we see now a hesitance from the owners of these big facilities like a power plant. There is a little bit  of a wait-and-see mode if they should start the investment now or if they should wait. We see a postponement of  the projects and they are waiting now for more clearance from the political sector. So that is – and I will say a new  thing that we have seen in the market. All of these projects, both on the public side but also on the private side,  will come and it's more of a question of the timing there. So we are still very positive in the long run regarding the  USA Civil sector.

texts.speaker: Peter Wallin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, Skanska AB
texts.text: Commercial Development, we see more activities especially here in the Nordics, and that is on the transactions  side but it's basically domestic investors. The strong krona drives the international players in Sweden in other  directions. But among the domestic players, we see more activities and the more appetite to buy premises. And  that is very good for us because they're looking at modern, energy-efficient, green, center-located premises which  is exactly the niche that we are facing and that we are targeting. We have a lot of activities in Poland, as you know,  and we continue to see that market as very good.

texts.speaker: Peter Wallin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, Skanska AB

And with that sort of we have quite – and a portfolio of  remaining project, which needs to be developed in order to realize value. So, we have taken the mature project  and divested them with good proceeds. And as we also had mentioned, the low energy prices has also made it to  take down the value of the wind assets.

texts.speaker: Johan Karlström
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Skanska AB
texts.text: Commercial Development, overall good. Leasing is good; a lot of demand on the leasing side. We see great  opportunities on the transaction side as well in the low interest rate environment that we see now and just in one  micro market that we talked about, the energy corridor in Houston. Otherwise, it's a very, very good market in the  various locations where we have operations.

texts.speaker: Johan Karlström
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Skanska AB
texts.text: On the PPP side, there is a lot of discussions. Will it be capacity for the administration and the governmental  bodies to prepare all the projects now that it will come to get them shovel-ready. And that's going to be a  bottleneck. That could also be one reason why it's going to be going over more towards PPPs. So, it's not only  because of the financing side, but also the capacity of design side because if you go with the PPP project, then  you move to design work over to the contractors. And that is also, like, you can say that's one reason to also  move over projects with a PPP setup. So, we believe that that could also boost an increase to PPP market in the  U.S. Otherwise, we see some projects coming in UK and there's also been announcements of some infrastructure  projects in Norway.

The year started with  the sale of A1 that Anders has talked about. If we look into next year, we will not have any pieces to sell. We have  four projects in the portfolio, and they are not mature to be sold. And that the return from the – recurring revenue  from the four projects that we have in the portfolio and the cost of bidding projects now only in the U.S. market,  that's going to be even-steven more or less. So, don't expect a strong positive EBIT from Infrastructure  Development for 2018.

texts.speaker: Peter Wallin
