file: SKA.B - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 8February2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Anders Danielsson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Skanska AB
texts.text: Infrastructure Development, we have a portfolio. As you know, we have closed down our project development.  We have a asset management now to – organization that will have the big focus on taking care of the value that  we have in our portfolio. And we have, as you can see here, net present value has increased to SEK 3.6 billion  and there are unrealized gains of SEK 1.1 billion. So, the focus is to maintain and realize value in the current  portfolio. And starting from 2019, the Infrastructure Development will not be reported as a separate business  stream.

texts.speaker: Magnus Persson
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Skanska AB
texts.text: What instead happens when we continue to start more units than what we sell is, of course, that the sales rate in  the portfolio under production goes down, and that you can keep track of very easily with the green line that you  see behind me here. We are now at 68%. We have tracked this at every quarterly presentation now during the  year, and we are well in control over sort of the market risk in this. So, we think we're in a comfortable position  here with 68% still.

texts.speaker: Magnus Persson
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Skanska AB
texts.text: What you can see here then is the divestment over time. Very high levels on the blue bars, as you know, then you  can also see the gain on sale here in the green line here. So, approaching again around SEK 4 billion which is  we've been there once before, and now we're coming up there again here, so very strong.

texts.speaker: Magnus Persson
texts.profession: Executive Vice President & Chief Financial Officer, Skanska AB
texts.text: And in addition to that, as we have said repeatedly, we do expect the volume of Construction to come down going  forward. And this is just a consequence of us being very prudent in the bid situation and to be sort of very clear on  what risks we are – we want to take in this business. So, of course, when these two – when the portfolio is  normalizing in terms of the quality as we win better work here and also the volume is coming down, that will affect  the net working capital position. It will affect the KPI. The green line you see in, it will also have an effect of course  on the nominal value of the free working capital that we have.

file: SKF.B - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 20April2010 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Apr-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: During the quarter, we continued inventing in our business and opened nine solution factories for  the group in Houston in Texas, which will have a main focus on energy. And right at the start of this  quarter, we opened two new factories in India. The Haridwar factory makes ball bearings used  mainly in the two-wheeler market and in the vehicle service market. The Ahmedabad factory, which  is really a sister factory to Dalian because it’s got the same technology and similar large size  products, that was opened also, and that will mainly focus on the Indian and of course the Asian  market.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: It’s important to note that we’ve built both these factories to LEED type standards, which means we  take true care of the environment when we’re building the factories as well as from the operator       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 factories. We will open a third factory, which we’re building just now in Tver in Russia at the start of  the next quarter beginning in July. Again, it is built to the LEED standards.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: I forecasted in January that we expected volume to be slightly up, and it was a little bit better than  that with a growth of 5.3%. The main difference was the strong volume development in the  Automotive business division, which had a growth of over 26%. The Service Division had good  growth and positive growth, but we still saw a decline in our Industrial Division of more than 12%,  driven by – primarily by a weak Aerospace business and a weak Renewable Energy business, and  that we saw particularly in the European business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the quarterly presentation available on our website, you will see the sales development per  region. So let us walk around the world and start with Asia. Here you can see the sales were up by  over one-third in the Asian region, which is a very, very strong growth. China was strong, car, truck,  railway and Wind Energy, to name a few segments doing well. India was also very, very strong with  two-wheelers, car, truck, vehicle aftermarket, but also the broad Industrial business is showing a  strong development. And then we’ve got – say, our problem just now is keeping up the market  growth because it continues to be very strong there. Southeast Asia in total developed very well  and that confirm also that the two-wheeler business in Indonesia is growing well.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Wind Energy was down a lot year-on-year in Europe for us. But if you look at that, you must  remember that last year in the first quarter, Wind Energy business was still growing for SKF. So  therefore, comparing that quarter we were into declining sales in the second quarter last year and  the rest of last year, comparing that essentially trend with the strong first quarter last year. We  think, if I look at Wind Energy in Europe it has probably bottomed out now, but it is not moving back  into growth. Aerospace in Europe was weak and continued to be weak. It will probably – it has  started to bottom out here.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Switching to material cost, we are seeing a big increase in surcharges now due to higher scrap and  higher scrap surcharges, and of course we all know and can see what’s happening in the iron ore  market, which has an imprint on the scrap price. I should remind you that we predominantly make  our – or the steel we use is predominantly made from scrap, not from iron ore, but of course the  scrap price is affected at what happens on the iron ore market as well. If you look at that scrap  surcharges, I know, up something like 40%, then – higher than they were at the start of the year.  We are also seeing increases in actual steel prices in some markets – some of the Asian markets  where we don’t have the surcharge system. So, if you look at that what you can see is the  increasing surcharges and the increasing steel prices will be somewhat of a headwind in the  coming quarters.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The general industry sectors will be up as well the Industrial aftermarket, between the sales division  will be significantly up compared to last year. Industrial Division remains more challenging with  general industry like pumps, compressors, gearboxes developing positively. I know we can also  see from a trend viewpoint heavy industries like construction equipment and pulp and paper  developing positively. However, as I said earlier, the Wind Energy business and the Aerospace  business would still be weak in the second quarter. Overall, what does that mean? It means a slight  growth for us in terms of volume sequentially and of course significantly up year-on-year.

file: SKF.B - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 19April2011 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Apr-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning to you all. Very welcome to this conference call for the
texts.text: 2 So let me comment a little on this. I will start with Asia. We saw a very good development in the  region and in particular in our main markets there, China and India. In China, with the strong growth  in segments such as renewable energy, fluid power, metals and the railway business and the  industrial markets, and also strong growth in the light vehicle and vehicle service markets.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning to you all. Very welcome to this conference call for the
texts.text: In India, the main segments of growth were renewable energy, railway, industrial gear boxes as  well as two wheelers and trucks and the vehicle service market. In other markets in the region we  had a good development, but I should comment our sales to the two-wheeler market in Indonesia  also developed very positively.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning to you all. Very welcome to this conference call for the
texts.text: Our sales to the truck industry were also very strong. And if you look at the truck business, you can  see it’s been a classic V-shaped recovery. Our aerospace business is showing a good, steady  positive development. And if I could comment on renewable energy, then I would say very strong in  Asia and improving situation in Europe which should give some better sales in the European  business in the second half of the year. So overall, with a stronger volume development in the first  quarter and a very broad based growth.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning to you all. Very welcome to this conference call for the
texts.text: It’s important to note, though, that we will continue to see higher raw material costs as we look  through the year. The surcharges for scrap we are facing from our steel and component suppliers  are significantly higher than this period last year, in fact – and in fact, on the average of last year.  Scrap prices have dropped a little from its high in February, but it’s still up over 30% compared to  the average of last year.

file: SKF.B - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 19April2012 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Apr-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: We gained a number of new businesses, some of which we were able to announce and highlight in the report, such  as the new business for the wind industry with Vestas, the new business for railway with Siemens, and the wheel  end and transmission bearing business with Scania, which will mean that we will start manufacturing these  bearings in Brazil which will -- for Scania, which were previously imported there. This will help support Scania,  but also support our other prop customers there.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: But we also did very well in the Industrial business, with good sales growth in virtually all our major industries in  North America. Energy grew for us, both traditional and renewable. Off-highway was strong, as was Aerospace  and our Lubrication business. We also saw a very positive development in our sales to our industrial distributors.  North America in total has been very positive for SKF during last year, and this has continued this year.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: In Europe, the development was very much as expected. The Industrial business had the best growth, with sales to  renewable energy, aerospace, railway and our Lubrication business developing very well. Sales to industrial  distributors also held up very well, despite the uncertain market sentiment. As expected though, we saw a major  decline in our sales in the Automotive business. The car industry, heavy truck industry and vehicle service market  all suffered.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Moving over now to look at Asia. And here, we saw the biggest decline in our business and our sales in Asia were  much lower than expected. This was driven by significantly lower sales in our Industrial business and particularly,  our business in China. Although I must say that even though January was weak, and even if I discount the Chinese  New Year, China was weak, we saw some improvement in our business as we went through the quarter in Asia.  So, let me start now by saying a few words about China and what we saw for our business there. Our decline in  sales was mainly in the Industrial businesses, with a continued weak renewable energy business and a weak  railway business, which we have commented on before. I would say we still expect to start to see some recovery in  our sales to renewable energy in the second half of this year.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: So as I look at it overall, what you saw in China was weaknesses in our renewable energy, our Railway business,  our sales to industrial distributors, which was into general market and our Automotive business, which is specific  to the car business. Other industries down there developed quite well.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Turning over to India. Here in India, our sales were relatively flat year-on-year. And that means it didn't  developed as positively as they had done before. It was quite broad-based in India, I've got to say. There was some  segments up a little bit, some down. For example, in Automotive, cars were better, but trucks were a little bit  down. In our Industrial businesses, our sales to off-highway in India were better, but to renewable energy were a  little bit down, et cetera. So it was a mixed picture in India and I think our development was very much in line  with what's happening in the marketplace.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Let me turn over now and look a little a bit at raw materials and what's happening in raw materials at the moment.  I'd say all the main contracts now are completed and show some ups and downs, but overall, the base prices are  slightly up for the group this year compared to last year. If we look at specifically the second quarter, then we will  face slightly higher raw material costs than the second quarter last year and that's due to the surcharges.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Because if you look at it just now, today's surcharges are slightly lower than the average of last year. And they're  lower, of course, than what we saw in the second quarter last year. But what we see in the books in the second  quarter this year is what we had is surcharges from the early autumn last year. So, that will have some impact on  us year-on-year. So raw material will up a bit on last – compared to last year in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: So what are we doing about it? Well, we're continuing to work with sort of three actions. One, sourcing, to do what  we can do in sourcing, to see what we can do to offset the increase. Secondly, we're working in cost reduction, as  we always do. But thirdly, we're working on price increases. And at this point, I'd like to comment that we've  announced list price increases of around 4% in both Europe and U.S.A. and these will come into effect from the  beginning of July. And these price increases in these two major regions will help offset the higher input cost that  we are facing.

file: SKF.B - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 17April2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: We gained in the quarter a number of new businesses, as you can see in the report, with companies like Pratt &  Whitney for main shaft bearings for the aircraft engines, with Nordex for both bearings and lubrication systems  for wind energy, and for a very big and important steel producer where unfortunately I cannot give you the name.  I can tell you though this is a very important long-term contract covering nearly all our technology platforms and a  very good [ph] business (3:18) the team have done.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: At the start of this quarter, we attended the Hannover Messe, one of the largest industrial fairs in the world. At  that Messe, we launched a number of new products, some of which joined the BeyondZero portfolio such as the  Extended Life spherical plain bearings, which are used in industries such as construction, farm and forestry. We  launched a new magnetic – permanent magnetic motor and active magnetic bearing package for irrigation  blowers and wastewater plants. And both of these, the Extended Life spherical plain bearing and the permanent  magnetic motor will give our customer really, really great energy savings.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: We're working with pilot customers in wind energy, railway and the steel industry just now, and then we will go  out to other industries. As I said, this is a new breakthrough and we've now made our bearing not only the heart of  the machine but also the brains.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: We see an improving demand picture in China when I talk about renewable energy customers, which, as you  know, have been weak for us since mid-2011. Our railway business was down in the first quarter in China, but that  was basically due to no major contracts going through on freight cars. This should improve in the coming quarters  as new tenders will come out. Sales to industrial distribution also, which as you know has been weak for some  time, has stabilized there. So, overall for China, when you look across it, I would say we see a more stable business  and some positive signs that that will develop positively – better as we go through the year.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: In India, however, we still have some concerns. Basically all major industries in India showed declines, with the  biggest drop being in renewable energy, but also industries off-highway and the general industry were weak in  India. Sales to truck industry and cars were down in India, but the sales to the Vehicle Service Market and to our  two-wheeler business were – developed positively. I think India will take some time to recover. It's not showing  the same recovery as we've seen in – or strength as we've seen in China.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: If I look sequentially though, what you can also see though is that we had some improvement, some 1.2 percentage  points, again, if I clean them both from one-offs. And this was influenced and as a result of, of course, slightly  higher manufacturing volume, but also the cost reduction activities which we have. Cost reduction activities are  starting to give us some benefit. And my estimate is in the first quarter this year we had around SEK100 million of  benefit from our cost reduction activities that we've already taken. And that, if you compare it to last year. A little  bit less if you compare it to the fourth quarter, but SEK100 million if you compare it to last year.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: From an industry viewpoint, basically, aerospace is expected to continue to develop positively as will two-wheelers  and electrical. And you can see that energy which is renewable energy, we expect a positive sequential  development and that is driven by China, whereas I said earlier, we're now able to see in addition to a lot of things  you could see an improving activity in renewable energy in China.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Before I close, I'll turn to raw materials. Raw materials actually are slightly lower at the moment, the cost for raw  materials compared to last year. And I think that will remain the same in the second quarter, and that is generally  due to lower surcharges that was seen in the business. So, we'll get a little bit benefit from raw materials.

file: SKF.B - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 15April2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Maybe let me make some comments on Kaydon right now. They've started the year very well indeed with very  good growth and they also gained some important new businesses. Operating margin also improved year-on-year.  Of course, they are impacted by PPA and the fact that the fuel savings expected this year have not kicked in yet,  but excluding this, we still improved margin. You can also see in the Specialty Business area that even PEER and  GBC saw strong growth in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: From a country viewpoint, very good growth in China, driven by cars, sales to passenger rail, renewable energy,  but also in China, general industry developed okay for us. Indonesia was up. Here, two-wheelers were the driver.  India also showed some slight growth in the quarter. However, we still see weakness in Southeast Asia and  Australia. Our industrial distributors development was also slow in the quarter in Asia overall, although somewhat  better in China.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Turning now to look at raw materials, they are slightly lower compared to last year at the start of this year and will  remain so in the second quarter. We are facing some pressure from our suppliers for higher prices, but our  purchasing cost reduction program is working and we expect a similar development this year as we had last year  from our purchasing.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: So in closing, I think we made a solid first quarter. We've taken some important new orders. Our cost reduction  program continues to deliver results even if we have some negatives offsetting these.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President and CEO, SKF Group and President, Industrial Market
texts.text: Thank you very much. Welcome, ladies and gentlemen, here. We are in Sweden, a wonderful spring day, sunny  and warm and a lot of pollen in the air. So if I'm a little bit – if I sound a little bit different today, it's because I  have starting to feel it myself.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President and CEO, SKF Group and President, Industrial Market
texts.text: Well, today, we released our report for the first quarter of 2015. As always, we were very busy in the quarter. We  took a lot of new businesses across many industries, as you can see in the report, in rail, renewable and  automotive to name a few. We've also launched several new interesting innovations, some of which we have  included in the presentation material.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President and CEO, SKF Group and President, Industrial Market
texts.text: Our profitability excluded one-offs has also come in according to expectations. Henrik will come back to this.  During the quarter, we also became one of the first organizations to achieve the energy management ISO 50001  certification on a global scale. The group's energy management system is deployed across 38 manufacturing  facilities around the world, covering more than 90% of the group's total direct energy use.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President and CEO, SKF Group and President, Industrial Market
texts.text: As mentioned many times, one of the key activities going forward is the continued step-up of relevant technical  development to be able to differentiate, create value to our customers and to be cost competitive. Once such  initiative just announced is the investment of SEK 300 million in two large size bearing test rigs in Schweinfurt,  Germany. One is to be dedicated to bearings for wind turbines and the other for a wide range of application  segments such as marine, mining, construction and steel. In these rigs, real-life running conditions can be  replicated.

texts.speaker: Henrik Lange
texts.profession: Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In North America, our sales were lower than we thought going into the quarter. This is due to three main reasons.  First and foremost, on the industrial side, the direct and indirect effects of the lower activity in mining, farm and  forestry, and oil and gas had a negative effect on our sales to customers serving those industries. And the parts of  the industrial business, which developed well in North America were energy and industries outside of mining,  farm and forestry, and oil and gas.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President and CEO, SKF Group and President, Industrial Market
texts.text: Turning now to look on raw materials. The scrap surcharge just now remain a little lower than the average last  year, and they are at a similar level as the first quarter.

file: SKF.B - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 27April2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: We also officially opened our new fully-automated production channel of spherical roller bearings here in  Göteborg with already more than 200,000 bearings produced and delivered. We're also making good progress in  our ongoing investments in new factory technology in increased automation in our production facilities in the U.S.,  Germany and in Malaysia. At the Annual General Shareholders Meeting at the end of March we presented SKF's  new climate targets, where we set out to reduce the CO2 emissions per tonne of bearings sold and per tonne of  products shipped to customers by 40%, respectively. Our customers, investors, and society as a whole all benefit  from the concrete actions we are taking to increase efficiency and reduce emissions.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Every percent of friction we save, every gram of weight we remove, and every drop of lubrication we avoid  contribute to helping customers to reduce their costs and their environmental impact. Being at the heart of the  rotating machinery and equipment means that we are in a unique position to work together with customers to  provide the solutions needed.

texts.speaker: Christian Johansson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SKF AB
texts.text: As you know, our cost [ph] saving is above SEK 60 billion (13:09)  in the quarter. And year-over-year, we saw in  this quarter a negative impact of SEK 230 million on that cost [ph] case (13:18). We saw increased raw material  costs in the quarter, but we have other commercial activities. We have designer specification changes that have  compensated for these raw material increases.

file: SKF.B - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 26April2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: In the North America and Latin America, growth is also there. The underlying growth is there. The little bit weaker  figures in Latin America is, in my mind, entirely dependent on wind. Our large-size bearing factory dedicated to  wind applications has basically been standing still due to the fact that there has been no deployment of windmills  in Latin America basically during the quarter. We see, however, that we are now starting up the factory again.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: The same in North America, heavy trucks is going well, we are selling strong into industrial applications. And  here, it's basically the wind as well. There are some businesses in wind that we have decided not to pursue, and  that's the reason for a little bit lower absolute comparison figures than the underlying figures.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: If you look at the next slide, we'll talk a little bit about product. We have been chosen as the main development  partner for Volkswagen on the all-electric MEB vehicle platform, which is their future platform for their new electric  vehicles. That's fantastic.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: If you take the next slide, we talk about another good initiative, the LEAP engine. This is the new GE engine for  aircraft that's been ramped up. And our hard work to get the main lion's share of that program is now paying off  and we are growing strong in this business.

file: SKF.B - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 25April2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Christian Johansson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SKF AB
texts.text: We see good cost flexibility, less project expenses than what we discussed at that time, and we see more  reduction effects than we forecasted. While we also on the material cost side, we see some of larger negative  effects than what we guided for.

file: SKF.B - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 15July2010 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 At the start of last quarter, we opened the 2 new factories in India. I mentioned them at the last  report. And at the start of this quarter, we opened the new factory in Tver in Russia, where we will  manufacture railway axle bearing units for the Russian railway. It is the most modern railway  bearing factory in the world and with many, many new manufacturing innovations. This factory, like  the 2 factories in India, is built to the new LEED standard and will use something like 40% less  energy and something like 40% less water than a normal factory. And it will be one of the first  factories in Russia and in Europe to be made to the – certified to the LEED standard.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: During the quarter, we also gained some important business and I’ll highlight just one of them. I  think that the new unit we will deliver to the i-StARS stop-start motor alternator for Valeo is a very  important new business and underlines the commitment we have to deliver new products and  solutions which are not only environmentally friendly in how we manufacture them, but also help  our customers reduce their environmental impact during their operation. This new unit is used in  Valeo i-StARS system which reduces CO2 emission in the cars in which it’s fitted.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Some important steps to strengthen SKF in the future were made in the quarter and we really  focused on 4 key areas. One, building our knowledge and bringing it to our customers with the SKF  Solution Factories; two, investing in new manufacturing facilities in faster growing regions; three,  investing in product development and innovation close to our customers; and fourth, getting new  business building from an environmental focus.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The Industrial Division moved back into growth, up some 7% driven by strong demand in Asia,  some improvement in North America, but Europe was still down a little bit, primarily due to the  aerospace and renewable energy segments being down year-on-year. But actually when I look at  them, both these segments show signs that the decline has leveled off in them.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In China, the main segments doing well are renewable energy, industrial gearboxes, fluid power,  railway and the car industry. In India, we also had a very strong growth, with a similar growth in the  segments as we have seen in China, but here also tops – the top two-wheelers, railway, renewable  energy, fluid power are doing well.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In North America, we saw a good growth run into double-digit, despite the fact that our Service  Division was down due to the earlier mentioned destocking. The car and heavy truck business was  very strong in the quarter, and then the industrial market, sales particularly in construction  equipment manufacturing was very strong, but also fluid power, agriculture areas in America were  doing well. We still see a weak aerospace business in North America and saw a small recovery in  the renewable energy in North America.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the industrial business in Europe, industrial segment such as fluid power, agriculture, pulp and  paper, machine tools are developing well. However, as I mentioned earlier, we have a weak  renewable energy business and a weak aerospace business. This looks to have leveled out in  Europe, so I expect some improvement in that as we go towards the end of the year and into the  start of next year. Overall in the quarter, very good volume development with strong growth in Asia  and Latin America, growth in North America and now growth in – also in Europe.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We still have some 2.5 to 3,000 people in short-time working, but the hours they are not working is  less and less as we’re increasing our production and weather in short-time is mainly in the larger  industrial sizes. Short-time working set does around SEK 60 million in this quarter. Restructuring,  the restructuring programs we’ve announced before, gave us around SEK 220 million savings. So  that means the combination of these two is around SEK 280 million savings compared to normal.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Regarding material cost, we’ve – if I look at in the results, we’ve not really seen the full effect of the  surcharges from our suppliers due to the higher scrap prices, yet it’s not really conflicted into our  figures. We have some effect, but not the full effect and that’s because it takes time to come  through, from us getting to come through into our results. Scrap, let’s say, the level is now  somewhat lower than it was just a couple of months ago, but it’s still well off on the average of last  year. And I think that in the third quarter raw material will be somewhat of a headwind.

file: SKF.B - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 15July2011 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: As planned, we are stepping up our activities in research and development and our investment in R&D is up over  20% in the first half. We launched a number of new products many of which help our customers reduce their  environmental impact, and we signed an agreement for a new University Technology Center with Chalmers that  will focus on sustainability.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: I'm sure that you are picking up our very interesting theme and what we've been doing during the last quarter.  And that is an increased focus on research and development within the environmental arena with many of the new  products and services we launched and lot of the development we are doing is focusing on helping our customers  reduce their environmental impact.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: In India, the main segments of growth were renewable energy, railway, industrial gear boxes as well as two  wheelers, trucks and the vehicle service market, I've got to say we had a good positive development on the other  main markets in the region as well, particularly in our sales to the two wheeler market in Indonesia.  In North America, we saw continued good development overall from an Industrial viewpoint, the main segments  of growth were fluid power or I should say pumps and compressors, we call it fluid power internally, pumps and  compressors, construction equipment, agriculture equipment and mining equipment.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: I must say, we don't see any positive development yet in our sales in North America to the renewable energy  sector. We've a very good development also in our Service Division with distributor sales going very well, which  little effect from the de-stocking which has affected our sales in previous years.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Our sales to industrial distributors in Europe are developing very positively as well. We're yet however to see a  recovery in our sales in Europe to the renewable energy sector. But as I said last quarter, there are signs that  towards the end of this year they may start to develop more positively.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: I must say, I said this last quarter, but I confirm, I think the team has done a great job in managing all these  activities, the reduced costs, the sourcing and pricing, to offset the higher raw material costs we faced in the  quarter. We've done it. We've offset as we said we would.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: If I look at the current view on raw material, we will continue to see higher raw material costs as we go through  the year. The surcharges we have for scrap, we're facing from our steel and component suppliers are significantly  higher than this period last year, and of course higher than the average of last year.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: When I look at the divisions, Industrial will continue to develop positively both from a sequential viewpoint year- on-year and we see all the main industries for the Industrial business continue to develop positively but we're still  cautious about wind energy in the third quarter and that's why we see a flat sequential development for wind  energy.

file: SKF.B - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 18July2012 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: The third order is the one we announced last week, and that's the – for the wind industry. The Nautilus bearing is  a special main shaft bearing we developed a few years ago. And recently, we launched the next generation of  Nautilus. And I'm delighted we've now received the first major order for this. It's a multi-year order with one of  the major wind turbine manufacturers. Wind market is an important one for SKF, and this order reinforces our  commitment to support our customers in that market. That's some important orders.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: In the quarter, we also stepped up our activities in the environmental arena with the launch of a new BeyondZero  portfolio of solutions and by SKF joining the WWF Climate Savers program. We'll cover this in detail at the  Capital Market Day, so I'm not going to lesson any more here. But just remind you that from the BeyondZero  solutions, we plan to quadruple our sales over the next five years, which basically means that with that  quadrupling, the BeyondZero portfolio will account for more than 10% of the growth of the group over that period,  which is a sort of important part of our growth.  Now, back to the financials and let me first start with demand development. For the group overall, our volume was  somewhat similar to the first quarter and down nearly 3% year-on-year. But again, we had a different picture  around the world, with our sales developing positively in the Americas, both North America and Latin America  showing very good growth, up over 8% and 16% respectively. In Europe, we saw a decline of over 3%. And in Asia,  our business is down some 8% which actually is a similar decline in Asia as we saw in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Our Industrial business developed positively as well, with a good development in our sales to most of the  industries we serve. To mention a few, we saw a positive development in our sales to energy, both renewable and  traditional, off-highway, aerospace and our lube business, lubrication business in total. We also saw a good growth  in our sales to our industrial distributors.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: East Europe developed well overall, with respective markets in Hungary and Russia developing positively, while  other markets like Poland, Czech Republic didn't develop so well. The main change during the quarter was in  Northern Europe, where we saw some softening as we went through the quarter in the major countries such as  Germany and Sweden. So let us look – maybe a little bit more detail in the industries in total in Europe. Industrial  business still saw growth overall, but I've got to say, this was driven by the sales to renewable energy and our sales  to aerospace, where we saw a strong development.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: In renewable energy, it is due to the new business we've gained, not the market as such. When I look at the other  industries, such as off-highway, metals, paper and railway, then we saw some weakening of our growth in the  quarter there and we saw some weakening in the business in the quarter. Our sales to our industrial distributors,  I've got to say, held up very well despite the uncertain market development.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Here, our decline in sales was mainly in Industrial businesses. Renewable energy continue to be weak. Railway  business improved for us for freight cars, but not for passenger rail and we saw weak sales to our distributors, due  to the continued money supply issues, which is also affecting their ability to pay us.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: In India, the turnover there, our sales overall all weakened a little bit in the quarter, reflecting, to be honest,  what's going on in the economy. While our sales to cars and two-wheelers grew in India, our sales to the truck  industry really dropped a lot. Our Industrial business also was a mixed picture with renewable energy down a lot,  but some general segments doing okay.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Turning to Asia, I've got to say this is – it and Europe are the most difficult to judge. But we expect to stay now in  Asia at a similar level sequentially. However, since the fact that we started to see a downturn in Asia in our  business in the third quarter last year, if you remember, that's when renewable energy really went down a lot, we  will probably also see a lot of the unchanged business year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Turning to raw materials, they will be a little bit higher than in the third quarter last year and that's – if you look  at surcharges in the third quarter are lower than the average of last year and also lower in the third quarter last  year. But what we will see in our books is the surcharges we got right at the end of last year, beginning of this year.  So that plus the slightly higher base prices that we'll pay will mean that our raw material will be a little bit higher.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: And as normal, we will continue to drive our three actions to offset raw material impact, which we've done  successfully so far and you know that well. We'll use our sources of supply and improve our sourcing. We'll reduce  cost and we'll increase prices. And I'd just like to, on the prices, remind you that we have increased list prices by  around 4% in both Europe and U.S.A. from July 1. So, we'll see some impact there as we go through the third  quarter.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: In closing, I think we had a pretty good first half of 2012, especially when you look at the uncertain and changing  invest in our business and launched our BeyondZero portfolio of solutions. Now, back to you, Marita, and then  over to questions.

file: SKF.B - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 16July2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Let's look region-by-region. Asia, our main business for SI in Asia is in China and India. In China, we see a slightly  positive sequential development, but driven by renewable energy and some positive signs in our general industry,  which is pumps and compressors. However, railway, off-highway remained very weak in China.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Turning to India, our business is down a lot here in SI, but we do  see signs of stabilization. And I've got to say also,  in India, we see some improvement in renewable energy.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: The first step of the program and the cost part of the program is on purchasing, and that's moving in a good way in  total, even if we don't see a major impact from the program so far. We have some benefit coming through from  lower scrap surcharges at the moment, which is reducing our input cost. This should continue in the next couple  of quarters when we will see the benefit in the surcharges in the first half of this year coming through to the  income statement.

file: SKF.B - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 15July2014 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: As always, we were very busy in the quarter. We took a lot of new orders, as you can see in the report, across many  businesses: renewable energy, service, automotive, railways, to name a few. There are many more which we  cannot mention yet, and it was a very successful quarter for new business for the group.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: We also increased our investment in R&D as planned and launched many new products, as you can see both in the  report and in the presentation. Again, I mean, focus of these new solutions is energy and fuel efficiency, helping  our customers reduce their energy costs and give benefits to their customers.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: One highlight though was the order for over SEK 1.2 billion for the North American renewal energy customer for  business in both North America and Brazil. I know personally that one major factor in that decision was the  combined strength of SKF and Kaydon with our existing SKF presence in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Taking China, our sales continued to develop very positively for renewable energy, for railway and, of course, in  particular high-speed rail where we gained market share. We also saw positive development in industrial drives  which is pumps, compressors and gear boxes. Our car business in China and in Asia in total, I'd say, developed  very well. Trucks were good in China, but weak in India. Two -wheeler business in Indonesia developed very well,  but is relatively unchanged in India. If I look at the industrial distribution arena, I'd say in all of Asia it still lacks a   little bit of traction.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: In North America, switching to there, our Industrial business developed well, as we felt it would when we  presented last quarter with renewable energy, railway and the drives business, which as you know is pumps,  compressor and gear boxes, developing positively. Our Aerospace business was down year -on-year, but this was  due to a tough comparison since we had a very strong quarter last year. Sequentially, it was as expected. Industrial  distribution was a little bit more positive in the quarter, and this change should continue in the third quarter.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Maybe it was some correction before the summer break, but there's too much to watch as we go through the third  quarter. Vehicle service market was also down a bit in the quarter. From an industrial viewpoint, we saw good  growth in renewable energy, railway and aerospace, but general and heavy industry were impacted.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Turning now to look at raw materials and excluding the purchasing program where we expect a similar saving  year-on-year as in the third quarter. [indiscernible] (15:12) just now remain a little lower than the average last  year, but they're at a similar level as at the start of this year.

file: SKF.B - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 15July2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson

texts.text: Weaker demand was seen in heavy industry and the distributor segment in North America, as well as an  underlying weaker demand in China. The automotive business in North America was also slow in the quarter. We  took a number of new very interesting businesses across several industries as you can see in the report; in rail,  renewable energy, aerospace and automotive, to name a few.

file: SKF.B - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 21July2016 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: We have also developed a new low friction truck hub unit. This wheel end solution offers 30% lower friction and  fuel reduction compared to standard wheel bearing sets. One European truck manufacturer has already placed an  order for this low friction wheel end solution.

SKF.B - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 19July2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-18.pdf

file: SKF.B - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 19October2010 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Oct-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, welcome to this nine month conference call with SKF. And it will last around 45
texts.text: In addition to our strategies, our strategic direction, which as I say is unchanged, the steps that  we’re taking, we’ve got three big initiatives that we’re driving in SKF. First of all, to accelerate our  growth – accelerate our profitable growth in the business. Secondly, to reduce cost and eliminate  waste and certainly to invest in growth.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, welcome to this nine month conference call with SKF. And it will last around 45
texts.text: And secondly to accelerate the growth, we need to increase the development and the launch of  new products. We’ve been successful in bringing new products to the market. But now we must  keep doing that and commercialize them in the marketplace. But in particular going forward, we  have a much more green emphasis on it; on products which are much more energy efficient, which  help our customers reduce CO2 emissions, reduce their energy costs and therefore very beneficial  for them in total.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, welcome to this nine month conference call with SKF. And it will last around 45
texts.text: The second initiative to hit the target is to focus very much on reducing cost, eliminating waste from  in the business. We have launched a couple of years ago in SKF an initiative we call Manufacturing       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, welcome to this nine month conference call with SKF. And it will last around 45
texts.text: Secondly, we will focus on continuing to move production or increase production in best-cost  countries and also increase sourcing in best-cost countries for the SKF Group. We have more cost- effective manufacturing. And certainly, we will focus on really looking at cost and see how we can  reduce cost in our products and that’s they key aim. We spoke at the Capital Market Day about a  program you’ve heard in SKF called Integrated Cost Reduction, which basically we release tons of  products and lots of detail; this is how we can reduce product cost, it’s been successful with  Automotive and we’re moving that into other areas.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, welcome to this nine month conference call with SKF. And it will last around 45
texts.text: Lubrication combined with other platform is all about managing and reducing friction, helping us to  help our customers reduce friction [inaudible] reduce cost and improve the effect on the  environment, and lubrication systems we believe is the key and core technology for us in SKF and  we see that we can continue to develop that business. It very much, as I say, supports our total  platforms and it supports our ability to help our customers improve productivity and reduce their  energy consumption. It’s a market – lubrication systems as a market – a little bit more 20 billion  SEK worldwide, it has two main product areas, technology areas; one is oil-based lubrication  systems and the other is grease-based lubrication systems. And that’s due to many, many –  industries from heavy industry, which could be metals or mining or pulp and paper to a machine  tools, marine industry to wind energy, of highway, agricultural et cetera. So many different  industries there.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, welcome to this nine month conference call with SKF. And it will last around 45
texts.text: The key industries that Lincoln are in, from an automated lubrication system business is of  highway, is wind energy, is agriculture and mining, which very much complements the key  industries we’ve got of machine tool, marine, printing and metals there.
