file: SKF.B - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 19October2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: However, even with this turbulence in the markets, we did not see any real impact on our business in the quarter.  Our Industrial businesses continued to grow at a similar pace to earlier in the year. Of course, from this I exclude  the wind business in China, which I will comment on a little bit later, so no real impact there.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: I also must say very pleased that we maintained our membership of both the Dow Jones' Sustainability Index and  FTSE Good Index. We continue to invest as a group in the research and development and have increased our  spend by about nearly 27% in the first nine months of this year as we're stepping up the innovation activities in  SKF. In fact in Q3, the increase was somewhat more and it did affect, of course, the gross margin there by

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Turning to Asia, you see that it grew by just under 5%. I'm sure you saw that as a strange figure. The reason was  quite simple. As the quarter progressed, the wind energy business in China went from weak to virtually a stop for  us. This is due to three reasons. One, the control of permits for new wind farms has been taken off. Secondly, the  supply of money in the new wind format operators to get to invest in the wind farms has become tighter.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: And, of course, there was a lot of wind farms that were installed last year that are still to be connected. I did a  rough calculation. And if I say without the impact of wind in China coming virtually to a stop, those sales in Asia  would have been up probably 3, maybe 4 points better than they were.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: In India, we had the same segments growing well. But here we also saw, in India, a good growth from renewable  energy. In other markets in the region, we continue to see a positive development, particularly in our sales to the  two-wheeler market in Indonesia.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Sales to the renewable energy sector in North America have stabilized with our old level. We have a very good  development in this Service division with our distributor sales going well. And Automotive business, our sales to  the light vehicle industry developed very much in line with our expectations.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: In Europe, our sales to industrial distributors are developing well. And we're seeing some improvement in activity  within the renewable energy segment in Europe. I expect it to fully improve as the year goes on.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Let me turn a little bit and talk about the profit development. We continue to face higher raw material cost, much  higher than last year, due to higher base prices and sub charges. However, as you probably see, the scrap price has  been down a little recently. But it still remained over 20% higher than the average of last year. It will be  interesting to see how raw material prices develop in the coming months alone. If I read commodity outlooks from  some independent agencies, it says it will remain at high levels. We have been able to offset the higher raw  material price in the quarter with the same three actions which we've used before and I will not go through them.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Let me move on now to the outlook for the fourth quarter, since I'm sure that that is the most interesting point for  you. I must say it's been a really difficult outlook to make this day, since there is a lot of uncertainty in the market.  But I've got to say, we do not see major signs of change in order intake from our customers and their information,  but especially if I exclude the four segments of car, trucks, railway, wind energy. In all the other segments, which  are mainly the industrial segments, we don't see any weakening demand from our customers.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Let me switch to Asia. Here I see no real change from the level we're at just now even with a continued expected  weak demand in wind energy business, which means a slight growth year-on-year. But really, running at the same  level as I just said.

file: SKF.B - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 17October2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Oct-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Marita Björk
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, SKF AB
texts.text: Now let's switch over to some of the new business we gained. And they're in the report, but I'd like to highlight  them, if I could. There's the new business for magnetic bearings. We'll supply them to projects in turbo gas  expanders and two new gas projects in Australia. And by the way, we are the world market leader in supply and  manufacture of magnetic bearings.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, SKF AB
texts.text: Another new business was the business we gained from our BeyondZero portfolio solutions, one of them is SKF  Bus Door Actuator. We talked about that back in May that we had been doing testing on that, and now we've  gained the business on it, and we will supply that to Volvo Bus starting early next year.  And we gained some important business in bonded piston seals, where we have a very good technology there, and  this will be used in automatic transmissions for Mazda in Japan. So, a number of good businesses in the quarter,  these are the ones we can talk about. There were many more businesses we gained.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, SKF AB
texts.text: Our industrial business, however, did not develop as positively as in the first half. Sales – our sales to general  industries such as pumps, compressors, small gearboxes, et cetera, were down slightly in the quarter. Our  business to off-highway was okay in the quarter, but it's weakening and we can see that – a weakening trend,  especially from an orderbook viewpoint there. And our sales to renewable energy were down a lot in North  America. But that, a you know, is not such a big market for us.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, SKF AB
texts.text: If we look at it from an industry viewpoint, then – and in fact with the industrial market, if we exclude aerospace  and renewable energy, who both grew in the quarter, then all other main industries declined year-on-year and  sequentially. Aerospace, as you know, is going pretty well. Renewable energy is due to the fact that we've gained  some new businesses, it's not that the market itself is developing well.  In the other industries we saw declines in general industry such as pumps, compressors, gearboxes, as we saw in  USA, and in heavy industries, such as metal, cement, and paper. And we also saw industrial distribution going  down for us.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, SKF AB
texts.text: In China, our decline in sales remains mainly in the industrial businesses. Renewable energy continued to be  weak. We thought it would get better as we went through the year, but it's remained very, very weak. The railway  business was weak a little bit for freight cars. What that means it didn't grow for freight cars, both the new tender  was delayed, and the announced stimulus for the railway industry has not really had any impact.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, SKF AB
texts.text: In India, our sales declined in the quarter. We faced a very weak development in the industrial market. Renewable  energy was down, general industry, et cetera: really quite broad based, down, in Indian market, as well as our  sales to industrial distributors was down there. From an automotive viewpoint, I'd say mainly the highlight was  the sales to heavy trucks, which were down a lot as well.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, SKF AB
texts.text: Turning now to look at raw materials. I would say, raw materials, they will be relatively unchanged to what –  compared to last year, but a little bit better than the third quarter. This is due to lower surcharges, not a big  change in the base prices.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, SKF AB
texts.text: Looking forward, we're working with our suppliers to finalize the contracts for next year, so it is too early to give a  view on that yet. But be sure we're working on that now. When I look at the macro environment, although, I must  say I expect some improvement in our purchase prices as we go forward into next year.

file: SKF.B - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 15October2013 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: We also gained a number of new orders in the industrial business and we highlighted some examples from China  such as the [ph] renewal (02:46) energy order from Goldwind where we're the main supplier for the 2.5 megawatt  turbine. We also gained some important business for wheel bearing units for high speed trains and for bearings  for coal power plants.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: In our service business, we continue to gain orders in Latin America, which helps drive our business in this region.  We're also setting up our activities to strengthen our service business in China with both the establishment of the  [ph] gear box (03:11) remanufacturing center, and the joint venture with WISCO Heavy for remanufacturing. Our  work on sustainability continues and I'm delighted that for the 14th y ear in a row we're included in the Dow Jones  Sustainability Index. I think that's a great achievement.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: In Asia, we had a growth of 5% in our sales which was broadly in line with our expectations. From a country  viewpoint, we had good growth in China driven by strong sales to the car industry, to the vehicle service market, to  railway and to renewable energy, which continues the trend we saw in the last qua rter.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Elsewhere in Asia we had good sales in Indonesia with two wheelers of course being the main driver and also in  South Korea. However, sales in countries like Malaysia and Thailand were weak. Looking at India, t he largest –  the second largest market in the region for us, we see a slight improvement but only slight, mainly from  automotive, renewable energy and general industry.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Let's go to North America and here we did not see the expected development. I still believe in the medium term  and long term development in North America, but just know with all that's happening politically, it's influencing  demand, especially in the industrial arena. Our distributors are very cautious and they are destocking. Off- highway, especially related to mining was weak also. However, we do see good growth in aerospace and in railway.  Our energy business both traditional and renewable developed well, but it is relatively small in the big picture.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: From a regional and a business area viewpoint, we see all of them staying at around the same level as they are just  now except for Asia where we expect a slight sequential improvement and this is driven by the end markets we  serve in Asia. Cars and light vehicles which we expect to continue well, renewable energy, railway, two -wheelers  we expect these ones to continue well and improve sequentially and that brings Asia up sequentiall y.

file: SKF.B - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 15October2014 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If you remember, we mentioned last quarter that we were very successful in getting new order, new business of  SEK 1.2 billion with a North American wind energy manufac turer for deliveries in both the U.S.A. and in Brazil. As  a result, we announced this week, we will now build a new factory in Brazil on the same campus as our existing  operating unit, [ph] I would say this – (04:00) operations outside of São Paulo to manufacture these bearings  locally. The total investment for Brazil is some SEK 220 million which roughly SEK 60 million is transferred  equipment.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Finally, I'm delighted that once again we've been recognized as a member of both Dow Jones Sustainability Index  for the 15th consecutive year and the FTSE4Good Index for the 14th consecutive year. So as always, a busy and  successful quarter from an activity viewpoint.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Let me comment specifically on China. We continue to see a positive development in our sales to industries such  as renewable energy, railway and the car business. Our sales within industrial drives, which is pumps,  compressors, gear boxes, developed slightly positively, whereas we still see some weakness in heavy industries in  China such as metals and mining. And I've got to say, [ph] a lack (06:41) of traction in industrial distribution in  China.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: From an industrial viewpoint, good growth in renewable energy, railway and aerospace, but general industry in  Europe remains pretty lackluster. So overall, Europe was flat in sales, but, of course, with the price/mix  magnitude, it is a little bit down in volume. This is not surprising at all when you look at the signals in Europe just  now and the geopolitical situation.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: From a manufacturing viewpoint, we will run the manufacturing level slightly lower than the third quarter year - on-year there to reduce inventory but also to reflect our cautiousness due to the uncertainty we see in the  marketplace. Turning now to look at raw materials and excluding purchasing program, where we expect a similar  saving as in the third quarter, scrap surcharges just now are a little bit lower, just to mention tha t – then they are  [ph] noted to (13:42) last year.

file: SKF.B - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 16October2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President and CEO, SKF Group and President, Industrial Market
texts.text: At the beginning of the year, we launched a white-collar cost efficiency program that would result in a reduction of  1,500 staff. Although these are very difficult decisions to make, I'm pleased to say that agreements have now been  reached with almost all of these colleagues. Given current market conditions, these actions alone are, however, not  sufficient and we will continue our cost reduction activities across the group.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President and CEO, SKF Group and President, Industrial Market
texts.text: Turning to the next slide and our sales development by region compared to last year, I would like to talk you  through each of our key regions with regards to sales and demand development. What we saw on an overall level  in the quarter is that the global economic climate with slowing growth rates in China and increased uncertainty  about how this will impact the world economy is impacting the industrial activity and therefore market demand.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President and CEO, SKF Group and President, Industrial Market
texts.text: Sales to the railway, energy, heavy industries, and off-highway segments were significantly lower. In Europe,  overall sales were slightly lower in the quarter with significantly lower sales to both energy and industrial heavy  industries compared to last year while we saw growth in the railway sector. In China, we saw weakening demand  across most of our segments, including rail and industrial distribution, while sales to the energy sector were  stronger.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President and CEO, SKF Group and President, Industrial Market
texts.text: Along the same theme of supporting global customers, we are now providing MAN with truck-matched wheel-end  units, having already signed a similar agreement with Scania. And on the industrial side, an interesting  development with condition monitoring where we are providing a total solution for one of Greece's major shipping  lines, equipping 70 ships with full remote condition monitoring services.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President and CEO, SKF Group and President, Industrial Market
texts.text: Turning to the next slide and some operational highlights. Divestment of non-core businesses in order to focus  our resources and strengthen the balance sheet continued with the divestment of Canfield. Our previously  announced new factory in Cajamar, Brazil to produce slewing bearings for the wind segment opened and a  number of new products were launched, including an updated range of SKF Explorer spherical roller bearings  used in traction motors for elevators.

texts.speaker: Christian Johansson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: Next page, we have the cost reduction program that was communicated in December last year. This will be  completed in the fourth quarter. We have agreements made with more than 1,400 employees out of the 1,500  targeted.

texts.speaker: Christian Johansson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President
texts.text: Given current market conditions, these actions alone are however not sufficient and we will continue cost  reduction activities across the group. We will report this program separately also in the next quarterly report, but  as of next year, it will be reported only as part of the profit bridge.

file: SKF.B - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 26October2016 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: And now to some examples of new business. SKF is supplying a range of bearings, seals, and linear actuation  technologies for Scania's new generation of trucks. The result of over 10 years of development, during which time  SKF has worked in conjunction with Scania on developing tailored solutions to improve fuel efficiency and driver  comfort.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: SKF delivers gearbox bearings, prop shaft bearings, and engine bearings and seals. The tailor-made wind  deflector, which uses linear action (sic) [actuation] technology to allow for ease of adjustment, is also being  supplied by SKF.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: SKF is also supplying updated front- and rear-wheel truck hub units, which reduce friction by up to 30% compared  to standard wheel bearing sets. Deliveries to Scania have already started with the first new-generation long haul  trucks currently being assembled in [indiscernible] .

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Next slide, SKF's active magnetic bearing technology has already enabled a number of breakthroughs within the  oil and gas sector. Through this agreement, we are strengthening our technology leadership, enhancing our  relationship with GE Oil & Gas. We are also implementing a new business model which will ensure that we widen  the scope of applications for these technologies.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: The groundbreaking mill will use 100% of the raw materials and run solely on renewable energy. SKF has  manufactured and supplied its largest ever spherical roller bearing with an outer diameter of about 2 meters to be  used within the mining industry. The bearing was manufactured out of a factory here in Gothenburg.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: SKF signed a two-year contract to supply a wide range of bearings and support services to CMPC, one of the  world's leading manufacturer of pulp, tissue, forestry, and paper and packaging products.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: The SKF HBU3 units are becoming the industry standard for high-end cars and was selected by FCA's recently  launched Alfa Romeo Giulia, offered a range of compelling advantages over conventional wheel bearing designs.  These include faster and more straightforward assembly and a longer service life as well as exceptionally low  levels of noise and vibration.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Next slide. I would also like to mention some of our new products offers. For the wind industry, we have launched  a new spherical roller bearings for wind turbine main shafts. Manufactured to deliver outstanding reliability, these  self-aligning bearings provide exceptional performance and meet self-service needs for more than 25 years.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: There is also a new one-box kit version of the proven Vibracon technology for the quick, accurate and clean  alignment and chocking of resilient mounts. It is particularly quick and easy to use in the maritime industry, for  example, under engines, generators, and skids, and is both adjustable and reusable.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: SKF Dynamic Stabilizer Cover is a flexible, pneumatically operated cover system that offers significant fuel  savings with minimal complexity and low maintenance requirements. It reduces drag and improves the efficiency  of passenger vessels equipped with SKF retractable fin stabilizers type S and Z. And finally, SKF Centrifugal Lip  Seals, designed to save energy, improve performance, and extend maintenance intervals in high-speed rail  applications that we launched.

file: SKF.B - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 31October2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: We continued to make good progress in our rotating performance offering. One recent example is the IMx-8  remote condition monitoring solution selected by Sirius Shipping, supporting its effort to improve reliability across  the fleet of 10 oil and chemical tankers. This compact system is a plug-and-play solution that is compatible with  Sirius Shipping existing maintenance systems.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: We're also investing for the future in terms of our own capabilities in research and product development, and we  have just opened a new European aeronautical test center dedicated to high-speed aeronautical bearings in  Valenciennes, France. It will enable full-scale, high-speed bearing testing under representative operating and  environmental conditions. It will also make it possible to speed up the maturity ramp-up for advanced technology,  such as those linked to sensors and signals processing.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Among the very first bearings that it now mounted, that's what you see to the left on the picture there how we  mount this big bearing, is the new line of spherical roller bearings that the Gothenburg factory has developed,  especially for the wind industry using our application-specific development approach.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: By industry, we saw strong sales to the energy industry, as well as the heavy, special and off-highway industries,  industrial and general industries, and to industrial distribution, while sales to the car and light trucks industries  were lower.

texts.speaker: Christian Johansson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SKF AB
texts.text: Turning page to the P&L of the group, just some comments to the margins. Gross profit in the P&L was – gross  margin was 0.6% lower in this quarter three last year. But since we have had, and as I've commented, large  changes year-over-year in the one-timers, if we adjust for one-timers as we have done in the upper right graph  there, gross margin improved 2% versus last year since most of the one-timers both last year and this year  related to COGS.

file: SKF.B - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 25October2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Christian Johansson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SKF AB
texts.text: Cost development in the quarter gave a negative effect of SEK 347 million year-over-year. The material cost  increased by SEK 160 million versus last year. And the higher material cost is due to delays in cost-saving  projects, the negative mix consumption effect, and to steel tariffs. Cost inflation was around SEK 275 million and  included higher utility costs due to the warm summer. Remaining cost items sum up to positive SEK 88 million,  and I will mention some of them.

texts.speaker: Christian Johansson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SKF AB
texts.text: So, I take some comments to the guidance on the bridge for quarter four, we expect to see a continued positive  effect from price/mix in quarter four with a similar year-over-year effect as in quarter three. Inventories, we will  continue to reduce our finished goods stock, and we expect a negative year-over-year effect on operating profit of  about SEK 120 million. And on the cost side, material cost impact, we expect to remain at SEK 160 million. We  will see more cost-saving activities implemented, but steel tariffs will increase somewhat.

texts.speaker: Christian Johansson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Senior Vice President, SKF AB
texts.text: Cost inflation will also remain on similar level as high energy costs will remain. And then we expect some  additional increases from bearing import tariffs due to volume. And then the impact on footprint, R&D and IT will  remain also in quarter four [indiscernible] (00:11:53) are good and improve our efficiency and pricing power for the  future.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, good afternoon and welcome everybody here today and everybody who are linked
texts.text: If I look now in the first quarter we can see surcharges are up again. There, I think the current, or a  couple of days ago, the scrap rate in Rotterdam was something like €345 a ton which is up quite  significantly, so the surcharges are up, but we also see that the raw material commodity suppliers  are increasing prices, pushing hard to increase prices into the markets. So we see higher base  prices and of course higher surcharges there. It’s clear that as in previous years our focus will be to  do what we’ve done which is to offset these raw material costs through actions in cost reduction,  through actions in sourcing, through actions in pricing in the market place area and we will do that  this year as well.

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, good afternoon and welcome everybody here today and everybody who are linked
texts.text: Let’s move on and just close it up by looking, and remind you, the long-term targets that we set  ourselves now: to move to a 15% operating margin level, to grow by 8%, and up to a 27% return in  cap employed in our business. These are the longer term targets that we want to meet, it’s not one  that we should meet immediately, but longer term targets that we focus on there. We put three  initiatives in place, accelerate our growth, reduce costs, eliminate waste in our business and invest       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Marita Björk, Head, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon, good afternoon and welcome everybody here today and everybody who are linked
texts.text: In terms of the efficiency in operations, I’ve already mentioned that we will move much more into  business excellence and I will talk more about that, what it means by that, at the Capital Market  Day when we go forward. But it’s very much about looking at the lean way of thinking, looking at the  flow in your business and finding ways to eliminate waste in our business. In manufacturing we’ve  done a lot of work in that and we’ve had good developments there. We’re now bringing that into all  the other areas of SKF as well, but we really believe there is opportunity to make us more effective,  more efficient in supporting the business.

file: SKF.B - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 26January2012 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jan-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Business in magnetic bearings for subsea compressors for helping them pump oil or gas over an operating subsea  that can support from Sandvik and what we've done with Sandvik, et cetera. A number of important steps that  we've been taking and this is just a sample of some of the customer orders and you'll see more of them when you  align your report in a few weeks' time as well.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Trading for our distributors is important and we've established two new technology – University Technology  Centers both in Sweden. One in Chalmers, which is for sustainability and one in Luleå, we announced just before  the end of the year, which is very much worked with asset management and condition monitoring. And it's good  because in Luleå, we have one of our major development centers for the group for condition monitoring there. So  that will work together with them. And we continue to work in sustainability, which I think is important.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: I am – but you can see Latin America was strong for us, Asia and Europe didn't really grow from a volume term  viewpoint for us. And Europe, very much driven by the automotive business, our car business being down in  Europe, our truck business, our vehicle service market. So, automotive in Europe that was the drive for the  European business and that will continue into the first quarter.  In Asia, it was primarily renewable energy, in India – railway in India, but of course sales of the car business in  India – China I should say. Renewable energy in China, railway in China and the car business in China didn't grow  so much in the fourth quarter, it wasn't growing with the rate that was growing overall in total for us.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: If you ask me compared to our outlook, how do I see things? Let's say America, a little bit better, because America  continued well. Cars was good for us in America. We saw good growth in that business, very good growth in our  industrial business, construction equipment strong, renewable energy coming back in North America and the  other broad-based industries that we've had before, fluid, power, et cetera still performing well in America. So I'd  say, North America, a little bit better. Europe in line, Asia a little bit less than we expected going into the quarter.  Divisions broadly in line in total.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Over the last eight years, we made 21 acquisitions. Over the last six years, 18 acquisitions across all platforms. And  I think one very important thing is with the acquisitions we've made – the six acquisitions we've made in  lubrication systems, we now have a clear leadership position and that was I think is very important. And we  stepped up a lot of our spend on research and development. And we – as you saw earlier, we're taking up the  innovation rate in SKF. More patents being put in place, bunch of more for us over 30 new products in the last  year and more than with our focus on energy efficiency.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: In Asia Pacific, we see the drop of that we've seen due to the renewable, due to the railways has stabilized, so a bit  relatively stable. But we also think it will be relatively stable year-on-year in our Asian business. North America,  we think will continue to develop very positively for us. We see good signs in our car business, into North America  which was strong in the fourth quarter. We expect to do good in the first quarter. We've seen our industrial  business very good signs.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Renewable energy has improved a little bit for us as we've gone through the fourth quarter in North America. That  should continue. We see construction equipment, especially some of our big construction customers, agricultural  customers, very optimistic and very positive and we see that in our business with them for the start. So,  sequentially, we see North America up and also up quite a bit, and that's across the three divisions. Latin America,  we expect to see at a good level such as now, but to be up a little bit year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: When I go into the segments, what you see from a sequential development is two coming up, Aerospace which has  been like that for some time, but also energy and you may say why energy there? I can say in the energy business,  we see a – for our demand on us has somewhat better energy business in Europe, somewhat better in Northern –  in U.S.A., somewhat better in India, but we still expect China to be very, very weak in the first quarter. I think  China wind energy will stay weak for a couple of more quarters to be honest.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: I've got to say, if you look at basically at our business what we're seeing, if you take away cars or the automotive in  Europe, cars, trucks and VSM in Europe, renewable energy China railway, China you take these away, sorry also  cars and VSM in Latin America, the rest of business is relatively flat, running a good level and relatively flat in  total there.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Let's go on to the industrial organization, and why we're doing what we're doing in industrial. The industrial  market actually is quite a complex market. We talk about the industrial market, but it's made up of many, many  markets there. What's required in aerospace is very different to what's required in renewable energy, which is  different to what's required in pulp and paper. But it is an industrial market, in total.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: Strategic Industries have seven end user, let's say seven industry businesses, plus the whole lubrication business;  aerospace, which they had before; renewable energy; industrial drives, which is gear boxes, electric motors,  pumps, compressors and material handling; off highway; traditional energy, which is oil and gas et cetera;  precision, medical, machine tool and automation; and railways, which they had before.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, SKF AB
texts.text: This team are responsible for all the OEMs and end users for each of these industries. That means, if you want to  follow them, by following what happens in aerospace, renewable energy, et cetera, as an industry and industry  figures, you'll have a better way to do it. In the past, you had some of the business here and some of the business  in another division; some in industrial, some in service. It will help you follow it. The other industries, metals,  pulp and paper, mining and cement, food and beverage, marine, et cetera and our distributors, will be handled by  regional sales and service in total.  So we think this, and we strongly believe from the discussions we've had with customers, because we talk to them  as well before we do this, customers see this as a very positive way of us helping work with them much better. We  will become better partners for our customers and we'll be able to drive, as I say, our development and our  satisfaction much better. And our intention is to drive the profitability as well.

file: SKF.B - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 30January2013 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jan-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: As I move onto orders, I'm not going to go through all the orders. We took a lot of good orders during the year  both in the industrial arena and in the automotive arena. Orders for renewable energy with both Siemens and  Vestas, orders into the railway business, again, with companies like Siemens but also good orders in China for the  railway business. We strengthened our service business with the contract with Fibria, LKAB, et cetera. So, good  package of orders there and, last but not least, the big one we did for Caesar's Palace for the big wheel, the largest  wheel that will be there. So that's an excellent business as well.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: And then for the automotive side, we took some good business as well. The Bus Door Actuator [indiscernible]  (06:09) BeyondZero portfolio, which Volvo's now launched as part of their bus program there and are out  promising based on the SKF actuator, even they're advertising that. Based on the SKF actuator, they can give  improved fuel efficiency to their customers there and a number of the other ones for Volvo, for Audi or wheel  bearings, et cetera.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: If we look at some of the highlights from 2012, our 100 years in China stands out. It's not many companies that  can say they have celebrated 100 years in China. We celebrated that – our presence in China and we did it with the  opening of our Jinan factory with the ground breaking for a new warehouse and with announcement of a new  campus that will be operational end of this year, and in 2013 and into 2014 and we'll house a new automotive  factory. We'll house our GTCC or Technical Centre and SKF College and Solution Factory.  We opened a new facility in Tver, a testing facility. We have five Solution Factories and for the green agenda and  for the electric vehicles, the partnership that we've put in place with Protean Electric will be interesting, an  interesting development – a self wheel-in motor. Very unique for the motor, that can actually fit into the existing  wheel end assembly. But it needs a very rigid component bearing to go with it and it's only with SKF technology  that can support that, which is very good. Yes. And the number one important one for the documented savings, et  cetera.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: We also entered a number of new products. Here we've been stepping up our investment in research and  development. A number of new products came to the market and products with very much are focus on how we  can save energy for our customers. For example, the low friction hub bearing unit, which can save 0.3 grams of  fuel for the customer, the Bus Door Actuator I've already mentioned, et cetera, et cetera, a good year for  continuing to launch products to the market.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: And we launched our new climate targets. We launched the BeyondZero portfolio and where we said we would  quadruple our sales of the BeyondZero portfolio product. And you'll see us for up going forward, and we don't  know the figures today, but we will follow the open report and annual report.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Industrial business renewable energy is still very, very weak in China. There are some indications now that started  to move ever so slowly, a little bit better at the moment. But it's too early to say recovery, but there are some  orders starting to come in renewable energy in China for us. Railway business will be good going forward in the  quarter as well.

file: SKF.B - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 28January2014 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jan-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Environment – environmental care, what we can do better to support the environment is important. As you know,  we have a policy in SKF to build our facilities to meet standards. Two of our newest factories in Ahmedabad, and  Dalian in China received a LEED certificate. And we are in the FTSE4Good Index for the 13th year, and the Dow  Jones for the 14th year in succession, which I think is major achievement, and shows that the activities we've got  in this area is really – are really working and giving us a benefit.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Okay. As we're also of course bringing Kaydon in and taking the one-off for the expected EU fine impacts the other  ratios. So if you take inventories, for example, we have a reported 21.5% of inventories, but if we clean out for  Kaydon, then it's 20.9%. And why do we clean that out? It's because we have the full inventories in for Kaydon,  but we only have two and a half months of sale, so we take that away to clean that out there.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: If I look geographically, and let's talk a little bit about what's happened in the world. In Asia Pacific, we had very  strong growth in China, very, very strong growth in China in the fourth quarter, driven by three specific  businesses. Generally, our business was okay, but three specific businesses. Renewable energy, we saw a good  recovery. Remember in renewable energy, we've gone through a couple of years of very low business in China. And  so there was some restatement because there'd been a lot of destocking taking place, and so we had some recovery  in that, partly due to the end of destocking and partly due to the market.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: In North America, a very good car business. We grew ahead of the marketplace in North America in the fourth  quarter. We also saw an improving actual renewable energy business, even though it was down year -on-year, as  we went through the year. Farm and forestry was down for us in the fourth quarter in total, but also mining and  infrastructure was down in that timeframe. Distribution, relatively unchanged in total in North America. So very  much an automotive-driven and especially car-driven growth there.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Linked to that also, renewable energy we felt was a little bit of a catch-up from the destocking that was taking  place. So we don't expect that to continue with the same rate. And also, the Chinese New Y ear is becoming an  increasingly important impact on the Chinese business. What went from being, some years ago, being one week  has spread out to being two weeks, and more like two and half weeks in terms of impact the re. So we think that  means it will still have a sequentially somewhat level business, we won't see the same momentum. But we will see  good growth in Asia, year-on-year, because the level we're at now is a higher level than where we were one year  ago.

texts.speaker: Tom Johnstone
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Cost reduction program. You know the program we launched, fourth quarter 2012, which had three big elements  to it, manufacturing, restructuring in footprint; overhead costs in our operations and, thirdly, purchasing. And if  you remember, it was SEK 1.5 billion for the first two, SEK 1.5 billion for the purchasing, in total, with a target that  by the end of 2015, we should be at a SEK 3 billion saving rate, which we will get in 2016.

file: SKF.B - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 28January2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jan-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Henrik Lange
texts.profession: Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Let me comment specifically on China. We continue to see a very positive development in our sales to industries  such as renewable energy and railway, trucks and the car business. Our sales within Industrial distribu tion  developed positively, whereas we still saw some weaknesses in the heavy industry segment such as metals and  mining, and also lack of traction in our industrial drives, which is pumps, compressors and gear boxes.

texts.speaker: Henrik Lange
texts.profession: Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: From an industry viewpoint, we saw very good growth in renewable energy and railways, but generally the two  remain lackluster. In Automotive our car and light vehicles was relatively unchanged but heavy trucks and vehicle  service markets were down. So overall, Europe was flat in sales but was slightly down in volume. This is in line  with all the signals in Europe just now and the geopolitical situation. So in summary, for the group, volume was  broad in line with expectation going into the quarter. We ran production in the quarter at the level to ensure that  we'll take out stock as indicated during the previous quarter. In fact, we took some SEK 600 million inventory out  in the quarter, if you exclude the currency effect, which of course strengthened the cash flow in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President and CEO, SKF Group and President, Industrial Market
texts.text: Turning now to look at raw materials. The scrap surcharge just now remain a little lower than the average last  year, and they are at a similar level as the end of the year. In closing, I think we produced a result in line wit h our  expectation and manage our working capital well to produce a strong cash flow. We took some very important new  steps in the quarter to strengthen SKF with launching the merger of Strategic Industries and the RSS division into  one strong customer and technology focused organization.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: In total, 16 propulsion shafts and eight vessels will be equipped with SKF components. As part of the subsea gas compression system, the bearings will contribute to recovering  additional gas volumes from depleting gas fields, as well as extending the lifetime of those gas fields.

texts.speaker: Alrik Danielson
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SKF AB
texts.text: Another example, as was presented by Jon Schmidt on the Capital Markets Day in November, is the supply of an  integrated seals, lubrication and bearing solutions to U.S. Steel for their hot strip mill table rolls in Granite City,  Illinois. This solution helps to increase machine availability while at the same time reducing energy and grease  consumption. In addition to what is shown in this slide, we were also awarded interesting new businesses across  different customer industries, such as a two-year supply contract with one of the main producers in the pulp and  paper industry in Latin America, supply of wind turbine bearings for renewable energy in Europe, bearings for use  in the mining industry in Latin America.

texts.profession: Well, good morning everyone and welcome. This is a new location to us. So, thank you to Deutsche
texts.text: 8 be very helpful in doing that pushes the Canadian marketplace has actually been quite robust  during the crisis. texts.speaker: Philip Bowman, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning and welcome to the Interim Results Presentation for Smiths
texts.text: Looking ahead, the operational priorities for Smiths Detection in the second half are to continue  implementing the cost reduction initiatives and introduce more flexibility into the cost base, to  accelerate the trials and developments of eqo, in particular, to meet the latest demands for aviation  checkpoint security, to continue our investment in developing innovative new products, and to build  on our recent contract wins in the high-energy cargo screening market.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning and welcome to the Interim Results Presentation for Smiths
texts.text: John Crane Production Solutions, the upstream energy services business, won a major follow-on  contract for pump repair services with Petrom for Romania’s oil wells. This new contract began in  December and is expected to generate annual revenues of some £14 million. John Crane has  worked with Petrom since 2007, delivering significant benefits in terms of increased output,  increased reliability and lower cost.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning and welcome to the Interim Results Presentation for Smiths
texts.text: We maintain our industry leadership through investment in product development, although much of  this is customer funded. Our recent expansion of our bearing and coupling test capabilities will help  speed the launch of new products, including the next generation of high-speed composite  couplings. Other new products during the period included advanced seals for the enhanced oil  recovery and carbon capture markets, energy efficient bearings and a sophisticated filtration valve  capable of withstanding ultra-low temperatures.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning and welcome to the Interim Results Presentation for Smiths
texts.text: We’ve made strong progress against this metric in the last six months, with a 21% increase in sales  from new products, and a more focused approach to research and development has clearly helped  achieve this result. We completed the launch of a new full range of convective warming blankets,  which have been well received in all of our key markets. Our new launches continue to meet or  exceed expectations and we’ve extended the reach of a number of our products into new markets.  These included the CADD-Solis pump and the UniPerc tracheotomy tube, among other products  listed on this slide.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning and welcome to the Interim Results Presentation for Smiths
texts.text: In Aerospace, sales of components and services have weakened, particularly in the market for  regional aircraft and business jets. Revenue from Heat Solutions, though now showing some signs  of stabilizing, fell 14% because of lower sales of gas piping and air conditioning units. And sales of  hose assemblies from Flexible Solutions fell 16% because of a continued weak demand in the U.S.  floorcare and general industrial markets.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning and welcome to the Interim Results Presentation for Smiths
texts.text: However, both Heat Solutions and Flexible Solutions are showing some improvements in recent  months, with an increase in sales in January and February. This chart illustrates the monthly sales  trend, where growth is compared against the prior year month. You can see the trend turned  positive in January and continued in February.

texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning, and welcome to the Interim Results Presentation for Smiths
texts.text: On an underlying basis, headline operating profit grew 18% to £79 million. The better volumes in  associated operational gearing increased the profit by £18 million. Pricing initiatives, particularly for  aftermarket services, contributed £6 million. However, the strong growth in the upstream energy  services business, which was slightly [ph] off margin, contributed £3 million of adverse mix.

texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning, and welcome to the Interim Results Presentation for Smiths
texts.text: Looking ahead, we are well-positioned for when the EU begins easing the liquids ban for hand  baggage next month, initially for transit passengers only. Our advanced X-ray scanner, aTiX, has  been certified for liquid detection.

texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning, and welcome to the Interim Results Presentation for Smiths
texts.text: Aftermarket sales grew 17%, driven primarily by the oil and gas sector, with particular support from  our upstream energy services business, John Crane Production Solutions, which doubled its sales.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman, Chief Executive Officer and Director
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning, and welcome to the Interim Results Presentation for Smiths
