texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We've extended our portfolio and presence through two acquisitions in the period. Power Holdings transforms  Interconnect offering in the area of power management and John Crane's aftermarket capabilities for its bearing  businesses have been expanded by the purchase of Turbo Components and Engineering. Both acquisitions are  performing in line with our expectations. At the same time, underlining our commitment to more active portfolio  management, we've identified some non-core activities which we will seek to divest before the end of the fiscal  year.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As I've commented a number of times previously, providing a safe working environment within all our facilities is  a key priority. I'm pleased to be able to report today that the steady reduction in both recordable and lost time  incident rates continues. In addition, you will also see we've made good progress against a range of environmental  metrics, and these reductions have been achieved over the past 18 months.

texts.speaker: Peter Turner
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: In addition, there were two new items. The first also relates to product liability litigation. Over recent years,  Titeflex Corporation, part of Flex-Tek, in common with other players in the marketplace, has experienced product  liability claims relating to alleged defects in its flexible gas piping products. The cost of defending these insurance  against headline operating profit. The continuing progress in pattern of claims now provides sufficient evidence to  recognize a provision for future costs in these accounts. We have estimated the cost to defend future financial  claims over the next ten years, resulting in an exceptional charge of £52 million.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Critical infrastructure revenue grew 21%. This greater focus on the market supported by increased sales resources  helped secure new contracts. These included the first order for the new radiation detector, RadSeeker, totaling  $4.5 million.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: The acquisition of PDI was completed in October 2011. The business is performing in line with expectations and  the integration should be complete before the end of this fiscal year. Its lower relative margins are being improved  through operational and procurement initiatives.  PDI transforms the power offering of Smiths Interconnect by adding a range of power-related products and access  to attractive higher-growth end markets such as data centers and alternative energy applications.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Company-funded product development grew by 8% to £11 million and we continue to focus this investment on the  best returns as seen by over 30% of sales coming from products developed in the last three years. These include  millimeter-wave components for a new poor weather radar system for helicopters and major product  enhancements for our wireless telecoms test equipment.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Revenue from the construction market rose 4% despite the sustained weakness in US housing. This reflects a gain  in market share achieved principally by cross selling our ducting, flexible gas piping and heating element product  lines to the US distributor market.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Sales of heat solutions fell 12% on the back of weaker demand for appliances from the residential market. Flex-Tek  has also increased new product development spend in heat solutions and fluid management and is investing more  in its manufacturing facilities in China and in India.

file: SMINL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 20March2013 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: In addition, you will also see that we're continuing to make excellent progress against a variety of environmental  metrics, in part reflecting increased investment in more and better HS&C resources, both people and new energy- efficient plant across the company.

texts.speaker: Peter A. Turner
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Now, let's review the Detection and restructuring program in more detail. You will recall that the plan was to  deliver £40 million of savings for £40 million of costs over three years as shown in the top left-hand corner of the  slide. We've continue to make progress with a further £4 million of savings delivered, bringing the savings to date  to £19 million, shown in the green bar across the center. Some areas, however, have not progressed as quickly as  we'd have liked. For example, the progress on enhancing the proportion of locally-sourced components from our  new Asian and U.S. manufacturing facilities has been hindered by the ability to find suitable sourcing for some  components.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Aftermarket revenue grew 4% on increased demand from rotating equipment such as seals, bearings, and  couplings that together represent about 90% of our revenue. Pipeline expansion projects from the increase in  shale oil activity in North America were a key contributor to this growth.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: In the first half, new service centers opened in South Korea and the U.S. Our earlier investments in the Middle  East and Africa are starting to pay off. Year-to-date sales for this region compared to prior year increased over  10%, reflecting strengthened customer relationships. We also delivered significant growth in China, where first  half sales were up over 13%. Growth in Australia has accelerated, increasing by more than 20%, as it benefits from  offshore natural gas discoveries.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: During the period, investment in new products and engineering rose by 16%, in line with our commitment to  increase investment annually by about 15%. We expect this to drive medium-term growth. We remain focused on  addressing customers' growing demands in sometimes challenging operating situations, while supporting the  reduced environmental impact and energy efficiency.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Now, looking ahead to the second half, John Crane's order book has continued to grow, albeit modestly. The  increase is primarily driven by higher margin end-user orders, which were slightly more than 4% above prior  period, helped by the shale oil activity that I already mentioned. Underlying revenues in the second half will run at  similar levels to the equivalent period last year, due to a cautious outlook by our first-fit customers. We believe the  softening of first-fit sales will continue at least through the end of this fiscal year.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Looking beyond this fiscal year, we anticipate continued revenue increases from emerging markets and growth  businesses. Of course, our large installed base of products delivers higher margin aftermarket services and helps  ensure more stable cash flows. Finally, shale oil extraction remains underdeveloped globally. Our order book  should be strengthened for many years ahead as customers tap into these shale fields.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: As you'd expect, over the past few months, I've visited many of our customers around the world. Saudi Aramco,  PEMEX in Mexico City, OMV Petrom in Bucharest, BP Amoco in South Texas, PetroChina and Sinopec in Beijing,  just to name a few of our aftermarket customers. I also visited first-fit customers such as Sulzer Pumps, Solar  Turbo, and Deep Blue Pumps in China.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: The enterprise data center sector, typically facilities operated in-house by large enterprises such as banks, was hit  by a fall in capital investment. However, this was offset by strong demand in the collocation sector, where PDI  won its single largest orders since acquisition. Demand in the alternative energy sector weakened further and we  have yet to see any sign of a recovery.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: In defense, we anticipate that the market will decline in both the U.S. and Europe as the impact of sequestration  and other spending cuts affect the supply chain. That said, we will continue to focus our efforts on sectors which  we consider may be less impacted, due to their strategic importance.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Heat solution revenues were marginally down, with weaker HVAC sales to household appliances partly offset by a  better performance elsewhere. Revenues in flexible solutions rose 4%, as the success of our new sleep apnea  product more than offset continued weakness in the floorcare market.

file: SMINL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 19March2014 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Earnings per share declined 4% but cash conversion remains strong for the half year at 86%. And the interim  dividend is up 2% to £0.127 5 per share. As on previous occasions, I'd like to highlight the good progress we  continue to make on our key safety and environmental metrics. We continue to see a steady fall in lost time  accidents whilst our recordable incident rate improved to a record low.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: We benefited from an enhanced safety culture and greater employee engagement as well as greater use of leadi ng  indicators. We beat our multi-year targets for environmental metrics at the end of last year. So, we've now set a  new five-year set of targets. And while it's early days, good progress is being made against these new goals. And we  expect to deliver further improvements as we invest more in people, improve manufacturing processes and new  energy-efficient plant.

texts.speaker: Peter A. Turner
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Philip, and good morning, everyone. Philip has given you an overview of the results. So, I'll start by  reviewing the underlying performance on a divisional level. John Crane delivered further revenue growth driven  by demand for OEM and aftermarket rev enue, particularly in the energy services sector. Profit grew strongly,  reflecting better volumes and the benefit of a range of efficiency initiatives.

texts.speaker: Peter A. Turner
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Philip mentioned that we began our Fuel for Growth program, and this slide presents the costs and savings by  division. Each division submitted a plan for another round of cost efficiencies that would support greater  investment in future growth. We've begun refining the program in the past six months and  the divisions have  identified further opportunities, which have expanded the program to £60 million of savings. The scale of the  opportunity varies by division as shown here.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Peter, thank you for that. Moving now to the operating performance and outlook for each of our businesses. I  will  also, as promised, set out the new medium-term revenue and margin ranges. Starting with John Crane, sales  growth was driven by healthy demand from both mid and downstream energy customers. Operating margins  remained high, reflecting both improved rev enues and operational efficiencies.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Underlying aftermarket sales, excluding revenues from our upstream oil service business, rose 3% on the back of  strong activity from energy services customers across the Middle East, Latin America, and North America. High- value Performance Plus reliability contracts were secured in Singapore, Colombia, Australia, the U.S. and a  number of other countries.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Underlying revenues from our upstream oil services business declined, reflecting the increasingly competitive  environment in the U.S. and also the impact of the unusually severe winter across North America.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Developing new products and services is also expected to drive medium-term growth. Our focus remains firmly on  providing engineered solutions that meet customers' processing needs while at the same time reducing  environmental impact and energy consumption. In the period, John Crane was awarded a patent for a  breakthrough in real-time condition monitoring technology for gas seals.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: While still early days for Jeff at Smiths, I've given him four initial priorities: one, to improve the competitiveness  and vitality of the portfolio with a continued focus on new product development and better marketing. In  particular, we will look at ways to accelerate our speed to market and achieve more quick wins. Two, as I  commented earlier, to accelerate and better execute our emerging market strategy. Three, to focus on delivering  the Fuel for Growth program as well as the other successful efficiency initiatives that are ongoing, such as value  engineering. And four, to further improve product quality and, importantly, on-time delivery to customers. And  Jeff will be updating me on progress against those challenges on a regular basis ove r the coming months.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Construction sales rose 10% buoyed by improved demand for HVAC ducting and flexible gas piping products, and  supported by a 7% rise in single family home starts. Revenues from Heat Solutions remained flat, with increased  sales of specialty heating elements, offset by lower revenues from household appliances and HVAC components.  Sales in Flexible Solutions rose by 2% as the success of our new sleep apnea products more than offset the  continued weakness in the floorcare market.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Looking to the second half of the year, we expect the positive trends to be maintained. The U.S. residential  construction market should continue to grow after some disruption from adverse weather in the latter months of  the first half of this year. There's ongoing demand from commercial aerospace as airframes need newer lighter  weight, high pressure hydraulic hose assemblies. And margins will benefit from higher volumes but will face  pressure as we further increase investment in research and development.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Despite the cash demands of our legacy liabilities, our strong balance sheet allows us to fund acquisitions and  returns to shareholders. We continue to further strengthen the management teams, bus iness development  processes, and information systems. And the senior leadership continues to be transformed as we strive to raise  the talent bar. While cautious about sectors such as defense and healthcare, we remain well-placed to benefit from  a range of positive market dynamics. These include growth in energy demand, the ever-present need for improved  security, the requirements of new fuel-efficient aircraft, and increased U.S. residential construction.

file: SMINL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 18March2015 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: John Crane delivered a resilient performance which benefited from its focus on aftermarket services for our  rotating equipment customers. Unsurprisingly, the upstream business faced a slowdown in customer demand  because of the lower price of oil, while our first-fit OEM business also showed some signs of softening.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning now to our safety and environmental record, we have made good progress over recent years in delivering  improvements to key safety metrics. Although the recordable incident rate rose slightly in the period, largely due  to a number of incidents within John Crane, more than 80% of our sites have been incident -free since the  beginning of the year.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of environmental metrics, we have again recorded further improvements on energy, greenhouse gases,  water, and waste. We're targeting a 15% reduction in these by the end of FY  2018, except for water where the  target is 10%. In general, we are making good progress in all of these metrics, with the exception of energy, where  consumption in the first half was adversely impacted by lower winter temperatures, particularly in the northeast  of the U.S.A. We expect to make further progress as we continue to simplify our manufacturing footprint, and we  continue to invest more in enhanced manufacturing processes and more energy-efficient plant.

texts.speaker: Peter A. Turner
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: We also had a £13 million gain from the changes we made in August last year to the U.S. pension plans, as I  described in the year-end presentation back in September. The ongoing amortization of acquired intangibles was  £18 million. And in addition, we have a £26 million goodwill impairment charge for John Crane Production  Solutions, the small upstream business that supplies products and services for artificial lift. This impact has been  triggered by the significant drop in oil prices, which has adversely affected our upstream customers and their  investment plans.

texts.speaker: Peter A. Turner
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director
texts.text: Philip mentioned that our Fuel for Growth program is on track, and this slide presents the costs and savings by  division. The two columns on the left-hand side sets out the costs and annualized savings incurred to date. And on  the right-hand side are the expectations for the whole program. The overall expectations of savings and costs are  unchanged, but we've slightly increased the anticipated savings in the current year to approximately £25 million,  slightly ahead of the original plan.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: In total, aftermarket revenues grew 3% on an underlying basis. However, an upstream – when upstream oil  services sales are excluded, revenues rose 7%, illustrating the strength of our rotating equipment business. Global  energy demand has remained robust, and many refineries are operating at full capacity. The business continues to  renew and win large contracts. A couple of recent wins include a global agreement with a major Saudi  petrochemical company and a gas seal reliability management contract in Singapore.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Upstream oil services, which represent a relatively small part of our business and ar e reported as part of our  aftermarket business, declined as the low oil price put pressure on upstream customers. Underlying sales of First - fit original equipment decreased 2% as market pressures in Europe were only marginally offset by demand in  North America.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Although we're seeing some delays or cancellations, we continue to increase our share of new downstream  business. These included an exclusive agreement for part of Kuwait's clean fuels project to upgrade two refineries.  This is one of the largest projects John Crane has won in the past 10 years.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: John Crane's strong focus on the aftermarket should support a continued resilient performance in the current low  oil price environment. The predictable revenue from our installed base supports an aftermarket that now accounts  for almost two-thirds of total sales. Our customers continued to depend on us for services and repairs provided by  our aftermarket business. Furthermore, our bias towards mid and do wnstream applications in oil and gas also  helps with refineries and petrochemical plants running at full capacity because of the low priced stocks,  feedstocks.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: In addition, we have a relatively limited exposure to upstream application, which has been hardest hit so far by the  low oil price. We also have experienced with managing the business through cyclical downturns and have already  identified a comprehensive action plan to preserve margins in this challenging environment. These plans include a  cost reduction program to address discretionary spend in overheads.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: John Crane is prepared for the ups and downs of the business cycle. While we're not immune, I believe our robust  business model means that we're better placed than many to endure a lower oil price environment. At constant  currencies, trading performance in the second half may be slightly lower than last year as our upstream segment  contends with the difficult market conditions caused by weak oil prices. But I expect mid and downstream orders  to show resilience and our cost saving initiatives should help to underpin operating profit margins.

texts.speaker: Tedd Smith
texts.profession: President-Flex-Tek, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Fluid management revenues rose 1% on growth in commercial airframe and automotive applications. This was  partially offset by lower revenue from satellite launch vehicles and military gas turbines. Construction sales rose  4% supported by improved demand for HVAC ducting and flexible gas piping products as well as an increase in  single family home starts.

texts.speaker: Tedd Smith
texts.profession: President-Flex-Tek, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Revenues from heat solutions rose 13% on the back of increased sales of specialty heating elements and  improvements in the household appliance sector. Flexible solutions saw revenue decline 2% mainly because of a  very strong year comparator period when new sleep apnea products were launched. Floorcare, on the other hand,  remained weak.

texts.speaker: Tedd Smith
texts.profession: President-Flex-Tek, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Our increased R&D investment, up 23%, is proving highly effective at gaining approvals and products for next  generation airplanes and new heating technologies. Healthy growth in fluid management is generated by demand  for quieter, more fuel-efficient aircraft for our lightweight and ultra-strong hoses. Sales opportunities for our  specialty heating elements continue to emerge in higher margin markets. Our investment in additional sales and  marketing capabilities is effectively complementing the proven strength of the business and management.

texts.speaker: Tedd Smith
texts.profession: President-Flex-Tek, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Looking to the rest of the year, U.S. residential housing should show steady improvement. Commercial aerospace  demand will remain muted until the new programs that need our fluid management products begin to ramp up  again. A general improvement in economic conditions is expected to benefit heat solutions while floorcare is likely  to remain weak. Overall, I believe we'll continue to make steady progress.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Over the past seven years, value engineering, site rationalization and organizational change have all helped drive  operational efficiency across the companies within the group. That said, real opportunities still exist and will be  delivered through the Fuel for Growth program. And as I've said earlier, this has already generated £20 million of  annualized savings. And most of the projected £60 million of savings, I would reiterate, are earmarked for funding  investment associated with the initiatives to accelerate revenue growth.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of outlook, we expect to deliver improved underlying performance in the second half. Smiths Detection  will benefit from a soft prior-year comparator which, of course, was affected by a number of non-recurring  charges. John Crane will probably see a slight easing in trading as upstream customers adjust their expenditure to  the lower oil price, and there's a potential risk of deferral of some OEM projects. The growth rate at Smiths  Medical was slow versus the strong first half performance. Smiths Interconnect expects some recovery but, as  Roland said, will not achieve the revenue and profit of last year, and Flex -Tek should continue to perform well.

file: SMINL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 16March2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: As we stated earlier in the year, John Crane's performance was impacted by persistently tough oil and gas  markets. However, the business model prevailed and our aftermarket revenues proved more resilient. We  benefited from continued growth at Medical and good profit growth at Detection. Performance a t Interconnect  and Flex-Tek was in line with expectations.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The world is still consuming 95 million barrels of oil a day despite the supply side issues that appear to be driving  the current situation. That said, we're seeing some facilities postponing operating expenditure on upgrade and  retrofit. This is driving an increase in preventative maintenance activity as efforts to improve reliability and  efficiency increase. That's a good thing for us.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: First of all, 40% of revenue is derived from non-energy sectors such as pharma, chemical and paper. This remains  a key focus of the division with, for example, a recently secured first-fit project in South Korea in the biotech  industry. Secondly, within the 60% of the business that is energy-related, our split is around 75% downstream,  that's the refineries; 15% midstream, that's the pipelines; and 10% upstream broadly around exploration and  production. So, John Crane's total upstream exposure is around 6% of total revenue. When you think about that in  terms of Smiths Group overall, it's less than 2%.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: But of course, our innovation is not just in detection. There are other examples of technology excellence including  patient-friendly portable infusion pumps for premature babies, where the level of delivery of the drugs is so  crucial and the sophistication so high and our precision is leading; new gas technology seals that help industrial  plants run better and cleaner; and high-performance connector systems for the satellite sector. We have more  than $250,000 of Interconnect ultra-high performance product on every SSL satellite that's launched, for  example, and that number's increasing.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Trends such as digital industrialization are reshaping customer and consumer expectations and the service  offering that we should be providing. That's an obvious area where we need to innovate and extend our  capabilities. I visited in Texas one of the INEOS refineries, which is one of the world first installations of our  condition monitoring technology, where a nerve sensor capability is put in place to monitor all the pressures,  flows, temperatures throughout the operation and then targeting the right levels of maintenance and repair. It's  going extremely well, and I think it's a technology that you'd be hearing more about in the John Crane model.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Finally, before opening up to questions, I'd like to provide you with the summary of the group outlook for the  second half. We're expecting global energy markets to remain challenging in the second half and are taking action  to ensure that John Crane is well-positioned in that environment. I expect Medical to deliver similar revenue  performance in the second half driven by growth in Infusion Systems and Vital Care.

file: SMINL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 24March2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew Lappin
texts.profession: Group Director-Corporate Affairs, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Couple of points of housekeeping before we get started, phones off please. And no fire drills, so if the alarm does  sound, exits to your left and your right. And I'd be grateful if you would read our disclaimer slide. Thank you. Very  important piece of [indiscernible] (00:51), okay? Don't worry. I've got it all under control, Andy.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Now, I'll take you through the highlights of each division. As we expected, John Crane continued to face some  difficult trading conditions in the global energy markets, and sales were down 4% on an underlying basis. But  aftermarket revenues returned to growth in the first half, up 3% as levels of activity stabilized, although, at this  stage, first-fit contract activity showed no signs of recovery. The aftermarket at 64% of sales is really a key factor  in the resilience of John Crane, and we continue to win some significant new contracts to feed the pipeline with  the likes of Solvay and BASF. First-fit sales were down 15%. This was due to continued low new project activity,  and it was particularly true in North America. But we did have major new contract wins in Saudi Arabia, Oman and  Kuwait, which were pleasing.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Another factor in John Crane's quality is the range of end markets that we serve. We continued our efforts, as we  said back in September, to diversify our non-oil and gas market revenue. And it was good to see that revenue  was up 3% in this area as we won new contracts, particularly in chemical, mining and water treatment.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: As I said before, we're taking decisive action to strengthen John Crane during these tough times. And that way,  we're much better positioned when the energy markets do start to recover. Back in November, we sold the  Artificial Lift business and that sale, combined with the other action that we've taken, led to increased profitability,  in fact operating margins were up versus the same period last year at just over 20%.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Asset light and sustainability competitive businesses. With more than half of our cost of sales bought in, we have  and we expect to maintain a low capital base that makes us adaptable and flexible as we change and grow, all, of  course, underpinned by world-class operational excellence.

file: SMINL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 23March2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jemma Spalton
texts.profession: Investor Relations Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Just a couple of housekeeping points before we get started. There are no planned fire drills today. So if the fire  alarm does sound, please exit through one of the fire exits at the front here. And also if you could take a moment  please to digest and read the disclaimer side, which is in your packs and behind me.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: As you can see, John Crane is back to growth, driven by the positive trends in oil & gas and further progress  accelerating our non-oil & gas activities. We got a strong order book in both OE and aftermarket.

texts.speaker: John Francis Shipsey
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Looking at end markets, John Crane's revenues from oil & gas and non-oil & gas, were both up 4% and 3%,  respectively. The latter driven by pharma, chemical and pulp and paper.

texts.speaker: John Francis Shipsey
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Flex-Tek revenue was up 10%, with growth across the board, including construction up 4%, and both Fluid  Management and Heat Solutions, up 14%.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: I'd like to talk now in a bit more detail about some of the stuff that underpins our confidence in the second half.  Let's start with John Crane. We're seeing good momentum in the business. Overall, we're back to growth and  margins remained strong with further potential in the coming years. The first half grew 3%, driven by improving oil  & gas markets and our strong push into non-oil & gas with particular strength and wins in chemical and  pharmaceutical. The momentum will continue, expanding our installed base and supported by both, strong OE  order book and further good aftermarket demand.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: We've also, in John Crane, increased our investment in innovative new products, which operate at higher  temperatures and pressures, helping our customers achieve greater efficiency. As the rate of investment in the  market begins to pick up, our customers are increasingly focused on getting more output from every dollar of  investment in their refineries and their processing plants.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Flex-Tek had a super half, and is really well-positioned for continued strong growth for the year as a whole. Key  markets are supportive and we're especially pleased by the progress in Heat Solutions, where the integration of  the newly acquired Osram business is on track and already opening new market opportunities, including Chinese  aircraft production. In this case, our products are contributing to large improvements in plant efficiency and  reliability. Revenue growth of 10% was more than matched by a 15% growth in profitability with good future  prospects as we build on our global markets and market positions.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Smiths Group Plc

file: SMINL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 19September2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Sep-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As I've highlighted a number of times previously, providing a safe working environment within all our facilities is  one of my key priorities and one shared by our Board. I'm pleased to report today of the steady reduction in both  recordable and lost time incident rates has continued. And in addition, you will also see that we have made  excellent progress against a range of environmental metrics, in part reflecting our increased investment in more  and better HS&E resources, both people and new energy efficient plant across the company.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: First, the acquisition and integration process has disrupted the sales and big win rates. Second, the data center  market has flattened, whilst the alternative energy market has faced headwinds. As a result, competitors have  been more aggressive on price to drive sales to offset declines in other parts of their business. Philip will talk later  about the actions we're taking to enhance performance here.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Investment in new product rose by 8% as we focus on developing products to meet customer demand, in areas  such as reduced environmental impact, energy efficiency, and condition monitoring.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: The addition of PDI to power management more than doubled sales, but on an underlying basis, they fell 12%  because of a strong comparative period and tough market conditions in China. In addition, we experienced soft  demand in the North American wireless telecoms market. PDI has transformed the existing power protection  group with a new range of product and high growth opportunities fitting our strategic criteria of adding  complementary technologies and leveraging existing sales networks. It also focuses on higher growth end market  such as data centers.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Sales at heat solutions fell by 9%, pulled down by weakness in the market's residential heating and air  conditioning. Revenues from flexible solutions were flat, reflecting a slight improvement in industrial and medical  sectors, offset by continued weakness in the floor care market.

file: SMINL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 18September2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Sep-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: We have also continued to make good progress on our key EHS measures. I believe that providing a safe working  environment with all our facilities is one of my main priorities, and one shared and reviewed regularly by our  board. And I'm pleased to be able to report today that the steady fall in recordable incident rate continued to its  lowest level ever, benefiting from an enhanced safety culture and employee engagement, as well as the use of  leading indicators. We experienced only a marginal rise in the lost time rate as a result of two additional injuries  in the period. You will also note our excellent progress against a range of environmental metrics, reflecting an  increased investment in numerous projects over recent years. These investments have resulted in more effective  EHS resources, both in terms of people, but also in terms of new energy -efficient plant.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Fourth, at the heart of what we do is our commitment to responsibility. Over the past fiv e years, we've raised the  profile of our sustainability agenda through a greater focus on health and safety, on ethics, and on minimizing our  environmental impact. We have invested consistently and made good progress. Our priority is to push through  further sustained improvements.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Revenue from high-growth emerging markets rose 7 % and now represents more than 21% of John Crane sales.  The increases included the Middle East up 12%, China up 15%, and Russia 21%. The growth momentum in target  markets will be maintained by continued investment in regional infrastructure to improve ser vice capabilities and  to broaden the company's product range. New service centers have already been opened in Busan, South Korea  and in Georgia in the United States. Investment in new products and engineering rose 9% as we maintained our  focus on meeting customers' changing requirements. These often involve extreme operating conditions with extra  demands on environmental impact and energy efficiency. Benefits range from expanded operating performance  and lower energy consumption to extended product life cyc les.

texts.speaker: Srini Seshadri
texts.profession: President, Smiths Medical
texts.text: Let me review what has gone well and where we need to do further work. We have seen good growth in the Middle  East, Southeast Asia and Latin America. Distributor coverage has been increased in [ph] key (31:07 ) markets.  We've also made good progress at product introductions such as temperature management in China and infusion  in the Middle East. However, progress in certain areas has been slower than we originally anticipated. For  example, product registrations have been complex and lengthy. Delays occurred and growth slowed as we  established new operating parameters with existing distributors. We have experienced some leadership gaps in  key markets like China where there have also been issues with re latively high staff turnover. We also saw a  slowdown in sales of our infusion products in China. As I said at the interim results, the returns are anticipated  over the medium rather than the short-term. We will pause on adding incremental investment until we have  effectively executed on this first phase.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Revenues from Heat Solutions were flat, with growth in specialty heating elements balanced by weaker HVAC  sales for household appliances. Sales in Flexible Solutions were down 2%, as the success of our new sleep apnea  products was offset by continued weakness in the floorcare market. The outlook for the commercial aerospace  market remains positive, and we expect this to continue. U.S. residential construction has rebounded from  historic lows and we foresee modest but steady improvement. Although interest rates, higher home prices and  stricter lending may act as something of a drag. As the Heat Solutions and Flexible Solutions move to more  bespoke specialty applications, they will benefit from improved general economic conditions.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: We have resisted updating the targets that we issued in 2008 because of the uncertain economic environment.  We're currently evaluating some new medium-term targets against which our performance can be measured. And  providing there is no major economic deterioration, we intend to publish these targets at our interim results in  March 2014. So looking ahead, the trading environment does not lack challenges. I remain cautious about sectors  such as defense and healthcare which is subject to government funding constraint. However, I do believe that we  remain well-placed to benefit from growth in energy demand, the need for new fuel-efficient aircraft, increased  U.S. residential construction and the ever-present need for improved security in an uncertain world.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman

texts.text: We continue to make good progress in improving our health, safety and environmental record. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Having beaten the multi-year targets for our environmental metrics at the end of FY  2013, we set new five-year  goals of reducing energy, greenhouse gases and non-recycled waste by 15% and water usage by 10%. texts.text: John Crane delivered further revenue growth, driven by demand from both OEM and the aftermarket, particularly  in the energy services sector. texts.profession: President-Smiths Detection, Inc., Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Contract sizes have become larger so that order flow is lumpier. And capacity management is also harder.  However, it's important to put the program issues into context. texts.speaker: Richard Ingram
texts.profession: President-Smiths Detection, Inc., Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: To address our cost base, we announced last month that we will close three facilities in North America and  consolidate their activities amongst our existing plants. texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Second half operating margins were inflated by about 80 basis points due to some one -time events. So the  normalized full-year operating margin was about 24.3%. texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Key renewals and new aftermarket service contracts were signed with global customers such as Shell, Chevron and  additional wins in China and Mex ico, contributed to the record order book. Underlying revenues from our  upstream oil services business declined, reflecting the increasingly competitive environment in the U.S. and the  unusually severe winter across North America. However, after a sharp decline in the second quarter, the business  began stabilizing on a sequential monthly basis in the second half.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Fluid Management revenues declined slightly, reflecting ramp-downs in existing aero engine platforms before  orders from new programs begin to build. Construction sales rose 8% on the back of improved demand for HVAC  ducting and flexible gas piping products combined with market share gain. And cross-selling of the product ranges  has been particularly successful.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Revenues from Heat Solutions rose 7% with increased sales of specialty heating elements easily offsetting lower  revenues from household appliance and HVAC components. And Flexible Solutions, saw revenue rise slightly as  the success of new sleep apnea products more than offset a persistent weakness in shipments to the domestic floor  care market.

file: SMINL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 23September2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Sep-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, with that brief introduction, I'll now provide an overview of divisional performance. The decline in oil price  over the past year has done John Crane no favors, but the division, nevertheless, delivered a resilient performance  which benefited from its focus on aftermarket services. Aftermarket revenues grew by 4%, however, the first-fit  business continued to soften with the slowdown in customer demand reported by our competitors. Margins held  up well benefiting from product mix and tight cost control.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Turning now to our safety and environmental record. This slide shows just how much we've achieved in delivering  improvements in our key safety metrics in recent years. The root causes behind the slight rise in the recordable  incident rate last year, primarily in one division, have been identified and are being addressed through a focused  program which is already delivering improvements.

texts.speaker: Philip Bowman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of environmental metrics, we've again recorded improvements in greenhouse gases, water and waste  with only energy showing a slight increase. We are targeting a 15% reduction in these by the end of FY 2018,  except for water usage where the target is 10%. texts.speaker: Rob White
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: We also rolled forward our provision for Titeflex litigation for product claims. This amounted to £8 million. The ongoing amortization of acquired intangibles  was £33 million. And as we reported at the interims, we have a £27 million goodwill impairment charge for John  Crane Production Solutions, the artificial lift business which has suffered from the big drop in oil prices.

texts.speaker: Rob White
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Philip mentioned that our Fuel for Growth program is on track. And this slide presents the costs and savings by  division. texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Key renewals and new aftermarket service contracts were signed with customers across the diverse mix of process  industries we serve including pulp and paper, chemical, food and, of course, energy services. Despite the  challenging markets, we're able to realize modest price increases in our aftermarket business.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Underlying sales to first-fit customers fell 9% as market pressures caused by the fall in energy prices affected both  volume and pricing across most geographies. While we continue to see delays globally in oil-and-gas projects  which have not yet secured funding, John Crane's overall project win-rate is higher than in the previous period  reflecting our concerted effort to expand our installed base.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: First-fit sales were also affected by declines in the upstream business due to especially severe conditions in this  market. However, tight cost controls helped soften the impact on margins. You'll note from the slide that we've  reclassified revenues for the upstream oil services business from aftermarket to first-fit. The upstream business  demonstrates cyclical characteristics that are more closely aligned with the first-fit business.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: We increased investment in innovation by 17% underlying our commitment to address future market needs  through engineered solutions and technology advances. The AURA 220 gas seal was introduced representing the  next generation of advanced gas seal technology.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Customer trials are under way for our new Predictive Diagnostics System, which represents a significant advance  in technology for our customers. The system is designed to reduce customers' operational costs by predicting their  maintenance needs and minimizing operational disruption. We also unveiled an advanced fiberglass sucker rod  that increases production output, improves load strength, and reduces lifting costs for oil producers.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: John Crane's strong focus on the aftermarket, which generates 56% of total revenue, should support a continued  resilient performance in the current low oil price environment. Our bias towards mid- and downstream  applications in oil and gas also helps with refineries and petrochemical plants running at full capacity because of  the low-priced feedstocks.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: We plan to continue investing in growth drivers aligned with our long-term strategy with a focus on commercial  excellence, innovation and IT infrastructure. We will, of course, also continue to review commitments based on  the market outlook. While not immune, I believe our robust business model means we remained better placed  than many to endure a lower oil price environment.

texts.speaker: Duncan Gillis
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, John Crane, Inc.
texts.text: Looking ahead, we expect global energy markets to remain challenging for the coming year with depressed oil  prices and significant market uncertainty. Absent any improvement in conditions, and despite the strength of our  order book at year-end, revenue is expected to decline further. At this time, we believe that it's more probable than  not that full year margins will be able to remain in the lower half of our previously disclosed target range.

texts.speaker: Jeffery A. McCaulley
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Smiths Medical
texts.text: Lastly, we'll continue to pursue investments in COGS and SG&A. And while we anticipate improving our operating  margins, some of the savings will continue to be reinvested in additional growth drivers for the future.

texts.speaker: Tedd Smith
texts.profession: President-Flex-Tek, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Construction revenue was up 6% supported by growing demand for HVAC ducting and flexible gas piping  products, as well as an increase in single-family home starts. However, sales of gas piping products slowed in the  final quarter reflecting a change in product mix. Revenues from heat solutions rose 8% in the back of increased  sales of specialty heating elements with China showing strong growth. This more than offset the flat demand in  the appliance sector.

texts.speaker: Tedd Smith
texts.profession: President-Flex-Tek, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Our increased R&D investment, up 13%, is proving highly effective at gaining approvals on products for next- generation airplanes and new heating technologies. Healthy growth in Fluid Management is generated by demand  from quieter, more fuel efficient aircraft for lightweight, ultra-strong hoses. Sales opportunities for our specialty  heating elements continue to emerge in higher-margin markets. Our investment in additional sales and marketing  capabilities is effectively complementing the proven strength of the business and management.

file: SMINL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 28September2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Sep-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Against the backdrop with some of the toughest global energy markets in many years, John Crane's margin  declined but to a still very resilient 21.9%. Despite the tough headwinds, John Crane remains our highest margin  division and I'm pleased that the quality of this business continues to show through in this year's results. Overall,  the group headline operating profit margin was 17.3%, down 40 basis points.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Now, let me take you through the performance of each division during the year. John Crane's underlying revenue  declined 10%, primarily driven by challenging conditions in global energy markets. Oil and gas represents nearly  60% of John Crane's revenue with 40% coming from other sectors like pharma, chemical and paper. This gives  us a broader range of exposures and increasing this focus in other sectors and verticals is a key focus for the  business in the future.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Key wins in first-fit including Mitsubishi, Siemens and Weir, and after a large project order last year, John Crane  delivered 600 seals and systems for the massive Clean Fuels Project in Kuwait. However, we do continue to see  delays in first-fit oil and gas projects globally.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: You'll also have seen that on Friday, we announced the disposal of our Artificial Lift business. This provides  sucker rods for onshore upstream oil and gas. It's a good little business but suffering from tough market  conditions. It has little synergy with the John Crane business overall, and limited potential to differentiate from a  technology perspective and achieve market leadership. I'm convinced this business will progress in its new home.  Just as I expect, there will be other examples of this approach across the portfolio as we actively manage and  focus ourselves to position better for long-term growth and market leadership.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: And, finally, moving to Flex-Tek, it delivered a solid performance over the year. Underlying revenue was flat, with  Fluid Management revenue down 1% due to a softening of aerospace orders. Heat Solutions revenue was down  5%. In contrast, 3% revenue growth in Construction showed the benefits of our exposure to the U.S. housing  market. 1% growth in Flexible Solutions was driven by increased demand in medical. Operating profit fell 3% on  an underlying basis, largely due to the transition to a range of new gas tubing products. However, we saw  margins improve in Heat and Flexible Solutions.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: We continue to see good sales growth in China and we focused our R&D spend on specialty heating elements,  gas tubing, and aerospace products to meet the requirements of the next generation of more fuel-efficient aircraft.

file: SMINL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 22September2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Sep-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Now just to talk a little bit about the divisions. John Crane's overall revenue was down 4%, largely reflecting some  of the ongoing challenges in the energy markets, oil and gas, particularly. However, despite the background of a  weak OE, oil and gas market, we did see a return to growth in the aftermarket piece of the business. Aftermarket  now represents 64% of the total business and is a key strength in the quality of the John Crane division.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: We've got over 200 John Crane service centers globally that respond and anticipate what the customer wants  wherever he is. We continue to focus also on diversifying John Crane's end market focus, with its non-oil and gas  business, including chemical, pharmaceutical, pulp and paper, now at around 45% of the division's revenues, but  importantly, that piece of the business growing 2% in the last financial year.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: On to Flex-Tek, another strong performance. Sales were up 3%, with good growth in most segments and in  particular heating solutions. Operating profit was up 11%, with stronger margin driven by operational  improvements. To further enhance Flex-Tek's leading positions, the Heat Solutions business recently signed an  agreement to purchase the heating element division of Osram. It's small, but it's a great deal, which broadens our  portfolio in engineering and heating solutions, one of our big growth markets. Overall, I'm very pleased with how  the year has gone. There's more to be done, and we'll return to that a little bit later.

texts.speaker: William C. Seeger
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer & Non-Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: John Crane fell 4% as a result of challenges in the global oil and gas markets. Although down year-on-year, we  are seeing some stability in the oil and gas OE markets and an improving aftermarket now 64% of our business.

texts.speaker: William C. Seeger
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer & Non-Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Smiths Detection improved 4%, with particular strength in air transportation. Our largest segment increased 9% in  the year. Smiths Interconnect grew 1%, but focusing on our core business, which excludes the divestiture of  power and microwave telecom businesses, we delivered a solid growth of 3% in 2017. Flex-Tek grew 3%,  reflecting strength in our Heat Solutions segment, which increased 12% in the year.

texts.speaker: William C. Seeger
texts.profession: Interim Chief Financial Officer & Non-Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Looking to 2018. The progress we have made in executing our strategy through portfolio repositioning and  organic investment supports a return to growth in 2018. We expect group performance to be weighted towards  the second half. Growth in John Crane's non-oil and gas business, as well as an increase in aftermarket is  expected to more than offset the oil and gas challenges. We expect the gradual introduction of new products  during the year to support an improvement in Smiths Medical. In Smiths Detection, we anticipate a strong second  half driven by our air transportation business, which should generate good growth for the year as a whole.

file: SMINL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 21September2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Sep-18.pdf

texts.profession: Investor Relations Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Just a few housekeeping points before we get started. We're not expecting a fire drill. So, if the alarms do sound,  please exit through the fire exits to the left and right. And I'd also be grateful if you are able to spend a couple of  moments just reading and digesting our disclaimer slide.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Exciting things are happening in all of our businesses. John Crane is making great progress in Non-Oil & Gas and  now also has more than 60 condition monitoring pilots running around the world in refineries.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: Flex-Tek continues to sparkle. It's a real standout performer. Growing strongly, having successfully integrated last  year's acquisition in the Heat Solutions area and is winning on all of its product lines.

texts.speaker: Andrew Reynolds Smith
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Smiths Group Plc
texts.text: It's very important when lithium ion batteries have a similar density to certain explosives for example. We've just  won an important tender for this in Asia as part of an integrated checkpoint solution and this business is now  rapidly becoming a software-led solutions business.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Against – sorry, against this background, we delivered a resilient performance supported by continuous strong  growth in the Negative Pressure Wound Therapy. The high point of the period for me was the launch of the new  generation of Negative Pressure Wound Therapy, PICO. I attended – I showed PICO – I will show it later – this is  PICO. This was the old one. This is a new one, you see, very good one. I will show it later. I attended the European  launch in May, and I will talk you about my excitement later on today.

texts.speaker: Olivier Bohuon
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Smith & Nephew Plc
texts.text: The last four years have been tough – I mean, the economic climate has been difficult and Smith & Nephew has  weathered them well. It has consistently grown revenues, often outperforming its market segment. It has  significantly improved the operating margin and its advanced Wound – its Advanced Wound Management  business, as you have seen earlier today. The business is very healthy, something clearly demonstrated by the  strong cash generation. It has maintained investment in R&D. Innovations continues their results, which have  brought us our VERILAST, VISIONAIRE, Negative Pressure Wound Therapy, to name a few. The culture is strong  one. In many organization, customer service is just a label rather than a behavior. This is not the case with Smith  & Nephew, where the businesses are focused on delivering customer needs and have deep relationship.

texts.speaker: Olivier Bohuon
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Smith & Nephew Plc
texts.text: And last but not least, I'm happy to report that we have received the approval on July 31 of RENASYS Negative  Pressure Wound Therapy in Japan and this opens a very significant market for us in this geography.

texts.speaker: Olivier Bohuon
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Smith & Nephew Plc
texts.text: In terms of the financial benefits, we expect to complete structural efficiency programs to deliver annual savings of  at least $150 million. We are delivering on these programs and expect to achieve about half of the total of these  benefits by the end of this year.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The second thing is we had on our processor, Naida CI Q7 0 in the summer months, and we are a waterproof  company, we got more return. We saw that people on the battery connector which is the thing, you do replace the  battery daily, you recharge it or replace the battery, this connector is very delicate. And we understood that we  need to make certainly improvement to make it more reliable on the heavy-wear waterproof – water kind of  wearing conditions. And in the U.S. we had issues in the summer months and people got a little bit worri ed and  said, if you don't fix that we are waiting with order. So we fixed that. We had a first correction wave in winter and  now we come this May with another improvement on the processor to really make sure even in these tough  summer conditions it has absolutely no issue. It does not have an impact on the implant or the system at all, it's  just that it doesn't work if the battery door is not connected perfectly or the battery connects perfectly with the  system.

texts.speaker: Hartwig Grevener
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: But if you look at the adjusted escalations year-over-year, you see that the cost of sales in LC has moved up by 6%,  so just a little less than our LC sales and we have 4.4% more R&D. I'm proud of reporting that G&A has o nly  grown by 2.1% in LC and that was certainly very instrumental for us to deliver the operating leverage that you  have seen.

texts.speaker: Vincent Paris

texts.text: Basically, there are six areas of progress. Over 15 years as well, you  can see average growth is 5.5% at group levels.

texts.speaker: Vincent Paris
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sopra Steria Group SA
texts.text: Then, another area of key progress which is important for us is our sustainability progress we've just awarded, so  our sustainability progress is based on pillars: ethics, environment, society, and workforce. In our sector, environmental performance is basically greenhouse  gas emissions because of travel, and we are fully aligned with our operational plan that we've set for the next 10  years. The other award that we got was EcoVadis. So, we were recognized for our social responsibility  performance. So, these are the highlights for 2018.

texts.speaker: Vincent Paris
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Sopra Steria Group SA
texts.text: And then the last value proposition that we're developing is reusing components. This is going to be a key  differentiating factor in the coming years. Knowing how to reuse components that are cloud native is going to be  important. We're working on this. And in 2019, all of our employees will have these capacities with a platform  that's available. So they're going to be able to reuse components that are already available. So these are the  topics that we're working for our major customers.

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: So, moving to Oil & Gas and Nuclear; the oil and gas activity are markedly down year-on-year. So, excluding FX,  it's minus 27% for the service activity. texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA

texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA

file: SPIE - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 27July2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: Turning to SPIE SAG. It is now a very important feature of our business and we are now looking at the tail end of  the integration process. Since its acquisition SAG has demonstrated that it does fit our business further and is  well-aligned with our strategy. Not only are we able to deliver as announced cost synergies of €20 million but we  are also now seeing the first commercial synergies coming through in e-mobility, optic fiber as well as industrial  services. With the strong organic growth and the potencies in the long-term provided by energy transition in  Germany, SPIE SAG has delivered well and it will continue to deliver strong business performances. We really  think that the acquisition of SAG has put us in a different place on the German market.

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: We have signed new contract in the first half of 2018 with IONITY. It is a joint venture between BMW, Daimler,  Volkswagen, and Ford. We have won the mandate to work in the deployment of a total of 169 high-speed  charging stations. SPIE was one of the few players able to address the needs of the consortium thanks to its pan- European presence. It pertains to charging points in Netherlands, Belgium France, Germany, and UK. So our  pan-European presence has been really a unique feature to win this contract but also our technical expertise  including notably the knowledge of SPIE SAG and the ability to deal with impact on the grid. So it's really a big  success for SPIE, and really in this area this is only the beginning.

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: S-Cube is an addition to our competencies in Data Center services, and as you see on page 9 these assets are  complex. We're able to offer the full value chain from project feasibility to installation, operation, and maintenance  as well as modernization and upgrade. A key focus of our customer is energy efficiency and we are now able to  offer our customers a power usage effectiveness close to 1.1, down from the 1.8 to 2 we were six to eight years  ago. In this field we just announced yesterday the award of our eighth data center with [indiscernible] (00:08:33) in  Frankfurt. It's a major data center operator and an important and a recurring customer for SPIE.

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: I must say that the German market is [ph] now (00:24:33) close to overheating at the moment. It is very extremely  strong, and in this context we are benefiting from the quality of our relationship with our customers that are really  concerned about the capacity in the market and are trying to secure our capacity going forward, so this is very  beneficial to us. On the strong development, we are also now pleased to have been ranked number one facility  services company in Germany by the 2018 Lünendonk Study which is a study made very regularly in Germany.  We used to be ranking second behind [indiscernible] (00:25:21). And this is now the first time we are number one  in this technical facilities market, so a very pleasing event on top of the fact that we are number one on energy  distribution and transmission with SPIE SAG.

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: And now Oil & Gas and Nuclear. So in Oil & Gas we definitely see signs of stabilization with lower organic  contraction in Q2 than in Q1. Margins remain under pressure as anticipated. However, the recent tendering  activity and the successful development in downstream activities provide an encouraging sign that activity is  bottoming out. I mentioned during our last call a range this year of minus 10% to zero organic growth. I can now  narrow the range to minus 5% to zero. Nuclear activity is line expectation with solid margin. The organic  contraction as anticipating reflects the ramp down of the EPR contract. But the second half of the year should  benefit from an increased Grand Carénage activity and from the group's strengthened position in general  electrical installations. So we're looking at a strong second half for the nuclear activity. And really going forward,  I'm very confident about this business which enjoys a very solid position with our customers.

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: So now moving to slide 28. And before looking at the full year 2018 outlook, I wanted to highlight how well SPIE is  positioned in the industry today. We do offer a comprehensive area of technical services and our long-term  drivers are extremely strong. We're very well-positioned in all four families of services, Technical Facility  Management, Mechanical and Electrical Services, Information & Communications Services, and Transmission &  Distribution Services which are obviously strongly reinforced with the acquisition of SPIE SAG. In all these sectors  long-term drivers are the business' common denominator. Energy efficiency is becoming increasingly important  for all our customers and we experience a shift in energy mix with emphasis depending on countries. In Germany,  renewable energy is strong; in France, the strength lies in low-carbon energy but we also see a very good trend in  the expansion of solar energy. All our customers expect us to help them deploy new solutions in the context of  technology changing at an unprecedented pace. And all these segments obviously are impacted by the digital  transformation, with the cloud as a key component. So really, as I've said before, it is definitely a good time to be  an electrical engineer.

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: And then a few words on page 29 on our commitment to social and environmental responsibility. So I just want to  comment the indicator pertaining to safety. We have a rate of work-related accident which is half the average for  the sector. So SPIE is one of the safest place to work in our industry and we continue to foresee our target of zero  accidents. In a world where we need to invest in technical competencies, we are more than ever committed to  ensure transmission of knowledge, and we pay special attention to young people notably through our  [indiscernible] (00:32:56) apprenticeship policy, and we aim at following the best practice in this area. This best  practice were in place in France and were brought to us also by the acquisition of SAG and Lück, so it is really a  strong focus going forward. So I was saying, it is a good time to be an electrical engineer. This is a view shared  by [indiscernible] (00:33:20).

texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: A word on sustainable development. texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: In all these sectors, long term drivers are extremely strong, such as energy efficiency a major focus of most of our  customers and especially in public buildings but also in data centers. So it's quite an evolutive market with a lot of drivers that benefit to the skills of SPIE.

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: We can evidence that in a few examples. First, the energy efficiency management for a clinic in Germany, where  we'll be managing the energy consumption for several years. texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA

texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: We have good momentum in Netherlands and again, a very strong activity level in the industry and a high level of  investment in the energy transition with our major customers. texts.speaker: Gauthier Louette
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, SPIE SA
texts.text: And now, Oil & Gas and Nuclear on page 31 (sic) [page 30]. As I said, Oil & Gas is back in positive territory. texts.text: Now, looking at operating profit before revaluations, just like in previous years, CHF 349.6 million, so we said that  we've earned CHF 1 million a day. So, that is looking good. texts.speaker: Peter Lehmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Swiss Prime Site Immobilien AG, Swiss Prime Site AG
texts.text: What are the main drivers here? Of course, the enhancement of care expertise. We are talking about subcontractors who  in the final analysis is going to give us direct access to future guests.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Swiss Prime Site Immobilien AG, Swiss Prime Site AG
texts.text: So much about the fields of business. What are the other important points with regard to sustainability? Let's  begin with clients, the stakeholders at the top left.
