We want to benchmark ourselves to be sure we're on the right track under the heading of sustainability.

texts.speaker: Peter Lehmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Swiss Prime Site Immobilien AG, Swiss Prime Site AG
texts.text: Then moving on to financial excellence. From next Monday, we are going to begin with business planning for the  three years to come and going to implement the so-called sustainability roadmap. Then, under the heading of  compliance and social commitment, we are going to report for the first time according to GRI and we're also going  to publish a sustainability report. You can do it together with the semi-annual results, which may be interesting  from a marketing point of view. But the other option is to publish it one year from now to give us integrated  reporting.

texts.speaker: Peter Lehmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Swiss Prime Site Immobilien AG, Swiss Prime Site AG
texts.text: The integrated reporting is precisely what we want to do, because we're saying that our sustainability roadmap is  part of the business plan, it's part of the business. So logically, it would mean that the first specific sustainability  report should be published one year from now as an integral part.

texts.speaker: Peter Lehmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Swiss Prime Site Immobilien AG, Swiss Prime Site AG
texts.text: Moving on to sustainable investments and services, a lot has been said about Schönburg of Berne. We also  managed by partnership with a company to change the statics in the building. If you look out, you've got the  support grids in the offices that are relatively narrow. Now, if you want to build apartments, you can imagine, you  don't like to live in an apartment with a lot of pillars, a lot of grid structure. So how can you change that, because  in an existing building that is to be converted.

texts.speaker: Peter Lehmann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Swiss Prime Site Immobilien AG, Swiss Prime Site AG
texts.text: We applied building information modeling, a 3D system to widen the structure and to create more appealing  space for apartments. The next objective we have is to protect the environment, long-term targets for energy use  and consumption of electricity and water at properties in our portfolio. We do not invest in sustainability just for  sustainability's sake, but we want to bring down operating expenses. It's no use setting goals that are not really  key to our business. So we need to reasonably invest our financial resources.

file: SPXL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 23August2011 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And overall, as you can see in the bottom right, group like-for-like organic sales increased by 10%, with the Steam  Specialties business up 8% driven by emerging markets and with good growth in prefabricated heat exchange  packages, controls, services and flow meters and Watson-Marlow's 17% sales increase was geographically very well  spread. Exchange movements were immaterial adding just £300,000 to sales on translation. Acquisitions  contributed 1% to group sales, and as you can see this was in respect of Mexico within the Americas.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As expected, higher material costs were a drag on profits and margins. We estimate a lag of around six months  between movements in base metals prices and seeing the effect in our cost of sales. We, therefore, saw some  2011, although largely offset by our own price rises and other actions. For the balance of 2011, we expect to  continue to see some increase in materials in our cost of sales.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Our business in Asia Pacific performed well as our markets improved, accompanied by higher general  maintenance, spending and increased project activity. Overall sales in the region were well ahead, increasing 12%  at constant currency with widespread sales and profit growth. Our businesses in China and Korea largely drive our  financial performance in the Asia Pacific segment. And we note that China has become the largest sales company  in this segment in the first half of 2011, displacing our Korean business, and it remains the highest profit  producer.  We have continued to add sales people in China in our 36 sales offices across the country who are key to  demonstrating and recommending energy savings, emissions reductions and improved plant efficiency  opportunities.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Steam boilers in U.S. are fueled largely with natural gas, which is currently relatively low cost. This has, to a  degree, lessened the attractiveness of energy-saving maintenance at most U.S. refineries.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: We saw higher sales of flow meters in the U.S. in the first half resulting from the Federal Government's push to  measure and report energy usage in federal buildings in compliance with the Energy Policy Act of 2005 and  funded by the government's stimulus program of 2009. These sales contributed the first half sales growth in the  U.S.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: From an industry perspective, sales growth was strong in general, industrial and mining markets, but was weak in  the U.S. water and wastewater market due to reduced federal funding to local governments and tighter state and  municipal budgets.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Our exposure to mining centers mainly on precious metals processing, where highly abrasive slurries are handled  by our Bredel Hose Pumps. I mentioned in March that about 20% of our Watson-Marlow business comes from the  emerging markets as compared to about 40% or over 40% for the Steam business. And we see good future growth  prospects for Watson-Marlow as we build greater market presence in these emerging markets.

file: SPXL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 22August2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our markets in Canada remain robust and we are benefiting from ongoing investments in the oil sands  development activities in Western Canada where steam is used for oil extraction and in facilities space heating.  Sales were therefore higher in both the U.S. and Canada, but U.S. profits were lower due to product mix and  higher materials expense.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: HVAC is our second largest end market that is served by the Steam business in humidification, space heating and  hot water generation applications and is driven by construction spending for large public buildings, universities  and resort hotels. Our third largest end market is refining and petrochemicals shown on the bottom left of the  chart, and steam is heavily used in thermal cracking, power generation and heat tracing applications.

file: SPXL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 8August2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: The economic difficulties in Europe are well-known and overall conditions deteriorated further in the first half of  the year and industrial output continued to shrink, although the pace of contraction is now moderating. Routine  maintenance spending across Europe was stable in the first half in our business, but customer expenditure for  higher value energy saving and plant efficiency projects remained weak.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: In our Asia-Pacific segment, sales increased 8% at constant currency led by continued strong growth in China and  a solid first half in South Korea. Overall sales growth slowed from last year's 12% pace due to a weak first quarter  in most of our Southeast Asia operations. Sales from metering and services increased at a pace above segment  growth as our Asian customers increasingly make investments to reduce their energy usage and lower carbon  emissions. We saw another period of robust sales and profit growth in China, which together with our small  Watson-Marlow China business generated 11% of total group sales in the first half, up from last year's 10%.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Overall market conditions in North America softened in the second half of 2012 and weakened a bit further in the  first half of this year. Demand in Canada for us was sharply lower due to fewer projects associated with oil sands  developments in Western Canada and lower HVAC construction project activity which is a big segment of our  Canadian sales.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: On a positive note, we saw a modest increase in higher value energy saving and process improvement projects in  the U.S. in the first half, which seems to correlate with the rise in natural gas prices above $4 per million BTU. As  a reminder, the vast majority of steam generators in the U.S. utilize natural gas as a feedstock fuel.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Overall geographic market conditions were broadly similar to the Steam business. We saw continued momentum  in biopharmaceuticals, the single most important end user market for Watson-Marlow at more than 30% of sales  along with broadly favorable trends in food processing. However, we saw lower project activity in precious metals  processing and in our general industrial and water treatment markets.

texts.speaker: David John Meredith
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Base metal prices have been falling, but labor, energy and transport costs have increased and these are important  elements in the cost of items such as [indiscernible] (21:05). We have largely captured the benefits of our  investments in manufacturing and the site consolidation in Cheltenham, so the major margin gains have been  won. Business and product mix has not had a significant effect either way in the first half on margins.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: For example, many of our valves and flowmeters can also be used for other processed fluids such as air, water or  hydrocarbons, and it is, therefore, difficult to separate out just the steam and condensate applications for these  products.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: We see three main segments in the Steam Specialties market. Firstly, it's traditional condensate management  products consisting of steam traps, condensate return pumps, isolation valves and so on, and comprising about  28% of our total addressable market.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Secondly is controls, comprising automatic control valves, boiler house controls, pressure regulators and  temperature controls, and making up about 22% of our total market opportunity.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Thirdly is energy management products, consisting principally of our metering products, heat transfer packages  and energy services, and making up about 35% of the total opportunity. Our addressable niche pump market  represents the final 15% of the total market.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: As I've indicated in the past, our market shares in controls and energy management are much smaller than our  traditional condensate management business, and we see good opportunity for growth over the next few years in  these product areas.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: In addition to market share gains, we also look at market expansion as an essential element in creating future  growth opportunities. Please remember that market expansion, of itself, does not guarantee revenue growth. Ours  is a technical direct sales business and growth requires new sales engineers to be recruited and trained, at the  same time, in front of customers, to demonstrate our expertise and convince them to invest money to improve  their plant operating efficiency and reduce their energy usage.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: In Steam business, we have focused most of our internal product development in areas of plant automation and  engineered heat transfer packages. These areas have the best long-term growth prospects and we are responding  to market trends for greater real time information flow between fuel devices and process control systems and  fewer purchasing transactions.

texts.speaker: Mark E. Vernon
texts.profession: Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: New product developments include a broader range of energy management products. This is [ph] custom (28:10)  standard pre-engineered heat transfer packages, flowmeters and boiler house controls. At Watson-Marlow,  product development efforts are even more critical in generating revenue growth. In the past year, we introduced  two new pumps that have materially increased our addressable market, and are already contributing meaningfully  to Watson-Marlow sales growth this year.

Sales and profits were ahead  in all our geographic regions in Watson-Marlow constant currency. Increased sectorization, particularly within the  EMEA region, benefited growth.

texts.profession: CEO, COO & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Base metal prices looked to have bottomed out, and labor, energy and transport costs have increased. And these  are important elements of cost items such in the [ph] case of accounting (26:03). We have largely captured the  benefits of our investment in manufacturing. We will be focusing increased attention on the end -to-end supply  chain, but this will take some time to come through.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: CEO, COO & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: And we have generated from that process six primary strategies that I will share with you now over the next couple  of slides. Our first primary strategy is to increase direct sales effectiveness through sector focus. And our drive will  include expanding and deepening the sector focus of our direct sales force, which in turn we will call a  sectorization of the sales force; enhancing the customer value propositions of those priorities sectors that we have  targeted; and increasing our focus on thermal energy management within those priority sectors.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: CEO, COO & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Finally, the sixth primary strategy is to operate sustainably and help improve our customers' sustainability. Our  approach is to increase sustainability encompasses, increase focus on corporate governance, employee well -being,  community engagement and environmental stewardship.

texts.profession: CEO, COO & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: We also look to further the success of our business by continuing to support our customers meet their needs and  their sustainability targets. With that, actually that we launched this strategy inte rnally. We did a global launch on  the 1st of July, with the very strong focus on the implementation. Our team – our organization is highly motivated,  very engaged. We had a very positive take-up and very focused on obviously making this strategy – put it into  action.

texts.profession: CEO, COO & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: The first of today's customer case studies comes from a major brewer in Brazil that was encountering numerous  problems with its bottle washing equipment. Typical problems included fouling,  low heat transfer efficiency, frequent breakdowns, high maintenance costs and safety concerns for the employees  responsible for cleaning and maintaining these machines.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: Our engineers developed a bespoke solution using a Turflow corrugated heat exchanger with rotary draining  strainers, which were installed externally to the washing machines. This solution saved over 4 million liters of  water per year lowering maintenance costs, reduced accident risks, and also generating energy savings in excess  of £90,000 per annum. Another nice example of how bespoke engineered solutions drive customer value and  drive our growth.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: The first of today's customer case studies comes from the Middle East, where the Address Hotel Dubai Mall was  encountering high energy costs when generating hot water for the use of their guests, laundry and kitchen.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Our expert sales engineers performed an energy audit at the hotel's existing steam systems, identifying some  inefficiencies in the condensate return lines and developed a bespoke system to recover waste heat from the  flash steam that was being vented into the atmosphere. Our automated low-cost solution uses Turflow heat  exchanger as an exhaust vapor condenser to recover heat from the flash steam and boost the temperature of the  returning condensate.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: This simple solution reduced energy usage and water usage for our customer, generating annual savings of  $100,000. So, as you see, innovative solutions uncover self-generated growth opportunities.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Today's second case study comes from Watson-Marlow in China, where the Bredel hose pumps replaced  conventional piston pumps for offshore concrete grouting in a series of prestigious construction projects along the  Chinese coastline.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Conventional piston pumps struggle with the abrasive nature of the cement based grout slurries, which cause  accelerated component wear, fluid leakage and unplanned maintenance downtimes.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: The adoption of the Bredel hose pump significantly increased production uptime, created safer working  environment, reduced maintenance and spare part costs. Importantly, the Bredel hose pumps also reduced slurry  leakages, significantly improving environmental performance.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: 90 Bredel pumps worth €1.8 million were delivered across five different projects. The larger Bredel 80 pumps are  used to transfer grout from the quayside mixing tanks into seafaring vessels, while the small Bredel 65 models are  used to meter grout from the vessels into the piles at the offshore construction sites. This is another good  example of Watson-Marlow peristaltic pumps displacing other pumping technologies.

texts.text: They were using very old and inefficient tube and shell heat exchangers to heat the water and maintain the  temperature throughout the process. texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: So, our steam application engineers designed and supplied a bespoke solution composed of five Turflow heat  exchangers and automatic pumping trap packages. The customers' estimated payback period for this investment was less than six months. Another  example of how, by understanding the customer's needs, we'll become a trusted advisor and uncover  opportunities for self-generated growth.

texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Today's second case study comes from Watson-Marlow in the UK. The solution was Flexicon's FMB210L fully-automatic vial filling and screw  capping machine with integrated Laminar Airflow System to maintain a near particle-free environment in critical  zones. The system is [ph] modern (27:37) and easily customizable, working with different liquids, containers, and  caps.

texts.speaker: Kevin James Boyd
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Efficient DNA sequencing requires multiple cycles of polymerase chain reaction or PCR effect to occur within very  specific and precise temperature shift for specific [ph] delta (28:58). Our sales engineers worked closely with the  OEM customer to understand the process and designed Kapton heaters to accommodate the specific needs of  each of the three primary heating shift, the nature and yield of extent.

texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: These caption heaters included thermal sensors, amplifier interface, microprocessors, and software interfaces to  existing equipment. texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: CEO, COO & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: The first example will come from Watson-Marlow and is an excellent case of leveraging our R&D investments to  expand our addressable markets and accelerate profitable growth. Turbidity or cloudiness is a key measure of  quality for potable water and is performed on a continuous basis by all water treatment facilities like Welsh Water.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: CEO, COO & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Traditionally, water samples are collected using positive displacement technologies such as bellow pumps, and are  then moved at very steady rates through a turbidity meter to assess the quality of those waters. Bellow pumps can,  however, produce uneven flows or cause the introduction of air in the water samples. And  this can lead to false  readings that put the quality assurance at risk with the largest and most important water supply to the populous  South Wales region.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: CEO, COO & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: The new Qdos 30 pump from Watson-Marlow is providing a steady, pulse-free, flow speed of 280 milliliters per  minute, completely free from air bubbles and is allowing Welsh Water to achieve accurate and reliable turbidity  testing. The point here to emphasize is that the new peristaltic pump that was wholly developed by Watson - Marlow and launched simultaneously across the world in mid-2012 has increased the addressable market by an  estimated £150 million.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: CEO, COO & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Menasha Packaging group's Coloma plant in Michigan, U.S.A. was experiencing a higher than expected material  scrap rate and Spirax Sarco's local team recommended a complete energy assessment of their facility. Through the  energy audit that they performed, we identified areas of their steam system that were actually undersized or  operating below optimal conditions. And we also identified an opportunity to recover some waste heat from their  boiler blow-down processes. So, the solutions that we implemented at Menasha's production reduced their losses  and improved their energy usage. This customer estimated savings at £100,000 per annum and less than one year  payback for his investment.

texts.profession: Group Chief Executive
texts.text: Lastly, we're very pleased by the progress of our sustainability initiatives, especially by the 13% reduction to our  global carbon emissions levels. The new combined heat and power unit installed in Cheltenham was a notable  contributor to that achievement.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive
texts.text: When brewing beer, boiling the wort is a crucial process with wide implications on product quality, productivity  and cost, including scrap rates and energy consumption. One of the process controls is to measure the hourly  evaporation rates, which should remain below 4% for optimum overall performance.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive
texts.text: This customer was experiencing some process instability, with periods when the hour evaporation rate peaked at  7 %. This affected product quality and cost, whilst also increasing the frequency of maintenance shutdowns for  cleaning that reduced productivity.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive
texts.text: Our expert sales engineer analyzed the situation and proposed a bespoke engineered pressure c ontrol loop, with  additional steam trapping stations and ancillary steam metering equipment. This fully resolved the problem. And  among various benefits for the customer, reduced maintenance downtime by 90% and energy consumption by  20% in that part of the process.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive
texts.text: Additionally, pumping accuracy of plus or minus 0.5% is essential in filling thousands of 5 -millimeter vials. A  typical batch at BDU ranges between 5 liters and 10 liters. So it is important not to overfill when you're producing  1,000 or 2,000 of these 5-millimeter vials per batch.

texts.text: The first of today's customer case studies comes from China, where Shanghai Totole Food Company was  encountering high energy costs. texts.text: Today's second case is from Watson-Marlow in Germany. It was also of paramount importance for this customer that the pumping solution would need stringent  hygienic standards and be easy to clean in place. The solution was the new MasoSine Certa pump launched in  2016 by Watson-Marlow. And this pump performed – the performance achieved by this pump was described by  the customer's operations manager as simply outstanding, with up to 50% more gentle handling than rotary lobe  pumps, reducing [ph] process scrap rate (32:33) and improving productivity.

texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: The much improved clean-in-place properties of the Certa pump significantly reduced maintenance downtime and  increased production process hygiene. So, again as you can see, innovative new product development, [ph]  engineered (32:50) sustainable value and generate growth opportunity.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Chromalox significantly expands our addressable market as it is also dedicated to transfer of heat energy into an  industrial process using electricity. Our group now has the unique capability to access a much wider range of  industrial heating application.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: The first of today's customer case studies comes from Spirax-Sarco in China where our engineers introduced  steam heating solutions in the manufacturing process of lithium-ion batteries. The increasing demand of batteries  for electric vehicles, consumer products, and energy storage systems requires growing investments in  manufacturing facilities for the production of lithium-ion batteries. This market is estimated to be growing at close  to 10% per annum.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Within the production process, the coating and drying stage is particularly important as temperature and relative  humidity along the 50-meter long drying ovens have a direct impact on production yields and product quality. Our  steam application engineers have developed bespoke solutions that reduced energy usage and significantly  improved process safety, generating annual savings of £140,000 for the customers. As you can see, innovative  solutions uncover self-generated growth.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: This required a pump that could meet the following four critical performance criteria. First, virtually no pulsation to  avoid foaming and loss of product integrity. Second, consistent and accurate flows. Third, hygienic and easy to  clean, with minimal downtime between production batches. And fourth, higher temperature resistance.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Only the new Certa pump met all of these criterias, displacing diaphragm pumps. This is another good example of  Watson-Marlow's peristaltic pumps displacing other pumping technologies.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Our sales engineers proposed a solution that brought the whole drying process onto a continuous production line  using dry compressed air at 200 degrees Fahrenheit. The air is heated by four Chromalox GCH circulation  heaters, which are controlled by Chromalox SCR temperature and power controllers. The result was a faster,  consistent, reliable and automated process.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: The entire operation is now done in 1 minute, compared to 11 minutes previously, without the risks of overheating  some of the bottles. This is a good example of how Chromalox also uncovers self-generated growth through  innovative solutions.

file: SPXL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 7March2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Watson-Marlow's organic sales grew 9% with strong contributions from all geographic regions. Currency  headwinds reduced reported sales growth to 7%. Sales growth was strong across the Pharma and Biotechnology  sector that accounts for over 40% of Watson-Marlow's global revenues. Good sales growth continued in the Food  & Beverage sector, driven by the innovative MasoSine Certa pump as well as the environmental sector due to the  extended Qdos pump range.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: On the 18th of February 2019, we announced that we'd entered exclusive negotiations to acquire Thermocoax  group of companies for a €158 million consideration. This will be the first bolt-on to our Chromalox business that  was acquired in July 2017. Thermocoax designs and manufactures highly engineered electrical thermal solutions  for critical applications in high added value industries where the cost of a solution is secondary concern to  reliability and performance. Headquartered in Paris, France, Thermocoax has manufacturing facilities in France,  Germany, and the USA, and employs over 300 people.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: This is another fine example of how our products help customers achieve significant process improvement and  cost savings whilst preserving the integrity and quality of their product. Today's second case study comes from  Spirax-Sarco India where our application engineers designed a bespoke solution to improve the efficiency of a  rice mill's de-husking process. The customers experience in frequent plant shutdowns and a higher breakage of  rice grains during their milling process which impacted the quality of the rice they produced and lowered the price  the mill could obtain of their product. Our bespoke solution reduced the customer [ph] crop rates (00:31:29) saved  water and energy, improved the quality of their rice grains, and increased the customers' revenues.

texts.speaker: Nicholas John Anderson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Spirax-Sarco Engineering Plc
texts.text: Today's final customer case study comes from Chromalox in the USA. Our innovative temperature management  system, which includes line-sensing technology, self-regulating, heat tracing cables, and IntelliTRACE  temperature control panels, ensured a much safer and reliable solution for the customers' LNG processing plants.  Also, the customer saved $300,000 during the installation phase and over $200,000 per annum of operating cost.

texts.text: And actually, as it happens. is that we barely find any part of the public service that is prepared to accept that,  even when we go to Peterborough, God bless them. You might think that you'd suggested a Harrodian act of massacre but quite apart  from taking NHS records and saying, do you mind if we take the NHS record for 10.5 million people and have  them processed in Mumbai? texts.speaker: Rupert Christopher Soames
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We've talked about the five pillars, the Defense, Justice & Immigration, Transport, Health and Citizen Services,  across the four regions. We like that we have strong existing positions in those marketplaces, so that's a tick  against the strategy. And we believe that having this crossing of the pillars in the regions will reduce volatility and  give us regional diversification and allow us to build international scale. And then the businesses that we're going  to exit are the private sector BPO, the level leisure and environmental services in the UK and the Great Southern  Railway in Australia.

texts.speaker: Edward J. Casey
texts.profession: Group Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In these operational reviews, we cover business development statistics, our pipeline, key new bids. We focus on  customer satisfaction and service delivery, and we receive reports on the achievement of KPIs on our contracts  with a considerable focus on those contracts where we're having difficulty. We review a wide array of people and  organizational information, including matters relating to ethics and health, safety and environmental. These are  detailed monthly reviews conducted by Rupert, Angus and me.

texts.speaker: Edward J. Casey
texts.profession: Group Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The other three businesses that have been announced for divestment include the Environmental Services  business, Leisure and Great Southern Rail in Australia. The process is well advanced for Environmental and  Leisure, and we're currently working with customers to novate contracts as part of the approval process.

texts.speaker: Angus George Cockburn
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As you heard from Ed, we have started a major cost reduction exercise which will reduce overheads through head  count reduction, purchasing savings and a program of continuous improvement.

texts.speaker: Angus George Cockburn
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: As we said, we'll change the emphasis of the business to include a focus in return on invested capital taking into  account the varying levels of risk that are attached to contracts. Our planned exit of non-core businesses will help  to focus the business from the B2G strategy implementation. And with the proposed rights issue, we'll establish a  sustainable capital structure.

file: SRPL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 28February2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our strong financial performance, increasing order book and broader portfolio has been achieved despite some of  the most challenging economic environment that we have operated in. And we responded to that changing climate  in 2011 by doing the following: Firstly, by focusing on operations, which we know, strengthens our customer  relationships and provides us with the incremental growth that is a hallmark of our company. Secondly, we  launched our BPO division, which we have been building for a number of years. Thirdly, we took the opportunity  to review our UK structure as well as our wider global cost base in order to maintain our competitiveness in these  challenging times.

texts.speaker: Christopher Rajendran Hyman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Serco Group Plc
texts.text: The environment was such that the entire federal contracting market experienced significant delays in decisions  contracts and even cancelled or reduced scope of many contract or task orders. Because the government could not  enact any of the 12 normal appropriation bills, it functions under continuing resolutions and faced the frequent  threat of a complete federal shutdown, bringing uncertainty and unpredictability into the market during the year.

texts.speaker: Christopher Rajendran Hyman
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Serco Group Plc
texts.text: In the Middle East, ridership on the Dubai Metro has tripled, as I mentioned earlier, and the green line opens in  September. Our Aviation business successfully rebid for air traffic control services at the three international  airports and the General Civil Aviation Authority in the UAE. And we completed the full transfer of the U.S.  military to the Iraqi authorities of its air traffic control services for lower air space in that region.

texts.text: Our ongoing portfolio management strategy has also led to four disposals in the year. All have become non-core to the future development of the Group.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Serco Group Plc
texts.text: Looking to the future, the environment is expected to remain difficult with the growing national debt and as yet  unknown impact of sequestration. Nonetheless, at around $300 billion per annum, the U.S. Federal Services  market remains the largest outsourcing market in the world.

In health, we are well placed to service the hospital support market and demand is likely to grow as  facility services and transaction processing are brought together.

texts.profession: Chief Executive & Transformation Officer, Serco Group Plc
texts.text: We also implemented a statewide advanced traffic management system overseeing 57 ,000 miles of roadway for  the Virginia Department of Transportation. Y et, we achieved organic growth in the second half of the year primarily through the startup of the two  major new contracts that I just mentioned, plus we had a number o f rebids, extensions, and smaller new contract  wins.
