EBITDA per tonne, just below SEK1,000 per tonne, and in the – at the same level as  we saw in Q1 2011.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Mining, I would say fairly strong in all regions, with maybe one exception, and that is [ph] energy (04:43) coal  mining in North America slowed down a bit during Q1, and that is of course a combination of a very mild winter in  North America and lower gas prices in North America as well. But apart from that, I would say the Mining sector,  as we see it, develops fairly well.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Energy, also an important segments – several segments, remains on a decent level. Wind tower demand is still  steady, but we haven't seen any extension of the production tax credit yet. So, this could be – we could see a  slowdown here after the presidential election in North America or going into 2013. So, we have to wait and see if  they will extend those production tax credits.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Taking a more broader look, global steel production increased with 1% and amounted to 377 million tonnes in Q1,  so in line with what we saw in Q1 last year. We saw and we see a continued recovery in the North American steel  market, but no surprise, the macroeconomic outlook in Europe remains uncertain. Demand in Q1 was, as I said,  impacted by some replenishment of the inventories among customers following pronounced destocking during  Q4. The strongest segments for us remains Material Handling, large Construction Equipment and the North  American energy sector. Spot prices in general turned up during Q1 and – after a downturn in Q4.

texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: A couple of words about the raw materials; iron ore prices for Q1 went down about 12%, but due to the inventories  it didn't give any major impact in Q1, but this impact will come in Q2. We haven't settled any prices for Q2 yet.  That negotiation is ongoing, and we'll get back to you when we have settled thee prices as well. Coal we buy – as  you may know, about 40% is coming from North America and 60% from Australia. Due to the winter inventories,  we haven't received any deliveries during Q1 although we have settled about 75% of those annual contracts with  American coal suppliers and the price went down about 30% compared to last year's contract. But that will not  give any impact in Q2 either due to the inventories we have. So from Q3 and Q4, we will get that impact. And in  North America, we buy scrap on continuous basis to our mini mills. And prices have moved quite a lot sideways  actually. It's slightly decreased compared to year-end or last quarter. But last week, the prices have been quite a  lot sideways.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Thank you. So as said, the recovery in Americas continued and is expected to continue. In Europe the market, due  to the financial situation, the macro economic outlook, the market remains uncertain whereas the outlook for, as  we see it, SSAB APAC is stable. European price contracts for Q2 will be on somewhat higher levels than in Q1. We  will see the impact, as Marco mentioned, of lower iron ore costs or prices in Q2 and the impact of lower coking  coal prices in Q3. The startup of the blast furnace in Oxelösund, the large one, was done in early March. And we  are planning to idle the small one in beginning of May, early May. The SEK800 million efficiency program that we  launched the beginning of Q1 is proceeding according to plan and we will continue to deliver on that one.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: In this example we, with our steel and our design, managed to decrease the weight of the dumper body with 50%  and roughly doubled the life length. So instead of using 6-tonnene, we were able to produce a dumper body like  this with only 3 tonnes of steel. That is of course extremely beneficial for the end user, the owner of the truck or  the driver of the truck. It gives that person or that company possibilities to increase payload or decrease fuel  consumption or a combination on that. But I think this is – this example is interesting in another aspect as well. I  mean for the producer of the dumper body, this of course is also extremely interesting. I have a number of KPIs  here, a number of components. If you compare the old design with normal steel, we were able to take down the  number of components from 100 to 27 in this example.

file: SSAB.A - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 25April2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: In general, with some ups and downs, our contract prices were stable in Q1 compared to Q4. And we also saw the  effect of lower iron ore and coking coal in the P&L during Q1 and the effect of that is roughly SEK170 million  compared to Q4.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Mining, fairly stable, with the exception of the East Australia and Indonesia, and coal mining slowing down a bit.  But apart from that, no big changes what we have seen. And as you know, US energy coal market has not been  doing extremely well for the last couple of quarters, the last year. So I would say no major changes as we see.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Energy, fairly good segment. There is, in the market now, some large multiple-year line pipe projects being  discussed, some of them fairly big. So this continued to be a strong market in North America. And the  transmission tower business continues to be fairly solid given the market sentiment.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Americas, on the other side, we don't – we run at decent volumes. Here, the problem in the North American steel  market is the difference between ordinary plate and scrap, and that difference has been sliding downwards during  the second half of last year and is now an all-time low. So if it is, call it, a volume issue in EMEA, it's a margin  issue in the first quarter in Americas.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: The demand from the energy and heavy transport segments increased during the quarter and during the end of  the quarter, but construction machinery or yellow goods is still on a fairly low level compared to historically.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: In Europe, capacity utilization among the steel industry is still on a low level. In February, it was 73% which is  quite low, I would say. When we look into the supply chain, we say, overall, but the inventories are at normal  levels after the modest restocking. So we don't expect any restocking or destocking effects in the near future. The  European strip spot prices have been under pressure from late March, April. As you know, we don't sell anything  on spot. We have contract prices. But spot prices have been somewhat under pressure.

texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: A couple of words about raw materials. As you know, we had a contract with LKAB for purchases during Q3 and  Q1. And that price went down 23% compared to the earlier contract. This will give an impact in Q1 and Q2 due to  about one quarter lag that we have in iron ore. So steel in Q2, P&L-wise, we will get the same prices in raw  materials, what comes to iron ore, as we had in Q1.

texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Coal, we buy from Australia about 60% to 70% of our needs. And that's bought in a monthly basis. And here as  well, you have seen the prices have gone down. The remaining part of coal is bought from US. And that's an  annual contract. The annual contract ended at the end of March. The new contract, starting from 1 April, same  here, as I said in LKAB contract, we don't know yet the price. We don't know yet the contract length. We are in  negotiations with our suppliers.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: We talked about the recovery we have seen in the beginning of the second quarter for US plate prices. And the  completion of the efficiency program within SSAB EMEA will start to affect the quarterly results from Q2. And the  full-year effect will be seen 2014 year-over-year. But quarter-over-quarter, sequentially, we'll see that already in  Q2.

file: SSAB.A - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 25April2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Automotive, fairly a good demand in EMEA, especially in Germany, continued okay demand in North America,  even though one or two of the big producers in North America have problems to ship cars due to the severe winter  weather. But the underlying demand fairly stable and quite okay.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Energy continues to be fairly okay and stable, and especially wind tower activity has increased during Q1. In  Europe though, from the energy segment, we get some mixed signals.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Market environment, the global steel production increased during the first quarter with 2% in the European  Union or EU28 increased by 7 %. In North America, only by 1%, and all of the North American steel producers  were affected by the extreme weather conditions, and production in China increased by 2%.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: We saw a demand from several segments increasing, and my conclusion is that our shipments increased more  than the underlying market demand. So we have been taking in Q1 market shares. Prices increased by 3% for  standard steel, and that was only a mix effect. We were selling due to the warmer winter, more [indiscernible]  (06:27) and more galvanized. So I would say contract prices more or less unchanged. And for high strength steel,  they fell by 1% compared to Q4 in local currencies. And high strength steel accounted for 41%, 2 percentage points  lower than the same quarter last year.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Americas, shipments increased by 8% versus Q4. And here we had problems with – and we had an EBIT of SEK  126 million. We had problems with the weather. We had problems to get hold on railcars. We had higher scrap  prices than normal. We had higher electricity cost than normal due to the weather situation.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Demand from automotive and construction machineries strengthened during the qua rter, and the prices of  standard steels were up 7% during the quarter. And for high strength steel, prices were up 3% compared to Q4.  And I said the weather didn't only affect our shipments, it also affected our costs.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB
texts.text: Then we had a negative impact from the variable cost of goods sold, and this is primarily rather only due to  Americas. And as Martin mentioned, the higher scrap costs also the weather-impacted higher electricity costs, and  we also had some production disturbances during the first quarter due to the extreme weather. And scrap prices  now in U.S. are on a significantly higher level than they were, for example, in September last year. And then we  had a positive impact of other – here we have for example some fixed costs and we have Tibnor there as well. So  all in all, an improvement of a little bit more than SEK 300 million and the short summary is that better prices in  Americas, better volumes in EMEA, somewhat offset but higher cost in Americas.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB
texts.text: We also have lower variable COGS and here this is also EMEA while Americas actually are slightly higher. But in  EMEA, some raw material prices impacted better and also production efficiencies and then we have some negative  on others for same reason as previous page. And all in all, that gives the improvement of SEK 162 million.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB
texts.text: Finally, from my point, some words on raw material prices. For iron ore, our prices were 7% lower than they were  in Q4. On the other hand, they were actually 3% higher than they were in Q1 last year. We have not yet signed a  new price contract with LKAB. The one we had expired at the end of Q1. We are, of course, still getting the  volumes from them, but we are in the negotiation on signing the new contract.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB
texts.text: For coking coal, which we buy then both from Australia and from the U.S., our price was 6% lower than in Q4, and  actually, 29% lower than in Q1 last year. Coking coal has, over the last few years, been on a downward sliding  trend.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: The maintenance stop in Mobile was moved a bit, and the reason for that was to be able to ship material to our  customers. So, we were first expecting outage to be half of it in March and half of it in April, we had to move it due  to closing down Mobile for three days due to the weather and also problems getting hold on railcars. So we moved  it to the May; majority of that outage has been done in beginning of April.

file: SSAB.A - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 27April2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If we look at the segments, I would say pretty much as expected. Heavy transport developed during the quarter  fairly okay in Europe and U.S.; Automotive, overall a good demand; Construction Machinery, stable at low levels  in the Europe and the U.S.; Mining, slow demand or low levels in all markets; energy, wind towers and  transmission towers in North America, quite okay, low activity in the pipeline sector; Construction Material,  seasonally slow; and then Service Centers, very slow during Q1, and if any surprise maybe a bit slower than  expected and the destocking phase will take slightly longer than we expected when we released the Q4 report.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So, what have we done? Well, we have done [ph] easy part of the easy stuff (05:51). We have lower purchasing  costs. We have renegotiated purchasing agreements. We are sourcing more internally to Tibnor instead of doing it  externally. We are shipping coking coal from Oxelösund to Raahe instead of buying it externally. And we have  lower administrative costs.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: We have a positive volume impact coming from both SSAB Europe and SSAB Special Steels. We also have positive  impact of variable COGS. This is related to lower raw material costs, but also that we have been running the  production well in the European system, and also some of the synergies are impacting on variable COGS.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: If we starting compare Q1 to Q1, we had almost zero Q1 last year, plus SEK 34 million. And here, we have a drop in  price of around SEK 400 million. This is excluding currency movements, and it's mainly coming from SSAB  Europe. Volumes basically no impact, and then large impact on variable COGS. And it's the same factors as with  Q1 to Q4, but here the raw material impacts are larger where all three of them, if you say, the big one, iron ore,  coking coal and scrap were lower now in Q1 than Q1 last year.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Moving then to the raw material side, starting with iron ore and coking coal. In U.S. dollar, we saw both iron ore  and coking coal decreased during Q1 and we have, on the growth rates, from the beginning of 2014 where iron ore  started on almost $140 and is now down at – well, right now it's $58, but it was actually down even below $50 a  few weeks ago. But these are the spot prices for funds. And we buy pellet and our pellet prices decreased with 12%  in U.S. dollar, but actually increased with 1% in Swedish kroner compared to Q4.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Coking coal has during the same time period, also decreased but not that all as much as iron ore. And for us, in Q1,  our purchase prices were down 3% in U.S. dollar, but actually 13% higher in Swedish kroner. And for our raw  material purchases, we are hedging the same length as the – we're hedging the U.S. dollar the same length as the  contracts. Usually, it's a quarter. And we have now seen the strengthening of the U.S. dollar, but we will continue  to see that also going forward for our purchases.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: For scrap, scrap prices in U.S. then also fell quite sharply during Q1, and they were down 24% compared to the  end of Q4 and actually 35% compared to the end of the same period last year. And we saw especially in February,  there was a big drop but since then, they have been pretty stable. It's important to remember though that despite  this drop now in Q1, scrap prices has not at all dropped as much as we have seen iron ore prices dropped. And  historically, they have been very much co-related but so far, scrap prices have not followed the iron ore drop yet.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Finally, then from my side, some words about relining that we're doing now in Luleå during the summer. We will  start in the beginning of June. It will continue for three months. We will and we are currently doing them,  replacing this 500,000 tonnes of slabs. So we started up this small blast furnace in Oxelösund during Q1, and we  will continue to run that until the big one in Luleå is up and running again.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: There will be some extra cost associated to this on top of the capital expenditures of between SEK 150 million and  SEK 200 million. This will mainly impact Q3, but somewhat also now in Q2. And it will also differ a bit between  the divisions because for Special Steels, which are now running the small blast furnace again, they will actually  benefit from this because they will have lower under-absorption while Europe, which will be standing down with  the big blast furnace for three months, that cost will be burden on Europe.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Then over to something completely different. A week ago, we launched our new brand name for structural steels,  for steels above 600 megapascal, and the name of that brand is Strenx Performance Steel, and that will be instead  of Domex, Weldox, and Optim, but this is not just a change of a brand name. We also launched this together with  much better guarantees when it comes to workshop properties like weldability, bendability, surface cleanliness,  and so on, and this has been received very positively.

file: SSAB.A - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 22April2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: However, we entered Q4 on a clearly higher price level than we entered Q1 and we also have, in all our three steel  divisions, a contract structure with some things on spot, some on three-year contracts – three months, some on  six months, which means that, on average, we got a negative impact from lower prices in Q1 versus Q4.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Another segment in the U.S. that has been developing in Q1 fairly well, it looks to be developing well going  forward as well, is the wind towers segment.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Thank you, Håkan. So, what are we then going to do? This is an updated picture with the target of c ost savings.  And as said, synergy program will be finalized during this quarter and will be met. When it comes to the Ruukki  Construction restructuring, all the actions are taken, and that will now onwards be seen in the P&L. What we call  selected efficiency investments, the PCI and the water treatment plant in Alabama, done, up and running.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: This is what we always going to focus on. This is what we always have focused on. But this is what we are going to  continue to focus on. The global market for advanced high-strength steels and Q&T where, we especially within  Q&T are the global leader. Our two important home markets, flat carbon steel and tubes in the Nordic region  where we today have a market share between 45% and 50%. So, higher than before the combination with the two  companies separate and then in North America where we today have a market share within heavy plate of 25%.  So, we have been able to increase that market share as well.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Sustainability is an important part of SSAB, and it's actually our business model because what we do is actually  helping end users to reduce weight, increase payload, increase life length, and reduce fuel con sumption. And that's  how we sell our steel and our steel products. So, that is the sustainable offering. This is one good example of many,  and I've said it many times before, but we – typically when we look into an application, we can typically double the  life length. We can typically reduce the weight between 30% and 50%, and by that then, increase payload, reduce  fuel consumption or a combination of that.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We are today the most carbon dioxide steel producer – carbon dioxide effective steel producer in the world in our  mill in Luleå. After the PCI investment in Raahe, we are on par with Luleå. So, we have, in that aspect, very good  measures. In U.S., we are 100% scrap based. We only use recycled materials. So, that is important.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: But a couple of weeks ago, we launched a new project together with LKAB and Vattenfall, where we are  determined to look into the possibilities to produce iron without any carbon dioxide as a great product. Today,  when you produce iron, you use iron ore and coal, and you get iron and carbon dioxide. We are looking into a new  process and it's not only theoretically possible. It's also possible in small-scale development tests to use hydrogen.  And then, you would produce iron sponge, and the residual would not be carbon dioxide, it would be water. So, we  are now determined to look into this and try to make it in a full-scale, cost-competitive industrial project. And that  project has been started a couple of weeks ago.

file: SSAB.A - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 21April2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: We also saw a strong growth within Automotive. Automotive premium volumes were up 20% year-over-year. We  also launched a new product, Hardox 500 Tuf was launched during Q1, a very important product for us. And we  also gained more support from the Swedish Energy Agency for our HYBRIT project. And as you know, the  HYBRIT project is the project we run together with Vattenfall and LKAB to find out a way to produce steel without  any carbon dioxide emissions.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Americas, I would say continued good demand from the energy segment. We saw higher prices. We saw the  Mobile outage, as we talked about. We also saw higher scrap cost. And this typically hit us a bit earlier than this in  the P&L due to the lead times and the lag.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Volume also contributed positively, not that much, but around SEK 300 million, and this is Europe and Special  Steels especially. And then we had a negative impact on variable COGS. To a very large portion, this is raw  material. Actually, all three main of them: iron ore, coking coal and scrap. It's also some impact in variable COGS  and also the negative impact in fixed cost from the Oxelösund breakdown from the Mobile outage.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Clear volume improvement coming from Special Steels and also from SSAB Europe, while Americas roughly on  the same level. And then variable COGS is, to a very large extent, raw material driven. Slight improvement in  fixed cost basically because we have the large planned maintenance outage in Special Steels in Q4, which we did  not have now in Q1. And we actually had quite a big negative impact from FX mainly due to a weaker Swedish  kroner during Q4. And other further losses then driven by under absorption – or improvement in under absorption  that we run in the mills at a high level.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: If we move then into raw material here, there's definitely more changes. We have seen in the P&L in Q1 and we  will see also in the next quarter increased raw material prices for iron ore and coking coal especially. This is a  new type of graph that we are using from this quarter on, it's our own purchase prices, but it's indexed. So, started  from $100 then at the end of 2015.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: And in this quarter, our coking coal prices – the purchase prices were up 2%. That's obviously very undramatic.  But if we would have added what they were up one year ago, they were up 162%. So, coking coal has moved  enormously. And as most of you probably have followed, we saw a spike in Q4 when it was about $300, then it  went down, almost down $250. And then in the last few weeks, there has been this cyclone in Australia causing  railways to break down, et cetera. So, now it's up around $300 again. At least we don't see any underlying  demand that would trigger this, but it's really much about the supply. So, we would expect that this peak would  come down again during this quarter.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: For our pellet prices, prices were 15% higher, our purchase prices in Q1 than Q4. If we were compare one year  ago, it's obviously not as dramatic as for coking coal, but they are still up 57% compared one year ago. So, very  strong increase on the raw materials side.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: We did during the quarter sign a new contract with LKAB. It's a one-year contract. So, from 1st of April to end of  March 2018. And it's now based on monthly pricing. It used to be quarterly, now it is monthly. And when we move  into this contract now, what we have also seen is pellet prices – the premium for pellets have moved up lately, so  we will in Q2 have a higher cost for the pellet premium as well.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: So, my last picture will be something completely different. It will be the four finalists in Swedish Steel Prize that we  will have in May. And these are four good examples of applications where you can have a lot of benefits by using  advanced high-strength steels or, Q&T. And these are also very good examples of what we work with in our daily  life, working together with customers, helping them to reduce weight, increase life length, increase safety, reduce  fuel consumption and emission.

file: SSAB.A - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 20April2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: The result was up compared to last year, higher prices, higher volumes, but last year we had the maintenance  outage in Mobile in Q1 and Q2 which we didn't have this year. We also saw higher scrap costs, but we saw  margins gradually improve during the first quarter. Tibnor, for lat products, I would say, decent development what  we suffered from both building-related products or building-related volumes where we had the lower shipments  during the quarter compared to one year ago or compared to the fourth quarter. And the Ruukki Construction  affected by the harsher winter than we had a year ago, so if there is a lot of snow, there are no roof repairs and so  on. So, we definitely felt that during the first quarter, and sales were lower than one year ago when we had a  milder winter.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: So, when we sum up, we see lower volume and lower margins, but this is, I mean, call it, an accelerated  seasonality then due to a lot of snow, especially in the Nordic region. Håkan?

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: On the volume side, it's a zero there, but it's some pluses and minuses. Higher volumes in Americas and Special  Steels offset by lower volumes in Europe, Ruukki Construction and Tibnor. On the variable COGS side, we had a  negative impact on more than SEK 1.1 billion. If you only take the raw material part of that, it's actually SEK 1.2  billion. So, basically offsetting what we have seen so far on the price increase side. Then, we have the higher  fixed cost in this quarter compared to last year. Some higher activity level in the downstream operations, also  general salary increases. What I think is important to mention I think I did that last time as well is that in terms of  fixed manning, we are actually at exactly the same level that we were after we had finalized the redundancy  programs at the end of 2016.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Higher prices compared to Q4, all three steel divisions, Americas, Europe, Special Steels, biggest increase in  Americas. Volume moving upwards in Special Steels. Europe moving in the right direction, but Rautaruukki  Construction [indiscernible] (00:11:35) going down compared to Q4. And on the variable COGS side, we see  actually a higher increase than we see on the price side, given that the raw material has – I'll come back to that –  but has increased quite a lot.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: So, coming back into the raw material as I talked about in the bridges, we have seen overall purchase prices have  increased, and we start with the main components for the Nordics operations, then iron ore and coking coal. Our  purchase prices both increased during the quarter, iron ore, 18%; coking coal, 23%. And for iron ore, part of the  increase that we get on purchase prices during Q1 will also impact the result in Q1, and that's mainly for the  operations we have in Luleå where we don't basically have any stock of iron ore, but we get it on a daily basis  from LKAB, and then it also quickly hits the P&L. If you compare with Oxelösund the raw, we will see the impact  of the price increase for us coming more into Q2 instead.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Purchase price of a coking coal increased actually percentage-wise more during the second quarter – sorry first  quarter for us. However, the main purchases for coking coal we do in Q2 and Q3 given that we have this winter  stock in Luleå and in Raahe, but also that we will see an impact of the higher raw material cost in the second  quarter.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: When we look at spot prices and this chart is spot prices. We actually also see that in April, scrap prices are  continuing moving upwards, and this long trend of increased scrap prices from basically beginning of Q4 and up  until today, it's actually quite unusual. Typically when the spring season comes, it's easy to collect scrap, prices  usually moves down, but we have not seen that, so far, this year. And the main and the logical reason for that is  that EAF steel producer just like us are running at high capacity utilization then increasing demand for scrap.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: I would like to end with this picture talking a bit about our Project HYBRIT. The way we try to figure out how to  produce steel without carbon dioxide. We close the prefeasibility study in Q1 2018 and we have found nothing in  that prefeasibility study that makes us believe that this is not possible. I would say quite the opposite.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: So we have decided to start to build a pilot plant together with LKAB and Vattenfall in a joint venture. We will have  the first groundbreaking – the groundbreaking ceremony during the summer and we will build this during – take 1  1/2 year and then we will start to do bigger trials and then we are planning to build the production plant or  demonstration plan from 2025.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: So, so far, so good, and we have also in laboratories and in tests produced the first steel according to this  method. And we will now, as said, start to build the shaft, the hydrogen generation and also the hydrogen storage  in a pilot scale up in Luleå and Norrbotten.

file: SSAB.A - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 25April2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Americas, 23% EBITDA margin in the steel industry. I think that's good. I think it's very good I think solid  performance. We had slightly lower shipments and the reason for that was that we had severe weather in  Midwest in Montpelier where we have one of our facilities for a bit more than a week. We had more winter storms  more than minus 50 degrees Celsius, some problems to get trucks and trains, and so on. So that's why shipments  came down compared to Q1 2018. But apart from that, a very good performance, and we are the market leader in  heavy plate in North America, but they are also clearly the cost leader. They are the most cost efficient plate  producer in North America, and that's why we see these kind of margins when the market are strong.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Then we have higher variable COGS. Raw material is the main part but on top of that we also have higher  maintenance costs partly driven down by the standstill in Raahe. That also implies that we have to ship slabs from  Luleå or from Oxelösund to Raahe and then we get high transport costs as well. Fixed cost is somewhat higher  than Q1 last year, SEK 270 million. We had higher maintenance cost in this quarter. We have an overall salary  increase year-over-year and also when we are running production and result as we are in Americas, their salary is  – we call it fixed cost, but their salaries is actually to a large portion variable depending on the performance. So  we're paying out higher salaries in Americas given those results.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: When we have to lower volumes in Europe, given the Raahe incident, we obviously cut the lowest priced volume  first, which means that we actually had a fairly decent price development in Europe. Volumes better than Q4, and  in Q4, we had maintenance outage in all three steel divisions. And this is mainly coming from Special Steels from  Europe. Variable COGS is, well it's almost zero, but it's somewhat positive. Despite the raw material increases,  but in Q4 with the maintenance outage, we started up the second blast furnace in Oxelösund. We had a lot of  different small variable COGS that added up. So despite raw material increase, we actually basically are net  them, compared to Q4.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Finally from me on the raw materials side and starting with iron ore and coking coal, we have seen these prices  continue to increase and especially iron ore have increased quite a lot during Q1. If we look at our purchase  prices, they have increased with 50% in Swedish krona and they increased at 14% in dollars. And iron ore, partly  or maybe even mainly because of the wall accident during Q1, iron ore prices have really spiked during this  quarter.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: We have also seen coking coal prices increase, not as much but they have increased with 8% of our purchase  prices during Q1. And as Martin said, in Luleå, we basically don't have any iron ore inventory. We get transport by  train from LKAB on a daily basis. So, there we have already started to see the impact of these higher costs in the  P&L. The other Nordic operations and including the coking coal, the higher raw material impact will mainly hit the  P&L now during the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: For our U.S. operation and for scrap, the situation actually looks quite different. Over time, iron ore and scrap  typically follow each other but they have not done so far now. Our purchase prices were relatively stable during  the quarter or they were 3% lower than in Q4. And we have actually also seen in April that scrap prices have went  somewhat downwards in April, which will obviously then impact our performance during the second quarter.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Construction Machinery, slightly lower momentum but at a very high level. Material Handling, we see continued  high activity within mining in several regions, and it's both investments and maintenance. Energy, solid demand in  wind energy in U.S. We see also high activity in U.S. oil and gas sectors. So, overall, in these segments, strong or  healthy demand in Q2. Construction, yes, good underlying demand but some hesitation especially in residential  building in Scandinavia or the Nordic region. And then as always, the Steel Service Centers, they are in a wait  and see mood. On the other hand, month on hand for Steel Service Centers are not at any high level. So,  eventually, they need to start to buy. But we call it healthy underlying demand, but there's always some swings in  the apparent consumption.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Prices in Q2 somewhat lower for Europe and the Americas and stable for Special Steels and Håkan pointed out,  we will see higher raw material costs especially for iron ore that will be visible in SSAB Europe and in Special  Steels, and that in the beginning of the quarter, slightly lower scrap prices in North America.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Another important project is the HYBRIT project that is moving on. And as you all know, this is our project to  produce steel without carbon dioxide. And here you can see a recently taken picture up from Luleå

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: and you can see the ice still on the Baltic Sea. But we are now in the phase of erecting the pilot plant. The pilot  plant will be ready and start to produce summer next year, be altogether with Vattenfall and LKAB investing in this  pilot plant SEK 1.4 billion out of that, the Swedish Energy Agency contribute with SEK 530 million, but the rest of it  is a split between the three owners of HYBRIT.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: And this is of course an important project for us in order to be fossil free as a company at the latest 2045. And the  next, call it, big event, will be in Oxelösund when with the 1st of January 2026, we'll have changed the whole  system into a fossil-free production plant and will be compared to today. And we will take away a lot of the carbon  dioxide emissions that we emit currently. So this is a very important project and it's running according to plan. And  if anything, we try to speed it up even more.

file: SSAB.A - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 22July2011 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Erik Martin Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Business Area EMEA, SSAB AB
texts.text: Energy is also an important segment for us, for our standard plates in North America especially. And the outlook  for North American line pipe plate demand is very positive. And the expectation this year is that U.S. wind power  installations will exceed the volumes we saw last year. Another important taker of our standard plates in North  America is of course the North American service centers, and they have increased their sales during Q2. And  during the end of June or Q2, the inventories in the North American service center system amounted to roughly  2.7 months of supply, which is somewhat lower than normal given the season.

texts.speaker: Erik Martin Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Business Area EMEA, SSAB AB
texts.text: Take a look at the macroeconomics or the environment and outlook. According to World Steel Association, the  global crude steel production increased with 8% during the first six months of this year and amounted to almost  760 million tons. And following a healthy April and May, demand growth slowed a bit in June in Europe, and that  was due to uncertainties regarding the macroeconomic situation in combination with the seasonal decline that we  see every year. During the latter part, spot prices of strip steel of Q2 – spot prices of strip steel fell and plate prices  held up better but started to weaken a bit or somewhat in the U.S. and China by the end of the period. But it's clear  for us that the recovery continues and the demand for 2011 is expected to be higher compared to 2010.

texts.speaker: Marco Wiren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: A couple of words by raw materials; as Martin mentioned, we have signed a price agreement now with LKAB and  the prices for Q2 and Q3 were settled giving a price increase of 19%. But due to the exchange rates, the difference  is only 8% in Swedish kroner, although 8% is a bit high as well according to me. Coal agreement during this  second quarter, as you know, we have monthly agreements nowadays; compare that to Q1, the prices increased  57% in U.S. dollars, which is 26% in SEK.

texts.speaker: Marco Wiren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: And as we mentioned before, the purchase of coal is partly coming from Australia and partly from the United  States and it's part 60/40 allocation and 40% is coming from the U.S. and that's annual contract. And the annual  contract was signed before this quarter but the prices increased by 36%, which is about 10% in Swedish kroner. As  scrap prices have been up and down a little bit, no major -- on that during the first half-year actually and they're  about the same level now as they in the beginning of the year. In our American mini mills, we purchased scrap  continuously off a spot market.

texts.speaker: Erik Martin Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Business Area EMEA, SSAB AB
texts.text: As said, we have recently seen ordinary steel prices coming a bit under pressure and we have seen higher prices on  iron ore and coking coal, and that will affect the P&L during Q3 and we will see the full effect during Q4. But  overall, steel demand is expected to increase in 2011 compared to 2010 and the recovery continues.

texts.speaker: Erik Martin Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Business Area EMEA, SSAB AB
texts.text: Last but not least, I would like to share with you two different ways of using Hardox material. The first one is a  more traditional way, as we have seen a couple of times before. This is a Finnish container company called  Ferreus. They have yet to become a certified member of SSAB's Hardox In My Body family. They have together  with us developed a new container where they were able to reduce the weight of the container with 1 ton, and that  is approximately 25% in weight. They've also been able, with this new construction, to increase the lifetimes of the  container with 3 times. The container is much cheaper to maintain due to less weldings and less reinforcements  and also cheaper to produce. So this is a typical example, but the payback time for the container owner or the  container user is very, very short to invest in these kind of containers, including Hardox.

texts.speaker: Erik Martin Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Business Area EMEA, SSAB AB
texts.text: A more odd way of using Hardox is done by the architecture firm, Rainer+Amann. They were assigned to solve a  problem of high noise levels at a restaurant in Austria. So, they thought about the problem and then they used cut- offs some of our customers of Hardox and constructed a wall, a sound-absorbing wall, but they rather call it a  piece of art, that took care of the problem. And I actually read a quote from the chief architect from that firm and  he said that, he hoped that – he said it was a fantastic, rough and tough material, and he hoped that somewhere in  the future he would able to make a sculpture out of Hardox. So, that is a different way of using our products, and  as said, the first example is maybe a more common example.

file: SSAB.A - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 26July2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Mining still also positive, Australian Mining remains strong, Indonesia is an important market for us, is also  positive. The only slowdown we've seen in the market – mining market so far is mainly within energy coal mining  in North America, where we've seen the miners being less busy and producing less quantities. Energy, line pipe  inquiries have slowed down a bit in both U.S. and Mexico, and the wind tower demand is also slowing down. And  as you know the expectations are that the tax credits will expire during this year. So it's expected to slow down  even further in 2013 if they don't take a new decision regarding tax credits.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: The gas pipe damage we had, or breakdown, we had in Oxelösund affected us. It took away 10,000 tonnes of Q&T  during the quarter. Some of it was expected to be delivered during Q2, [ph] but the bigger part (6:41) during Q3.  customers on the global markets. So we are now selling Hardox material and we will during this year, introduce  higher grades of Domex and then after that also higher grades of Weldox from that quenching line. And as said,  the efficiency and flexibility program within EMEA runs according to plan and we have during the second quarter,  started to see some effects out of that.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: To say something about the market environment and our outlook, global steel production increased by 1% during  the first six months, compared to last year and U.S. steel production increased – with 8%. We saw also increased  import of steel to U.S. during the first six months of the year.

texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: When it comes to coal we buy about 60% of coal needs from Australia, that's on monthly contracts. And during the  winter, we don't buy coal. So the purchase we've done in late Q2 entitles prices about 30% down in U.S. dollars  compared to the purchase we've done in the fall; that's about 25% in Swedish krona. And the same goes for the  United States, where we actually buy on annual contracts, and that's about 40% of our needs. And scrap, we buy  continuously and you have seen perhaps also that prices have declined during the first half year and especially in  the second quarter, and are now 20% – 24% lower than in the end of last year.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: As said, we have signed new annual iron ore agreement, a yearly contract with [ph] a corridor (16:54) where we  have the possibility and LKAB has the possibility to renegotiate that contract. Volumes in Q3 will as normal, be  weaker demand for standard steels. The efficiency and flexibility program in – within SSAB EMEA proceeds  according to plan and we've started during Q2 to see the effects of that program.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: As said, we had a healthy cash generation the last quarter and the last couple of quarter-to-quarter and the  ambition is to continue with a healthy cash generation going forward. The work to increase operational flexibility  to reduce the breakeven point continues according to plan. And in general, steel producers are cutting back  production, we see that in Europe, but we also see that for the first time being done in China. We have not seen  that before producers taking away or idling capacity.

file: SSAB.A - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 19July2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: In the annual contract, steel prices for us were stable to slightly lower compared to Q1. We also saw the positive  effect from the efficiency in cost cutting program in EMEA. We were able to reduce our costs according to plan,  fixed and variable costs with approximately SEK 200 million compared to the year before during the quarter, and  we will see, as said before, the full year effect of that from 2014.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Energy continues to be fairly okay on fairly okay levels. We see now in the markets several line pipe inquiries  ongoing. Wind towers is picking up from very low levels and transmission towers are fairly s tronger market in  North America.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Market environment and outlook, World Steel Association just yesterday released the figures for the first six  months. The global steel production increased with 2% and the Chinese steel production increased with 7 %. The  reduction in Europe was 5%, and the reduction of the steel production in U.S. was 6%. When we look at the supply  chain, not only in service center but the full supply chain, we feel that the  inventories are at balanced levels or  slightly below normal levels, given the volumes and the sales. And we don't expect any major re - or de-stocking in  Q3.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB
texts.text: On the positive side, we had a good impact from the variable COGS. This is to a large extent but definitely not  exclusively due to raw material and we had positive impact from iron ore and from coking coal but also from  scrap.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB
texts.text: For coking coal, we had during the quarter, lower prices with approximately 4% compared to Q1. And finally, for  scrap in the U.S., which we obviously use for our U.S. mills, the prices at the end of the second quarter were  approximately 10% lower than at the end of the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: In Q3, we will have the effect of the planned outage or the moved outage in Mob ile, and we will have usual outages  in the Swedish production system. And the efficiency program will continue to deliver expected results for the  coming quarter. And as said, the full year effect will be seen 2014 compared to previous years.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: If we take a look at the market environment, World Steel Association estimated that the production of steel during  the first six months of this year increased by 3%. They increased in EU28 was 4%; North America, 2%; and China,  3%.

texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB

In total negative downward SEK 7 6 million, which brings us to the SEK 260  million.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB
texts.text: When we look then at the year-over-year, the chart looks a bit different. We have a slight improvement in prices.  And here, we have a big improvement in the U.S. in prices offset by a negative development in Europe. We have a  positive development on volumes of SEK 7 0 million driven by the North American business. And also here, we  have a big positive item on the variable COGS for the same reason then as – between the Q1 and Q2.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB
texts.text: Finally then on the raw material prices. During the second quarter, we signed a new contract with LKAB. It's a  yearly contract but with a quarterly price component. And we normally say that, roughly, it takes one  quarter for the iron ore that we buy to hit the P&L, so you can say that what we bought now in Q2, you will see in  the P&L in Q3.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB

And if we look back one year and compare to end of  Q2 last year, they were basically on the same level as last year.

file: SSAB.A - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 22July2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Andreas Koch
texts.profession: Director-Investor Relations
texts.text: Okay. Good morning. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to the SSAB's Q2 Results Presentation here at  Stockholm. And my name is Andreas Koch, Head of Investor Relations. The agenda for today look like this. Martin  Lindqvist, CEO, will start with a walk through of the main event for the group and also for the divisions. Håkan  Folin, CFO, will then talk more about the cash flow statement, the P&L and the balance sheet. After that, Martin  will give the outlook and also give some information about our updated sustainability targets, and finally, we'll  have the Q&A.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Saying a few words about the key segment development during the second quarter. Heavy Transport remained at  high level, both in Europe and in U.S. And Automotive has also continued healthy demand during the quarter.  Construction Machinery, fairly stable on very low levels, and we have not seen any improvement in the U.S market  yet for Construction Machinery and the Chinese market remains depressed. Mining, no visible improvement  during second quarter. And Energy continued good demand for wind towers, and the only change during the  quarter was a slight pickup or slightly better demand for pipelines in North America.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: We have slightly higher unabsorption which is due to not running the blast furnace [ph] Luleå (09:51) for one  month. And then we had no impact of FX, and very limited on other. So all-in-all, between Q2 and Q1, it's very  much about the lower prices which are partly compensating them by higher volumes and lower variable COGS.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: If we look then at Q2 last year compared to Q2 this year, we can see that the price element is even lower here, and  Q2 last year, we had SEK 389 million in EBIT. But since then, we have experienced a change in prices of over SEK  1 billion. This has been compensated for by higher volumes or rather better volumes, significantly lower variable  COGS, which is partly raw material. But here, you have the full synergy effect of not only variable COGS, but large  portion in variable COGS, and also other efficiency improvements.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Moving then to raw material, we have seen a decline in iron ore and in coking coal. And during Q2, we saw that  this decline stabilized, and was not changing so much. And then, once we thought, the iron ore stabilized, we saw  a huge drop then in the beginning of Q3, and iron ore is now below $50 per tonne.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: For coking coal, our average price during Q2 was 13% lower than Q1, both in U.S. dollar and also in SEK. If we  move then to scrap, scrap prices are at the low level, but if we compare them with iron ore, they are still fairly  expensive. In the U.S., we saw the spot market prices during Q2, the end of the quarter, 8% higher than at the end  of Q1. But then as you can see in the beginning of Q3, they have gone down, and the expectation is now that they  will either stay on this level or might even decrease slightly further.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: If we compare to Q2 – end of Q2 this year to last year, we can see that there has been a significant drop of 24%.  However, if we compare the scrap and iron ore development over time, we can see – we have chosen now to index  this from the beginning of 2012, and you can see that up until the start of 2014, basically here, there was a fairly  strong correlation between iron ore and scrap. But since then, iron ore prices have continued to drop, but scrap  has not dropped in the same way as the iron ore prices. And this implies then that, for scrap-based manufacturers,  at the moment, they have a disadvantage compared to integrated players.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: In Q2, the net impact was between SEK 60 million to SEK 80 million. And in Q3, we expect it to be between SEK  100 million and SEK 120 million. And as Martin mentioned before, as he said, Europe is negatively impacted by  this, both through the higher under-absorption, by not running the blast furnace, which on the other hand, Special  Steels in Oxelösund gets a positive development since they are now running two blast furnaces.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: But Europe is also impacted by a higher, more expensive slabs. The blast furnace in Luleå is the most efficient one  we have. And we're now rolling, balling and using more slabs from Oxelösund instead, they come at a higher cost  then for Europe. So let's say, negative impact for Europe, slightly compensated in Special Steel. Okay. Back to you,  Martin.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Automotive is expected to stay on a continued good level. And Construction Machinery, fairly stable compared to  Q2 and Q3 as well. Mining, we don't expect any improvement there either during Q3. And Energy, we expect  continued solid demand from wind towers. And there is, of course, continued uncertainty when it comes to oil- related pipeline investments.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We've also during the second quarter, revisited our sustainability strategy, and come up with new targets. We have  said that, by the end of 2019, we will achieve a lasting reduction when it comes to carbon dioxide emissions of  200,000 tonnes per year from a very good level. As you know, we are the most CO2-efficient producer in Europe  and by that probably also in the world.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We will also have a lasting reduction of purchased energy with 300 gigawatt-hours, and we will increase recycling  from very good levels. So we will reduce the amount of landfill with 30,000 tonnes per year. And of course, we are  in an industry that are emitting carbon dioxide. But I think even though we are the most carbon-dioxide effective  producer in Europe at least, and probably, I said, in the world, our biggest contribution in that area is the products  we produce, and how they are used.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And this is one example. If you would replace 1 million tonnes of standard steel in a vehicle, we could actually,  during that lifetime of the vehicle, reduce the carbon dioxide emissions with 8.4 million tonnes. And if we do that  1 million tonne per year, this is almost as much reduction of carbon dioxide as we emit ourselves, because we emit  in our production system 9.5 million tonnes roughly every year.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So this is apart from being or on top of being a very carbon-dioxide effective producer. This is, as I see it, the  biggest contribution to reduce emissions by using our products, our knowledge in applications on vehicles.

file: SSAB.A - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 20July2018 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: This is a new chassis for a dumper trailer. We have, together with a customer, developed a new design with Z- formed beams instead of traditional beams, and we have with a new design and with advanced high-strength  steels been able to reduce the weight of the chassis with 30%.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: And that gives, of course, a possibility for greater payload. It gives more on-road stability. It gives also significant  reduction in fuel consumption and tire consumption. And if you – as in this case – on top of that chassis, put a  developed U-box-shaped dumper body, you can reduce the weight of the whole trailer with more than 30%, and  that, of course, gives also extra payload and a lot of less fuel consumption. So, this is one example, and this is  also a good description how we work with customers, when we help them to develop their applications into more  modern design and more modern materials.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Volumes, slightly higher than Q2 last year, and this was Americas and Special Steel, actually slightly lower in  SSAB. But then we had quite a large negative impact, SEK 855 million from variable COGS, and this is almost  exclusively raw material cost, and it's the large items, iron ore, coking coal, scrap. But it's alloys or at the higher  level refractories electrodes. So, all in all, that has a negative impact of SEK 850 (sic) [855] (00:10:47) million.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: We had a positive impact from FX, SEK 195 million compared to last year. It's given – it's due to that we have a  much weaker Swedish krona now. So, when we sell in – especially in Europe but also partly in U.S. dollar, and  then we collect that back we get the higher results in Swedish krona. But all in all, had some improvement of SEK  425 million, and it's very much coming from that we get the margin improvement, given that we have better price  increases than the variable COGS increases, which is partly driven by that we have a better mix as well.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Variable COGS, slightly negative, SEK 285 million. It's raw material again, and I would say it's especially the iron  ore prices where spot prices increased during Q1 and we get the P&L impact of that during the second quarter.  And we also have a negative impact of fixed cost, SEK 195 million, which is partly temporary when we are hiring  more summer temps in order to fill in during the vacation period in Sweden or Finland. As usual, in Q3 we will see  lower fixed cost given the seasonality that we have.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Finally, from me on the raw material side, for iron ore and coking coal, the purchase prices were fairly stable  during Q2. For pellets, they were 2% higher in Swedish krona, but actually minus 5% in U.S. dollar. For coking  coal, they were flat in Swedish krona and minus 6% in U.S. dollar. So, no big drama on the purchase price side.  For iron ore, it's actually been – the spot market have been unusually stable during Q2 and actually so far into Q3  as well at slightly below $65 per tonne. What we have also done in the quarter is that we have signed a new  agreement with LKAB, so from April 1 this year up until end of March next year. And the structure is similar to  what we've had before, so which basically mean that it will follow the spot market prices over time.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: The biggest event or the most important event during the second quarter was the groundbreaking ceremony of  our HYBRIT project. And HYBRIT is a new way of producing steel without any carbon dioxide emissions. We  have a joint venture together with two partners, LKAB and Vattenfall. And we have decided to invest SEK 1.4  billion in a pilot plant up in Luleå for this. We have, as part of the financing, got SEK 528 million from the Swedish  Energy Agency in financial support, and we are now starting to build this pilot plant. It will be up and running 2020  and then we will start to do trials, and then we are planning to build a demonstration plant which is really a full- scale production plant.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: And the reason why we do this that during the pre-study and everything, we have learned we are getting more  and more convinced that this is actually possible to produce the steel without any carbon dioxide emissions. So,  the only emissions that will come out of this process is pure water. And if we are successful with this, we will be  able to take away 10% of the Swedish carbon dioxide emissions and more than 10% of the Finnish carbon  dioxide emissions. But we will also be able to sit on a lot of valuable IP for a completely new way of producing  steel. So, that was according to me, at least, and according to SSAB the most important event during the second  quarter. So, from now up until 2020, we will be doing construction on this plant, and it will be up and running 2020.
