texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Energy, wind power has slowed down or actually stopped in North America due to the end of production tax  credits in 2012. That market will not go away, but it will be lower if they don't extend those tax credits, and I guess  there have been some pre-fabrication to utilize these tax credits. But there will be also wind towers produced next  year regardless of tax credits, but it's definitely on a lower level compared to having tax credits. On the other hand,  the line pipe demand is still decent both in U.S., in Canada, and especially in Mexico.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: So if we take a look at the market environment and the outlook, World Steel Association released a new demand  forecast two weeks ago during the annual meeting in New Delhi and they have revised it down, the steel  consumption, and they now expect an increase of 2.1% in 2012, compared to 2011. We have also revised down the  consumption this year in Europe and China and North America.

texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: I think I'll jump immediately to this slide. You can see that last year, we had plus-SEK511 million EBIT. And now,  it's minus-SEK665 million. And the major items that has affected the result is, of course, prices. We're seeing a  slowdown in the market in general and the prices have gone down, both in Europe, but also quite heavily in North  America due to the scrap prices has declined and as the scrap prices and steel prices follow each other quite  closely on the standard products.

texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Coal, we buy on a monthly basis from Australia and annual based from United States. And those monthly prices  that we purchased in Q3 were about 10% lower than quarter-before. And the coal prices – the annual price for  U.S. coal is about 30% lower than the previous annual contract.

texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: And that's all I had. Back to you, Martin.  Martin Erik Lindqvist  President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB  Thank you. So looking forward then, we don't expect any major changes in demand for Q4 compared to what we  see right now or what we saw in Q3. We expect, as said, prices for quenched steels being fairly stable going  forward. We expect the continued pressure on prices for standard steel, given the direction raw material has  taken. And as Marco said, the impact from lower iron ore cost of about SEK200 million will affect the earnings in  Q1 2013. And the efficiency program plans according to plan and what we are doing is, as you know, the efficiency  program and cost reduction program is to – with the target to breakeven at 70% capacity utilization in our  Swedish operations.

texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: That's the last picture. This is the nominees to the Swedish Steel Prize 2012. And if you want – and these are  typical projects that we have done together with our customers. You've seen high-strength steel or quenched and  tempered heavy plates. We will have the announcement of the winner within a couple of weeks here in Stockholm,  and we have about 400 customers globally attending that meeting. So this is one important way for us to promote  the usage of advanced high-strength steel globally.

file: SSAB.A - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 25October2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: If we take a look at the segments and this is sequential Q3 over Q2, I would say no big differences with a few  exceptions. Heavy transport, heavy equipment demand has been weak due to uncertainty in the business climate.  On the other hand, heavy equipment in U.S. booked at slightly improved levels in Q3 compared to Q2.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: And in mining, we saw a continued slowdown during Q3, compared to Q2. Energy, during Q3, a fairly okay  segment with tank cars, pressure vessels, pipelines and wind towers. Service centers continued to buy what they  need and only what they need during Q3 and inventory levels of service centers on low levels. During the  sequential outlook for Q4, I would say that we see some bright spots in these, some of the segments compared to  Q3.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: There is currently, a positive momentum in the market. We expect the plates or the steel consumption and the  plate consumption to continue upwards according to the market or the general development. We introduced the  price increase last week of $30 per tonne. And we have, effective from today, introduced another price increase for  all new orders of $20 per tonne effective from today. The reason why we do that is that we have a strong order  book and a good order intake. And we will continue to, as a market leader, increase the margin over scrap and  help the market to do that.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: We offset this by higher volumes and better utilization rate in the mill, which means lower under absorption cost,  better variable COGS, which is both due to raw material prices, but also due to the efficiencies we have done in  terms of production.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Finally, I will mention some about the trends in our raw material prices. We mentioned in our report last quarter  that we have signed a new agreement with LKAB ranging from 1st of April this year to end of March last year and  where the prices are set on a quarterly basis. For Q3, our iron ore prices increased with 6% versus Q2.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: And as we have said before, there is roughly one quarter lag from when we buy the iron ore until we see it in our  P&L. So this will be seen then in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: On the other hand, our price for coking coal decreased with approximately 11% during this quarter compared to  last quarter. And then finally, our U.S. scrap buy, the scrap has been fairly volatile during the quarter, but ended  up in the third quarter 2% higher than it was in the end – sorry, in the beginning of the quarter.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Thank you, Håkan. So what we do see then? We expect steel demand in Europe to be fairly stable in Q4. Of course,  as always, if the momentum trends upwards into Q1, we will see better apparent consumption at the end of the  quarter and if the trend is downwards, we will, of course, see lower apparent consumption. But the underlying  demand is expected or we expect to be fairly stable.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: We expect the Asian steel consumption to continue to grow and in North America steel demand will increase in  line with the economic recovery. As said, we have, together with other producers, recently announced price  increases and as said, we have from today announced another price increase for the North American plate market.

file: SSAB.A - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 22October2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: One and a half week ago, I was at the World Steel Association meeting in Chicago and it was an interesting  meeting and most of you have probably read the short-term outlook. And as you know, they downgraded the  outlook for 2015 and they also downgraded slightly the outlook for 2016. So there will be in 2015 a small increase  of apparent steel demand in Europe and a reduced apparent steel demand in North America and China had a big  decrease of steel consumptions.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Markets, I would say, as expected with one exception. Heavy Transport and Automotive, stable on high levels.  Construction Machinery and Mining stable on very low levels. Energy is kind of rough in North America divided  market, everything that is oil related is slow. But wind tower is one example where we see very good demand.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Of course, they are benefited from not having a summer outage this summer and also running the small blast  furnace in Oxelösund the full third quarter. That is now closed. We closed it in beginning of October. But during  Q3, due to the relining in Luleå they were running the small blast furnace.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And now, as said, the blast furnace is relined and up in running. We lost two and a half weeks for – it's already  explained the reasons, but now it's delivering according to plan. We managed to do it cost wise within budget. And  now – this is important because this was – now gave us the opportunity to that flexibility which was a key part of  combining SSAB and Ruukki. So now we have the blast furnace fleet that – where we can flex and produce in a  much more cost effective way, we'd almost like to say, regardless of market situation, and that can be done now  since end of September.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Americas, as said, mainly prices explaining the drop and not compensated at all fully or at all by lower raw  material prices. What has happened in the beginning of Q4 or in October is that scrap prices has come down  additionally $50 to $60 per tonne. And what we have suffered from is non-existing correlation between scrap and  iron ore. And now since beginning of October that correlation is back to where it has been all the time. So scrap  prices for the October buy is down between $50 and $60 per tonne.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: During Q3, they have also invested in coal injection in Raahe and I would say that, that is mainly or partly due to  environmental reasons and partly due to cost reasons. Now that is up and running, so we will go from oil  injections to the coal injection. We will have a much better, call it carbon dioxide effectiveness in the blast  furnaces. As I said before, our blast furnace system in Luleå is the most carbon dioxide effective system in the  world, and now, after this we will be on par with Luleå in Raahe as well. But on top of that, going from oil injection  to coal injection will, at current oil prices as we have today save us on yearly basis another SEK 200 million  compared to where we stand today.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So when we sum this up – and I take the starting point, September 1, when we got the new organization in place  and the two companies together, we will with these actions reduce the yearly costs – run rate mid-next year of the  SEK 2 billion with these three areas; synergies, Ruukki Construction, and coal injection in Raahe.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Then we have a big positive impact of COGS, variable COGS and also fixed cost. It's coming from lower raw  material cost. It's coming from more synergies realized and it's also – or fixed cost is coming from a – between Q3  and Q2, [ph] regularization (12:57) impact, when you have the summer [ph] vacation (12:59) reserves they sold in  the Nordic regions.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Some word on the cash flow development, where I've said we had a negative operating cash flow in the quarter,  very much impacted by high maintenance expenditures, which out of the SEK 600 million, approximately SEK  300 million were for the Luleå relining. If we look at it where we are year-to-date, we have the net cash flow down  of more than SEK 800 million positively and that's I would say despite high level of maintenance CapEx, but also  we have fairly high strategic CapEx this year, which is the largest single item here is this PCI coal injection that  Martin mentioned before. But , all in all, still after three quarters net cash flow positive SEK 800 million.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Moving then to raw material, and starting with iron ore and coking coal, the prices were fairly stable during Q3,  both for iron ore and coking coal, they dropped slightly in July, but since then been fairly stable actually. Iron ore  now at around [ph] $65 (18:11) per tonne, coking coal at around $80 per tonne somewhat.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: For us, our prices for iron ore was down 1% in Q3, what we were buying, compared to Q2, both in U.S. dollar and  SEK. And what we also did in Q3 is that we signed a price agreement with Severstal for continued deliveries, and  these deliveries will be both to Raahe and but also to Oxelösund. Given the logistical setup we have with  [indiscernible] (18:41) Luleå, we will not use the Severstal pellets in Luleå. For coking coal, prices were down a  little bit more, they were down with 8% in U.S. dollar and 5% in Swedish kroner. So all-in-all, both iron ore and  coking coal, slightly down, not as dramatic as we've seen before, but still somewhat on the downward trend.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: If we move to scrap then, the situation is quite different actually, where we saw sharp price declines during Q3,  and these have also continued now into Q4. The spot prices, and we buy scrap for our use operations in the spot  market, they were down 30% in Q3 versus the beginning of Q3, and when you compare year-over-year, they were  down as much as 46%. And as you can see here on the chart, they have continued going down somewhat in  October. And that brings us to the correlation between iron ore that not been talked about before, where we have  been suffering and we've been a bit frustrated in our North American operations that scrap hasn't followed iron  ore, which it has done historically.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: If we look at this chart, it's an index starting in the beginning of 2012, and for two years, you can see that iron ore  being the black one and scrap being the grey one, they were basically following each other. But then here  something happened in the beginning of 2014, where iron ore went down shortly, but scrap did not really follow.  But what we see now in beginning of October, it has actually converged again, the scrap prices and the iron ore  prices.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: If you look at the segments, I would say no big changes from Q3. We expect Heavy Transport and Automotive to  be stable on high levels and Construction Machinery and Mining to be stable on very low levels. We expect to see  the same pattern in the Energy segment as well. Construction Material will typically go down seasonally in Q4,  and we don't expect any major changes in Steel Service Centers either. The destocking will come to an end. Yes.  When? I don't really know. I was pretty sure last time, I don't give you any prognosis of that this time, because  then I run the risk to be wrong once again and I really don't like that.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: My last picture is about Swedish Steel Prize 2015 and these are the finalists. Facil System from Brazil, TEREX  Cranes from Germany, Ponsse from Finland and the Milotek from South Africa. And what they have in common is  that they are using advanced high strength of steels, either to increase productivity or to reduce weight or to  reduce – or increase payload or reduce fuel consumption or energy consumptions.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: I think these are very good examples on how you can utilize advanced high strength steels and in lot of these cases,  also you see fairly big environmental benefits. And I think that is also important and it was discussed also during  the meeting in Chicago with World Steel Association, the increasing importance of doing the right things  environmentally.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So, this I think is probably the most, the best contribution we do when it comes to reduce emissions and reduce  fuel consumptions and so on, on top of being the most carbon dioxide effective producer of steel in the world. But  by these customers and other customers using our products and reducing weight and reducing emissions and  increasing payloads and typically doubling life lines, I think this is the real contribution that SSAB can do in that  aspect.

file: SSAB.A - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 28October2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: No major change on variable COGS. On fixed cost, we see Q3 versus Q2 a very positive development of SEK  380 million. Here, I think it's important to point out that around SEK 300 million of those SEK 300 million (sic)  [SEK 380 million] (09:45) is coming during Q3 because we are dissolving vacation reserves. So, that's a typical  Q3 effect which we did not have in Q4 and we will not have in – or sorry, we did not have in Q2 and we will not  have in Q4 either.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Finally, on other here, it's also here, it's the underabsorption that's playing a big role. Last year, we were not  running the Luleå blast furnace during the whole third quarter when we had the relining. And this year, we've been  running it. And that's a large portion of this SEK 193 million.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Moving then into the raw material, and of course, the big item is the coking coal development. Coking coal prices  during Q3 really spiked and took off in a way I don't believe anyone had foreseen. And this one ends here at the  end of Q3, but actually even after Q3, we have seen additional increases on the coking coal side. For us, this is  the purchase price for us, not the consumption price. But the purchase price for us during Q3 was 25% higher in  U.S. dollar versus Q2, and 34% higher in SEK.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: The main impact of this coking coal increases will come from Q1 and onwards, but we will already in Q4 start  seeing the impact of the higher coking coal in our P&L, especially for the Special Steel division. For Europe, we  build up winter stocks up in Luleå and up in Raahe because the big boats cannot go there when there is ice. So,  there it will come more in Q1. But for Special Steel, we'll start seeing it already in Q4.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: On iron ore, well, it hasn't been very dramatic. It's slightly up versus Q2, but not at all in the magnitude of how we  see coking coal develop.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Then for scrap, which is obviously what we use in our U.S. operation, well, the scrap price has been moving  down. During the quarter, they're down 17%, in the end of the quarter versus the beginning. They're still actually  slightly higher than what they were one year ago. But I think this is quite interesting because iron ore being flat,  scrap slightly moving down, and coking coal then going like this, it means for us as a scrap-based plate producer  in the U.S., we will definitely compared to the integrated players have a competitive advantage.

file: SSAB.A - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 25October2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Ruukki Construction, decent market, good sales. We have not been able to fully compensate for increased steel  prices in our selling prices. So, a bit of a margin squeeze in Ruukki Construction. But I would say, all in all, a fairly  decent quarter.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: We saw spot – plate prices decreasing. During the quarter, we saw scrap prices going up and down, fading off a  bit and decreased at the end of the quarter. So, no dramatic changes compared to previous quarter, a bit more  wait-and-see maybe in U.S.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Americas shipments, 21% higher than Q3 2016. So, good demand in the Energy segment, but as I said, wait-and- see from Steel Service Centers in Q3.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: And then, Ruukki Construction where we typically see seasonally higher demand in Q3, and I would say that  demand is higher in most markets compared to previous year. This is what changes it a bit. We haven't been able  yet to fully compensate for higher steel prices in the Ruukki Construction business. But I would say also a decent  performance during the quarter.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Volume-wise, SEK 370 million positive impact. This is mainly coming from Special Steels with a good volume  increase, but also coming from Americas. Then, we get the negative impact on the variable COGS, SEK 840  million. And here, we actually saw higher cost for compared to last year iron ore, coking coal and scraps, all the  three main raw materials had a high cost this year.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Somewhat positive on the variable COGS side. We had lower costs for iron ore and coking coal, on the other  hand, mitigated by higher cost for scrap during the quarter. Then, we have a quite large positive impact from fixed  cost. And for those of you who have been around a few years, you know that every third quarter, we have a  seasonally positive impact, where in the Nordic operations and given that such a large portion of our employees  are in the Nordic, we have this [ph] dissolvement (00:10:57) of vacation reserves that typically happen in the third  quarter. So, when we look into fourth quarter, it's more likely that fixed cost will be more similar to the second  quarter than to what we see now in this third quarter.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: So, that's it on the balance sheet side, and I will now move into raw material. We could see in the quarter that our  purchase prices for iron ore and scrap went down quite a lot – sorry, iron ore and coking coal. If we start with  coking coal, they were down as much as 25%. In Swedish krona, 19% in U.S. dollar in Q3 versus Q2. I think it's  important to remember though that given that we have winter stocks for coking coal in Luleå and in Raahe, we do  the majority of our yearly purchases in Q3 and in Q2. And that means that what we consume and what will hit the  P&L in Q4 is more likely to be what we bought in Q2 than what we bought by now in Q3. Q3 buys will more  materialize later on in Q1 and Q2 next year.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: For iron ore, we also saw a decrease, not as much as for coking coal, but it was down 15%, our average  purchase prices in Swedish krona, but only 8% in U.S. dollar. And there we have a faster turnaround, so that's  more likely then to have an impact in Q4. We buy the majority of iron ore from LKAB. We also buy from Severstal.  And with LKAB, our contract is valid until end of March next year, but prices there are adjusted on a monthly  basis. So, we do see an impact also during the quarter when the spot prices fluctuate.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: What we can also see on this chart is that in October, scrap spot prices have decreased quite a lot actually in  Americas. They're down around €30 per tonne to €40 per tonne for the October buy. So, moving into outlook.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: My last picture, we posted new sustainability objectives today, I think. And, when I think about this, I mean, the  steel industry has always been regarded to be a big part of the [ph] program (00:18:50). In SSAB, we have felt  that with our products, the lightweighting, taking out weight, increasing life length, reducing fuel consumption,  helping customers to reduce emissions, we have seen ourselves as part of this solution.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: I think with these new objectives, where we state that we will be among others, fossil-free, completely fossil-free  2045. I think, we take another step in showing that we are not only part of the [ph] program (00:19:17), but we are  definitely part of the future solution. Of course, HYBRIT is one important part in this promise, but there are other  things as well where we need to continue to work with fuel-related emissions.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: We also have what we call sustainable offerings. We say at the latest 2025, we should help our customers to  reduce 10 million tonnes of carbon dioxide during the user phase of their application, and that is the equal to what  we emit today, emit roughly 10 million tonne of carbon dioxide, and that's a lot, of course. But, as you all know, we  are also the most carbon-dioxide-effective steel producer in the world.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: So, you could claim, and I'm not probably allowed to say that, but you could claim that, 2025, we should be  carbon neutral, and 2045, we should be completely fossil-free. We're also raising our ambitions in what – within  what we call responsible partners. So important for us to say in a clear statement for the future.

file: SSAB.A - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 26October2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: We had some production programs during Q3. We had the fire in Hämeenlinna end of Q2, that affected Q3. We  also had problems with the blast furnace down in Oxelösund, where the bricks were burn out too much earlier  than anyone could have guessed, which caused us production outage of two weeks. We had some other  production-related problems. We had problems with lightning in Borlänge, and so – but I will come back to that.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Construction Machinery, high levels both in Europe and U.S. Material Handling also quite okay. Energy, solid  demand from wind energy and higher activity or high activity in oil and gas in U.S.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Europe, good demand, underlying demand. EBIT down compared to Q3. We had higher prices and also higher  materials, but we suffered from these production disruptions that led to lower shipments. We had problems with a  new crane in Luleå that was installed in the [indiscernible] (00:08:01). We were not able to get that up and running  according to plans. We lost production up in Luleå. We had problem with a shear, a new shear in the continuous  annealing line, a very important bottleneck for us. We lost production there in Borlänge, and we had problems  with lightning strikes and so on, forest fires, during Q3, and possibilities to ship materials. So we lost volumes.  And I think the market is not worse than it were here. So we lost definitely some volumes in Europe and that  affected the result.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Slightly down on volumes, just like I explained last year, it varies between the divisions, but all in all, SEK 100  million negative impact for the group. And then on cost side, variable cost, almost SEK 1 billion negative impact.  And here, basically all the main raw material, iron ore, coking coal and scrap are up compared to last year. And  this impact is spread fairly evenly between the three steel divisions.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: So, I will not spend more time on this, but I will move into raw material side instead. For iron ore and for coking  coal in Q3, prices are very stable, I would say. However purchase prices were slightly lower on iron ore side, 3%,  6% in dollars. They were basically stable. On coking coal, slightly down in dollar, but really very much stable  development in Q3.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB

file: SSAB.A - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 10February2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Prices of standard steels were lower in Q4 compared to Q3 and prices for high strength steels were also somewhat  under pressure during the quarter. Included in the results for EMEA is a gain of SEK270 million from disposals of  emission rights. And the reason for that is, of course, that we have idled one of the blast furnaces in Oxelösund  since this summer. So, these are excess rights that we don't need or needed for our production.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: We had sales of almost SEK11 billion during the quarter and we had an EBITDA per ton of SEK600 and if we take  the average EBITDA per ton for 2011, it amounted to toughly SEK1,000 per ton. And that is compared to a lot of  other steel companies, a very good figure.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Energy is a very important segment for us in North America. We see that line pipe projects in both U.S. and  Mexico remains healthy. And we have secured quite a few interesting orders there as well. The wind tower  industry, as we expected, will be or will remain strong at least until the election this year or at least during the first  half of 2012. So that is also performing in a very good way.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: EMEA had sales of SEK5.8 billion during the fourth quarter with an EBIT of SEK248 million (sic) [minus SEK248  million] (05:27) and that is included the sales of the emission rights. Shipments were lower than Q4, 2010 and 9%  higher compared to Q3, 2011. And as you know in Q3, we had an extended summer stop for certain weak  investments at our Swedish sites.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: This is a picture of the new quenching line that we are commissioning right now during the first quarter in  Borlänge, with an initial capacity of 300,000 tons that is measured over bottleneck. So, the new installed capacity  in this quenching line is 3.5 million tons in the line itself. This will broaden our product offering.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: This is a picture of the new quenching line that is finished now and will be commissioned during early Q2 in  Mobile that will give us another 200,000 tons of quenching capacity. The line is able also – that line, to produce  Hardox and Weldox material measured from 4 millimeters up to 50 millimeters thick and up to 3.1 meter wide  that will further strengthen not only SSAB Americas but also SSAB's position within these areas.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Local prices for advanced high strength steel increased by 5% during the quarter, and were unchanged for  quenched steel during the quarter. We are right now up to speed commissioning the new finishing line in Kunshan  K2 and the new R&D center that will on top of the transportation terminal I showed you help us to reduce lead  times and, most importantly, increase service to our customers.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: If we take a look at the market environment and the outlook, global steel production increased in 2011 with 7%,  but we also see in Q4 that capacity utilization in the global steel industry came down and production decreased by  5% compared to the third quarter.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: The strongest segments for us remain material handling and the U.S. energy sector. And prices for hot-rolled coils  in Europe appear to have bottom-out and prices in the U.S. are expected to increase during the quarter. So,  Marco?

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Good morning. So, let's go to highlights first when it comes to Q4 figures. The net sales was about SEK10.9 billion  and that's an increase of 7% compared to same period a year ago. And as Martin mentioned in the operating profit  have had one of the blast furnaces is idled during the fall, so we had excess emission rights and that's why we  decided to sell those.

texts.speaker: Marco Wiren
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: FX impact and that's FX – if you take the rates that we had a year ago and compare that with rates we have this  year, so this is not a gain, it's a comparison between two periods. And in the others you see also the emission  rights.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: A couple of words about the raw materials. We've been negotiated iron ore with LKAB and due to fact that prices  went down on the spot market during Q4, so we're able to decrease our purchase prices for Q1, which means that  deliveries during Q1, but that will actually affect our P&L first in Q2 positively. So, prices went down 12% for Q1  purchases compared to Q4 purchases. And, going forward, we'll see – and we'll get back to you as well, if we can  have quarterly prices or something else.  When it comes to coal, we have – deliveries from America is on and annual basis, no change in there. The contract  is going to end in the end of March this year while purchase from Australia is on a monthly basis, so the prices in  Q4, when it comes to purchase prices compared to Q3 went down about 20%.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: SSAB have initiated an efficiency program within SSAB EMEA to lower the cost base by SEK800 million.

file: SSAB.A - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 8February2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Mining I would say, with a few exceptions, is the more stable business, both in Australia and China and in the  Nordic region. The exception is coal mining. And there is a possibility on the east coast in Australia that we could  see improved demand with higher coal prices.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Energy, we see continued activity and saw a continued activity within line pipe, an important segment for us. And  we have taken orders for deliveries during the first half of this year. texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Local prices decreased by 3% for niche steel and by 8% for standard steels versus Q3 2012. And we also sold  roughly 100,000 tons of slabs externally, which we typically do from time to time over the years.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: So the market environment and outlook. Global steel production according to World Steel Association fell with 2%  in Q4 versus Q3. Capacity utilization for the overall steel industry in Europe for Q4 was 67% but in December, it was below 60% for  the European steel industry in average. Demand affected by destocking and prolonged outages among customers  in December and early January was clearly felt by us as well and other steel companies.

texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: And then in the others, if you remember in 2011, the fourth quarter we also sold emission rights and the amount  was about SEK275 million. That gives the impact – the difference between these two quarters.

texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: A couple of words about the raw materials. As we mentioned last time as well, we signed a new contract with  LKAB, [ph] which accounts (14:02) to iron ore pellet deliveries. texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: When it comes to coal, we purchased about 60% to 70% from Australia and the residual from the North America.  And the consumption that we had in Q4 was about 10% higher compared to Q3 and that will give an impact in Q2  and later on.

texts.speaker: Marco Wirén
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: And when it comes to U.S. coal purchases, the contract period ends in the end of March as well and then we will  have a new contract. When it comes to scrap, we buy scrap for North American facilities on a continuous basis and  during the quarter, prices by the end of quarter were actually a little bit higher than end of Q3.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Thank you. So the outlook, well, we expect volumes in Americas and APAC to improve compared to Q4. We say  that the trend in Europe continues to be uncertain. We will have a positive effect  or impact from lower iron ore costs that will affect earnings in Q1 and Q2 compared to Q4.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: As said, we have a planned outage in Montpelier that will affect Americas in Q1, end of Q1 beginning of Q2. And  the efficiency program and the flexibility program runs according to plan and will be delivered.

file: SSAB.A - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 7February2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: If we look at our key customer segments and these are the important segments for us. And if we look at the trend  in Q4 versus Q3, I would say fairly flat with the exception of the U.S. energy segment that started to pick up late  Q3 and was picking up in Q4.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: If we look at the sequential outlook Q1 versus Q4, I would say that we see more or less the same trend in heavy  transport, not getting worse. Automotive picking up, constructio n machinery on the same level, mining in our  segments bottomed out and somewhat stronger market compared to Q4 in energy. And we see also for the first  time in a long period that service centers still are cautious, of course, but they're buying at slightly  higher levels  than we have seen during 2013 and the inventories in the service center system is not on the high side and that  goes for inventories in the full supply chain, they are normal or below normal.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Americas, better shipments than in Q3 and compared to Q4 last year. Demand from heavy transport segment and  service centers increased. Demand from the energy segment remains strong throughout Q4 and into Q1.  Unchanged prices in local currencies in Q4, so the price increases have not been seen in Q4. And we have so far  announced $130 per short tonne which will have a gradual impact from Q1 then.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: What we saw and what we have seen is the seasonally higher scrap prices in Q4, we typically see that every year,  but this winter season has been fairly tough with cold weather and even snow in Alabama. During a couple of  days, we had to close down the mill due to snow and strong wind for two days.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: The scrap prices have moved up with $70 per tonne, and that is somewhat more than normal during the winter  season and the weather is still – or the winter is still fairly strong, so maybe it will take some extra weeks before  we see the normal downturn in scrap prices as we always see.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB
texts.text: Finally from my side, some words on our raw material prices. Iron ore, we have a yearly delivery contract with  LKAB, however, the prices are set on quarterly basis. And in Q4, in Swedish krona, our iron ore prices were  4%  lower than Q3. For coking coal, we buy both from Australia and from U.S., the bulk are from Australia. It was also  lower in Q4 than Q3 with approximately 9%.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, SSAB AB
texts.text: Then Martin mentioned this briefly before on the scrap. There's actually a pretty different s ituation where U.S.  scrap prices increased quite a lot during Q4 and has continued to go up so far this year. And in Q4, the market  spot prices were up approximately 20%. And if we compare with one year back at the end of the year 2013, they  were up approximately 12%. And the high scrap prices will, of course, also impact our Q1 results. Okay.

file: SSAB.A - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 10February2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Construction Material, Q4 is always a seasonal slowdown, and we saw that this year as well. And we are expecting  a seasonally better demand in Q1. That will, of course, be dependent on how much snow and how the winter  develops. But, typically, we see better demand in Q1 compared to Q4. Of course, the development in Eastern  Europe, in Ukraine, in Russia, of course, continues to impact the construction material segment.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The market for energy, transportation and railcars expected to be strong in 2015. And that is due to the order  books for those customers. But we see some negative effects related to delayed investments in pipeline projects.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And if you take SSAB's sales in North America, it is less than 10%, including what goes via service centers, that  goes directly to the oil and gas sector. And we have currently a fairly limited exposure to big pipeline projects.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: What have we done then? Well, what we have done so far and what is in that SEK 300 million is lower purchasing  costs, new suppliers, new contracts and [ph] combining best of growth (10:08). We have in-sourced material to  Tibnor that previously was bought externally, that we can produce ourselves now. We are taking coking coal from  Oxelösund to Raahe instead of purchasing externally. We have also announced some actions with later impact. As  said, we will close the galvanizing line and the color-coating line in Borlänge and that will affect to start with 210  employees. We have closed or we will close the Ruukki headquarter and reduce staff functions not only in Finland,  but in the full Europe. And we will consolidate service centers in Tibnor. And we will continue then to do things  during this year according to the initial industrial plan.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: We had slightly higher volumes, especially than in the European division, since we had the summer outage in Q3.  Negative impact of price, partly in Americas, but, actually, mainly in Europe, given the mix effect. And then  variable COGS also a slightly negative impact where we had positive from the raw material, but on the other hand,  we had the outage in Montpelier, which impacted negatively. And in the other SEK 50 million, it's, for example,  foreign exchange, it's Tibnor and fixed cost.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: The other big item then between the two quarters is variable costs. And here, it's both production efficiency has  been improved, but it's, of course, also the lower raw material cost mainly due to iron ore. And then, once again,  we have the same items in the other bucket. So, all in all, it's an improvement of a bit more than SEK 400 million  from Q4 2013 Q4 to 2014.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Then, I would like to say some words about the relining of the blast furnace in Luleå. This is our largest blast  furnace. It has a capacity of 2.3 million tonnes. It's now 50 years since it was built, so it's definitely time to do the  relining. We will do it this summer. And we will have it closed from June until August. The capital expenditure for  the relining itself is around SEK 700 million.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: However, at the same time when the blast furnace is closed, we will anyway do some other investments, which is  good timing to do when you don't have production. So all-in-all, we will spend around SEK 800 million in Luleå  this year.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: What we will also need to do is, we need replace approximately 500,000 tonnes of slabs, and we will do this by  starting build-up slab inventory in Luleå. And we have also started up the small blast furnace in Oxelösund, that  has been idle for some time. And we will also build up slabs and ship them from Raahe.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: On top of the investment, we will have an extra cost for this, for example, transport of the slabs, start of the blast  furnace in Oxelösund. And we have estimated, the extra costs will be between SEK 100 million to SEK 150 million.  Some of them in Q1, but most of it Q2 and Q3.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Finally, from my part, some words on the raw material prices, where in general, we see clearly lower prices year- over-year. Our iron ore price was 7% lower in Q4 versus Q3 in Swedish krona, but 29% lower when we compare  with Q4 last year.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: For coking coal, we saw coking coal prices go down significantly already in 2013. What we see now is that in  Swedish krona, they were actually somewhat higher in Q4 than in Q3. In U.S. dollar, they were fairly even. But  when we look one year back, we can see that the prices are still 13% lower.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: And what we see on scrap prices is, as you know, iron ore prices have been going like this, scrap has been fairly  stable so far. But right now, we haven't seen the normal uptick that we see in the winter season, and for March,  scrap prices are expected to decrease rather significantly.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Then, I will show you something beautiful. This is the world's largest mining dump truck, also the winner of  Swedish Steel Prize 2014, this is with a loading capacity of 450-tonnes, produced by Belaz, developed by Belaz  with the help of SSAB. And of course, there is Hardox in the dumper body. But what is interesting with this one as  well, that axles and the chassis and frame is also developed by SSAB Steel. I think it's a huge and fantastic  machine, requires a lot of steel as well.

file: SSAB.A - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 12February2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: I will start with this picture, not to give you a lection in geography, but China is very important for the global steel  industry and impacting the global steel market a lot. What we have seen in the last 10 years is China going from a  net importer of steel to a net exporter of steel. China has built up a massive steel production capacity as well. And  the demand increase the last number of years has been huge in China. But now, when it's plateauing out, China is  having a lot of excess capacity of steel.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Well, we try to concentrate on the things that we can influence ourselves, of course, being very active on the  market, reducing lead times, increasing delivery performance, safe guard, and if possible, increase market shares  in the Nordic region, the whole market for flat carbon steel in North America for plates and globally for Q&T and  other niche grade.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Synergies, as we see it, is due to the combination of Ruukki and SSAB. On the top of that, we need to do additional  efficiency measures like all the other steel companies to keep up our cost position. So, if this is a relative change in  cost position, this is to keep up with the pace in the steel industry.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So, at the end of this year, we will be approximately 15,500 people, a reduction of 14% or 13.6%-something, which  is with – if you measure it tonnes per man hour, quite an improvement in productivity.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Americas, sharp price drops, lower volumes, partly offset by lower costs, and the declining volume is due to  destocking among steel service centers. Heavy Transport started to slow down a bit in Q4, while demand for wind  towers and some other segments remained strong. You'll also hear, we don't have any synergies here, but we have  a strong focus on cost efficiency. We do, twice a year, benchmark study to check the cost position compared to  other plate producers. We have recently done that. And we keep our leading quality and cost position compared to  other plate producers.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: On the positive side then, we had positive impact from variable COGS, to a large extent, that the scrap prices in   the U.S. decreased very much, but it's also here where we see some of the synergy impacts coming.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: We're compensating the huge drop in prices heartily by variable COGS, where raw material, all three main ones,  iron ore, coking coal and scrap, are down quite a lot year-over-year. But it's also here we see our own action in  terms synergies and also other cost improvements. But despite that, clearly, we are not compensating the variable  COGS with the drop in prices.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Energy, oil-related segments will continue to be demanding. We expect to see a continued strong demand from  wind towers. Construction Material, we typically see a seasonality in Q1. Q1 is, very often, stronger than Q4 due to  seasonality. We expect to see that pattern this year as well.

file: SSAB.A - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 15February2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Looking at the cost position, as said, we move into 2017 with a structurally lower cost base of SEK 3 billion, or just  above SEK 3 billion compared to the time when we merged the two companies. The majority is, of course, as we  have talked about before, synergies and the synergy realizations. We have done efficiency investments up in  Raahe. We have gone from oil injections to coal injections. That gives us SEK 200 million. SEK 200 million on the  restructuring of the Ruukki Construction. And then other cost savings, a big part of that being in Oxelösund. So, in  total, SEK 3 billion.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: If we look at the outage, we were, during the outage, changing or replacing the control system for the power  supply of the rolling mill. And there was a design error in the control system, and that resulted when we started up  the 15 of December in a damaged transformer. That had to be rewinded and sent to Norway for rewinding. We  got it back and did a second attempt during January 8. Then we blew two transformers. And then we said that we  would be up and running again early February, and we are up and running again, full speed since early February.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Lower variable COGS to a large extent due to a lower realized cost of scrap, consumption cost, and also that we  had the maintenance outage in Mobile in Q3. Then on the fixed cost side, it's quite negative here in Q4 versus Q3  with SEK 400 million. But this is, if you remember when we talked about Q3, we had a very good improvement  versus Q2. It's a seasonal thing because in the Nordic operations during the third quarter when most people take  vacation, we have dissolvement of vacation reserves. So, we look at this, when we compare Q4-over-Q4, you will  see a totally different picture. So, it's not Q4 that was high, it's more Q3 that is seasonally low.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: If we instead compare Q4 to Q4, we get the much more positive picture where we had a very tough Q4 last year  when EBITDA minus SEK 800 million and now then slightly above SEK 100 million, so more than SEK 900 million  improvement year-over-year. Somewhat at the price, this is almost exclusively coming from SSAB Europe.  Volumes, we see positive development in all three steel divisions and also Tibnor having clearly high volumes,  Q4, this 2016 and 2015. Variable COGS, somewhat positive and this is despite that on the raw material side, we  have a very negative – big negative variation 2016 versus 2015 of roughly SEK 150 million. But, again, our own  actions there have given us the positive improvement.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Slightly positive development from volumes, and this is mainly Special Steels volumes. Clearly, positive  development on the variable COGS. Roughly half of that is coming from raw material or actually less than half,  and the rest of it is coming then from our own actions.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Then moving over to the raw material side. And here, we have seen quite a, call it, interesting or at least bumpy  development over the last year, especially for coking coal where we had an enormous peak here during the fourth  quarter where the coking coal price was actually above $300 per tonne, coming from being here around $100 or  below $100 previously. It was a quite short peak, and we are now below $200 again, it's at $175 or something like  that. And for us, it implied that in Q4, our average purchase price was up 65% U.S. dollar and 75% in Swedish  krona. So, it's quite amazing the high figures when you compare only Q4 versus Q3.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Then we actually don't buy that much in Q4 because for [indiscernible] (22:51), we have – we need to take the  material in earlier to have winter stockage. We do buy steel [indiscernible] (22:56), but the main coking coal buys  we do in Q2 and Q3. We haven't so far seen the cost impact. We've seen a little bit of it, but the most of it will  come during the first half 2017.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: On the iron ore side, it doesn't look as dramatic here, but that's just because the coking coal is extremely  dramatic. But if you compare with beginning of 2016, iron ore was at $50 or something, then it was creeping  upwards. It felt like it had plateaued and ended around $80. But then just yesterday or the day before, it actually  broke $90 again. So, also, iron ore has increased enormously if you go back one year. And if you look for our  purchases, then, well, in Q4, we were buying iron ore 20% high price in dollar and given the weakest Swedish  krona, then 24% higher in Swedish krona.

file: SSAB.A - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 26January2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jan-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Per Hillström
texts.profession: Head - Investor Relations, SSAB AB
texts.text: And here is how we have set it up. First, Martin will talk about full year 2017 and the targets in 2020, how are we  doing there. We have revised our financial and environmental targets. And then we're coming to the – going down  first on the divisions and on the group, and Håkan then covers financials. Martin comes in again to discuss the  outlook, and then we have Q&A as a final point on the agenda.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Other targets, we have revised the environmental targets we setup. I would say, fairly ambitious targets 2015 with  a net reduction of carbon dioxide or 200,000 tonnes and the reduction of purchased energy with 300 gigawatt  hours and will see a reduction of residuals with 30,000 tonne. The reason why we are changing or increasing  those targets are that we reached them already 2017. Just set up new targets for 2020 where we will reduce the  carbon dioxide emissions with 300,000 tonnes, energy with 400 gigawatt hours, and residuals with 50,000 tonne.  And this is, of course, an important part of our operations.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: We have also during last year come out with new sustainability objectives where we state and claim that we will  be completely fossil-free by the latest 2045. And of course, the HYBRIT project is an important part of that and we  will, next week, the 1st of February, release the pre-feasibility or report the outcome of the pre-feasibility study,  but there are other important actions ongoing as well in order to become fossil-free.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: And on the journey towards 2045, we have said that 2025, we will help our customers to save 10 million tonnes  annually of carbon dioxide emissions. And I know that this is not scientifically correct, but then at the latest 2025,  we will be carbon-neutral. And so 10 million tonnes is approximately what we emit as a company in our  operations.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Then we also see higher volumes contributing with SEK 280 million. That's almost exclusively coming from higher  volumes in Special Steels. And this is then counteracted by variable COGS increase of SEK 1.250 billion, and  that's almost exclusively on the raw material side. We also have higher costs now in Q4, higher fixed cost partly  because we have more maintenance cost and then, partly because of the overall higher activity level. I'll come  back to a bit more details on the fixed cost.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Higher volume, Q4 over Q3, it's coming a little bit of everywhere, Special Steels, Europe, also Tibnor,  counteracted by especially Ruukki Construction, where Q4 in the construction industry is always seasonally low.  Variable COGS, not a big difference. On the fixed cost side, we have an increase and we always have seasonally  low fixed cost in Q3, given the Nordic operations and the summer vacation reserves. We had a few type of one-off  items as well in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: You can say that the higher prices all counteracted by higher variable costs, and again to a very large extent, this  is driven by the increase in the raw material. And we have basically seen that it increase everywhere. It's on the  iron ore side. It's on the coking coal side. It's also on the scrap side. On year-over-year, we have higher fixed cost  of SEK 550 million. It's partly explained that we have more planned maintenance costs in 2017 than in 2016, but  it's also because the overall higher activity level.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: And when we move into more advanced product mix, we also do more with the products. We do more cutting, we  do more slitting, we have produced more tubular products, et cetera, more heat treatment, and then that result in  higher fixed costs.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: And if we spend a little bit more time on working capital and what we have been doing then during the last year- and-a-half, I will go back to saying when we released this SEK 10 billion net debt reduction target, we said that  working capital would be a key contributing factor. We also said that since the merger with Ruukki, that had not  been on our top priority list. We focused on being out with the customers. We focused on the synergies and other  cost-reduction items. We focused on the mining reduction.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Moving on to raw materials starting with coking coal and iron ore, coking coal prices in Q4 were 4% higher than in  Q3. However, as we had talked about before, we don't buy very much in Q4 given that we have winter stocks in  Raahe and up in Luleå. We buy the main part of our coking coal in Q2 and Q3. So, it's mainly, it's mainly these  purchase points that will impact our P&L in Q1 and Q2.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: For iron ore, our average purchase in pellets was unchanged in Swedish krona. It was slightly down in U.S.  dollars. What we have seen now in the beginning of 2018 is that these prices have started moving upwards.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Then when we look at scrap, which we're obviously using our two electric arc furnaces in North America, all in all,  in Q4, it was basically at the same level in the end of Q4 as in the beginning of Q4, what we have seen in  December, and also now in January, as you can see on this chart, that spot prices for scrap has started to  increase. And scrap, we turned around quite quickly so the December and the January increase you will see in  our P&L basically in Q1. And that's why we also talked about in the outlook that's one of the reasons that we talk  about the higher raw material prices.

file: SSAB.A - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 29January2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jan-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: If we start with Special Steels, we said that we would reach 1.35 million tonnes at the latest 2020, and I think that  will be doable. If we look at Automotive, we are slightly behind plan, but I think we have a good chance to reach  those 750,000 tonnes as well, and this is for us mainly advanced high-strength steels to safety details, so very  small part of the Automotive. And what we experienced is that the structural growth within Automotive to lighter,  more safer cars is getting stronger and stronger.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: the new way of producing steel without any carbon dioxide emissions. We got a groundbreaking ceremony in  June and we are now in the process of building this pilot plant up in Luleå. It will be finalized during 2020. And we  will, during 2021 or early 2022, know if this really works and we are looking into this more and more, or the more  we are looking into it, the more convinced we are that this will work, but we will, as said, know 2021, 2022. This is  a fairly big investment, SEK 1.4 billion, and we are doing this together with Vattenfall and LKAB.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: And the Swedish Energy Agency decided also to contribute to this SEK 1.4 billion, so they are contributing with a  bit more than SEK 500 million to this very interesting project. And as we have said before, if we are successful  with this, we will take away 10% of all the carbon dioxide emissions in Sweden over time and 7% of all the carbon  dioxide emissions in Finland.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: And on the variable COGS side, this is, to a very large extent, raw material. It's also partly because we had more  maintenance outage Q4 this year than Q4 last year, which also spills over here on the fixed cost or it's also  impacting the fixed cost, where we are SEK 400 million higher cost in 2018 versus 2017. It's the outages. It's also  a general salary increase. In the U.S., we have production-related bonuses. However, what we have focused very  much on is that fixed manning, we have kept at the basically totally flat level. Since the beginning of 2016, we  have increased some of the temporary, but we've kept the fixed manning on a fixed level.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: Variable COGS, somewhat higher. It's iron ore and it's partly the maintenance outages. Fixed cost, clearly higher  than in Q3. You remember that we always have roughly half of that is related to – we have seasonally lower fixed  cost in Q3 in the Nordic areas. And the rest is basically related to the maintenance outages.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: We are still below the long-term average CapEx of SEK 2.7 billion. But in the last few years, we have not had any  major relining of the blast furnaces and we have not had any major capacity expansion. When we have those as  in the year, in 2015, then we have clearly higher investments. Going forward, with the announcement of the new –  or the added capacity of quenching and tempering in Mobile, we will have CapEx for 2019 and 2020 of around  SEK 2.5 billion.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: On the raw material side, we saw iron ore and coking coal purchase prices increase in Q4. Pellet the most  increased by 15% in Swedish kroner or 14% in dollars. Coking coal is somewhat less, 7% in Swedish kroner and  6% in U.S. dollar. Given the time lag from when we purchased these until they hit the P&L, we have seen some of  it. We have seen some of the iron ore impact in Q4, but we'll see more of it coming now as high raw material cost  in our P&L in Q1. That goes especially for iron ore. Coking coal is a bit more of a lag.

texts.speaker: Håkan Folin
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, SSAB AB
texts.text: In the U.S. for our operations there, we use scrap in the electric arc furnaces. Those prices were very stable in  Q4, almost unchanged, our purchase prices compared to Q3. What we have actually seen in January is that  scrap prices have gone down somewhat in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: Construction Machinery, it's leveling out a bit or a lower growth momentum but still at a high level. And when we  talk to the big customers, we expect Q1 to continue to be strong or at a healthy level. Material Handling, high  activity in mining in several regions both maintenance and new equipment. So we expect that to be strong or we  see it to be strong. Energy, solid demand in wind energy and that will continue beyond Q1. But we also see high  activity when it comes to oil and gas in North America, number of pipeline projects, energy distribution now during  Q1.

texts.speaker: Martin Erik Lindqvist
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSAB AB
texts.text: So before we open up a question, just to sum it up then. I think – as I showed at my first slide, we are on track to  reach the 2020 targets. We are slightly behind when it comes to Automotive. But I think the reasons are there and  I would not be surprised if we met those targets. So I expect us to meet those targets 2020.
