texts.text: Scottish & Southern Energy  Plc SSE.GB Q2 2010 Earnings Call Nov. 10, 2010 Company▲ Ticker▲ Event Type▲ Date▲

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: In Gas, we are buying our first North Sea gas production asset. In Networks, the big transmission  upgrades and therefore the associated RAV growth are now getting underway in Scotland. And in  Contracting we’ve completed our first development zero-carbon home. We are the only U.K.-listed  company can view operational investment or acquisition opportunities throughout the U.K. and Irish  electricity and gas sectors. This enables to us achieve on a consistent basis levels of profitability  that can support sustained real dividend growth.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: Diversity within our balanced range – balanced business is what delivers dividend growth, and we’ll  look at each of the business areas in return, starting with Generation. We’ve still got the most  diverse generation portfolio in the U.K., and that’s the way we intend to keep it, while achieving our  long-term goal of cutting by 50% the carbon intensity of power producer stations where we have an  ownership or contractual interest.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: In practical terms that means getting new megawatts of wind capacity on the ground, all on the  seabed and generating. It means capitalizing on our leading position in hydro to maintain a diverse  portfolio of renewables. It means that Paul Smith through the Chairman and Chief’s view -- it means  that Paul and his team operate our gas and coal-fired power stations on an increasingly flexible  basis. And it means developing long-term, low carbon options.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: I believe we’re making good progress because soon after the start of the financial year we have  commissioned 90 megawatts of new onshore wind farm capacity, made material progress at  Walney and Gabbard, where we expect the export of the first power by the end of the year, gained  consent for developing a pumped storage scheme at Sloy, completed significant pre-planning work  on two great and large-scale pump storage schemes, successfully operating gas-fired power  stations on a two-shift basis this summer, started work on Europe’s biggest post-combustion  carbon capture trial at Ferrybridge and continued to develop potential new nuclear at Sellafield,  albeit slowly and cheaply.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: In other words, when it comes to generation, we’re combining diversity with de-carbonization. I  believe this will stand us in a good state as the U.K. and Ireland enter the electric era. There is no  doubt that low carbon power will pay an even bigger part in meeting heat and transport as well as  their traditional needs.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: Alistair Phillips-Davies, Energy Supply Director  Thank you, Ian. First to see the last decade has been about rapid growth in our customer numbers,  and with 10 million accounts, we’ve given ourselves the scale that we needed. But we’ve been  involved in more than just a numbers game. As Ian said earlier, just 1.5% of our customer accounts  were for anything other than electricity and gas in Great Britain three years ago. At the same time  as growing our customer base, it has now increased to 7.5% as we diversified through Home  Services and Ireland.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: We prioritized increasing the number of energy customers on loyalty tariffs. We now have over 3  million accounts on programs such as energyplus Argos, energyplus Pulse and M&S Energy.       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: Scottish & Southern Energy  Plc SSE.GB Q2 2010 Earnings Call Nov. 10, 2010 Company▲ Ticker▲ Event Type▲ Date▲

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: 7 Growth has also been supported by product development. Three years after its launch, the better  plan has secured almost 300,000 customer accounts. Throughout the period of growth, we’ve led  the sector on service and surveys like the U.K. Customer Satisfaction Index and Usage, which  recently voted us best overall energy supplier for the seventh year in a row.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: So, with a strong position on service and products, it shows that beneath the headline customer  numbers, we’re working hard to maximize customer attention for the long-term. Clearly, the October  announcement on prices was difficult, but having absorbed losses in our gas supply business for  some time, we could not delay an increase in retail prices any longer. At the same time, our goal  has been and remains offering constantly competitive prices over the medium-term to our  customers.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: The range of supply is evolving from the simple retailing of electricity and gas to the provision of a  range of smarter products and services, all consistent with the de-carbonization of energy  production and consumption. You can see this for yourself at Slough where our zero carbon homes  development is giving us real experience of what supplying energy to customers will be like in the  future. If you would like to visit this excellent development, please speak to Sally or myself  afterwards.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: In the meantime, we already have the iplan, the new smart products and service we launched in  September. It delivers smart energy features to customers, allowing them to track their energy  usage and provide the real-time and historic information they need to change the way that they use  energy. It means customers can be smart without waiting for the meters.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: Smart meters themselves, we believe, will be a marathon, not a sprint. We will be taking a cautious  approach to what will be a strategic infrastructure project for the entire country, but we start off with  four key strengths.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: First, we gained extensive experience as the biggest player in the Ofgem-sponsored energy  demand reduction trial. Second, the in-sourced GB-wide metering team that we finished putting  together in March is already giving us better management of customer data and more reliable  service for our customers.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: Third, our metering team means we have to start, scale and scope to manage the huge GB-wide  project that smart will require. And fourth, in line with our step-by-step approach, we started  installing 2,000 smart meters in trials in Midlands and the South of the country.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: By diversifying into the Ireland market two years ago, we’ve given ourselves a new market for major  headwinds for further growth. At Airtricity we now have reached one-third of a million accounts,  making us the fastest growing energy supplier in Ireland. With increasing customer numbers,  growing generation capacity and our street lighting business as well, we have the ambitions and  capability to grow significantly in Ireland in the years ahead. This is a key market for us and it is  also one which we believe will become increasingly harmonized with the U.K. in years ahead.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: Scottish & Southern Energy  Plc SSE.GB Q2 2010 Earnings Call Nov. 10, 2010 Company▲ Ticker▲ Event Type▲ Date▲

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: 8 Ian Marchant, Chief Executive  SSE is first and foremost a customer facing business. We source energy because we supply  customers. And we know we can provide more diverse sources of energy, we struck the agreement  to acquire North Sea assets from Hess. We currently need on average around 30.5 million therms  of gas per day to supply our customers and to fuel our power stations. Gas from the Hess assets  will provide around 6% of that initially, at the headline transaction price of $324 million, which is a  good disciplined deal, which we expect to complete later this year.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: It will enable us to enter the upstream gas market in a measured way by providing – by proven and  geographically diverse production assets, which will give us a new source of primary fuel and a  hedge for our gas generation and supply activities. Our upstream entry means we now have  involvement across the gas chain production, storage, distribution and supply.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: Last, we again highlighted these strategic significance of gas storage capacity. The development of  new storage at Aldbrough is now making important and significant progress, it remains on the  schedule and budget set out in July 2009 and is on course to be completed in 2012. More capacity  will be come available later this year, when sixth caverns should have been completed. This will  provide a total of around 175 million cubic meters of storage, which is around half of the final  expected capacity for the development as a whole.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: With Statoil, we have consent for the extension of the Aldbrough site. This was and remains a  strategically important option, but we’ve concluded that any investment decision on it should be  deferred, while the U.K. government decides – develops and decides on its policy on gas security.  This is the disciplined thing to do, but we’re still committed to gas storage.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: Within the SSE model, market based businesses like gas storage, generation and supply are  balanced by our economically regulated natural monopoly network. These networks give us a  financial backbone and operational focus, are central to our commitment to sustained real annual  dividend growth and provide significant investment opportunities.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: I’m going to pick out just five key points. First, six months experience of the new electricity price  control regime shows we have the capability and efficiency to deliver a post tax real rate of return in  excess of 5%, between now and 2015. Second, over five years, we have increased SGN’s  efficiency and value and reduced its risk profile. With March 2011 external bad debt is likely to be  around 3.1 billion and the RAV likely to be 4.2 billion, we believe SGN is well placed to deliver even  more efficiency and values SSE over the years ahead.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: Third, the level of risk associated with economically regulated businesses is now lower; for example  revenue is no longer dependent on energy volumes. Fourth, the trend -- the upgrade of our  transmission network is getting underway. Construction work is starting on the Beauly-Denny  upgrade, although it has been deferred on the Western Isles link. Our transmission RAV is on  course to develop double to around £1 billion by the middle of the decade and then double again by  around 2020.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: Scottish & Southern Energy  Plc SSE.GB Q2 2010 Earnings Call Nov. 10, 2010 Company▲ Ticker▲ Event Type▲ Date▲

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin, Chairman
texts.profession: Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to be with you this morning. Looking back at the
texts.text: 9 I started out by promising the SSE strategy in 4D. I’d like to take that one step further and give you  discipline in 5D. One, disposed, Ardrossan, Butendiek in Germany and subject to achieving value  over 100 megawatts of onshore wind.

file: SSEL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 9November2011 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Nov-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: At the start of 2011, SSE established a management board to lead the operation of the business. It's made up of the  three executive directors here and a number of managing directors. And also with us today are Lady Susan Rice,  our Senior Independent Director, Chariman of Rem Comm. And Susan, where are you? Right at the back there.  We've got David Franklin, who is Managing Director for Energy Portfolio Management. David, here at the front.  Paul Smith who is MD for Generation, and Alan Young who is Managing Director – Corporate Affairs at the back.  You'll have a chance to talk to all of them at the end of the session.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Having said that, this is not a straightforward time in which to do business, with economic uncertainty across  much of the world, and turmoil in the global energy markets, SSE's half year results reflect a number of these  issues such as the high wholesale cost of gas. Nevertheless, subject to the normal caveats, we expect to be  reporting moderate growth in adjusted PBT the full year.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Looking at our businesses in turn, the main half-year issues were in generation and supply where operating profit  fell by 71% to £58.8 million. This was driven by four issues: higher wholesale gas prices, with summer prices  almost 40% higher than last year. Spark spreads, which were more than 60% lower than in the same period last  year, falls of 4% and 16% respectively in wholesale consumption of electricity and gas and the decision to help  customers by delaying retail price increases until mid-September.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: There was however one very positive aspect of performance in generation supply, the 55% increase in output from  renewable energy. This reflects some new operating capacity from our investment program and more favorable  weather conditions. That's more favorable for us at least.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: There was operating profit growth of 9.5% in Energy Networks which accounted for just over 70% of our operating  profit in the first half. Two things stand out. First, as a result of the progress made in the investment program,  now gathering momentum. Second, SGN performed particularly well with profit growth of 16%. Additional  revenues have come through this year and there have been continuing cost efficiencies.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Across the other businesses segment as a whole, there was profit growth of 16.6% to £77.2 million. This was  despite falls in operating profit for Telecoms and for Contracting, Utility Solutions and Metering, which face tough  trading conditions. Growth was driven by the first contribution over a half-year from gas production of £17.3  million, and the increase in operating profit in gas storage partly due to the new capacity coming through at  Aldbrough. Our investments at Aldbrough and in transmission upgrades are now starting to deliver revenue.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: I also said earlier that the increase in output from renewable energy was due in part to new operational capacity,  with more new assets from our investment program coming on stream. Delivering returns from investment has, of  course, become our key means of securing dividend growth over the long term, and you can see the progress of our  major wind farm projects on this slide.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Investment and capital spend totaled £796.9 million during the six months. You can see the detail in the  statement, but I draw out three points: first, major progress has been made at a number of key projects such as the  wind farms at Clyde and Griffin. All of the large wind farms you can see in this slide other than Gordonbush have  now started to earn revenue. And we expect first-generation at Gordonbush to start shortly, with more to come as  all the projects near completion.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: The latest indicative split of the spend is set out on the slide. It is made up of economically-regulated electricity  distribution investment plus essential maintenance of other assets. Economically-regulated spend on  transmission upgrades and spend that is either committed or could be committed to development of new assets  like wind farms or CCTTs to support dividend growth.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Across SSE, we've got a lot of opportunities to choose from. There's transmission, CCTT, solid fuel, pump storage,  and wind farms. The breadth of these opportunities will allow us to reject projects with questionable returns and  choose projects with good returns from investment, quite simply, good returns mean growing dividends.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: The management reasons are fundamental. Clear dividend targets provide a simplicity and transparency and  make management genuinely accountable. The focus on dividend drives a disciplined, consistent, and long-term  approach to operations and investment. The value of our long-term approach has never been greater. Our goal is  to offer shareholders a degree of certainty in what is a fast-changing energy sector. From Prime Minister's  questions to Question Time on the BBC to questions from friends in the pub, the whole of my sector is having  criticism piled on it. And alongside the colorful language, we've got yet more legislation and regulation. We have  RIIO, electricity market reform and retail market review in Britain and market harmonization in Ireland.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Our energy networks are a case in point. Within the SSC model, they matter for three key reasons. First, they give  us a financial backbone and operational focus. Second, they are central to our commitment to sustained real  annual dividend growth. And third, they provide us with significant investment opportunities. Their combined  regulatory asset value has now reached £5.5 billion, £400 million higher than a year ago, and the opportunities to  build on this are significant. I'd first roll out three points on distribution.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: First, 18 months experience of the new price control in electricity distribution shows we have the capability and  efficiency to deliver a post-tax real return in excess of 5% between now and 2015. Indeed the latest indications  show we're still at the efficiency front here.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Second, we're making significant progress on smart grids. Ofgem has announced a funding package for our  Shetland project with 85% spend going on the RAV. The project features heat and electricity storage to manage  intelligently the demands for electricity generation in Shetland. And that will allow more renewable and energy  capacity to be connected. It also features new active network management solutions.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: The main project currently is of course our part of the Beauty-Denny upgrade, for which Ofgem has now a funding  of £539 million in 2009/2010 prices. Work on removing and replacing the old pylons have started and the whole  project should be finished around 2014.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: In addition to Beauty-Denny, we're also building phase 1 of the transmission upgrades in the North of Scotland.  The £200 million group of projects included the Knocknaegael substation. Work on the Beauty-Mossford upgrade  is also underway. These projects are on-time and on-budget, with the first one due to complete early in the New  Year.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: The planning issues that have been tackled means that the Beauly-Denny upgrade has been nine years in coming.  Interesting you compare that to energy supply, where nine hours can feel like a long time. So I'm going to get  Alistair to give you some perspectives on that.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Executive Director & Director-Energy Supply, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Thank you Ian, good morning, everybody. Shortly after our results in May, Ofgem said that in a period of rising  prices, suppliers have to transform the way they deal with customers. Ofgem was right and we believe we've  responded faster and with more commitment than any other company in the sector. Five important decisions  illustrate the point. In July, we became the first leading supplier to drop commission-based doorstep sales in GB.  We've frozen our retail prices until August next year at the earliest. We've helped to transform volumes the day- ahead electricity market with our initiative to improve transparency and price discovery. We've removed  online/offline price differentials and called for an end to predatory pricing by other suppliers. And we've set out  initial plans to tackle tariff complexity, improve cost transparency and promote a better relationship with  customer all around.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Executive Director & Director-Energy Supply, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: We've set out 10 different proposals to build trust and we're working to implement them all before the end of next  year. We believe the net result will be reduced political and regulatory risk, a new and distinctive proposition in  the energy supply sector and most importantly of all a fair deal for customers that is sustainable over the long  term.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Executive Director & Director-Energy Supply, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: From that position, we need to move forward. That means going from the retailing of electricity and gas and the  legacy of complexity, to providing a wider but much simpler range of smarter products and services. This will get  extra impetus with a roll out of smart meters and the launch of the Green Deal.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Executive Director & Director-Energy Supply, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: The smart meter rollout is a job we have to do well. But fundamentally, it's part of doing business not a profit  driver. Green Deal is different. We have specific obligations as a collection agent, but it does provide business  opportunities as well and we're looking at these very closely. Throughout, we're taking a disciplined and pragmatic  approach.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Executive Director & Director-Energy Supply, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: SSE is first and foremost a customer-facing business. David Franklin's job is to source energies so we can supply  customers, our investment in renewables is a hedge against volatility in fossil fuel markets and is an increasingly  important source of energy.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Executive Director & Director-Energy Supply, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Indeed in the first half of the year, output from our Hydro schemes and wind farms gave us the equivalent of £95  million therms of gas. To provide more diverse sources of energy, we bought North Sea Assets from Hess. This  was a good, disciplined deal, and the assets have performed well in this six-month period with good output and  profitability.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Executive Director & Director-Energy Supply, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Through this and the 5% stakes secured in Faroe Petroleum, we've fulfilled a longstanding SSE ambition to enter  the upstream gas sector. We've done it in a measured way which has given us a new source of primary fuel and a  hedge for our gas generation supply activities.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Executive Director & Director-Energy Supply, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: We hope to build our presence in the sector over time with a focus being on mature, producing, gas-weighted  assets with no operating role. Our approach to potential assets will be consistent with our financial principles and  that will be pursued only where fair value can be secured.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Executive Director & Director-Energy Supply, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: We've also added to our long-term gas supply through the 10-year contract with Statoil for the annual supply of  500 million cubic meters of gas. Fuel supply contracts play a key part in helping us to meet our customer needs  and they contribute to the long-term stability of our energy portfolio.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Executive Director & Director-Energy Supply, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Stability is something the politicians believe that greater gas storage capacity can give the UK and they're right.  Our investments in the facility at Aldbrough is nearing completion. Our option to extend it is probably the best in  the country. But in the absence of adequate returns, we see no prospect of investing in it in the foreseeable future.  Our overall fuel position is however evolving in a careful SSE-type way. And I'm optimistic that other  opportunities will emerge and allow us to continue to add to our mix of natural gas assets and contracts.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Alistair. Our plans to build trust in energy supply reflect the fact that in this decade and beyond, energy  needs to be about three things. The customer, as Alistair has talked about, plus capacity in carbon. And it's  capacity in carbon that the Electricity Market Reform is focused on. And it's still work-in-progress. There are two  key questions for SSE. Will policy changes have any negative impact on investment decisions already made? And  secondly, what will the impact of policy changes on investment decisions be that have yet to be taken?

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: On the first point, committed investments, we are comfortable with the political and policy commitment to  protecting value. That was illustrated yet again by the recent ROC banding review. If implemented, it will not have  any impact on our assets under construction. Longer term, we believe the combination of ROCs and the carbon  price support make – it represents a fair package of support for on and offshore wind.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: The good news is that construction work continues to make solid progress. A total of 122 turbines have now been  installed and 83 of these have exported electricity. This means that all 140 turbines should have been installed as  planned before the end of next year. The bad news is that our investigations into the turbine foundations suggest  that around one-third of them don't meet the standard required by the contract signed by the principal contractor,  Fluor. The onus is currently on Fluor to determine how it plans to meet its contractual obligations with regard to  these foundations. We hope it will do this in a satisfactory way but if necessary a very substantial claim will be  issued against Fluor.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: In the meantime, the construction focus is – and it is on installing the remainder of the turbines. Despite the  difficulties with some of the foundations, Greater Gabbard should be generating significant amounts of power this  winter and beyond.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: There's good news and bad news at Glendoe, too. The good news is that the repair work scheme is currently going  well. The bad news is that that work is extensive and we've decided that around half of the entire tunnel should be  lined. Taking those two factors together, we're confident that electricity generation is on-course to resume towards  the end of the first half of 2012.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: The second bit of good news on Glendoe is that we have significant insurance and legal options available to us to  make sure there's an appropriate settlement by the contractor of the costs incurred in respect to tunnel repair. The  bad news however, it is likely to take some time to resolve.  Our next spend on Glendoe will represent less than less than 3% of the total CapEx program over the period since  the original construction program started. The strategic nature of the asset is -- has value that will be realized as  the UK generation portfolio changes. That change is underway, which is why we've made it such a priority to get  Glendoe back into service as quick as possible.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: If you take £100 million as the threshold, we have four major wind farm projects in construction at the moment in  addition to Gabbard. Here the news is all good. We're seeing a growing momentum as the portfolio takes major  steps forward. The 130-megawatt South section at Clyde was finished earlier than expected and the rest of that  project is on course to be finished next year.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: Turbine installation at Griffin is nearly finished and the whole farm should be operating earlier than planned by  Christmas. Turbine installation at Gordonbush is now well underway and first electricity generation should take  place very shortly. Phase 1 of Walney has operated successfully since the summer and we've just had first  electricity from Phase 2, which should be fully commissioned in the first half of next year. In addition to these  specific projects, we've got a number of smaller onshore wind sites under construction in Scotland and England,  together with the project at Keadby we bought in May. Work on these is on time and on budget.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: On time and on budget are not phrases normally associated with the nuclear industry which partly explains our  decision to pull out of the NuGen consortium. We could have spent many millions of pounds and a lot of  management resource to keep the option open but we preferred to make a clean break.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: So our ambitions now are as a non-nuclear generator and our investment plans go well beyond on and offshore  wind. We've got extensive options for new CCGT at sites around the country starting with Abernedd. Solid fuel is  important too and we have an opportunity to build a significant business in multi fuel, working with our new  partner, Wheelabrator and starting at Ferrybridge. The detail on that project is in the statement.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: We also have Europe's biggest post combustion carbon capture trial at Ferrybridge and it should begin operating  later this year. And we're considering building on this experience at Peterhead. Our ambition at Peterhead is to  build a full chain post combustion CCS scheme on the back of one of the gas turbines. It is however dependent on  securing enough of the available government funding be it in UK or European level to make it possible to proceed  with the project. Making progress in securing that funding is what lies behind the joint development agreement  with shale that's been announced today.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: CCS is a complex area, but for more than six years, we have felt that the UK's best location for our first CCS  scheme is Peterhead. And then applying CCS to a gas plant is vital for the long-term of the UK. We still believe  both those factors still to be true.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: For the avoidance of doubt however, let me be clear about one thing; for SSE, CCS has to be an economic energy  project, not a value-destroying vanity project. As such, it has to be consistent with our six generation principles;  compliance, capacity, diversity, availability, flexibility and sustainability. Through these principles and the  experience and knowledge Paul Smith's team has build over the years, of managing our generation assets, we're  able to make the right decision about operations and investment in generation.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: In networks, we've decided that transmission is a core asset and its RAV will growth dramatically. In supply, we've  decided to change the way we retain and gain customers and show leadership in building trust. And in generation,  we've decided to be non-nuclear focusing on technologies and fuels where we have skills and experience.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc
texts.text: SSE's core purpose is to provide the energy people need in a reliable and sustainable way. Providing energy is a  long-term activity. SSE is a company that aims to do the right thing and make decisions for the long term. It's not  always straightforward. You have to anticipate change, influence change, respond to change.

file: SSEL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 13November2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: We have a consistent strategy for achieving that. It's the efficient operation of, and investment in a balanced range  of economically regulated and market-based energy businesses in the UK and in Ireland. SSE has a clearly defined  core purpose, financial objective, and consistent strategy. At the same time, it also has a set of long-term values  that are at the heart of everything this company does and their safety, as I mentioned earlier, service, efficiency,  sustainability, excellence and teamwork. And staying true to our purpose, our financial objective, our strategy, and  our values and exercising a strong operational financial discipline is, we believe, the right course for SSE to  maintain in the testing environment we currently face, and that is what we'll do.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're forecasting capital and investment spend of over £1.5 billion in this financial year with electricity networks  and generation continuing to be the main components. Next year, we're expecting it to be around £1.5 billion as  well, but the eventual total, will obviously depend to what new investment decisions are taken in the next few  months.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: The extent to which we will be giving – willing to commit to the development of new assets in the next few years  will depend on things like electricity market reforms specifically. And more generally, the extent to which  policymakers will allow companies to secure a fair return on capital that they have invested. All of this means that  greater uncertainty about the shape and extent of SSE's investment program in the years from 2015, it may, in  practice, be lower than the £1.5 billion to £1.7 billion range we've seen since 2010.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: The immediate priority for this business is to keep the lights on for customers during – whatever the winter  months bring us. That's a critical job. As the picture shows, the 28th of October storm was a major event that led  to over 100,000 customers losing supply in our distribution area. The effort to get the lights back on was  absolutely excellent, fantastic result from over a thousand of our staff.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: Beyond the immediate operational focus, tension is turning to the new RIIO-ED1 price control. It's just over 16  months away. At the heart of the Business Plan, we submitted in July 12 customer commitments, these include  reducing our distribution networks part of the electricity bill by 10% in 2015 and reducing the number and  duration of power cuts.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: Efficiency and innovation are the watchwords, and the Business Plan is designed to keep us at the frontier of  efficiency while preparing for what might happen in energy use between now and 2023. It's very clear that all  aspects of the electricity bill are under intense scrutiny at this moment. And it's obviously far too early to see what  the final price control would look like, or to suggest what return we might earn from electricity distribution after  2015.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: Good progress is being made with projects under construction like Beauly-Denny where we're now expecting the  cost to be over £675 million. Projects under development like Caithness and Moray are moving forward, and the  £200 million subsea link from Kintyre to Hunterston is the first project to go through the transmission price  control Strategic Wider Works program. The key driver for all of these projects is a need to accommodate  renewable energy developments in the north of Scotland.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: In line with this, we expect to invest between £350 million and £500 million in transmission in each of the next  few years. Longer term, there is greater uncertainty about the extent of renewable energy deployment, and  therefore, of the extent to which the transmission network we need to develop to accommodate it. The  combination of existing network constraints and windfarms recently completed or in construction, however,  means that there's a huge amount of work for our transmission business to do over the next few years. That means  that its RAV should reach £1.6 billion in 2015.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: Like transmission, SGN started its price control in April. This has got off to a good start and this is seen in the  12.6% increase in our share of operating profit over the six months to €138.2 million. A total of £144.4 million was  invested by SGN as a whole in the period, taking a share of the RAV of the business to £2.4 billion. SGN is one of  the most efficient gas distributors and that, together with further efficiencies to come from the project we are  calling RIIOmax, should mean we are well placed to outperform Ofgem's base case. There's no scope for  complacency however, and SGN, like our transmission business is already looking ahead to the mid-term review  of the price control in 2017.

texts.speaker: Lord Smith of Kelvin
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: With Networks, Retail and Wholesale businesses, SSE's activities reflect the broad structure of the energy sector in  Britain and Ireland. I believe that this gives us a better understanding of the end-to-end issues in the sector,  allows us to earn revenue and deliver dividend growth from nine different businesses, reduces the risk from any  one business, and allows us to apply best practice and benefit from core synergies in key areas like safety,  customer service, stakeholder relations and large capital project management across all aspects of the business. In  other words, it makes the whole business greater than the sum of the parts.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Gregor, and good morning, everyone. For some years now, energy policy in the UK and Ireland has  had three broad objectives characterized as the energy trilemma, a word actually that the BBC looked up in the  dictionary earlier today and decided what a proper word for those looking at news feeds. And that trilemma is  about three things; affordability, security of supply and decarbonization. At SSE, we have three long-term  priorities which reflect and respond to the issues arising from that trilemma. They are efficiency and innovation in  Networks, as Gregor has just described, to help keep the lights on and provide connections to the system for  renewable generators; digital excellence and a brand people trust in Retail, so that operating costs are kept to a  minimum, energy efficiency is maximized and the customers trust SSE to do the right things for them; and  sustainability in Wholesale through a diverse generation portfolio that has the flexibility to respond to changes  and demands when they occur and helps keep the lights on.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: I believe that these are the right long-term priorities because they reflect the energy sector as it really is. I also  believe that the right short-term priorities, because they address directly the key concerns of the people, will  ultimately pay for everything and for whom affordability is a key issue, the customers.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Retail is clearly the focal point for politicians and customers, and given the cost of the entire industry are  recovered through bills, that's hardly surprising. It's now seven weeks since Ed Miliband's call for a 20-month  price freeze, and a lot has happened since then, notably tariff increases from five of the major suppliers, including  SSE; a review of what are now known partly through our intervention as the green taxes; and the launch of an  annual competition order of the energy market.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: The tariff increase, we clearly regret. By having incurred a six-month operating loss of £89.4 million in Retail  because of an even bigger loss in energy supply, and with cost forecasts to rise again next year, we have no  practical alternative. The review of green taxes is very welcomed. We support what they're trying to achieve, but  we think it's got to the point that taxpayers, not bill payers should fund them. Finally, a balanced order of  competition in the market should help build customers' trust.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Overall, our approach is to have a very open mind on reform. We know we have to earn continually the right to  make a profit in energy supply. With that right, goes the responsibility to make a profit that is fair and reasonable.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: The six months to September, saw us gain a small number of customers in Ireland. But this was outweighed by a  bigger loss in GB. So, we have seen a net fall in customer account numbers with a reduction of 190,000 to 9.41  million. Even so, our customer base is less than 3% smaller than it was at its peak in 2011. Given all that has  happened in the time since then, I think that means we have a solid energy supply business. In a very competitive  market, it's difficult to predict what customer account numbers will be at the end of this financial year, and it's not  the first key performance indicator in energy supply. The future is about value, not volume, which means this  business must be about gaining customers in the right way and retaining them for the long term.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Given some of the headlines in recent months, customers could be forgiven for thinking that this Retail and brand  stuff is all very well, but that it won't be much good if the lights go out. There's no doubt, as Ofgem put it, that the  risks to the security supplies over the next six winters have increased. The combination of tighter environmental  regulations, low spark spreads, prolonged uncertainty around Electricity Market Reform and the current  investment hiatus could definitely put security of supply into some pressure.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: The question for this morning is, what does this mean for SSE? The answer to that lies in the long-standing  principles that underpin the management of an investment in our generation portfolio. They bear repeating  because I think the next few years will show they're more relevant than ever. The principles are availability to  respond to customer demand and market conditions, capacity to meet the electricity needs of domestic and small  business customers, compliance with all safety standards and environmental requirements, diversity to avoid  over-dependence on particular fields or technologies, flexibility to ensure that changes in demand for electricity  and intermittency of wind generation can be addressed, and lastly, sustainability to reduce the CO2 intensity of  electricity generated through cost-effective decarbonization.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: In the six months to September, we invested £211.2 million on renewables and £151.9 million on thermal  developments. More indicators of progress in our investment program stand out, over 400 megawatts of  renewable energy capacity in construction or preconstruction with a further 300 megawatts consented. In Ireland,  the construction of the 460-megawatt plant in Great Ireland is in its advance stages with first electricity  generation expected to take place before the end of the financial year.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: At Fiddlers Ferry, we finished a significant trial of one unit which has reduced emissions of NOx to a level that  would enable additional electricity to be generated under the IED National Transition Plan. We're now looking to  see whether we can extend this solution to the other three units at the plant, although the government's response  to the Lords' vote on the emissions performance will be key to this.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: And finally, the 69-megawatt multi-fuel plant that our JV with Wheelabrator is building at Ferrybridge should be  generating electricity in 2015, and if successful and market conditions allow, could be the first in a series.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Take gas by generation in GB. Although Abernedd is close to being shovel ready, and others such as Keadby 2 are  at an advanced stage of development, continuing uncertainty around the operation of future capacity mechanism  and lack of other clear market signals for investment mean that we now don't expect to take any final decisions to  construct these projects until 2015-2016 at the earliest.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're working with JV partners and other stakeholders to scale back our involvement in wave and tidal  technologies, facilitate more third-party involvement in the future to help take projects forward to consent  application.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: On offshore wind, at the expense of the government's ambitions seems to be less than we and everyone else had  been led to believe. And this will have implications for our development portfolio, and though we're working hard  to maximize the prospects for both Galloper and Beatrice.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking at gas storage, we have good long-term assets at Hornsea and Aldbrough, but market returns are  challenging and too low encourage additional capacity. So, we've decided with Statoil not to progress with the  development in the second facility at Aldbrough until market conditions improve.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: In 2011, we made our first move into gas production. The primary reason was to secure a supply physical gas at a  fixed price. We've since added to our presence in the sector and completed the £127.6 million acquisition of the  Sean assets in April. This has helped to take our operating profit in gas production from £16.5 million to £69  million and our output from 80 million therms to 206 million therms. This means that our total portfolio gas  production assets represent around 3 billion therms or proven and probable reserves.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: We expect the volume and production profile of these assets to provide a secure and fixed price supply of gas that  should meet around 25% of the forecast amount from our domestic gas customers over the next three years. We'll  continue to look at opportunities to add to our asset base in gas production if it enables us to secure supplies of  physical gas at a sensible price.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: As an energy company, SSE has huge responsibilities. We're entrusted by Act of Parliament, originally to deliver  the best possible service for customers and invest in the right assets for the future energy needs of this country.  For doing this, we're able to pay dividends to shareholders who invest in us.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking across the business, from my vantage point, I believe that the capacity of SSE to meet its responsibilities  and meet the challenges over the next few years is enormous. But the challenges are clearly significant. They all  come down to the energy trilemma; affordability, security of supply, decarbonization. There's no doubt we are  currently facing the slings and arrows of political fortune.

file: SSEL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 12November2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: In a challenging business environment such as we now face, it's vital that companies have a clear purpose, a clear  strategy, and clear financial objective to achieve success over the long-term. SSE has all of these. Our core purpose  is to provide the energy people need in a reliable and sustainable way. Our strategy is to deliver the efficient  operational and investment in a balanced range of economically-regulated and market-based energy businesses in  the U.K. and Ireland. And our financial objective is to increase annually the dividend payable to shareholders by at  least RPI inflation.

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: Adding volume means, having an effective strategy supported by strong actions. We put in place, the GB markets  longest ever household energy price freeze, and we have well-defined plans for net investment of around £5.5  billion in the four years to 2018, maintaining, upgrading and building electricity assets customers depend on.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Looking now at our three business segments; in wholesale, operating profit is down 83.4% to £26.7 million,  mainly through lower electricity output and lower day ahead prices in gas production. In networks, operating  profit is up 4.7% to £458.4 million, mainly through our investment in transmission. And in retail, the operating  profit of £37.3 million follows a loss a year ago, and the improvement reflects the increase in tax last year and  lower wholesale costs offset by lower demand. Retail now includes the B2B enterprise business, which contributed  £42.9 million to operating profit, including a £15.3 million gain on the disposal of the gas pipelines business.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: We continue to use adjusted EPS to monitor financial performance over the medium term. We're currently  operating in a challenging business environment, and top of this, we had lower-than-normal production and  consumption of energy due to the weather.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: October, an important shoulder month was 1.6 degrees warmer than average. And November is also forecast to be  mild. This means, we now expect adjusted EPS for the full-year to be at the lower end of the range we set out in  March, and therefore to be around the same level as last year.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: In March, we also said that the wider energy sector issues like potential legislation and the price freeze could mean  our ability to increase EPS is subject to greater risk in the two years from April 2015. As we said back in March,  this also means dividend cover could temporarily fall below our target range of around 1.5 times, and in some  circumstances, could be closer to 1.2 times in 2016-2017. And this remains the case.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Over the four years to March 2018, we're looking at a CapEx program of around £5.5 billion net of disposals,  which are expected to total around £1 billion. This covers three main categories; committed spend, including  regulated networks, projects and construction and maintenance; land spend, which is the transmission link  between Caithness and Moray, the costs of which are currently out for consultation; and optional spend, which is  currently uncommitted, for that we may choose to spend to build new assets that we're still developing such as  onshore wind farms.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: When it comes to optional spend on new assets, we'll recycle capital from disposals to stay in line with the targeted  £5.5 billion net spend. As I said in March, we expect to secure financial benefit of around £1 billion from a  combination of the disposal of non-core assets and businesses and the sale of existing onshore wind farms in  order to recycle capital.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Following the £326 million street lighting deal we announced this morning, we've sold assets resulting in debt  reduction of around £400 million, and other sale processes are getting underway. The result is a simpler, more  focused SSE Group.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: In the case of onshore wind farms, we're confident we've achieved excellence in development and construction  and have some good opportunities to add new capacity before the Renewables Obligation deadline of 2017. To  enable us to do this, we'll continue to sell operating wind farms where we believe greater value can be secured  from investing in new ones. We believe there will be significant interest in those assets we decide to sell.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Special investments which earn returns that are clearly greater than the cost of capital help provide customers  with the energy they need. And they help us fulfill our first financial objective of annual dividend increases of at  least RPI inflation in this financial year and beyond.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: At £3.1 billion, electricity distribution remains the biggest single part of our RAV. The revenue for this business  has been adjusted as a result of the £25 million that was over-recovered last year and its operating profit also fell  to £215.7 million as a result of lower volumes of electricity distributed plus some additional costs.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Last autumn and winter presented us with eight exceptional weather events. In January, we consulted on what we  could do better in response to severe weather in the future. We've implemented a number of practical  improvements, such as doubling of investment in tree cutting, which we believe will benefit customers in the  coming winter months.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Good progress has been made with the major projects under construction. The key driver for these and for  projects under development, like Caithness-Moray link, is the need to accommodate renewable energy  developments in the north of Scotland.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: A total of £168 million was invested by SGN as a whole in the period, helping to take our share of the RAV of the  business to £2.45 billion. SGN is one of the best gas distributors in the country. It has a clear focus on safety,  reliability, and innovation to minimize the disruption for customers and communities arising from its capital  works. That clear focus, together with the further efficiencies and innovations to come should mean it's well- placed to deliver good results in the coming years.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We're simplifying our business and securing efficiencies, focusing on value and investment decision making,  easing the burden on bill-payers through our price freeze through 2016 and showing our appetite for reform and  our commitment to having a voice in the debate around energy markets and policy.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The CMA investigation is now well underway. We want to achieve a lasting political and regulatory stability for the  GB energy market for the benefit of both customers and investors. In our response to the CMA's Statements of  Issues, we pointed out that the GB energy market is generally well-functioning. We also highlighted specific areas  where there maybe potential for reforms to produce additional benefits for competition and customers.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: These include reforming the carbon price floor to improve longer-term liquidity, continuing to build transparency  around financial reporting, lowering and simplifying customers' bills by [ph] paying for (18:56) policy through  taxation, reviewing regulations that complicate bills and tariffs, and introducing a national charge for electricity  transportation to make price comparisons simpler.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Looking ahead to the UK general election, we published a series of proposals to deliver affordable, secure and low  carbon energy that we believe are consistent with the policy objectives of all the major parties. We'll continue to  argue for these proposals in the months ahead, and we remain optimistic that we can and will play a constructive  part in arriving and enduring political and regulatory settlement for the GB energy market.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: It's a market that's clearly competitive. While the retail segment, as a whole, achieved an operating profit of £37.3  million, we have again reported an operating loss of £16.9 million in energy supply. This is smaller than the loss in  2013, when rising costs ultimately forced us to increase household energy prices which we've frozen since.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The impact of milder weather, Gregor described earlier, can be seen in the marked fall in consumption of  electricity, and in particular, gas. Nevertheless, our customers now benefit from the longest every price freeze in  the energy market. This has certainly helped us to retain customers, although the exceptionally-competitive  market conditions mean that customer account numbers have fallen by 2.3% over the six months to 8.89 million.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: There is, however, no getting away from the fact that sales of our core products, electricity and gas, are on the  decline. This means our energy supply business has to evolve, if it is to prosper. Investing in the brand, as we have  done this autumn, is an important step in that direction.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We believe a practical program like this is exactly the right response to the challenges our energy supply business  currently faces. It does involve investment in systems amounting to around £27 million during the six months, to  enhance customer service and install smart meters.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The alternative, running for cash, will not be the right thing to do for customers or for the long-term well-being of  the business. As a dividend paying company, we have to be focused on long-term. The same applies to power  generation. And that's why six months results need to be treated with caution. Lower electricity output in  generation, lower day-ahead prices in gas production and the continuing issues in gas storage, all combined to  reduce operating profit in wholesale by 83.4%.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: One continuing issue is the very difficult market conditions affecting thermal plant, which is historically low spark  spreads, which have persisted now for several years, and which resulted in our thermal plant being loss-making in  the first half of the year.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Nevertheless, this does not detract from the underlying quality and value of our assets. We're continuing to invest  significantly in maintaining, upgrading and developing power generation plant, with CapEx across wholesale  totaling £208.4 million in the first half.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: From CCGTs in Ireland to multi-fuel in the Yorkshire or wind farms in Scotland, we continue to modernize our  generation portfolio to maintain the diversity that's been such a strong feature of SSE over the last 15 years.  Diversity of fuel and technology is an important feature of the secure electricity system, and security of supply is  looming large as an issue; a point illustrated by the Winter Outlook published last month by National Grid.  Between them, National Grid, Ofgem and DECC are confident that they have in place the right leader to keep the  lights on for households this winter.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: As one of the country's leading generators, we bring 10.1 gigawatts of capacity in GB, the most diverse fleet in the  market, flexible plant, a strong engineering capability to maximize plant availability and a commitment to working  constructively with Grid, Ofgem and DECC. All of this gives us a generation portfolio and capability with real long- term value.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We have wholly-owned thermal assets that can play an important part in keeping the lights on this winter;  Ferrybridge, where unit 3 returned to service before the end of last month; Fiddler's Ferry, where all four units  continue to operate; Medway, which has benefited from £48 million investment in reliability and flexibility; and  Peterhead, which has just secured a contract under the Supplemental Balancing Reserve, the 780 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We could operate unit 4 Ferrybridge, so it can contribute in security of the country's energy supply, but it will  require agreement they can run in parallel with unit 3.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In terms of other plants, Keadby is pre-qualified for the capacity auction and the investment made two years ago  means it will be able operate in more flexible and efficient way if and when it is brought back into service. On top  of this, our renewable assets have a part to play in security of supply as well. We have 300 megawatts of pump  storage at Foyers and over 1,100 megawatts of hydro electricity generation capacity.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Next month is the first capacity auction. We were pleased that all 7.2 gigawatts of de-rated capacity submitted by  us successfully pre-qualified. This includes around 3.6 gigawatts of gas-fired plant, 2.6 gigawatts of coal-fired  plant, and almost 1,000 megawatts of hydro and storage. The gas-fired plant includes Abernedd, which has been  shovel-ready for some time. Whether we take Abernedd to construction depends very much on the outcome of the  auction. The auction process itself is commercially confidential, but the introduction of the capacity market is a  welcome step in recognizing the value of security of electricity supply.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Contracts for Difference are also important – an important step forward in providing greater certainty for low  carbon generation. We were pleased when Abernedd's offshore wind farm secured an early CfD in April. This has  allowed us to continue to invest in the engineering and procurement work needed to maintain progress towards a  final investment decision in 2016.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In line with the plans we set out in March, we scale back our stake in the project to 50%. While we didn't  participate in the first full allocation ramp for CfDs, we continue to be a substantial developer of onshore wind  farms. We have 900 megawatts of capacity in construction with consent for development. This means we have  good opportunities to add new capacity before the RO deadline of 2017 and the same applies into CfDs.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Whatever the support mechanism, the test for these wind farms in Beatrice will be the same. Can they earn return  that are clearly greater than the cost of capital, and can they be funded within the capital program we defined last  March.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: One asset that has already passed those two tests is the new CCGT that we're developing in County Wexford. First  fire and system synchronization were achieved in September and the plant is on course for full commercial  commissioning around the end of the financial year.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Completion costs are [ph] likely throughout (27:23) turnaround £125 million over three years, and while capacity  is constrained to 431 megawatts for now, it will be the cleanest, most efficient and reliable gas power plant on the  Irish grid.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Like GB, the market [ph] known (27:38) is also undergoing significant change, with a high-level design for the  reform of the single [ph] Alt-50 (27:43) being published in September. This plus the government's green paper on  energy policy mean we are fully engaged in the regulatory and policy processes in Ireland.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: While change always brings both risk and opportunities, with comfortable SSE to maximize the opportunities that  emerge from these processes for a modern CCGT like Great Island and for our onshore wind farms.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Clearly, the challenges are not going away, and within nine months, we'll have the distribution price control,  capacity auction, the UK general election, and provisional findings and potential remedies from the CMA. They all  present a degree of uncertainty, but they also provide an opportunity to achieve a stable policy and regulatory  framework that gives customer's confidence, allows regulators to regulate, and encourages investors to invest in  the energy market.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Throughout the period to come, we will continue to be focused on delivering annual dividend growth that at least  matches RPI inflation, and thereby giving shareholders, a fair return on the investment they've made and are  making in the future energy needs of Britain and Ireland. Thank you.

file: SSEL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 11November2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: From this work, two key things are clear. First, there is a significant value in operating and investing in a balanced  range of energy assets and businesses. And second, within those businesses, we have a wide range of opportunities  to develop new assets on the one hand and new customer propositions on the other. This means that we're  confident that the foundations for continuing dividend growth are well laid.

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: We believe that policymaking should take a long-term view, should be clear and transparent, should respect  committed investments and have effective transitional arrangements where that is deemed necessary. We believe  strongly in a constructive engagement with policymakers and regulators. And that's the approach we'll maintain  as we work to achieve a long-term framework for the energy sector that benefits both investors and customers  alike.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: In the first half of this year, there has been high output of renewable energy benefiting Wholesale and relatively  good performance in Energy Supply. This is in marked contrast to the position a year ago when operating profit in  Wholesale was exceptionally low and Energy Supply reported an operating loss. As we said in September, this  means slightly that we've earned over one-third of our full year adjusted PBT in the first six months compared  with around a quarter last year.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: We've always focused on full year results and we manage our business, including the energy portfolio and phasing  of costs, accordingly. In addition, we're continuing to manage a wide range of issues across our Retail and  Wholesale activities, including the continuing negative trend in commodity prices and the generally challenging  outlook for market conditions.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Looking now at our three business segments. In Wholesale, operating profit has recovered to £159.6 million on  the back of a 38% increase in the output of renewable energy, reflecting wetter and windier conditions in Scotland  and Ireland during the spring and summer months. The relatively dry and still weather in October, however, saw a  fall in renewable output of around 50% compared with the year ago.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: And in Retail, the operating profit of £101.5 million reflects a return to profitability in Energy Supply compared  with a year ago. It follows a strong focus on operating cost and a better performance in the I&C sector. As I said  earlier, we manage business across the financial year as a whole. We still expect to report a decline in profit in  household Energy Supply at the year-end.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Last month, S&P affirmed our A-/A-2 rating, albeit, with a revised negative outlook, reflecting its opinion of the  impact of energy and commodity prices on the sector. As usual, we'll continue to engage actively with both  agencies and remain committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet and remain focused on the current criteria  for a single-A credit rating. We're confident we'll be able to mitigate the recent action by S&P on the treatment of  some of our hybrid securities, which will allow us to reinstate the 50% equity content.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: When it comes to investment decisions on new assets, we'll continue to recycle capital from disposals to stay in  line with the targeted net spend for the period of 2018. In line with our established value programme, we currently  expect to secure financial benefits in excess of £1 billion from the disposal of non-core assets and businesses and  from the sale of onshore wind farms on-developments.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: We've already sold and reached agreement to sell assets with a total value of just over £600 million. And the main  disposal programme on wind is now underway. This will enable us to recycle capital from current assets where  greater overhead value can be secured from investing in new ones, especially in the context of the renewables  obligation. As I said earlier, we have a strong and diverse asset base. That's where we wanted to stay and that  means retaining the ability to optimize what we build, what we own, and what we operate.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Investment in Distribution was £113 million which helps keep the lights on for customers. And that's our first  priority.
