We have, for example, what we believe is the only machine in the UK which allows tree felling to take  place without the need to switch off power lines, reducing both costs and the inconvenience experienced by our  customers.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: This example of innovation in our Electricity Distribution illustrates a wider point. The business is adapting to the  changing needs of customers and changes in the way in which electricity is produced. That will be a key theme for  us for the duration of the new price control. The price control that came in effect in April will, amongst other  things, deliver an underlying reduction of over 15% in the distribution part of the average household bill in our  Southern and Scottish areas.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Transmission's price control is now over two years old. This business is continuing to grow in a strong and  sustainable way and its RAV is now over £2 billion. This investment in the asset base is driving the sustained  growth in profitability, illustrated by the 44% increase in operating profit we've reported this morning.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Work is also well underway on the Caithness-Moray link, following Ofgem's approval of capital funding last  December. We invested £163 million in the project in the six months to September. Construction is progressing at  seven major substations and converted stations and has reached an important milestone last month with the start  of the installation of the HVDC land cable.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: As the RO example illustrates, policy and regulation loom large over our Wholesale businesses. Their role is to  provide energy and related services for energy market participants in GB and Ireland. And they continue to be  affected by macroeconomics, commodity prices, and the impact of decarbonization on how energy is produced  and used.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In this environment, results for any six-month period need to be treated with caution. In the first six months last  year, our Wholesale businesses contributed an exceptionally low amount of £26.7 million to operating profit. This  has recovered to £159.6 million this year with the main factor being the 38% increase in the amount of renewable  energy generated.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In terms of gas production at £14.1 million, first half operating profit slightly higher than year ago, although, the  outlook for the second half is more challenging. The economic environment for gas storage facilities has, however,  been persistently difficult, although, there has been some recovery in operating profit to £3.7 million through cost  savings.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Between them, the UK government, the National Grid and Ofgem have responsibility for security of supply, a  point affirmed by the Energy Act 2013. Last week's NISM demonstrated again that they have a range of tools and  options in place to keep the system running. The role of a company such as SSE is to ensure the generation plant is  available to generate in response to contractual obligations and at times when electricity demand is highest.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In Peterhead, Medway and Keadby, we have three flexible gas-fired power stations which can contribute  significantly to the stability of the electricity system. Peterhead secured a one-year contract from National Grid to  provide electricity reserve capacity totaling 750 megawatts under the 2015/2016 SBR. Medway has continued to  perform well in response to market requirements with a good level of availability to generate. And we've recently  broke Keadby after deep mothballed and secured transmission energy capacity. And so it should be in full  commercial operation before the end of the year.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: These three stations have benefited from significant investment to boost their reliability and flexibility. They  should play an important part in the country's energy system in the next few years. In doing so, they'll have the  opportunity to take part in the capacity market. So, while we're optimistic about the prospects for existing gas- fired power stations, the economics in new plants are different all together.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Our commitment to financial discipline means we have no plans to develop or build any new gas-fired plant in the  foreseeable future. In Ireland, however, our new CCGT at Great Island has completed six months of full  commercial operation. This has confirmed its position as the cleanest, most efficient and reliable gas power plant  on the Irish grid and a natural complement to our portfolio of renewables.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The future of coal-fired power stations, which are increasingly expensive to maintain and subject to major  environmental legislation and regulation, is clearly time-limited. As we said in May, it costs over £50 million a  year simply to keep a large coal-fired power station open. Environmentally, they're major emitters of CO2. Coal- fired generation at Ferrybridge will, as you know, end in March.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In terms of Fiddler's Ferry, the majority of the plant there has a capacity contract for a year from October 2018.  It's our intention to submit the plants into the forthcoming auction for providing capacity from 2019. We'll  reassess the options for the future operation of the station after the outcome of that auction is known. Including  Fiddler's, we successfully prequalified 6.1 gigawatts of de-rated capacity to take part in the auction.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In the meantime, in the coming months, we'll seek to operate as well as possible capacity at both Fiddler's Ferry  and Ferrybridge. And we'll also aim to use stations coal in the most efficient manner as well. The gradual end of  coal-fired generation is being accompanied by major changes in the way power is generated. At SSE, we're playing  our part in three key ways.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: First, we demonstrated through our joint venture our ability to develop and commission multi-fuel plant. The new  £300 million 69 megawatt plant at Ferrybridge uses a range of fuel sources derived from Yorkshire and the wider  area and is a sustainable energy solution in every sense of the word. I'm pleased we've secured consent to develop  a second plant of up to 90 megawatts, also at Ferrybridge, and expect the final investment decision to be taken in  2016.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Second, we're working with Shell in the development of the world's first full-scale gas carbon capture and storage  project and are close to completing the feed stage that started early in 2014. There will have to be a satisfactory  outcome for the government's CCS Commercialization Competition funding process. But we believe this is a  project with a strong environmental case that is worthy of the right level of economic support to ensure the  opportunity it represents can be realized.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The third feature of the progressive change in generation is renewables. SSE has developed a quality portfolio of  renewable energy assets across the UK and Ireland with hydro, onshore wind and offshore wind and with assets in  Scotland, England and Ireland. Since April 2010, we've invested £2.8 billion in renewables and completed around  800 megawatts of new onshore wind and 350 megawatts of offshore wind. In addition, Glendoe has been fully  operational since 2012 taking our conventional hydro capacity to 1,150 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Looking ahead, we have almost 600 megawatts of onshore wind farm capacity under construction at six sites in  Scotland and Ireland. Subject to the outcome of the judicial review, we also hope to be able to complete  Stronelairg as a result of the proposed growth periods. This means we're on course to add significant additional  capacity in Scotland and Ireland before the RO comes to an end.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Looking offshore, the Beatrice project, in which we currently have a 50% stake, already has an early CfD. And  we're continuing to do the engineering, environment and procurement work that's needed to maintain progress  towards a final investment decision in 2016. The phasing out of ROCs for new projects and the introduction of  competition for support through CfDs will change the way projects are developed and constructed.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: There are, however, three things that we need to take account of in considering the place of renewables in our  generation portfolio and in our investment plans overall: the cumulative impact of changes in the way electricity is  being produced and the potential for market harmonization and interconnection; our disciplined approach to  capital investment and in particular our planned net spend of £5.5 billion for the full years to 2018; and our  commitment to maintaining a balanced portfolio of businesses and assets within Wholesale and between  Wholesale and other main businesses.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: For these reasons, we're selling existing onshore wind farms in-developments in order to recycle capital. We've  already sold wind farm assets and projects for a total consideration of over £100 million. As part of our disposal  programme, we've invited bids for further assets and are planning to recycle capital where we believe greater value  can be secured from investing in new assets across the business. This should help to take the total financial benefit  from our overall value programme to in excess of £1 billion.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We've been involved with gas production since 2010. And in line with our focus on maintaining a balanced range  of energy businesses, the acquisition we completed in October was part of a well-established strategy. It also  completes SSE's portfolio of gas production assets for the foreseeable future. Production from the newly acquired  assets is expected to continue until the early 2030s making them a long-term investment and include the Shetland  Gas Plant critical pieces, state-of-the-art industry infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Amongst other things, investment in gas production assets help secure energy for customers and customers are  rightly at the heart of the energy related debates currently taking place in the UK and Ireland. Over the last couple  of years, we've seen particularly competitive market conditions. And our customer count numbers have fallen in  the first six months of the financial year to 8.41 million. We have, however, maintained a strong focus on  operational and financial efficiencies.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: This, combined with better performance in the I&C sector, helped Energy Supply to return to profitability in the  first six months, having sustained an operating loss in the same period last year. Nevertheless, we manage our cost  base and our NG portfolio across the full financial year and continue to expect domestic Energy Supply operating  profit to fall over the financial year as a whole.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: To develop our Energy Supply business further, we've launched an industry-leading offer on broadband in line  with our commitment to offer customers more Home Services, actively apply the principles of treating customers  fairly with clear industry leadership in complaints management, taking a series of other substantive steps to  improve customer service, invested in delivering new systems to help customers such as our Home Services  business, invested in a fundamental overhaul of digital channels for our customers, and added to the positive  profile of our brand through sponsorships of arenas at the Hydro, Wembley and Belfast and the SSE Women's FA  Cup.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The investment in digital communications, along with the smart meter rollout, has required considerable  investment across the six months. We spent around £70 million on Energy Supply and related services in what  amounts to a significant modernization of the business. We believe this plan will put us in a strong position to  retain and gain customers as the shape of the retail energy market becomes clearer over the coming year and as  the rollout of smart meters begins to make an impact.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Clearly, the shape of the market is going to be influenced by the conclusions of the CMA. While it means that the  degree of uncertainty about the final shape of the Energy Supply market remains, the decision of the CMA to  extend this investigation is, as I said earlier, prudent because it implies appropriate degree of caution about any  recommendations.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Retail includes the B2B Enterprise business which contributed £16.5 million in operating profit in the first six  months of the year. The business is just over 18 months old. But as customers' energy management and  infrastructure requirements evolve, we believe we've created a business that has a potential to achieve significant  and sustainable growth. To do this, we will have to integrate products and services further, keep pace with changes  in energy production and consumption, and achieve excellence in customer relationship management.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In the last six months, we've delivered solid results on EPS and PBT and, most importantly, delivered our  dividend growth target. We've also made significant progress in terms of our key priorities in the first half of the  financial year. In Wholesale, we've completed the multi-fuel plant at Ferrybridge, developed enhanced roles for  Peterhead and Keadby power stations, acquired new gas production and infrastructure assets and began the  disposal of onshore wind farm assets.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We'll retain that constructive approach as the CMA completes its investigation and as the government takes  forward its energy policy programme. And in a changing and challenging sector, we'll take the operational,  financial, and investment decisions necessary to ensure SSE is well placed to deliver for investors and customers  alike over the long-term.

file: SSEL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 9November2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: In May, we said there was an emerging policy and regulatory framework, within which we could do business  successfully in the years ahead. The EU result doesn't necessarily change that and we are encouraging ministers  to provide stability by maintaining the policy framework that has emerged over the last few years. And that now  includes retaining the ability to access and trade with European electricity and gas markets.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our half-year results are in line with what we set out in our pre-course statement in September. In Wholesale, the  fall in operating profit to £121 million was mainly the result of lower output of renewable energy compared with a  year ago, partly offset by an improved contribution from the thermal portfolio. Gas Production was affected by  commodity prices and challenging market conditions continued to prevail in Gas Storage.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Operating profits in Networks saw an expected decrease in transmission due to the phasing of CapEx and  revenue, which was more than offset by increases in both Electricity and Gas Distribution. Operating profit in  Retail fell to £60.5 million as a result of increasing non-energy cost and the lower number of customer accounts in  Energy Supply, and there were lower operating profits in both Energy-related Services and Enterprise where the  focus is on investing for long-term growth.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The Stronelairg onshore wind farm represents such an opportunity for the SSE group. After meeting transaction- related costs, we plan to donate around £100 million of the proceeds to supporting the Stronelairg investment and  return around £500 million to shareholders by way of an on-market share buyback. We would expect to execute  that by the end of 2017. Thereafter, the ongoing EPS impact of the sale and how the proceeds are used should  be broadly neutral.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Since April 2010, excluding our share of SGN's CapEx, we've invested around £10 billion across the SSE group.  Around £7 billion of this was in Electricity Networks and Renewables. In 2010, including [indiscernible] (09:33), we  had 2.3 gigawatts of renewable energy capacity in operation and an Electricity Networks RAV of £3 billion. As a  result of our investment and our renewables capacity in operation should be almost around 50% greater at around  3.6 gigawatts, at the end of this financial year. And our Electricity Networks RAV should have doubled to £6  billion.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In this financial year, we've already invested £782.4 million and with the Stronelairg opportunity, we're on course  to invest around £1.85 billion for the year as a whole, which would be our highest ever. Next year, we expect to  invest around £1.75 billion. This is part of our full year CapEx program that is now likely to total closer to £6 billion  when it is completed in 2020. Economically regulated networks and government-mandated renewables will  account for around two-thirds of this expenditure.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: I'll now turn to Networks. Although the shape of our Networks business is evolving, it's clear that the relative  stability of the returns from them and their index-linked RAV and revenues continue to bring balance to SSE as a  whole and support our target for annual dividend growth. The index-linked point is particularly important given  some economists forecast for inflation. And as Alistair will point out, it also applies to renewable energy support  schemes as well.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Before the sale of the SGN stake, we were looking at total Networks' RAV of around £10 billion by 2020.  Following the sale, the total RAV of our Networks business is now £7.4 billion until it's well placed to reach £9  billion by 2020. At £3.2 billion, Electricity Distribution remains the biggest single part of our RAV. As expected, this  business assume the benefit of revenue arising from under recovery and incentives from 2 years ago. And  despite more challenging weather conditions in the spring and the summer, it is continuing to perform well in  terms of the number and duration of power cuts.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: This is allied to further investment in network resilience including additional automation, other innovations and  targeted tree cutting. This means that the Distribution business remains on course to achieve the performance as  targeted for the period of the price control.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Gregor, and good morning, everyone. While the UK, and to some extent Ireland, focuses on the  economic, political and social consequences of the Brexit vote, it's easy to lose sight of the extent to which there's  been continually continuity in the overall direction of policy and regulation over the last few months. The UK  government has accepted the fifth carbon budget proposed by the Committee on Climate Change. They've  confirmed the forms of the capacity market and CMA's final remedy confirming its two-year market investigation  were as expected.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Also this morning, for the eagle-eyed amongst you and not too bleary-eyed amongst you, government has also  announced further CfD auctions in April of next year for offshore wind and consultations around coal and Ireland  CfDs. All of it is welcome. However, this is not to suggest that we foresee a benign period with no political or  regulatory risk. It is a fact of life in energy. With a political cycle increasingly built around autumn statement and  spring budgets, there's always some uncertainty and always a need for us to be politically aware and engage  constructively with politicians and regulators.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: But two key points continue to stand out for me. First, while there's always change, the sector continues to feature  robust economic regulations for network, a remuneration framework for providing generation capacity and a  competitive retail market. Second, SSE is focused on maintaining and investing in a balanced range of  businesses that's not only designed to realize opportunities across the energy value chain, but manage the risks  associated with it as well. In the current environment, this is illustrated by the fact that the majority of our forecast  earnings for the full financial year have a link to RPI inflation.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The principal of strength to diversity applies to the SSE group and to our Wholesale businesses as well. These  businesses continue to be impacted by a number of key issues, including an uncertain macroeconomic  environment, the ongoing transition to a low carbon economy, and shift in commodity prices. In EPM and  Generation, the diversity of our assets and contracts mitigates the volatile power market conditions we've seen in  recent weeks which could have wide-ranging impact.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: While in the first six months, the impact of lower output from our renewables is being partially offset by improved  contribution from our thermal portfolio; those power stations operate in a very complex environment. They derive  revenue from a number of sources including a variety of contracts and operate in the context of a wider set of  energy portfolio management decisions. All of this means changes in spark and dark spreads may not always be  reflected in the financial performance of our generation plant.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In terms of Gas Production, commodity prices remained a key issue. Even so, we're pleased with the  performance and output from our assets since they were commissioned. An improvement is expected in the  second half of the financial year.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Gas Storage remains a very challenged business and we've taken the decision to mothball two of the nine  caverns of Atwick. This was a difficult decision, but in terms of maintaining our financial discipline, the right one.  The Atwick facility is already fully impaired.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: As I said earlier, we welcome the UK government's endorsement to the fifth carbon budget and of the planned  reforms for the capacity market. At the same time, the market and framework within which it operates are always  subject to change and we have to monitor and manage continuously the shape of our portfolio of assets and  contracts accordingly.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The next key market milestones are the capacity auctions in December and January. The results of  prequalification clearly demonstrate the range and diversity of existing assets that we have to offer the country's  electricity system. As you know, we've also secured prequalification for a potential second gas -fired power station  at Keadby. These are competitive processes, but in keeping with our overall approach to financial discipline, I can  say that we'll always take a rational approach to our participation in auctions.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: And as we demonstrated with Fiddler's Ferry earlier this year, we'll always take a responsible approach  considering options for the future operation of assets. The benefits of that approach are clear. An important time  when the UK electricity market is fundamentally changing as can be seen in the graph on this slide, Fiddler's  Ferry remains an important shorter-term option for the GB electricity system and for SSE. As the market features  significant volatility with high and low prices on the same day, the importance of a diverse and flexible portfolio of  assets has never been greater.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: At the same time, the Clyde disposal earlier this year showed the value of renewable energy assets have never  been clearer and with high inflation forecast, it's important that the renewables obligation is linked to RPI.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking further ahead, we retain other options in on and offshore wind and if future CfD auctions or other  developments provide the opportunity to deploy the capability we've built over the last decade, then we'll look to  do so. This could include other pro-wind jurisdictions.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: As I said earlier, we expect Gas Production's results to improve in the second half of the financial year. And we  remain confident about the long-term prospects for this business. Our new assets are fully commissioned and  operating well.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking to the 5 years to 2021, the Greater Laggan Area acquisition is expected to mean an average annual  volume of gas produced will be around 500 million therms of liquids in addition to that. Naturally, they'll benefit  from higher commodity prices that have prevailed since the acquisition. They represent a substantial collection of  assets that contributes to the overall balanced nature of the energy businesses in the SSE group. On top of that,  the Shetland Gas Plant is a critical piece of state-of-the-art infrastructure that will generate a return for SSE into  the 2020. Overall, these assets are a natural complement for a company that operates gas-fired power stations  and supplies gas to customers.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: As I've said before, everything SSE does is ultimately paid for by customers. And as a group of energy  businesses, we must always remember how important it is that people can afford to pay their bills. Today's results  were a reminder of the competitive nature of the markets in which all of our retail businesses operate. In fact,  although we made a profit in energy supply as a whole, we recorded a small loss in supplying household gas and  electricity.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: As far as energy supply as a whole is concerned, we have three clear priorities. The first is to build our presence  in the I&C market. To do that, our Business Energy team is transforming what it offers customers in the  commercial sector and the associated services it provides.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The second is ensuring we offer customers what they're looking for in terms of products, service and value. The  net loss of customer accounts slowed in the first half of the year. Part of the reason for that is that we competed  successfully for over 350,000 new customer accounts across energy supply and related services in the first half.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Both smart metering and the CMA remedies have financial consequences across the sector and put the onus on  us to take cost out of the business, which we are doing. Excluding the meters themselves, we have so far  invested over £250 million in the smart rollout and the PPM price cap will have an estimated revenue impact of  over £40 million per annum. But we have to go [ph] with a grain (26:52) in areas such as this. That means doing  our best to implement what is expected of us while working with the government and Ofgem to be clear about the  challenges and their potential impact on customers.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking at Energy-related Services, our Home Services customer account numbers have continued to rise. At  440,000, they're up 10% since the start of the financial year. This represents a positive step forward in delivering  our strategy and diversifying the range of products and services we offer to customers. While operating profit is  down in the first six months, progress has been made in this business. We've launched market-leading boiler  cover propositions as we move closer to completing the national expansion of our Home Services business, and  we've introduced a range of market-leading and well-subscribed tariff in broadband. At the same time, delivering  these service and propositions has to be supported by good customer service. And I'm optimistic that our long- term plan to build scale in this business will bear fruit.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Capital investment will, however, continue to be a major engine for growth over the next few years. Over the 4  years to 2020, we now expect CapEx to be closer to the £6 billion mark. The reason for this is that we intend to go  ahead with the 225-megawatt Stronelairg onshore wind farm following the ruling in favor of the project from the  Court of Session in July. Although it's not without its challenges, the Windfarm project should secure accreditation  under the renewables obligation, and we're expecting investment in it to total around £300 million.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Including Stronelairg, we now have a net total of over 1 gigawatt of wind farm capacity at various stages of  construction. In addition to seven onshore projects, the Beatrice Offshore project, of which our share is 235  megawatts, is also now well underway and on course for completion in 2019. We're also building a second multi- fuel plant at Ferrybridge.

file: SSEL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 8November2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: Now, in addition to encouraging results for the first half of the financial year, we have today announced a planned  transaction, and as described on the slide, that will create a new independent energy supplier. We plan to  implement the transaction in a single step by demerging our GB household energy supply and services  businesses and combining it with npower's GB household business – energy supply business, and then listing the  new supplier on the stock exchange.

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: We envisage that the proportion of the new energy supplier to be demerged to our existing shareholders will be  65.6%. Expect that this will all take place at the end of 2018 or early 2019. We hope that all the stages of this  transaction and associated approvals will be completed by the last quarter of 2018 or the first quarter of 2019. We  are in absolutely no doubt that separating the businesses in this way is the right thing to do both for customers  and gives us a greater opportunity to earn returns for our investors.

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: We believe that creating a new independent energy supply business in Great Britain and a new market model,  combining the resources of two established players, with the focus and agility of an independent supplier is the  right response to all of the trends in the GB energy supply market. We also believe that focusing the other parts of  the SSE Group on building, owning and operating energy and infrastructure assets is the right response to  transition to a lower carbon future and keeping with SSE's core competencies.

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: In renewing SSE in this way, we are giving each of its businesses the best platform to succeed and a greater  opportunity to earn returns for investors. As SSE itself changes, we are and will remain committed to energy  provision that meets the customer needs and to remunerating shareholders' investment through the payment of  dividends.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're then focusing on creating the best platform for our businesses' future success from 2019 onwards. For  SSE, our dividend and dividend policy will reflect the quality and nature of our assets and operations, the earnings  derived from them and the long-term financial outlook. Following the demerger, we expect the target DPS  increase to be at least RPI inflation. The new energy supply company will benefit from the combination of  resources and being a stronger retail competitor with the opportunity to secure efficiencies. We believe this will  make it an attractive proposition.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The results for individual businesses are also in line with what we set out in September. In Wholesale, operating  profit rose to £159.9 million with improved performance in EPM and Generation, aided by higher electricity output,  and in Gas Production, aided by a higher achieved gas price. In Networks, operating profit fell to £355.1 million, in  line with the expected position for Networks for the financial year as a whole following the sale of the SGN stake  and the reduction in revenue in Transmission.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: And in Retail, although household energy supply experienced a loss, operating profit increased to £70.3 million  through improved performance in energy-related services and Enterprise. Although we focus on our adjusted  measure, the reported position for each of our businesses is set out in this morning's statement. In May, we talked  about delivering value from reshaping SSE, and that is continuing. A year ago, we secured £621 million for a  16.7% stake in SGN, having paid £505 million for a 50% stake 11 years before. This demonstrated the value of  our Networks businesses.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In August, we completed the sale of a 5% stake in the enlarged Clyde onshore wind farm development, with an  implied valuation of the wind farm extension of £3 million per megawatt of capacity. This showed the value of our  renewable energy portfolio, and there is in place an option agreement for the sale of a further 14.9% for the wind  farm as a whole.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We have a longstanding commitment to recycle capital where we can see value for shareholders. We're already  using around £100 million from the SGN proceeds to support the Stronelairg wind farm investment. It remains on  course to secure [indiscernible] (09:58) and contribute significantly to future earnings. We've also committed to  returning value to shareholders through the £500 million share buyback we started after the SGN sale. So far, we  have completed buybacks totaling around £400 million and still expect to complete it by the end of December.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Excluding SGN, we've invested £11.6 billion across the SSE Group since 2010. Around £8.3 billion of this was in  regulated electricity networks and government-mandated renewables. In 2010, including pumped storage, we had  2.4 gigawatts of renewable energy capacity in operation. That's now over 50% greater at 3.7 gigawatts.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Also in 2010, we had an electricity networks RAV of £3 billion, that's more than doubled to over £6 billion. Across  the two areas, this has created a new modern asset base that is sustainable, provides index-linked earnings,  supports dividend growth and creates long-term value for the SSE Group.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In the first six months of this financial year, we invested £780 million across the SSE Group and remain on course  to invest around £1.7 billion for the year as a whole. Overall, we estimate that SSE has invested around £900  million in onshore wind assets, Beatrice still in construction or have yet to contribute to full years worth of  earnings. We also expect to invest around £1.7 billion next year, which means we're on course to invest around  £6 billion across the four years to March 2020.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Economically regulated networks and government mandated renewables will account for around two-thirds of this  spend. There are also opportunities in thermal generation. We're therefore adding to an asset base, that is  already of very high-quality, which through RAV growth and renewable energy output in particular, paves the way  for future sustainable earnings.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our CapEx program is already focused on networks and renewables. And that, plus the expected timing for  completing the transaction, means we don't expect this morning's announcement with regard to retail to change  materially our CapEx plan. Clearly, we won't be incurring any retail-related CapEx after completion.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In August, we issued the biggest ever green bond by UK company, and the first of its kind issued by UK- headquartered energy company. This showed SSE's commitment to sustainability and responsibility principles  and also showed our commitment to maintain a strong balance sheet and strong market rating, allowing this €600  million of funding to be secured at a coupon of 0.875%.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We are also confident of our ability to deliver the all important dividend increase in the next financial year.  Thereafter, we expect to create value to establishing a new independent energy supplier and to have a dividend  policy for the remaining SSE Group that reflects truly the quality and nature of its assets, operations and earnings  including the key index-linked and financial outlook.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: I'll now turn to Networks. The shape of our Networks business over the years has evolved. With the relative  stability of returns from them and their index-linked RAV and revenues, as I have just mentioned, we underpin our  target for annual dividend growth. The index-linked point remains particularly important giving some economist  forecast for inflation. And it also applies to renewable energy support schemes as well.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Including SGN, the total RAV of our Networks businesses is now over £8 billion. And so, it's well placed to reach  close to £9 billion by 2020. With almost £1.8 billion share of RAV, we retained an important stake in SGN, and its  new shareholding structure gives it greater flexibility in its future development. The business is continuing to  evolve with the construction of a third distribution network comprising 700 kilometers of new gas pipelines to the  west of Belfast.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: With backing of shareholders, it has also launched a Meter Asset Provider company which will fund the purchase  and installation of smart meters on behalf of energy suppliers.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: It's also delivering an innovation program designed to ensure that gas has a secure long-term future in the UK  mix. That's almost £3.4 billion, electricity distribution remained the biggest single part of our RAV. It continues to  adapt to the RIIO-ED1 framework and delivers significant changes to its operations, processes and standards to  meet the needs of customers and it deliver against the measures offset by the Price Control.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Ofgem started the process of preparing for RIIO-2 which has opened latter in July. It really wants to give  customers a stronger voice in the RIIO process and also acknowledges the changes in the energy system.  [indiscernible] (20:41) one of Ofgem's stated aims for RIIO-2 [ph] has allowed companies (20:44) to earn returns  that are fair and represent good value for customers and we're confident of playing a constructive part that helps  achieve [ph] lateral (20:54) important aim.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: One of the biggest changes in the energy system is the flexibility revolution. Distributed generation, electric  vehicles, demand-side response and energy storage are transforming our energy system and giving customers  access to new products and services from a new range of providers.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The transition from network operator to system operator is now underway. Using non-network solutions such as  flexible demand to make the most of existing assets [ph] on the road to be a (21:31) neutral facility [ph] to unlocks  (21:33) local solutions.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: While technology is driving this change, we're maintaining a clear focus in solutions that work best for our  customers and the communities we serve. We just have [ph] set right (21:47) our approach to this transition in a  new publication called Supporting a Smarter Electricity System. And I think we'll make an important contribution  as this transition moves forward.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Gregor, good morning, everyone. We said in May that this substantial sector change will reflect that  change fully in all of the operational, investment, and strategic decisions that we make. That has always been the  SSE way. Next year, for example, marks the 10th anniversary of the UK's Climate Change Act and SSE's  acquisition of Airtricity. A decade on, we're as committed as ever to taking the decisions necessary to secure the  right outcomes for customers and shareholders.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: I'll say more about this morning's announcement on Retail shortly. But as Richard said earlier, we believe that in  creating a new independent energy supply business in Great Britain and a new market model combining the  resources of two established players with the focus and agility of an independent supplier is the right response to  all of the trends in the GB energy supply market.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We also believe that following the proposed separation of Retail, we'll maintain a balanced range of related  businesses, creating value by specializing in building, owning and operating energy and infrastructure assets that  support the transition to a lower carbon future.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our Wholesale businesses continue to be impacted by macroeconomic uncertainty, the ongoing transition to a  low-carbon economy and shift in commodity prices. In EPM and Generation, the diversity of our contracts and  assets helps mitigate the volatile energy market conditions, which can have wide-ranging impact. In volatile  markets, we have to monitor and manage continuously the shape of our portfolio of assets and contracts to  ensure we're delivering the best outcome for energy customers and shareholders. The importance of diversity and  flexibility has never been greater.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our Gas Generation assets have seen a recovery in financial performance with their flexibility making important  contribution to the electricity balancing market. We set out that we see a future for Peterhead Power Station  subject to confirmation of a planned regulatory change from April 2018. If this change is adopted, we intend to  continue to operate Peterhead assets full capacity.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: More broadly, we believe [ph] there's a major, if evolving, (26:47) role for gas-fired generation to play in the future.  We're making good progress in constructing the second multifuel plant in Ferrybridge and believe there's potential  for further development of multifuel power generation.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In terms of both gas and multifuel, our commitment to disciplined investment decision-making applies. We have to  be confident as we're carrying returns that are clearly greater than the cost of capital and contribute to earnings  and dividend growth well into the future.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In the meantime, strategic disciplined capital investment in building new, modern assets is already a major engine  for growth over the next few years. In onshore wind, we made good progress in constructing new wind farm  capacity with over 400 megawatts completed in the first half of this financial year, including Ireland's largest wind  farm of Galway and a further 128 megawatts is on course to be completed by March. We also have a 228  megawatts Stronelairg wind farm in construction and all of this capacity should qualify for the RO or REFIT  support.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: As our current arrangements to hedge the risks associated with renewable energy generation unwind, the  benefits of the returns earned from this investment in onshore wind will be reflected in the adjusted EPS and  dividend towards the end of this decade and beyond.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In offshore wind, our capacity share at Beatrice is 235 megawatts. The construction on and offshore are now well  underway, the project is on course to be fully operational in 2019, at which point we'll have 579 megawatts net of  offshore wind farm capacity.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The completion in Beatrice and other projects is expected to take SSE's total renewable capacity in operation to  4.3 gigawatts by the end of 2019. And in a typical year, this should enable us to generate around 12 terawatt  hours of electricity from renewable sources from 2020 onwards. The earnings from this will underpin the dividend  for years to come.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Within our renewables portfolio, we have diversity through onshore wind, offshore and, of course, hydro, as  electricity generation has changed, so too the role of hydro. In addition to the pumped storage scheme at four  years, we have over 400 megawatts of fast, flexible hydro capacity with a storage function that allows each hydro  schemes to function more effectively than ever as [ph] nature's batteries (29:15). The diversity and flexibility of the  pumped storage and conventional hydro contribute [indiscernible] (29:21) system will be of significant value in the  years ahead.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: As the Beatrice and Clyde disposals have shown, the value of renewable energy assets is clear, and with higher  inflation in the pipeline, it's important that renewable obligation and CfDs are index-linked. Looking ahead, we  retain a number of options in on and offshore winds such as the projects as Seagreen, Arklow and Dogger Bank,  where we now have a 50/50 joint venture with Statoil, covering up to 3.6 gigawatts of potential capacity.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're now working closely with Statoil to consider all the options available to us in order to develop the Dogger  Bank project. This includes examining in detail the outcome of the most recent CfD auction. Taking account of all  the factors, a future CfD auctions or other developments provide the opportunity to deploy the capability we built  up over the last decade and we would clearly love to do so.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our Greater Laggan Area assets are operating well and the Edradour and Glenlivet fields started production  ahead of schedule in August. In line with this, the production for the full current financial year is expected to be  weighted to the second half. These are important long-term assets and expected to make an important  contribution to operating profit with our annual volumes of gas and liquids produced expected to average around  500 million therms between now and 2020.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: On top of that, the Shetland Gas Plant is a critical piece, a state-of-the-art industry infrastructure in a location that  is central for future gas production in the UK and which will generate a return for SSE into the 2030.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We have around 470,000 Business Energy customer accounts and we want to build a greater presence in this  market. To do that, our Business Energy team is offering a range of energy contracts tailored to the customers'  needs and adding value by providing business customers with advice and support in managing their energy  usage. This is backed up by a high quality of service, by growing credentials and commitment to sustainable  business conduct.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Subject to the completion of the transactions we've announced this morning, we'll take SSE forward on the basis  of creating a retail business with the new independent energy supply, capable of realizing significant synergies  and focus on the changing needs of energy customers. And developing a new business model featuring  networks, enterprise and wholesale with a clear focus on creating value from building, owning and operating  assets, play a part in the transition to a lower carbon energy and infrastructure future.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We believe that the creation of the new energy supply business we have announced provides three important  opportunity. We will combine resources with independence, bringing together the resources and insights of two  established players with both the focus and agility of an independent supplier geared entirely towards the needs  of retail customers.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: It'll be able to secure significant cost savings. It will ultimately enable us to be a strong, new competitor in this  market, competing more effectively and contributing to lower cost to customers. And it will be able to adopt the  best-of-both of existing supplies whether it's innovative programs to help vulnerable customers or deploying new  technology to transform customers' experience of energy supply. All of this will make it capable of providing an  attractive and fair return on investment.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In addition to enabling the creation of a new standalone energy supplier, able to make a major positive impact on  the GB market, we believe this morning's announcement paves the way for a renewed SSE Group that will make  a major contribution to transforming energy provision in GB and Ireland in the years ahead.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We will maintain a balanced range of related businesses, creating value from specializing in building, owning and  operating assets, to play a part in the transition to a lower carbon energy and infrastructure future. We believe the  refocused SSE will benefit from a greater focus on assets and infrastructure, which is more aligned to SSE's core  competencies and investor base.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: At the same time, we'll continue to use our balanced and diverse business model, efficient and disciplined  approach, the excellence in asset building, owning and operating and its visibility and understanding of the whole  energy value chain to deliver for customers, investors and community [ph] doing (35:55) transition to a lower  carbon future.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: As Greg had said earlier, after the planned transaction is completed, we are committed to a dividend policy that  reflects the quality and nature of our assets and operations, the earnings derived from them, and the longer-term  financial outlook. Based on the last three years only, around 80% of the operating profit of the reshaped business  have been derived from economically regulated networks or government mandated renewable sources of energy,  much of which is index-linked.

file: SSEL - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 14November2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The last few weeks have clearly been difficult. Analysts' notes haven't made for comfortable reading and  shareholders' feedback hasn't made for easy listening. I regret that the EPM situation cannot be overstated and  nor can our disappointment that the Energy Services transaction is proving more difficult to complete than we  expected. In respect of EPM, we've taken significant action to limit future exposures in this financial year and the  next, and to define a clear new strategy to managing commodity price exposures giving investors enhanced  visibility. And in respect of the Energy Services transaction, we're continuing to do all the work we can to seek to  achieve the formation and listing of the new company, while recognizing there can be no certainty the transaction  will be completed as originally planned.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In terms of where we go from here, let me be clear about three things. First, in assessing any potential changes to  the commercial terms of the Energy Services transaction, the interest of customers, employees and shareholders  will be paramount. Second, we still believe that the best future for the Energy Services business is outside the  SSE Group and we remain committed to the strategy we set out in May for creating value from focusing on  economically-regulated Networks and Renewables. Third, we've made material progress across our investment  program in key assets like Caithness‐Moray, Stronelairg and Beatrice, and they will deliver sustainable value for  many years to come. We intend to build on that and focusing on those core businesses, we're also aiming to give  greater visibility of assets, earnings, and value for investors. That's what lies behind the plan we've announced  this morning to create SSE Renewables.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Although the last few months have presented particular challenges in relation to EPM and Energy Services, it's  the value and quality of our core Networks and Renewables businesses and their financial outlook that underpins  our five-year dividend plan. This morning's interim dividend of £0.293, up 3.2%, is the first step in delivering that  plan and we look forward to recommending a full year dividend of £0.975 per share in May. Later, I'll say more  about how we will focus even more on those core businesses of Networks and Renewables, and about the  significant progress made in positioning them for sustained value creation.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Alistair, and good morning, everyone. These results reflect the fact that Energy Services is being held  for disposal, and therefore accounted for as a discontinued operation with the resulting needs to restate the  September 2017 and March 2018 position for the SSE Group. The results themselves are actually ahead of  where we expected to be in September, although clearly well short of what we hope to achieve at the start of the  financial year.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: On a like-for-like basis, adjusted PBT is down 41% to £246.4 million and adjusted EPS is down 40% at £0.196.  The exceptional items include two Renewables-related gains totaling £88.4 million, and in Energy Services,  property impairment and transaction costs totaling £67.1 million. Most of those transactions costs actually relate  to the business hive down.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The planned SSE Energy Services transaction is in line with our strategic theme of focus, visibility of assets and  earnings, and platform for success for each of our businesses. Since then, the Energy Services business has  been successfully hived down from the rest of the SSE Group. The CMA has confirmed that the planned  transaction does not raise competition concerns and key appointments have been made and integration planning  has made good progress.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're not in a position to comment on the discussions until we issue an update on their progress, which we will do  as soon as we can, and by mid-December by the latest. But I can say four things. First, the issues in EPM have  had no bearing, whatsoever, on the progress or terms of the transaction. The two things are totally unrelated.  Second, we continue to believe that creating a new independent energy supplier has the potential to deliver real  benefits for customers and the market as a whole, and that remains our objective.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Third, in assessing potential changes to the commercial terms of the proposed transaction, the interests of  customers, employees and shareholders will be paramount. For this reason, there is less certainty it will be  completed as originally envisaged. Fourth, as Alistair said, we still believe the best future for the Energy Services  business is outside the SSE Group, and we remain committed to the strategy we set out in May to focus on  economically-regulated networks and renewables.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking now at results for the Wholesale businesses, adjusted operating profit fell from £159.9 million to £2.3  million, reflecting the impact of the issues in EPM and renewables. In renewables, lower output along with lower  achieved prices contributed to a 50% fall in adjusted operating profit to £74.8 million. The drop also reflects the  fact that last year's results benefited from a £24 million gain on disposal. Output since September has been more  encouraging.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking at the EPM position, the adjusted operating loss of £85.9 million for the six months is lower than the £100  million forecast in September, due to [ph] thermal (9:33) prices being more favorable than expected. The adverse  movement on operating derivatives under IFRS 9 of £565.4 million arose mainly from a deterioration in the fair  value of forward gas contracts. Whilst indicative of the direction of travel, there are limitations to IFRS 9 if using it  to assess SSE's commodity exposure, namely; the IFRS 9 values do not reflect all contracts, but only those  designated as held for trading; and the IFRS 9 movement in operating derivatives represents the position up to  September 30, 2018 and does not reflect price movements and actions taken since that date.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We set out today a new approach to managing commodity price exposures and giving investors the maximum  possible visibility over it. Looking ahead, SSE will be exposed to variations in the value of energy commodities  through activities in renewables, flexible thermal generation, Business Energy sales, and Gas Production. Our  new hedging approach addresses each of these with the objective of reducing SSE's exposure to volatility in  energy commodities, and so make the impact on shorter-term earnings more visible and predictable. This means  SSE will now generally seek to hedge its broad exposure to commodity price variation 12 months in advance of  delivery, and we'll aim to transition towards this approach to be fully in place from April 2020.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The five principal commodities that SSE trades listed in our document this morning have different liquidity  characteristics. This means, where there's insufficient liquidity, we may trade alternative commodities to give an  effective proxy hedge. There are three areas where significant variations in earnings cannot be fully mitigated  through hedging; the impact of the weather on renewable output; the impact of operational matters such as  unplanned outages; and the ability of flexible thermal plant to earn income by providing services to the electricity  system and responding to electricity market conditions. Quite simply, our new approach means a much more  systematic approach to hedging.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're confident we've identified the right hedging approach and support framework, and will give visibility over the  practical implication of the approach in each financial reporting period. That means, including in each half and full- year results statement, information and commentary on the hedge position. This will include the proportion of  hedge volumes and the average hedge price achieved in respect to the policies on wind, hydro and thermal  generation, as well as those for Business Energy and Gas Production. And this in the future, we believe it is in  SSE's shareholder interest to evolve this hedging approach, we would disclose any changes and their rationale  for them.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The cumulative impact of the hedging approach, supporting framework, governance and disclosure commitment  should be assurance that traded commodity positions cannot and will not have a major influence on shorter-term  SSE Group earnings or take investors by surprise. It should allow investors and analysts to see what changes in  commodity price has been for SSE's portfolio of assets over time. As a portfolio that will be focused on regulated  networks and renewables. In the six months to September 30, total adjusted operating profit for these businesses  was down 10% at £454.5 million. Reflecting the impact of dry and still weather on renewables is still a major  contribution showing the underlying value of these businesses. That's why they are the core of the new SSE.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In the six months to September 30, we invested £783.5 million across the SSE Group. Over 75% of this was on  regulated networks and renewables with a further 8% on thermal generation, including multifuel. We're still on  course to invest around £1.7 billion across the group in this financial year, with around two-thirds of that in  regulated networks and renewables with complementary investment in thermal on top of that. It is returns from  investment like this that will support our dividend for many years to come.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In Networks, good progress continues to [ph] move ahead (16:32) with the Caithness-Moray transmission link,  which is now in advanced stage of commissioning. The project remains on track for delivery in the next few  weeks. The RAV of our Networks businesses has now reached £8.6 billion and is on course to reach £10 billion  by 2023. In Renewables, good progress continues to be made onshore at Stronelairg and offshore at Beatrice. At  Stronelairg, 57 of the 66 turbines are commissioned and the project remains on course for completion as planned  in the spring of next year. At Beatrice, 33 of the 84 turbines are exporting power and this project too remains on  course for completion as planned, again, in spring of 2019.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The progress of Beatrice is reflected in the fact a Start Date Notice has been submitted to the Low Carbon  Contracts Company to trigger commencement of CfD payments. These two developments will add a net 463  megawatts to our current Renewables capacity of 3.7 gigawatts. Recent market transactions indicate the huge  value the capacity and the scale will create for the SSE Group and a comparison with the current value of the  Retail business is highly instructive. Our renewables capacity may go down by around 160 megawatts if we sell  stakes of up to 50% in Stronelairg and Dunmaglass wind farms. These are really quality assets with P50 load  factors of 40% and 44%, respectively, and illustrate our onshore wind could and should have a growing future in  the UK energy mix.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Should a sale go ahead, we'll continue to operate the wind farms and take the power from them. As you know,  we've previously sold onshore wind assets as part of a capital recycling program to optimize our portfolio. Our  strategy is to create value from development and operation of assets as well as ownership, and the potential sale  of stakes in Stronelairg and Dunmaglass is entirely in line with that strategy. Market asset values are currently  very encouraging and we're seeing significant interest in the wind farm stakes. We'd expect the new SSE  Renewables business to be equally agile in taking opportunities to create and deliver value.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We also expect to seek new partners for the Seagreen offshore wind farm development, and as with the onshore  projects, are confident of a good level of interest. And taking forward these opportunities, I believe we can point a  strong record of delivering significant value creation through disposals, most recently illustrated by the gains on  sale in respect of Clyde wind farm and Indigo Pipelines, which equate to around £125 million. When it comes to  proceeds from future disposals of businesses, assets or investments, we'll look at several options or combination  of options, including debt management, returning value to shareholders through share buybacks, and creating  value through future investment.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're still expecting capital and investment spend to total around £6 billion across the five years to March 2023  giving an annual average of £1.2 billion across the period. That compares with an average of £1.6 billion in the  previous five years. Our core businesses of regulated Networks and Renewables should account for around 70%  of this, with complementary developments at Keadby 2 and multifuel accounting for around a further 10%. This is  an investment program focused on core businesses and key assets that meet the long-term needs of energy  customers. In May, we called out the key strategic trends of decarbonization, electrification and infrastructure. Our  core businesses have a critical part to play as these trends make their impact felt through the investment and  growth options that go with them.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Ability to raise funds at competitive rates is fundamental to investment. Our fundraising over the last five years,  including hybrid capital and term loans, now totals £5.8 billion. Excluding hybrids, our average debt maturity is  now at 7.3 years. This is lower than the case some years ago, but reflects great value in fundraising can be best  achieved. That £5.8 billion total includes our second Green Bond which we issued in August. It's a nine-year,  €650 million euro-denominated euro bond with a coupon of 1.375%. Proceeds have been swapped back into  sterling and the all-in funding cost is around 2.6%. This affirmed SSE as the largest issuer of Green Bonds from  the UK corporate sector and the only UK corporate to offer up multiple benchmark sized tranches in the euro  market.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Taking all of this into account and excluding Energy Services, we expect to deliver adjusted EPS in line with  analyst consensus in the range of £0.70 to £0.75 for this financial year, which on a like-for-like basis compares  with £0.983 last year. This is clearly not where we want it to be, although it's worth noting that adjusted EPS  excludes gains on sales relating to Clyde wind farm and Indigo pipelines of around £125 million, equivalent to  over £0.10 on EPS.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Gregor. Gregor summarized three strategic themes that underpin the renewal of the SSE Group of  businesses and delivery of the dividend plan, focused especially on the core businesses of regulated Networks  and Renewables, complemented by flexible thermal generation and Business Energy, visibility of assets and  earnings for investors, and platforms for success and growth for each business in SSE.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In practical terms, that means ensuring each business in the SSE Group has a part to play in helping SSE be a  leading provider of energy in a low-carbon world and a meaningful contribution to make to delivery of the dividend  plan. This demands a clear strategic purpose and focused management that is effective at allocating capital and  driving delivery of strong business performance, and this means taking forward the new business model for focus,  visibility and success that we set out in May.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Total's September announcement of a major gas discovery on the Glendronach prospect, in which SSE has a  20% stake, represents an important addition to SSE's gas investment portfolio. Recoverable resources equivalent  to around 10 billion therms have been estimated by Total, although not yet on a net proven and probable basis.  It's expected that the discovery can be developed quickly, benefiting from existing infrastructure. Glendronach is  good news and we'll continue to support exploration and appraisal activities around our existing assets. But we've  said for some time that we won't acquire any new assets.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: For SSE, gas production is an investment, not a business, which we're required to develop or operate. Ultimately  it's not consistent with the focus on de-carbonization of the energy system that we set out in May. This focus on  low carbon means it is an example of a non-core business, with different routes available for securing value, and  we would expect disposal over the next couple of years to be the most likely outcome.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our view of the future for gas production is the natural outcome of our commitment to focusing on regulated  Networks and Renewable energy. And our focus on creating value through investment in renewables is  exemplified by the good process in our key investments.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The construction of Stronelairg has so far gone extremely well, despite the challenging altitude and topography,  and this speaks to our ability to compete in onshore wind if future opportunities arise. The construction of Beatrice  has also gone very well and is currently on course to come in under budget. This speaks, again, to our future  potentially in offshore wind.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: These assets have value that market evidence clearly states is very high and value that's sustainable in every  way. Our commitment is to a new business model that gives greater focus on core businesses, gives investors  greater visibility of assets and earnings and gives each business the best platform for success. That's why we've  decided to consolidate the development, operation and ownership of all of our renewable energy assets under a  single entity called SSE Renewables, and includes JV interests, we'll bring under a single entity SSE's existing  operational assets and assets under development and construction in onshore wind, offshore wind, flexible hydro,  run-of-river hydro and pumped storage.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Prior to any further disposal, SSE Renewables' operational assets are expected to total around 4.2 gigawatts in  spring 2019, be capable of generating around 12 terawatt hours of electricity in a typical year from 2020 onwards,  and earn around EBITDA of £800 million based on market and ROC price assumptions.
