The business will be led  by a newly appointed MD, Jim Smith, who has one of the broadest and deepest experiences of anyone in the UK  renewable sector and a strong management team focused entirely on creating and delivering the long-term value  and opportunities, which renewable energy represents.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: This means a strategy designed to fulfill the potential of offshore and reinvigorating the onshore wind farm sector.  SSE has a unique portfolio of renewable energy assets and a valuable pipeline of future opportunities, not least  with offshore wind auction set for next year. The creation of SSE Renewables will build on our established skills in  asset management and large capital project development, and put the business in a strong position to succeed in  a sector that's rapidly changing and rapidly decarbonizing.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: It will have five key opportunities; a strong and experienced management team supported by skilled employees  focused entirely on creating value from developing, operating and owning renewable energy assets; enhanced  ability to raise finance from diverse sources, building on SSE's position as the largest issuer of green bonds in the  UK corporate sector; greater scope to enter into strategic and financial partnerships and joint ventures with  companies with a shared commitment to de-carbonization; taking forward SSE's established capability and  partnering with other organizations; greater visibility for investors with comprehensive financial and operational  disclosures through renewables-specific reporting; and more potential to add to future growth opportunities by  extending its core competencies in renewable energy to other technologies and geographies where the right  risk/reward balance can be achieved. We're now actively looking at this.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: This means we'll focus more business development on other geographies, while also maintaining a clear focus on  the UK and Ireland. Work on separating the renewables business is underway and we intend to have an  identifiable separate business by next April. I'm looking forward to the huge contribution I believe it will make to  society through de-carbonization and to value creation for shareholders through any returns to support dividends.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our flexible gas-fired power stations will play a key part in the transition to a low-carbon economy. They also  contribute to a robust electricity system by providing reliable capacity at scale in response to variability and output  from renewables or market changes. As we said in May, participating in National Grid's balancing mechanism has  earned annual operating profit of between £50 million and £100 million in each of the last three years.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: SSE's CCGTs continue to demonstrate that they are amongst the most flexible on the GB electricity system. Work  is now underway in the first-of-a-kind, high-efficiency gas-fired generation plant at Keadby 2. In return for the  investment of around £350 million, we'll get 840 megawatts of state-of-the-art thermal capacity, and it's our  intention to participate in future capacity market auctions to secure an agreement for this plant.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Business Energy also complements our core assets, providing a route to less-liquid markets for electricity output,  both through standard contracts and corporate power purchase agreements. We also have a real opportunity to  build our strong competencies in commercial insights, sales and service, in what is a deeply segmented market.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The first six months, we added 25,000 customer accounts and delivered £41.6 million in adjusted operating profit.  As part of SSE, Business Energy is in a good position to price and hedge most customer requirements at a time  when there is a clear trend towards end users seeking these sorts of solutions. It's clearly linked to the core  business of electricity generation and is an important part of SSE.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The strategic priority for Transmission has been enabling the transition to a low-carbon economy, through building  the infrastructure needed to connect renewable energy and transmit it across the GB transmission system. The  capacity of renewables connected to our network is continuing to grow and is now over 6 gigawatts. One of the  key features of the Transmission business is the continued and substantial growth in RAV, which will support  earnings for years to come.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Gregor described earlier the progress of the Caithness-Moray transmission link, which is now in the advanced  stages of commissioning. It's more than a link. It's a £1.1 billion group of complex projects that combined has a  quite outstanding skill, focus, and execution capability. It bodes well for Transmission's pipeline of projects, which  includes £1.2 billion of CapEx and projects associated with on and off-shore wind generation development and  projects to renew infrastructure dating back to the 1950s and 1960s. This will take the RAV to around £3.8 billion  by March 2023.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We also have visibility on a further £700 million of contingent projects, dependent on the progress of onshore  wind developments, which means the timing and ultimate need for them is not yet clear. In addition, we're  continuing to prepare to deliver links to the Scottish island groups. Following the submission of the Orkney Needs  Case in March, we've now submitted final Needs Cases for both the Western Isles and Shetland. Both links will  deliver 600 megawatts subsea cable, subject to the main renewable developers on both island groups being  successful in next year's CfD auction. These three island links could provide an investment opportunity of £1.5  billion.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In May, our Networks MD, Colin Nicol described how our Networks businesses share services and skills, but also  operate separately on a day-to-day basis. In Electricity Distribution, we're delivering significant changes to our  operations, processes and standards to meet the needs of customers. We're bearing down on costs and  delivering against the measures as set out by the ED1 framework, while also getting ready for RIIO-2. This  business too has a key part to play in the transition to a low-carbon economy.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: This translates into four key areas of focus. First, incentives, especially in relation to customer supply  interruptions, customer satisfaction, and stakeholder engagement; second, investment in a major project of capital  investment across both Networks to deliver significant improvements for customers, support local economic  development and add to the RAV; third, regulatory outputs, and delivering transformational changes that enhance  customer's experience of the networks, while driving operational efficiencies; and fourth, leading on networks'  innovation and preparing for the transition to smart, flexible electricity systems through trialing new technologies  and alternative network solutions. SSE is in a leading position and getting ready for the DSO transition.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Electricity Distribution is a business with a big part to play in the transition of the electricity system and de- carbonization of our economy. I believe we built a leadership position in preparing for this so far and are well- placed to strengthen it further towards the end of RIIO-1 and throughout RIIO-2.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Enabling the de-carbonization of the electricity system must be a key feature of the RIIO-2 framework in 2021 for  Transmission and 2023 for Distribution. As we look forward to the next stages of the price control process, it's  crucial that the regulatory framework provides fair and sustained returns for high-performing networks companies.  We're confident that it will, that Ofgem can still deliver this equitable outcome, and that we will own and operate  networks that come into the high-performing category throughout RIIO-2.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We plan to create value through focus, particularly on the core businesses and regulated networks and  renewables, complemented by flexible thermal Business Energy, visibility of assets and earnings for investors and  platforms for the success and growth for each of the SSE businesses.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: This morning we set out plans and routes for creating value for businesses and being clear about our focus on the  call. In summary, we see regulated networks and renewables driving us towards our vision of being a leading  energy company in a low carbon world. We've highlighted material progress made in these businesses.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In May, we set out a five-year dividend plan. With today's interim dividend announcement, we started to deliver it.  This is a company with a growing portfolio of highly valuable assets in a sector that's yielding investment  opportunities, that go with the grain of political, economic and environmental focus on de-carbonization. That's  why we're confident of our ability to deliver the rest of our dividend plan in the years ahead.

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: First, we're all disappointed by the impact of the decisions we took earlier this year to mitigate commodity price  risk. But we're also all right behind the action we've taken since September to manage the overall position and  associated exposures. And we're now confident that we have the right approach to hedging for the future.

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: Second, we're continuing to work hard to take forward the planned SSE Energy Services transaction. While there  can be no certainty this transaction will be completed as originally envisaged, we have no doubt that the best  future for SSE Energy Services, including its customers and employees, lies outside of the SSE Group.

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: Fourth, we're taking a decisive step forward with SSE Renewables, which will make a really significant  contribution to society through de-carbonization and to value creation for shareholders through earnings returns,  which support dividends. Fifth, we've set out a clear direction for networks, delivering the Transmission pipeline,  leading in innovation, and targeting frontier performance in the RIIO-2 price control.

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: All of this means SSE is a company with a clear strategy for core businesses and a growing portfolio of highly  valuable assets in regulated Networks and Renewables. It has major opportunities in a sector that's yielding  investment opportunities to go with the grain of political, economic and environmental focus on de-carbonization.  As I said a moment ago, we're committed to focusing on this call and giving full visibility on value.

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking ahead to May and beyond, this is the sector that's yielding future opportunities that support our vision of  being a leading energy company in a low carbon world. We've continued to demonstrate our strengths in  regulated Networks and Renewables and our ability to create value from them. That's why we're confident about  the long-term outlook for the SSE Group, and about its ability to deliver dividends in the years to come.

texts.text: At SSE, I don't understand the current [ph] flair (0:00:58) anyway, but anyway at SSE, we also have a  Management Board to lead the operation of the business. texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now, obviously the dividend needs to be adequately covered and including 1.41 times this year, our dividend cover  has averaged around 1.5 times over the last few years and we expect it to be in a range around that over the  medium term. That's why sustaining growth in adjusted profit before tax is important. The operating environment  is tough, but despite high wholesale gas prices, low spark spreads and falling energy consumption, we still  managed to deliver an adjusted PBT increase of 2% to £1.335 billion. That's almost 25% higher than it was five  payments in September. As we said last year, the charge for the hybrid debt coupon is presented within dividends  and is reflected within EPS.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: While this year's PBT increase was partly the result of our acquisition of gas production assets a year ago. texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Capital and investment expenditure in the year totaled £1.7 billion. Around 60% of this was in the wholesale  segment, where we've commissioned around 700 megawatts of renewable energy capacity in the year, and around  30% was in network segment, where we've added £360 million to the electricity RAV.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Looking to the new financial year, we're forecasting spend of around £1.6 billion with electricity networks and  renewable energy continuing to be the main components. We're expecting capital and investment spend to remain  in the £1.5 billion to £1.7 billion range for the next few years, and there's a lot of flexibility in our plans. The Board  keeps economic evaluation of the investment program under very close scrutiny. We're very pleased with the  progress that has been made in the past year and we continue to be confident, with totals being achieved means  significant value has been created across the program as a whole.

texts.text: We aim in energy supply to retain and gain customers for the long term. The last financial year did, however, see  us experience a net loss in supply customer numbers for the first time in a decade with a fall of 100,000 or 1% to  9.55 million. The loss of customers in GB outweighed the gain in Ireland. The main loss in accounts in GB was in  the six months between July and December last year on the back of our decisions to stop doorstep sales and to put  up prices. We said then that the fall in customer numbers could be a short term consequence of our doorstep sales  decision and we said in November that the fall could continue for some time yet. Unfortunately, that has proved to  be accurate, although the rate of loss in GB in 2012 is significantly slower than that sustained in the second half of  2011.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Building on our customer base in Ireland, we today announced the acquisition of Phoenix gas with 130,000 gas  customers in Northern Ireland, meaning we now participate in all areas of the energy supply market in the island  of Ireland.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Five important initiatives illustrate the point. We've frozen our retail prices, until at least October; we've helped  transform volumes in the day-ahead electricity market, too, with our initiative to improve transparency and price  discovery; we've overhauled our tariff structure reducing the number from over 60 to just four core products; in  the interest of fairness, we've removed online/offline tariff differentials making all products available to all  customers; and we've made rapid progress in customer service with a successful pilot of an annual energy review  that will now be made available to every customer. All of this has made a positive impact with politicians,  consumer groups and even Ofgem.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Retaining and acquiring customers in the future will take place in the context of the Green Deal. And assuming it  finally goes ahead, the smart meter roll-out. Under the Green Deal, there is a challenge and an opportunity. The  challenge is the obligations we have to meet as an energy supplier to collect Green Deal payments through  electricity bills. In doing this, we and other suppliers are having to make complex system changes without  definitive guidance from DECC, which is less than ideal, but the commitment of our team to making this work in  difficult circumstances is very strong.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: The opportunity is, as a Green Deal provider, we see insulation of solid walls, cavity walls and lofts being the  dominant measures. Last month, we were one of 22 organizations to sign an agreement with the UK government  to become one of the first Green Deal providers. Our priority in the early days will be to ensure customers'  experience of the Green Deal is a good one.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: A good customer experience will also be essential if the roll-out of smart meters is to be a success. The smart  meter roll-out is a job we have to do well, but fundamentally it's part of doing business and not a profit driver.  That's why our smart meter installation program has extended just 2,500 homes, which compares with about  200,000 installed by one other well-known supplier, most of which do not conform to the technical specification  issued by the government in March. We hope that the roll-out of smart meters is something which starts well and  is completed successfully.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Throughout the Energy sector, ever higher standards are expected of companies, nowhere could this apply more  than in energy supply. We accept that and we recognize that in this area, we have to earn the right to make a  profit. We believe we can combine transparency, simplicity, fairness, and service in a way that meets the needs of  customers and which thereby supports a reasonable but not excessive profit margin. That profit margin will allow  us to invest in the business and support our first financial responsibility to shareholders, sustained real dividend  growth.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: I'll now hand you over to Ian who will cover our final segment, wholesale.  Ian D. Marchant  Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Scottish & Southern Energy Plc  Thank you, Alistair, and good morning, everyone. The purpose of our wholesale business is straightforward; it's to  sell source and produce energy for our customers. The environment in which we do that job is however becoming  increasingly complex for four key reasons. First, UK gross imports of natural gas now exceeds gross production for  the first time since the 1960s. That means there's even greater integration of the UK energy prices into the wider  global market and macroeconomic and geopolitical factors are increasingly important. Second, global demand for  gas and coal continues to rise. The IEA is forecasting increases of 65% and 25%, respectively, over the next 25  years. Third, renewable energy and the climate change legislation at EU and member state levels continues to  have a profound effect on electricity production and public quality development. And fourth, everyone appears to  expect the tightening in the electricity capacity margin in the UK as older plant is forced to retire. The questions,  however, are when and at what rate.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Against this background, the performance of our wholesale businesses was solid with a 6.4% increase in operating  profit compared with last year. Obviously, poor spark spreads have a negative effect on the result, but this was  more than offset by two key points. The gas production assets we acquired in February 2011 delivered £42.6  million in operating profit, and the output of renewable energy was up by over 70%.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Investment played a big part in the output of renewables and I'll say more about that later. But being wet and  windy, the weather conditions were excellent for this particular bit of our business and helped, for example, to  deliver a record year ever for hydro output. Indeed, we've noticed that hydro and wind output is generally higher  in milder winters, and therefore provides a hedge against lower energy consumption, which is also linked to such  conditions.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: The £491 million exceptional item in the wholesale segment stems from changing market conditions. And they  have led to impairment and other charges being made against the value of some generation plant, CO2 emission  permits and some gas and oil production prospect.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Gas production has had an encouraging first year for us with the output of 177 million therms, pretty close to  expectations. This has given us a new source of primary fuel and a hedge for our gas generation and supply  activities. As you will know, we hope to add to our presence in this sector over time with the focus being on  mature, producing, gas-weighted assets. We have opportunities to build on our asset base in gas production and  we'll do so when value can be secured.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Complementing this, we've also been building up our portfolio of long-term fuel supply contract. During the last  12 months, they include a 10-year contract with Statoil due to begin later this year, and another 10-year contract  with Shell due to begin in 2015. They fit well with our business requirements and will cover a significant portion of  our future gas needs with a fair pricing structure and minimal risk.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: While gas production has had a positive year, the effect of higher wholesale prices and lower spark spreads from  our gas-fired power purchase has been negative. The reality is, however, that gas-fired power stations will be  critical during the forthcoming de-carbonization of the electricity sector. That's another reason we're seeking long- term gas contracts of the type I've mentioned with Shell and Statoil.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: The role of gas-fired generation will change focusing much more on flexibility and systems security to compliment  other low carbon sources of energy. That means – that will mean changes in the way they will operate and be  remunerated. We flagged up the issues with Keadby and Medway in our last IMS statement and they make up

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Current market conditions are however exactly that, current. We have to look further ahead. That's why we have  consent to build up to 470 megawatts of capacity at Abernedd and while we're looking at new CCGT options for  existing sites, including Keadby, Ferrybridge, Fiddler's Ferry, and some other sites.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: The outcome of DECC's review of the role of gas in the electricity market will obviously have a bearing on how we  go forward. But these and other potential sites mean we have a range of CCGT options for independent or co- development. We also have in Peterhead, the UK's best option for fitting carbon capture and storage to a gas-fired  power station, and we expect the forthcoming FEED study to validate that claim.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: While gas-fired power stations have been struggling with low spark spreads, our coal-fired power stations have  again showed their virtues of availability, flexibility, and reduced reliance on gas. They produced an additional 3.2  terawatt-hours of electricity in 2011 and 2012. And we have also built up our coal stocks in anticipation of another  busy year. Alongside their virtues, however, coal-fired power stations have vices in the form of CO2 and NOx  emissions. On CO2, our post-combustion capture trial at Ferrybridge, which is the largest of its kind in Europe, is  now demonstrating the operational characteristics of capture plants on an actual working power station. On NOx,  we are planning to install abatement equipment on one 500-megawatt unit at Fiddler's Ferry. It doesn't require  expensive catalyst banks, but will still give us options for operating unit up to and beyond 2023.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: The ROC banding review has opened the door to enhance co-firing of biomass at the stations, and we're looking at  that option very closely as well. Alongside gas and renewables, we expect solid fuel to be an important part of our  generation mix for some time to come. Our new joint venture with Wheelabrator to build a multi-fuel facility at  Ferrybridge is in line with that. Multi-fuel is a tried and tested way of generating sustainable base-load power,  which has significant, but as yet, untapped potential in the UK. CapEx of our coal and gas power stations totaled  £129 million last year. With the work that's going on across the portfolio, not least with that multi-fuel  development, we expect that spend to be around £250 million in this financial year.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Our investment in renewables is partly a hedge against volatility in fossil fuel market, and is an increasingly  important source of energy. During 2011/2012, output from our hydro schemes and wind farms gave us the  equivalent of 260 million therms of gas.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Over the last year, we invested £852 million in renewables, and completed almost 500 megawatts of new onshore  wind farm capacity, all of which has produced electricity, and excluding disputed turbines at Greater Gabbard,  commissioned over 180 megawatts net of offshore wind capacity. To put that into perspective, that means that  team SSE were involved in installing more than one turbine each and every day of the year – last year, that's  weekends as well as weekdays.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: In total, we now have 3020 megawatts of capacity we're generating electricity from conventional hydro schemes,  wind farms and biomass, up from just 1520 megawatts five years ago. The first big batch of projects, Clyde,  Griffin, Gordonbush, Walney and Gabbard are either finished, or well on the way to completion in the next few  months. Keeping up the momentum is vital, and our priorities for this financial year are clear; complete over 150  megawatts of onshore wind farm capacity, finish construction at Gabbard and Walney, and restore power  production at the Glendoe hydro scheme.  The process of refitting the reservoir at Glendoe should begin shortly with generation resuming in the summer.  This has been a major engineering exercise. Even after it's finished, there will be insurance and legal issues  ongoing for some time. I'm confident, however, that the strategic value of the asset will become very clear in the  next few years.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: The legal issues at Greater Gabbard are well known. The main development since November is that the Gabbard  JV has now issued a claim against the principal contractor, Fluor. That claim and the one for Fluor against  Gabbard centers on up to 52 of the 140 turbine support. Resolving the two claims will inevitably take some time.  So the up-to-date position is that all 140 turbines at Gabbard are up. There are now more than 80 commissioned  turbines which are not subject to any claim and which are successfully generating electricity.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: There are also more than 40 of those disputed turbines that have produced power. And all of the remaining  turbines should be producing power over the next few months. This means that the Gabbard dispute is still a  problem, but the Gabbard wind farm is also now an asset. Obviously, future investment in renewables will be  shaped by electricity market reform or EMR. We know that the carbon price floor will be introduced next March.  As the UK's biggest generator of electricity from renewables, a long term strong price for carbon is welcome.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: The other element, the capacity mechanism, the emissions performance standard and the CfDs are what still  might be politely called work in progress. In particular, there are number of concerns about how the low-carbon  CfD, in terms of complexity, counterparty, compliance [ph] with state case work (0:38:55), a number of concerns  about how those issues can be resolved.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: One of our financial principles is rigor. Rigor analysis to ensure investments are well founded and achieve returns  greater than the cost of capital. That's particularly important is wholesale, in gas production and generation,  where there is more discretion in investment decision making than networks, but also more complexity.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Our annual CapEx has increased from £660 million to £1.7 billion over the past five years. Over that five-year  storage at Aldbrough, 420 megawatts of CCGT capacity at Marchwood, around 1,500 megawatts of new capacity  for generating electricity from renewables and £1.7 billion increase in the RAV of our economically-regulated  network.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Thank you, Robert, and this being my 10th full year results presentation, I think it's apt that I've delegated
texts.text: Across networks and wholesale, we've got something to show for our money. These assets and the returns from  our investment means that despite a very tough period of low spark spreads and falling energy consumption, we  have been able to sustain profit growth and keep adequately covered our growing dividends.

file: SSEL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 22May2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: We also have three of SSE's Management Board members here with us today: Jim McPhillimy, who's the MD for  Group Services; Jim Smith, who's the MD for Renewables; and Alan Young, MD for Corporate Affairs.

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: In the last week of March, thousands of properties across Arran and Argyll were without electricity as a result of  the dramatic impact of severe snow and ice in the power lines. Over 500 SSE engineers and staff were mobilized,  working around the clock in a military-style operation to restore power. But this was a military-style operation  with a human face. The support provided to customers without power included amongst many other things  serving 16,000 hot meals and 30,000 cups of hot tea and coffee. In other words, nothing was too much trouble.  This was SSE at its very best and the company rightly deserves the place it received for its efforts. SSE's  relationship with the islanders blossomed. And in support of this alliance, we brought you today some Arran  goodie bags. These are not freebies from SSE. We got them free from the good people of Arran. And I'd like to  encourage you to visit, it's a beautiful island.

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: Then in contrast, the first week of April saw Ofgem announced a £10.5 million penalty on SSE for breaches of  license conditions relating to sales of electricity and gas, mainly between 2009 and 2011. We accepted the penalty  immediately and like everyone else associated with SSE, I have no hesitation in saying sorry for the breaches that  occurred. Those breaches were clearly wrong. The actions SSE has taken to deal with them in the time since they  occurred have been right, and Alistair will cover these in more detail later.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Evidence of the tough operating environment, particularly for gas-fired generation plant can be seen in the  exceptional charge of £584.7 million made in the year. It relates mainly to the Wholesale segment, and I'm going  to say a bit more about that shortly.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The Retail segment comprises of two business areas, Energy Supply and Energy-Related Services. Together, they  account for 23% of SSE's adjusted operating profit. Energy Supply's contribution was £364.2 million. We've said  we expect the margin of this business to average around 5% over the medium term. In the year to March 2013, it  was 4.2%. And over the last three years, it has averaged just 4%. The increase from last year was largely due to the  colder-than-average weather that the UK experienced throughout the year as well as good control of operating  cost.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The financial performance of the Energy-Related Services businesses, however, reflects the challenging economic  conditions with operating profit down 8% to £45.9 million. A small part of the exceptional item I mentioned  earlier, less than 10%, relates to metering and other issues in the Retail segment.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Lack of seasonality and volatility in the gas price resulted in another difficult year for Gas Storage where profits  dropped 22.7% to £18.4 million. And operating profit in Gas Production was inflated by a few one-off benefits in  2012, so it was down 7% this year to £39.6 million.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Most of the exceptional item of £584.7 million relates to Wholesale issues. These include write-downs on the back  of difficult trading conditions in the thermal generation and carbon markets, as well as the Medway insurance  issue we covered at the interims.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The impact of market conditions on our thermal assets was reflected in the outcome of the review that we  announced in March. That review has sustainable commercial viability as one of the key requirements for all of  our generation plants. I'm sure you all know the outcome. We announced the closure of units one and two at  Ferrybridge during this financial year, deep mothballing at Keadby, reduced capacity and released transmission  export capacity at Uskmouth and reduced transmission capacity at Peterhead.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: On a positive note, Medway's returning to service with the successful completion of its upgrade program to  support more flexible operation. As I indicated, these decisions are reflected in that exceptional charge we've  included in the accounts. Looking ahead, we're moving towards a flexible lower carbon portfolio of assets and  Alistair will say more about that later.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The profile of our capital investments then can be seen on this slide. In the five years to 2008, it averaged £530  million, while over the last five years, it's averaged £1.45 billion. And in the last year, it stayed around that average  level at £1.49 billion. This was mainly made up of around 45% in Networks where we've added £355 million to  RAVs and around 40% in generation where net of a small disposal, we commissioned over 200 megawatts of  renewable energy and continue to build thermal plants at Great Island and Ferrybridge.

texts.speaker: Ian D. Marchant
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: I'm proud of the assets we've built and continue to build to deliver the energy infrastructure that our country and  our customers need. These assets should also help extend into the future our track record of delivering sustained  real dividend growth for our shareholders. And that track record of sustained real dividend growth is set out on  this slide, and it's been delivered by the whole of the SSE team and it's another thing of which I'm proud.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're forecasting capital and investment spend of around £1.5 billion in this financial year with electricity  networks and generation continuing to be the main components. We're expecting it to remain in the £1.5 billion to  £1.7 billion range for the next few years. There's a lot of flexibility built into our plans, but we expect electricity  networks to continue to be the largest element.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The example of SGN's innovative approach and how it can lead to operational efficiencies is a coring device you  see in this picture. Put simply, it reduces the amount of digging up of roads we have to do when repairing the gas  network. Following successful trials with a number of local authorities, SGN now aims to use this technique in all  areas of operation. As SGN's Chairman, I'm very proud of this and everything else that has been achieved since the  company was formed in 2005.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The Electricity Transmission business has also now started its new price control period which also runs to 2021.  For the foreseeable future, transmission would largely be a construction business. That means the focus is on the  delivery of the key construction and development projects shown in this map. The RAV of the transmission  business is growing significantly and has now passed £1 billion. This reflects mainly the progress made in the  construction of the Beauly-Denny project. With the completion of it and progress in other key projects like Beauly- Mossford, Beauly-Kintore, Kintyre-Hunterston, the transmission RAV should reach around £1.6 billion by 2016.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The Beauly-Denny project is well underway, and at the end of April, 173 pylons were in place, and the north  section between Beauly and Fort Augustus is now almost complete. The photos on this slide gives you an idea of  the scale of this project which when complete will comprise 536 pylons, be strung with 201 kilometers of cable,  have involved 40 SSE staff and 830 contractors and have added capacity for up to 2,000 megawatts of generation  capacity.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: While two eight-year price controls covering roughly half of SSE's total RAV have now been settled and have  started, the price control process for the other half of SSE's RAV Electricity Distribution is just starting to gain  momentum. As with Transmission, distribution companies will be required to develop comprehensive business  plans, which will define planned outreach for the eight-year period on how to deliver them.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In February, we published Innovating for a Greener, More Efficient Future: Our Second Consultation to invite  viewers on the priorities for the distribution business between 2015 and 2023, including a safe and reliable supply  of electricity, good customer service and as the affordability of energy comes under greater scrutiny, value for  money.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: There have been a number of encouraging developments in this area, including lighting services new eight year  £56 million contract in Cornwall; utility solutions contract to provide combined heat, electricity, gas and water  services to over 5,000 homes in four large developments; and telecoms 10 year £30 million JaNet contract to  provide 6,500 kilometers of fiber network to over 30 sites used by the UK's research and education community.  Like the economically regulated networks, the success of these businesses depends on a clear focus on customer  service and the successful deployment of new technology.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: You saw earlier on our commitment to Networks' customers on Arran and Kintyre when they needed us most.  That commitment also applies to our Retail customers. As you know, SSE has been leading the industry for almost  two years with our Building Trust program to bring simplicity, transparency and new standards of customer  service in energy supply. This Building Trust program clearly took a knock in April when Ofgem announced this  buying-for-license condition breaches. Individually and collectively, we've all apologized for this and rightly so.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: To move forward, we have two clear goals. The first is the successful execution of our existing sales guarantee for  those customers who lost money as a result of switching to us. Our sales guarantee is still the only one of its type  in the industry. We've received 14,000 claims since the Ofgem announcement and have reviewed over 80% of  these. We've paid an average of £80 to over 5,000 customers, and we've got to contact again a group of customers  who may be at a higher risk of having suffered some financial detriment. We expect to do all of this before the end  of August. The balance of the £5 million we've provided for the retrospective part of the sales guarantee will, at  that point, be given over to a group of energy-related charities. The sales guarantee itself is now a permanent  feature of what we offer customers joining SSE.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The commitments are based on three key objectives: helping customers save money, making life easier for our  customers, and helping customers when they need it most. Since its launch, we've made around 300 payments to  customers. I believe that it's exactly the kind of thing that will engage customers and build trust in SSE as a  responsible energy supplier.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The aim in Energy Supply must be to gain customers in the right way and then retain them for the long term. The  last financial year did, however, see a net loss in customer account numbers with a reduction of 80,000 to 9.47  million. Given this total includes 130,000 gas customer accounts in Northern Ireland that we acquired last June,  the underlying fall was 210,000.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Even on that basis, however, our energy supply customer base is only 3% smaller than it was at its peak two years  ago. Given all that has happened since, I think that means we have a very resilient supply business and then our  mix of fair prices, simple products and excellent service continues to stand us in good stead.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: It's difficult to predict what customer account numbers will be at the end of this financial year. And it's not the  first KPI in Energy Supply. As I've said, this business must be about gaining customers in the right way and  retaining them for the long term

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We've made it clear that we have to earn continually the right to make a profit in Energy Supply. With that goes  the responsibility to make a profit that is fair and reasonable. In our assessment, fair and reasonable means that a  profit margin averages around 5% over the medium term. If you compare that margin with what other businesses  selling essential products are able to earn, it passes the fair and reasonable test.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We believe that margin is achievable, although we also recognize that Ofgem's retail market review represent  another significant regulatory intervention in the GB energy supply market. While we take issue with some aspects  of it, we believe our Energy Supply business is well placed to succeed under RMR, partly because our Building  Trust program anticipated a number of its key features such as limits on a number of tariffs customers can be  offered.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Another reason for our confidence is that the shape and structure of our Energy Supply business and our Retail  division as a whole has been transformed over the past year. It's about building on solid foundations we have  through our strong track record on customer service and supply and a broad range of energy-related services we  also provide. Our track record on customer service goes well beyond the many awards we've won for sector- leading service. It's about the financial support we provide for low-income customers, the partnerships we've  maintained with key organizations like Citizens' Advice and the practical steps we take to make vulnerable  customers' lives easier such as our Careline. That's what customer service means.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In terms of energy-related services, we have an extensive product portfolio and a high-potential customer base  with large businesses, developers and local and other public authorities. We also know we can achieve much more  in the future through more effective customer relationship management in a broader sense of the phrase. With  new leadership and the new structure, our Retail division is getting in a position to develop and deploy a central  proposition to households and businesses that enables them to receive key services from a single provider, SSE,  based on value, convenience, choice and quality.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In practice, that should mean earning the right to secure a profit margin of around 5% in Energy Supply and  securing a growing contribution to profit from more effective deployment of energy-related services.  Fundamentally, the job of our Wholesale businesses is simple, their purpose is to secure the energy people and  businesses' need. In saying that, they also have to stand on their own two feet and contribute to the success of SSE  as a whole. That has not been easy. We've had a near-perfect storm of minimal economic growth, sustained fall in  underlying demand, high wholesale gas prices and spark spreads that have often been negative.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The fact that we've still managed to deliver £450 million of operating profit from our EPM and generation  activities is testament of the diversity within our portfolio, especially our coal assets at FFF and our 3,240  megawatts of renewables. Maintaining diversity of fuel sources will remain a key feature of our generation  portfolio in the years ahead. Here is evidence why. You can see how over the past four years our generation output  has changed in response to prevailing market conditions, in particular high wholesale gas prices relative to coal.  Although 1,000 megawatts at Ferrybridge will cease operation in this financial year, we still have around 3,000  megawatts of coal-fired capacity as a key feature of our generation portfolio. While the amount of capacity in GB  has remained well in excess of peak demand forecast, commentators including Ofgem and National Grid are  beginning to sound the alarm.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Three reasons for that stand out. Persistent uncertainty around electricity market reform, especially on the  capacity mechanism, is making investment decisions in thermal capacity in GB almost impossible to take. The  grip of emissions legislation is tightening leading to the closure of coal and other capacity.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: And finally, the carbon price support mechanism, the implementation of which is leading to a lack of liquidity in  the UK power market beyond two years. Add to that the globalization of everything from commodities to the  supply chain for constructing new power plant, and you can see that from the point of view of this country as a  whole, this is not a good place to be.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking through the second half of the decade, we expect to make a balanced range of new investments focused  on both renewal – renewable and thermal plants. CCGT is clearly the right technology to support security of  supply as the amount of renewables on the system increases. To move forward, however, we need the right market  signals. But when they come, and ultimately we believe they will have to come, we have very valuable options in  terms of Abernedd 1, Keadby 2 and Seabank 3. We don't, however, expect to take any investment decisions on  these until 2015 at the earliest.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: However, with its capacity mechanism, Ireland is different and construction of the new 460 megawatt CCGT at  Great Island is well advanced. It's due to be commissioned next summer and will support the diversity of our  generation assets as a whole and in Ireland in particular. It's also adding to our experience of constructing CCGT,  which will be very useful if and when we're able to start construction work at the likes of Abernedd.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Alongside gas and renewables, we expect solid fuel to be an important part of our generation mix for some time to  come. At Fiddlers Ferry, we've almost finished installing NOx abatement equipment on one 500-megawatt unit. It  doesn't involve expensive capital expense and subject to how it performs, it will give us more options for operating  the unit up to and beyond 2023.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our JV with Wheelabrator is now building the multifuel facility at Ferrybridge that's due to become operational in  2015. Multifuel is a tried-and-tested way of generating sustainable base load power, which has significant but  untapped potential in the UK. It features a gate fee for taking fuel and will add to the diversity of our generation  portfolio. We have further options in this area.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our investment in renewable which is partly a hedge against volatility in fossil fuel market and is an increasingly  important source of energy. During 2012-2013, output from our hydro schemes and wind farms gave us the same  amount of electricity that would have come from 250 million therms of gas. Over the year, we invested £383  million in renewables and completed 138 megawatts of onshore wind farm capacity, all of which has produced  electricity, and including all of the turbines at Greater Gabbard commissioned 162 megawatts of offshore wind  farm capacity.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In total, we now have 3,240 megawatts of capacity for generating electricity from hydro schemes, wind farms and  biomass, up from just 1,600 megawatts when we acquired Airtricity five years ago. I'm glad to say the capacity  generating electricity includes Glendoe which returned to service last August. It's generated more electricity  already than it did in its first period of operation and has again clearly demonstrated its strategic value. Our  priorities in renewables for this new financial year are clear, the onshore wind developments at Calliachar,  Keadby, Strathy North and Dunmaglass. And we expect total CapEx in this area to remain at similar levels to last  year. Jim Smith can tell you more about our plans later.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The key thing for the future is we have a diverse range of options into increasingly harmonized markets, solid fuel  with NOx abatement and multifuel in Great Britain, renewables in both Great Britain and Ireland, and CCGT in  Great Britain and Ireland. These options and the fact we generate electricity from gas, coal, biomass, water and  wind with multifuel coming soon shows the diversity will be the hallmark of our generation portfolio for a long  time to come. That means we should be in a very good position when the market recovers.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Two years ago, we made our first move into gas production. The primary reason was to secure a supply of physical  gas at a fixed price to help meet the energy needs of customers. We said last year that we hoped to add to our  presence in the sector with focus being on mature, producing gas-weighted assets. In line with that, we've bought  additional assets which fit exactly our criteria including the Sean field for £117 million. This means that at the start  of this financial year, our total portfolio of gas production assets represented around 3 billion therms of proven  and probable reserves. We expect the volume and production profile of these assets to provide a secure and fixed  price supply of gas that should meet around 25% of the forecasted demand from our domestic gas customers over  the next three years. We have further opportunities to build on our asset base in gas production and we'll do so  providing value can be secured.

file: SSEL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 21May2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: In a challenging external environment, it's vital that companies have a clear purpose, strategy, and financial  objective. SSE has all of those. Our core purpose is to provide the energy people need in a reliable and sustainable  way. Our strategy is to deliver the efficient operation of and investment in a balanced range of economically  regulated and market-based energy businesses in the UK and Ireland. And our financial objective is to increase  annually the dividend payable to shareholders by at least RPI inflation.

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: That's why we are listening to and helping customers with the GB market's longest-ever household energy price  freeze. It's also why we're taking forward well-defined plans for net investment of around £5.5 billion in the next  four years in maintaining, upgrading and building the electricity assets customers depend on. And to support both  of those things, we're undertaking a value program to streamline and simplify the SSE business. So with this focus  on value, investment and customers, we believe we're in a very good position to deliver our financial objective – an  annual dividend that keeps pace with inflation.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Exceptional items of £747.2 million are mainly non-cash. Around 70% relates to the continuing impact on our  Wholesale businesses of the challenging sector conditions we faced in recent years. Coal-fired power stations,  offshore wind and gas storage account for well over half the total. The other significant element is the cost  resulting from the implementation of the value program we announced in March.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking now at our three business segments, operating profit is up 9.3% in Networks due to investment in  transmission in particular. Operating profit is down 28.6% in Retail due to higher wholesale cost and lower energy  consumption particularly due to the mild weather in the second half of the winter. Operating profit is up 24.8% in  Wholesale due to higher output from renewables and our new Sean gas production asset, which had brought in  around £90 million of additional operating profit.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking ahead, we'll continue to use adjusted EPS and monitor financial performance over the medium term. We  expect that EPS in this new financial year will be around or slightly greater than the £1.234 we reported this  morning. As we said in March over the wider energy sector issues like difficult market conditions for thermal  generation or potential legislation and a price freeze could mean our ability to increase EPS is subject to greater  risk in the two years from April 2013.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: This covers three main categories. Committed spend, including regulated networks projects, and construction and  maintenance; expected spend, which is the £1.3 billion transmission link we believe will be required between  Caithness and Moray, but which is currently out for consultation; an optional spend, which is currently  uncommitted, but that we may choose to spend to build new assets such as onshore wind farms that we're still  developing.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: When it comes to optional spend on new assets, we'll recycle capital from disposals of existing investments and  assets. This is entirely consistent with our commitment to financial discipline. As I said in March, we expect to  secure financial benefit of around £1 billion from a combination of the disposal of non-core assets and businesses  and the sale of existing onshore wind farms in order to recycle capital.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We've made some progress on the disposals since March, and we're targeting the autumn for completing the sale  of the PFI lighting contracts, non-regulated gas pipelines, and the data center at Fareham. In the case of our  onshore wind farms, we're confident we've achieved excellence in development and construction and have good  opportunities to build more before the renewables obligation deadline in 2017. To enable us to do this, we'll  continue to sell operating wind farms, we believe greater value can be secured from investing in a new one, with  the next disposals likely to be in 2015-2016.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: To put the benefit of this in context, the RAV of our Networks has increased by 45% in five years and is now £6.82  billion. At £3.05 billion, Electricity Distribution remains the biggest single part of our RAV, and had a solid year.  Revenue was essentially flat, and storm-related costs had to be incurred. So there was a slight reduction in  operating profit at £507 million. The Networks ended the year in an over-recovery position of around £25 million.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Last autumn and winter, however, presented us with eight exceptional weather events. We're still very grateful for  the dedication of the engineers, tree-cutters, and customer service advisers who work tirelessly, and for the  patience of our customers. This sequence of exceptional weather events has contributed to the increased political  scrutiny of the Networks businesses and their costs.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: A revised business plan for the 2015-2023 Price Control has cost efficiency and customer service at par. It's  designed to keep us at the frontier of efficiency while preparing for what might happen in energy use between now  and 2023. While Ofgem has reduced its central estimate of the load base effect, return on equity, that's just one  part of a wider package of measures, and we're confident that our revised business plan should lead to a Price  Control package that's fair to customers and investors alike.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Transmissions Price Control is now in its second year, and this business is continuing to grow in a strong and  sustainable way. In just five years, its RAV has more than trebled to £1.33 billion. This continuing investment in  the asset base is driving the growth in profitability, illustrated by the 47.6% increase in operating profit we  reported this morning.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Good progress has been made with the four major projects under construction. Key driver for these, and for the  projects under development, like the Caithness-Moray link, is the need to accommodate renewable energy  developments in the north of Scotland. While there's no consulting in our proposed solution for Caithness-Moray,  Ofgem's view is that there is a need for a reinforcement of the transmission systems in Northern Scotland. The  combination of existing network constraints and wind farms recently completed or in construction means there is  a huge amount of work for our Transmission business to do over the next few years.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: A total of £321.7 million was invested by SGN as a whole in the period, taking our share of the RAV of the business  to £2.44 billion. SGN is one of the best gas distributors in the country. It has a clear focus on safety, reliability and  minimizing the disruption for customers and communities arising from its capital works. That clear focus,  together with the further efficiencies to come, mean it's well placed to deliver good results in the coming years. I'll  now hand you over to Alistair.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Gregor. Good morning, everyone. With Networks, Retail and Wholesale businesses, assets, customers,  SSE's activities reflect the broad structure of the energy sector across Scotland, England, Wales, Northern Ireland  and the Republic of Ireland. I believe that this gives us sector-wide understanding, a broad revenue base, lower  risk from any one business, and the ability to secure cost synergies and apply best practice in key areas from safety  to large capital management projects.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: With this focus, we're closer to our customers and our markets, and better connected with the politicians,  regulators and other stakeholders who will shape the energy sector across these islands in the years to come.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: In March, we set out our plan for making sure SSE is well positioned for the period to 2020 and beyond in what is  a challenging business, market, regulatory and political environment. We're simplifying our business and securing  efficiencies, focusing on value and investment decision-making, easing the burden on bill payers through our price  freeze to 2016 and our campaign on green levies, and showing our appetite for reform and our commitment to  having a voice and a debate around energy market and policy.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Ofgem said in March that they believe that referring the energy market to their Competition and Markets  Authority offers the opportunity once and for all to clear the air. We must make sure that this opportunity is not  missed. In our response to Ofgem's referral consultation, which we've published this morning, we said we should  not pass up what could be a once-in-a-generation opportunity to reach a new, lasting settlement on the energy  market that commands broad regulatory, political and public support. That's why we believe that the CMA  investigation should go beyond the energy market for household customers and reach everything that is not  economically regulated. It should extend to small businesses and to the industrial commercial sector and cover  gas storage and electricity and gas production as well.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: In summary, we want to achieve lasting political and regulatory stability for the GB market for the benefit of both  customers and investors. Companies need to back up words with actions. Through our price freeze, we've taken  action that would make a difference for our customers. As you know, it comes at some financial cost with Energy  Supply profit margins unlikely to recover to their March 2013 level of 4.2% before 2016-2017. In the year to March  2014, the Energy Supply profit margin is 2.9%. This reflects a fall of almost one-third in operating profit to £246.2  million. The fall resulted from the high cost faced by this business and the lower demand for energy from  customers.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: The increase in bad debt followed the increased energy consumption during the prolonged colder period at the  start of 2013, combined with continued pressures on disposable income. We aim to get in touch with customers  with arrears as early as possible, but this proved more difficult last year when we had other operational challenges,  and there will be renewed focus on this in the coming financial year.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: In what has been a very competitive market, customer account numbers have fallen by 3.9% to 9.1 million. Even  so, we have a good Energy Supply business, and the early response of customers to our price raise has been  positive. That's because it's a clear step towards restoring stability and trust for the long-term.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Long-term, an important point. Sales of our core products, electricity and gas, are on a decline last year against a  falling consumption by our customers. This means our Retail business has to evolve if it is to prosper.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: We'll start with some strong foundations. SSE has been ranked first for customer service in the Annual uSwitch  Report for eight years running. On top of this, we've led the drive to higher standards. We're bringing an end to  cold calling, and implementing two sector-leading guarantees on sales and on customer service. In addition, I  believe our campaigns to take social and environmental levies of bills, and our price freeze has started to position  us as a company that will take action to make a difference for customers.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're building our brands for our sponsorships at the Commonwealth Games. The SSE Hydro, which many of you  hopefully will have seen on TV this morning, is hosting Sports Personality of the Year Award, the SSE Arena,  Wembley and the SWALEC Stadium. This is about engaging with customers in a completely different way  rewarding them for their loyalty for us. We'll also be continuing our campaign to ease the burden on bill payers of  social and environmental levies.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Over time, we believe that all this should help us to create a brand that people trust and from which they're willing  to buy a wider range of products and services so that SSE is regarded as the leading energy provider and a leading  provider of other services as well. The net result of this should be a sustainable Retail business for the long term.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: If any business should be long term, it's power generation. We're maintaining and developing a resilient and  sustainable Wholesale business. And you can see that in the 24.8% increase in this segment we reported this  morning. The increase has come largely as a result of the £127.6 million acquisition of the Sean assets last April.  In Gas Production, this has helped take output from 184 million therms to 414 million therms and operating profit  from £39.6 million to £130.2 million.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: We also have increased output from gas-fired power stations and from renewable energy. The closures of Units 1  and 2 at Ferrybridge and Uskmouth, however, clearly means our total output from coal-fired stations will never  again return to the levels seen in 2012-2013.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Despite the closure of Ferrybridge and Uskmouth, we still have 11.6 gigawatts of capacity, the most diverse fleet in  the market, flexible [ph] plant (23:42) and a strong engineering capability to maximize plant availability. We'll be  adding to our capacity and operation later this year when the 460 megawatt CCGT at Great Island in County  Wexford is commissioned. All of this gives us a Generation portfolio with a real long-term value.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: In GB, however, the sustained impact of plant closures and difficult market conditions mean there is a continuing  debate about security of supply. There's no doubt, as Ofgem puts it, that the risks to the security of supply over the  next few winters have increased. That said, the Energy Act 2013, which enjoyed broad support across the political  spectrum, effectively gives the UK's Department of Energy and Climate Change clear responsibility [ph] and hold  (24:32) the security of supply, including the creation of a mechanism to support generating capacity.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking at our thermal plants in GB, we've wholly owned thermal assets that can play an important part in  keeping the lights on. Fiddler's Ferry where all four units continue to operate; Ferrybridge Units 3 and 4; next to  which we're also building our first multi-fuel plant, Medway, which has benefited from a £48 million investment  in reliability and flexibility; and Peterhead which has just entered into a voltage response contract with National  Grid.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: In addition, the investment in Keadby in 2012-2013 means that if it should be brought back to generate electricity  in the future, it will be out to operate in a more flexible and efficient way. In saying this, I don't want give DECC,  National Grid or anyone else any grounds for complacency because there aren't any. Both the supplemental  balancing reserve and the capacity market has to be introduced in an effective and timely way. In the meantime,  we'll do everything we can to make sure that Fiddler's, Ferrybridge, Medway and Peterhead are all available to  operate as and when needed in the run-up to the next winter.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our renewable assets have a part to play in security of supply as well. We have 300 megawatts of pumped storage  at Foyers and over 1,000 megawatts of flexible hydroelectricity. The energy contribution of wind farms is  important as well. In 2013-2014, for example, Greater Gabbard on its own produced a total of 1.9 terawatt hours  of electricity.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our capital spend on renewables peaked at £852 million in 2011-2012. And since then, we scaled back spend to  focus our development work on the best available projects, delivering the greatest amount of energy. We currently  have onshore wind projects under construction or nearing completion totaling 250 megawatts. In addition, we  have projects totaling over 600 megawatts at advanced stages of the planning process. All of these, however, come  into the optional category and will be financed at least in part by the asset disposals we described in March.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: We've also scaled back our ambitions in offshore wind and our decision to focus on the 664-megawatt Beatrice  project has been vindicated by DECC's announcement that it has been successful in securing an early Contracts for  Difference. This decision means we can continue to work through the issues on Beatrice and advance to the final  investment decision in 2016, by which time we don't expect our stake in the project to be any more than 50%.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our approach to renewables is an example of our wider approach to managing the business as a whole, simplifying  what we're doing to focus on what's important. As an energy company, SSE has huge responsibility. We're  entrusted to deliver the best possible service to customers and invest into our assets for the future energy needs of  the country. By doing this, we're able to pay dividends to the shareholders who invest in us.
