To maximize our  ability to pay dividends, we maintain a balanced range of businesses, operational and investment efficiency and  strong financial management. I believe we demonstrated in March and again today that delivering the right  decisions to the customers now puts us in a better position to deliver the dividends that investors are looking for  in the future.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive, SSE Plc
texts.text: The energy sector has undergone massive changes since the first year on this chart. In each of the 15 years since  1999, we've delivered a real dividend increase. We acknowledged in March that dividend growth in the next few  years may be a bit slower than it was in the past, but be in no doubt that we're still focusing on delivering growth  that at least matches RPI inflation and thereby giving shareholders a fair return on the investment they're making  in the future energy needs of Britain and Ireland. Thank you.

file: SSEL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 20May2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-May-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: Through capital investment of over £12 billion in the last 10 years, we've transformed SSE's asset base and  extended it to Ireland, all the while maintaining the balance streams of energy businesses that have been SSE's  hallmark from day one.

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: Now, politics and legislation have loomed large throughout my time as Chairman. No fewer than eight energy  ministers and seven energy-related acts of parliaments since I took the Chair in 2005. And throughout that time,  SSE has been a constructive and progressive contributor to energy policy debates. And I am very proud to have  been associated with a company that's a living-wage employer and, officially, a [ph] fair tight spear (01:39)

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: In a challenging business environment, it's vital that companies have a clear purpose, clear strategy and a clear  financial objective. SSE has all of these. Our established core purpose is to provide the energy people need in a  reliable and sustainable way. At its heart our strategy is to deliver the efficient operational and investment in a  balanced range of energy businesses in the UK and Ireland.

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: Now whatever way you look at it, 2015 will be an important year for energy businesses with the new UK  government taking forward its energy policy commitments and the Competition and Markets Authority ma king  progress towards the conclusion of its market investigation.

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: The combination of these events is not without risk. But it does mean there's an opportunity for the emergence of  a more coherent and enduring framework for the energy sector, and I know that SSE will continue to be a positive  contributor to the work of the UK government and the [ph] CME (4:45)

texts.speaker: Hon Robert Smith
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: 2014-2015 financial year was expected to present a number of major challenges and it sure did. Intervention in  Wholesale, regulation in Networks, and competition in Retail and in Enterprise. Despite these challenges, we've  maintained our record of annual dividend growth. We've delivered a solid performance on adjusted earnings per  share and profit before tax. We've invested £1.48 billion in assets in the UK and Ireland, and we've extended our  household energy price freeze having cut prices twice in the last 15 months.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: The exceptional charges relate mainly to businesses in our Wholesale segment, with 46% of the total being  impairments relating to Ferrybridge and Fiddler's Ferry, 24% being impairments relating to the Aldbrough gas  storage facility, and 15% relating to our E&P assets. We did, however, benefit from exceptional credits relating to  £7 5 million of gains from assets held for sale on 31 March 2014.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Looking now at our three business segments. In Wholesale, operating profit is down by around a quarter to  £47 3.8 million mainly through tough market conditions, lower electricity output from coal and wind, and lower  day ahead prices for gas production. This also provides some context for the difficult decision on Ferrybridge  which we also announced this morning.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: In Networks, operating profit is up almost 2% to £936.8 million with the drop in electricity distribution [ph] being  (8:00) more than offset by the benefits from our long-term investment in transmission. And in Retail, the  operating profit of £456.8 million reflects a strong focus on performance and cost efficiencies, which helped  return energy supply and profit around the level reported in 2012-2013. It equates to £69 for a typical dual fuel  customer. Retail profit also includes £88 million attributable to our enterprise and our energy-related services  businesses.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Our asset base benefited from capital and investment spend in the year of £1.48 billion, with Networks accounting  for just over half of that. This company has always had a strong and diverse asset base. And over the la st five  years, we've added to it with an increase of $2.4 billion in the RAV of our Networks, completion of almost 800  megawatts of new onshore wind, completion of 350 megawatts of new offshore wind, and completion of the new  CCGT in Ireland.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: We expect that our capital and investment spend in this new financial year will be around £1.75 billion before  proceeds from disposals. We also expect the trend towards Networks to continue, with them accounting for  around half of the total. While the exact phasing and value of CapEx and disposals could vary, we're still looking at  a CapEx program of around £5.5 billion net across the four years to March 2018. This includes committed spend  on maintenance, projects in construction and regulated networks like Caithness and Moray. And optional for new  assets under development such as onshore wind farms that will be committed if [ph] turns out (12:42) clearly  greater than the cost of capital.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: In addition, we have a strong portfolio of projects at earlier stages of development. When it comes to optional  spend on new assets, we will recycle capital from disposals to stay in line with the targeted £5.5 billion net spend.  In line with our value program, we currently expect to secure financial benefit of just over £1 billion from the  disposal of non-core assets and businesses which has already secured £475 million and the sale of existing  onshore wind farms in development.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: We've already agreed to sell 16 megawatts at Langhope Rig before the main disposal program is even underway.  This will enable us to recycle capital from current assets where greater value can be secured from investing in new  ones.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Investment in distribution was £328 million, and the total for the five-year price control to March 2015 was just  over £1.4 billion. This follows spend of just under £1.3 billion in the previous price control. Investment like this  helps keep the lights on for customers, and that's our first priority. One example of this is our investment in smart  fuses to improve fault detection and supply restoration. And in March, we achieved the fastest ever restoration of  supplies following a Category 2 weather event in the north of Scotland.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Our goals over the last year have been to deliver good operational performance for customers, deliver solid  financial results for investors and ensure SSE is well-positioned to succeed in a changing sector. Much change is  driven by politics and regulation. And we've been contending with the combination of Ofgem's distribution price  control process, as Gregor had described; the first ever auction for generation capacity; the CMA energy market  investigation; and the extended buildup to the UK general election.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: This means that 2015 will be an important year for energy businesses, with a new UK government taking forward  its energy policy commitments and the CMA making progress towards the conclusion of its market's investigation.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: As Robert said, the combination of these events is not without risk. But it means there is a good opportunity to  create a more coherent and enduring framework for the energy sector. SSE will continue to contribute positively  to the work of the CMA and the new UK government. The interim findings of the CMA are not now expected for  another month or so. And it's important to remember, they will then be the subject to more analysis and  consultation before the final report is published around the end of this year.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Our goal is to secure a coherent and enduring framework for the energy sector on the basis that they are soundly - based, right for the industry and its investors, and most importantly of all, customers. It's encouraging that the  new UK government is committed to supporting the CMA.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Much of the political and regulatory debate will continue to focus on energy supply. Over the last couple of years,  we've seen particularly competitive market conditions and our customer account numbers fell by 5.7% over the  year to £8.58 million. We have, however, maintained a strong focus on operational and financial efficiencies. And  this helped operating profit in Retail recover to the level seen two years ago.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Looking at Energy Supply, our profit margin was 4.6%, equating to £69 for typical dual fuel customer. We think  this is a reasonable return for an efficient operator and the lowest cost base among the leading suppliers. Last  month's cut in household gas prices however, means we expect Energy Supply operating profit to fall in this new  financial year.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: With a dynamic market and more than 20 competitors, we expect customer numbers to continue to decline in the  short-term, but we have a clear plan to help us achieve stability and trust for the long-term. It's based on  providing customers with value for money, peace of mind and sector-leading service. In support of this plan, we've  cut household prices twice in 15 months, extended our household energy price freeze until at least July 2016.  Started a long-term brand-building program, launched an industry-leading offer on broadband in line with our  commitment to offer customers more, actively apply the principles of treating customers fairly, taking a series of  substantive steps to improve customer service and invest in the fundamental overhaul of digital channels for our  customers.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: This, along with the smart meter rollout, has required investment amounting to £109.6 million during the year to  enhance customer service and install smart meters. We believe that this plan will put us in a strong position to  compete effectively as the shape of the retail energy market becomes clearer over the coming year. We think it's  the right plan for the long-term.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Retail now includes the B2B enterprise business. It's just over a year since we brought together SSE services in  competitive markets for industrial, commercial and public sector customers under the leadership of Jim  McPhillimy. Bringing together these businesses, supported by dedicated relationship management function,  complemented by the energy solutions business we acquired last summer, gives these customers one point of  contact for their energy and telecom's needs.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Including a disposal gain, the business earned £70.4 million in operating profit in the last financial year. As  customers' energy management and infrastructure requirements evolve, we believe we've created a business that  has a potential to achieve significant and sustainable growth.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: I'll now turn to Wholesale. Our Wholesale businesses provide energy and related services for energy market  participants in GB and Ireland. And in recent years, they've been impacted by long-term trends including an  uncertain macroeconomic picture, volatile commodity prices, increasing competition, government intervention  and the continued drive to a low-carbon economy.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: This has affected thermal generation and gas production assets, in particular, and contributed to two features of  this morning's results: a fall of 25.3% in operating profit in the Wholesale segment, and exceptional challenges of  £685.9 million relating to coal-fired power stations and gas storage and gas production assets.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Our thermal generation assets were again loss making during the year. And the trends I describe d plus our  commitment to value meant we had no alternative but to review them. We have to ensure that SSE retains the  right balance of assets, contracts and auctions for future development. These trends have had a particular impact  on our coal-fired power stations, which are increasingly expensive to maintain and subject to major  environmental legislation and regulation. Against this background, we've concluded that we should not reopen  Unit 4 at Ferrybridge, where equipment was badly damaged during last summer's fire. We've also concluded that  Unit 3 should be closed by the end of the current financial year, which will mark the end of coal-fired generation  at the station.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: This was a difficult decision to take because of its impact on the people who work at the station and their families,  but it was also the right decision to take. Financially, it costs over £50 million a year simply to keep a station like  Ferrybridge open. Environmentally, it is a major emitter of CO2, and therefore, a contentious source of electricity.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Ferrybridge will, of course, remain an active electricity generation site with the forthcoming commissioning of the  £300 million multi-fuel plant. The financial and environmental issues also apply at Fiddler's Ferry. But unlike  Ferrybridge, the majority of the plant there has a capacity contract for a year from October 2018, and it's our  intention to submit the plans into the forthcoming auction for providing capacity from 2019. We'll reassess the  options for Fiddler's Ferry after the outcome of that auction is known.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: All of this is consistent with our long-established strategy of moving towards a lower carbon generation portfolio,  weighted towards gas and renewables. Although gas-fired generation has struggled financially in recent years, it  will play an increasingly central role in meeting the company's electricity needs.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: SSE's gas-fired power stations have underlying quality and value in which we've continued to invest. They're  supported by a strong engineering capability, which can maximize plant's availability and flexibility. In terms of  our wholly-owned plant, Peterhead is undergoing a £15 million investment program that will improve its  flexibility, allowing it to operate in the market at up to 400 -megawatts from this winter. And it's also benefiting  from voltage contracts with National Grid.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Medway and Keadby have benefited from a combined investment of over £100 million to boost their reliability  and flexibility. And we've recently decided to bring Keadby out of deep mothball, so it have the option of returning  to service in the coming winter. The future looks more positive for Keadby and Medway, which both secure  contracts to provide capacity in the 2018 realm. And for Peterhead as well, where the Carbon Capture and Storage  project is also making good progress.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: New CCGT development is another issue, however. And our commitment to value means we don't intend to  commit any further investment in the projects at Abernedd, Keadby and Seabank unless they're successful in the  future capacity market auction process.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: SSE had developed a quality portfolio of renewable energy assets across the UK and Ireland with hydro, onshore  wind and offshore wind and with assets in Scotland, England and Ireland. As Gregor said earlier, in the last five  years alone, we've completed just under 800 megawatts of new onshore wind and 350 megawatts of new offshore  wind.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The net result is that we have a renewables portfolio that is diverse in terms of technology, location and  jurisdiction. There are, however, three things we need to take into account, our disciplined approach to capital  investment, and in particular, a planned net spend of £5.5 billion for the four years through 2018; avoiding over- dependency on particular fuels or technologies, especially where they required government-sponsored support;  and the introduction of competition for support through CfDs which will change the way projects are developed  and constructed.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: For these reasons, we're selling existing onshore wind farms and developments in order to recycle capital. And  we've already agreed to sell 16 megawatts at Langhope Rig before the main disposal program has got underway.  We're targeting at least £500 million of proceeds from that program and we're planning to recycle the capital  where we believe greater value can be secured from investing in new assets.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In the meantime, we have over 280 megawatts of onshore wind farm capacity under construction at four sites in  Scotland and Ireland. This means we're well placed to add new capacity before the  RO deadline of 2017 and well  placed to compete for CfDs there afterwards.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Looking offshore, the Beatrice project, in which we now have a 50% stake, already has an early CfD, and we're  continuing to do the work needed to maintain progress towards a final investment decision in 2016. Whatever the  support mechanism and however the government chooses to phase out our support for onshore wind, the test for  all our projects is the same. Can they earn returns that are clearly greater than the cost of capital and  can they be  funded within the capital program we defined last March.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: One asset that has already passed these two tests is the new CCGT at Great Island. The plant is now in full  commercial operation and completion costs have out-turned close to £125 million over the three years since the  development was acquired. And while capacity is constrained to 431 megawatts for now, it will be the cleanest,  most efficient and reliable gas power plant on the Irish grid.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Like GB, the market in Ireland is already undergoing significant change, with planned reform of a Single  Electricity Market being published in September. We have a Dublin-based team that is fully engaged in the  regulatory and policy processes. And while change always brings both risk and opportunities,  we're comfortable  with the reform process so far.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: It's now five years since SSE first invested in gas production assets and the time since then, we've built up a  portfolio of assets with estimated reserves in excess of 2.2 billion therms at March 31 this year. Clearly, lower  wholesale gas prices have taken their toll on profitability with operating profit down to £37 million. But as we said  at the interims, we'll look at gas-weighted opportunities to increase our reserve base in line with our investment  criteria and financial discipline.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Financial discipline is key because the business faces continuing challenges. By the end of this financial year, we  will have the outcome of the CMA's look at the distribution price control, start of implementation of the  new  government's energy policies and provisional findings and potential remedies in the CMA market investigation.  They all present a degree of uncertainty, but they also provide an opportunity to achieve a stable policy and  regulatory framework that give consumers confidence, allows regulators to regulate and encourages investors to  invest in the energy market. In such an environment, there will be significant opportunities for growth.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: On top of this, we've successfully commissioned the CCGT at Great Island. We focused our distribution business  on its customers, secured Ofgem approval for the Caithness-Moray link, extended our price freeze to GB  household customers, invested in the modernization of our energy supply business, launched our integrated B2B  business Enterprise, maintained a strong pipeline of options for future investments, and reduced the level of our  net debt and its cost with the issue of hybrid capital securities.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Working with Richard, we'll continue to be focused on delivering annual dividend growth that at least matches  RPI inflation and taking the long-term decisions so that shareholders continue to receive a fair return on the  investment they have made and are making in the future energy needs of Britain and Ireland. Thank you .

file: SSEL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 18May2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman
texts.text: With further significant investment to come in Networks and renewables and with the continuing focus on core  operations, the board is confident that SSE will deliver a dividend increase of at least RPI inflation in the new  financial year and in the years beyond as well.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: In the year just finished, adjusted profit before tax fell by 3.3% and operating profit fell by 3%, reflecting mixed  results across the SSE Group. In Wholesale, the 6.6% fall in operating profit was mainly the result of challenging  market conditions in Gas Production. Challenging market conditions also prevailed in Gas Storage and in Thermal  Generation. Operating profit in Networks, however, was closer to the previous years, with the 1.1% fall largely the  result of the expected reduction in our Electricity Distribution revenues under ED1. Operating p rofit in Retail was  also very close to the previous years, reflecting strong performance in Business Energy Supply.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Looking across the board, commodity prices at the end of March were around one-third lower than a year before.  All of this has contributed to the total exceptional charges of £889.9 million, comprising £613.4 million relating to  Thermal Generation and £312.7 million relating to Gas Storage and Gas Production. Within the Gas Production  total, £121.2 million relates to the Greater Laggan assets.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: At the time of challenging market conditions, the benefits of SSE's balanced range of businesses and the program  of investment in them are more important than ever. In 2015/2016, we invested £1.62 billion, around the half of  which was in economically regulated networks and there was a further 20% invested in government-mandated  renewables.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: This continues the balanced approach to investment we've taken over the past few years, the benefits of which we  can see in today's results. 11.5% increase in output of renewables helped to maintain operating profit at EPM and  Generation segments. And the ongoing progress of large capital projects delivered growing operating profit in  transmission.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Since April 2010, including our share of SGN's CapEx, we've invested £ 10.4 billion across the SSE Group. Around  7 5%, or £7.7 billion, of this was in Networks and renewables. In 2010, the output of our renewables assets was  around 5 terawatt hours, and the RAV of our Networks businesses was £5 billion. As a result of our investment,  the output of our renewables is now close to 10 terawatt hours and our Networks' RAV has reached almost £8  billion.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Across the two areas, this has delivered since 2010 a compound annual growth rate of around 12% in operating  profit. And the underlying value of our renewables assets was confirmed by the proceeds received and £138.6  million gain on sale from part-disposal of Clyde. This has been strategic, disciplined investment in assets that are  either independently regulated or government-mandated and, therefore, lower risk. It supports our earnings and  our continuing commitment to dividend growth.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Economically regulated network and government-mandated renewables will account for around two-thirds of this  expenditure. It also includes around £1.75 billion in this new financial year and around £1.65 billion in the next,  although this is obviously subject to change.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Over the four years, around £4.3 billion of the expected CapEx is committed on projects ranging from Caithness- Moray transmission link to the Clyde extension wind farm. This means the rest are subject to ongoing  development and final investment decision.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Enhancing earnings to support dividend growth is key. But as we have said before, the nature of energy position  now means that financial results in any single year are always subject to well-documented uncertainty. As I've said  earlier, we are looking ahead to the three years to March 2019, and we're expecting dividend cover could range  from around 1.2 times to around 1.4 times based on dividend increases that at least keep pace with inflation.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: I believe that these results tell you four important things about SSE. Even in a challenging year, the company  delivered what it says it will. Having a balanced range of energy businesses brings real benefits. The returns from  investments in Networks and renewables have come through strongly and have continued. And the scope for  investment for future growth remains strong based on rigorous financial management.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: The continued investment in automation, network reinforcement and tree cutting has also delivered  improvements to help secure positive financial incentives under the new price control. They should equate to over  £20 million that should come through as revenue in 2017/2018. The renewed focus on customer service and  innovation will continue in this second year of the price control and beyond.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Finance Director
texts.text: Transmissions price control is now over three years old. An Ofgem's decision that a midterm revie w of this is not  needed is obviously good news. This business is continuing to grow in a strong and sustainable way, and its RAV is  now over £2 billion. This investment in the asset base has driven the sustained growth and profitability illustrated  by the 56% increase in operating profit we reported this morning.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Thank you, Gregor, and good morning, everyone. The fog of uncertainty surrounding the energy sector has, to a  significant extent, cleared over the last year. As Richard reminded us earlier, the RIIO-ED1 framework has been  confirmed. The overall policy direction of the UK government has become clearer, and the provisional remedies  from the CMA market investigation have been published.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: As Richard also pointed out, there are aspects of this that we welcome positively, and there are aspects about  which we have some reservations. A degree of political and regulatory uncertainty is unavoidable in energy. With  effort now seems likely, the sector is to feature robust and economic regulation for Networks, effective  remuneration for providing generation capacity, and the degree of consensus about the future operation of the  retail market [ph] than it is a sector (21:45) in which SSE can be successful for the benefit of customers and  investors alike.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We've also shared indicative CapEx  plans for the full year to March 2020. For the financial year just started, we're  targeting a return to growth in EPS and, therefore, dividend cover that is comfortably within that range. Gregor  has described the strength that our Network businesses bring to the SSE Group, the same can be said for our  Wholesale business, businesses continuing investment in renewables.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The 11.5% increase in renewables output helped our EPM and Generation segment maintain operating profit  around the same level as a year ago. Our investment in renewables has still some way to go. The UK government  adopted a reasonably pragmatic approach to the implementation of its policy to bring to an end the renewables  obligation. This means we still have 428 megawatts net of RO qualifying onshore wind farm capacity to come on  stream in Scotland and Northern Ireland within the next two years.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: On top of this, by March 2018, we also expect to have commissioned a further 120 megawatt net of onshore wind  capacity in the Republic of Ireland. Financial close on the Beatrice offshore wind farm, in which our stake is 235  megawatts, should be reached shortly, it's expected to be fully operational by 2019.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Looking ahead, the 783 megawatts that is still to come on stream represent a major portfolio o f government- mandated projects that are still to be completed. We have so far maintained a good track record for wind farm  construction that I believe will be extended.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The value of renewable energy assets was recently confirmed by the disposal of Clyde, and I believe this next phase  of investment will allow us [ph] to have returns that are fair (24:05) to investors who'll provide the capital and fair  to [indiscernible] (24:14) ultimately remunerated. Looking further ahead, we retain other options in both onshore  and offshore wind in the future CfD auctions or other developments provide the opportunity to deploy the  capability we have built up over the last decade, and we will definitely look to do so.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: While global commodity prices have had some effects on the revenue earned from producing renewable energy,  we have made generating power from several sources a loss-making activity. With that, which led us to consult on  the future of Fiddler's Ferry earlier this year. Between them, the UK government, National Grid and Ofgem have  responsibility for keeping the electricity system running. They've repeatedly demonstrated that they have a range  of tools and options in place to do this, such as National Grid's tender for a provision of ancillary services. That  resulted in a black start contract being awarded to Fiddler's Ferry, it should enable [ph] the station (25:11) to be  around breakeven over the period after significant losses.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In addition, the UK government has agreed plans to strengthen the capacity market with the clear statement that  the volume of capacity procured needs to rise and the clearing price needs to increase. The plans, therefore,  represent the pragmatic package and if they allow thermal power stations to be adequately rewarded for providing  capacity, it should achieve its number one objective of maintaining secure electricity supply to the families and  businesses across the country.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: More broadly, I think the event of the last few months, which also include the extension of carbon price support,  demonstrate two things. First, the importance of maintaining an open and constructive relationship with  government; and second, the importance of maintaining a diverse portfolio of assets, contracts and investment  options to be able to respond effectively to changes in the external environment.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Three examples illustrate the benefits of diversity in generation technology. On coal, we will now have the  opportunity to enter some or all of Fiddler's Ferry into the plant's capacity market auction for 2017 and 2 018. On  gas, the prospects have improved to the extent that we will step up development work on a second CCGT at  Keadby. And on multi-fuel, we're in a good position to go ahead with a second plant with Ferrybridge.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: In all of these, we've maintain our financial discipline and emphasis on strong project development and execution.  We've seen this in Ireland with our new CCGT at Great Island that has completed a full year of commercial  operation. And this has confirmed its position as the cleanest, most efficient and reliable gas plant on the Irish  Grid and a natural complement to our portfolio of renewables.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: While EPM and Generation operating profit was around the same as the previous year, commodity prices  obviously contributed significantly to the falling operating profit in Gas Production. The longer-term prospects for  this business, however, a much brighter in the assets acquired last October expected to make a good contribution  to profit in this new financial year and well beyond.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: The acquisition was part of the well-established strategy to maintain a balanced range of businesses. Production  from our new assets could continue until the early 2030s making them a long-term investment and include the  Shetland Gas Plant, a critical piece of state-of-the-art industry infrastructure that was officially opened by Amber  Rudd earlier this week.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Everything that SSE does is ultimately paid for by customers, and as a business, we must always remember how  important it is that people can afford to pay their bills. So o ur low commodity prices have an impact on the returns  earned from operating and investing in energy assets. They do contribute to a generally more stable environment  for the Energy Supply business.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We've been able to cut prices three times in the last two years. This has benefited customers and helped to  maintain domestic Energy Supply margins at a reasonable level, although there are different underlying issues in  electricity and in gas.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Across Energy Supply, we benefited from growth in Business Energy especially in the I&C sector. This offset the  decline in household energy and contributed to operating profit across Retail as a whole being around the same  level as a year ago.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Over the last few years, we've seen particularly competitive market conditions [ph] and our (28:38) Energy Supply  customer account numbers again fell to 8.21 million. On an encouraging note, however, Home Services account  numbers grow by 15% to 400,000. This represents a positive step forward in delivering our strategy of diversifying  the range of products and services we offer to customers.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Y ou've hopefully seen this morning [ph] we're in the (29:21) midst of transforming our customers' experience to  dealing with SSE. Over the whole of 2015-2016, we invested £169 million in Energy Supply and Related Services  in what amounts to a significant modernization of the business. Key initiatives under way include optimizing the  smart meter rollout to drive digital customer engagement, upgrading customer-facing digital channels, and  diversifying the customer base, including expanding Home Services across the whole of GB.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We've already seen how modernizing our proposition in Energy Supply can have positive benefits in terms of  customer numbers with the growth in Business Energy. There we've launched new propositions, sharpened our  focus on the individual needs of customers and improved our overall level of customer support. This work is  continuing, and the ongoing development of Business Energy is a key priority for this financial year and beyond.  This includes working with SSE Enterprise, our B2B division. With integrated but bespoke products and serv ices  for businesses, SSE Enterprise should help to drive growth in the next two years.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Our priority has been and continues to be to ensure SSE is in a good position for the long term. We believe that  the foundations laid and the progress made puts us in a good position to meet the needs of our customers and  deliver a dividend commitment. This morning, we've demonstrated our ability to deliver what we say we will. We  affirmed our commitment to dividend growth that at least keeps pace with RPI inflation, confirmed that we're  targeting a return to growth and at least £0.120 EPS in this new financial year, extended our outlook for dividend  cover to 2019, set out the broad shape of our CapEx plans to 2020, shown the extent of the continuing investment  opportunities in both Networks and renewables, highlighted the opportunities that are emerging as a result of the  planned reform of the capacity market, and shown progress in modernizing Energy Supply for both household  and business.

file: SSEL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 17May2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: The focus on the energy trilemma remains, but this time, along with an – issues around industrial strategy. Our  position is that any proposals for market reform should always be subject to the fullest possible consultation, and  we will be a constructive contributor to any energy market reform process as we have been in the past.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The key headlines from today's results are that we've earned a 2.1% increase in adjusted PBT taking it to £1.546  billion. We've exceeded our target for adjusted EPS with an increase of 5.2% to £1.257. We've achieved our first  financial objective with a full-year dividend increase of 2.1% to £0.913, and we've delivered dividend cover of  1.3.8 (sic) [1.38] (04:35) times which is towards the top of the expected range. In a complex and challenging  environmental sector, these represent a robust set of results.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The results for individual businesses are in line with what we set out in March. In Retail, operating profit fell to  £422.3 million. There was a slight increase in household energy supply operating profit but this was outweighed  by falls in business energy and enterprise. In Wholesale, operating profit rose to £514.6 million with improved  performance in thermal generation, EPM and gas reduction, more than offsetting the impact of lower output of  renewable energy. In Networks, operating profit rose to £936.5 million with the expected reductions in electricity  conversion and gas distribution being outweighed by a higher contribution from electricity distribution.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We recognized impairments, charges and provisions totaling £374.6 million across thermal generation, gas  production, gas storage and retail, and a total gain of £366.4 million on the sale of a stake in SGN and the  revaluation of SSE's Clyde Windfarm investment. Overall, this gives us a net exceptional charge of £8.2 million.  Factors on gas production and retail account to the larger part of the £374.6 million. In gas production,  assessments of reserves on the one hand, and decommissioning cost on the other, had a significant impact. This  is clearly disappointing but we believe these assets will make an important contribution to SSE in the years  ahead.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In Retail, we decided last autumn to focus on improvements to customer-facing systems and channels, and so,  we decided not to replace our billing system. The last time was a difficult decision, giving rise to the exceptional  impairment, but it was the right decision. The reduction in operating profit from gas distribution followed the sale of  a 16.7% stake in SGN. In 2005, we paid £505 million for an equity stake of 50%. In 2016, we secured £621 million  for an equity stake of 16.7%. This shows SSE's ability to deliver value for shareholders.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're putting the net proceeds to good use, with around £100 million to support the Stronelairg wind farm  investment in line with the approach to resizing capital we first adopted in 2014. More broadly, we plan to return a  total of around £500 million to shareholders by way of a known market share buyback. To date, we've completed  £196 million of the buyback and still expect to complete it by the end of December. We also still expect the  ongoing EPS impact of the SGN sale and how the proceeds are used to be broadly neutral over the medium term.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In March, we completed the sale of our equity holdings in PFI street lighting projects, thereby completing the  three-year, £1.1 billion business disposals and debt reduction program that we announced in March 2014. The  delivery of this program, along with the sale of a stake in SGN, confirms that timely disposals to create value for  shareholders should always be an option for us especially where, as we said when we started the program, we  help to simplify and streamline the SSE group.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Excluding SGN, we invested almost £11 billion across the SSE group since 2010. Around £7.8 billion of this was  in electricity networks and renewables. In 2010, including pumped storage, we had 2.4 gigawatts of renewable  energy capacity in operation. That's now almost 40% greater at 3.3 gigawatts.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Also, in 2010, we've had an electricity networks RAV of £3 billion. That's almost doubled to close to £6 billion.  Across the two areas, this has created a new modern asset base that is sustainable, provides index-linked  earnings and will create long-term value for the SSE group.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In 2016/2017, we invested £1.73 billion across the SSE group. In this new financial year, we again expect to  invest around £1.7 billion, and around the same again next year. This means we're on course to invest around £6  billion across the four years to 2020. Economically-regulated networks and government-mandated renewables will  account for around two-thirds of this. This means the investment and the transformation of SSE are continuing.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Subject to the standard factors that affect earnings in our market-based businesses, such as energy production  and demand levels, we continue to expect the dividend cover for this new financial year will be within or towards  the bottom of the expected range of around 1.2 times to around 1.4 times. This clearly means that adjusted EPS  will be lower than the £1.257 we reported this morning.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: With around two-thirds of our operating profit derived from owning and operating economically-regulated networks  and government-mandated renewables, we think growing the dividend in line with RPI is a reasonable and  sustainable target. With the quality of these assets and the index-linked revenue allied to our long-term view of  the business, we also believe our target dividend cover range is reasonable and sustainable.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: I'll now turn to Networks. The shape of our Networks business has evolved, with the relative stability of the returns  from them and the index-linked RAV and revenues, as I have just mentioned, meaning they underpin our target  for annual dividend growth. The index-linked point remains particularly important given some economist forecast  for inflation. And as Alistair will point out, it also applies to renewable energy support schemes as well.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Including SGN, the total RAV of our Networks businesses is now almost £7.7 billion. And so, it's well placed to  reach close to £9 billion by 2020. We retained an important stake in SGN and its new shareholding structure gives  it greater flexibility in its future development. The business is continuing to evolve with the construction of a third  distribution network comprising 700 kilometers of new gas pipelines to the west of Belfast.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: With the backing of shareholders, it has also launched a meter asset provider company which will fund the  purchase and installation of smart meters on behalf of energy supplier. It's also delivering an innovation program  designed to ensure that gas has a secure long-term future in the UK energy mix.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: As I hope most of you here saw before the session began, our Distribution business is also looking to the future.  The findings from the work we've done in the Thames Valley and elsewhere, will be key to inform any transition of  network operators to system operators and will help with the transition to a low-carbon economy. We believe that  customers' interests are best protected by this transition, which will meet the needs for a smart, flexible and de- carbonized electricity system, thus ensuring networks remain resilient and affordable.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Gregor, and good morning, everyone. In the interims, we acknowledged the considerable political  interest in energy market and said that the sector will continue to be subject to scrutiny and, possibly, further  intervention. At SSE, we've always accepted that politicians and regulators have a role to play in ensuring the  energy market works for customers. We believe that any proposals for a price cap or, indeed, any other  substantive proposal for change should be the subject of the fullest possible scrutiny and consultation so that all  of the impacts and consequences understood before final decisions are made. Our approach to such  consultations have been and remain to engage actively and constructively. In that spirit, we published our own  manifesto two weeks ago.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our Wholesale business continues to be impacted by macroeconomic uncertainty, the ongoing transition to a low- carbon economy, and shifting commodity prices. In EPM and Generation, the diversity of our contracts and asset  helps mitigate the volatile energy market conditions that can have wide-ranging impacts.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The impact of lower output from our renewables is partly offset by improved contribution from our thermal power  station portfolio in the year to March. At the same time, those power stations operate in a very complex  environment. They derive revenue from a number of sources including a variety of contract. And operate in the  context of a wide [ph] extensive (25:28) Energy Portfolio Management decision. The year-on-year volatility in the  economic position of Fiddler's Ferry is a good example of the impact such complexity can have.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In terms of Gas Production, despite the reduced year-end assessment of 2P Reserve, the performance, output  and operating profit were all good. Gas Storage, however, remains a challenged business, but we're continuing to  respond to the trading conditions by providing flexibility and hedging services to customers while managing  profitability.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In volatile markets, we have to monitor and manage continuously the shape of our portfolio of assets and  contracts to ensure we're delivering the best outcome for energy customers and shareholders. The importance of  diversity and flexibility has never been greater.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: While we're continuing to review the [ph] future piece (26:18) ahead, we believe there is a major, if evolving, role  for [ph] gas by (26:22) generation to play in the future. And we're actively considering options in this area. We also  believe there's potential for further development of multifuel power generation. In both cases, our commitment to  disciplined investment when it comes to decisions on building assets applies.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: At the same time, what the Clyde and Beatrice disposals have shown the value of renewable energy assets is  clear and with higher inflation forecast it's important that the Renewables Obligation and CfDs are index-linked.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking ahead, we retained a number of [ph] auctions (26:54) in on and offshore wind such as

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Forewind project at Dogger Bank. The future CfD auctions or other developments provide the opportunity to  deploy the capability we've built up over the last decade, and we'll clearly look to do so.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In the meantime, strategic disciplines, capital investment in building new modern assets is a major engine for  growth over the next few years. Looking at our current investments, we're making good progress in constructing  the second multifuel plant in Ferrybridge. In onshore wind, we've made good progress in constructing new wind  farm capacity, with over 500 megawatts due to be completed in the course of this financial year. We also have a  225-megawatt Stronelairg wind farm in construction, and all of these new capacity should qualify for the RO or  REFIT support. As our current arrangements to hedge the risks associated with renewable energy generation  unwind, the benefit returns earned from the investment in onshore wind will be reflected in EPS and dividend  towards the end of this decade and beyond.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In offshore wind, our capacity share at Beatrice is 235 megawatts. With construction on and offshore now well  underway, the project is on course to be fully operational in 2019. The completion of Beatrice and other projects is  expected to take SSE's total wind farm capacity in operation to 2.8 gigawatts net by the end of this decade.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: While the need to recognize an impairment was disappointing, our Greater Laggan Area assets are operating  well. Their output contributed to a significant rise in production, which more than offset the natural decline in  output from existing fields. This should ensure that our average annual volumes of gas and liquids produced  continue at a high level than those reported in previous years.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking across the next couple of years based on the latest assessments, the Greater Laggan Area acquisition  [ph] is expected to meet (28:50) our average annual volumes of gas produced will be around 500 million therms.  They represent a substantial collection of assets that are a natural complement to the energy businesses in the  SSE Group.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: On top of that, the Shetland Gas Plant, a critical piece, a state-of-the-art industry infrastructure that will generate a  return for SSE into 2030. As I've said before, everything SSE does is ultimately paid for by customers. And as a  group of energy businesses, we must always remember how important it is that people can afford to pay their  bills.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The slight fall in operating profit across Retail is a reminder of the competitive complex nature of the markets in  which all of our retail businesses operate. There was competition and our focus on customers that led us to delay  for as long as possible the household electricity price increase that took effect last month. And as far as  household energy supply is concerned, our first priority is to ensure we're doing the right things to give customers  what they're looking for in product, service and value. The net loss of energy customer accounts was lower than in  recent years.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The other priority in household energy supply is to manage our regulatory obligations especially the need to treat  customers fairly. This obviously includes the rollout of smart meters and the implementation of the agreed CMA  remedy. These obligations are significant and so maybe the extent of market reform. Their financial  consequences across the sector, excluding the meters themselves, we have so far invested over £300 million in  the smart rollout. And the PPM price cap will have an estimated revenue impact of over £40 million a year. This  puts the onus on us to look at every opportunity to take costs out of the business, which we're doing and to look  very carefully at any investment, that's why we've ruled out replacing our billing system for the foreseeable future.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: This was a tough decision, and we'll take more tough decisions if their necessary in response to regulatory or  political development. These could clearly include some form of cap on household energy bills. The results of the  election and the nature and timing of any cap, and the timing of this introduction are not certain, and this leads to  financial or operational impact of that. This morning's statement lists some of the key features of an energy price  cap which, along with the company's actions in response, would determine whether its impact on our Retail  business would be relatively minor, very major, or something in between.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: This is one issue where the devil really is in the detail and the real work begins in June when we're engaged  constructively in response to any government proposals for household energy price cap or other sector reform.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In the B2B space where we have around 450,000 customer accounts, we want to build greater presence in the  market for energy supply to businesses. To do that, our business energy team is transforming what it offers  customers in the commercial sector and associated services it provides. And the new leadership is offering a  range of energy contracts tailored to customers' needs and adding value by providing business customers with  advice and support for managing their energy usage. This is backed up by our high-quality of service which is  illustrated by our success in being ranked the number one domestic energy provider for handling complaints from  small business customers.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Clearly, the next three years, will bring challenges managing the factors that affect earnings in our business and  potential regulatory change as well. Looking over the three years to 2020, SSE is aiming to deliver annual  dividend increases that at least keep pace with RPI inflation, achieve dividend cover within a range of around 1.2  times to 1.4 times, continue the £6 billion program of capital and investment expenditure mainly in networks and  renewables, increase the RAV of our economically regulated networks to close to £9 billion, increase the amount  of renewable energy capacity to 4.3 gigawatts and influence positively changes in energy retail markets and  respond decisively to them.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The second is that SSE is a resilient business with a commitment to doing the right things for customers and a  good pipeline of investments in energy assets for the future. The third is that SSE is an adaptable business that is  constantly changing in response to key developments in the energy sector and will continue to evolve to best  serve the interest of customers and shareholders. Focused, resilient and adaptable, are qualities that will stand us  in good stead in the months and years ahead.

file: SSEL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 25May2018 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Richard D. Gillingwater
texts.profession: Chairman, SSE Plc
texts.text: In the course of today's session, the team will set out how SSE has the strengths, strategy and assets, and the  earnings engine, cash flow capability and focus to deliver on our five-year dividend plan. It's a plan which for  2018-2019 gives clarity about the dividend in this time of transition for SSE. For 2019-2020 reflects the expected  changes to the SSE Group, arising from the planned SSE Energy Services transaction, and then for the three  years to 2023 sets the dividend on a path for sustainable growth. It is a plan to which the entire board and  management team is committed to delivering. And with that, I'll now hand over to Alistair. Thank you.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Richard, and good morning, everyone. Our dividend plan reflects our commitment to realizing the  significant opportunities we see to create value in an energy system that is changing rapidly. First, a decade on  from the Climate Change Act, the momentum behind decarbonization appears unstoppable with a focus on clean  growth, supported by public policy and falling renewables cost. This presents opportunities for SSE as a leading  generator and developer of renewable energy. We've already cut the carbon intensity, the power we generate by  50% and we have a new ambition for a further 50% reduction taking it to around 150 grams per kilowatt hour by  2030.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Second, the trend to electrification is clear and is being reinforced by the focus on air quality as well as  decarbonization, illustrated by the expansion of electricity in transport. This presents opportunities for SSE as an  electricity generator and distributor and as a utility services provider.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Third, the commitment to a major upgrade of infrastructure is at the heart of the UK's Industrial Strategy,  illustrated by the fact that public infrastructure investment is expected to have doubled in a decade by 2023. This  offers opportunities for SSE as a provider of local energy, telecoms and rail solutions. The opportunities  presented by decarbonization, electrification infrastructure development are clearly very significant but change  brings challenges as well. In particular, options to provide new infrastructure and services are a growing feature of  the energy sector with competition very strong. Meanwhile, scrutiny of the costs of energy to customers extends  to Networks and the RIIO 2 process is now well underway. Fundamental political questions are also being asked  about the privatization of energy – sorry, the private provision of energy, apologies.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Ensuring SSE's best place to meet the challenges and capitalize on the opportunities will require an even greater  focus on core strengths and competencies in regulated networks and renewables, and a range of complementary  businesses with relevant options and opportunities. This, in turn, requires the capacity to make the right decisions  at the right time. That's why we took the strategic decision to renew SSE. We're giving each of the businesses in  SSE the best platform for success in the light of the challenges and opportunities that lie ahead. We're more  convinced than ever that the strategic decision to demerge our GB household retail business and combine it with  npower is the right thing for customers and the energy market and for SSE and shareholders.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Compared with the status quo of GB household supply and services retained within SSE, the new supplier under  Katie Bickerstaffe's leadership will be able to secure a greater value from focusing entirely on strategic and  operational developments in the retail sector, combining resources and being a stronger competitor and  significant synergies that we remain confident of delivering and there will be a further update in next month's  circular on this. These synergies expected to contribute to lower costs for customers. We're confident that we'll be  able to demonstrate to the CMA that the [ph] proposed (00:05:57) merger will deliver benefits for customers and  the energy market as a whole and we remain on track to complete the creation of the new independent supplier in  the second half of this financial year.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We believe that reshaping the SSE Group gives two clear advantages. For SSE, it gives a greater focus on the  infrastructure and related services relied on by energy customers which is more aligned to our core competencies  and for investors it gives greater visibility of assets and earnings in the future; the majority of which is expected to  come from regulated networks and renewables. Today's session marks the start of that.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: And if you look at the last three years, and exclude the SSE Energy Services business, over 80% of the SSE  Group operating profit is related to regulated networks and renewables. Going forward, Networks and renewables  will be core with flexible thermal generation such as the new plant at Keadby also having a key role.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In the likes of Enterprise, Business Energy in Ireland, we also have businesses as a complementary that benefit  from direct and indirect synergies. In all of these remaining business areas, the needs of energy customers will  continue to be a key focus for the group. We also have growth and value options for the future across all the  businesses in a fast-changing energy and infrastructure sector where opportunities may be fleeting, this  optionality is vital. It's why we need to maintain a range of complementary businesses and so maintain the ability  to create attractive long-term growth and value options.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: It also means making the most of the strength that reshaped SSE, so we're in the best possible position to  respond to the challenges posed by the key trends in the energy sector I mentioned earlier, to seize the  opportunities arising from decarbonization, electrification and infrastructure upgrade and generate the earnings  and cash flow that will sustain dividends in the years to come.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: I work with these people every day and I can assure you that as well as being great colleagues, SSE's people are  a key competitive advantage. And when you hear later from the likes of Stewart Reid and Jerry Williamson, you  will also see why. The achievement of our dividend targets will only be possible if we execute our strategy in a  sustainable way and this is our second key strength. Our ability to create value for shareholders depends on  working constructively with stakeholders to improve the outcomes we can achieve for energy and infrastructure  users and for our society as a whole. We have good sustainability credentials, which help us to do that and we  want to do more. Our Director of Sustainability, Rachel McEwen is here with us today.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: SSE's third key strength also relates to business sustainability. It's our commitment to discipline when it comes to  financial and risk management. Gregor will say more about this later, but amongst other things it means a clear  commitment to a strong balance sheet, effective cash flow management, diverse funding sources, agility in raising  capital, maintaining optionality and a disciplined approach to capital allocation, investment and acquisitions. SSE's  capacity to generate earnings is founded on this discipline which will be maintained in the future. SSE is focused  on core markets, the energy sector complex, the interdependencies are significant and with significant ambiguity  and change. This requires a clear management focus, which in turn generates greater experience of an insight  into our chosen markets. That supports effective disciplined and timely decision making. We've demonstrated that  in the past and it will be equally important in the future. Our market focus is the UK and Ireland and it will remain  so. But although we don't have any plans in the pipeline for now, we are open to extending to other markets our  core competencies in areas such as renewables.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The first strength I see in SSE is our relentless focus on operational efficiency, now becoming a broader culture of  continuous improvement; it's bringing clear benefits. For example later, you'll hear how our Network's team is  building a leadership position in influencing and preparing for the flexibility of evolution and transition to a smarter  electricity system. And you'll hear how our generation team is going to take steps to enhance the value derived  from some of our oldest assets, the hydroelectric schemes in Scotland.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The quality, nature and value of our assets is a key advantage since the acquisition of Airtricity in March 2008,  we've invested £15 billion across the SSE Group. This has delivered the value, range and quality of the asset  base that we have today. We have ownership interest in five economically regulated energy networks, four  classes of renewable energy capacity including pump storage and three main types of thermal generation. This is  a prized collection of assets to which we are continuing to add. It is complemented by an extensive telecoms  network, two B2B businesses, an interesting gas production and gas storage.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In the fast-changing sector, these assets present us with a strong pipeline of future opportunities for future value  creation. The two examples bring to mind; distribution networks are central to the fight against climate change,  connecting clean energy, supporting electrification of transport and facilitating change of system operators at  regional and local level. From the point of view of the country as a whole, the DNO is a by far better place than  any possible alternative to deliver change with the focus, speed and efficiency that electricity customers deserve.  And, in generation, we hold valuable prospects for each technology type and especially offshore wind where the  market continues to grow.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're taking active steps to be in a strong position to compete in the changing environment. It's now 14 years  since our venture with two Canadian financial institutions agreed to buy what is now SGN. The significant value  created in the time since reflects the enduring success of that partnership.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: So SSE is being renewed, building up on core strengths and competencies to meet the challenges and realize the  opportunities presented by the changing energy sector. Drawing on these strengths and competencies, the future  direction of SSE is clear. We will have a simple purpose to responsibly provide energy and related services  needed now and in the future.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our vision is to be a leading provider of energy and related services in a low-carbon world and our strategy is  clear – to create value for shareholders and society from developing, owning and operating energy and related  infrastructure and services in a sustainable way.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: When it comes to the political debates about energy, we believe that our responsible approach to business, our  support for a low-carbon future, our focus on sustaining skilled jobs and our commitment to making a positive  economic and social contribution will stand us in very good stead. The financial objective of this strategy is to  remunerate shareholders' investments through paying dividends. We're pleased that today's increase in the full- year dividend to £0.947 is the 20th successive increase since SSE was formed in 1998. As we said in March, this  will be a year of transition for us to see. Nevertheless, we are keen to give shareholders as much clarity as  possible in this year of transition. Drawing on a range of forecast for RPI inflation, we intend to recommend a 3%  increase in full-year dividend for 2018, 2019, taking it to £0.975 per share. This is not subject to the timing of the  planned SSE Energy Services transaction or of the price cap bill.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: SSE is committed to remunerating shareholders' investments through paying sustainable dividends for the long  term. Our longstanding view is that dividend sustainability is based on the quality and nature of the operations and  assets from which our earnings are derived and the long-term financial outlook. We also believe the dividend  should be set at a level that allows for annual increases and that at least keeps pace with RPI inflation for the  period for which targets are set. The next period is the five years to 2023 when the current electricity distribution  price control comes to an end.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: So, through this year of transition and in anticipation of the completion of the retail transaction, the SSE team is  giving you a clear and sustainable five-year dividend plan. We are giving clarity in this time of transition, intending  to recommend a full-year dividend of £0.975 per share in 2019, planning to set the first post-transaction full-year  dividend at £0.80 per share in 2020, a level that reflects the changes in the SSE Group and is clearly sustainable,  and targeting annual full-year dividend growth that at least matches RPI inflation in each of the following three  years to 2023. This is a five-year plan that quite simply reflects the underlying quality and value of SSE's assets  and the earnings and cash flows they deliver. And in addition to it, those SSE shareholders with shares in the new  independent energy supplier will be able to benefit from the value created by that business in the years ahead.

texts.speaker: Alistair Phillips-Davies
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: This morning, I've summarized the significant opportunities for SSE to create value in a changing energy system,  described how the SSE business model will evolve to seize those opportunities, set out the key strengths that I  believe will enable SSE to seize the opportunities and create value for shareholders and society and emphasize  our commitment to remunerating the shareholders' investment through paying dividends with a clear and  sustainable five-year plan out to 2023.
