We're fully aware of the challenges the energy sector faces but the  opportunities are there to be taken. In SSE, we have the strengths that are significant, opportunities that are  excellent and a dividend focus that is enduring.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Total exceptional charges were £213.3 million, a significant proportion relates to the gas production and retail  businesses. In Gas Production, a net impairment charge of a £104.7 million was recognized. This was driven  mainly by the latest annual independent reserves report. It takes account of all the technical and economic  variables and estimates, including current price projections for the Greater Laggan and Bacton fields. These  charges were slightly offset by reversal of previous exceptional impairments on the ECA field following an  increased estimation of hydrocarbon reserves in that field.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The results for individual businesses are also in-line with what we set out in March. In Wholesale, operating profit  rose by 26.8% to £652.4 million, mainly through improved performance in EPM and Generation, aided by higher  electricity output from gas and renewable plant. Within this, renewable capacity has increased through sustained  investment; helping to deliver a 21.3% increase in adjusted operating profit from renewables to £374.9 million.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In Retail, there was a relatively small fall in operating profit of 4.6% to £402.8 million. GB household energy  supply profit was similar to last year's but there was a decline in Business Energy which was offset by a recovery  in performance in Enterprise. Within Retail total £278.7 million is attributable to the SSE Energy Services  business that is subject of the planned transaction. That compares with £373.5 million a year ago.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: As you know, we increased electricity prices last year to reflect rising non-energy costs. We also secured  efficiency savings. These will offset the customer current losses and price caps for certain customer groups.  Overall, however, the financial performance of the business was robust.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: This is a year of transition for SSE and it's been clear for some time that it will present some challenges and some  uncertainties. Across the Networks segment, we expect adjusted operating profit to increase by a mid-single digit  percentage. In Wholesale, we've had to deal with the usual uncertainties associated with markets, plant and the  weather. And adjusted operating profit will also be affected by the end of – in the money power purchase  agreements. In addition, renewable energy output is forward-hedged at a price lower than in 2017-2018.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In addition, the timing of the key SSE Energy Services developments and their impact on our financial results is  not certain. Nevertheless, we're keen to give shareholders as much clarity as possible on the dividend over the  next five years, starting with this year of transition. That's why we said we intend to deliver a full year dividend of  £0.975 for 2018-2019; that will represent a 3% increase.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Looking at 2019-2020, we've assessed the impact of the planned transaction and so we intend to deliver a full- year dividend of £0.80. This reflects the fact that SSE Energy Services business will not be contributing earnings  or cash flow to the SSE Group and is consistent with our goal of delivering from the reshaped SSE annual  increases in the dividend that at least keep pace with RPI inflation which we are targeting for the three years to  2023. This five-year plan supersedes our previous focus on dividend cover because it gives shareholders visibility  and clarity on the company's sustainable commitment to the dividend for the years to come.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We believe this is a clear, responsible and sustainable approach to the dividend as we reshape the SSE Group  for the future. It's worth putting in context. EBITDA position from the core businesses of renewables and regulated  networks and dividends from SGN is strong. It's supplemented by the other businesses remaining within the SSE  Group.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: If from that, you take tax, interest, typical maintenance CapEx and cash payments based on an ETP dividend,  there remains significant headroom to support disciplined investment for growth. This underlines the extent to  which our dividend plan is sustainable. It was through our disciplined strategic investment in regulated networks  and renewables that we started the transformation of the SSE Group a decade ago.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: This transformation is supporting our earnings on our five-year dividend plan. Excluding SGN, we've invested £15  billion across the SSE Group since 2008; around £11 billion of this was in regulated electricity networks and  renewables.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In 2008, including pump storage, we had 2.4 gigawatts of renewable energy capacity in operation, that's now 50%  greater at 3.7 gigawatts and delivering EBITDA of £692 million in the last financial year.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Also in 2008, we had announced electricity networks RAV of £2.7 billion that's more than doubled to over £6  billion and delivering EBITDA of £894 million in the last financial year. Supported by excellence in operations,  we've delivered a new modern asset base that creates long-term value for shareholders and society. It's an asset  base that has been expanded, particularly rapidly in recent years. It means SSE as an earnings engine and cash  flow capability that enables us to deliver our five-year dividend plan.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: In 2017-2018, we invested over £1.5 billion across the SSE Group with around 70% of this on regulated networks  and renewables, building on a decade's work since the acquisition of Airtricity. That work is continuing and in this  new financial year, we expect to invest around £1.7 billion, with around two-thirds of that in regulated networks  and renewables. By 2020, our unique and diverse portfolio of renewables will comprise over 4.2 gigawatts of  capacity, capable of generating around 12 terawatts of electricity per annum in a typical year.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Based on an electricity price of £45 per megawatt and a raw price of £50 per megawatt hour, that would earn an  EBITDA of around £800 million. A five-year CapEx plan to 2023 includes £1.3 billion investment in renewables  and assumes the joint ventures in which SSE is involved, are successful in securing some CFD contracts for  additional offshore wind capacity.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: For the purpose of our CapEx plan, we've made a prudent assumption that the SSE will add 1 gigawatt of  additional project-financed offshore wind capacity by 2023. This would increase our renewable generation output  to almost 16 terawatt hours by 2024.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Over the next five years, we expect to invest around £2.8 billion in our electricity networks. This includes the  forecast pipeline investment of around £1.2 billion in Transmission. This should help take our electricity and gas  [ph] tariff (00:30:12) from around £8.3 billion at March 2018 to around £10 billion in 2023. And over that period, we  expect our Networks business' EBIT contribution to average around £800 million a year. This is a very strong  asset base from which to deliver dividends.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: We're currently expecting capital on investment spend to total around £6 billion across the five years to March  2023, giving an annual average of £1.2 billion across the period. That compares with an average of £1.6 billion in  the last five years. Regulated networks and renewables should account for around 70% of this. And as you would  expect, the CapEx is weighted more towards the first half of the period than the second. The CapEx investment  total includes £1.7 billion planned in the current year and around £1.3 billion planned for the next, although this is  obviously subject to change. Around 80% of the £6 billion is committed as well as regulated networks and  renewables investment, it includes an additional multifuel plant and a new type of high-efficiency gas plant we  have decided to build at Keadby. We invest around £350 million in the project with a substantial proportion of the  financial exposure deferred until the plant is operational.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The first quality is optionality. Regulated networks and renewables are core to the reshaped SSE and flexible  thermal generation is a natural complement to our renewables business. We have a significant number of options  that are not currently in our five-year plan. I've always said that optionality is key to our business model.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: But our other businesses such as Gas Production, Enterprise, Business Energy and Electricity benefit from direct  and indirect synergies, and provide us with options as the energy sector and energy provision itself evolves.  These businesses generated an EBITDA of over £310 million last year, and around 50% of that was in Gas  Production. We don't intend to acquire any more assets in Gas Production, but we are prepared to invest further  in those we already have if the prospects for returns are good enough.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: The third is discipline, as well as discipline in financial and risk management. This means be prepared to take  tough strategic decisions to make sure that the SSE Group and the businesses within it have the best platform for  success. We did it with the acquisition of Airtricity a decade ago, and we're doing it again with the planned Energy  Services transaction.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Optionality, agility and discipline are important qualities in financing SSE. Ability to raise funds at competitive rates  is fundamental to investment, and we again showed in the last financial year. In August, we issued the biggest  evergreen bond by UK company and the first of its kind issued by a UK-headquartered energy company. That  showed SSE's commitment to sustainability, responsibility and to maintaining a strong balance sheet and strong  market rating, allowing the €600 million of funding to be secured at just under 1%. This takes our total fundraising  over the last six years, including hybrid capital and term loans, to more than £7.5 billion. Excluding hybrids, our  average debt maturity now stands at 7.9 years. The reshaping of our hybrid debt means that coupons in 2018- 2019 will fall to £77 million from £128 million in the previous year.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Our proposition to shareholders is clear. In addition to creating a new independent energy supplier with significant  potential for value creation, we are targeting a full-year dividend of £0.975 for 2018-2019, regardless of the key  unknowns in the Retail business, committing to remunerating shareholders' investment through paying dividends  with new targets for up to 2023, building that dividend on a business with earnings from regulated networks and  renewables at its core. Confident of investment opportunities totaling around £6 billion over the next five years,  but disciplined in investment decision making and focused on robust financial management with robust credit  ratios.

texts.speaker: Gregor Alexander
texts.profession: Executive Director & Finance Director, SSE Plc
texts.text: Reshaping SSE is right for customers and right for investors. The SSE of the future will be a leading energy and  infrastructure company. It will develop on and operate energy and related infrastructure and services in a  sustainable way, and I'm confident it will create significant value for society and for shareholders in the year to  come. Thank you.

texts.speaker: Peter Sands, Group Chief Executive Officer

texts.speaker: Richard Henry Meddings
texts.profession: Group Finance Director, Standard Chartered Plc

The  exposure is spread across eight subsectors, more than 350 client groups and multiple markets. The largest  exposures are typically global oil and gas majors or government-supported entities.

texts.speaker: Peter Alexander Sands
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive, Standard Chartered Plc
texts.text: We're using our network to facilitate trade and investment close between Africa and the rest of the world. We're  leveraging our sectoral expertise to help develop Africa's infrastructure. For example, last month, I was with  President Obama in Tanzania for the launch of his Power Africa initiative, under which we are contributing $2  billion to finance power generation and distribution across Africa.

STANL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 3August2016 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Bill T. Winters
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: We set out a strategy in November that contemplated a challenging environment. The environment is probably a  bit more challenging than we imagined at the time. But nevertheless, we remain convinced that the strategy is the  right one for our group and are not making material changes to the strategy, although we're continuously looking  at refinements.

texts.speaker: Andrew Nigel Halford
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Group Executive Director
texts.text: The top left chart there in the dark green is the cost takeout through normal business activities, so not through  divestment of the businesses and you can see that, that $1 billion is roughly double what we achieved last year  and that itself was roughly double what we achieved the year before, so a very, very significant step-up in effort in  this space.

texts.speaker: Bill T. Winters
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: So if I could just say quickly in summary, really do continue to believe that we've got a great franchise. As yet  substantially underexploited, but we're taking the steps that are necessary to get to the maximum value out of this  franchise that we've got. The strategy is right for the business that we see in front of us and for the environment  that we've got, clearly recognizing that relative to November of last year when we stood up here and talked about  our earnings strategy, economies are slower than they were at the time. The outlook for interest rates is lower.  The pass-through to the income line and to our – the possibility of loan impairments which, of course, remain  elevated despite the fact that there's been some improvement period-to-period, we have a more uncertain  environment as it relates to regulation.

texts.speaker: Andrew Nigel Halford
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Group Executive Director, Standard Chartered Plc
texts.text: So, just a little bit more detail then on the income. A year ago, $7.2 billion in the first half; this year $7.6 billion, so  about $400 million increase in income. You can see in the green blocks on the left-hand side here, the things that  have contributed to that; and on the right-hand side, the things that have detracted from it. So, the biggest  contributors have been Transaction Banking and Wealth Management, both of those up 15%, 16% year-on-year.  Particularly within Transaction Banking, the cash side of Transaction Banking up about 25% year-on-year. And  then other contributions from Retail, Financial Markets, et cetera. On the right-hand side, Treasury down a little  bit, and that was primary the non-recurrence of the big boost we got in January of the previous year, otherwise,  we're fairly similar to prior year.

texts.speaker: John Peace, Chairman
texts.profession: Well, good morning, London, and good afternoon to those of you in Hong Kong and India. I’m
texts.text: In January we opened our new office in the Marina Bay Financial Centre development, the first  company to move in. This building, which accommodates about 4,500 people, has a trading floor  with 790 positions across 65,000 square feet. We believe it’s the largest trading floor in Asia.  Singapore is also the main hub of our private banking business. From a greenfield start in 2006 and  with the benefit of the AB acquisition in 2007, private banking now has $46 billion AUM, up 31% on  2009. It’s been less than five years since we opened for business and we’re already the sixth  largest private bank in Asia.

file: STANL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 29February2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Alexander Sands
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Standard Chartered Plc
texts.text: Of course, such growth brings challenges: inflation, friction over resources, social inequality, environmental  degradation. Moreover, the lack of consumption growth in the West undermines the export-driven model that has  powered most Asian economies. But whilst we shouldn't underestimate such challenges, neither should we  underestimate Asian countries' ability to respond. Intra-regional trade and investment is growing extremely  rapidly, domestic consumption is growing fast, policy makers in Asia and particularly in China, have much more  monetary, regulatory and fiscal flexibility than their counterparts in the West. Taken as a whole, emerging Asia  should continue to grow at mid to high-single digit rates, slower than before the crisis, but still much faster than  the West.

texts.speaker: Peter Alexander Sands
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Standard Chartered Plc
texts.text: So far, I've talked big picture stuff, the macro environment, regulation, our strategy. Now I want to change gear  and talk about some specific markets. And rather than start with the success stories, let me start with some of the  places in which we've faced challenges.

texts.speaker: Peter Alexander Sands
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Standard Chartered Plc
texts.text: Whilst this correction was very real, and the slowdown in regulatory reforms and vital infrastructure projects will  have lasting consequences, we remain confident about the longer-term growth prospects of India. The underlying  drivers of growth – urbanization, demographics, better education and an extraordinarily dynamic and  entrepreneurial business culture remain robust. Indeed, there are already some signs that the climate is changing,  clear signals of an end to the rate cycle, some steps on critical reforms, progress on transparency issues.

file: STANL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 5March2013 445 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-13.pdf
STANL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 5March2014 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Alexander Sands
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Standard Chartered Plc
texts.text: This is not what we aspire to achieve. So, as we saw the challenges mount and our momentum slow, we took  action to mitigate the impact and to adapt to the changing environment. Some of the things we've done are  unashamedly tactical, putting even tighter controls on spend and head count, de-risking certain portfolios. But the  more fundamental changes relate to our strategy on how we are organizing ourselves and deploying our resources  to deliver the sustainable, profitable growth and returns that drive shareholder value. That's what I want to focus  on today.

file: STANL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 4March2015 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew Nigel Halford
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Taken as a whole, these represent a significant program of initiatives that will deliver sustainable cost savings of  some $1.8 billion in total over the next three years. Peter will pick this up later.

texts.speaker: Andrew Nigel Halford
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Two years ago, we identified which clients in our Producers portfolio might be potentially vulnerable to a sharp  correction in commodity prices. We have actively managed those names since, reducing exposure, taking  additional collateral, and exiting relationships were necessary. Whilst we have seen non-performing loan  formation reflecting the extremely low level of some commodity prices, refreshed stress tests have identified no  new names to add to this list.

texts.speaker: Andrew Nigel Halford
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Group Executive Director
texts.text: Turning to oil specifically, which represents around half of our commodity exposure. 98% of our oil producer  exposure is either to state-owned enterprises or to low cost of extraction companies who have a breakeven price  below the current market price. The real situation may be somewhat better than this, in fact, as we have  conservatively allowed no slowdown in these companies' capital expenditure, no refinancing, no depletion of cash  balances for a period of one year. We simply do not have exposures to high cost of extraction parts of the industry.

texts.speaker: Andrew Nigel Halford
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Group Executive Director
texts.text: The final point of context for our portfolio is that many of our markets actively benefit from lower commodity  prices. Even oil-producing markets like Ghana are net importers of oil and markets like India are receiving a real  boost from lower prices.

texts.speaker: Peter Alexander Sands
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The progress we've made in attacking the cost base underpins our confidence in achieving $1.8 billion in cost  savings over the period 2015 to 2017. Where will the rest of the savings come from? Some will derive from the full  year impact of actions we've already taken. For example, the decision to exit equities, which will give us $100  million savings in 2016. Some will be the result of further peripheral business exits or withdrawals that we are  currently pursuing. But most of the future savings will be from achieving sustainable efficiency improvement in  our big markets and in our core business activities.

file: STANL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 23February2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew Nigel Halford
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Group Executive Director
texts.text: And then the balance, some of it sort of clearly discernible. So, we put here commodity price falls. If we were  funding a barrel of oil a year ago, we were taking a margin on $100. We're now obviously taking it on $30 or  thereabouts. So there is discernible sort of impact from that. The other $700 million is more the general impact of  lending to businesses, whether that'd be because of liquidity and margin pressure or other factors, but the overall  sort of balance about $700 million to come to the $15.4 billion for the year.

texts.speaker: Andrew Nigel Halford
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Group Executive Director
texts.text: The light green on those charts, just by way of reference, is the impact of divestments in terms of reducing the  cost. But the core of the dark green is what we're really working on. And a lot of the 2016 target is pretty much  now hardwired into the business. In fact, some of the head count reduction we did at the end of last year  essentially underwrites that.

texts.speaker: Andrew Nigel Halford
texts.profession: Group Finance Director & Group Executive Director
texts.text: If one takes the subset that is oil and gas producers, then 88% of the current exposure of $9.6 billion is either to  state-owned companies or to companies that can withstand a $30 price point for a year. So we have over the last  12 months, as we have produced this stat at different price points, we have worked our way down the oil price  curve and still have kept the percentages that are sitting in the high quality end very high.

texts.speaker: Bill T. Winters
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Clients, 100% behind us. I've not had a bad client discussion yet in terms of the clients' understanding the process  that we're going through and the degree to which we're going to be behind them. The strategy that we put in place  in November, which we articulated quite clearly, warts and all, was one that was created in contemplation of this  kind of environment. Did we know that the price of oil was going to collapse immediately following our  presentation? No, of course not. But we imagined it might. And having imagined it might, we put in place the  actions and the program at the time that were intended to deal with exactly the environment we're going through  right now.

texts.text: Now, another dimension that we've been working on quite a lot has been one to reduce the concentration risk that  we had on a smallish number of very big clients. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Page 13 is just a photo shoot and it's a computer-generated image. We haven't built the mill yet, but that's how it's  going to look like a bit. And as you can see, it's 450,000 tonnes of consumer board, with 900,000 tonnes total  pulp, pulp plant and obviously, facilities. Goal is towards the end of 2014 to start it up.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: As stated on page 14, maintenance stoppages in several of the European mills will impact mainly Biomaterials.  And it's a bit driven by the fact that we have quite a few operational or production issues in the Nordic pulp mills  in the Q1, which obviously limited the operational performance of Biomaterials. We do want to run through two of  the maintenance, just to make sure that we get the reliability and all that stuff up to the good level. And then yes,  we're seeing in my personal opinion, too slow, but anyway the impact of deflation coming through, actually  meaning variable costs start to improve.

file: STERV - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 23April2013 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Slide five, which is the working capital. There was two specific reasons why the working capital went up actually.  Higher wood inventories and you won't believe I say this, but that's because of weather. And the serious point is  the very long and cold winter that we all enjoyed, well most of us, actually has given us an extraordinary good  harvesting season. So we decided to use that opportunity and do quite a bit of harvesting while everything was still  frozen. That was about €50 million.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: If you then would move to slide seven. I'll try to be clear. What does it say? We took our own recently announced  permanent capacity cut plans as well as other published permanent capacity reduction plans that the other  industry players have announced. And then we did a relatively simple math, we said, let's calculate the capacity  utilization assuming that the European demand early this year plus the net export is then placed against the  theoretical – against the European capacity, meaning capacity in – located in Europe.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: The black bars by grade is essentially what the capacity utilization was in first quarter. I don't know whether  they're green or gray bars, these when you take into account, the announced permanent capacity reductions. But  think about it this way. If we could reset the clock in all the newsprint capacity that has been announced in the  recent months and couple of quarters, would have been implemented January 1, that would have actually meant  that the CapEx utilization rates would have been 103%.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Obviously with the market development and the actual timing of these capacity reductions is not going to be  103%. But the point of the slide is in newsprint and in SC, the already announced capacity reduction will have a  significant impact on the demand/supply balance, which is obviously what we want and need and so forth. Less so  in coated mechanical, where the utilization rate is low and there hasn't been any recent announcements, the only  good thing I can say about that, that segment is relatively smaller for us. And then you see wood-free coated and  office paper, no big news there, but a bit better utilization rates anyway.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: We have very little shared assets. The customer overlap between the BAs is very small. It essentially is resources  like wood supply, logistics, IT and then the famous group management that pull these businesses together. In  these chains, where we combine Building and Living and Printing and Reading, under Karl's leadership, the focus  is two-fold.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: One, if you look at the track record of Renewable Packaging, but also especially when we get Montes del Plata up  and running, Biomaterials, those businesses need to grow and grow profitably. And I don't want them to be  slowed down by the reality on the other side, where we have lots of issues in the market and obviously, issues also  with the fixed cost ratios and so forth and so on.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: If we move on to slide nine. Karl, after his relatively short time as the CFO of the company, will now take over  almost 60% of the company revenue. Yes, part of the thinking is with his broad experience from other industries,  there will be quite a bit of rethinking on how do we make that a success. We won't change the Renewable  Packaging or Biomaterials. So Mats Nordlander and Juan Carlos Bueno will continue there. And to be very  specific, this is not a capacity cut program. This is to make the overhead cost of the company more fit to the reality  and give our businesses, our mills and sales organizations a better chance to make money on the market.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: We've also done, not just waiting for something, but we've tried to reduce the time in the past 9 months to 12  months to get more ready, mitigate issues, risks, and so forth. We've tested the wood supply in various areas of the  plantations. We've done a lot of training for mechanical harvesting. We have continued to discuss the capital  equipment. No commitments made. No selections made just in case one of the suppliers would listen. But  obviously, we believe that that all gives us two benefits. One, it gives a better chance of making the right choices  and it also gives us speed when the time comes to hit the ground running, so to say.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Page 12, different presentation, but same story. The delta between the two curves, what does it say? What it's  saying that we are rebuilding the company. And we're investing in things with zero revenue to some significant  effect. And especially in Renewable Packaging, I think it's quite important to realize that the burden is there.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then we had some around a percentage point in Renewable Packaging causing €15 million. So all in all, that is  €56 million less EBIT due to pricing. That was compensating basically by lower variable costs. And of which, 2013  is actually lower variable cost coming in.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: If you do the same comparison versus Q4, the picture is slightly different. We have a €12 million or 1.4% price  decline in Printing and Reading. We have higher variable costs, which is both logistic and energy. We have lower  fixed cost, basically because of lower maintenance of around €27 million. We have less profit from the forest  associates of about €11 million. And then we have FX and other things causing about €13 million explaining the  difference of €40 million versus the Q4.

file: STERV - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 23April2014 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: And if any of you doubt this, maybe some of my own people doubt this a year ago, it still works. You can call it  restructuring. I call it productivity. But I think it's very, very critical for the future that that mitigation still seems  to work very well. Remember, that cost take-out is not including capacity reductions. That's extra.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Even more important, our growth engine, renewable packaging, a very strong quarter, solid markets and a 15%  return on operating capital again. I think that team has all the reasons to be very proud. And obviously, it's a proof  point, why do we want to invest in growth in that area.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Moving on to biomaterials, what can I say? We have a mill that's being commissioned. Every valve, every motor,  every pump, every pipe's being readied and tested and cleaned. I'm sure one of our good people is standing there  with the first pile of chips to the conveyor. Well, we can't do that before DINAMA gives us the permit. So that's  what it is now between us and starting up this mill with a long delay. But still a conviction, it is a good mill, it's  been built very well, and it's in a great location. We have revised the expectation with this year's volume, slightly  down just because of the simple fact that when we ramp up a mill like this, even a small delay has a bit of an  impact.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Building and Living, slide 10, one of the nicest graphs in terms of the trend. But they joined the 15% ROC now,  with renewable packaging return on operating capital. Why? Well, it's a self-made recovery. They started about six  months earlier here before the reshape program, and yet they got recovery in markets, too. But I must say I'm  quite happy with that.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: In the Renewable Packaging, where I'm also the lucky division head, very solid performance. Sales prices up, costs  down, another reason to invest in it. I'm talking about investments in Guangxi. I was actually last week there. IFC  has joined us both with equity and the loan. I watched the two-thirds of the leveling work of the mills have been  completed. Equipment, quite a bit of the key equipment has been selected. We will not promote the brand names  here. I'm sure the selected ones will. But I think the good news is that we are moving ahead. Harvesting has  started to ramp up. It, obviously, will go to the market which is quite a significant market in Guangxi. And the  timeline is early 2016, as I said before.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Q2 for packaging, I need to mention, has a bit of a maintenance burden. Ostrołęka has a two-week breakdown not  because of us, but because of the electrical grid, and then there is something in Imatra. But I think that change is  nothing off a great story.

texts.speaker: Seppo Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: It's worth to notice that Renewable Packaging and Building and Living are already above the group ROCE, started  at 13%. Biomaterials is, of course, burdened by the Montes del Plata project which will start in the coming weeks.  Printing and Reading, as said earlier, concentrates on the cash flow generation.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Thank you. We'll go straight to quarter two guidance. You might call it boring when we're saying more of the  same. Sales is expected to be similar, operating EBIT in line with the currently reported €182 million and then we  just mentioned the Biomaterials and Renewable Packaging maintenance impact there.

file: STERV - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 22April2015 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If you look on Packaging Solution and Wood Products, the Varkaus conversion is going according to plan and we  plan to start up in the fourth quarter of 2015. The wooden elements that we announced last quarter, the €43  million investment, is expected to start up in Q2 2016. And the Murow Sawmill in Poland is already starting up  next quarter.

file: STERV - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 28April2016 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Biomaterials improving €11 million and most of that is coming from a stronger performance of the Montes del  Plata Mill. Wood Products, €1 million better. And a very strong performance in Paper. In Other, the improved  result is coming mainly from logistic operations but also from our forest associates. If you look upon the operating  margin since the first quarter 2013 to today, we have actually been running a compounded average growth rate of  21%, which I think is something to reflect upon.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The transformation is proceeding and here is just a short presentation of the major project we're running. Right  now, we are in the mood of starting up the Beihai Mill. It's an investment of €800 million. We will start up in the  month of June, the wood products for Varkaus wooden building elements. And we are also going into the last  phase of the xylose demonstration plant which will be ready early 2017.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The BCTMP, which is the mechanical pulp operations, will be ready during Q4 2016. And already today, we have  started deliveries of both hardwood pulp from Veracel and softwood from the market.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Operational EBIT, like mentioned earlier, went up €11 million due to lower wood costs and higher sales volumes  from Montes del Plata, and we are planning the maintenance shutdown at Montes del Plata mill during the  quarter two now.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Wooden building elements investment in Varkaus is proceeding according to plan and we have already started  raw material supply for the production there, which we plan to start in June this year.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And just to remind that capital expenditure figures mentioned include approximately €100 million for the group's  biological assets, that's the forestry CapEx and we estimate to spend about €160 million for the Beihai Mill in  China for the [ph] final (13:38) investment.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And as a summary is that sales are growing, if we exclude the Barcelona divestiture and the structurally declining  paper by 2.4%. So the growth continues. EBIT grew by almost 13%. We reached a record high 10.1% EBIT margin.  Strong cash flow from operations, strengthened balance sheet, net debt to EBITDA 2.3 versus 2.6. And we are  constantly for the third consecutive quarter above 11% in operational return on capital employed. And excluding  Beihai Mill, we are also above the 13% for three consecutive quarters. Continued progress in transformation into  renewable materials growth company continues.

file: STERV - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 27April2017 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: In Beihai, we had €12 million more cost than we had a year ago, which includes a €7.5 million provision related to  a turbine damage. And I would like to explain that this came in very late in the process, it came in the 31st of  March. So we have been working very hard and this is the best estimate that we have at this moment.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Included in this is the expensed feasibility study of Ostrołęka PM6 that we have decided not to go ahead of.  Biomaterials, coming down €31 million versus a year ago. Included in that is €16 million of lower pulp prices,  mainly hardwood pulp prices compared to a year ago, and a write-down on a credit loss of €4 million. Wood  Product had the best first quarter in 10 years and Paper coming down €9 million, partly because of less mills  because we had closed down, but also price explaining about €5 million of the €9 million.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: And then you have Other, basically making some additional provisions for land-related issues with old sites,  turning out that we ended up at €250 million. But if you then look upon the underlying business with gradually  improving pulp prices and the ramp-up of Beihai that is faster than anticipated, this sends a good signal for the  future.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: We expect full production in the first half of 2018. And so far, for a mill that is less than a year in startup, we're  already producing 87,000 tons in the quarter. The PE coating is expecting to be ready by mid-2017, adding  additional value added to our food service boards and Beihai pulp mill decision to be reconsidered as announced  earlier is moving along the timeline that we are expecting.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: And like Kalle already mentioned, we are reconsidering the plan to build chemical pulp mill in Beihai China as  announced earlier and that negotiations and plans are going ahead as expected. An investment of €9 million was  announced during the quarter, to invest more in MFC production at Imatra, Ingerois and Fors mills.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then also a startup at the Raceland mill is proceeding as planned where we produce bagasse to xylose, and that  is a demonstration plant and expect to deliver first batches of xylose still in this year. Also, first commercial  deliveries of lignin from Sunila Mill were shipped during the quarter.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: We have also a feasibility study in progress in Sweden for new CLT feasibility facility there, and we expect to  finalize that no later than in connection to the group's Q2 reporting. We have announced €12 million investment at  the biocomposite granules production in Hylte Mill in Sweden, and we also have been selected as a supplier to  various CLT buildings in Europe and Australia during the quarter. And this really demonstrates that the wooden  buildings are huge.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Biomaterials at 7.9%, this is, of course, reflection of the still low hardwood pulp prices. Hardwood product at  16.4% continues to demonstrate solid performance. Paper, cash flow was seasonally low at 4.3%. But we are  confident that Paper business continues to generate good cash flow also going forward.

file: STERV - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 27April2018 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Return on capital employed, for the third quarter in a row at 17.7%, we've been above 13% for three quarters in a  row. But this is the highest return on capital employed in the single quarter since 2000. The wood situation in the  Nordics tight but been managed after the mild winter and extraordinary snowfall in the middle of Sweden.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: When it comes to the Biomaterials, which say it's improving by 93%, and we said here, it gained some headwinds,  and the headwinds here are basically coming from that we'd be running the pulp mills on a slightly lower capacity  for the Nordic mills, due to the tight wood situation, basically holding back about 30,000 tonnes of pulp production.  And we also for the Latin American mills had some issues with shipping dates, which is about 20,000 tonnes. And  then coming back to the very positive development in Paper of a 64% improvement compared to a year ago.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: With that, I just want to highlight some of the important transformation steps that has been concluded in the first  quarter of 2018. So Baienfurt sheeting center in Germany has been sold. The Heinola corrugated plant has been  shut down. And we have also made a deal of selling of Rio Grande do Sul plantation. We believe that the  transaction will be concluded during Q2.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: When it comes to new investments, as part of the consolidation of the corrugated business in Finland, we have  opened up the new corru – new and expanded corru mill in Lahti. The Skutskär environmental performance  improvement investment is concluded and we have started production in Hylte biocomposite. And Seppo will  mention some more about that when he comes into that part.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then moving to our Biomaterials division, we are also reporting all-time high results despite the headwinds  relating to wood sourcing situation in the Nordic countries [indiscernible] (10:34) Sweden as well as some  negative foreign exchange impact mainly coming from U.S. dollar. Sales were up 7% and operational EBIT 93%  reaching all-time high of €102 million.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Operational return on capital also fairly above the targeted 15% level at 17.6%. We also completed during the  quarter our environmental performance investment of €16 million at the Skutskär Mill. I'm very proud also to tell  about the innovation award we have received for Lineo by Stora Enso, our lignin product that is a renewable  replacement for oil-based phenolic materials.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: In Sweden, we are proceeding as planned with the CLT investment in Gruvön, and this investment is scheduled  to begin production during the first quarter next year. We have also started production of biocomposite granulates  at our Hylte Mill in Sweden and commercialization is in process with several customers already.

file: STERV - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 25April2019 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then there have been two areas where we've been focusing on. One is, obviously, the increased variable costs.  And here is the total of €68 million, of which fiber, mostly wood costs but also [indiscernible] (00:03:33) stands for  €44 million and other €24 million are everything from increased logistics, chemicals and [indiscernible] (00:03:41)  material. And this is the area where we are focusing the profit protection program and this is what we're working  on now to secure a profitable future. On the value management, we have been working a lot between sales mix  and volumes and that had come back to compensating the increased costs by €43 million. So all in all, these two  factors had an impact of €25 million in the quarter. Next slide, please.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: We've had some interesting events happening in the quarter. One of them is the decision to invest as a startup  phase, €5 million in formed fiber production in Hylte Mill in Sweden. This is a new line of forming fibers for new  products such as inserts, containers, cups, industrial packaging et cetera. This is a circular product and contains  no plastic. It's basically 99.9% wood. And now we are ramping that up in a very fast beat.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Oulu conversion feasibility study was completed in the quarter and the proposal that we have is to convert the  paper machine number 7 into kraftliner and close down the paper machine number 6 and the sheeting plant. The  decision of the potential conversion is planned to be made by the Stora Enso board of directors during the first  half of 2019 after the co-determination process has been completed. We also started first deliveries from our new  CLT factory in Gruvön in Sweden, and it's ramping up according to plan. And last but not least, the investment in  the addition drying capacity in Imatra Mills has been completed and we can now start to drive the  commercialization of the micro-fibrillated cellulose which is a step in the right direction. We announced in Q4 if  you remember that we are also converting one of the paper machines in Imatra Mills for the production.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: The ongoing and fairly long process of restructuring of Bergvik Skog is proceeding as planned. The aim is to  complete the transaction in the second quarter. As you know this is a change from being [ph] partly total now  (00:06:57) 49% in company to basically increase our forest holdings as well as taking it into our balance sheet, so  where we increased the forest holdings by 300,000 hectors and we will increase also the productive forest land  which is part of the reconstruction of Bergvik. And this has been financed with the first Green Bond made by Stora  Enso which we did during the quarter as well as an increase of capital employed about €1 billion and a return on  capital employed by around 1 percentage point. That transaction is forecasted to increase the net debt to  operation EBITDA temporarily above the strategic target of 2 during Q2 and Q3 and then coming back to below 2  by the end of 2019.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deputy to the Chief Executive Officer, Country Manager Finland, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Operational EBIT decreased €37 million to €54 million that is due to significantly higher variable costs especially  for wood, also negative total volume development had negative impact on the result. Operational return on capital  decreased to 10.3%. This is due to lower profitability as mentioned earlier. And impact of IFRS 16 leasing  standard.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deputy to the Chief Executive Officer, Country Manager Finland, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: In China, we launched premium quality folding boxboard new grade Arctic Deer, and this is suitable for  applications in food and pharmaceutical packaging, as well as publications. At Imatra Mill, co-determination  negotiations relating to close of PM6 were finalized. And it will be shut down by the end of 2019. This will increase  annual sales by approximately €70 million after the closure.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deputy to the Chief Executive Officer, Country Manager Finland, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Operational return on capital remained above 20% targeted level, and was at 21.8%. At the Heinola fluting mill  here in Finland, industrial scale pilot plant will be built to turn sludge from the mill's water treatment plant into  renewable fuel. This plant will test new energy-efficient technology and these new biofuels will reduce carbon  dioxide emissions at the mill's power plant going forward.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deputy to the Chief Executive Officer, Country Manager Finland, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then finally to summarize where we are with the strategic targets that we have set for the company and different  divisions and businesses that we are in. As already earlier noticed, we start to be on green on most of the targets  and remain there. Fixed costs to sales ratio is still on red, coming down to 22.4% now compared to 22.6% a year  ago. Consumer Board remains below the targeted 20% level at 10.3% and thereby continues to improve the cost  structure efficiencies as well as to increase prices also going forward in order to compensate for the higher raw  material costs that we have been facing during the past year or so. Wood Products like mentioned also a bit short  of the targeted 20% level, but this is due to seasonal demand. And Paper cash flow of 6.1% of the net sales  slightly below the 7% targeted level. Others are on green.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: We will now start and show you a progress report every quarter, we saw the take-out of the cost which is the  program impact. And we say, show also separately other impacts on fixed cost. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: When we implement the second phase, which is the chemical pulp mill, that obviously then has two implications. texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

Now we can do it in a controlled, cost-efficient and responsible manner, and I think for the  companies also very, very good news.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

With good contracts already with global  customers and tests even, we will start producing lignin to replace fossil materials in insulation foams, in  adhesives. And in the second phase, I'd call it more a bit later, also replacing fossil materials for carbon fiber,  which is a very exciting opportunity.

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

And who knows,  even become a technology provider one day.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Printing and Living & Deputy CEO, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: But what happened is that, if you look upon the sales price and the mix and the volume impact, you're talking here  over €60 million of profit disappearing, while we basically haven't had any improvement in the fixed costs. And obviously, the majority of the announced €200 million is coming into  Printing and Reading.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Printing and Living & Deputy CEO, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Variable costs are €25 million lower or 0.9 percentage points and that is basically explained by lower fiber cost,  wood, recycled paper and pulp and chemicals, that is cheaper than the year ago period. But it also includes a €15  million increased cost of energy, which is coming from green certificates, but also that we had some issues in  certain plants with boilers, so we have to buy, but also some of the mix of the energy that we have bought, there's  been more coal in this period than expected. And then you basically had a fixed cost variation of 0.4 percentage  points or €10 million and that's a number of smaller items.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Printing and Living & Deputy CEO, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: And if you look at the sequential, you have the sales and price mix, increase of 0.3% or €9 million, that's almost  everything coming out of Building and Living and it's part of that seasonal strong quarter that Building and Living  had in Q2. It's the fiber supply, about €26  million or one percentage point.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

texts.speaker: Jouko Karvinen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: And essentially, the business case is based on how do you replace a very large number of different chemicals,  specialty chemicals, and food stuff with non-food based biomass, specifically non-food-based biomass. This time, we'll leave with happy smiles to my successor. It's a  small bet, but I hope it'll be a great success in the years to come.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Printing and Living & Deputy CEO, Stora Enso Oyj

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Printing and Living & Deputy CEO, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: And we will continue to focus on increased customer focus based on the strategic investment that the company  has done recently, and are doing, which is the Montes del Plata Pulp Mill in Uruguay. texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: But despite that, the full potential was not reached in the quarter. We had the wood shortage, which has meant  that in many of our integrate mills, we have not been able to run them full and actually being able to take  additional volumes to the market and that is an impact of €12 million. And that is because of the tight wood  situation. And we've been buying wood from Poland and Ireland at high levels to keep our [ph] pulp mill working.  We came out with a €15 million higher versus the guidance of €40 million for the maintenance impact. It was both  more expensive and it took longer time that we have estimated. And then we have had production challenges in  Q1, mainly in the areas around Consumer Board. So, all the €32 million headwinds we had, basically €12 million  is with Consumer Board and that's coming from wood shortage impact and production challenges, mainly in  pricing in Skoghall and Imatra.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: In the quarter, we also announced through environmental impact assessment, which is a semi-public document  that we're all considering a conversion of the Oulu fine paper mill to become a packaging mill, integrated with  brown-based kraft pulp and integrated a new CTMP plant. There are two machines at our plant there, one is for  cartonboard 450,000 tonnes and 400,000 cotton kraftliner.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: The products we are focusing on are CUK and kraftliner. If we would consider to continue with this, we're talking  about €750 million to €800 million in additional sales up of this mill, while at the same time, it will be a reduction  about 20% of its paper capacity. However, the option is to continue to make a current fine paper, if we don't meet  the numbers when we go through these assessments.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: In the transformation in the latest step, we have completed MFC investment in Ingerois, which means that we  have MFC capacity in both Imatra, Fors and now in Ingerois. We have concluded the investment in Heinola,  where we have improved quality and a quantity and what is more output. And we have also started up Skutskär,  which is now fully converted to fluff.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: We have announced in the quarter, a investment in sawmilling and planing in Launkalne. And we've also released  the release today of an investment of €25 million in Maxau to be able to reduce energy cost and also generate  additional green power.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Production challenges in European mills and wood shortage impact was €12 million during the quarter. And  Beihai Mill ramp-up is continuing as planned. And there also it's worth to notice that as we have decided not to  move ahead with chemical pulp mill there that we are importing pulp there from our Veracel mill as well as buying  some pulp from the market.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: This, of course, to large extent news around Stora as a group level, but this, of course, has an effect on  Consumer Board division profitability, as pulp prices have been going up.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Operational return on capital reached 13.1%, which is slightly less than a year ago, due to the mentioned  headwinds and operational currencies. MFC invested at Ingerois Mill was completed during the quarter and we  have also announced a new joint development agreement with startup Sulapac. This is to license Sulapac  materials and technology in order to begin the development of fully renewable caps and closures for liquid  packages.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Ramp-up of the LVL production at Varkaus Mill was also completed during the quarter and also when it comes to  biocomposite granulates that we have been starting up at our mill, our new mill in Hylte, Sweden. We have now  made first commercial deliveries and launched a new brand new DuraSense by Stora Enso.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: And we have also today announced a new €25 million boiler investment to reduce energy costs and to boost  green energy generation at our Maxau Mill, in Germany. This project is expected to be completed in 2020.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: And this is also demonstrating the fact that our transformation to renewable material's growth company has been  successful and we have reached a new milestone there. During the last years our balance sheet has  strengthened considerably, thanks to strong cash flow generation, combined with sale of non-core assets. We  have also reduced our capital expenditure now at about €600 million level, which is aligned with our depreciation  and operational decrease in the value of biological assets. And this is the level [indiscernible] (00:15:25) going  forward.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Before I hand over back to Kalle some comments on our strategic targets, where good progress is visible, but  there is, of course, still more potential. Lot of green dots as you can see already, couple red and one yellow, still  work to be done on fixed costs to sales, where we are now at 23.5% level, still above the targeted 20%, but clear  improvement compared to year ago.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: The Nordic wood supply situation is expected to continue tight due to the risk of forest fires, affecting the  harvesting conditions. The wood supply is expected to be up – impact on the wood supply is expected to  approximately €10 million negative in Q3, 2018.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Then, to page 10, and the operating profit, what a fall from last year to this year. This is a rather  important slide. The first bar shows the pricing development, and basically our prices increased in  pulp wood products, fine packaging, went down in newsprints and magazines, and half of this sales  price increase is pulp.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Then looking at sales volume, sales volumes grew across the board, but also, let’s say, one-third of  this was pulp. Then moving to the cost side, the biggest single factor was the purchased pulp  impact which was about half of this. Then recycled paper, logistic costs, wood, chemicals, all  contributed to cost increases. So the variable cost pressure has been there all the time.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We’ll also have seasonal demand weakness in consumer board and wood products, and we will  have more maintenance stoppages in Q4 than we had in Q3. And looking at the year-on-year  demand development, quarter-on-quarter price development, some positive on the demand, and on  the pricing side, quarter-on-quarter, magazine, fine paper, industrial packaging up; wood products  down and combined with the pressure on raw material prices, wood products will be a challenging  business for us.

Demand continued strong,  so we are confident that going forward we can also increase selling prices as planned.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deputy to the Chief Executive Officer, Country Manager Finland, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Operational return on capital 10.3%. And then important step in our transformation and development of alternative  for plastics was successful rebuild of the machine at Imatra Mills in Finland for industrial production of MFC for  barrier film production. Ramp-up is starting now during Q4 this year.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deputy to the Chief Executive Officer, Country Manager Finland, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: In our Wood Products, wood-based building continues to grow and sales excluding divested Puumerkki increased  6.4%. Operational EBIT up 64% to record-high Q3, thanks to better prices and mix as well as volume growth  supported our strategic investments at Murów sawmill Varkaus LVL. Operational return on capital continued at  record-high level of 31.6%, clearly above the strategic target of 20%. We also continued to develop our business  portfolio. We announced €7 million investment in building a Competence Center for biocomposites in Sweden.  We also announced operational steps with Finnish start-up TRÄ Group to develop innovative digital services for  wooden buildings. And with Orthex, we launched a new range of kitchen utensils made from biocomposites, a  total of 98% bio-based material.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deputy to the Chief Executive Officer, Country Manager Finland, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then look at the strategic targets where we are making good progress. Most of the targets are green as you know  already the previous quarters. Couple of them remain on red. Fixed cost to sales coming down to 23% but still  above the maximum 20% that we have defined as a target level. [indiscernible] (00:12:34) came across at 10.3%  below the 20% level. I think it's a reflection of the burden of [ph] pain our mills filling (00:12:43) the balance sheet  [indiscernible] (00:12:45) and qualifications and the time lag between the cost increases that we have seen this  year and the steady price increases that have been started now.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: And then, in the estimate, a negative €10 million impact on operational EBIT is expected due to production  restrictions at the uncoated fine paper mill in Nymölla, Sweden. This is because water at the nearby lake which  supplies the water for the mill operation, is at a very low level and we have to actually stop production in one line.  And the impact of annual maintenance shutdown is expected to be similar for Q3 2018 and all these are included  in the guidance.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 5 Final slide, with three words. We think we are strong, we are stronger than a year ago. That to us is  the biggest change. It’s not that the environment has gotten easier; I mean demand may have  gotten a little easier, but the pricing pressures have increased. We hope that the cash flow, the cost  and the balance sheet are proof points of that to you. More important, strong is that we’re  improving. We’re not done, our cost base will improve further this year, and my simple message to  my own people this morning was now that we’ve practiced for three years, including myself, maybe  we should finally start putting the gas pedal down and get some more speed. Why? Because we  want to be able to invest into our future, which then has to be profitable on a totally different level  than our past and I repeat fiber-based backed, cheap low-cost pulp as being one of two of the key  areas.

Board mill investment in Beihai is moving ahead, and we're going ahead of plan. And the journey and the  transformation towards renewable materials company continues.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then Biomaterials, better result and sales are impacted by historically low hardwood pulp prices. We are working on fixing the problem but unfortunately we expect  repairs to take some time and the effect is about €10 million negative in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then we are moving ahead with the start up at the bagasse-to-xylose demonstration plant in Raceland, U.S.A.  where first batches of xylose are expected to be delivered this year, and we also have signed our first commercial  contract for xylose.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Biomaterials, 6.1% for the quarter and 8.5% for the year; that is a reflection of the historically low hardwood pulp  prices. Wood Products,13.1% for the quarter and 16.8% for the year, slightly below the targeted 18% level, but I  think we can still summarize and comment that they continue solid performance. And I do believe that they will  also improve going forward. And Paper clearly about targeted cash flow after investing activities of 7% both for  the quarter and full year.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: So as I've said initially, we believe that we are well-prepared for 2017 and beyond. 2016 has been a year of  transformation. We have strengthened the balance sheet, we have proven once again that we have strong cash  generation capabilities, we have a solid performance despite low hardwood pulp prices and the Beihai start up  costs that are coming earlier than expected because we are ahead of the schedule. The lower hardwood pulp  prices, we believe, are gone and we are in a stable level; the question is how fast they will increase.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: And then we are moving away as demonstrated in the releases of this investment that has been popping up  recently like MFC, the wood composite investment in Hylte as well as the Heinola announced today. We are  moving more towards the innovation and sales transformation.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: We also announced some new investments during the quarter, CTMP investment at Imatra Mills in Finland in  October and also completed some of the previously announced investment projects like PE coating plant in Beihai  and Imatra, also chemical plant at Skoghall Mill in Sweden, and MFC investments at Imatra and Fors mills.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: This is also fully in line with the strategy we have announced for Biomaterials where we concentrate at our Nordic  pulp mills or specialty pulps, but it's the same case for Skutskär Mill where we are now proceeding ahead, full  speed the fluff pulp investment project and expected that project to be completed in second quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then, a couple of words about the Nordic wood supply situation that has been sort of hot topic before and the  year after because of the mild winter weather conditions in the Nordics.
