But we are  very happy and pleased with our wood sourcing organization in Finland and Sweden that has been doing an  excellent work here and actively manage challenging harvesting conditions and enabled stable wood inventories  at the end of the year, and then they ensure undisturbed wood supply to our mills.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then to end my part about the strategic targets, they're like the title says, steady progress continues in the right  direction. And as you see a lot of the targets are green or yellow. Actually, there are still some red ones, red spots  that we need to work on to be fully happy and satisfied when it comes to the strategic targets.

file: STERV - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 1February2019 730 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: The bigger issue was the €40 million in temporary operational challenges and that is basically six mills. In  Biomaterials, we had a problem in Skutskär, starting up after the first annual shutdown after the conversion to  fluff. And we also had some issues in Montes del Plata. The Biomaterials impact was about €20 million. The  challenge that we already talked about in Q3 of Nymölla and the lack of water in the nearby lake continued longer  than the expected time to us that we had an issue with the pulp mill in Veitsiluoto, totaling a loss of EBIT of €16  million. And last but not least, we had both small hiccups in Imatra and Fors totaling €4 million. So, all of these  operational issues are now cleared and we are ramping up production again. But unfortunately, in this kind of  process industry, this happens. But I'm very, very unhappy with having six mills basically towards the end of the  year.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: In conjunction with our fourth quarter report, we also issued a press release and it's referred to in the end the  report, and that is what we call a profit protection program to strengthen the competitiveness of Stora Enso that  has been launched. And the reason for it is that we have seen cost increases and we see cost increases in the  fourth quarter, especially continuing to the first quarter especially in the areas of wood, chemicals, and logistics.  And yes, it take one number here. The wood costs are €50 million higher we expect in Q1 2019 versus Q1 2018.  We are also reducing the CapEx by €50 million from the previously announced guidance of CapEx for the full year  of 2019. The reason is also that we are entering into a more unsecured future and we want to be proactive, first of  all, to get the competitiveness back and fighting back the cost and secondly compare – be prepared if unexpected  events are happening because right now the macro situation quite unpredictable.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: This in the first phase includes that we are closing down – are planning to close down the PM6 in Imatra. That's a  90,000 tonne paper machine and we are also doing adjustments at Ala sawmill in Sweden and Imavere sawmill in  Estonia. This is just the beginning. The total program is €120 million in cost reductions of fixed and variable costs  and we expect that we will get some 40% to 50% of the program during 2019 and the full effect of the €120 million  program will become by the end of 2020.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: There was a number of important events during Q4 and one of them is, obviously, the partnering with H&M and  IKEA to be a fourth partner to industrial TreeToTextile. We also launched the RFID, the only sustainable RFID tag  in the market. We actually completed the environmental impact assessment for Oulu. We divested the June  Emballage in Sweden and then there was a number of investments that we have announced during the fourth  quarter.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Also, we entered a binding agreement about the restructuring of Bergvik Skog. We are expected to finalize this  during the first half of 2019 and it's totaling a direct ownership of 1.4 million of hectares of forest land, of which  1.15 million is a productive forest land. This is an increase of the Stora Enso balance sheet totaling about  approximately €1.31 billion (sic) [€1.0 billion] (00:08:36). I also want to say that in the fourth quarter we had two  items affecting comparability. One was the Latvian land sales, which gave us a gain of €47 million and the other  one was the increased fair value of the biological assets of Stora Enso, €49 million.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deputy to the CEO, Country Manager Finland, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Operational EBIT was also at record high Q4 level of €91 million. That is increase of €30 million. Higher pulp  prices were partly offset by higher variable costs, especially for wood and energy. We also had some production  problems at Montes del Plata and Skutskär pulp mills during the quarter.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deputy to the CEO, Country Manager Finland, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then, moving to Paper division where we have solid growth, but impacted by operational challenges. Sales  increased 5% to €761 million and clearly higher sales prices in all grades and a better mix was partly offset by  lower sales volumes. Operational EBIT was stable at the level of €45 million. Significantly higher sales prices in all  grades were offset by higher variable costs, especially wood, pulp and chemicals. We had production issues like  mentioned earlier. Production reductions caused by water shortage at Nymölla Mill and some technical problems  at Veitsiluoto pulp mill having total €16 million negative impact on the result.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deputy to the CEO, Country Manager Finland, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: We also had to take some market-related curtailments at the Oulu Mill due to softness of the coated woodfree  market. And cash flow after investing activities to sales ratio was down to 2.5% and that was negatively impacted  by temporary working capital challenges. Here, we should note this that Q3 cash flow was significantly better at  8.3% to net sales. So, now, there is a two quarters like the second half of last year over 5%, but still below the  targeted 7%. But we are confident that this is a temporary reduction in cash flow and paper visibility is back on  track in the beginning of the year that has now started.

texts.speaker: Seppo Matti Parvi
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Deputy to the CEO, Country Manager Finland, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: Then, moving to strategic targets before handing back to Karl. Our targets are progressing, but there is still more  potential as you can see in the table. Most of the targets are in green, but there are still some on red or yellow.  When it comes to balance sheet, balance sheet has continued to strengthen. We are growing [indiscernible]  (00:17:12) relevant market, but especially when it comes to fixed cost to sales [indiscernible] (00:17:17) to do to  reach the target to be at 20% or below.

texts.speaker: Karl-Henrik Sundström
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Stora Enso Oyj
texts.text: I would like also to remind everybody that the first quarter of 2018, we did not have any annual maintenance  stops. This year, we have changed the schedule and we will have two annual maintenance shutdowns: One at  Ostrołęka PM3 and PM5 and the other one Veracel Brazil. And that will give a total negative impact on  maintenance estimated to be €20 million compared to Q1 2018.

In this environment, corporate culture and trust has never been more important and I would like to come back to  that in a couple of moments. The momentum in our business is driven by very hard-working, dedicated and  focused team of people throughout the organization, focused on delivering good outcomes for clients. The  our partners develop their skills and professionalism and the encouragement of specialisms in our business is  business as usual for us.

texts.text: The other major change this year, of course, has been in the regulatory environment. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, St. James's Place Plc
texts.text: Take your time. Okay. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us this morning. As is usual at our  interim results meetings, I'll run through the new business and advise the numbers we released earlier today,  hand over to Andy to talk about the financial performance, the profits, the dividends, and I'll spend some time  talking about the environment we find ourselves operating in and a little more about the future. We then, as usual,  will take questions at the end.

texts.speaker: David Charles Bellamy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, St. James's Place Plc
texts.text: And as Andy said, our contribution to this year's levy is yet another £20 million, the third consecutive year of near  maximum contribution. Frustrating for all of us. Moving on to the fourth reason why we're doing so well today, and  that relates to the environment we work in. Not only are there complex rules and regulations to adhere to, our  lives are more complicated today.

texts.speaker: David Charles Bellamy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, St. James's Place Plc
texts.text: So four key reasons, why we're doing so well. Our investment approach, the St. James's Place partnership, the  support we have behind them, and the environment we find ourselves in today. And are any of those fundamental  drivers going to change any time soon? I don't think so. If anything, the momentum we've experienced in recent  times is set to continue. Our target market is getting bigger, as evidenced by Datamonitor's annual research, and  personnel responsibility is here to stay. Pensions deficits and the challenges of funding care in old age the world  over are all further evidence of that fact.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now let me turn to our second quarter outlook. We think it is appropriate to have some caution with  respect to the short-term environment as there are some new headwinds that we face. Certainly the  situation in Japan will be first, and we want to express our heartfelt concern for those affected. As a  company we do not have manufacturing facilities in Japan, and about 4% of our revenues are  shipped to Japan. The impact from the earthquake so far has been manageable from ST  perspective, but we could see in the near-term unexpected shifts in demand or changes to the  semiconductor supply chain, so this is something we are managing and watching carefully with an  intense focus on supporting our customers.

file: STMPA - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 24April2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Apr-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President, CEO & Member-Managing Board, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Yesterday, ST-Ericsson talked about $320 million in annualized cost reduction to come by the end of 2013 giving  further color to the ongoing and proposed SG&A savings and site reductions to ensure more R&D working  synergies. The expected ST-Ericsson savings will fully benefit ST's consolidated result starting in Q3 2012 through  the completion of the saving plans by the end of 2013.

file: STMPA - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 23April2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Third, in March, we signed an agreement with Ericsson to split up the ST-Ericsson joint venture. Subject to  regulatory approvals, we expect the closing to occur during the third quarter as already anticipated. Now, while  the closing is in the third quarter, we have each began to fund our respective products as of March 2 and jointly  fund the wind-down activities.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: So this entails Ericsson assuming the funding of the LTE modem development activity, while ST is assuming the  funding of the existing products and the related business as well as certain assembly and test facilities. And  together we are jointly and equally funding the wind-down related activities. This was an important decision and a  key part of our cost reduction.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: And now, let me turn to our product highlights. Looking at our Sense & Power and Automotive businesses, for  MEMS and Sensors during Q1 we started production of a 6-axis MEMS device for the flagship model of an Asian  smartphone manufacturer. In the Automotive space, we are making a strong push into automotive sensors for an  accelerometer for an airbag. We also began production of our active noise cancellation chip for an important Asian  gaming manufacturer.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: In Power And Smart Power, we earned socket for our high voltage products in several large and small appliances  with major European manufacturers and in Asia. Intelligent Power Modules scored several design wins from  home appliance leaders in the US and in Europe. We also began ramping production for a new LED lighting  platform for a major US LED manufacturer, and the newest AMOLED driver for a market leading Korean  manufacturer.

file: STMPA - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 29April2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Another booster, our environmental sensors took a step forward with a 100% share in all pressure sensors with a  leading consumer brand in Asia and the launc h of a new pressure-sensor ideal for wearable applications.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: In closing now with power and smart power management products also during this quarter we continue to focus  on the three main growth areas, power management for portable, industrial automation, and SmartGrid.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: In portable we landed a number of design wins in portable devices for filtering and protection, which will  contribute to the ramp of the business this year. And in industrial we secured qualifications from several power  supply manufacturers for low-voltage MOSFET and earned a first win from a large Chinese manufacturer for  high-voltage IGBT for a telecom application. Finally, we launch a complete configurable plug -and-play street- lighting solution to address the growing digital power management market.

file: STMPA - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 30April2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Turning to our Industrial & Power Discreet Group, net revenues totaled $430 million. Sales increased by 6.8% on  a sequential basis largely due to sales to power supply components with PC applications, as well as exposure to  euro denominated revenues.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: During the quarter, we recorded a number of achievements across our focus areas. In energy management for  portable equipment, we ramped the production of an AMOLED power supply chip for Samsung's S6 and we  continue to gain traction with RF Integrated Passive Devices for smartphones and Internet of Things applications  with leading global brands.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In power transistors, we have one of the broadest product portfolios of the industry. Here we gain several design  wins, to name a few, we were awarded low-voltage power MOSFETs in a power supply for game console  applications. We landed a win for high-voltage IGBTs for an induction heating application with the major Chinese  customers. And we won a design for high-voltage MOSFETs in ultra-high-definition display applications.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In power conversion, ST revealed together with Flextronics, the world's first plug-in charging platform for mobile  devices with zero no-load power based on our multi-mode power management controller. We also capture wins  for high-voltage power converters from several mass market customers in Greater China.

file: STMPA - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 27April2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: ADG's strategic focus is mainly on Smart Driving, that for ST means making cars greener, safer and more  connected. A part of our offering to make us greener is our power discrete products. They are increasingly  important to enable the pervasion of car electrification, and they represent an important opportunity moving  forward. In this area we achieved the significant design win with multiple products in a silicon carbide technology  for electrical traction in fully electrified cars. Our innovative SiC MOSFETs and rectifiers provide greater power  efficiency, and will significantly reduce the size of the electrification modules.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And finally, we confirmed low-power high-performance accelerometer and Bluetooth Low Energy socket in a new  activity tracker for a top player. We also won several projects in Smart Home, Smart City and the  Smart Industry  applications. I will give three examples of key markets where we won sockets during this quarter; electricity  metering, factory automation, and datacenters.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In electricity metering, we won a significant first order for a next generation meter from a key European  manufacturer. In factory automation, we delivered engineering samples for a new IO-Link communication  transceiver device that is designed to support the transition of factories to Industry 4.0.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And in datacenters we introduced a family of ICs that delivers the industry's highest power conversion efficiency  for the next generations, which is a 48 Volt datacenter architecture recently presented by Google.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our high-end STM32F7  has been selected by an American OEM for its next generation smartwatch. And our en try  level STM32F0 has been selected by a major OEM for a smart charging application.

file: STMPA - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 27April2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Now, let's move to a detailed review of our product groups, beginning with Automotive and Discrete. ADG  revenues increased year-over-year by 5.6%, reflecting growth in automotive and strong growth in power discrete  products. On a sequential basis, ADG revenues posted a better than seasonal results with a decrease of 1.2%.  ADG's operating margin was 5.4% in Q1, substantially stable in comparison to the year ago period. Moving to  customer activity, bookings in automotive were robust in the first quarter. Thanks to our focus on technologies and  products, enabling greener driving, we had important design wins related to car electrification, particularly in the  area of battery management and on-board charging.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: As well, we continue to gain share with motion and the environmental sensors in smartphones and wearables  worldwide, but also in communication systems. Automotive is an important focus area for our sensor business.  Moving to IoT, we continued the strong design-in momentum in low-power wireless connectivity with our  Bluetooth low energy solutions, as well as the SPIRIT sub-1GHz family for home and building automation. During  the quarter, we also launched a partnership with USound to produce the world's first piezo-MEMS speaker with  excellent sound quality, targeting IoT applications.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: We also captured an award for our U-Chip power supply and drivers for engine-management and battery- management systems from a major Chinese tier1, and we received multiple design wins from German tier1s for  electric power trunk applications. Our automotive microcontroller business saw multiple wins including a design  for a chassis stability control unit in Japan.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Let's now discuss Power Discrete that are pervasive across all the end markets that we address. In Automotive,  we continue to grow our silicon carbide business with our silicon carbide MOSFETs in the traction inverter  applications of two carmakers in China. We also maintain strong momentum in silicon carbide diodes with multiple  design-wins for electric-vehicle on-board chargers. In Industrial, our silicon carbide diodes and power MOSFETs  were selected for higher efficiency power conversion systems in servers, solar energy and the Hi-Fi audio  systems with both U.S. and European customers.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Moving to the AMS products, our Analog portfolio was very successful with industrial customers. Here, we  recorded many design wins for our high-end solutions for smart metering, motor control, solar power appliances,  and power supplies. This is thanks to our portfolio of dedicated solutions that have been defined together with  industry leaders built on ST proprietary technologies and refined over the past years. Good examples include our  STSPIN motor control solutions and our metering ICs.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: For silicon carbide, we announced the agreement to acquire the Western manufacturer, Norstel, on top of the  multiyear supply agreement with Cree we already announced. In Q1, we also started to provide global carmakers  with sample of our ACEPACK Drive module with silicon carbide embedded.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President, CEO & Member-Managing Board, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: In the power management and energy savings sector, we started deployment of STarGRID Power-Line  Communication System-on-Chips in China for newer smart metering programs as well as collecting important  design wins in the Automotive marketplace for a range of body and powertrain applications in U.S. and in Europe.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President, CEO & Member-Managing Board, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: The careful management of our assets includes our cash. So, with a reduction in capital expenditures, reduction in  operating expenses, focus on profitable market share gains and moving our VLSI business to self-sustainability, all  these steps should help us to substantially improve our free cash flow over time.

texts.text: Now, let me turn to our product highlights. From our Analog, MEMS and Sensors group, our very low -power RF  transceivers are gaining traction. For example, Paris, the City of Light, has begun deploying our SPIRIT1 device to  remotely control street lights along the river Seine.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV

texts.text: 7 I would like to mention also the last initiative that we have talk about, it’s on the photovoltaic. As you  know, we have created a joint venture, one third own by ST, one third by Sharp and one third by  Enel. This photovoltaic initiative is manufacturing, is a pure manufacturing, and ST has an equity  injection of about $70 million, but almost all in-kind. In fact, we are bringing our M6 fab, which is in  Catania, to the joint venture.

texts.speaker: Tait Sorensen, Director, Investor Relations

texts.text: Just to make sure that we are clear, we do not enter  – we do not intend to enter into photovoltaic  as a new business. Our core competencies remain the IC semiconductor business. But I think for  us, it’s a participation which is aimed at capturing some short term opportunity, of using this M6  facility, which was – been empty for too long. Redeploy our employees in Catania by the transfer of  some very skilled workforce, and also by the same token, I would say, having a closer relationship  with Sharp is helping, because Sharp is one of the key customers I was mentioning before.

texts.speaker: Tait Sorensen, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Okay, so we’ll get started here, just a couple of seconds for people to catch their seats. Okay, we’ll
texts.text: I think, and I would like to reinforce this, I think was mentioned by Alain during the presentation,  there is a strong focus today to contribute, in the company, to resolve some of the key challenges  that the world is facing. One of course is the limitation of natural resources and we have plenty of  opportunities to contribute to energy savings. We are doing with our Power products, with a lot of  products. This is a great opportunity for ST and the other one is Medical, of course accessible and  affordable healthcare to many more people in the world is a key challenge that the world is facing  and we see electronics becoming more and more important here and we are focusing more and  more in this area.

And so the fourth area of – so I did mention, sorry, excuse me, of course  healthcare what we want to do is to make sure that we can provide more and more people in the  world with affordable and accessible healthcare.

file: STMPA - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 24January2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Jan-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President, CEO & Member-Managing Board, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: And to build upon our continuous efforts in energy management and savings, we launched a new generation of  Smart Grid products such as new Smart metering chips for next generation Smart meters, including a new power  line communication platform that has already been adopted as the core of major Smart metering infrastructure  deployment in Europe, in China, in Japan and in United States.

file: STMPA - Q4 2011 Earnings Call Paris 24January2012 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Jan-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Philippe Lambinet
texts.profession: Corporate Strategy Officer & Senior Executive VP, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: In Industrial and Power Discrete, again many design wins, particularly in the areas of energy conversion,  particularly solar energy. And 2012, we have introduced new families of products – IGBT, power management for  amoled screens, and the new generations of process for very high voltage power MOS, Mdmesh, Fdmesh V  technologies. So, again, another areas of growth.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President, CEO & Member-Managing Board, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: And to build up on our continuous effort in energy management and savings, we launched a new generation of the  Smart Grid products, such as the new Smart-Metering chips for the next generation of Smart Meters including a  new power line communication platform that has already been adopted as the core of major Smart Metering  infrastructure deployment in Europe, in China, in Japan and in U.S.

file: STMPA - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 31January2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jan-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: AMM revenues increased 7.4% sequentially. As we had anticipated, we did see strong sequential revenue growth  in our motion MEMS and environmental sensors and continued progress in the Microcontrollers. We also saw a  quarter-to-quarter improvement in the operating margin to 13.9%.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Smart Power is the second key growth driver for us. With our innovative range of products in the smart grid,  power management for portable equipment and automation. We delivered high volumes of a new MOSFET family  for high-end chargers for a leading smartphone manufacturer.  For new generation 4G LTE devices, we also  introduced to several leading smartphone manufacturers, high-performing, power-saving tunable capacitors. And  one measure of the market's recognition of our success in managing power is that more than 70% of the world's  ICs for powering efficient AMOLED displays are supplied by ST.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: ST's proprietary 28-nanometer FD-SOI Technology Platform manufactured at our Crolles, France 300-milimeter  facility, has now proven it can deliver 30% higher speed at the same power and up to 50% greater power efficiency  at the same performance as bulk processes.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: With respect to ST-Ericsson, we will communicate further details when they become available. We are finalizing  our decision regarding available strategic options and while we do not underestimate the challenges related to the  transition, we are committed to ensure a smooth and timely exit.

file: STMPA - Q4 2012 Earnings Call Paris 31January2013 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jan-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: EVP, Chief Technology & Manufacturing Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Smart power and you'll see that smart power and power are not limited to Automotive markets. We introduced  new low-voltage MOSFET and IGBT families to complement of our usual strength, usual carmaker strength in  high-voltage. For new 4G LTE device, we also introduced to several leading smartphone makers high-performing,  power-saving tunable capacitors to optimize the antennas. And I would like to say that one measure of the market  recognition of our success in managing power activities is that more than 70% of ICs powering efficient AMOLED  displays are supplied by STMicroelectronics.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: EVP, Chief Technology & Manufacturing Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: The top 2013 priorities focus on expansion of low-voltage MOSFET and IGBT, major turnaround, as Carlo said, in  distribution and mass market following tough 2012 conditions, and we will introduce innovative solution in power  management for portable equipment as well.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: EVP, Chief Technology & Manufacturing Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: And last, but not the least, we have finally delivered our 28nm FD-SOI on time, full technology platform with the  first application processor engineering sample confirming, as our CEO said, superior performance and power  consumption optimization.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: EVP, Chief Technology & Manufacturing Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: So, now it's time to, let's say, to talk a little bit more in detail about CMOS FD-SOI. This CMOS FD-SOI technology  is, as Carlo said, providing a unique value-enabling device, significantly more performing, 30% less in power  consumption and with better power consumption at the same performance, so 50% below.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: EVP, Chief Technology & Manufacturing Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: But equivalent important or more important, it's able to operate across various sets of operating voltage. As an  example, this technology enable the device able to operate at 0.6 volts with a very, very, very low power  consumption, but delivering for the value context equivalent of 1 gigahertz speed, which means 5,000 bps  basically which cover all the application you need on the smartphone.

file: STMPA - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 28January2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jan-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: From a cost perspective, we managed the ST-Ericsson exit at lower cost than our original and the revised down  estimate. Currently, we estimate our remaining wind-down cost to be about $30 million to $40 million. This is the  remaining wind-down cost. As a result of the split-up, we added some of their competencies and strengthened our  product development teams across every product group. The transfer of resources is starting to deliver a wave of  new products that we'll discuss more in detail shortly.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Moving now to Power and Smart Power Management products; this year, we expect significant growth to be  supported by the overall macroeconomic improvement, in particular, in industrial and housing. We will benefit  from the investments made during 2013 with the launch of promising new power management products,  including an expansion to the server market, thanks to the additional competencies we took onboard from ST- Ericsson. We will also ramp up the production of our design wins in smartphones and tablets.

file: STMPA - Q4 2013 Earnings Call Paris 28January2014 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jan-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Ferro
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President, Finance, Legal, Infrastructure and Services, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: So, in life.augmented, which is our brand, I'm sure that likely from this morning to now, you have already  experienced benefits from several of our products in your home, in your car, in your portable device. Perhaps in  [indiscernible] (05:22), and indeed ST is number one in MEMS, encompassing motions, acoustic and  environmental MEMS to serve smartphone and portable devices, wearable devices, and now entering automotive.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: Executive VP & GM-Embedded Processing Solutions, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: I would like to come back a few minutes and to share with you the reason why FD-SOI now is showing a stronger  – well received from our customers. First if we start with the infrastructure networking customer, so basically our  customer need three major factors of merit in order to design their products. First, they need the best product  between performance of the processor or the logic you have in your design and power consumption, but also  standby leakage, so this is point number one.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: Executive VP & GM-Embedded Processing Solutions, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Then consumer. Of course consumer, they like the first figure of merit, so to find out between performances and  power consumption. But they like as well the leakage, the low, low, low leakage of the [indiscernible] (46:29) you  have in the System-on-Chips, which provides to you the best power balance in the mission profile of your System- on-Chips.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: Executive VP & GM-Embedded Processing Solutions, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: The last but not the least is, this technology offer a huge flexibility in the usage. It means you can operate the  transistor from your System-on-Chips at a very, very low voltage, but delivering enough [indiscernible] (46:55) to  your system. And at very, very low voltage, basically, your power consumption is zero. So you imagine that for  mobile Internet of fixed application, this feature is key.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: EVP & Corporate Strategy Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: And from a margin perspective, SP&A will fully enjoy the impact of two manufacturing efficiency improvement  programs where we are conducting the capacity from 6 inch to 8 inch in Catania and in Singapore, as well as the  consolidation of the back-end facility in China.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: EVP & Corporate Strategy Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: For several years, the product strategy has been clearly established and executed expanding the product portfolio  to new sensors beyond the motion MEMs. We are now able to offer four category of sensors, motion MEMS,  acoustic MEMS, environmental, and touch sensors, and without forgetting that AMS also contain our general  purpose analog offer and micro-actuators.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: EVP & Corporate Strategy Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: We added several steps executing along the strategy in 2013. We have consolidated our leading position in motion  MEMS with wins at top phone OEMs and getting wearable. We have also recorded strategies in our new sensors  offer. We have shipped more than 100 million units MEMS microphones and multiplying our revenue by four. We  had several wins for environmental sensors. We started shipping a new touchscreen controller to a large Asian  consumer OEM, and we have taken our highly integrated smart sensor system, iNEMO into high volume  production.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: EVP & Corporate Strategy Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: In 2013, we have continued our course of production innovation. For example, we launched the world's first  intelligent gateway system on chip for metering, embedding powerline modem, metr ology and diagnostics. We  introduced the best-in-class 600-volt IGBT and high performance low-voltage advanced trench MOSFET. In 2013,  we also enlarged our product portfolio to new power management IC family for battery management in mobile  platform and handsets thanks to resources we got from ST-Ericsson. And we also got a good traction on recently  launched products.

file: STMPA - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 28January2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jan-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: First, with our FD-SOI, we have developed technology that makes the benefits expected of the next-generation  CMOS technology available faster with low power consumption and at a lower cost. This is a value proposition  that resonates with many of our customers and has resulted in a broad design win by applying for ST.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And the last but not least, our smart power technology is second to  none. Our BCD technology, we are now on the  ninth generation, continues to be a key differentiator in our power, industrial, and automotive businesses.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Moreover, we have a number of other technologies, such as vertical integrated power, silicon carbide, power  MOSFET, IGBT, and intelligent power modules that are at the core of our power product and application strategy.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: EVP & Corporate Strategy Officer
texts.text: In AMS, microphones and touch-screen controllers, two recently added product families, both recorded very  strong growth becoming significant contributors to AMS sales during 2014. The group also pursued expansion in  key customer and application diversification. We have a leadership position in MEMS for wearable devices,  expanding from motion to environmental sensors, with the ramp of MEMS for automotive, and a first design win  for a combo motion MEMS for active safety. On a regional basis, it recorded strong growth in China, where ST  MEMS were adopted in over 60 new phone models from 12 companies during 2014.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: EVP & Corporate Strategy Officer
texts.text: Revenues for 2015 are expected to return to growth, boosted by this new generation of 6 -axis motion MEMS with  key customers, and by continuing to ramp-up automotive MEMS. We expect further expansion of the touch- screen and microphone businesses, together with a wider adoption of environmental sensors.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: EVP & Corporate Strategy Officer
texts.text: Our STM32 Open Development Environment and open software solution initiative will help us address ma ss  market and Internet of Things applications, with products like our Bluetooth low-energy solution.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: EVP & Corporate Strategy Officer
texts.text: Let's turn now to IPD where we recorded solid growth in a number of applications in LED lighting, digital and  analog solutions, motor control ICs, IGBT and intelligent power modules for appliance and industrial  applications, and field effect rectifier diodes to leading mobile phone charger manufacturers. We also ramped  production of high-voltage rectifiers and transistors at a leading electric car manufacturer.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: EVP & Corporate Strategy Officer
texts.text: Among the many innovative, best-in-class technology and products brought to the market by IPD last year, I  would like to mention our power management chipset for servers, the galvanic isolation technology for industrial  applications and our 1,200-volt silicon carbide transistors. The group also expanded the Automotive product  portfolio with rectifiers, with IGBT, silicon carbide diodes, and thyristors.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: EVP & Corporate Strategy Officer
texts.text: Revenues for IPD will continue to grow in 2015 through customer base expansion with important initiatives in  distribution and mass market, as well as through a wave of new leading products such as advanced low voltage  trench MOSFETs for industrial and server applications, intelligent power modules for industrial, AMOLED power  supply and power management ICs for smartphones, various components for RF applications, and silicon carbide  Schottky diodes for servers, telecom, and automotive.

file: STMPA - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 27January2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jan-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In automation for smart factories and homes, we broadened our offering of smart power ICs and transistors, and  we further developed our ecosystem to make the designing of the complete ST portfolio for motion control  including MCUs, sensors and connectivity even easier. For power conversion, we launched new solutions for  digital power and LED lighting and the server power supply including silicon-carbide based products.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In the area of energy management, we secured wins, in automotive, in various electric and hybrid vehicle  applications, while continuing to develop innovative solutions for energy harvesting and energy management. And  finally, in portable, we grew our business of protection devices and introduced innovative antenna-tuning  solutions.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Analog, our low-power connectivity solutions were well received by the market with volume sales of our  Bluetooth low-energy solutions for a top-tier wearable manufacturer and wins with our sub-gigahertz RF  transceiver for smart home applications.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our diversification also included new environmental sensors brought on to the market such as the smallest mo st  accurate pressure sensor in the industry. Of course, smartphones continue to remain a focus for us and we are  confident that products such as our – the latest six-axis device and our gyroscopes for optical image stabilization  will soon be found in flagship devices.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And second, we have today announced the reorganization of our business into three product groups and we will  align our financial reporting in Q1 accordingly. The first group, Automotive and Discrete is led by Marco Monti  and includes all our automotive ICs, both digital and analog, and our discrete products. As you know, Power  Discrete are increasingly important in the growing segment of car electrification.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The third group, Analog and MEMS is led by Benedetto Vigna and includes our low power analog ICs, smart  power products for industrial and power conversion and all of our MEMS activity. The technology and the  manufacturing organization is now under the leadership of Jean-Marc Chery, our Chief Operating Officer.

texts.speaker: Carlo Ferro
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President Finance, Legal, Infrastructure and Services
texts.text: Sense & Power and Automotive margin at 6.5% was compressed by lower revenues and also heat by unused  capacity charges. Only IPD operating margin has been resilient compared to the prior year thanks to the  manufacturing initiatives in 6 inches and 8 inches and in the [indiscernible] as well as thanks to the turnaround of  the Power Discrete division.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & EVP-Human Resources
texts.text: So, how are we going to address them? Let's start with Smart Driving. Smart Driving is about making driving  safer, green and more connected. This is very much in line with the forecast development of the automotive  market in the coming years with areas such as safety and infotainment, showing above average growth. Both  mixed signal and digital technologies here are key. The key examples are the RF applications that are fully digital  and we are addressing a very large portion of them. Smart Drivers covers all of the key application areas in the car,  active and passive safety systems, electric and hybrid vehicle electrification, infotainment and telematics and all  the body, chassis and powertrain-related subsystems.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & EVP-Human Resources
texts.text: Moving to the Smart Home and the Smart City, ST's portfolio is very well adapted. And our ability to offer  solutions involving multiple ST products tailored to specific vertical applications, positions us well to address this  area of the Internet of Things. And with our sales channel and customers, we will benefit from the above-average  growth forecast for home and building control, LED lighting and metering, and this is among the many principal  opportunities.

file: STMPA - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 26January2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jan-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: In our focus on safer driving we had a number of achievements for ADAS-related components. These include a  next-generation ADAS processor in cooperation with Mobileye featuring level 5 autonomous driving capability and  based on 7-nanometer technology from foundry. And there are several design wins with our new 77 GHz radar  solutions. Using our technology to make driving greener, we had multiple design wins for our silicon carbide  products for on-board and external charging systems as well as for traction applications.

texts.speaker: Carlo Bozotti
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: We also had many awards with our latest generation of smart power technology both in Japan and in Europe. ST  is also bringing personalized entertainment and connected experience into the car in an easy to use manner while  enabling secure communications between vehicles and the infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Carlo Ferro
texts.profession: CFO, Executive Vice President-Finance, Legal, Infrastructure & Services, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Wafer cost reduction will be a key priority in 2017, leveraging our investment to scale up production in 12-inch,  and on technology evolution, as Jean-Marc will mention shortly.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Following extensive work, our internal manufacturing footprint is improving. And in the course of 2017 we expect it  to reach higher production at lower wafer costs. In particular, our Crolles 12-inch fab is now reaching a better  balance and loading, which resulted in the significant reduction of unused capacity costs by the fourth quarter of  last year. In Crolles 12-inch we are also moving to expand equipment capacity scale within the current and  existing infrastructure, which will allow us to significantly reduce wafer costs.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Finally, I would like to highlight silicon carbide. ST has been investing in this technology organically for a number  of years. As a result, today we are one of the few semiconductor companies able to provide it. In simple terms our  silicon carbide technology is more efficient than the other technologies available on the market today. And we  have seen a dramatic increase in the interest from current and potential customers. For example, in the  electrification of the car silicon carbide can bring up to 20% more autonomy or significant reduction in the cost of  the battery. During 2016 we received a number of design wins. And we are now working to bring this technology  to market and accelerate the development of the ecosystem to support its adoption.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: Chief Operating Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: In regard to the important design wins with our silicon carbide MOSFET, we are on track to ramp production in the  second half of 2017.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & Executive Vice President, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: If we look into the area of car electrification and the longer-term forecast, we see that the various types of hybrid  and electric vehicles are set to grow from 5% of total car production last year to 16% in 2023. This is a great  opportunity for ST with our broad offering of Power and Smart Power products, automotive microcontrollers,  EEPROM, and protection devices.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & Executive Vice President, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: The electrification of cars is accompanied by a significant increase in silicon content. As car makers add battery  management, power conversion, inversion, and charging functionality, the silicon content of the average car is  forecast to increase by over $500. This is also driven by the need for higher value silicon devices that can meet  the higher power and voltage requirement for full electric traction cars.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & Executive Vice President, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Our silicon carbide technology, as mentioned by Jean-Marc, brings significant benefit for car electrification  compared to the solutions available today. This allows car makers to deliver vehicles with greater range and  faster changing – charging capacities. This will lead to a rapidly growing market for silicon carbide devices.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & Executive Vice President, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Smart Metering. An example is Smart Meters, where ST had been developing solutions for over 20 years in  partnership with key Smart Grid players. We are shipping now the new generation of Smart Meters that  represents significant business for ST moving forward.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & Executive Vice President, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: In addition to the hardware solutions we provide middleware that enables key application functionality, such as  local or cloud connectivity or sensor capabilities. We also provide development of ecosystems that allow fast and  easy prototyping and support for developers to get their design rapidly into production.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & Executive Vice President, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: Worth repeating, we recently shipped our 1 millionth development board for the STM32, which includes our most  complete ecosystem, the STM32 ODE, Open Development Environment.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & Executive Vice President, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: And finally, I would like to mention the smartphone market, which remain an important focus for ST. Here we have  a number of product opportunities, including motion sensors, gyroscopes for optical image stabilization, Time-of- Flight ranging solutions, NFC and secure element solutions, environmental sensors, micro-actuators for  autofocus, wireless charging, protection devices, display-related components, and also our general purpose  microcontrollers.

file: STMPA - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 25January2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Jan-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & President, Strategy, Communication, Human Resources and Quality, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: We also had success with our 24 77-gigahertz radar products, which grew revenues by about 25% in 2017. In the  area of greener driving, we won new designs in car electrification, growing our market share in power  components. These wins include our silicon carbide products. We have already talked about important wins in the  U.S. and Asia, and I can now mention that we are collaborating with the Renault Group on the next onboard  charger generation with our silicon carbide diodes and MOSFETs. Silicon carbide revenues started to materialize  last year, and looking forward, we see big opportunities as the adoption of hybrid and electric vehicles increase.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & President, Strategy, Communication, Human Resources and Quality, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: During the fourth quarter, we acquired Atollic to offer our customers a full Integrated Development Environment,  specifically tailored for the STM32 family the STM32 Nucleo development ecosystem.

texts.speaker: Georges Penalver
texts.profession: Chief Strategy Officer & President, Strategy, Communication, Human Resources and Quality, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: We continued to have success with our smart metering solutions, and we announced a new modular,  programmable chipset. We also grew with power conversion products such as our VIPerPlus family of high- voltage AC/DC converters. In 2017, our wireless connectivity revenues more than doubled versus 2016. We  launched a new System-on-Chip Bluetooth Low Energy 5.0 certified, and we won multiple designs in a range of  applications.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: MEMS, sensors, and actuators, 2017 saw a significant increase in our manufacturing volume in MEMS  associated with the prior introduction of a number of new market-leading motion and environmental MEMS  product based on our optimized micro-machine technology.

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: In 2018, we plan to increase our 6-inch capacity in line with customer demand, while extending our product  offering base on our third-generation of silicon carbide technology. At the same time, we are continuing the  technology development of our next generation of automotive-grade MOSFETs, which will include a move to  trench technology in the fourth generation.

file: STMPA - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 24January2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Jan-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Marc Chery
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: However, part of this CapEx is also devoted to support three strategic initiatives. First, a new 300 millimeter wafer  fab in Agrate, our site near Milan. The construction work of the first stage to support R&D and first industrial  deployment phase has already started, with the related building and facilities to be completed and ready to host  some equipment for R&D in 2020. This new fab is designed to be expandable, of course, according to demand to  start volume production starting from 2021. It will be focused on supporting our growth ambitions and leadership  in BCD, IGBT and power technologies.

file: STMPA - UBS European Conference 11November2014 830 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Nov-14.pdf
STMPA - UBS Global Technology Conference 21November2013 100 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Carlo Ferro
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President, Finance, Legal, Infrastructure and Services, STMicroelectronics NV
texts.text: We are moving on, expanding the offering of MEMS from the motion MEMS that we started with towards acoustic  MEMS, and those are the microphones; and with what we call the environmental MEMS, and those are pressure  sensors that adapt on the device in order for instance to give added functionality of an altimeter. The combination  of the opportunities of expanding the product and the func tionalities and the fact that the number of MEMS  components in a single portable device is increasing from generation into next generation give us an opportunity  not only of continuing to grow in MEMS, but also to maintain the profitability of this busines s against any level of  natural price erosion coming from competition and coming from maturity of solutions introduced years ago.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Going to slide six, remind you our commitment to sustainable development. Clean products, clean processes,  commitment to ethical business. And the strong commitment to the development of the communities, where we  work around our BipBop program for electrification of underprivileged people, on insertion of underprivileged  youngsters, with a big commitment in education in our business, particularly the business of energy and  electricity.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The things that we develop in new economies are really based on the investment we do, on the new activities we  are capturing. It's about services, it's about solutions, it's about energy efficiency, in some cases, it's about  renewables. It's really things that we develop on markets which overall, when you take the average of Europe and  the U.S., have still not recovered from the crisis. But you see really the strong kicker that new economies represent  in our growth.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, what strikes me in H1 is that it has been an intense application for implementation of our strategy. What we  see today is that energy efficiency is mainstream. And by the way, what – the tragedy that happened in Japan, and  especially the pressure it puts on nuclear industry, is making the two technology banners, Germany and Japan,  have decided to adopt new energy models and to be stronger on energy efficiency.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We totally support this. We believe that we need all kinds of generation, but anyway, that the world will become –  will have to become more efficient. And clearly, we have an edge today on the solutions and particularly the, what  we call eco-structure, in the field of energy efficiency solutions. So, what you saw in the first half is a development  technologically around the eco-structure breaks and in terms of competence with a set-up of competency centers  on our solutions for energy efficiency particularly are developing by 14%, growing by 14%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Smart grid emerging on the most striking element of the first half, and this time, it's the offer on Telvent, which is  bringing – which is doubling our software capabilities in the field of the smart grid. Our new economies are  driving the world growth, the striking difference between the debt in the mature countries and the capacities of  financing in the new economies, where we are well rooted, not because we decided yesterday to go there, but we  decided a long time ago, and it's a well-rooted, well – I'm very happy at present that we have there, again, 17% in  H1.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And there was a lot of work also in reengineering – there is a series of products that we totally reengineered,  because some of the components were not there anymore. I mean, the factories have been wiped out. And we  reengineered, which is, in my dialect, a tour de force, they were reengineered in like two months and made  available with the customers.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Co-Chief Financial Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: By business now, as you can see, industry is clearly leading the chart here with 18% organic growth. Industry  business is growing in each region. So, the dynamism is not limited here to new economy. We really see a nice and  strong growth everywhere. The competition for industry player is there. There is a need for more productivity.  There is a need for energy efficiency and it is clearly developing very nicely as a business.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Co-Chief Financial Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Moving now to the other businesses. Power, 9% growth. Power is developing extremely well in new economies. No  need to say that there is a nice construction market, well-oriented in new economy, but there is also strong  investment in low voltage for infrastructure, for industry that is driving the growth.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Co-Chief Financial Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: When we look at the metro country, in the U.S., we have seen a rebound, but which is clearly not driven by what  we see in the construction, because here, there is no rebound in the U.S. neither in residential nor in non- residential. So, it is what we sell in term of low voltage through the industry and through the data center and  market which is the engine of the growth.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Co-Chief Financial Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Moving to the energy performance, 5% organic growth. Energy has been accelerating between Q1 and Q2. Q1 was  only marginally positive. So, indeed, we know that this business is more late cycle than many of our other activity.  And we are seeing momentum rising notably in new economy, with the project and infrastructure in oil and gas  and that is generating a nice increase of the business, 9% organic growth on the second quarter.  IT business, almost 10% growth through this first half. We are seeing a very nice development of demand for the  big system, big data center project, largely related to the development of the cloud. At the same time and notably  in the mature country, because situation is still good in the new economy, we see a slowdown in the growth for  small systems. So, that is somewhat slowing down the IT performance, which has been still very solid with this  10% growth.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Co-Chief Financial Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Buildings, well, I remind you that today, buildings is, I think, the lowest exposure to new economy. So, of course,  that is somewhat a disadvantage for this business. Still, a 7% growth during this period. We've seen very strong  demand for services and notably, advanced services, so strong added value to our client in the building industry to  manage their energy.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Co-Chief Financial Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: We see a nice development for solution and project around security and we have seen a nice growth in new  economy, which is start to develop well and certainly, we are investing a lot there to achieve that. We are seeing  projects around energy efficiency in new economy gathering momentum.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Co-Chief Financial Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Second category, businesses where we have stable margin as a case of power and energy and here, we have been  able to compensate the inflation for raw material. And then two negative evolution of profitability, IT and  Building. This is, of course, the weight of solutions for these two businesses. This is the raw material inflation and  this is, again, the very conscious decision that we need to invest for the future in these two businesses and that is,  of course, having an impact on the profitability at new economies here.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Yeah, sure. So, while the first thing is to look at our priorities today on – I'm going to share an internal document  which is where we drive our teams today, we continue to drive organic growth. We've got some very interesting  spots of the business with high dynamics. We spoke about the new economies. We spoke about our new activities  in major countries. So, we keep capturing new opportunities in energy efficiency, in the smart grid and in the new  economies.

file: SU - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 1August2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: So a very quick overview about Schneider; €23 billion of sales over the last 12 months; 40% of our sales in new  economies; close to 40% of our sales in Solutions; and we are at a very interesting point in time where the  business of the group is completely balanced between the Americas which represent roughly 30% of our sales,  Western Europe roughly 30% of our sales, Asia Pac around 30% of our sales, so a very, very balanced presence on  business around the world. Remind you that we have a very strong commitment and sustainable development will  be by our mission, which is to help our customers to make the most of their energy and particularly to reduce  energy consumption and also complete commitment to corporate social responsibility, a multi-faceted  commitment that we measure every quarter in terms of progress on results.  Now, I'm going to go through the review of this first half and first go to the headlines of the main achievements of  the first half. And as we said at the beginning of the year, we've been totally focused on execution – operational  execution. In the first half, the main achievements have been, first, pricing power; price increases by €141 million  in H1 and I'm going to come back to that. But with that, we have covered 80% of the raw material impact that  affected us last year. Then operational efficiency, our adjusted operating result, adjusted EBITA increased by 9%;  the earnings per share plus 10%. Our cash generation is back to a normal profile after a disturbed 2011 year. And  the free cash flow over the last 12 months is equivalent to 108% of our net income.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Now, let's have a review in more details business by business. Our Power business has very strong dynamics. As  it's well known, it represents 38% of our business, plus 3% on the full first half of organic growth and plus 8.7% of  current growth. Well, we have – this business is very resilient in – and is very diversified in terms of market  exposure, geographical exposure. And we fully benefit of our strong leadership worldwide. Infrastructure, flattish  over the first half, minus 0.7%, the current growth of 17%. Well, we had said very clearly that the priority in this  business was to realize – finalize the integration of Schneider, Areva and Telvent. So a lot of work devoted to this  integration, to making sure that the organizations are well merged together, that the synergies are put into place,  on clear priority in measuring our margin and our profit and Solutions model. This has been well done. We are  developing very satisfactory oil services. We are developing our Solutions for infrastructure, for oil and gas. This  semester has been also characterized by the lower demand from utilities.

texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: On those, particularly we selected them because they illustrate the work of integration of architectures that we do  in the field of water, in the field of process, in the field of integrated hospital, on the field of data center. And our  cash investment in R&D increased from 4.6% of sales last year to 5.1% of sales in H1 2013.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Finance, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Second element, price, €48 million positive. You will remember that initially we had said that we could reach for  the full year €100 million. Then when we saw the decrease in raw material, we said, well, we may be a bit more  tactical here and there. So it's better to look at the global total price increase plus raw material impact. At the  beginning of the year, we were targeting to be neutral or a little bit better. If I look at what we've done through  these first six months, plus €48 million for price, plus €17 million for raw material impact, so it's a nice €60  million plus combined for the two.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Finance, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: For the rest of the year, I would expect price probably to be more limited in term of positive price impact, given  the environment and the low inflation or deflation that we're seeing on the raw material. But I would expect  further good news on the raw material impact, and we could be anywhere between €40 million and €50 million  positive for raw material impact based on the current price, which would be good news coming from the copper  and the silver.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Finance, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: So these are the negative and positive on COGS inflation just to finish on margin. As always, €40 million to €50  million inflation on wages, nothing particular to mention during this first half in that respect.

texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
