So two examples here and I can't make names, but on the [indiscernible] (18:47) that Invensys had won for the  DCS system, we add [indiscernible] (18:54) on the energy package and that's significant value that's in the  magnitude of €30 million.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Now, some words about the Planet & Society barometer, which is a sustainable development part of our equation,  the actions that we're doing, we're ahead of our targets with respect to the Connect brand and well positioned –  well, actually, we have already reached the end of the year target.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Remind you in two words the pillars environmental, which we call planet; bottom of pyramid, which we call profit,  and our people, the security of our people and the well being of our people. In all of these, we're above our targets.  And we've got some very significant recognitions recently, being ranked by Newsweek as one of the top 10 green  companies in the world, which came on the top of the recognition in Davos as being one of the top companies in  terms of sustainability in the world.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: The negative currency impact is today evaluated at 40 basis point with really almost all of the impact, or most of  the impact, concentrated in H1. I don't want to forget the fact that we have committed, and we're going to start a  program of share buyback to compensate the [ph] emission (45:53) of shares for the world employee stock  ownership plan for the restricted shares for the leaders of the company. And that would amount to around 6  million shares in H2, 2014.

file: SU - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 29July2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Second point, of course, Oil & Gas, division of the oil price by more than two in the past six months, which affected  directly our turnover or indirectly because we have collateral investments of Oil & Gas happening in other sectors  like construction. One thing that would appear very clearly in our presentation is the fact that Invensys results are  impacted by rather high base of comparison in H1 2014, which gives place to one -offs, which are not likely to  repeat in the future, so those are the major elements.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the other side, and I don't come back into the detail of all this, two one -offs are impacting quite a lot the first  half, the Q1, and I spoke about it and we spoke several times about it. The second point is the Nuclear business,  which, as you know, we had to resolve. We are [ph] phasing out two (13:56) Services, so that's a reduction of  volume with some costs associated to finish resolving these issues.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We, of course, suffer from the dynamics of the oil and gas market. And one proxy for that is what we do in field  devices, which are the valves that go into a oil & gas system. And you see they are down by 20%.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But on the other hand, we are repositioning ourselves into other segments. And what strikes me is that the  underlying trend of sales, if you exclude the one-offs, is slightly negative and not exactly a mirror of what we hear  and what we see from global oil and gas markets. So I believe we are, on that side, from the turnover point of view,  on the profitability difference point of view, doing a reasonably good job.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: To mention also that H1 has been marked by a number of launch of new products that we developed in the past  few years. We don't yet have the volumes associated to those products, but we have the cost of amortization of  some of the capitalized R&D associated to those products and that sees out in the gross margin of this first h alf  especially in Industry, which at the same time is knowing – the slowing down that I mentioned before. That's not  only on product, but also in software. To mention some of the software suites that we just came out with, Resource  Advisor for Energy Management, StruxureWare for Data Centers, StruxureWare for Healthcare, hospitals  particularly.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And I will finish with overview by speaking about our Planet & Society barometer. You know that when we  restarted our new company program, "Schneider is On", we fixed ourselves new targets. At the end of the first half,  we are in advance on those targets. Well, it's a kind of classical that it's easier to start than at the end, so a good  start, but we have to keep working hard in achieving those objectives.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy CEO in charge of Finance and Legal Affairs
texts.text: Now, if I go more deeply in our P&L, so the gross profit has reached €4.752 billion. It's up almost 7%. When I look  at the SFC, they are also up 7 %. Jean-Pascal said it. Organically, we are down 2.1 points. So, if you take as a very  reasonable assumption that structure costs are evolving to a minimum pace of plus 2%, notably because of  inflation and natural evolution of cost, that means that we have generate a saving, which is above 4% versus the  trend or forecast. So, already significant impact, but of course just the beginning of the journey and more is to  come in term of SFC efficiency.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Second point, we are facing again headwinds for oil and gas. Most of the shock or large part of the shock is behind  us. But we are going to benefit from a better base of comparison for Invensys, but Invensys will still be impacted  by oil and gas. We're going to work on the recovery of the core and historical part of industry, and that's already in  process. And if I would say the place where we are going to spend, as a management team, most of our time is to  make sure that we square this project and solution situation where we have explanations. We know what we have  to do. We just have to make sure that we accelerate the squaring of the situation.

file: SU - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 28July2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Oil and gas, which I remind is today 6% of our direct sales exposure, so being at lower level, remains now more  stabilized. And we feel that the stakeholders and our customers are getting more rational in front of that new  environment. So, decisions are now being made, with the consequence that some of the countries where we  operate like Russia are going better and is actually back to positive in H1. Actually, the only element of disruption  is Brexit that we have talked about already, but where we see today an impact which is limited to the UK which is  less than 4% of our sales. And actually, we delivered stable H1 in the UK.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The second cylinder of Schneider is On is an intense work on simplification that we describe. We don't make  much noise about it, but we work in depth on this subject. We have a target cost reduction of €1.6 billion by 2017.  We deliver in H1 €300 million, one-third on base cost, two-thirds at the COGS level like productivity.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I move on to the next slide, which is the growth by business. I would say very happy to see all of our business  performing. All of them have different priorities. So, Buildings & Partners up in a mixed market, but up by 1.3%.  And you know that this is the big ship at Schneider, a world-leader business at Schneider. Industry at minus 1.9%.  Remember that we have a part of our business which is exposed to oil and gas. But this – and I'll speak in detail  about that – this is improving through the quarters. Infrastructure at minus 1.3%, which is the byproduct of  selectivity on projects, actually, it would be plus 1% without the selectivity. And overall, today as we show roughly  flat sales on H1, the impact of project selectivity on the total portfolio is €70 million to €80 million, which means  the underlying is plus 1%. IT is delivering solid sales, flat sales at a solid margin.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Moving on to page 9 and having a look at geographies. Well, West Europe confirms its rebound, and actually Q2  is at plus 3%. So, we benefit from everything we know, low euro, low interest rates and low prices of fossil energy,  which are helping the investment of the zone. U.S. and North America are back to positive in an environment  where construction is doing well, technology is doing well. But we know that industry is impacted particularly by oil  and gas and the high level of dollar.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Second part of the work that we do in cost is on support function cost where we generate in H1 €120 million gross  SFC savings on the top of the €300 million last year. Remind you that we have a commitment to deliver €300  million on the total of 2016 and 2017. A lot of work on the simplification of our business organization and regional  organization. A lot of work on putting together some business which were separate before. A lot of work R&D  efficiency, mutualization of the back office which is something we have started a long time ago. So, all of this,  again, is carrying results in our environment.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the next slide, 13, some examples of some products that were launched in H1 around this architecture. There  are some very foundational products in this slide. I want to mention Masterpact MTZ, which is a world-leading  product, which is the core of the low-voltage distribution. Well, MTZ is bringing unparalleled capacity of precision  one metering which make that customers don't have to equip their systems of supplementary accessories to  measure the characteristics of power. So, that's an incredible savings for people who have to control their process  on their energy. New launch of speed drives which are saving 30% to 70% of energy on motors and preserving  the mechanical assets. And complete renewal of our range of relays of protection, plus the launch of Galaxy VX,  which is our new range of UPS for large-scale datacenter and for industrial application.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: More launches in the field of automation platforms. Our BMS, Building Management System platform. TAS, which  combines together the control of process and energy. Microgrid controls, we are doing more and more microgrids,  not only in emerging countries, but also in mature countries. And our totally new system for datacenter operation  that is [ph] plugged on (18:49) at the next level, which is a level of the analytics to our cloud base structure and  software, which helps customers to manage their assets. On that level of analytics, there again you see a number  of new applications and analytics which help our customers to manage their installations.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, this is about innovation and launches. Now I want to go into the detail of each business, starting by the major  business of Schneider, 45% of the group H1 revenues, which is Building & Partners. That goes from home  buildings such as all of low voltage, that goes also that pervades into industry and infrastructure. Well, very good  organic growth at plus 1.3%. In this business, we have been also selective with projects of building controls. So, if  you focus on the low voltage product parts, we have been actually growing quite well, I would say around 3% for  the total of the company on a worldwide scale, which is a great performance in a place which is our area of  excellence on a global scale.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Moving on to the next slide, 18, on Industry. Well, there again progress and continuous progress. Industry has  been impacted by weaker market and especially the collaterals of the oil and gas evolution. Q1 was at minus  2.3%, Q2 minus 1.2%, resulting minus 1.9%. Work on profitability, plus 40 bps in terms of adjusted EBITA. It  would have been 1.2 points before forex there again.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We had a good dynamic in Europe boosted by OEM markets. We are impacted in the U.S. by oil and gas and  strong dollar, which impacts OEM. We had a decline in China which remains a difficult market. Process  automation, actually, which is the legacy of Invensys, was slightly up in weak markets because it's impacted by oil  and gas particularly. But we kept benefiting from the revenue synergies and the cross-synergies of the integration  of Invensys.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: A quick look at a continuous focus on sustainable development with a lot of recognition of the commitment of  Schneider in this. Lots of progress. We are above the targets of our barometer which measures us against the  main things, with practically good performance in energy savings and development of circular economy within  Schneider.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer-Finance & Legal
texts.text: We keep managing to curve our SFC and decrease our SFC and create a leverage between the revenue  evolution and the SFC. Jean-Pascal has already largely detailed all the action that we are implementing on our  SFC to deliver this performance and, of course, we will continue to do so in the coming quarters.

file: SU - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 27July2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: We have four business, and those business have two roles. They have to develop technologies that are serving  all the markets of Schneider. And what we report on this names of the business are technologies. So IT is Secure  Power on what we report in this name of IT are Secure Power technologies. Building, Low Voltage, and what we  report on the Building is Low-Voltage technologies. Infrastructure, Medium Voltage. On Industry, Industrial  Automation.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So you're going to hear me speaking more and more about Secure Power, about Low-Voltage, Medium Voltage  and Industrial Automation, we're going to [indiscernible] (09:58) that together over the next reporting, always  associating the two names, but be prepared that we're going to report in function of the thing that we count and  that we report.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: The thing that's really important to understand with Schneider is that our – we've built our company from the end  markets, but with design the growth model to be based on cross-selling. So we have four technologies, again,  Secure Power, Low-Voltage, Medium Voltage, that's combined together into a power energy management chain.  And then we've got one business, which is Industrial Automation that combine with energy management into  complete efficiency solutions.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So, the business, the technology leading the charge in building is a business of Philippe, here in the room, so it's  Low-Voltage. But when we sell one of low-voltage, we sell 25% to – 20% to 30% of other products into the same  package. And we do it normally with integrators and distributors that buy the whole package. So cross-selling in  this field is most of the time done by our distributors and our integrators.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: In data centers and networks, the key activity or the centerpoint activity is IT, but it brings 25% of other business  of Schneider, namely Low-Voltage and Medium Voltage. And those business today – and I'll come back on that  because data center is a great, great market of Schneider is growing double-digit, which means all application is  growing mid-single-digit, okay. And when you focus – in this business, you've got two parts. You've got the  products for distributed IT and you've got the data center part of the business. When you focus on data center, it's  almost 50-50. 50% IT technology, central power technology, and 50% Low-Voltage or Medium Voltage.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: In Industry and Infrastructure, you've got a double synergy, which is we sell Medium Voltage and Low-Voltage  together into integrated packages, right. And those combining into solution of efficiency. When you do a machine,  you don't do just the automation, you do the automation and powering the machine. When you do plant, that's a  key differentiator of Schneider, but by the way, most of our competitors are doing that, too. We sell, on one side,  automation, and we combine it with powering the plant. So that it's a combined efficiency solution. So 50-50  between Low-Voltage and Medium Voltage, and then 50-50 between Medium Voltage, Low-Voltage on  automation.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So projects represent roughly 40% of Schneider turnover and that the first place for cross-selling and the first form  of cross-selling. But 60% of the turnover at Schneider is happenings with network of integrators, and those  integrators need the full offer to supply their customers, mixing power, energy management and automation. And  you see here new products that we are launching in H1 that are going to directly to distributors and integrators of  all sort, supported by integrated digital tools that don't know any border between our technologies. We support all  of our technologies for same customer. And that generate the 4% organic growth that we've had in H1.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Plenty of new bricks of our EcoStruxure architecture, which says that today this represents – EcoStruxure sales  represent 45% of the sales of Schneider. Every product that we develop today has a place on the connection into  EcoStruxure. And EcoStruxure is made of six vertical architectures that combined together to serve the  customer's needs. So you've got a few examples here.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: And I would like to mention that customers are not really interested by technologies. They are interested by the  value that the convergence of energy automation on software provide, and you've got here, four examples where  this technology really mix in connectivity, edge controls, analytics, computing capability on the cloud, brings  significant value of efficiency and reliability to the customer. And what you see also is that every time, this  combines different technologies of Schneider.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Energy and Sustainability Services whereby we help customers to manage their demand and source the right  supply of energy. It's purely digital, it's all about connectivity, analytics and specialist bureau. EcoStruxure  machine, which is machine automation. Really a great success of

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Schneider, very significant part of our Industrial Automation business. EcoStruxure Grid, which is a smart grid,  where we are scoring number of wins. And Cloud and service providers segments, which is the most  sophisticated part of the data segments where we grow double-digit.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Provisions grow, again an exceptional for the [ph] fourth of this year (20:07) mid single-digit growth for Final  Distribution on the Wiring Devices. We are really accelerating in EcoStruxure power on Building, double-digit  growth of Low-Voltage in data centers, so our data center presence is a strong accelerator of this one, I'll detail on  that one. And we should – but it's a news of the night, we should have this year acquisition of ASCO that confirm  our position of world leader in power sources management.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Priorities, more partners, more products, more connectivity, and of course, this is a place of the highest or most  acute intensity in terms of pricing to cover the cost on the ForEx. Secure Power, that's one of the flagship  technologies of Schneider. We are here growing by 2% and I'm going to be a bit more detailed about that.  Decrease of margin on this first half are the reasons I was mentioning. Launch of our EcoStruxureIT base of  comparison on projects on destocking in Japan with the road map, yeah – as a road map.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: The second part of the business are data centers, which are mixing Secure Power and Low-Voltage and Medium  Voltage technologies, while our sales in data center are growing mid-single-digit in H1. So IT, low single-digit,  MV/LV sales in DC up double-digit.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: I want to make a quick zoom about data center. Data center has been for the past 10 years a very attractive  market for Schneider, and it keeps being so. So we grew mid-single-digit. What is important to understand is that  in data centers we sell €1.4 billion of IT, which drove to the permanent increase on development of our presence  in Low-Voltage and Medium Voltage. So we sell €800 million in that space. And our market share due to that in  Low-Voltage and Medium Voltage in datacenter is much higher than on the rest of the market. So it is a strategic  objective for us to keep developing on that segment, knowing that the technology evolution makes it more intense  in Low-Voltage and Medium Voltage as we go forward than in IT, but you absolutely need the IT infrastructure to  be relevant in that segment.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So we are growing in all four regions with a strong growth in China. We are performing extremely well with  machine manufactures with EcoStruxure machines growing double digit. Process automation is now back into  positive after this year was impacted by oil and gas. On software, we spoke about it, are up.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Point one, the product that we sell in bundle with low-voltage products to low-voltage partners and we have by far  the largest network of partners around the world. Second, services that we always deliver with the common theme  between Medium Voltage and Low-Voltage around the world, and that's one of the fastest growing business, and  the most profitable business we have at Schneider over the past years. And finally, EcoStruxure Grid, which is a  smart grid, which has been developing very satisfactorily, and it's typically another automation business.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: I'll finish the presentation by a very short review of our Planet & Society barometer; I won't speak very much  because we are ahead of our objective. Schneider is very committed to corporate social responsibility, actually at  the core of our strategy. We are beating all of our objectives here. This being said, and that was a pretty extensive  presentation, I hand over to Emmanuel for the financials.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Chief Financial Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: And at the same time, of course, we are taking all the conclusion of this improving environment and top line and  the effort that we need to make on utilization. So that means that we've been absolutely relentlessly working on  our program for SFC saving, almost €100 million of gross saving generated in H1. I can tell you we work 360  degree on the global function like finance, and – or we work on the real estate, for instance, we work on  optimizing the structure at the level of our operation. But I can tell you everybody is working on generating  simplification, efficiency, mutualization and that has been delivering in the first half, when we then intend to  continue.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Chief Financial Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: All right. So, that drives the gross profit of a bit more than €4.7 billion, up more than 4%. The SFC are, despite  ForEx still a bit below the €3 billion. And we have an adjusted EBITDA of €1.718 billion, it's up plus 8.3%  organically. Same ForEx, same scope. We are up plus 7%. Remember we have this three-year objective growing  4% to 7% organically on the adjusted EBITDA, where we are actually in the high-end of this range for the first half  and that is translating into a margin of 14.1% versus 13.5%, it's up plus 60 bps. The last year number have been  restated of the de-consolidation of the Solar business. So that's why versus a 13.3% that we published last year,  we have 20 bps more.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Chief Financial Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Income tax, the €361 million negative. This is a 26% average tax rate for the group. We are in the low-end of the  bracket that we initially gave for the year, which was 26% to 28%. So we are hopeful to be able to finish the year  in this lower-end of the bracket. Discontinued operation, that's the Solar business that we've been  deconsolidating, and it's for the vast majority of this amount, an impairment of the goodwill of the acquisition that  we have made, I think, in 2008 of the [indiscernible] (42:48) business on Solar.

texts.speaker: Amit Bhalla
texts.profession: Senior Vice President, Head of Investor Relations, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Thank you, Jean-Pascal. I think we'll spend maybe 15 minutes or so to discuss, of course, the acquisitions this  morning of Asco Power Technologies. So, like to invite up Philippe Delorme, the Head of our buildings Low- Voltage business.

texts.speaker: Philippe Delorme
texts.profession: EVP-Building & Information Technology, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So ASCO, maybe to tell you a bit, so ASCO is a leader in North America by transfer switch. And transfer switch is  something pretty simple. In many critical application, take data center or take hospital, you need to make sure that  you always have power on. So, you will have your connection to the grid, of course, that you will have some  backup power, could be in most of the case, gensets and you need the piece of technology to connect or to  switch sources from the grid when the grid has a problem, to that sources of energy which are mostly gensets,  and coordinate the different gensets together.

texts.speaker: Philippe Delorme
texts.profession: EVP-Building & Information Technology, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So alongside with transfer switch, a collection of other products, because when you switch sources, then you  need to coordinate the different gensets, that's what we call power control system. You need to test those  installation, especially in the case of hospital and the load banks, monitoring surge. Associated with that and that's  very good, they need a lot of services. So that our service team is attached to it, which by the way needs an  additional of a few products, higher pump controllers typically, actually to monitor the gensets, so it's a full, let's  say, set of capabilities, again, very strongly positioned in North America.

texts.speaker: Philippe Delorme
texts.profession: EVP-Building & Information Technology, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So what does it bring to Schneider? A few things and these are very simple. I'll elaborate a little bit with our  position worldwide, but it position Schneider as a global market leader in power source management, which again  is really critical in critical application. It enhance our capability in North America in the field of energy management  or really the core business of Schneider. Very strong complementarity with what we have in Low Voltage. Again,  in segments like healthcare, financial services, data centers, so places where today we see market growth. So,  it's really a key piece of technology that will complement our EcoStruxure power set of technology, which is the  backbone of Schneider Electric.

texts.speaker: Philippe Delorme
texts.profession: EVP-Building & Information Technology, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So, market positioning. Again, I told you, ASCO is today the leader in North America. You know that our business,  our Low Voltage business is very strongly associated with standards. So in North America, the market is ruled by  NEMA standards, where we have China rule by CCC standards, and then Europe, and let's say international rule  by IEC.

texts.speaker: Philippe Delorme
texts.profession: EVP-Building & Information Technology, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So, to give you an example – and maybe, before giving example, so last time we met in London, we've been  pretty detailed about EcoStruxure. Jean-Pascal was talking about different field of expertise within the different  domain of expertise in EcoStruxure. The biggest EcoStruxure we have is around power, which is again the  backbone, Medium Voltage, Low Voltage application. And really we see the transfer suites of the power source  management has been a very strong complement to our capability in EcoStruxure power, really in the field of  power availability.

texts.speaker: Philippe Delorme
texts.profession: EVP-Building & Information Technology, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So it allows our customer to have better power availability and then connect to the old suite of technology of  Schneider Electric with two components, Automatic Transfer Switch, again, something that will switch a source  from the grid to a genset, if you make it really simple; and by the way, doing this is really complicated. So, this is  why these guys have been doing that for 100 years. And associated to that, you need Power Control System,  which actually will coordinate the different gensets together. So these are the two central piece of technology, with  again, would happen in places where power is critical, healthcare, financial institution and data centers.

texts.speaker: Philippe Delorme
texts.profession: EVP-Building & Information Technology, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So in data centers, so Schneider has very strong capabilities, I mean, Jean-Pascal was talking about it. It's  creating very strong growth especially in Low- and Medium Voltage and associated with Secure Power. So you  see ATS and PCS, so we like acronym, Automatic Transfer Switch, Power Control System that is – let's say, or  that was probably the last line that we wanted to complement the full, full lineup of, let's say, perfect technology  for data center application. So this should reinforce us further in the field of data center, where we see a very  strong market traction.

texts.speaker: Philippe Delorme
texts.profession: EVP-Building & Information Technology, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: These offers are actually also very interesting in the context of the new energy landscape. We know renewable  developing pretty fast. That mean that transferring sources from different sources, whether renewable, genset and  the grid will happen more and more. And the Automatic Transfer Switch will be the key component to drive those  application, and for many of these customers, power is so critical that you want the switch application to be really  reliable and done by specialist. This is what ASCO bringing us alongside with the other capabilities we used to  have in Schneider Electric. So, good market trend, a great technology and a great combination to make it a great  business going forward.

file: SU - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 26July2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Then this is, of course, boosted by an accelerated growth or a stronger revenue growth in H1 of 7%, actually  7.6% if you include the non-consolidated debt issue in our accounts. And this is funded on our two business:  Energy Management, which is growing by 7% in H1. And if you go into the detail of Energy Management, well, the  good headlines is that Medium Voltage is back to growth, so selectivity, as we said, is over, on Q2 is actually  growing by 3.2 and that proves the end of selectivity. Low Voltage, at more than 9% in H1. Actually, if you  integrate debt issue, which again is not consolidated, is double-digit growth. So we are clearly taking market  share in these very profitable business of Low Voltage.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: And remind you that H1 was active in signing or closing operations. Of course, the signature of the agreement of  buying Larsen & Toubro in India, which will make of India our third-largest country for the group, and the closing  of two operation in software, AVEVA, that we closed in H1; and IGE+XAO, which is supporting in Energy  Management.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: What is the growth based on? And, again, remind you that Schneider is all about Energy Management and  Industry Automation (sic) [Industrial Automation] solutions targeting to supply to our customers full efficiency  solutions, energy efficiency and process efficiency.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: On Energy Management, which is growing 7% during H1 is benefiting from the fundamental phenomenon of  energy transition. We see an acceleration of every electrification on energy consumption on everything which is IT  which is powered by AI, storage, big data, analytics that part of our portfolio is the fastest growing. And we have  an unparalleled and un-comparable offer to service business. Then we see an acceleration of electricity as a  vector of consumption of energy. You see it, of course, in the very media published or media publicized, electrical  mobility. But you see that everywhere, particularly in temperature control, where the way to control temperature  would it be cooling or heating is becoming more and more electric, you see a massive push for energy efficiency  all over the world characterized by digitalization and, of course, where the grid is sometimes not completely  reliable and people want to get more autonomous, a trend to distributed decentralization of energy which pushes  the generation which used to be upstream of the value chain, downstream into the natural territory of Schneider.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: The other megatrend that we are addressing at Schneider is Industry 4.0, which is today boosted by software,  Internet of Thing and automation. So, the combination of those two make that we propose to our customers full  efficiency solution, energy solution, process solution, integrated in EcoStruxure with its [indiscernible] (00:07:25)  connected products, controls and advisors on software.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So, going into the detail of that, I'm going to go fast through a set of more explanatory slides, but more products in  H1. We see products revenue up 7.3% and actually accelerating as we go forward. In Energy Management, that  portfolio goes up 6.6% if you take all the products from Medium Voltage, Low Voltage, and Secure Power.  Product sets are really growing in all regions. Remind you that the tremendous success of Schneider is what we  do on the home, on small buildings segment which is a segment we've been consistently developing and growing  in the past years, on the back of acquisition, we did long time ago that we have now consolidated and that we are  boosting with a lot of innovation, a lot of new products.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: One thing I want to mention here in this slide is the alliance that we have made with Somfy and Danfoss, which is  a convergence of what we do in the environment of home to supply consistent systems and make sure that our  customers, when they buy things, objects coming from all of our companies can find them converging on any of  our applications.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Going to next priority, more services, you remember that the growth of services at the slowdown last year, and  that was due to a cleaning of a situation or rebooting of a situation in the U.S., we are back to cruise speed in  services, 9% in H1, growing in all regions. This is getting accelerated by the digitalization of what we do. Once we  are intervening on the installed base of our customers, we plug that installed base to go from one short service to  a 24/7 contacts on a lot of value delivered around asset performance, condition monitoring and predictive  maintenance, which is complemented with very successful value proposition that we deliver today around the  world, which is energy and sustainability services, helping our customers base on the profile of their consumption  to source the best source of energy and particularly, renewable energy.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: You know that Schneider is part of the RE100 group of more than 100 companies actually, moving together to  source to be getting its energy from renewable sources. And we are the biggest provider, particularly in North  America, of advisors on the digital platform that helps you doing that. So, what do we want to do here is continue  to track and penetrate the installed base of our customers, which is still vastly underserved and continue  progressively in the head count investment that allows us to deliver those services.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: More digital, third priority. Of course, it's a development of EcoStruxure that we are pursuing here. So, we are  continuously developing applications within open ecosystems. So, we've got more and more developers working  on EcoStruxure. We have a very good traction of our digital offers across market. And we are investing also in  complementary start-ups to help us innovate at the fringes and the borders of our ecosystem, like Claroty in the  field of end-point cyber-security.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: On the other side, while H1 was the time of the creation of AVEVA, of which we are very happy, first very good  steps. The integration is on track. Cost synergies plans have been put into place. We are building revenue  synergies, we're putting together the teams of Schneider and AVEVA in front of a number of customers. And the  market conditions are becoming even better at the moment, as oil and gas is kind of reawakening from the crisis  we've known over the past three years. So, promising perspective on this side of those key process industries.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So, with that, what we see is more and more traction for integrated EcoStruxure. The appeal of having one plug- and-play architecture where people can address their double issue of efficiency, energy efficiency, process  efficiency and have one repository while you've got plenty of very interesting projects here, including, by the way,  more and more decentralized energy like connecting to your demand, a microgrid, a local microgrid to improve  the reliability of your supply and also to improve the sustainability of the energy consumed by our installation.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: The last point I want to mention which is creating acceleration in the top line is cross-selling across our markets.  And that's pretty much across all geographies. So strong cross-selling between Low Voltage and the rest of  Energy Management and – well, power automation, EcoStruxure Power, and everything which is building,  residential, commercial and industrial. Very strong traction in data centers and network which as a segment for  Schneider is growing double digit totally. So that's a very strong dynamic. I'm going to come back on it afterwards.  Industrial and infrastructure, there, again, double digit, very strong there, with a mix of – not double digit – double  digit on automation, with a mix of 50/50 between Energy Management and Industrial Automation on utilities,  which is mostly a Medium Voltage play complemented by Low Voltage. But cross-selling is keeping on  accelerating. Here, you've got a number of examples of segments on projects we have addressed. Proud to say  that many of the stadium that we all followed in the past period were powered by Schneider, and this has no  relation with the conclusion of the Cup, but we'll come back on that one later.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Commitment to sustainable development, as you know, we have the Sustainability Impact barometer, whatever,  index that we have across the companies where we measure all our progress on those directions, and we are on  a good track. We've put here one example of what we do in circular economy, making sure that we help our  customers to deal with the end of life cycle of their products. And that's also a very promising place where  digitization, of course, is helping a lot.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Now I'd like to go into the detail of our portfolio beyond those transversal lines that I just described. And I'm going  to comment Energy Management on one side and Industry Automation (sic) [Industrial Automation] on the other  side. So if you look at the global picture of Energy Management that in most of the case is selling together  Medium Voltage, Low Voltage and Secure Power, growing 7% including Delixi. Profitability above 17%, still  increasing by 40 bps, and we want to keep developing that.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Three titles, Medium Voltage – or three activities with the major headlines which are Medium Voltage is back to  growth, that means selectivity is finished. Second point is that one year ago we told you we would do a strategic  review of what we do in Medium Voltage. That strategic review is done and we've identified actions on the  portfolio. Second point, Low Voltage accelerating to double-digit growth and really gaining market share together  with the whole chain of Energy Management. And Secure Power leading the charge at the level of the IT segment  and reaching in Q2 a growth which is close to 5%, so very good dynamics here.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: What we see here as shared priorities is keep working on key targeted segments, maximize the cross-selling  between those business, and develop EcoStruxure, EcoStruxure Grid, EcoStruxure Power and EcoStruxure  Building as a major vector of digitization of what we do.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: What we see in H1 is a sound execution of our strategy, acceleration of product sales to partners which are  common with Low Voltage, acceleration of services. One year ago, we told you we would put into place in the  next year, which is finishing today, an organization called Power Systems, streamlining what we do in the field of  equipment and projects. And that has been deployed and it performs. And what we see in H1 is a strong  contribution in the U.S., in China and in the data center segment.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So, what we want to do here is to keep growing our sales through partners, our distributors, our specifiers, our  contractors across the world who are strong partners of Schneider; accelerate digitization around EcoStruxure  Power and Building; and keep building synergies or build the synergies from the ASCO acquisition last year which  is serving applications like data center microgrid that I already spoke a lot about; and keep leveraging what we  acquired in IGE+XAO to develop more software to help our customers deploy their system. No need also to  mention that across all that chain, the acquisition of Larsen & Toubro on the plan of integration is a big focus of  the period to come.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer in charge of Finance and Legal Affairs, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Last but not least, Rest of the World, so the other new economy outside Asia-Pacific, stable nice performance,  around plus 5% and we see globally new economy benefiting from increased price on energy or on resources and  raw material and that is helping the economy of many of these countries.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer in charge of Finance and Legal Affairs, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Moving to the Rest of the World, what I would like to flag here is really the nice news coming from some of the  region that has been difficult in the past years, namely Middle East and South America. Middle East probably not  coming as a surprise when we see energy price going up, that is, of course, improving the economy of many of  these countries. South America, accelerating, not so much Brazil, which is close to flat in fact, but in other  countries in South America. Africa continued to be positive and Russia has really been the country where we've  been seeing some difficulties, notably because of the sanction, the uncertainties it – all that triggers and that is  slowing down the Russian business. So, let's see how things unfold in the coming quarters.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer in charge of Finance and Legal Affairs, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: A bit of an analysis now on the growth, both at the top line level and the adjusted EBITA. You see that when it  comes to the growth, all businesses have been rather stable, but at a very high level in the case of Low Voltage or  clearly accelerating in Q2. That has been the case of Medium Voltage. Jean-Pascal commented it, that was  absolutely expected.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer in charge of Finance and Legal Affairs, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Secure Power accelerating and the order intake level was even better than that. So, we see a nice performance  of Energy Management, north of 7% if you include Delixi now. And Industrial Automation at a fantastic  performance, above 10%, again gaining market share clearly in several end-market and in several geographies.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer in charge of Finance and Legal Affairs, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Now, when you look at the margin, all margins are progressing or in the less favorable scenario, they are flat. On  Medium Voltage, we stay at 8.4% with a very strong negative impact coming from the ForEx and the disposal of  DTN. The organic growth is there. And as we see a much lower impact on ForEx and we are now with the scope  impact behind us, we do expect a nice improvement of the Medium Voltage margin in the second half. The  organic growth targets didn't change, 100 basis point to 150 basis point.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer in charge of Finance and Legal Affairs, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Now, let's move to productivity, 1.4 point of improvement on the margin because of productivity. Last year, it was  1.7 points. So, yes, the productivity is under pressure for all the reason I mentioned. We are seeing increased  inflation. We are seeing tension on the supply chain, which is not enabling the same kind of work to optimize the  footprint, which creates an inflation like the airfreight. What happen when you are running late because the order  intake are growing extremely fast? You need to meet very strong customer demand. You need to deliver where  you use airfreight and when you use airfreight, that is increasing your cost and that decrease the productivity.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer in charge of Finance and Legal Affairs, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: We're doing a lot of great things on our supply chain and beyond the momentary tension that we are seeing, we  keep improving on the long term the efficiency of our supply chain. Some of you went to China to visit how we are  implementing our EcoStruxure technology to make our factory more efficient. We continue to build and optimize  footprint and to build agility and a really tailor-made approach for the supplier, therefore, I would say the  underlying trend of the supply chain remains super positive.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive Officer in charge of Finance and Legal Affairs, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: Income tax, a 23% effective tax rate for the group, which is in the middle of the 22% to 24% bracket that we  shared with you at the end of 2017. The discontinued operation impact, minus €35 million. This is the Solar  business here with the loss of the H1 plus still some impairment. I do expect H2 to be much better. And therefore,  we expect to come with much better news in H2 on the performance of the Solar business.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SE
texts.text: So, well, we are riding very powerful waves at the moment, that energy transition in Industry 4.0 in a world where  the economy is pretty well aligned and positive in all parts of the world, and firmly decided to increase our  profitability while also gaining market share to create the ground of a more solid place with our partners and with  our end-users.

Copenhagen, people can criticize and spend a lot of time speaking about the pluses and  minus of Copenhagen, but you can’t go to any company, you can’t go to any country which doesn’t  have the green and energy efficiency at the top if its agenda.

And  we’ve delivered quite a lot of innovation in offers and solution. The most part of the innovation is  really coming into the plug-and-play integration of all our systems into a unique and integrated  system, EcoStruxure, which doesn’t exist anywhere else.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: All right. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for being here. [French language] So today we are
texts.text: To make this solution approach more competitive and to make sure that we are more competitive  than our competition in supplying those solutions, we need to have a system which is easier to  integrate than any other system in the world, so this is EcoStruxure.

texts.text: And I’d like to move you to Slide 16, which explains what is EcoStruxure in a building. But on the left side, you’ve got what people use to do in the traditional building, where you have got  vertical system for power distribution, for air conditioning, for lighting control, for energy control, for  access on security control.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire, President and Chief Executive Officer

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: All right. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for being here. [French language] So today we are

You can cut your consumption by a factor of four, so decrease it by 75%.  It’s less OpEx, minus 30% of OpEx because everything is integrated. It’s less CapEx, because  everything is integrated, 30% of CapEx reduction.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire, President and Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: All right. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for being here. [French language] So today we are

The  first one is the fact that we have been resisting well in terms of price. Globally, we have increased  our price by 1% throughout the year 2009, which is a good achievement given the environment;  and the second reason has been globally, the manufacturing productivity, I will come back on that.  Of course, we have been helped as well by the positive evolution of the raw material cost, which  has been positive by more than €140 million and globally helping our margin.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire, President and Chief Executive Officer

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire, President and Chief Executive Officer

texts.speaker: Carina Ho, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Schneider Electric’s 2010 Annual Results
texts.text: We’ve done, and I’ll be back to that, a lot of renewable projects. Here, we don’t intend and we are  not doing solar panels or wind turbines. Our business is to connect those new generation resources  to the grid, to the smart grid and make sure they interact intelligently with the points of  consumption. And big business today in buildings, in the energy efficiency of buildings, where we  guarantee performance contract, by performance contracting we guarantee the energy  performance of more and more buildings.

texts.speaker: Carina Ho, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Schneider Electric’s 2010 Annual Results
texts.text: Renewables, while we build also the, we architect the smart grid and we are participating to a  number of initiatives around the world to make the smart grid a reality. We realized in 2010 more  than 600 photovoltaic projects of rather medium to large scale. We are working actively as you  know on the infrastructure to recharge the electric vehicle.

texts.speaker: Carina Ho, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Schneider Electric’s 2010 Annual Results
texts.text: Third engine for growth is R&D, and R&D is the only budget we’ve not touched during the crisis  actually we stepped up our expense in R&D to build our ecostructure for all of our key segments.  We put here a few examples of products which are coming up but there are only a few examples.  The Roombox which is a product of convergence, a product that converges into one very simple  system, the control of HVAC, the control of power, the control of security into intelligent buildings.  With that kind of solution, you cut the installation systems by 30%, that’s beyond the pure saving  that you get on energy and on OpEx.

texts.speaker: Carina Ho, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Schneider Electric’s 2010 Annual Results
texts.text: EcoBreeze, which is a cooling solution for the data center, you know that we are the leaders in in- room cooling in the white space. But when you need room cooling in more traditional designs of  data centers, this is a space where we are not traditionally, last year we went out with – this year  we go out with EcoBreeze which is our own solution. And at the same time, we complement this  solution by the acquisition of Uniflair in Italy, which gives us a full lineup of perimeter cooling  solutions to face our major competitor.

texts.speaker: Carina Ho, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Schneider Electric’s 2010 Annual Results
texts.text: Obviously, it’s a very complicated operation. We are working a lot on that, the teams are doing an  excellent job. Well, I think it’s an ambitious operation and every ambitious operation goes with a lot  of hard work. But we’ve ensured the continuity of operation. We have merged the front office in 53  countries; that means we have an energy front office operating as one already in 53 countries.

texts.speaker: Carina Ho, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Schneider Electric’s 2010 Annual Results
texts.text: Europe, which started the year negative, did rebound. The country such as Germany and Italy  performed very well. That is the weight of industry and notably of course in Germany in this country.  France did perform well as well. For the three countries I have just mentioned the renewable  business has been good in 2010 and has been helping the performance. Other market have been  very difficult in H1 that has been the case of Spain obviously, the Nordics or the U.K. and for all this  market, we’ve seen improvement in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Carina Ho, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Schneider Electric’s 2010 Annual Results
texts.text: When I look at building, building is a business with lower support coming from the new economy.  We only have a 15% exposure to new economies for the building business. And the business has  been recovering on the back of strong need for energy efficiency and solutions for that in the  building in the Western economies and despite a construction business which has not yet  recovered, as we all know.

texts.speaker: Carina Ho, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Schneider Electric’s 2010 Annual Results
texts.text: The SFC evolution, a nice reduction from 26.4% to 24.1%, the 2% decrease that is of course  helped by the Areva Distribution integration, but excluding scope and excluding inflation we did  manage to generate an extra €75 million of SFC reduction which means that we are crossing the  bar of 600 million SFC saving which was our objective of SFC reduction. We had said at the  beginning 1 billion, that including 400 million of adjustment to the crisis. The crisis now, we see is  largely behind us for us. So we’re happy to realize this objective for slightly more than €600 million.

texts.speaker: Carina Ho, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Schneider Electric’s 2010 Annual Results
texts.text: Jean-Pascal Tricoire, President and Chief Executive Officer  Briefly before we go to questions and answers, the environment that we see in front of us for the  top line is we’re going to keep improving power in power business. Energy also is to return to  growth. Industry and IT are still on the growth, but they will be facing tougher comparisons and we  see really energy efficiency, as supporting our building business.

file: SU - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 22February2012 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We can't speak about 2011, and I'm going to next slide, without mentioning something which is more strategic,  which is building at Schneider of a new world leader division in the sector of Infrastructure. Two years ago, what  we are calling our energy business, our medium-voltage business, was at €2.3 billion sales business, number three  worldwide. I would say a distant number three; quite specialized in terms of product offering on secondary  medium voltage and mostly serving industry on building as key segments.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Two years after, this business has a global turnover of €5.3 billion, is number one worldwide with a total coverage  of medium-voltage on-grid automation, covers all the parts of the competencies you need to address the issues of  electro-intensive customers and discovering extensive use segments of utilities oil and gas building on industry.  Due to that expanded coverage, we changed the name of this division from Energy to Infrastructure, because it's  really covering the whole issues of smart cities and smart grid.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Very simply, and to give you a big picture of the new capability of Schneider that we have for efficient  infrastructures. We used to be delivering medium voltage [ph] chemicals (15:07), right? These are the needs we  are able to address with our customers. It's about efficient energy management, efficient mobility with software  for transportation which directed product into our electrical infrastructure that we are developing for the electrical  vehicle and everything we do in the city infrastructures. Water management, which is already a big sector for  Schneider; security where we have a big activity also on efficient buildings and the homes which combine together  in connected communities to share together the fruit of energy efficiency.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Finance, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: And then, of course, the two elements which are not matching during this year, the productivity at plus €370  million and the global COGS inflation, both raw material and other labor inflation, which was reaching minus  €520 million. That's really where the margin consideration has been principally.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Executive Vice President-Finance, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Then evolution of our SFC, each time we think it's important to show two things. First of all, a kind of natural, I  would say, evolution of our SFC which is largely coming from inflation. And this year, we see €150 million  increasing SFC coming from inflation. And then what has been a net – let's really realize it, it's a net amount  between investment and savings that we have been generating. A net further increase in investment, new  initiative, growing our skills, developing into new territories, new economy of €112 million. Then you have a  minus €47 million Other elements that includes the increase in restructuring costs. There is a pension element.  There is other element in term of provision on inventory on renewable. The scope effect, the €98 million, which is  coming from all the acquisitions that we have made through the year.

file: SU - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 21February2013 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Moving on, I want to remind briefly a very critical signature of Schneider which is our engagement in social  responsibility, in sustainable development by being totally focused on green business, having a responsible  commitment to all the stakeholders of the society, on being innovative in measuring every quarter this  engagement on reporting, this engagement in the initiatives of all the people in the company at every level.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Within those Solutions, a point of attention is the development of our services, plus 5% of growth respect to the  rest of the business of the group. While I don't want to go into the detail but a lot of focus on energy management  of connecting our customers to our control centers and then enabling new services on the base of this data  collected, a lot of work on the huge installed base that we have out there that we are not servicing to them, our  customers are needing this service, a lot of work on tracking the systems.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Then, next one, next point of focalization is software. You know that our Solutions are controlled by more and  more software. 2012 had been a year of big achievements in software, on the right side, we've launched new suite  of software, integrated suite of management for buildings, StruxureWare for buildings. We've launched a very  innovative suite – integrated suite for manufacturing, which is mixing both discrete capabilities and process  capabilities on putting into one package the control of process on manufacturing. On the control of energy, so  that's StruxureWare for plant, it's plant structure. On – again, the launch of an integrated suite for the  management of data centers.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Then a lot of things in the field of energy efficiency, Wiser for homes, simple building control for building retrofit,  mid-building retrofit, and a lot of new drives for industry because you know that 60% of energy consumption in  industry is coming from motors.  Big effort also in developing mid-level offers for the mid-class – middle class of new economies and you see here a  few lineups of products that we are launching in new economies. On the development of new business, you have  shore connection for ports to avoid pollution in ports and also a lot of things happening on the electrical vehicle  front where we have been selected by BMW as their preferential partner in the field of electrical vehicle, Renault  and Ford in Europe. So we are keeping on developing our presence in this sector.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Well, to tell you that during those years of crisis, we don't stop investing in new activities, and doing our job which  is to be entrepreneurs in the field of – in the vast field of energy management.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: And another group of business led by Laurent, here again, we've focused on end users of 12 key segments, focused  on delivering integrated solution [audio gap] (17:10) 1%; COGS productivity well in line to deliver our three years  target of €1 billion; support function cost improved by 0.2 points; and inventory efficiency increased by 1 point or  decrease, actually, or inventory level decreased by 1 point of sales.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Executive Vice President Finance, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Infrastructure is another example of what I've just been describing, 30 basis point improvement in an  environment which was not easy. And here we are harvesting the fruit of the integration of Areva distribution with  legacy business of Schneider in the medium voltage.

file: SU - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 20February2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: And finally, keeping on developing solutions which are based on Software-as-a-Service. Y ou have the example of  what we do with SOHO in China, which is monitoring their park or buildings on our cloud, and contract that we  have with Sanofi on helping them to decrease their energy consumption, things that we do in partnership with  other companies.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Now, last point, in terms of – which is very important and big element of our strategy is keeping on developing in  the field of sustainable development. Y ou know that in our company plans, we have a barometer whereby we  measure the progress that we have in the major dimensions of sustainable development and corporate social  responsibility.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: And if you look a bit at the detail, you've got like we've progressed tremendously in the field of our green premium  products. Those are products that are beyond standards in terms of sustainability, recyclability and being  environmentally friendly. We kept on reducing our own energy consumption. We eat our own food. And we want  to be a role model in what we propose to our customers. A lot of things happening in supply in energy to bottom of  pyramid in between investing in small business, micro credit, putting into place great technology adapted to those  places and training people to deploy that. A lot of things happening in training, skilling up our people, incl uding  our people in all our initiatives of sustainable development.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy CEO in charge of Finance and Legal Affairs, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Also negative contribution, negative mix coming from our sales on product with the evolution among the range  that we have been selling in product, which has been playing negatively on the mix. Then, the productivity of €358  million, I don't come back to it. I detailed the various impact. COGS inflation, it is the net of the two im pact,  traditional and very normal inflation on salary and wages of production, minus the positive impact coming from  the raw material evolution.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy CEO in charge of Finance and Legal Affairs, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: I go very happily on these two, because that's just the summary of what I've just said. I would just want to maybe  spend a little time – a little bit of time on the support function costs, because very often people tell us, you're not  active enough on reduction – reducing your support function cost, you're not leveraging your platform, you're not  generating efficiency. Well, actually, it's not true. I mean, we're not sitting on o ur end and we are indeed quite  active in generating materialization, simplification, rationalization.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Schneider Electric SA
texts.text: Delicate exercise of outlook. So as we look into 2014, the world remains quite complicated, but what we see is that  we see North America, which should continue to grow, though the first quarter will be certainly impacted by what  we understand to be the cold weather in the northeast of the U.S.

file: SU - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 19February2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So two titles to the year, solid execution delivering full-year targets in the environment that I was describing,  pretty much with many moving parts. On the second big title, which was extremely important for us in 2014, is the  Invensys integration; well on track; above target.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Going into more detail about Invensys and I won't dwell on each. We've got some examples here of synergies that  we have started to establish. Just after the acquisition, we managed to package completely the offer energy and  automation in India with Reliance refinery, in Jamnagar, a more hybrid system in wastewater treatment plants. In  Invensys, you are the control part doing PCBs for repetitive machines called Eliwell that we integrated into our  OEM offer that has been [ph] serves (19:17) out for everything we do in HVAC, for  instance.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And then, construction – in construction of coal-to-liquid plants for coal enterprise in China where we [ph] mix  there again (19:28) energy on the DCS. As I told you many times, it's not about automation plus automation  mainly, it's about automation on power helping customers to manage their whole efficiency equation, reducing  their energy consumption, which is very big in electro-intensive processes; and also managing on diminishing the  waste of the process into one integrated system.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Finally, still Schneider wants to be at the forefront of sustainability as a company, want more and more, and we do  that every day. We want to be the sustainability advisor of our customers, make sure that they progress with us in  sustainability. To do that, we have a barometer that you know well. We've overshot our target respecting in the  Connect plan. Now, if – this has been also recognized by a number of rewards of – on premiums that we received  in Davos. Three weeks ago, we were recognized as the ninth most sustainable corporation, all industries  confronted in the world. And we've received a number of recognition, which is a subject of loyalty and a subject of  pride for – loyalty for customers and a big subject of pride for our employees on the big argument to recruit the  best talents in generally. And we see that as very positive. On the top of it, the whole mission of the company is  geared and directed to making this planet and the world we live in more sustainable.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy CEO-Finance & Legal Affairs
texts.text: Then productivity, it has been largely commented by Jean-Pascal, so I don't come back on it. And then the mix  impact, negative, which accelerated in H2. We had more solution in the mix of our sales and that has been  impacting. We can say also that we have been seeing some pressure on price for some businesses. There were  some drift in some margins for some project. But we really want to highlight the fact that we also consciously take  projects at a low margin because this is the name of the game. Y ou take greenfield at low margin, but this  greenfield will generate in the future some nice services business with nice margins. So there is also this element  playing in the impact of the solution.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy CEO-Finance & Legal Affairs
texts.text: For the rest, I mean, we've been paying the dividends and net impact of acquisition. Here, you have the net impact  between the share buyback and the employee shareholder plan. And then, you have other effects which are mainly  the negative Forex impact. As you know, it's a picture of the debt at the end of the year. There was an increase of  the dollar versus the euro with a significant Forex impact on the debt. So that gives us at the end of December  2014 a debt of approximately €5 billion.

texts.speaker: Emmanuel Babeau
texts.profession: Deputy CEO-Finance & Legal Affairs
texts.text: On Invensys, that has been largely commented; I don't think I need to go into a lot of detail. All lights are green.  Revenues are going up. Adjusted EBITA was growing significantly. And Invensys was accretive, in fact, on our  margin from the first year. The cost synergy are there. Jean-Pascal mentioned the topline synergy, tax synergies  are also delivering; so all lights are green once again on Invensys.

file: SU - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 17February2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I want to spend two minutes on this page, which is our commitment to a sustainable responsibility. And you see  that we were in the first year of a new barometer, Planet & Society, we are on target. Local recognition of the  strong, on differentiated engagement of Schneider in this, and you see a list here. It's been quite an impressive and  converging set of awards that we received over last year and in the beginning of this year.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We are weaker on [ph] went through (3:48) transitions in 2015. Oil and gas, though it is limited exposure for our  company, but a rupture breaks through in the changes of energy price for an energy company represents a  disturbance. Forex in the second part of the year. This year has been quite uncertain, unpredictable. On forex, it  has been also a very intense year of adaptation.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Now, let's dive a bit more in detail into each business. So, Building & Partner, low-voltage, building control, this is  a place where we are a very strong world leader where we strike a double improvement, improvement on the  growth and improvement in the margin percentage.

texts.speaker: Jean-Pascal Tricoire
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Infrastructure. It's been a good year somewhere. Still at too low margin, but we really have turned the corner on  Infrastructure.
